reviews.review: Must see in Hanoi. I was not excited to see a prison at first, but then despite the sad story I was glad I did. So much information and emotions to get from it. I recommend doing it through a walking tour as you can ask question to your vietnamese guide. You could in theory just read everything that is written on the walls and watch the videos, but there is something more to get from sharing this moment with a local. Even if our guide wasn't born when all of this happened and that she probably did the tour thousands of time, the emotions that were transpiring from her were something else. Of all the things in Hanoi, this is my favorite tourist sight.

Leaves one thinking.... Strongly recommend a visit with a guide who will do the story justice. Well worth a visit to get to understand and experience the story behind the prison. Truly emotive and a rich piece of history.

Interesting . Very interesting part of Hanoi and provides an interesting version of the country's history.The prison was built by the French and housed communist prisoners during the French colonial period. The prison was later used during the Vietnam War to house American POW's. It was about 20 or 30k VND entry and takes about 30-45 mins to have a good look around.

Very sad. I visited here a time and just know that was very truested about Vietnam war with France and American. Remember what the guide said about Vietnamese prisoners: dont ask what country do for you, ask what you do for your country.
The "Hanoi Hilton". It was much more interesting with a guide, and ours was excellent. There were plenty of English explanations, but don't expect to see the actual cells that held US POWs.
Horrors Exposed. A great insight into the hardships suffered by the Vietnamese in the hands of the French. Harrowing torture.

Worth a visit if you are in the area. . A large part of the prison has long since been torn down. However what is left is enough to give an insight into the history. Boards give information in Vietnamese, English and French and are located all around so you can get a good sense of the history. Admission was 30, 000 and children under 15 are free.

Good history lesson from the Vietnamese perspective. Part of the old prison has been retained to create interesting (albeit in some parts gruesome) displays and explanation of the phases when this prison was used - by the French colonialists and later the Vietnamese (as the 'Hanoi Hilton' during the American war). Bear in mind that this is one side of the story.

Hoa La prison. Well laid out and interesting displays with good explanatory signage in english so there is no need to hire a guide. Some reviewers complain about bias in the explanations but what do you expect in a site like this, of course it gives the Vietnamese view of the French and American wars. Old photographs and film clips are especially interesting.

Good Insight to Old Ways. The jail areas graphically show how the inmates were kept, treated, and not looked after. Cruel old ways to repress people trying to make their voices heard. Well worth a visit.

Be prepared for anti American propaganda . This was one of the most interesting things we saw in Hanoi. Very little is there about the Americans who were there, but what is there makes it look like they were treated very well. I suggest reading John McCain's book before going so you have both sides of the story. Most of the museum is about how the Vietnamese were treated by the French.

very informative. i like this prison relic because it so very informative, see how Vietnamese people live and work under french time and special know vietnamese policy with American pilots, it was built in 1896 long time already but when i walked along felt fear and breathing from prisoner from past, look like live in prison, where prisoner called hell of hell, i would like recommend this relic for whom would like to see about Vietnam war..
Fascinating museum. Really interesting museum with information laid out in a variety of ways. Obviously it's biased to a certain degree but still well worth a look round.
Informative. Not knowing that much about Vietnam's past this quick visit really helped with some background. Well laid out exhibts with a lot of sad history.

omg what a shock. people really need to visit this (hanoi hilton)it shows you how people who were captured were tortured and imprisoned,how they were shackled in their cells and also killed,a sad but interesting place to see
Impressive. You're going to get a good impression of the different times this prison was used. This is a must see!

Highly educational . Well worth the visit to help learn more about the history of Hanoi. The displays were all in English along with Vietnamese and French. The history is grisly but important and interesting to learn.
Worth seeing if you have time.. An insight into political prisoners and the difficulties/atrocities they faced. Doesn't take too long to visit.

History Can Be Very Sad. This was a very moving museum that left me extremely emotional in its wake. If you're interested in the evils of colonialism, then this museum has you covered. If you're interested in the history of Vietnam, then this museum is a must see. You can easily spend an hour here touring the vicinity.
Hao Lo Prison. This museum is a must see! Great information and insight into the prisons history and it is also in English!

Chilling visit. Historical must see place - fascinating look around the prison, through cells and reading the facts from the perspective of the revolutionaries that were housed there. Terrible conditions but obviously pride in their resilience. Our two daughters went with us - aged 8 and 10 but elements were a little harrowing, for example there was a guillotine with a picture next to it with heads in a basket, so I recommend caution for families with younger children, although my girls did enjoy the experience.
Very informative and well worth it. A visit to this prison museum was excellent. We are a family of 5 with two teenages and a child . We all learnt much.If you have time whilst in Hanoi . Do visit

Very interesting and sad. We took our 3 children to see this prison. If you take the time to really read through what they went through it will make you appreciate what you have in life. It is also good for children to experience. It is not expensive and well worth the time.

Historical must see. It doesn't take much time to visit the remains of the Hoa Lo Prison and is with the 30.000 VND entrance fee. Most of the prison has been torn down to build a new office tower but a portion remains intact. Inside the museum you can see a model of the original prison. They cover information from when the French held Vietnamese people imprisoned and also when the Vietnamese used the prison to hold US soldiers captive. It was interesting to see a site with so much history.

Feel like you have to go to get a better understanding of Vietnam . We have three boys 8, 7 and 4 and I wasn't sure I wanted to expose them to the horrors and tragedies of what went on in the prison, but Hoa Lo Prison isn't as confronting as some of the other ones we have gone to and the two older boys behaved respectfully and asked good questions so I'm glad we went. The write ups were informative and didn't seem too too propaganda-ish. The four year just walked along but wasn't interested, which worked out because it was hard enough explaining what a political prisoner is to the other two.
Really emotive!. Well worth a visit providing so much detail about the experience of inmates at the hands of The French and Vietnamese.
Spooky but fascinating . Take the time to visit this prison. It's an excellent representation of the French Occupation of VN. There are sculptures of prisoners and real photos, fascinating!

Interesting. Worth a visit if you have time. Only a small area still remains due to development . I learnt a bit about the American pilots and hanoi hilton I didn't know. Some interesting original video footage. A bit of one sided explanations but that not surprising. Some people found it annoying but take it as the local explanation and their point of view.
Hanoi Hilton. Very somber experience from a dark time in history. The prison was first used by the French to punish Vietnamese and of course later for US pilots

As someone else said .... "Hmmmmm...". The tour is interesting enough: well-laid out, fluid, clear information. I knew nothing of the history of Vietnamese patriots, so that focus of this site was of great interest.My issue is in the obvious untruths being told throughout regarding treatment of foreign prisoners. (Isn't the point of preserving historical sites to understand and reflect on what actually happened, learning from our successes AND failures?) Though we live in Hanoi, we rarely feel that this is a Communist country (in the way you do in other Communist places), but you will definitely see political rhetoric on full display here.Is it worth a tour? If you are in this area, sure. It's a quick 45-minute jaunt and costs 30,000 VND (roughly 15USD). However, as other reviewers have noted, there are a ton of things to do in Ha Noi, and you could easily miss this stop and not feel that you've missed much.Either way, we love Vietnam! Enjoy your visit!
Worth seeing . A great thing to see while you are in Hanoi, but it is a bit one sided - it looks like prisoners were here on a vacation. :)
worth a visit . Interesting place to visit and good value for money at just over £3 entry. Definitely worth a visit when staying in Hanoi

No need for a guide. We visited while we were wandering through Hanoi, and learned a lot. The English guidebook was only 20,000 D, and had lots of interesting information. The prison is much more focused on the history under the French, but still had a couple of rooms about its time as the Hanoi Hilton. You can walk around the whole place in under an hour too, and entry is cheap.
Shocking history!. They don't hold back on letting you know exactly how it was to be interred or tortured here. Quite the eye opening experience. Well worth the trip/ $2 usd

You have to go here. Eye opening and thought provoking. Very moving and exhibits are well put together. Lots of english translations. I bought a booklet at the ticket office but it wasn't necessary with the plaques and descriptions. Very one-sided, but its good to hear that side of things.

A wonderful and frank tribute to the Vietnamese. Wow. This is a thought provoking place. They certainly don't hide the harsh reality of what happened here. Quite up front explanation of the story of the prison.

Good to see. I think Hanoi is not that big to miss this place.It is small but sad enough, good explanation in english.There were facts I am not sure to believe, but a lot od real things good to see.There are also sculptures for better imagination how it used to je crowded..that was scarry.Still recommended (not for kids).

Hmmm........ If you have spare time, go but I wouldn't recommend it if there are other things to do. First it is a small portion of the original (MAJOR HOTEL built on top of the prison) and what is there is replica. Being from America, I was dumbfounded that they actually portrayed that they took very good care of POWs there to the point they made themselves out to be saints. I have been to Germany to see their WW prison camps and they could display the truth in all of its ugliness after all it was war with a mission but not here. Either we have been fed a lie here or their is a lot of false propoganda to make it sound like it really was the Hanoi Hilton in the sense of being a hotel....Unless you have a personal reason/link to go, I would probably skip it.as their is so much other things to visit.

Prison converted into a tourist attraction. Affordable ticket price. 30,000VND and i showed my student pass (university student from singapore. I am not a local) and they gave me the student deal too (15,000vnd)!Very interesting history behind this prison. Especially when it holds different groups of prisoners over different time periods for different reasons.It is tourist friendly. Texts are in English Vietnamese (and i think French? Can't recognise the text).There are several wax figures to depict the living conditions of the prisoners. The prison rooms are preserved. And some of the tools used within the prison and foot execution purposes are also preserved in this museum too.One of the better tourist attractions i been to in hanoi so far.

Interesting. It was interesting to see this old prison and read about the history, but I think it's not a highlight of things to see in Hanoi. The history is told in a patriotic way, perhaps not so strange, but a bit odd that the exebition prisoner dolls have faint smiles on their faces.
Interesting place to discover. We got a lot with that visit, interesting, good display, easy to find, cheap entry. Well worth it. Recommanded
Basic. The museum has an interesting history and thus there was much more place for movies and explanations.

an eye opener. As a westerner we have little knowledge of the true struggles in colonial Vietnam. The tour of the prison was informative and sobering. Although there was a sense that this was a very "official" version, I was impressed with the sewer escape display. Impressive.
A well set out museum. I'm not a museum lover, but found this one to be informative and set out in a way that was interesting and thought provoking.

Interesting place to visit. Interesting place and worth the visit, if those walls could talk!!There are English translations to be read, but I reckon it might be worth getting a guide to get a deeper explanation and further insight into how the historical events are perceived by the locals, I kept trying to eavesdrop on the small group near me.I look forward to reading an un-biased explanation of the place when I do a bit more research on the web back home. As others have mentioned, it is very Communist-uprising focused and the language used will bring on some smirking.

Could be more interesting.... This museum has the potential to be really interesting but I think it's current state isn't very engaging. I do realise we are in Vietnam but there was often no more than one line of English to explain what something was. A tour guide or something would be really useful so I could've left feeling like I'd learned a bit more.

ok. I was a little disappointed at this attraction and question some of the propoganda about how well Americans were treated. The films were of some interest but the cells may be scary for some young children.

Provides an interesting Vietnamese modern history timeline. Worth a quick visit just to establish an understanding of Vietnam's last hundred years. From the communist uprising/political prisoners to downed US pilots, this place has played an interesting role in the local history.
Not the best. There is hardly any of the original prison left. Entrance is 30000VND to the prison. It takes about 45 minutes to view all the rooms.
Never again. A place where is possible to learn that humans and war should never get in touch. A place where to learn how wrong was colonialism.

Hoa Lo Prison/Hanoi Hilton. The Famous Hoa Lo Prison, Or More Commonly Referred to, as The "Hanoi Hilton".This is the Infamous French Colonial Jail, Built in 1886, to hold Political Prisoners. Vietnamese prisoners were locked up, with many facing torture and Execution, within the Prison walls. A Complete French Guillotine, is part of the display, from this Era.During the Vietnam War,captured U.S.Pilots were held here until their release, after the armistice, in 1973. Hoa Lo Prison, is Just A 20 Minute walk from the "Old Quarter" of Hanoi.It is Open from 8:AM -4:30 PM Daily. The Entry fee, is 30,000 VND.Definitely Worth A Visit.

Must see in Hanoi. We were here as part of our Urban Adventure tours hence we had a guide which I would recomend It is quite interesting but also scary especially considering that it operated as a prison till the end of the 90'ties It takes about an hour to look around and would be quite OK for older children as well

Great Historic Experience. This was one of our favourite museums during our trip in Hanoi. We really enjoy it so much, the way they present and explain the historical factors is no nice! You must visit.

Hoa Lo Prison. Super interesting. Thought it was going to be all about the "Hanoi Hilton" era but that was just a segment of this prison's history. The abuses suffered by those imprisoned there were incredible and horrible. Certainly a highlight on our visit to Hanoi.

There's always two sides. The famous Hanoi Hilton. If anything it should be a lesson that violence is pointless. It presented its side of the story in which American POWs were well treated even though I still doubt that is true. But it helped me realized why the Vietnamese wanted to be free of western dominance.

Hanoi Hilton. Hoa Lo prison was used to hold US prisoners captured during the Vietnam War. Originally constructed by the French only a small portion of the original prison remains but sufficient to give you a good feel of what it would be like to be incarcerated there. A good eye opener into a small but significant piece of history. The displays include English captions & mannequins which really add to the atmosphere.

Not the best prison . My girlfriend loves prison's so we tend to visit historical ones whenever we are in a place and this was one of the worst, the information wasn't very good, just a few stories about people who were held there without much background

A fraction of the truth. Firstly the prison is only a small fraction of its original size. Secondly what there is (eg the condemned cells) has been moved around - and when you're talking about concrete you might as well say 'rebuilt'. The result is that you are left wondering if anything is original. Thirdly the level of misinformation, from the trivial (Guilotane wasn't a doctor who invented the guillotine) to the patriotic to the propaganda rhetoric, is quite distorting. Even with a good knowledge of the truth it's hard to wade through all the rubbish and see the underlying reality. It's interesting to see some of the stuff but it's barely worth the effort. At least the entry price is cheap. In the end it's one of those places you have to be able to say you've been to, but it's a disappointment.

Very interesting. Must visit!. We learned a lot about the history of the Vietnam and it was haunting to see the living conditions of the prisoners and how they were tortured by the French. We came here with a local guide so she was able to share with us some of the stories behind the torture rooms, many of which did not have English description. There was a smaller section of the prison dedicated displaying what we considered propaganda. Nonetheless, it was very interesting to see the other side of the story.

Lots of Vietnamese propaganda. This shows a very one sided view of history. Shows how much the Vietnamese who were kept there suffered and as if the American soldiers were amazingly. It's interesting to see if you come with the understanding that it's not the objective view of history. It was also a bit confusing to walk around- though we saw everything and were about to leave and then noticed another path we didn't go to.

Staycation. Very informative and detailed. I felt awful when I get to see the prisons and the prisoners life. It's very painful to learn and hear there stories how they struggle to get the independence. Young generation should be very thankful to their ancestors for the freedom they are experiencing right now.

Great experience... Very biased though!. We went on a guided tour. Was there for about an hour and theres lots to see. They've got a lovely propaganda room where they make out all the American POWs had a great time there but if you take that with a pinch of salt its facinating.

worth the visit. Not sure if that really was John McCain's flight suit but Lonely Planet says it is---great musem, very well laid out.Would like more of the plaques to be in English as well as French. Worth the visit if you like American/Vietnam history.

Good information . Lots of great stuff on the French use of the prison. Very well constructed. Essentially serves as a propaganda tool for the communist government, depicting basically all prisoners as "Freedom Fighters" when a lot were probably common criminals and murderers of other ilk. Conveniently, the part on mistreatment of American POWS is skipped in favor of a propaganda reel with general information about the Vietnam War similar to the museum in Ho Chi Minh City.

Haunting. I was moved by my experience at this prison. The guide was extremely knowledgeable about the events that took place here and the exhibits showed the harrowing conditions and treatment of the prisoners. A must see in Hanoi.

What a surprise!!. I visited this site as a bit of a "time filler" one day but it turned out to be one of the highlights of my Hanoi stay. If you're into history or just want to get a sense of the will and determination of the Vietnamese people over hundreds of years, this is a must see. It dates back to the 19th century and the imprisonment of locals by the French. It's fabulously reconstructed and powerfully and "lovingly" restored. I really felt the horrific conditions that prisoners had to endure. The exhibition closes with a memorial to the dead and a very interesting film of the Vietnamese efforts during the American War. Only a dollar to enter and you'll see it all in around 90 minutes. I highly recommend it.
A Bit of History. The museum takes you back in history and while it displays what happened over the years, be warned that there is plenty of propaganda thrown in.
Very impressive. Just to think that this prison was in use by the Franchise until 1854 is terrifying.the small rooms are frightening. Also the American pilots were kept there in awful conditions.

Harrowing Reminder. The moment I stepped into the former cell blocks my legs started shaking at the darkness and sheer sense of despair. It reached a climax at the former punishment block and death row...not a place where I want to linger too long.A harrowing and powerful reminder of how brutal and cruel one people can be to another... and of the indestructible strength of a people who love their homeland enough to give their lives for her.
Very interesting . Grim but important to see. Interesting to see the history from a local perspective. Nice museum store as well.
A GOOD HISTORY OF THE NATION. Hoa Lo Prison (Maison Centrale) brings out the history of the various stages the Vietnam nation has undergone over time..

Good history lesson. Good history lesson ,how people stood up against the hard times .A well preserved prison ,terrible how people can treat each other ,to be shankled up all day is beyond terrible .i enjoyed it more than the wife did .
Amazing. This is really a history on the war in Vietnam! So good to knew everything of past. The wall, the people and food nearly so fantastic ! Lovely Vietnam

Good exhibit on history of the prison (beyond the American War). The exhibits are labeled in English and French and set up in a way that is easy to navigate through the complex. We spent about an hour there.

Interesting to understand the background. Taken to the prison by some uni students on a walking tour who gave me a better understanding of the history of the building . The artefacts are ok with English text , we only spent 30 -40 minutes which was sufficient the fee of 15,000 for a tourist.
History . This can be either a long or short visit. Lots to see how the bombings. And of course the American pilots captured.

Confronting but enlightening!. The remains of this notorious prison, have been well preserved, The cells with the mannequin-type figures was distressing, and transported you back in time. The death cells were also confronting, but such wonderful stories of escape, balanced the sadness I felt. The Vietnamese were brutal to one another. A time capsule of history that should definitely be visited.

Different view of history. Tells a different story of the history of the time of Vietnam being a French colony and then the, as the Vietnamese call it, 'The American War'.The world knows Hoa Lo Prison as the Hanoi Hilton and gives a slight insight of the conditions the US PoWs were held in.It is just a door in a wall on an nondescript street but is a place were during its long history indescribable horrors were carried out. A lesson for the world and just not in relation to the US PoWs but for prisoners down the generations as for many this was their last place on earth.
Vietnamese Patrotism. By visiting this old prison, you will be amazed at what the Vietnamese people would be willing to do to defend their country. An amazing depiction of Vietnamese patriotism.

Haunting reminder of French occupation in Vietnam. Wander round the prison and learn about the harsh conditions in which Vietnamese political prisoners were detained. Artefacts and pictures from the time as well as some daring stories of escape! Interesting information about US pilots captured and held in the facility during the Vietnam war. Give yourself about an hour to get through and watch the handful of short documentaries scattered throughout the exhibit.

Worth the visit. On the edge of the old quarter it is a good way to pass an hour. Good to understand the French occupation. Was starting to feel a bit cynical about some of the stuff on American POWs but then saw bit on the guy who became American Ambassador to Vietnam.

The infamous Hanoi Hilton. Cheap 30k VND entry fee and a must visit if only to see Vietnam's side of the story regarding the American prisoners of war - they did nickname it the Hanoi Hilton after all. An interesting museum which is an eye opener into the conditions in which prisoners were kept.You can easily spend a good couple of hours here looking around. They have a modern drinks vending machine on site which also contains a few nibbles. Don't forget the Police Museum that is around the corner too whilst your nearby, it's free entry.

Great thing to do. I didn't know much about the Vietnamese wars and struggles or history and this museum was very informative. New found respect for the Vietnamese for sure! A must visit in Hanoi. Tickets were easy to buy on the door, not huge so you can do in an hour or a bit more if you read everything and watch the videos etc. and it's easy to navigate round with almost all exhibits having an English, French and Vietnamese explanation.
Interesting to see the history. Very well presented and gives you a real view of life as a prisoner. Great records and explanation of the history. Fascinating and sad at the same time
Worth to see the guillotine. AKA Hanoi Hilton. There's lots to read and it's interesting to see the gullotine , cells and conditions . It's worth a trip but you won't be here long .

Eye opener. "Hanoi Hilton".....museum for a while now. Very interesting representations of conditions for prisoners and pows. Great explanations in Vietnamese and English. Walking distance from Old Quarter.

a good experience. a good experience to see this famous prison which is also known as the Hanoi Hilton. the clearly shows the vietnamies version of how their prisoners suffered. a small fee but worth the visit.

A peek into the POW days. It was quite interesting to know about the history of this place and get a peek into the cells the prisoners used to live in though the conditions I believed should be much worse than how it was presented at the museum.Only the first level of the prison was interesting and the stuffs on the second storey were pretty mundane.Recommended for a visit anyway:)

A very interesting experience take your time to read and learn. Also know as the Hanoi Hilton by the american pilots held there during the Vietnam war.Very well set out with plenty of information on how the prison came about The first prison built in Vietnam by the French Read about the conditions that the prisoners lived in.Very good place to visit.I would recommend it as a must see.A real part of Vietnam History.
Worth a look.. This tells yet another story of the brutality that Vietbam yas experienced. Definitely worth a look for an hour or two.

The Hanoi "Hilton". Read a lot about this prison- it's place in the French period and during the Vietnam-American war. It emphasises the local struggles against the French colonial powers. However it gives a highly slanted version about its own treatment of their American prisoners. Informative historical site. Able to complete the visit in less than 2 hours.

A must-go to!. This museum of the prison is very confronting but informative and factual. It is only a tiny part of the old prison as the rest was torn down for other buildings as it was not used. It is a very important part of Viet Nams history and well worth a visit.

Worth visiting. My husband visited here by himself after the hot weather defeated me and I taxied it back to the hotel. He said it was well worth the visit and he recommended it as an attraction to see.
Good buy you need a tour guide . Most in this prison/tour is in Vietnamese language so it is a good idea to hire a tour guide.. We didn't have one so didn't really know a lot that was going on

More than we expected!. We were not expecting much when we went to the prison but we were surprised by the interesting place! There were a lot of statues and interesting videos and pictures that my boyfriend and I enjoyed. Not your boring kind of museum (those that is full of words only)!! Definitely recommend coming here for a look. But there is obviously a propaganda, just take it with a pinch of salt! Very fascinating nonetheless!!!

An important place in the birth of Vietnam. It's not an easy place to visit, but it's important you do. It mainly covers the brutal treatment by the French colonialists to the Vietnamese patriots from its construction in 1896 through to the run up to Independence in 1945. You get a good feel for how miserable conditions were, how many passed through its grim doors, and the knowledge that the guillotine displayed has seen use, is a sobering reminder. What you won't find is much on how the American prisoners were treated. The displays say they were treated well and in accordance with the Geneva Convention, with many photos of sporting or social activities. As with every country, the view of history presented is written by the victors...Perhaps fittingly for the 'Hanoi Hilton', only a fragment of the original prison remains as a memorials relic. The rest has been demolished and is now... a hotel.
Okay . It was interesting and we wouldn't have missed it. Despite the obvious propaganda it was worth the visit due to the historical significance. There could be more information though
Interesting place. A look into a rather disturbing world, fascinating in it's own way. Never ceases to surprise me how my fellow human beings can be so cruel to each other.

An important experience. After going around the place, you can begin to understand the difficulties of the Vietnamese people under the French occupation and the horrors waiting for prisoners. The place is not recommended to visit with children as there are "hard to see" exhibits (original guillotine, dark rooms, etc.).
Well worth the visit. A good museum to visit to learn about the prison history. Spent roughly an hour at the museum. Some very good original artefacts from the prison life on display.

Pow prison called the Hanoi hilton. It was a david sting place to visit to learn of both Vietnamese prisoners, male and female, and also American pow pilots, including John McCain. There is a memorial wall to see
Must do. Real eye opener. A must do if you're in Hanoi it's crazy to think how they were treated. One of the highlights of our trip

If you have time. We were not sure we could fit Hoa Lo Prison into our long-weekend in Hanoi, but decided to visit as it considered worthwhile in most guide books. It is interesting, but it is important to have in mind that the stories told of the French colonial power and Americans POWs are told from a Vietnamese standpoint. However, it is without a doubt a place of horror regardless of the political statements made.Can it be compared to 2nd world war camps in Germany or prisons in Cambodia? Not really – it is a place for reflection, but to “clean” to give a lasting impression.Can you bring children? Yes, but maybe avoid telling them the most gruesome stories. The prison is not very graphical and most kids will not have any sort of trauma if they can accept that not everything is as "at home". Our philosophy is that children also should learn about the atrocities committed by man - not just a picture perfect holiday destination.

Insight into Vietnam History. The prison is easy to get to on foot. They have the historical information in English, which is helpful. It was very one sided though (fair enough) but unsure how factual it was.
Derek. Interesting and a bit forbidding. Tells a story of colonial abuse of a culture and its people. Short tour well with the small entrance fee.

For Vietnam and Hanoi this is good. First of, to those that hope to see much about Americans in prison during one of the many wars this nation has seen, you want. Yes the American war as it is named here is also represented. But more importantly it is about the people of Vietnam's struggle for independence and how the French so brutally shut that down. The inhuman treatment of the locals by the hands of the French government is something well worth learning about. This is one attraction i recommend you visit in Hanoi.

A look into a brutal past. If you love history, any and all history, I would definitely suggest Hoa Lo Prison...Hoa Lo Prison is an eye opener to a brutal piece of Vietnamese history with the French. I found the exhibits to be very well done and the history very well explained. I found so much respect for the Vietnamese and what they have been through as a nation.
Visit to the prison . Leaves you very depressed. Man's inhumanity to fellow human beings is very evident here. After visiting a similar prison in Phnom Phen Cambodia I should have avoided this

Interesting. It was a very interesting place to visit. Quite harrowing in places. Lots of things to see. The only thing I was disappointed with was the blatant bias however, it is in Vietnam, so therefore this is only to be expected. Well worth a visit though.
Very interesting and at times heartbreaking. Extremely interesting. A good insight of how to be a political prisoner or a POW. Really sad at times but insightful

This place made me feel and think lots of things. This place is a quite historical place.
If you are not interested in visiting some places like those historical places, it might make you boring.
but if you are, I would like to recommend you to visit here.

Maison Centrale. Just really wanted to see where our living hero, John McCain, was imprisoned. Disappointed that there was no specific cell/ prison uniform used by McCain. Saw only two pics- one when his plane crashed and the other when he returned.
Area was initially used by the French to imprison local dissidents. A guillotine is on display there😢

Gruesome. A place you can get the insight of prisoner's suffering in the past. A large cell that hold thirty prisoners where they were lock in their bed . You can get inside a death cell. Get close to a guillotine. Definitely Vietnamese people have suffered a lot.

Sad history . I been here when I was a tour guide . Taking a group of teen people from Malaysia. All most they cry for the victims . I was understanding very much about the value of freedom to day was cost many bloods and tears of our generation !

Insightful and worth a visit. Had a really good day out wonderful around Hanio. The prison was a good spot to go. Cheap entry, 30,000VND and you get discount if you are a student which was a quirky thing to have which took it down to 15,000VND.
Took about 1-2hrs. And it is open on a Monday.

Don't miss this bit of Vietnamese history. Hoa Lo (the Hanoi Hilton for US POWs) was built by the French to incarcerate Vietnamese resistance members. The museum is well designed though somewhat biased in the propaganda that permeates curation notes and the English guide book. It's nonetheless effective for that, in fact it's a sobering and moving experience. And it has an excellent gift shop. Don't miss it.

Sanitised history. Visiting this "prison" or I would prefer to classify this as museum did not really give much punch in describing the history. As compared to s21 in Phnom Penh, s21 is way out of league. I would recommend travelers to skip this attraction as you get more information on the internet as compared to this.
Informative but propaganda . Interesting place that shows you the other side of the story although a bit to propagandistic. If you are into history it's a recommended visit.

Hanoi hilton. Worth visiting, but quite depressing seeing the way prisoners were treated by the French.There is a courtyard where you can buy books & North Vietnamese stamps etc..A note for descendants of former US prisoners: the prison's history during the Vietnam or "American war" is very glossed over & presented in a manner that is at odds with the experiences of US POWs.
Confronting. Found it very confronting and sad, although the way it is set out is well done. Shows mans inhumanity to man

Very powerful. Lots of information in English. Only 30000 dong to enter. All air conditioned so it's pleasant to take your time looking and reading.
An incredible display if the strength and determination of the Vietnamese.
If you like history it's a must.

Very good attraction, even if it just to see propaganda. We went here in mid September 2016. I didn't think we would like it because we're not heavy history buffs. However it was a great insight into the country and watching the videos inside the prison on TV's it is evident that even today the Propaganda machine in Vietnam is alive and kicking.

Fascinating history. Visiting the Hanoi Hilton gives a great insight into the history of the wars in Vietnam... And the horrific conditions the French put the Vietnamese political prisoners through. Very interesting.. And doesn't take long to walk through. Highly recommend.
Fantastic and informative . We had a Great visit educational and found the site very educational. We learnt about the french occupation and the US POWs. Highly recommended

Good visit. The museum is a definite for the history buffs out there. But be forewarned, it is extremely biased. Parts of it were very hard to go through and ticked me off as an American but I'm glad I went.
Educational . Showed alot about the life in Hoa Lo Prison. Very good write-ups about the different cells, events, equipments.

A walk through the history. Small but you can spend about 1 to 1.5 hrs here to know abt vietnam side of her story on vietnam war. How the french colonise and build the building to house the local villagers, which later became the accommodation for prisoners of war. Informative.

Fascinating insight. Visited as part of a day tour. Was a highlight for the teenagers and adults, saw the Vietnamese perspective of a place that has seen much trauma over history.
The escape of the Vietnamese revolutionaries through tiny tunnels was interesting to learn about and see.
Worth including in your city tour.

nice place. it didn't kick off our shoes but anyway it's a nice place to see. However, please bear in mind a high level of communist propaganda! I'm not sure if really everything what happened to Vietnamese was such a tragedy while they treated all the American prisoners in such a good manner as they present in the prison:) So - visit but before or after - read something about the French and American wars in Vietnam, but from different sources

Really informative . We wanted something interesting to do within walking distance of our hotel. This was a good choice. The history lesson is a good one, and all is well set out. We really liked the scale model of the prison, especially as it showed so much that has been demolished. Some of the displays are confronting, one of which we made sure our eight year old didn't get a good look at. All of our kids were free as under 15s don't need a ticket. At 30,000VND it was very fairly priced.

English titles and information made it easier to appreciate the information and displays. Well worth the 30,000VND entry fee, with half price admission for students and seniors. Made me better understand and appreciate how much trauma the Vietnamese people have been through after successive hostile invasions. It is always enlightening to get other perspectives on historical and political events. Good displays in original buildings. Some incredible photographs and it was good to see the role of women in war recognised as well.

Very moving. I went with a friend who was in Aussie RAAF during Vietnam war. He was telling me all the American Air Force POWs were taken there but there is no history of them being there. Only the revolution people. Very harsh conditions. Well worth a visit.

Interesting history. There is a lot of history here about the revolutionary prisoners that were held by the French here and the conditions in which they where held. Lots of stories to read I found this place really interesting. Unlike a lot of sites in Vietnam where it a case of going in to a temple that is supposedly 800 years old but was rebuilt in 1970 with next to none of the original structure left - this place looks and feels authentic with the remaining buildings retaining their integrity. Equal emphasis given to the stories of male and female revolutionaries.
Very interesting . Really enjoyed the tour.Went on a tour witb hanoi kids.They were so knowledgeable and informative about the prison Very interesting to see how prisoners were treated then

Interesting visit, though bias throughout. We spent an hour or two here, worth the 30k VND in my opinion. Displays were in English/Vietnamese/French. Original cells were open to walk around, from this some of the conditions must have been terrible. The section on US POWs was interesting to say the least. Displays and videos declaring how well American prisoners were treated, claiming the moral high ground. Testimony from prisoners would indicate that conditions weren't as depicted, at least not until the end of the war.Despite the propaganda it was an interesting start to our day. Worth an hour or two depending how quickly you move through.

Walk back in times of war. Entry fee is 30,000 foe adult. It has some life size human sculptures to give you an idea of how the political prisoners were treated by the French. A Giletine used by the French to behead prisoners is also on display. Some videos of downing US aircrafts and uniforms and kits used by US military air men on display. A small Temple behind the main prison building maybe to honor the dead with fresh food offerings.An hour should be more than enough to take a self tour.

Worth a visit. This was worth coming to visit. Quite harrowing in some areas. Gives you a real sense of what went on. They still have some of the actual cells from death row. Some of the torture methods are on show and a guillotine which I found quite upsetting. It's only a very small section of what was original prison. But worth the visit.

Comprehensive layout. Mansion was a small and it took me nearly half an hour to expedite the whole place. However single piece of exhibition was well organized and arranged.At the end of tour, I was so happy to see the vending machine for beverage which was super cool!!!

WOW! (you have to go, vous devez y aller). WOW, WOW, WOWIt's a must!!! A lot of people had recommended us to go there! And we were not disappointedC'est vraiment un incontournable!!! On nous l'avait recommandé et nous n'Avons pas été déçu!
A historical destination in centre of Hanoi. If you want to know abt the history of HN & VIetnam, you can go here. That could show u a bit abt the history. It's small but kept historical value :)

Hanoi Hilton. I don't know if it was worth the ticket price to go...It was informative to a point. It depicts how deplorable life was in the jail for locals during the French occupation and how nice it was for the captured US airmen during the American war.
Informative.. To all conflicts, there are two sides. This shows the Vietnamese side of mainly the French-Indochinese war and the 1964-1975 Vietnamese war.

Vietnamese History. Hoa Lo Prison was among the first places we visited in Hanoi and we immediately got immersed in the complicated and sad history of Vietnam under French colonial rule. We recommend to anybody interested in real history and not just main attractions.

Interesting Educational. This place is a hit and a miss. It really depends if your interested in the historical side Vietnam and how their people were treated by the French and the idea of communism.Its not expensive to visit about 10000 dong and its self guided. Recommended an hour or less. A lot of interesting read in each of the rooms and you can feel the atmosphere in there. Some of the rooms with mannequins were pretty spooky, you can feel the vibe as it quite realistic. Great for rainy days and its walkable from Hanoi Old Quarter.

Insightful. A must visit to begin to understand the fractured history of Vietnam and its people. It covers the French colonial times all the way to the war prisoners from the American led invasion. A must visit to understand the cruelty of war.
Great history lesson. This was one of the must visits on our list while in HaNoi. An important and fascinating history lesson, in a very interesting set of buildings.
a moving experience. This was an emotionally difficult place to visit, but a necessary reminder of the futility of war and man's inhumanity to his fellow man.

Ok, only if bored. The prison museum is very small, it's got a couple of interesting rooms but not a lot going on, an hour max will do it. It is pretty cheap and does student discount though, if you've ran out of things to do it's worth popping in.

Educational propaganda tour. This was the only museum tour we did for our Long weekend in Hanoi. It was well done and each sign is written in English so you can learn the events, though they are written with a clear leaning towards Communism. I found it interesting to learn a different perspective. It's self guided and you can be in and out in 30 minutes to an hour. The mannequins are quite realistic and some of the cells are eerie. A section is devoted to the American POWs held there during the Vietnam War. If you are in Hanoi, it's worth the the relatively inexpensive ticket.
Very Interesting Place. There is certainly a lot to be learnt from visiting this prison, I have visited many prisons in different places and I this is the best I have ever been too.
Worth a visit.. Very interesting place. For someone like myself that wasn't aware of the history I found this very interesting. A little but of history in the middle of the hustle and bussle.
Worth to visit. I like history and like to visit museum. Hence, it's interesting for me and I think it is worth to visit. It is small while compare to other museum.

Sept 2016. Although loaded with the political rhetoric of the French and then the American invasions, the overall impression was that they had only converted a small area of the prison to make into a museum. Unfortunately there is very little to keep your internet up......only worth an hour or so out of the day.
Interesting . Stopped here during our day tour - found the museum to be interesting. It's small and can be seen in 30 minutes tops.

Historical yet scary . You can feel the atmosphere inside . Definitely not a happy place to visit, but you have to. Political prisoners were involved mostly.
30k VND for adult.
Discounted price for senior citizen, students (make sure you have your ID with you) , & child.

Cool to check out. It was a good sight to see! English on all the signs which was nice to see what we were looking at. Entrance fee 2USD ish for the fee. The a/c also was very nice to escape the heat outside on a hot day! And had western bathrooms for those who need somewhere away from hotels or hostels.

Macabre .... Interesting museum. The atmosphere there is peculiar / overwhelming : when you come in there is a communist music playing in the background; it's empty but you have fake prisoners, ... There are bits of information which is good for understanding this place

Just interesting. Interesting visit to help you understand part of the recent Vietnamese history: since French ocupation until the war. Small prison, not a lot stories, but all of them are translated to English and French.
Half day visit. We were a little disappointed in the size of the prison, but it is worth a visit, very chilling to see what the prisoner's went thru.

Hoa Lo Prison. This was such an interesting site to see. Our tour guide Linh from Paloma Bike Tours was very knowledgeable about the prison and the history.
I would highly recommend this tour.

Well worth the trip. It's impossible to imagine how horrible it must be to endure imprisonment anywhere, let alone during a Hanoi summer. This place will make to glad that you have your freedom... And the guillotine will make you rub your neck!

I do think it is worth to visit. I took my friends to visit and learn about a part of Vietnam history. I was surprised how the prisoners escaping from the prison. See the life of Vietnamese communists during the French war and the life of American pilots here.

Hanoi Hilton. Very worthwhile place to visit. Interesting to see how the Vietnamese people were imprisoned and tortured by the French, which many people are not aware of. This is probably why our American soldiers were also tortured by the Vietnamese people, However, Vietnam still claims in this museum that American prisoners were treated humanely, which all of the world knows is not accurate.

A Reality Check. This place was so depressing and yet so intertesting. It's hard to believe that this treatment was carried out on other human beings. There was a lot of reading to take in and so I would have liked to have spent more time here

Neat to visit. I found this museum to be very biased. It portrays how terrible the conditions were for the Vietnamese imprisoned by the French, but how great the conditions were for American POWs. It doesn't add up. Lots of propaganda.

We found this very interesting. Cost was only 30,000 each. You can stroll at your leisure which was nice! There was so much to read about and learn. We were glad we added this however we didn't spend very long here. Maybe an hour to an hour and a half.
Worth a visit, very interesting . Well worth a visit, not that expensive.. Very interesting history and plenty of looking around to do..
Sad at the treatment :(. The history of what Hoa Lo prison offers is incredible and also incredibly sad with the cruelty perpetrated here over 100 year.Very worth seeing and experiencing

Do it once. Is certainly a place you need to visit in hanoi but frankly i expected more, perhaps i saw already other places like this in Cambodia with more insight but anyway is a piece of history that if you are french, American or vietnamese you should not miss. Is about vietnam war American prisoners, the struggle between french forces & the vietnam revolution..Entrance 30k vnd, students 15k vnd daily 8am-5pm

An interesting history lesson.. You can walk around the prison, see lots of different parts as they were used then and also learn about the change of use of the prison through history. You can spend 1-2 hours here easily. Would recommend!

Interesting . This old prison was manly used for political prisoners back in the day and then turned into a prison for American pilots. Very cheap to game entry (30,000 dong or $2Aud). Many plaques around also provide further information.

Hoa Lo Prison. Artefacts and information was really good.
You can spend as long as you need viewing the cells and other holding areas soaking up the stories which will make you realise the treatment the prisoners were dealt out and their suffering.
Makes for a very interesting few hours.
Must See. We visited the prison with Paloma Motor bike tours- the visit gaves us a more in depth understanding of the Vietnam culture and history

An historical footnote. The prison itself is only a fragment of its old self and although some see some heavy handed propagandizing, I should think they are a little sensitive to the topic. Are there some exaggerations and untruths? Sure, probably, but anyone with cognitive capacity will be able to sort that out. My favorite part of the museum was the section that seemed to attract the locals rather then foreigners like me. Very worthwhile for those interested in history.

Hanoi Hilton. The prison features do not hold back on how barbaric the treatment was to the original Vietnamese prisoners. Only one wing remains of the prison but you get a very clear sense about how tough it would have been if you were an in mate.

A vivid reminder of the recent wars that have been fought in Vietnam. Walk through the museum and soak in the stories that are told through images, artifacts and videos. Understanding from the start that this is a Vietnamese story. Americans should especially make the visit - which is in reality a journey.

Hoa Lo Prison Hostorical Relic. The prison shows how French Colonialists, imprisoned, tortured and executed the Vietnamese revolutionary fighters.Also used to hold American Airman during the Vietnam war, a gripping visit which cannot but shock and inform on how badly human beings were treated.You will see cells, holding areas, and a guillotine that was actually used.The visit will take about 2 hours, current cost 30,000 Dong or a $1.25.
Interesting. Well worth a visit. Museum is well laid out for the visitor to see things. Allow yourself maybe an hour for a visit.
Great museum. Really interesting museum. Great exhibits. Very reasonable as well. Only 30 000 vnd. Get the book which they offer too (20000 vnd) as has some extra info.

Interesting and makes you think. Good entry price and interesting (although of course sad) museum.Good museum to visit if you want to learn about the history of Vietnam as well as see their patriotism coming across in the exhibits. Don't forget to find John McCain's outfit in which he was captured in.No staff around but everything is labelled (in English and French if I remember correctly) or self explanatory.

Must visit!. This place is steep with history. I spent about an hour here at the museum. If you enjoy reading all the history, then maybe you need another hour. There are many different rooms showing the men prison's cells, women's prison cells, the relics of the bowls, water tins, utilities the prisoners used during their confinement. It was a very sad visit.

Good use of 1-2 hours time.. Very informing even if a bit oriented like the Vietnamese handled the Americans like kings and the French were just brutal to the Vietnamese. Maybe true, maybe not. Lots of material in English, also presented in an interesting and motivating way. I wasn't sure about going there with children but they enjoyed it, there is no very traumatizing material on display so you can teach them about the history without scaring them.

Well worth a visit . The prison museam is well worth a look. Costing 30,000 roughly £1 to get in, its great value for money. We spent about 45 minutes looking around and didnt feel like we had streched the time at all. Lots of information, both written and visual displays.

Very interesting but sad . We went with a guide . Lots of rooms to walk around . Makes you think about what it was like . But its not nice .the history very intetesting . Glad we went . Not all the prison is here . Alot of it is a hotel now . But still good the part that has been made into a museum . Its like all museums it all depends on how long you want to see and read . Interesting . Small charge to get in .

Good place to know the history of vietnam. Went to this place with my girlfriend. First impression, it was nice and informative. They provide audio in some languages. Its a good place to know the history about colonial in Vietnam. French colonial, American invasion, civil war. Everything was described completely in this place.
very interesting. This was a really interesting museum at a very affordable price!Definitely worth a visit if your in Hanoi.

Impressive building. We went to visit the prison on a very hot day. Inside were fans blowing. Made us realize how hot it must have been inside without them. Also makes you realize how cruel people are. Some parts are clearly propaganda. It seems American POW's had a great time there, playing pool or decorating X-mas tree. Later this was confirmed to me by an Vietnamese guide, who didn't really wanted to take people here because of that. anyway, it was still an impressive experience and definitely worth while when you're in the area.

Interesting and informative. To get the best out of your visit it is best to take a guide. The prison is over 150 years old and was used first by the French to hold Vietnamese prisoners and then the Vietnamese to hold American military personnel during the Vietnam war. John McCain, the US Senator, was held here for 5 years. The conditions under both regimes were not good and the exhibits are informative and display this.Best known as the Hanoi Hilton

Fascinating. This was great place to visit and makes you want to read more of the history. Only probably worth visiting for an hour before the propaganda gets you. The French treated the Vietnamese pretty shabbily and of course the American prisoners of war were treated well so take everything with a grain of salt. But seeing the actual conditions was eye opening. Visit and read!

An experience not to be missed!. Prison life that will scare you. It shows the horrific side of prison life. How any person can survive the harsh conditions is just beyond comprehension. Good film with English sub-titles.For those that grew up during the Vietnam War where the USA was involved, this is a MUST! Entry fee is cheap.
Interesting insight into the early beginnings of the war. A truly historic site which reminds us of the french involvement here long before the "American War"

Fascinating insight into Hanoi's past . Hao Lo prison is open to visitors in the morning and afternoon but closes around midday. The tour includes rooms and corridors that have been preserved as a historic relic and there are lots of items and pictures on display although not all are labelled with English subtitles. The information given describes the origins of the prison and its construction and treatment of the inmates by the French during their occupation. There are also small displays and a video describing the use of the prison for American pilots during the Vietnam War. A very worthwhile place to visit.

Journey through Vietnam's Past. The place is relatively big so do cater at least 1hour if you want to fully maximize your time there. Some of the exhibits were grim but it was to be expected since it serves as a stark reminder to the trials and tribulations the country endured to come to where it is.

Informative!. interesting to see how the legendary Vietnam War history here. the place is still as creepy as our imagination could gone wild here. but in other side, it is really informative to tell the story of the war itself.
Sobering. Educative experience about the appaling ways humans can treat each other, and the resilience of the human spirit. A good choice for a short visit.

Very Interesting and Humbling. This is an interesting museum now. You get to the old barracks and holding cells -- definite not a place you would like to have been a prisoner in. There is lots of explanation in English and it is easy to spend an hour here going through the exhibits.
Piece of history. For those who like history，its a place to visit. They charge reasonable entry fee. The film has only subtitle in english, i want to sugest to have other language version.

A box ticked.... It's one of the Things to See in Ha Noi, but a bit underwhelming really. The focus, understandably, is on the historical function of the prison with little on the "Hanoi Hilton" period. It's very heavy on socialist propaganda - we found the further we went from Ha Noi, the less political dogma we enountered.

"It was a great experience!''. Although I live in Hanoi, there are lots of things to explore. Hoa Lo Prison was one of the scariest. They showed me what life was like before I was born. I really recommend for tourists to visit if you are new.
Museum. Excellent value for money. I learned a lot from this trip about the history of Vietnam and it was the best museum that I attended in Hanoi. Would recommend to anyone.
Hanoi Hilton. They protray the american dog as the Villian, but you will see in the prison that it was the FRENCH the the Viet Namese learned from. Sad,but ya gotta see it, it is history.

Retelling of History. The remains of this old French prison is a portal into Vietnamese history circa late 1800's and beyond. It shows the brutal conditions of Vietnams colonial period and in that respect it is very educational. The prison is also known as the "Hanoi Hilton" and to many connotes a different period and a new set of prisoners. The museum tries to depict the humane and civilized manner that the US POWs held there were treated.Over the past 15 years the displays have been modified to show more of the period but it is still a retelling of history.

LOur Our trip . A 150 year old Prison, built by the French to imprison the Vietnamese dissidents & criminal's. It was used by the Communist North during the war to house the American Airmen shot down. The French Guillotine is still" Institu" and still looks horrendous!!!! The Americans called it the "HANOI HILTON". It housed around 2500 Yanks '

Hanoi Holiday. This was on our list of the must do while in Hanoi - we have been and it is a really good collection of local communist history and the ill treatment of so many and well worth the visit to understand. 30,000vnd per person and 20,000vnd for the history booklet of the prison...

Worth visiting. I'm not usually into museums but Hoa La Prison was a very interesting place to visit & to see what it was like to be there during the war. Our guide filled us in on the history & whilst it was one sided, it was still interesting to learn about what happened there. Very sad but something that we should all be aware of.
must do. this one will only take you an hour to get round but hey its a must for all those interested in colonial vietnam or the american war. See the mccain flight suit and the guiloteen

AMAZING VISIT. Visiting Hanoi this is a must see. It traces the use of the prison from the 19th century to the mid 1970s. Awful how cruel people can be but a valuable lesson in the history of this resilient country.

Small but interesting . Small, interesting but very progandarific. It's a good way to kill an hour and a half, and has some interesting souvenirs and exhibitions, just don't expect an unbiased view of its history.

interesting, but less informative. if you do it without a guide, youll manage to understand the story but the effect is not as strong as the war museum in ho chi minh for example, it tells some of the Vietnamese history with the french and has a small section about the Vietnamese war- but dont expect for too much.

Worth Understanding the Hanoi Hilton. Very thought provoking. John McCain (US Senator) spent 5 years here as have other US personnel as well as Vietnamese. Quite spooky in some ways as the statues look like they could come to life. Of course the winners of war write the history, so remember that as you walk around. but it is important to understand the very long term fight of over 1000 years to get rid of the Chinese first, then the French then the US.

Heavy to see, huge impact. There isn't much left of the old prison but what is left is very striking. I reccomend it a lot. To walk trough it and to imagine that there were so many people held prison here is unbelievable. The only downside was that the second part of the prison was only propaganda about how good they were to the americans and how bad the americans treated the vietnamese.

A must see. I did this a year ago but it's impact is ongoing. If, like me, you had a "typical" start to your Day 1 Hanoi visit: to the Mausoleum which we didn't get into, and then all the significant places where Ho lived and worked, which again, we didn't get into, then the prison is the place to go!! The prison has a message which it clearly delivers but for those who can encompass photos and their descriptions and recreations of life in the prison under the French, then you will derive a good basis upon which to add the info from the National Museum and emerge with a better understanding of just how badly the French managed Vietnam. Like soMuch of Vietnam's history is coloured by the victors. However, the section dealing with life under French rule rings true.There are sections to avoid-especially if you belong to a country that sent soldiers to fight for the south. I found parts of it tasteless and unforgiving. I can understand their point of view but any loss of life, from either side, should be acknowledged.
Hmmm. I was expecting an interesting visit. It just seems that this site is mostly a re-creation of parts of the prison that used to be here. High expectations.
Good to know more about Vietnam history. Was not expecting much, but the exhibition is really well done and you learn more about the country history. Specially america war and french occupation.

Interesting history. Astonishing propaganda. The Hanoi Hilton -as it was known - has an interesting history, having held originally Vietnamese and later US prisoners. The information panels are astonishingly blunt in their propaganda values. The Vietnamese prisoners were badly treated and valiantly held onto their state-generated values against all the odds. The US prisoners were well treated , with respect and kindness. Apparently.
Interesting . We spent an enjoyable couple of hours at the prison and learnt a lot about the history of the place. It's really good value for money and the perfect thing to kill a couple of hours.

Makes you stop and think. Very interesting visit. The prison was originally built by the French and exhibits detail the appalling way the French treated Vietnamese political prisoners (of both sexes).There are also exhibits regarding the U.S. pilots who were held here during the war with America. Well worth a visit. Allow up to 2 hours

Historical place. Definitely worthy to visit this place, even it's quite scary for children though.I will strongly recommend this place to my friends as well, HoaLo prison reminds us that how war make normal citizens and prisoners' life.You should visit here if u r looking for historical place.

Hanoi Masion Center. This museum build on a small part of the old prison and it is always somethings that bring visitors the guilty of the war. Built by french solders to keep Vietnamese political prisoners then used by Vietnamese authorities to imprison American airmen during the Vietnam war (including John Mccain)
Looking at history. Truly a very good depiction of what life was like for the prisoners of war. It may be slightly scary for young kids.

History from the local perspective. Definitely worth a visit, especially on a rainy day in Hanoi as it's mostly indoors. The area of the prison open to visitors isn't huge but you can easily spend well over an hour wandering the exhibitis, some of which make uncomfortable viewing, and watching the video footage.

Reality!!!!!. For those who were imprisoned here it would have been totally traumatising. Dark ages conditions, cramped tiny dark cells with basically no fresh air The photos suggested it was like a vacation for the captured US pilots and other prisoners of war and the newsreels were very interesting---- and very sad. A must see. Lest we Forget!
Dark history. We visit some of this places in vietnam. The prison is a good place if you want to learning something over the dark history of vietnam.

Hanoi Hilton, not what I expected.. We did a tour with Urban Adventures, our guide was Anh Voung. Anh is very knowledgeable about the prison fans is a fabulous guide, ask for her.I did not expect what we saw. I was expecting it to be about American pilots from the Vietnam war, I was totally unaware of its past history. The French were not nice back in the day. Well worth a visit even though it is a little depressing.

Informative historical site. Worth a visit for further perspective on vietnam history from the time of French colonisation through the American war in Vietnam. Well laid out with an interesting Vietnamese perspective.

Interesting perspective. The information provided mainly focuses on the French invasion. The area that's focuses on the Vietnam war seems a little skewed. The Vietnamese perspective of how war prisoners were treated while imprisoned is very different to all other historical accounts. Propaganda kind of ruins the experience, but worth a look.
Spine Chilling Visit. Very informative trip around the prison. Some good photography of the French times and the Vietnam war.

Moving. It is a compact site that cannot fail to move the visitor. The suffering endured at the hands of the French regime beggars belief. The contrast with Vietnamese treatment of US pilots is laid on thick, but appears to be true.

Good, but would've been better. It's a shame only some of the prison is still standing and that it seemingly made way for a huge hotel tower to be plonked over one of the wings. What's left only takes just over an hour to walk around. It is however very interesting to learn how the prison was used first by the French and then by the Vietnamese.

Unorganized and Full of Propaganda . Like all of the museums I have visited in vietnam the history is a little one sided Obviously the Vietnamese have suffered massively at the hands of their invaders so there's really no need to try and emphasize this through lies.The museum makes it out that the American prisoners of war were treated with kindness in the jail and shows staged photos of them enjoying thanksgiving dinners etc. Reading numerous other sources we know this is not the case. Keep an open mind when visiting this museum and don't believe everything you read. It was also quite hard to navigate and the exhibitions were carelessly laid out

So much History. The prison has a lot of information cards around the place giving full information about the going ons since the construction to the Vietnam war. It has a lot of good statues and exhibits to give an idea what it was like for the prisoners. The architecture has been well preserved. I spent about 30 mins looking through it.

Worth a visit. We really enjoyed our visit to the prison. There is a lot to see inside and it was a great insight into Vietnamese history. Each exhibit has explanations in English, French and Vietnamese. Entry was 30,000 dong and we spent 2 hours inside.

Interesting visit for followers of war history. Entry fee cost 30,000 VND p.p. and you get to see various exhibits of this prison, originally built by the French to house the Vietnamese revolutionary prisoners and later, the American POW during the Vietnam War. An interesting thought-provoking visit.

Disappointed . I was really looking forward to learning more about the history of this prison during the Vietnam war however this really gets whitewashed and pushed to the side. According to two little rooms the Americans lived it up like they really were in the Hilton and life was great, which clearly wasn't the case. The focus here is on the French v Vietnamese so much many years earlier. Simply, the bulk of the prison has been demolished to make way for an office tower and what is there isn't factually correct. Upside is it was cheap and they sold cold bottled water.

A must for travellers and history enthusiasts alike. . A reasonably priced and very informative journey. You won't see the hours drift away in a trip back through this prisons brief yet enthralling history. Impressive preservation adds shock to the complete afternoon experience. Recommended!!!
Horrors of chains. So it is an prison it is not funny. You get a good impression of how people had to live there. Though a bit more/better information in English would be helpful.

Eye opener. Everyone should visit this site to take a lesson from history. The treatment of the prisoners was harrowing and very well portrayed and walking into the room which housed the guillotine was a shock. To some visitors, this building is something that they will have been told about in news reports as it was still being used in the 1970's but the conditions were unlikely to have got an airing. This is a sobering place which must be visited.
Prison. I went and visited the prison with my husband I wasn't that keen, to see it. It was real and original and gave you a good insight into the conditions that the prisoners had.
Interesting. Excellent place to visit and super interesting - mainly in English language however be careful of "guides" they're not worth the cost

Local Prison History. As one of us works in a Prison this was an interesting stop in! Learn About the history of the prison, conditions inmates endured and some of the struggles had by various political and war time prisoners. Very interesting and cheap to visit.
Fascinating and haunting . Really interesting. Could spend 2 or more hours here. Is hot, but there are fans and plenty of shade. A must see for everyone who is travelling in Hanoi.

Worth a visit. . We headed over during a rainy hour and it was worth it. Very reasonable entry and a comprehensive exhibition about the usage of the prison over the years but particularly during the war. The viewpoint is a little one sided but I found that to be true everywhere in Vietnam.
Really impressive!. Worth visiting to have a deeper knowledge of what happened with prisoners and understand different perspective of war, coming from people who lived it.

A must see. Shows the cruelty on with the french ruled Indochine. They left nice buildings but on what prize! It doesn't take long to visit the place but is well worth going there, you can still feel the oppressive atmosphere at "Hanoi Hilton"

A real experience of history. A tangible part of history still in the heart of Hanoi.
This museum is a must see to see the treatment of the revolutionary soldiers and then decades later, the treatment of the US capture pilots from the Vietnam war days.
A powerful exhibit.

An interesting place. Visited on a rainy day and spent about 2 hours here (I have no clue how you could only spend 30 min). There are interesting displays and several videos to watch that explain the history of both the imprisonment of revolutionaries and american soldiers. Very beautiful statues and memorials as well. I wouldn't list it as a 'must-see' but if it's raining, check it out with the Vietnamese Women's Museum (you get a half off coupon) - both are better than the fine arts museum.

Definitely worth a visit. This was probably my favourite place we visited on Hanoi. There was some great documentary footage and the information and atmosphere were intriguing. Like others have said, there is definitely an air of bias and propaganda, but I felt the prison told a story more so than some of the other historical attractions and museums. I definitely recommend a visit.
Short interested overview. Interesting walk around through an old prison built by the French. Once don't need a lot of time but it's quite fascinating.

Sobering visit . Was very moved by our visit to the former prison. The treatment there was tough. There is so much history packed in to this building and gave me a real sense of other parts of the nation's history. Good to visit and spend time considering

Mind-blowing. WOW! Definitely worth a walk through if you're looking for something to do in Hanoi. It is very cheap, only $2-3US or 30,000dong. This is a huge part of Vietnamese history, and although it is very interesting to see, it can be a little scary to think about. Though, it is in no way an eerie place to visit, like you may think going to an old prison might be. It is astounding and I highly recommend you taking a few hours to visit here, whether it is raining or just extremely hot!

Very well done and very moving. This is really worth a visit as the information is presented incredibly well. It makes you feel quite humble seeing and listening to the experiences of the prisoners. The sculptures add to the atmosphere along with the presentation of information.
I feel I am clearer about Vietnam's past after visiting here.

Have a proper gander at the propaganda . A really interesting museum with some harrowing accounts of what happened there. It did feel a bit manipulated in places - of course the 'comrades' of the communist party were holier than thou and fought until the bitter end despite the horrific conditions. Yet when the roles reversed and the communists were imprisoning the Americans, they treated them like royalty? Not entirely convinced myself.

Very interesting. Quite a chilling place to visit on a hot day, and very thought-provoking ... probably the only time I will see a guillotine that has been used for executions as recently as the 1950's.

Hanoi Hilton tour. Very interesting visit into a time very long past, it really shows how prisoners at the time of French occupation were treated if they were to step out of line. Was fascinating to see the way that they eventually escaped through a small sewer system and where that led Vietnsm as we know it today, this is an easy and inexpensive tour and can be done by anyone of any age, it's with walking distance of most hotels in the Old Quarter, and not far away from Hoan Kiem Lake which is a major attraction in the near centre of the Old Quarter. Must see and easy conditions, well wirth the few dollars to go through....

War Stories. If you are into war stories, you must visit Hoa Lo Prison. You will see how brave Vietnamese soldiers were and how they fought for their freedom and how they treated American soldier prisoners during the Vietnam war.
Prison . Spent the afternoon here.. Was very informative and interesting. Worth the trip and worth the visit. Good way to spend a few hours and gives good perspective on the history

Mixed feelings but good to visit. My friend took me to the museum which was not in my first list but it was interesting to see how the war interpreted through the vietnamese point of view. Every museum of this kind gives audience some mixed feelings but I learned again that Vietnamese had a complicated past. The country is however improving so much now. A good place for some history lesson of the recent past of Vietnam.

What a history. We arrived with our guide who had clearly visited many times, he explained every bit while we we walked, read, pondered, reflected, Vietnamese prison during the war.The cells, torture, stories were horrific. The conditions, food, treatment was harsh.Pictures and explanations are pretty clear and in English and the videos were nice.My mom was actually scared to go into the confinement areas.
