Whole tour took about an hour. Just depends on how much you like to read and watch.I recommend reading up on the prison beforehand to give you an insight on why Vietnamese loathed this place.
Maison Prison. Glad we took the time to visit this place. It helped to have the background when we visited other places in Vietnam like the Chu Chi Tunnels and the War Remnants Museum in Hoi An.

Visit Hoa Lo Prison before Womens Museum. Having visited here some 15 years ago, it was good to see the upgrades and maintenance of this important historic site. Most rooms are now airconditioned, providing a comfortable visiting environment, and not having to rush to get out of each room due to the heat.Save your ticket stub and receive 50% discount to the Womens Museum just down the road.

Great . It is a history lesson that in Europe they don't obviously teach at school! it is a history of pain and torture of the Vietnam people from the "democratic nations". people were chained like animals. It is really upsetting! very useful visit!

Historical. One of the main reasons for my visit was to see the "Hanoi Hilton". Sadly, most of the prison has been torn down to make room for new development in the area. What is left just gives you a glimpse of how it was in its early days. Pictures and explanations are pretty clear and in English. The videos were nice, but a bit over the top in propaganda. It does make you question who's propaganda to believe. Luckily some of the cells were still there to see how horrible the conditions were. My daughter was actually scared to go into the confinement areas. Whole tour took about an hour. Just depends on how much you like to read and watch. Kids entrance fee was free as in most other places. I recommend reading up on the prison beforehand to give you insight on why Vietnamese loathed this place.

Piece of History. Anyone remotely familiar with the Vietnam War should visit this. The official guides are blatantly propaganda machines and the displays falsely depict the Vietnam war conditions. The guide continually said the prisoners called it the Hanoi Hilton because of its luxury accommodations. It said the same on the plaques. He clearly does not understand irony or satire. The staged photos are not very convincing. Sad to see how they portray the truth. If you want to know what they did to Americans, pay attention to what they claim the French did to their prisoners. Anyone visiting the prison should read John McCain's book first. That is your best guide. A real piece of history and communist propaganda.

Nothing all that great. If you have visited any of the bigger war museums through Vietnam I would probably leave this one out. Not a lot more info on anything in particular other than the main history of the prison itself.
Nice museum. We went there on a rainy day and spent about half an hour to go around . Nice museum telling about the Vietnamese' past time

Scarry place, but very cinematic!. No museum can express the feelings of nation, which was not long ago on their knees with guns pointed to their heads. Anyway, it's worth visiting and observing local people reactions.

Moving experience, one that confused us.. We arrived with our guide who had clearly visited many times a week for years...he sat whilst we walked, read, pondered, reflected!The cells, torture, stories were horrific.the conditions, food, treatment was harsh.This was a Vietnamese prison during the war.It held some fighter pilots from the USA....I had read about their fears, their time in prison...yet they received letters from home, they celebrated Christmas, they wore their normal clothes...not like a war prison...more like an English prison in the present century
interesting. an old prison built by French colonial government to detain the revolutionists. it was turned into a museum.

Haunting. Vietnam is a special country where people overcome mighty injustices. This prison was the site of terrible events - a clear example of man's inhumanity to man. After a visit, you come away valuing human life more than ever.
Must visit . What can I say but pop along and afterwards you will have nothing but the utmost respect for the country and the people allow 2 hours to get around.

Fascinating . I found the prison to be extremely eye opening. I never really knew much about the French invasion of Vietnam and this museum really showed the struggles of the people during this time. It also shows how the Americans captives were treated here which is very different to how I would have expected.

Thought provoking. Cold drinks can be purchased at the ticket check in desk... The exhibits are well labelled in English too but a timeline of events might be helpful for those visitors who are less aware of the history of Vietnam. Some of the exhibits are gruesome; guillotine and implements if torture but it certainly puts things into perspective and help give an insight into the struggle that took place for independence. Really shows the resilience of the people here. I wouldn't call it an 'enjoyable' experience to visit here but it is certainly not one to be missed.

Hoa Lo Prison (Maison centrale). Not must to do list but if you have a time or love in history you might like this place.I think you should have about 1-2 hours there because it's not smallThe entrance fee is 30.000VDN/pp (Student Card can be a discounted 50%)
Excellent informative visit. Highly recommend place to visit. Spent a good hour and a half looking around.Buy the guide book as its really interesting.

One-sided presentation of interesting history. Conclusion: interesting for the wrong reason. The history of the prison is very interesting. You get a peak into how the prison was used before actually being a prison, how the French transformed it, and how the Vietnamese drove the French out and took over the prison. Lastly how the Americans were enprisoned. The presentation is however quite one-sided, describing the French in the worst way possible, and praising the time when the Vietnamese run the prison with outmost respect for the prisoners (even though different sources claim that the time there wasn't so great).Then again, you get a feeling of the nationalism of the Vietnamese, presenting the history in this matter. That was actually quite interesting, but at some expense of the history.

Lies still lives. This museum is intresting not from the point of how prisoners lived in this place but how Vietnamese government still lies about how americans were held in Hoa Lo. I don't support American invasion to Vietnam but it's well known that American prisoners were not happy being held in "Hanoi Hilton" and do non regret about not staying there one more year. But Vietnamese still say that. Not 30 years ago but in 2016. Great lies of propaganda!

Full of interest and the macabre. Learnt a lot about the history of Vietnam just from the prison. 30,000 vdn per adult which was good value for what you got. Lots of displays with all the info in Vietnamese, French and English. A shrine of sorts for the Vietnamese and the political struggles they had. Easy to walk around with a mix of relics, video displays and information boards.

Unsettling...as it should be. . It was really cool to walk around the prison and see the various artefacts they had, along with easily digestible snippets of information. It is really unsettling to imagine people living in those conditions though. Highly recommend if you're a history buff.

Absolutely disappointing and boring. We felt that we lost money and time.There is not interesting info just some pictures and small stories about people who was emprisoned there. It also looks like super false and reconstructed and you feel like walking through a park land. It also has 2 videos saying how good vietnamese peple was with us army prisoners sounding like a joke.The real story is so hard and the museum looks like a turist atraction.Not recommended at all.

Very impressive and certainly not a happy place. This museum confronted us with how inventive people can be when it comes to punishment and torture. I think it is a must see but if you're a very sensitive person you might think twice before going.

Very Interesting!. Stumbled across this and it was probably the best place I saw in Hanoi, very interesting reading about the history of the country through how the prison was used during the different ages. A must see if in Hanoi in my opinion and it only takes an hour or so to walk round.

Must See!. As an American this was very enlightening. Most Americans are unaware that this prison, which we refer to as "Hanoi Hilton" (named by US POWs), originally was built by the French to house Vietnamese political prisoners both male and female. Do not skip this museum you will not be disappointed.

Educational and interesting to walk through for reasonable price. The museum was 60,000 per person which was well worth the visit. We spent nearly 2 hours walking through, reading the texts and watching different films about how the space was used. Quite humbling to see the many who occupied that space.
Interesting . There are some odd translations but overall an interesting visit. Walking distance from Hanoi old town and they offer student discount.

Might as well do it. The prison was interesting to see. It was pretty one sided though. Americans were terrible, the French were terrible - and the Vietnamese were terribly hospitable. Still cool to see and get a history lesson, even if it wasn't the best one.
Interesting. A good pedagogic tour, with clear illustrations and story telling, both from the French occupation, and the captured US pilots.

Hoa Lo Prison - Educational experience . We went to the Hoa Lo Prison as wanted to gather some insight into the history of Vietnam. Whilst a background of knowledge is probably required it does provide information regarding the conditions of the prisoners and a brief historical overview of the American War.Great value and has many facets to explore, even dare to step inside the the prison cells. There are no wardens or posts to prevent people from looking which adds to the experience. Overall definitely worth visiting!

Propaganda but worth a visit!. As we had some time in Hanoi before our flight I decided to take my boys to the infamous "Hanoi Hilton", as it was called by the US airmen that were incarcerated there during the Vietnam war.In fairness it doesn't simply focus on the American War but also on the struggle of the Vietnamese during the French colonial days and their struggle for freedom. It is thought provoking but more because of the conditions people were kept in rather than the social struggle that was taking place.It is a very one sided view of the war against the Imperialist aggression of the US. They also go to great lengths to show how well treated the US prisoners were - quite a few photos of smiling US personnel busy decorating the prison for Christmas. Was that the reality?

One of eye opening historical things we need to be aware of. We found this visit challenged our faith in humanity. The Vietnamese people have endured so much. A very interesting place with many of the historical facets still intact. The old french fittings fascinated me.
Hoa Lo Prison . Very moving place to see knowing that so many people suffered there. Both Vietnamese and American service members. A must see while in Hanoi.

1 part history education, 2 parts propoganda. The building exterior is pretty like many other buildings in Hanoi, and the exhibits inside like the guillotine and ankle-shackled prisoners had quite the impact on my young boys, but the information felt more like propaganda than history education.
Interesting. Really interesting way to spend a few hours. Very biased in its presentation of information but worthwhile to help understand the history of the country.

Was expecting more. Having visited various museums etc in Saigon we were expecting this to be as good. It was interesting to see how the prison functioned at various stages of its life and there were some interesting photos in some of the rooms but overall it wasn't overly inspiring.

historical, creepy, propaganda. The so-called "Hanoi Hilton" informs visitors of the different uses of the prison in different eras, including who the jailers and prisoners were. The first part of the visit details the cruelties the French subjected the Vietnamese prisoners to and the bravery and perseverance of the Communist Vietnamese. Then, the second half of the visit insists that the American POWs held in the same place enjoyed good treatment. While I appreciate history and try to visit historically significant sites, Hoa Lo Prison was a letdown.
Good Place to visit. Very interesting place to visit to learn how the prison come about and what about the prison that made it so famous.
Interesting place to visit. An interesting place to visit. Good to spend a couple of hours reading all of the info available.. Good price

Heavy with history. This site was very interesting to see. If you're a history buff and interested in things like war crimes and the colonization of the French, this is the perfect place. Both amazing and uneasy to see, highly recommended!

Bit grim. We spent an hour or so here and it was time well spent. Very good displays of how prisoners were treated (not very well in most cases but when it was used to house American airmen shot down during the American war they appeared from photo's to have been treated well). Worth a look.

Interesting though a large part of the prison is now gone. I was looking forward to visiting the prison. Some parts were quite interesting, however a large part of the prison no longer exists so it was hard to get a feel for what it would have been like.It was still worth a visit though, but only include if you have more than a couple of days in your itinerary.

Well worth a visit. This place was a really shocking and sad insight into some of the history of Vietnam. While some of the information boards are quite biased, I still learned a lot from my visit. Would definitely recommend.

WORTH A SHORT VISIT. I had watched Hanoi Hilton movie many many years ago and was intrigued to visit the prison.
It is angled more at what has happened to the Vietnamese and only a very small portion devoted to Vietnam war and nothing to events after the war.

A must on your visit list. A pity they knocked down part of this establishment ,but what is left gives you a strong message of how the French and Americans who were incacerated here existed. John Mc Caines flight suit still hangs here!

Interesting Experience at Hoa Lo. Like so many attractions in Hanoi, if you have a student ID, bring it! This was one of our first stops in Hanoi. The self guided tour around the prison was a very interesting introduction to Vietnamese life under French rule. The majority of the prison is about Hoa Lo when it was run by the French. At the end of the tour you get to the Vietnam/American war. As expected, the tone of this part of the prison is a vastly different narrative. Just be prepared! I'm glad that I saw Hoa Lo Prison while in Hanoi.

A brutal part of history. The irony of a place we Americans equate with the "fight against Communism" is that it is located right next door to a new shopping mall, with very upscale shops. Once you are inside, however, you are in a different and very intense world. The prison, which was used to house Vietnamese prisoners in the fight against the French colonists, and then American POWs, is a powerful statement of the cruelty of imprisonment, the efforts of prisoners to maintain some degree of humanity, and the power of politics to "spin" the story. It is a fascinating look at a time when there were no "good guys."

Hoa lo Prison experience. Loved this place has a very interesting history and story behind it well worth the visit ,the displays are great and look so real ...even a little bit spooky in the men's section one might say ! definitely some spooks in there !

From French Prison to American Prisoners. Very interesting old prison built by the French Colonial establishment to administer their colony, then used to jail nationalists fighting for independence after WW II, then housing American and other prisoners of the American war (POWs). Well worth a visit for history of this period, and how the Vietnamese survived such treatment.
Hoa lo prison. Very emotional same can be compared to robben island .we can see the history regarding the oppression suffered by vietnamese people.a must see

A must see for history buffs ... just go with an open mind. If you're a modern history buff, this is definitely a must-see. The "Hanoi Hilton" is more than just the prison where John McCain was detained during the Vietnam War. It was also an important part of the Vietnamese resistance against the French occupiers during the early 20th Century. To me, that was the most fascinating part of the prison. Yes, you should be prepared for a fair amount of propaganda. But did you expect them to show the real conditions for the US Airmen who were detained there? The level of propaganda is no more that the propaganda you get from my neck of the woods, at the Old North Bridge in Concord, Massachusetts or the Bunker Hill Monument in Charlestown. It portrays the Vietnamese as brave revolutionaries and the French as brutal occupiers. That's how history works.

Must See . As far I van judge a well balanced museum about the French, Vietnamese and US prisoners. Not all departments and section are there anymore but what's left over gives you a good insight how the prisoners were treated. It takes you about 1 to 1,5 hours to see most rooms. The entree fee is 30k for adults and children under 12 years are for free.
Very intetrsting. Very interesting museum. We walked around for about an hour, there's English explanation throughout the museum.
Interest morning. We enjoyed the museum and learning the history of its use. It was very informative. Would recommend.
vietnam Prison. was interesting, I would recommend going on a tour, because you are just looking at items with very little explanation.
Worth a visit . Interesting place given its recent history, but more English literature would have been a benefit. Certainly worth visiting for 45 minutes out of your day
Interesting place. Makes you more aware what the South Vietnamese and North Vietnamese thought of each other and how the French where involved. Worth a look.

Interesting view of the old French rule. Its ok. I didn't know a great deal about the French rule in Vietnam. Learnt a little. I think the American part of the Vietnam war was played down a bit, as I have heard worse stories then what was portrayed at the location.
Interesting . Well worth a visit to help understand the history and culture of this country . One of the vest museums we visited in Hanoi.

Creepy Experience. The famous Hanoi "Hilton" with John McCain's jumpsuit when he crashed during the war is quite a creepy experience (considering all the stuff the French did to the Vietnamese as well during their rebellion).Quite the contrast when you're in the courtyard and right next to the building is a Somerset (?) building next door which is a gargantuan hotel.You have to go here if you in Hanoi
interesting yet disturbing. amazing the french built it for vietnamese who were fighting them for their independence, then the vietnamese used it on americans

Hanoi Hilton. A thought provoking visit showcasing original cells and some of the shackles used to hold the Vietnamese prisoners incarcerated by the French. There are photos of the American soldiers kept there as POW with some shrapnel from B52's. Not much left of the original buildings as the land was sold to developers many years ago.
Very Interesting!. A must-see. The most amazing part was the old sewage drain through which several prisoners escaped using acid and a hack-saw smuggled in by a woman visitor.

Worth the visit.. This was a very moving experience. The Hanoi Hilton as it was known was well worth the visit. The day we went it was not really crowded and you could take your time reading about the dark history of this place.

Hoa Lo prison. It's about the way the Vietnam people were treated when the French invaded, very sad to see like any other country that is take over in colonial times, it also shows so things about the Vietnam war & the American prisoners, it's worth going as it is part of there history & very interesting

Very interesting!. We came here as part of a tour and I'm very glad we did. Being born after the Vietnam/American war I knew very little about it. This museum was very interesting. A good size to help learn a lot about the war and the prisons part in it. I think we spent around an hour to easily walk around through it all. The tour guide payed for us all but pretty sure it cost next to nothing to enter. Well worth it!

Eye opening. I am not usually into visiting museums but Hoa Lo prison was an exception to the rule. It was very interesting hearing about Vietnam's war history but quite confronting too. Highly recommend adding this one to your list.

if you want to know more about Vietnam war, this is where u go. in the museum, they have a lot of information about the vietnam war and french war. It will be totally different from books that you have learnt. Many people had to cry when they come here
Hoa Lo Prison. Well worth a visit! Very confronting, but a must visit.Central to get to, and well set out. Easy to get around.

The witness of war. Last month we went to Hoa Lo prison (it is known as Hanoi Hilton) to learn about Vietnam's war history, this prison was really perfect place to find out the realm of Vietnam war, after visiting Hoa Lo now we know how Vietnamese suffered during the colonial time and the way they defeated some huge enemies. Highly recommended.

Only thing worth seeing. out of all the museums we went to in Hanoi, this was the only one worth visiting. well preserved and labeled and interesting. Its conveniently located and the perfect size for a museum. It took about 40 minutes to see it all and the rooms have proper air conditioning for the hot vietnamese summer.
Sombering. An amazing piece of history, videos and information boards throughout. Able to see a lot in here. Including how it was for the prisoners to be incarcerated.
Worth a visit. The museum covers a decent period of turmoil and has good displays. The information boards are very informative. Entry was 40k each. Reasonable fee for the venue.

Good museum telling some terrible historical stories. Worth a visit to see how humans have treated other humans appallingly throughout history.
A good museum with the right amount of information available so you can understand old and new Vietnam history.
A few people were visibly upset by imagery and display.

informative and propagandistic at the same time. I had a really great impression of the museum as I walked through the parts which tell you about the French occupation and the beginning of the Vietnam war. Then there are the two rooms about the American POWs (Prisoner of War) and the Hoa Lo Prison, which is known as the notorious torture prison, is pictured as paradise for the American pilots.After having seen that propaganda, I couldn't help but feel doubts about the rest of the museum and leave with a very fishy feeling. The Vietnamese government would do itself a favour it would start to be real about what happened in the war and admit the own misdoings.
Prison visit . I popped in here when i had a spare afternoon. I looked at everything within an hour. Its not a big prison. You could spend longer if you were to read everything.
Frighteningly familiar to those who remember the confllict. Yes- worth a visit- its all quite harrowing ..looking at the way prisoners were treated is always shocking...

Really Enjoyed My Visit. I thought this visit was great, full of information, signage in Vietnamese, English and French. Very clear and easy to read (not to wordy), very well laid out. I think great for the whole family, does definitely give you a glimpse into the past horrific conditions prisoners faced.

Good visit, as long as you remember to keep your eyes open. I was definitely glad I visited Hoa Lo Prison. Very interesting to find out about Vietnamese history, although having also read information from other sources I think it's important to take it with a pinch of salt. Very reasonably priced, although I wish I'd known before hand to take my student card for discount.

Touching experience. The visit was very educational and also very touching. My fav part was the documentaries about prison life and how the Vietnamese army took such good care of the American prisoners of war, whilst it was quite the opposite with the way americans treated the vietnamese.

History.. Interesting because it belongs to a difficult period for VN. Don't just walk through, but if possible have someone explain what you're looking at as there is a lot of information to be understood., May be hard on small kids.

Interesting place. Whilst staying in Hanoi, we went to visit Hoa La prison. It was very interesting place to visit . All the signs are in Vietnamese, English and French so it is easy to follow.I am not sure it is really suitable for young children.

Grim but a startling reminder of history. Whislt only a small section of the person remains it has been well set up as a museum. Interesting reading their little booklet (extra charge) and viewing the exhibits. The original guillotine from 1984 is also on display. Just don't be too swayed by the propaganda....there were barbaric acts on both sides!

Definitely go!. This museum was definitely interesting – we got to learn about what happened with both the French and the Americans throughout Vietnamese history. I recommend visiting this place – it made me want to learn more!
Great place to visit. Definitely worth a visit. Full of information remnants pictures etc. Cheap to enter and easy to find!

interesting but very sad piece of history. It's a bit propaganda-like. It's about the prison the French used for a lot of Vietnamese people and a few American. They do picture it that it was a (Hilton) hotel overthere. Besides that, very interesting to have a look at. A black page of history

Hoa Lo prison museum is a must. I went with one friend and we were both very glad we did this. The museum is very respectfully designed and they have almost all signs in english (and french). The Price was not bad at all, but if you are a student you should bring your studentcard for discount. I Think it is a must see in Hanoi.

Interesting and sad. I think this place is best experienced with a local guide that can tell you more about this prison and it's history. During the French occupation this was where many Vietnamese revolutionists lost their life, and during the Vietnam war it was where the captured American pilots were held.

Insightful. Went here on a very very warm day, air con was on but still uncomfortably warm. Personally it was an interesting visit and something you should consider but there are certainly other attractions if prefer to go to. I do feel that you must take it all in with a pinch of salt. Il let you figure out why yourself.
Interesting. The old French jail was turned into a museum elaborating how Vietnamese prisoners were tortured and how American air force pilots were treated.
Hoa Lo Prison. This is a sad place to visit but important to see and understand the history of both sides of oppression.The cost to get in is 30,000vnd which is very good
Really interesting. Having little knowledge of the war and Vietnam history this was a great introduction and a cheap morning. Recommended visit for history buffs and culture lovers.

Lots to learn. Came here as part of a group tour before heading North West to Mai Chau. A worthwhile stop given the history of Vietnam and a sobering look at the conditions and uses of the prison over the years. Busy place but very quiet and respectful. Lots to look at and learn so if you have the time, read and watch all on offer.

Hoa Lo prison - a witness of war. A tour there sheds light on how savage and horrible the prison could be for the inmates: the cachot, the Guilotine (head cutting machine) and so on. If you want to know more about the war between Vietnam - France, you should not miss this historical sites. Though only 1/4 of the prison remains today (the rest was destroyed and constructed into a skyscraper - Hanoi Tower), the prison is for sure well-worth a visit.
Nice walk. A nice walk in the morning. Nice activities around the Lake. The Vietnamese people will invite you to join them in their morning exercises.

Hanoi Hilton. Visited this late in the afternoon when not many people around. Not that big and only takes about 45min. Quite interesting and a lot of information about the various uses of the prison including the jailing of American pilots. For Aud $2.50 you cannot go wrong checking out this piece of history. Quite centrally located near the old quarter.

Very interesting . Poignant and well explained museum that taught me a lot. Some macabre things like a real life guillotine and pictures of decapitated heads, but it'll stay with me and in a way I'm glad they don't try to "prettify" the conditions of war. I'm a tad sceptical about how well treated the US pilots were, but that's a discussion for another day... Go check it out.

An above average place to see and cheap. I had no idea about the French in Vietnam and didn't know a lot about the Vietnamese/American war. We had done almost everything we wanted to do in Hanoi and to fill in a bit of time before leaving we thought the prison would be nice. It was quite good, it took about 2 hours to walk through and read just about everything. Pretty close to the centre of town, and from memory didn't cost much at all.

A Historical Perspective. There is so much about Vietnam War written about by the media that one does tend to forget the occupation of Vietnam by the French and the subsequent communist rule under Ho Chi Minh.This web of complex history will really excite you if your are interested in war history. Even otherwise the place does educate you about the futility of war and what we end up doing to mankind

Creepy and historical. We went with a guide. Walking from French Quarter hotel is doable. models, photos, exhibits were good. The section about the American prisoners had some unrealistic bias. We got a coke in the shop. I recommend seeing this site while in Hanoi.

a good bit of history. The Hanoi Hilton doesn't disappoint. A good bit history of how the French colonists dealt with the Vietnamese political prisoners and there are displays about the American POW's.I've read that it may have housed up to 2,000 prisoners in the 1930's. Go see it yourself and you'll be hard pressed to understand how they got that many within the confined complex.I enjoyed the day walking around.

Hmmmmmm... Weird place since didnt feel its honest. It was a nice place but didnt feel it was an accurate representation of how the American pilots were treated. But for whatever its worth good to see it and make your own final analysis of what it is about.
Interesting!!. Is a good place to understand a bit more colonization and war in Vietnam... it is also fun to see the history from another perspective!

Interesting visit. Touring the old prison gives a realistic and disturbing view of the hardships experienced by Vietnamese independence fighters under French rule. We visited just after 9am and there were no queues and hardly anyone else there which was a bonus.

Too restored. It's a nice place to visit to understand a part of vietnamese history. I think the prison is too restored. The prison looks pretty much new and I think this ruins a little bit the atmosphere because you can't really imagine how it was longer ago. I prefer seeing ruined walls and floors rather than new painted ones.
Must see in Hanoi. Great for learning more about Vietnamese history. Interesting items kept from American POWs. Definitely worth stopping by. We weren't there longer than 2 hrs and took our time.

Interesting perspective. It was interesting to see this piece of history from the Vietnamese perspective. Seeing how prisoners were kept by the French helped explain how information was shared and plans were built. Parents have to decide if they want their children to see the guillotine, but otherwise this is a good exhibit to teach about war and differences in perspective.

Pure propaganda. The Vietnamese were treated bad by the French but the Americans were treated like kings there? Are you kidding me. I have to watch out what I say so I will spare the rest for myself. If you want to learn more about this particular prison or the Vietnamese American war, read an independent history thesis, book or novel. Don't waste your time here!
Well worth the visit. Very interesting to hear about the Vietnamese from the French era and american air pilots who were locked up here. The Americans had it a bit better hence the name Hanoi Hilton.

how rude people can be. Hilton Hani is the nickname. a good impression about how prisoners were treated by different governments in different times and maybe it happens nowadays still, but that is not told!

Good Historical Visit. This prison is a humbling reminder of the ugliness of war and the effectiveness of propaganda. Originally built to hold Vietnamese rebels against the centuries long French occupation, the museum includes several well designed installations demonstrating the horrors to which these unfortunates were subjected in their daily lives as prisoners. For American visitors, Senator McCain was kept here, but his recollections of the place do not jive with what the prison presents. Dozens of clearly staged photos of happy POWs playing basketball or poker, working on handicrafts, and in general having a great time.It is definitely a worthwhile visit for the historically inclined... Especially those who supplement visits with a bit of research.

Interesting. Interesting museum, with some really nicely crafted exhibits. The information on the plaques were very politically loaded and subjective which tells you something in itself, I guess. The place in itself was surprisingly well kept and clean.

Interesting, but Full of Propaganda. The museum was interesting to see and tour, and it showed what atrocities and nightmares the prisoners there must have endured, but the placards described a very one-sided and decidedly anti-Western perspective on history. There were many derogatory references to Americans and French people and governments that were unnecessary in the telling of history as well as a strict adherence to the stories that American prisoners were all treated well, despite the accounts of torture and other inhumane activities that occurred at the prison. It was very informative to see the living conditions of the prisoners there, however, and I did think they did a good job of preserving what remains of the site. I just wish they removed the political narrative and focused on the history.

one of the rare attractions in the old quarter. My free Hanoi tour guide said to me that I could spend there 20 minutes. I visited by myself and had nothing else to do. And I have spent more than 2 hours in it. I've read all, seen all the videos and looked at all the artefacts.I enjoyed the visit for a cost of only 30.000 vnd, about one euro.Near of it, there are 2 restaurants that recommand : Zenith yoga and Pho.

Eye opening tour. We were both very keen to visit the 'Hanoi Hilton' with it's well-known history during the Vietnam war. It was very worthwhile and really exposed the terrible conditions, torture, persecution and suffering of the prisoners. The prison has been well maintained, the exhibits and text are excellent. We felt that the prison has retained that sombre, horrifying atmosphere and it made us understand what life must have been like for inmates. Go visit the prison, I would definitely have it on my list of thing to do.Louise
Informative on history. Found this to be more interesting than the other typical museums. Shows about the Vietnamese political prisoners, how the American POW were treated. Overall a good experience!
Very interesting. We visited Hao Lo Prison (Hanoi Hilton) yesterday and it was worth a visit. It explains the struggles that the Vietnamese people had to gain their freedom.

Tour. You don't have to be morbid to enjoy this tour, although the original guillotine and body casks leave you a little in awe, particularly as you do not have to go back too far in history to relate to the dates.About an hour and you've covered it.

Another Example of Man's Cruelty to Man. Of course, had to visit this attraction since I heard a lot about the Hanoi Hilton back in the 1960s and how American Prisoners of War were treated; the French abused Vietnamese citizens as well. Somewhat air conditioned, I can barely imagine what this place was like during summer when air conditioning was non-existent. A brochure is available for US$1.
Historical Interest. The prison was only built in the 1890s but it was clearly a pretty horrible place to be incarcerated. The nationalist/communist propaganda is a bit unrelenting but worth an hour.

Good way to kill time. If you're in the old quarter and if you want to get away from the heat, then I'd recommend visiting this. A good place to read a bit about history while you burn off the food you ate.
Spend time at Maison Centrale. Thought provoking but very interesting museum of great historical significance. Definitely worth a visit.

Remembering the past. This is well worth a visit particularly if, like myself, you are interested in the history of the Vietnamese people. While I associated this prison with the so- called 'American' War, it was actually mostly used by the French and only partially used for the capture of American Pilots during the Vietnam War as we know it. My biggest concern was they made it look like a holiday camp for the pilots - having Christmas Dinner, playing basketball etc. We all know there were horrific atrocities on both sides so no need to pretend it was all one sided.

Prison life and death. The prison is a stark and grim place . The entry fee includes a map. Several cells have life size models of prisoners to provide an understanding of living conditions. There are interesting details of escape routes and solitary confinement cells on death row. The women's cell conditions were extraordinarily overcrowded. There are interesting photos displayed of POWs during their capture and imprisonment and finally returning to Vietnam after the war . A good rainy day activity.
Visit to Hoa Lo. Very interesting to learn about the history of the prison only 30,000 vd to enter. Well laid out, tells Vietnam side of the war not Hollywood version

Enriching experience. I browsed through this museum in a rush because it's going to close soon. I wish I could spend more time there. The models look very real life and you could really feel the experience those POWs went through in the past.
Very interesting!. Great to visit. Interesting history from the Vietnamese point of view. Highly recommend for a memorable day out in Vietnam.
Very educational!!. I learned so much about the prison that I did not know before! I definitely think that if you are in Hanoi and even slightly interested you should go!

Better than expected. When we arrived at the Prison I was expecting it to be a pretty quick visit. The Prison is actually bigger than at first glance and offered an interesting insight into the wars that have shaped Vietnams history.Dubbed the Hanoi Hilton by the American POWs. The prison was built by French Colonists to hold Vietnamese prisoners and later was used by the Vietnamese to hold American prisoners of war.The conditions the prisoners lived in were horrific. I would say the prison visit was good, if that's the right word, for something that is quite depressing and horrifying.
Hoa Lo Prison. Was a very good experience, well planned out with heaps of original pieces like clothing, cells and instruments used back in that time. Be sure to make time for it.

Worth a visit . We visited here with two boys, it is inexpensive and an interesting view into colonial occupation and the internment of U.S. pilots during the war. If you have a spare hour in Hanoi it's worth a visit.

Propaganda!. Wow! This was interesting. I teach history, so this place was on my must do list for Hanoi. They charged different prices for each of my friends - I paid 50k dong (2.25 US) to get in. Some of my friends only paid 30k. Welcome to Vietnam?!? Anyway, they have a nice booklet that explains (using Vietnamese propaganda) what the prison is all about. Get the booklet. If nothing else it will crack you up (or really disturb you). The museum includes an explanation about the use of the prison under the French and the use of the prison to hold US pilots. As you can imagine, they explain that the pilots were well taken care of. There's a memorial room for Vietnamese who died in the prison under the French. Visit it. It's interesting. The prison was a worthwhile visit for the money. Don't expect a fair explanation of what went on there. After all, the winners get to explain history.

Worth a visit. Come to see how the French used the prison against the Revolutionist and how it was then transformed into a prison to hold the American soldiers captive during the Vietnam war. It's a quick, informal stop. Doesn't even take an hour to go through everything.
A 15-mintue experience of visit. The most interesting part is to understand how the prisoners escaped from their cells and how the pilots got captured... Great to visit if you are a history person.

Insight into previous history . Many will have heard of this prison as the 'Hanoi Hilton' from the era of the Vietnam war and the American POWs held there. There is an interesting section dedicated to that period but new to me was the story of the Vietnamese held by the French in shocking conditions. Chilling photos and the guillotine are a bit of a shock. It's good to be reminded of the 'other' side of the story,even if the language is propaganda style. One of the better museums in Hanoi.
Historically significant. Takes an hour to walk the corridors and see what conditions were like in this ex-colonial French prison. Would recommend if you are visiting Hanoi

Nice place to visit for a break from the heat. It's nice place to visit to hide from the heat, to read something interesting about history, however it will make you feel little down for a moment. It's also nice to see other side of the story even though it's exaggerated as well, but that's ok.

Interesting. Most of the prison was demolished but what's left is worth a visit. A couple of rooms are devoted to the US prisoners from the Vietnam war days but most is French colonial era. All interesting and well worth a stop.

Slightly disappointed. Expected a bit more, Interesting but not great, all done in under an hour as it a small prison, found the US Airmen prison section interesting but at only a couple of Dollars it is value for money

Guillotine is a highlight. Interesting how this prison was built by the French to imprison the Vietnamese, then was used as a POW camp for the US pilots.There are a couple of really interesting 5 minute videos in the US pilots area that give an interesting spin on things.The guillotine used by the French on the Vietnamese was a highlight. Put this as a must see on your list.
Amazing. Pretty gruesome place but full of history about the French occupation of Vietnam and also the war. 30,000 VND to enter ....

In case you were unaware of how awful humans can be, this is a crash course. . Very educational. I was reminded of how humans lead the animal kingdom in terms of viciousness. They did an amazing job recreating the conditions in abstract form. No rational human can leave this place without feeling....(insert strong emotion, I can't choose an appropriate word for how I felt).

Chilling Cell Visits. While only small section dedicated to Vietnam War with the Americans, it was fascinating to visit (as an American). We had just meet Mr Hong My (Vietnam Fighter Pilot) so this built on our visit with him. Get to visit the jail cells. Video of American bombing was scary. They have all these pictures of the American pilots celebrating Christmas, playing sports, and smiling. Quite counter to what we've heard so a bit hard to believe. Definitely worth a visit. The French guillotine on display was absolutely gorey!
Quite interesting. Much bigger than I thought it would be. This is a very simple but interesting museum. The propaganda alone is a talking point. Cheap entry.Well worth a visit!

Hoa Lo can you go..... A lot of people recommended Hoa Lo Prison Museum or the Hanoi Hilton as a must see attraction. The visit is more meaningful if you have (or will) visited the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh.As with the War Remnants Museum there is a heavy bias towards the Vietnamese people but that is understandable given the way in which they have suffered as a nation.You can finish off the museum in an hour (potentially two) and it's worth it although my view is that the war remnants museum is better.
Very interesting perspective.. Very interesting to visit and to see the Vietnamese attitude towards their wars. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Informative and well presented. The prison wasn't just for women but political prisoners who were held in some of the most inhumane conditions which are very well presented. it is impossible not to walk out without being effected by the displays. A must see when you are in Hanoi

Worth a visit to the "Hanoi Hilton". This is worth a trip if one had interest in learning about Vietnam's take on French occupation (very pissed off about it for good reason) and "The American War" (ditto). It is about an hours worth of effort and includes some interesting comments about how great the US aircrew prisoners had while enjoying the hospitality of the Vietnamese.

Fascinating insight into prison life and Vietnam war. There is only one wing of the prison complex remaining with the main entrance, but despite this , it provides a fascinating insight into the experiences of both Vietnamese prisoners and ultimately American POWs. There are many displays of photos and artefacts with descriptions in English as well as Vietnamese from early days of its history with the French (who built it) to latter days of 60/70s, including a chilling guillotine that was used during French occupation to behead the Vietnamese resistance. The videos displayed were sometimes shocking but always fascinating - they provide a north Vietnamese view of the Vietnam war, its impact on the locals, and how US POWs were treated - very different to that which we were fed by our governments, so quite thought provoking.A must see.

Very interesting perspective on the Vietnam war and NVA POW treatment. We were worried there would not be much to see here due to other reviews we have read. But there is actually quite a bit left of the prison. The sections still standing are really well taken care of. The government has done a wonderful job building displays and presenting the history of this prison from French colonialism through the Vietnam war.
Interesting background history. Even though only a small part of the prison is still left, it is worth the time to go and see and learn some of the horific history the area has.
Experience. The first impression is so scared :( . The prisioner had a very poor and hard life. Location : city center

Harsh life behind bars. This is a must-do for the visitors to Hanoi. Well maintained and very informative. You could stay for as long as u like, but can do it all in an hour. Reasonablypriced30000dong($us2)Walking distance to the women's museum and St Joseph's Cath churc.
Interesting . Great to get an inside of the Vietnam war. Great displays with lots of information. I think visitors should be giving a free information guide for the prison.

Be prepared . If you are American, do some reading on the American POWs' experiences there before you go. The contrast between how it's represented is hard to describe. Most of the museum is dedicated to memorializing the communist leaders who were imprisoned there by the French. Overall, really interesting, but be prepared if you have any connections to the war to feel a little strange about it.

Good history of the famous Hanoi Hilton, worth checking out. Not the most popular tourist site but I think it's good to see how the site was used to imprison Vietnamese, POWs during WWII and Americans during the Vietnam War here. The interior is quite authentic with various jail cells and escape routes displayed albeit a bit of government propaganda present which is expected. I say it's worth visiting and architecturally worth checking out.

It's small, but may be worth seeing. What remains is only a small part of the original prison. It is worth seeing if you have an hour to kill while in Hanoi. The second floor is mostly for propaganda.

Harrowing, but go.. The prison (and the displays and information) impacted me more than I expected. Very educational. Gruesome facts were mostly written, but there are a couple graphic photos/murals if I remember correctly, so you might like to check out photos from other visitors if you're considering visiting with small children.

Memorable. If you have time, you should pay a visit to the prison in Hanoi. The exhibition details the years the French held Vietnamese soldiers there as well as later when the Vietcong used the same prison to hold US pilots. Our visit left a lasting impression on me. It is not too far from the old quarter and only about AU$1.70 for entry.

Good museum . The museum is good and tells the history in a good way, even though it is as all the war museums in Vietnam - not that historically correct and with a lot of focus on what was done to the political prisoners. It's worth a visit.

Worth Visiting. Though only 1/3 the original size, it was powerful to visit actual cells and see real artifacts, and learn more about the war and prison. I was particularly fascinated with the stories about the captured US Airmen, and the women's area.
Interesting museum. Tourists get to check out the remnants of Hanoi Hilton. Many displays and artifacts focusing on Vietnam's struggle for independence. A great way to spend an hour
Fascinating . Very interesting look into a couple of different periods in Vietnam's history.A good stop close to the old quarter on a self guided walking tour

Another interesting take on Vietnam History? . Interesting place to visit, if a little bit full on propaganda on the videos shown. However, well kept museum, some good historical parts about the B52 bombings.

A Glimpse at History!. This is one of the museums in Vietnam a tourist ought to see and visit. In every Hollywood movie you see, the Vietnamese people were most often demonised. But the truth is they are as much nationalists as the Americans are. The prison will teach us their struggle for freedom and how much they endured from the colonists. The prison also shows how they treated the american prisoners of war with dignity and with more humanity than how they were treated by the colonists. No doubt, after seeing the prison and all the exhibits there, my view of the Vietnamese people has changed dramatically.

Interesting. Spent about 1.5 hours at this place, which outlines the history of the prison from the original ethnic craft village through French colonial times and then through to the Vietnam War prisoners. Commentary very one sided and propaganda laden, and some of the imagery was difficult for my small kids. But quite interesting. Kids under 15 are free.

Interesting. It was a great site to go to and I would recommend it to anyone to be able to experience the different opinions of the vietnamese, the propaganda was very interesting to read. Although it was quite small due to most of it being demolished to build the huge tower and you can't really spend more than an hour in there for a price of about $1.50 usd it was worth it

Interesting but touristic . The prison was interesting but felt a little staged with the manakins put in the chains. Still must see in Hanoi to understand the history of the French colonization of Vietnam
My Journey My Views . I Was Stunned To See The Hoa Lo Prison As I Came To Know About The Atrocities Done By The Colonial Rulers To The People Who Were Demanding For Freedom.

Amazing great to see this prison. Very interesting place to visit and shows so much history on how the Vietnamese people were treated by French in the prison. There is a guilotine which the French used. There a section on the American War Prisoners from the Vietnam War.
Lots of propaganda . I loved going here. Really great. There is so much propaganda here. You experience the different opinions of the different countries. It's great. Really injured the information

Very moving visit. There is a lot of history here starting with this being a pottery village. The French moved the villagers and opened a very harsh prison. Later the Vietnamese used it to detain Americans and it was called the Hanoi Hilton. John McCain was a prisoner here for years.
Awesome experience . We really enjoyed this attraction. Seeing the conditions that prisoners were kept in. The history of the prison. Lots of pictures and other points of interest to look at.

Vietnam vietnam vietnam!. This prison museum is open my eyes about Vietnam before, a
a national hero , a country after more painful still stood up and developed after the war,still robust. Vietnam, you're stronger country.
Interesting site. Worth a visit but quite small you not too much to see. Fills in about an hour no more. Small gift shop , not much to buy. Toilets on site.

Sobering but definitely worth doing . I initially wasn't keen to visit as I'm not that into history and thought I'd be bored. But I was fascinated with the information I learned at the Hoa La Prison. It's definitely worth the 30,000vnd ($1.50) and I would certainly recommend it. Came away having learned a lot.

Both fascinating and heartbreaking . It's difficult to say I enjoyed this but it is incredibly fascinating, especially given it's very recent history.
Seeing the way people were treated was a shock to the system and it is difficult not to be moved by that.
The death chamber and the guillotine were hard hitting.
A must see.

Well worth a visit. We decided to go to the Hoa Lo Prison as our first activity when we arrived in Hanoi and it set the bar very high. For the entrance fee of 30,000 Dong (around £1), it was a thoroughly interesting and sobering experience. It focused greatly of the revolutionists during the French colonialism in Vietnam and we were able to read many first hand experiences from such a difficult time. Everything was Vietnamese, English and French which allowed us to experience the museum fully unlike others we have visited. Its a real must see when visiting Hanoi

Fills time. It is an interesting visit but we saw S21 and it was a lot more harrowing. This prison is a lot smaller but also considerably cheaper. An entertaining factor comes from the very one sided view within the prison.

An insight to Hanoi's past. You don't visit prisons for a fun experience, but if you want to understand a little of Vietnam's history then Hoa Lo prison is worth walking through. A few different eras of the country's complex past are covered, one while under French colonisation, another during the American bombing of Hanoi in the 1960s. The room with the guillotine was particularly sobering.

So real, so creepy. Visited prison with a Vietnamese friend who I met on facebook long ago. Everything there in the prison was so real, so alive and so creepy. I didn't remember much about the history but I could feel how Vietnamese people were suffering from wars. A good place to understand Vietnamese culture

Fascinating perspective on the history of the area. We really enjoyed our visit to the prison and learned a lot about it's history. There was some information placed around the prison but we left with many questions and not really understanding the context of the prison. Worth a visit but read up on the history of Vietnam if you want to understand the significance of what happened here.

Short & Easy Cultural Experience . A great stop for someone who wants to get a little more history in without spending hours in a museum. Some tough images but overall a very interesting supplement to other Vietnam War sites, particularly as the prison was built by the French and then later used for American POW (including John McCain).
Very interesting . Very interesting to explore the museum and get a feel for how they treated political opponents. Would recommend to spend an hour here.

Disappointing.. Not really worth the effort except to say you been to the Hanoi Hilton. Very little info about the servicemen imprisoned here during the Vietnamese War. Most exhibits relate to the French colonial political prisoners.

A somber and sobering must-see. This is an important, slightly underrated Hanoi sight (admittedly, we were there in low season). It's part of the old prison compkex for political prisoners and American pilots shot down over Hanoi and other cities. You can walk the narrow halls and gaze at the exhibits, among which a French guillotine and the immaculately preserved uniform of Airman and later presidential candidate John McCain, who was also shot down over Hanoi. Even more impressive, and eerie, are the many life-size puppets of prisoners chained to their bunks and on death row. Signposts are of course patriotic along orthodox communist lines. A sobering and somber experience, visiting this place, but it brings the struggle and pain of the Vietnamese resistance and wars real close.

Very Interesting. Very informative. Having to be able to see the actual prison which the vietnamese suffered under the french rule gave you a feeling of how strong the early vietnamese were. Good place to vivit for just a 30,000 dong ticket.
Worth a cidit. We visited the Hoa Lo prison after the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and liked it. It was very interesting and quite confronting. Was worth the visit and would go back.
Totally a must!. If you are not sure what to explore, explore this! Its unbelievable how the Vietnams have unstoppable power of will. My favourite museum, no doubt!
Enjoyed . I'm not the type of person to enjoy museums but this prison was excellent way to get a hint about vietnam's history. You need more than an hour to explore it, we ran out of time.

Daunting. I found this quite interesting and sad. I have trouble grasping how some people can be so cruel and in humane. The government have set it up very well to depict how the prisoners were treated. Definitely worth a visit.
A moving experience . This is only one of the museums that you need to visit while your in Hanoi! It was inexpensive to go in and interesting.John McCain stayed here.

Sobering. Did this tour with the Hanoi Street kids, really great insight into this infamous place. The history of the prison and its past are well presented, the "American" section very one sided but its very evident how everyone locked up here suffered terribly.

Painful sad memory to remember. When you stepped into this old prison, you will have a goose bums and fears came instantly. It was really sad to know what was happening in the past at the era of Vietnam

Hanoi Hilton: Not Just About the Vietnam War. This is a self-guided tour of what Americans typically call the Hanoi Hilton, but the site is not just about the American involvement in Vietnam. In fact, just about all of the early part of the tour is about the abuse and mistreatment of the Vietnamese people at their own hands, and the site pulls no punches about the mistreatment. Then you will come to the portion of the site dedicated to the American prisoners and the exhibits make it seem as though the American visitors were treated very well, including photos showing them playing ping pong and displaying all the good food they were given by their benevolent Vietnamese captors.

Great place for history story. When i walk into the Prison museum-Hoa Lo prison, i am so scare first but i can't get over my thinking want to learn more about the war, how much Vietnamese people had to pay for the peace. After the trip i find out my answer. Great place.

Interesting museum. We found it a very interesting place to visit. The museum does seem a little one sided in terms of the information provided but interesting nevertheless. Cheap entry price of 40 000 VND per person. Takes about an hour to go through as it is pretty small

Well worth a visit . A story to be told. It is told from the Vietnamese poit of view, and I believe they have the right to put their side forward. The prison is very interesting and there are even some dated ( yet functional) audio systems to give one an English description of events. Thoroughly enjoyed. Insightful and thought provoking.

Spooktacular- a well worth visit . The museum features a few scary life-like models that you should watch out for if you are easily frightened. They are placed in dramatic lighting in a few cells to demonstrate how the prisoners were once kept. They do not provide warnings for when the models are coming up so be aware. They aren't gruesome or anything- they are just quite life like and I got spooked.Learnt a lot. An important part of the history of the city which is worth checking out. It's not that large but has a lot of info and artefacts. There is a student discount making it 15000 VND for one. Spent around 40 minutes inside but didn't really read everything because we were hot. But there are fans/ aircons in some rooms so don't worry.
Worth a visit. Interesting museum, well worth a visit. The entrance fee is just 30 000 vnd for adults, 15 000 vnd for students. Open 8-17 even though tripadvisor says otherwise
Pretty basic . It was good to see the prison. However I think it was simple in nature. Not a ton to see. Good things to read on the walls. Overall worth visiting but do not expect too much.

Interesting. Was a little hard to find but got there eventually by foot. Small prison and interesting how they had the models of the prisoners in some of the cells to look realistic a little creepy but did give you a better idea.

Impressive and very heavy emotions here . Good to see the history of vietnam and this prison. So many bad things happened here. Good to see and learn about the history of this prison. Worth a visit. I would go there Agian.

Interesting historical museum. But I'm not really that keen on visiting prisons even if they have a lot to say about the negatives of colonialism and ill-considered American wars "to protect democracy". But considering how the Vietnam wars are fading from memory, it is good to be reminded of our shared histories.

If you do one thing in Hanoi. Pretty stiring, the Vietnamese are strong people ! Its hit in there so bring some water. No need to buy the guide, the same information is written on the walls in each room
A slice of History. Well organised and easy to find, allow 1-2 hours to look at all the exhibits and read all the commentary. It's a little sombre, but really interesting. A must do!
Interesting place . We visited here on the advice of our hotel. Definitely worth the visit. It gives you a great insight into the kind of life lived by the prisoners.

Surprising. A different way to spend an afternoon. An interesting insight into the nations politics prior to the American War. When the country was under the control of The French and Japanese. It expands a little on the rise of the communist party detailed at the Ho Chi Minh Museum
Interesting Museum. Museum is an excellent place to visit. Showcases how prisoners of war were treated, imprisoned and executed. Can be done without a guide. Worth the trip. Admission fee is cheap.

Great lesson on Vietnam's struggle for independence. Every country struggled to gain their independence and freedom. Be it the United States, South Africa or Vietnam. The same struggle happens. The French built the prison to house the Vietnamese and later the Vietnamese used it to hold US prisoners of war. Great visit.

Morning visit to prison. Interesting museum of the history of the prison. Its great to get there early so you easily read the description of the exhibits and watch the videos. You leave with a sense of wonder of what it would have been like for the prisoners. Especially in the heat of summer with walls painted with tar.

Great excursion. Our visit to the prison will be one of the most memorable excursions that we did during our trip to Hanoi. It is rich is history and quite well compiled. Rich in history, it definitely gives you a sense of the brutality that occurred. They charge 30,000 vdn for entry which we thought to be a very good price. They offer an information booklet for an additional 20,000 vdn which we purchased but recommend not bothering with it as it is really just the exact same information and photos that are displayed inside.

Amazing history in the clean and well kept attraction. We were impressed with the amount of history contained within the prison walls. We had no problem going without a guide and enjoyed it fully. Very clean and well kept.

Worth a look. You have to see Hoa Lo to give you some background to the struggles undertaken by the Vietnamese under French Colonial rule. Minimal US historical info in comparison and a little one sided.

Very interesting. Very interesting to learn about the history of this place. Be open minded. Perhaps not the most engaging place for young children as it is a lot of reading, but nether less we really enjoyed our visit.

Thought provoking . The conditions which the prisoners were kept in were horrendous and our group found it very thought provoking . It was a very informative tour and we learned a lot during our visit.
Interesting. Very thought provoking - interesting to see the history - the guide was very informative - I believe commonly known as the Hanoi Hilton

Excellent and informative. I cannot believe this site is not any of the internet sites I saw. I would have loved to have had a guide but it was still informative. Its clean, well set out and creatively done. Well worth the visit.

Interesting experience. . Worth a visit if you are bored of walking the streets of old quarters. More interesting than the army museum.
Spent about 1 hour here.

Small and not very engaging, especially when you have small children. Most of the old prison is gone, some parts are left, curates museum style, but looks like it can do with a face lift and more digital interface- the story is told through life size clay figurines and photographs with caption. Overall it's worth an hour at max, but place is too small ( as it remains) but the story is too large, and not being told too well. I have seen the Holocaust museum in Warsaw, not a real prison, but the story is told well, this can be at that level! But not yet.
A true gem. This place is a must go if you're visiting hanoi. With its actual infrastructure in place and it's history from the vietnam war, there's a lot to know about!
Travel. OMG to see inside of what is left of this prison is humbling. The conditions that the prisoners endured were horrendous. Well worth a visit

Thought provoking. Well worth a visit. Spent about an hour and a half here learning more about Vietnamese imprisonment. Includes - but not limited to - the Vietnam war.Some of the early stuff was pretty sordid - as you might expect. The Vietnam war material makes it sound like the American prisoners we treated fairly (even well treated). Would be interesting to hear more about it from an American perspective - but guess this is not the place for that!Very hot inside - limited fans/air con. But worth making the effort.
Well presented. The route of the exhibition is very clear, it won't make you confused about the time line, quality present, very good to know more about the history of Vietnam
Interesting. Very good, well preserved but brief. More displays in English would be good. Bit difficult to find but worth it if you're a history buff.

Don't waste your time. You can spend about 20 minutes in this museum and see it all. The place is tiny. A few cells and some small descriptions written in awful English. Highlight was a giant guillotines. The place is stuffed to the brim with typical communist revolutionary propaganda. Would not recommend. We paid 30VND a person.
Interesting. Worth your time if you are willing to see Vietnamese history from a different perspective. Definitely recommend taking the time to visit this place.

The infamous Hanoi Hilton, worth a visit. Centrally located, not far from The Old Quarter, this place is worth one visit. It isn't worth two, as I discovered a couple of weeks ago.The prison had a sordid history long before John McCain crashed his plane into a nearby lake and, in fact, he and the other US POW's are not the focus of the place. Unspeakable horrors went on here and clearly the Americans got off lightly in comparison.I've heard and read complaints from mostly fellow Yanks that the narrative here is one-sided and not what they learned here in the US about the war. Umm, what do you expect? History is written by the victors and this is their country. Get over it.The exhibits and cells etc are a bit bleak but I was glad of that actually, because shouldn't prisons evoke that? The memorial garden in the center is quite lovely, with beautiful sculptures and etchings and you can cool down with soft drinks and purchase inexpensive souvenirs too of course. I returned a second time but there really isn't much point. One visit is interesting and worthwhile but two isn't.
Very good for the kids to get a perspective of the wars in Vietnam.. Good experience for me and the family to get the Vietnam perspective of the wars and conflicts in Vietnam.

A look back at history!. Take a tour of the Hanoi Hilton...as this former prison was formerly called. Many American prisoners including Sen. John McCain spent torturing years here until VietCong rule. A harrowing place to look at what it may have been...a cold, dank place to visit.

Worth a visit.. Interesting place to visit if you have 1-2hrs to spare in Hanoi. Be prepared to know a bit of history before visiting this place, otherwise it will just be a session spent looking at prison cells, historical models about the war. Information and audio is provided which gives a bit of context on the displays. You can easily spend at least an hour in this site.

Very informative and interesting. I recommend visiting the prison when in Hanoi, it was very interesting and I learnt a lot more detail about the war and the conditions. You can go into cells and there are a lot of artefacts to see and read about. We walked there from the main city area, it only took us about 20 minutes

Lots of information, really interesting. Sometimes in SE Asia you visit attractions that have the potential to be interesting but are let down through a lack of information. Not this place! Great information, great exhibitions, cheap to enter, highly recommended.

A real slice of history. We spent a good couple of hours going round this prison. Many will only be aware of it in it's incarnation as the 'Hanoi Hilton' during the Vietnam/American war. It has actually been a prison for much longer. Seeing the conditions people were kept in over the centuries was fascinating. The visit is well laid out and documented with excellent exhibits. They have lots of exhibits from the Vietnam/American war and the commentary is interesting, albeit reading slightly like propaganda. All together this rising is well worth a visit.

Worth Seeing!. Entrance was only a few dollars and it was a really cool experience exploring this old prison. There is a lot of history to read on the walls and memorabilia to be seen. The pictures showing how well they treated the American prisoners is very interesting. After doing some research and reading John McCains autobiography on his experience here, it was at great conflict with the way the prison decided to present the same story. Not going to say much more here, but do your own research and explore both sides of the story for yourself! Worth checking out though!
Good history. A small place of interest that depicted history. Very interesting and informative. Not recommended for small children as they can be scared by the live size statues.
Sobering. Great way to learn about Vietnam and the struggles the country has endured. Now we can say we went to prison in Vietnam

Eye opening as a Westerner.. Some photographic evidence and journaling provides an insight into how respectably the Vietnamese treated the Americans who were shot down when they tried to bomb this city. A very different take on what we, as Westerners are taught about the Viet people. Was happy to visit and see it all.

Small but intersting.. We paid 40 000VND per person, looked into a few dark cells, read a bit of history. Mainly telling how the french treated them. Had the feeling it was mostly propaganda, still it was horrid to be incarcerated there.

Humbling Hoa. Be sure to visit this famous prison which is also known as the Hanoi Hilton. So dubbed by the US pilots who were shot down over Hanoi during the Vietnam War. There's only a small section of the jail left but it's been well preserved and presented. Some interesting exhibits including Senator John McClain's pilot suit. The video presentation is also illuminating of the Vietnamese take on the war.

A very interesting morning !. I found this museum very interesting. The displays & photos help you understand a little more about Vietnams history. Of course it is one sided as it is from the Vietnamese perspective, but it is still worth the visit. We caught a cyclo from the old quarter to the prison as it was raining & then walked back along the lake.

Interesting place to visit. We found it a very interesting place to visit. Eerie and creepy on parts particularly the cells where prisoners were kept awaiting execution. The museum does seem a little one sided in terms of the information provided but interesting nevertheless. It probably takes less than 1 hour to explore in full with a cheap entry price of 30 000 VND per person. A guidebook is available for 20 000 with supplemental information.

Interesting but one sided. Only a part of the prison is still up, the rest has been destroyed to build other buildings. A few expositions and mainly an interesting version of historical facts, which are different than what we know outside of Vietnam. Takes about an hour to go through as it is pretty small.

Worth a look. This is a good museum but I didn't find it as interesting as other museums I've been to recently, such as the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh. We spent about 1-1.5 hours here which was enough to do it justice. Some of the exhibits are only in French and Vietnamese.
Interesting Take on the "American" War. A good place to catch up on some of the history of the fight against the colonial French and where Senator John McCain was kept as a POW.

Typical French 19th C prison, added interest as US prisoners were held here.. The French built prisons like this at home and in all their colonies. There is only part of one wing of the large original complex remaining (see scale mode) but it has been used to good effect with realistic representations of the conditions in which prisoners were held.In the condemned cell area was a guillotine, we also saw one in Saigon.Captured US pilots were held here and called it the "Hanoi Hilton"

Interesting Experience. We visited the Hoa Lo Prison to get some history on Vietnam. It was an interesting experience. Most of the original buildings are gone but the museum bit has good displays and exhibits. There is a vast contrast in the way the information is presented with quite a pro-Vietnamese bias. The section on the Vietnamese struggle against the French presents the French as barbaric whereas in the section on the Vietnam War, it presents the Vietnamese as very civilised towards their American prisoners. If you take some of this "history" with a grain of salt, it is an interesting experience to see this style of museum. I would recommend checking it out if you have a day or two in Hanoi and are looking for things to do.

Cheap time killer. Spent just over an hour here. It was an inexpensive way to kill time. Interesting archival pictures and documents if that's your thing. Also good to get out of the sun and into the shade at around midday!

View from the other side.. Well worth the visit, but early morning visit recommended because of the heat. Very interesting looking at the harsh reality of war through someone else's eyes. A lot of propaganda only enforces the uncomfortable feeling you will get from this old prison. Worth the visit while in Hanoi.

Quite interesting. Quite an interesting history. Of course the story is very much told from the Vietnamese revolutionary perspective. Most of the old complex is gone but there's enough there to give you an idea of what it was like
History lesson learned!. Very interesting to get the real perspective of the Vietnam War. I was so impressed of how terrible the prisoners were treated. Worth a visit! Definitely recommend to pop in!

Interesting.. Prison was demolished, but museum stands in the guard shack. No brochure or guide to help with the tour. Self-guided. Most of the museum is the history of the prison when the French housed Vietnamese prisoners. Smaller part is when the American POWs were imprisoned there. Stark contrast in the portrayals. Very interesting. John McCain's flight suit is displayed there. Made me appreciate the US Vietnam War Veterans even more.

Filled with Communist Propaganda. Nicknamed "Hanoi Hilton", named by the US pilots detained here during the Vietnam war. There are rich information related to how prisoners were treated here. However I can't help to observe bias all the way throughout the visit, there is only one message the exhibition tried to convey: French Imperialists maltreated or even tortured Vietnamese Communist heroes, but Vietnamese Communist in return treated the US Pilots really well... But still, apart from that, I think the Hoa Lo Prison worths paying a visit, especially for history lovers. Please remember there is a half-price discount for students for purchasing entrance tickets! Showing student cards of your own countries will do, I showed my Hong Kong student card and was able to enter with only 15,000 VND.

Amazing hour spent here. Costs 30,000 DNG for entry each and another 20,000 for an english guide, we bought this but you dont need it as everything in the guide is displayed inside the prison in english anyway! definitely recommend you visit, i learnt so much here

Intriguing and educational. This is well worth an hour's visit and only costs 30,000 Dong per ticket, just under a pound. Only a small part of the original prison built by the French is on display, but there are exhibits and documentaries in English which cover the Vietnam War and the treatment of the American prisoners kept there. Thought provoking.

Rich in information. I've been to places like the coconut prison at phu quoc, as well as the war memorial museum at Ho Chinh Minh City, and I must say this prison is a nice touch towards the addition information that I've gotten for the first two places.
