Not as big as I've expected, but I figured it's one of the places u MUST visit in Hanoi
Hoa Lo Prison. This was a very good and moving experience which is worth a visitThought the art was very graphic and told a very good outcome of it all

'Hilton Hotel'. I have one day free day in Hanoi and decide to visit the Hoa Lo prison. Look on the map it is not too far so we take a walk there. It is nice on the way as we go through the French Quarter. The small prion shocked us with the way French treat Vietnamese soldier and how Vietnamese treat American pilot. We had 02 hours there. A big lesson for me after all.

Captivating. I arrived with thoughts and left with so many more. This is a place that captivates you in many ways and makes you very philosophical as you come to realise the strength of people in such adverse conditions. From planning my trip and knowing I would be in Hanoi I felt compelled to visit and I am very pleased I did as I have a greater sense of understanding.

Worth a Visit in Hanoi. Particularly poignant for those who lived through the Vietnam War although materials presented portray a different perspective of conditions that we have come to know and believe from our American captives. Was also interesting to see Vietnam's history though the French reign. I believe we spent about an hour, maybe less which was sufficient time.
Great Museum. This prison is a must to do in Hanoi. It will give you a different prospective on Vietnam recent history! Well preserved and organised

Day out. Good little day out for some learning and history!! Really enjoyed it... Says in Linley planet 15vnd but it's actually 30vnd, only 15vnd if your a pupil or student with id... But defo worth the trip if you like history!!

Taste of war prisoners . Only a small portion of the prison is retained. There are explanations on the wall in English. The statues of the prisoners is life-like and can cause one to experience the pain they experience.

Sobering . Went and toured. Really cheap attraction- worth it. Bring a student card if you have one you get half off admission.
Small but succinct

Not the nicest place to visit, but a place you must visit. Takes about an hour to walk through this old Prison. It's quite moving walking through the old rooms and prison cells. Worth while doing this in Hanoi and the War Museum in HCMC to compare the two. You will leave this place with a different view on the world.

A view into the history of Vietnam. A visit to Hanoi isn't complete without catching a glimpse of the history of north Vietnam. Hoa Lo Prison is a landmark that allows visitors to understand Vietnam during the time of French occupation and the time of the Vietnam War. With hundreds of pictures, videos and stories, the museum is a memorial to the men and women who were imprisoned there throughout the prison's history. And don't forget to grab a guidebook when you buy your ticket. If nothing else, it's a great souvenir that gives a little more detail about the site.
Small but interesting. Most of it has gone bit still worth a visit to understand about some of the history of the city and country, enjoyed it

An hour well spent! . Firstly the good things about the museum: it's inexpensive, the signage is excellent, and the exhibits are quite good, it's very clean and well ventilated with lots of fans and air-conditioning where possible. It's mostly indoors, so good for a hot summer day. The not-so-good things: it's (obviously) very biased towards Vietnamese politics so read the signs with a liberal dose of salt, it's small and will take only an hour at most to stroll around and see everything (but that might be a good thing for some people), the shop is in US$ and ridiculously overpriced. Bizarrely they were selling copies of "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas". Go figure. The museum is only part of the old prison, which was demolished to build the hotel next door (I heard it was once the Hanoi Hilton, ironically). Overall it was a great little museum, and I'd recommend anyone with even a passing interest in Asian politics and history, or military history, to go. Worth the 30k dong entry.
Very confronting part of history. Although it is confronting I would recommend a visit. Take about 1-2 hours to walk through the prison. Very solemn place.
Worthwhile. Nice visit, takes around an hour or so. Good inside in to how the prison looked and enjoyed the visit. Layout very good.

War-Why. This is a sobering place. Hanoi Hilton. Well worth the time to go through. Conditions and brutality of war. People that send our young men and women to war should see this and the war museum in Saigon

Must-Visit Place. This is one of the historical place in Hanoi. You should really visit this place. This is the real prison back in the days, and now it becomes museum with lots lots lots to see. The museum will tell you the long story from vietnam war to date. Worth visiting.

Interesting but not the best. It a small museum with not that much info on french colonialism and the museum seemed to be very centred on presenting a version of history in which the vietnamese were super nice to american prisonners detained there, whereas the french were horrible to the vietnamese detained there.
Makes you think!. This was a sombre experience viewing the displays and photography of a past detention centre. good to understand just what this country has been through.

The sorrow of the war. A very interesting place to visit in Hanoi center, just few minutes walking from Hoan Kiem lake. This historical relic make Hanoi more charming and different to the other capital city in asia.

Affecting place. Also known as the Hanoi Hilton, this is where captured American airmen were held during the Vietnam war (known as the US war here). But also, you will learn how the prison was built by the French and used to imprison Vietnamese people during their occupation. There is a guillotine, and a death row, women's section and the cells are suitably unpleasant to view.There is a sense of oppression in the place, which I suppose is entirely natural. They have what purports to be John McCain's flying suit on display there. It was nice to get out into the sunshine.....

Very interesting.. I had heard of the movie "The Hanoi Hilton" but not seen it. The remains of the prison in Hanoi is a very interesting look at how prisoners were treated in the past. It's quite easy to find and you can view the cells with the obligatory mannequins inside. The exhibits are good and I found the propaganda about American pilot prisoners a little amusing but overall Hoa Lo Prison is certainly a place to visit whilst in Hanoi, especially if you want to get an idea about the French occupation of Indo-China.

Fascinating history lesson. Very interesting to get the perspective of the Vietnamese conflicts from a different perspective & to see the conditions that they were subjected to. I wish I had more time to read & study everything so allow a couple of hours as a minimum if you really want to take it all in

The Prison that conveys Vietnam history. People of Vietnam has fought and defended their land from several occupying countries. This has brought in prisoner of wars and you could see how they were jailed in those days. Very interesting is the Hanoi Hilton and the amazing escape route of one jailbird.

Very interesting. This was really interesting! We walked here from our hotel in the old quarter and really enjoyed the walk! It was so cheap to get in and it was interesting to see the different parts of the prison from the French rule to when the Vietnamese regained control! Some good stories and with a visit!

Interesting propaganda. There is not a lot of narrative in English, a few snippets of what's what. Worth a visit though to see how bad the French treated their political prisoners and then how well the Vietnamese treated American POWs!!!! Make of it what you will.
Eye Opener. A real eye opener to where the Vietnamese prisoners where kept. Abit gloomy but humbling experience. Definitely recommend popping in!
A bit unnerving. Very interesting place but not for the faint hearted. It looks so real it made me ashamed to be French!
Good to see. More focused on the French than Americans, but really interesting to see, and the old videos were especially enlightening

A lot of history. This place is amazing, the perfect place to visit in the first travel to vietnam since you can learn about history. It has a lot of pictures where they describe everything about the 100 years that the prision is being there

Startling. Our family of 5 visited Hoa Lo Prison in May 2016. Some of the content is a bit startling for children so preview some of the rooms before you allow them to enter. We also visited the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City and found some overlap between the content. Worth a visit as the admission is only 30,000 dong and it provides you with some perspective regarding the difficulties the Vietnamese people have had to endure during war.
Sinister!. Old French prison, also used for American pow's. High level of propaganda, worth one hour visit. Have a look at the photos and movies

OK but nothing special. We used the experience of the local Hanoi Kids guides to escort us around Hanoi and their knowledge was superb. If we didn't have them as our guide, it would have been a tour that we would just have wandered around without knowing the facts and figures and much of the information would have been unavailable to us. They made the trip enjoyable and informative.

Macabre . This is well worth a visit to scratch the surface and appreciate what life was like for political prisoners under French colonial rule due the 19th and early 20th century. Visit the cells of the condemned prisoners, see the guillotine used in the execution of prisoners and the sewer and man hole of the only successful escape in 1945 (Shawshank Redemption for real) by 5 political prisoners. There is also a brief history on the Vietnam war and US prisoners of war.

Disqueiting. It is not a place if you want your Spirits uplifted. But well worth a visit. It is without reservation, that I state, the Vietnamese People have endured great hardship at the hands of many, for way too long. Go and feel and learn about the Vietnamese extraordinary strength and perseverance from the hands of others.

Provides Perspective . The exhibits focus mainly on the French colonial period and help to educate the visitor of the atrocities the Vietnamese suffered during colonial rule. I appreciated that so much of the exhibits were devoted to this period and thought it telling that only one room was devoted to the American War. Great place to go - a must see. Would not recommend brining young children.

There is Always another Story to Tell. I believe this was originally built by the French but of course became the famous Hanoi Hilton. According to the information provided here no one was mistreated and prisoners played ping pong and were well fed. The flight suit of Sen John McCain is here but I'm not sure he has the same story to tell.

Not much to see. On the plus side it's only 30,000vmd to get in but you can get through the whole prison easily under an hour. Something nice to do if you've got some time to kill but I wouldn't plan your day around it. Whilst the history is fascinating the prison does not do the complex story justice.

Mixed feelings!. No doubt it is a must to see while in Hanoi, wasn't super impressed by how they made the display.it is interesting for sure and makes you feel bad to imagine how those people were leaving for the time they had to spend in those holes.
Prison. What the French did to the people of Vietnam.And then it was the turn of the American s History never to be repeated.

Not what I expected. I was very disappointed in the "Hanoi Hilton prison. First of all it is a bunch of propaganda. I have read many books about the war and several have been about this prison, so know more than they probably thought most people knew. We weren't allowed upstairs where the prisons were kept, there were a couple of cells down where the people are allowed. It was insulting to me the pictures they show of prisoners playing volleyball and pool! I'm sure none of the pow's would remember that happening! I suppose it is worth your time just to say you have been there, just prepare yourself to be mad.

An ok place. This is an ok place to visit. Nothing compared to an Alcatraz visit. Not much information on what you're seeing and a lot of Vietnamese propaganda against the US. It's ok to check out but don't waste your time if you have limited him in Hanoi.

The jailhouse. This visit was okay, good to see if you have time but not a must. Gives a reasonable insight to what the prisoners endured , however I expected more detail about why he war actually started

Worth a cisut. This is an interesting place to visit and gives you a good grasp of life in the prison during the fight for independence from the French. It is filled with a lot of propaganda but none the less very interesting and for 30,000 dong it is worth a trip.
Really worth a visit. I fascinating visit showing the history of quite recent events. Air conditioning in some of the exhibiting rooms so could feel quite comfortable as you walked around.

Exaggerated propaganda! Worth a visit if little else to do! . Um ok where to start. It's cheap at 30 K Dong (just under a quid). There are 2 exhibits essentially. The period of French occupation and the Vietnam ("American War"). We whizzed through the French occupation period as this wasn't of huge interest to us and I have little knowledge of this chapter in Vietnamese history. The period covering the American War was interesting but is clearly written with political intent and amounted to propaganda!! Even a Brit could see this! The stats just didn't add up. The museum wants to paint a picture that the incarcerated American pilots were well looked after compared with Vietnamese population of the time and that the war was totally unjust and the Vietnamese were victims. The legends on the photos stated that 'thousands of American war planes' were shot down and 'thousands of Americans' were imprisoned there. These stats are simply exaggerated and not correct!These criticisms aside it was an interesting visit and it's worth a visit when you've done everything else you wanted to in Hanoi.

Best museum in Hanoi, cheap entry and the information is great- possibly slightly bias though. Loved this museum the displays and information given were wonderful and insightful. Talks about the French occupation as well as when it was used during the Vietnam war. Big must do for history lovers and extremely interesting for those who don't know much.

If theses wall could talk. Unfortunately, about 2/3 of the original prison has been torn down to make way for a 5-star hotel, but what is left is greatly preserved. Fee to get in is 30,000 VND which is like $1.50 USD.Before entering, our guide was very good about saying "I know you are American and have your thoughts/beliefs, and with me being Vietnamese, mine are different so while we are inside I won't say much and let you read for yourself." That was very refreshing because he could have very well firehosed us with propaganda... though the prison did that well enough. Most of what is left is dedicated to how poorly the French treated the VIetnamese who were imprisoned there. There are quite a few artifacts and pictures. It was very interesting. Then there are two small rooms dedicated to the treatment of American pilots who were held there during the war. It was interesting, yet frustrating, to see the blatant propaganda of how well the American's were treated... to see the pictures of the "smiling, happy, Christmas celebrating soldiers." A very interesting take on history. It just makes me curious as to what do the VIetnamese really think?you will also see what they claim is John McCains flightsuit, boots, helmet and parachute. Seeing the cells only made me wonder how the prisoners endure living there for so many years. I highly recommend seeing this sight if in Hanoi!

Interesting but one sided. This was an interesting visit. Lots to see and well set out but feels very much like a lesson in propaganda.
Lots of bad things happened here there is no doubting that but do some research before and after going to read between the lines.

Fascinating Prison visit. I actually found this far more interesting than many tourist destinations! Loved the blatant propaganda--just a fascinating perspective. Allow about 90 minutes to check it out.

Great place to visit. It is what it says on the tin. It's a prison and for only £1 to get in, you couldn't ask for a lot more. Pay for a guide if you like but it's well laid out and signposted for you to make your way and most things are in English as well as a range of other languages. They do make it clear that they don't like the French very much! We wandered around for a couple of hours, there was an extra exhibition going on in the courtyard when we were there - which was interesting. Worth the trip to escape the hustle of Hanoi for a bit.

Definitely worth a visit despite historical inaccuracies. A worthwhile visit, and historically educational vis a vis the time when it was operated by the French. As an educational tool, they falsely claimed that American POW's were treated perfectly in subsequent times which is clear now nonsense. But worth the visit.
Great piece of history. This was a privilege to see. It is wonderful that the city has kept this as an education piece for both locals and visitors.

Worth a Visit. The prison is an interesting part of Vietnamese history. Although the whole prison no longer exists, a good portion of it still remains. The english descriptions throughout the various rooms are very good. If you enjoy history, or things that are generally a bit creepy, I would recommend visiting.
Interesting 2 hours. Visited Hoa Lo Prison in May, spent a couple of worth while hours wandering around. Only £1.50 entrance fee and small shop. Definitely worth a visit

Harrowing experience but worth the trip. But of a mission to find but worth the wait. This heart wrenching museum shows the appaling conditions the local population were kept in by their French colonial masters. As with many museums in Hanoi it is a very one sided perspective that the museum presents although it looks difficult to see how much sympathy the gaolers should be given.Only downside is a lack of extensive English translations but jail cells, shackles and images don't need much translating...
Impressive . Impressive prisonbuildings. You pas 30000 dong to get in. I stayed for little over an hour. Must see in Hanoi

Vietnam history. Hanoi had many nice sight to see and many historical place to visit. Hoa Lo prison had story to tell you about Vietnamese spirit in the war... not only the hurt and dark of war. It take 1 hour to visit all around this place
Interesting. We arrived shortly before closing time, so were a little rushed. However, we found this attraction well put together and quite informative.

Interesting but a guide would be nice. As I asked for a guide they gave me a little book for 20' dong, nice for take away but a guide could tell maybe so much more. All in all it was realy interesting and I would recommend it to people when you have some time in hanoi. With a guide there will be 5 stars

Behind the locked cells .. History awaits you. A must visit place if you love the history. They preserved most of the things from the past including men's cell, women cell , US soldiers cell and the torture rooms. It takes 2-3 hours for the complete trip but it is really worth.

Great short visit. This is a small museum and so you don't need to dedicate hours and hours to it. Really enjoyed reading about its history and seeing the photographs. The guillotine was a bonus as I've always wanted to see one in real life and this prison had one! Would recommend a visit as it was only around 30,000 VND for entry.

A Must See!. Explains the French colonization of Vietnam and then how the prison was used to hold captured American soldiers during the Vietnam war. They have Senator John McCain's uniform from when he was captured. Very informative.

Hanoi Hilton . A very sad and difficult place to visit. You really appreciate how the Vietnamese suffered. This is not about the Vietnam War and John McCain. There are two teeny rooms about that. Everything else is dedicated to the Vietnamese...as it should be.
Interesting outlook on Vietnam's wars. A good place to spend and hour or two in learning Vietnam's war history and the struggles of the Vietnamese people for independence.

Well worth a visit, highly recommended. We came here with our tour guide who was really helpful about explaining the history of the prison and some background around the french occupation of Vietnam and the subsequent war. The prison is only about one third of the size it once was as around two thirds of it is now an office block,but it's really well presented and informative. It was really interesting to read and hear the local story. At first I was slightly shocked to listen to our guide state how well the American POWs were treated during their imprisonment, and to see the displays of smiling US airmen playing basketball and preparing a Thanksgiving feast for visitors. This was at odds with the stories the airmen, particularly Senator John McCain, had told upon their release. It brought home to me how each side has its own stories and recollections and that there is no one history to be heard. I felt a great deal of sympathy for the Vietnamese people who suffered terribly during the war and how they are now building a vibrant and rich new Vietnam. This museum made me think - I can't imagine not being moved by a visit.

Eyeopener on Vietnam's war. Thought provoking site as I must say; visiting this place makes you understand the suffering of too many people and at the same time,the courage a others by graphic pictures and videos…. It's a MUST , glad I went.

Bit boring . Not much to say about this prison your. Pretty boring. Not much happening. Only takes about 20 minutes. Unless you read all the info which a lot of it is fairly full on. Not at lot happening here

Remark in the Vieatnamies history.. Hao Lo Prison is a well organized attraction for all visitors in Hanoi, who interest to know near history of Vietnam under the French Colonization and how does it affect to people's life. all parts of this prison open for visitors are so informative with audio guide, modules of political prissiness with inhuman punishments, dark room etc. It makes the real feel we are in a real dark prison in real life.

Very interesting and well designed museum, cheap entry. $1 (USD) entry for around a 90 minute attraction. Worth it to see the infamous Hanoi Hilton!Interesting history, all signs are in English and other languages. Sen. John McCain's flight suit is on display!Would recommend.
Fascinating. Make time to visit. Fascinating place with excellent displays and information. The prison has a very interesting history
Must to see. It's a must to see this prison if you are interested in Vietnamese history.Very clean and well-organised, cheap entrance fee.

The Hanoi Hilton as it was known during the American war!. Shocking to see how brutal the people were treated during the French occupation but I'm not so sure the depiction of what went on during the American (Vietnam) war is that unbiased!

Very interesting. My family and I went to this prison with our 2 guides from Hanoi Kids. The tour was interesting and I learned many stories. Lots of the people there before were shackled, but some of them were so thin that they were able to escape. I was also able to see the torture chambers. After visiting the prison, I realized how badly treated the people were. I wouldn't really recommend this for kids, but if you are interested in history like me, then give this a try.

Very interesting place. I had heard so much about this and I was glad I had the opportunity to see.. While traveling with Gate 1 travel on a 10 day tour of Vietnam, we had the opportunity to see what most would know as Hanoi Hilton. While only a small part of the prison remains because a large part has been torn down to make room for another building, it is still enough to get the feeling of what it must have been like for prisoners. I left respecting the sacrifices so many made.

Interesting. Only a two minute walk from our hotel so decided to have a look, glad we did as it gives an insight of what the prison was like during the war. Cheap enough for entry and the guide book and if you have an hour or so to spare give it a go, it adds to the experience and understanding of Vietnam

If you love war history. If youre the kind that love war history, this is the place for you! Showcase the time when french held captive of vietnamese political prisoners, & the time where vietnamese held captive of american b52 pilots. Its quite saddening to walk through it, read & know about how the prisoners were treated, you get a great deal of knowledge but its nice to keep ur mind open to the information provided though.

Sober reflections of history and perception.. This is an interesting place if your a history buff or student but I never really enjoy tours of prisons that much. I suppose thats not the point anyway but... the tour is well done although one must keep in mind that it is a museum that gives a biased perspective that may not reflect others perspectives... or actual experiences.
The Hanoi Hilton. Come see where many American pilots were held as POWs during the Vietnam War. You can also learn about its previous history as a French Colonial prison.

It's just a small museum but it reveals a lot on the Vietnamese.. Get to know a little bit about the Vietnamese during the war time. Somehow you will discover that Vietnamese are people with a wide warm heart. Never regret visiting this museum. Entrance fee: 30,000VND

interesting. A must do for anyone visiting Hanoi. Get the guide book at the very least. An interesting journey through the jail andthe conditions eexperienced by the Vietnamese political prisoners and the American pilots. Great to see a different perspective

Sobering. I'd like to think when I am visiting places like this that such excesses as in the past are not tolerated. This may not be entirely true but we now have ways to protest. The museum is mostly about the French period, with a special set of rooms dedicated to the 'American' war and in particular its pilots that were held, some for many years, in the Hanoi Hilton. Good to see things from the other side's perspective.
Very sobering . Outlines the struggle the country has faced over a century of occupation in its fight for independence. Very eye opening.

Reminder of the costs of colonialism. This museum documents the direct suppression of the nationalist and anti-colonist movements by the French. Most moving for me was: the Almond tree, the bark, leaves, twigs & fruit all used for remedies for a range of suffering; and the collection of charcoal & rocks which had been used to conduct lessons between incarcerated.The museum also documents the far gentler detention of US prisoners of war when Hoa Lo was colloquially known by the west as the 'Hanoi Hilton'.
Average. Not bad a place to visit but I prefer the war museum and cuchi tunnels in Ho Chi Minh which is bigger and has more information.
Great display, fantastic piece of history. very interesting to hear and see the history of this building and its horrors. Displays and facility are in good maintenance.

Nice slice of history. They've done this place up really nicely and you're able to get a feel for what went on there. It's not a huge place but it will take you at least an hour to see and read everything.

Worth of seeing, but expect to see things from Vietnamese point of view. Let me tell you right on the beginning that I love vietnamese people, culture and food. What I don't like is all kind of twisted information these people are served from their government. This prison is nice example of this. You'll see lot ofl propaganda, half truths and one-side views. It is still worth of going and seeing the big piece of Vietnam history.

Strong, shocking and touching experience!. If you are emotional person maybe you will feel too touched by the place. Well it is an old prison, you can see real cells where prisoners where kept until die. That prison was built by french army during the war and they arrested and left in there Vietnamese people that were part of the resistance. It is quit shocking see the conditions that people were living in there. It is very sad but very important part of the story of the country. There are a lot of material in English and many original stuffs from the war time. If you are in Hanoi you shouldn't miss it out.

Worth a visit. Within walking distance from both Hoan Kiem lake and the Womens museum is this prison museum. It gives you a closer look at how the colonial power of the french dealt with the communist freedomfighters of Hanoi and the rest of Vietnam. Now a small part remains of what once was the biggest prison in Indochina. Give it about an hour, tops.
Good . It's not the best museum. It's a little bit small but I think for the cheap price it's quite ok :) So it's a good visit for 1-2 hours

Independent trip at end of intrepid tour. An interesting place and a great way to learn some history about the struggle for independence the country has been through - from the very first French colonisation through to recent visits to and from US presidents. Displays pretty static and some audio equipment not functioning. Layout was a bit confusing and I think the videos shown upstairs should be seen early on the walk through - not at the end. They were very informative and set the scene for the walk through .

Sad History of Vietnam. Hoa Lo Prison has long sad history since French occupation in Vietnam. You can tour the jail complex and cells. The interior building has A/C so the visit can help you take a break from the outside humidity. The jail was used by French, Japanese then by North Vietnamese army to detain the US air forces during Vietnam war in 1967. There are pictures & propaganda videos of US air forces detainment during Vietnam war in one of the exhibits. Overall, I would put this visit as the last on the list. Too many sad stories in the prison exhibits.

Good short stop . We visited the prison for about an hour in the early afternoon. It had the standard mix of preserved and refurbished buildings and displays, and reading material. All materials were translated to English. Very interesting, and worth a visit.

Interesting other side of story. Was a good visit. Interesting history. Made a change to see the opposite perspective on events firstly with the French and then the US.Clearly a very hard place to be captive in but also served as the birthplace and school of the vietnamese communist party. 1 to 2 hours max to see it all.

You'll learn a lot about wars in Vietnam. Divided into 2 mains part : 1, how the French treated Vietnamese political prisoners and 2, how Hanoi was damaged during the Vietnam war. This is the place where you can have extra information about the French colonial time of Vietnam as well as the Vietnam war ( Vietnamese call it American war ).Should go with a guide to have insight stories of the wars. The guillotine is really impressive !
Interesting but not gripping.. Good place to learn about the history of Hanoi and its prisoners. It is from a Vietnamese perspective so expect a different point of view. Loved the guillotine.

Some interesting bits but not an essential visit. We visited this as part of generally wandering around the old quarter, there was some interesting bits to look at and learn about the resistance to French colonial rule. Not an essential stop but probably worth doing if you are nearby.

Very emotional. Lots of information not only about the Vietnam (they call it the "American" war) but lots about French occupation. Modern displays, photos, art.
We were easily able to walk to our hotel, the Charming II, 31 Hang Ga Str. from the museum and we ate street food the whole way and spent under $4 US dollar. Everywhere takes dollars.

History, with a pinch of salt.. I'm British, so I'm glad that we had barely any part to play in the atrocities that people endured in the time this prison was in function. The French and the Americans, on the other hand...It's good to visit and to read and learn what those poor prisoners went through, be it the Vietnamese in the French colonial era, and the American POWs who were also kept there during the Vietnamese war. Including John McCain, former runner for president, I believe.A pinch of salt with the propaganda videos played in the upstairs section, however.

Top attraction list. I was staying in Hanoi for 2 days and unfortunately it fell Sunday and Monday so some things weren't open. My visit to the prison cost 30,000 dong, the prison looks like it has had a face lift.....seemed more new so I was kind of disappointed. They had films playing and a lot of different things to see though which was interesting. For the price I would recommend to check it out :)
Reality of a sad history. Tough but a good learning experience. Explore all the rooms and watch the videos to understand the sorted past of the many warrs that this poor country has had to indure.
Hoa Lo Prison. We visited the Prison in March, and spent a few hours here reading and learning about a very sad part of Vietnam's history.

Interesting angle on a depressing place. It's not much fun to be in a place where so much suffering has taken place. What is interesting is that the prison is primarily presented, understandably enough, in terms of what Vietnamese prisoners of the French went through. The museum does cover the US prisoners who were held there, but it suggests they were well treated and shows pictures of them playing basketball, receiving gift packages from home, and so on. I'm not sure James Bond Stockdale or John McCain would agree with this version of events. A historically significant place nonetheless, and cheap to get in (50,000VND, which is about $2.25).
The Hanoi Hilton. Interesting place in Hanoi's history. It must have been grim place to be as a prisoner. The heat would have been unbearable.

Prison. Visiting Hoa Lo prison was interesting. It was setup nicely and it was definitely worth the visit. It really outlines how the French treated prisoners and the horrible conditions they lived in. Small section on US prisoners which is the main reason I visited. It is a bit depressing but well worth the visit. The flight suit was cool to see.
Piece of history. a quick tour (we did it in 30mns) to understand what happened in this prison - obviously this is the view from Vietnamese side...
Really interesting. Harsh reality check and very very interesting. Must see! I like how they have made fake people to illustrate exactly how people would be held. Would highly recommend!

On holiday from New Zealand. We visited the Prison mainly from curiosity as our Uncle had fought for NZ in the Vietnam war. The display is excellent and well done although somewhat biased towards the North Vietnam point of view, still well worth a look.

Not for me . It's tiny and not much there is actually from the prison. Lots of modifications. Also the information is poorly written in English and sometimes did not make sense. I have been to many prisons preserved a lot better.

Worth a look. Well kept and easy to navigate tour. You do get reasonable feel for the conditions as a prisoner, but it's a shame that a large portion of the prison no longer exists. Nice touch to have all of the models in situ . The commentaries are a little biased, but then Hoa Lo was used for political prisoners and POWs. Use of artefacts and video is good?
Informative museum. Hard to believe how the people had to suffer during the war time if we do not go to this museum. The guillotine was a bit shock to me.

Get ready for Propaganda. Beautiful building / atrocities committed inside. It is a visit that is definitely worth it and it is striking to observe that only one side of the story is told: ie the French were so cruel when it was under their control, however when the Vietnamese were in charge they treated prisoners like guests, nicknaming the prison "Hilton Hotel". Yeah right. Just read John McCain story of what happened to him there and you will actually get the truth. It is very sad to witness such obvious propaganda and to think that young kids in Vietnam learn history that way even today..On a more practical subject do not hop on taxis waiting for you outside the prison, their meters go wild...

Informative tour about Vietnam history . The prison held POWs since the French colonization all the way to Vietnam war days. Very interesting stories and educational information about Vietnam. The prison feels slightly creepy and it really showcases how the prisoners might have felt.
Very interesting. Was interesting to learn about the history of this place, eery to see the tough conditions, John Mccain was held there!!

Harsh Reality. History is important to know, even if it is difficult to understand. This prison was built by the French imperialists to imprison political activists. The conditions by which the French maintained the prisoners and their cruelty towards them can only instill anger among those who see it today.Surprisingly though, during the American war, the Vietnamese treated the American POWs with respect. To see exactly how well the Americans were treated, you must see the prison museum.Visiting this museum is historically important.
A place of significant History. The prison has been converted to a museum which offer information to the war histories that the locals experienced.

Toured with Hanoi Kids, Worthwhile visit. We did 3 tours with Hanoi Kids and each one was different and enjoyable. Commenting on the prison, it was certainly more worthwhile going with a guide. Having th interpretations of young people made it quite special. At times we felt they were communicating the "party line", then every now and then we found them to personally comment, "well, we're really not sure it happened this way". A sobering experience, but not depressing. I would suggest about an hour here.

A Shocking Look into The French Colonial Prison. Def one for those interested in history. Although much of the prison has been demolished, a visit here provides visitors with a look into what terrible conditions north Vietnamese suffered during the French occupied years. The conditions and tools used to execute prisoners such as the guillotine makes one wonder how humanity can stoop so low. 45 minutes in total will be enough. 40 Vietnam dong to enter.

Very interesting!. Entry fee is 30,000 dong (£1) and it was totally worth it. The exhibitions are really detailed but not too detailed that it becomes a bore to read. Life like figures of men in the prison gives it a real life dramatic aura. The tense music being played around the prison is a good touch. Overall would recommend anyone interested in the history of the colonial times and during the American war to come here to learn about how revolutionaries and POWs were kept!
Hoa Lo Prison. is well worth seeing , located just behind Hanoi towers in the Hoan Kiem district, full of stories and history
Hoa Lo prison. nice place to go lots of history.only was 30,000 Dong each to go in which is about £1.The morning is the best to visit.not so hot.
Fascinating. Really well done museum, all well preserved and visually very powerful. Worth the entry fee (under £1!) best museum in Hanoi
Must Visit!. If youre just wandering off where to go to around hanoi, make this on your list. A good historic tour!

Worth a visit . We had a couple of hours to spare so went to look at Hoa Lo Prison and we where glad we did. It was quite interesting and put a bit of perspective on what it would have been like for the Vietnamese prisoners.

Very interesting museum. Hoa Lo Prison is an very interesting museum for everybody who want to know a little bit about Vietnam's not-so-glorious history. This prison is not so big, but as said before very interesting. Really recommend this museum. Good rainy day activity!
Interesting. It was worth going to for sure. All very one sided from the Vietnammese point of view, but what else would you expect?

Prison from another time. This prison is a sad reminder of how people suffered in the past and at times needlessly. It is educational for youth and for a lot of us that have never participated in war. Picture-taking is possible. Walking shoes are a must since there are many parts to the prison and the visit could be lengthy.
Very interesting. A small, but very interesting museum. Not as much on the American section as I would have liked to have seen. Well worth a visit.
Interesting place to visit. Was interesting to see how the prison was used and the conditions experienced by the Vietnamese from the French and how the Vietnamese treated the American POW.

Very interesting. Tour is reasonably priced and fit for everyone.
Scenes aren't too graphic and it's OK to bring kids in to explain the history.
Gives an interesting perspective to what occurred in the prison back in the war.

Great place to visit, mind the propaganda though. Very interesting place to see as it gives an insight into two important and hard times for Vietnam - French occupation and the Vietnam war.The only flaw is the laughable levels of propaganda, namely about the Vietnam war and the treatment US POWs received there. The museum insists they were treated like guests in a hotel - just make sure to have a look into the personal accounts of actual POWs (such as John McCain) to get a full circle perspective.Despite this, well worth seeing and good value.
Moving. Visited this historical place this morning it was a very moving experience. So sad to see the way these beautiful people were treated by the French and the Americans!!

Another Stark reminder WARS achieve nothing.. Most exhibits relate to the prison’s use up to the mid-1950s, focusing on the Vietnamese struggle for independence from France. A gruesome relic is the ominous French guillotine, used to behead Vietnamese revolutionaries. There are also displays focusing on the American pilots who were incarcerated at Hoa Lo during the American War.The vast prison complex was built by the French in 1896. Originally intended to house around 450 inmates, records indicate that by the 1930s there were close to 2000 prisoners. Hoa Lo was never a very successful prison, and hundreds escaped its walls over the years – many squeezing out through sewer grates.

Worth a visit. Found this place quite interesting. I was expecting more of the American section as this is squashed at the back in quite small rooms and I think a lot of the tourists that were there were there because of that war. The displays are well set out with interesting comments and written from a their perspective. Just be warned that the Taxi drivers opposite are out to rip you off - avoid red taxi's.

Interesting step back in time. Only part of the prison remains but if you want to see the history from the French occupation until the war with the US and the treatment of prisoners then this is a must see. Compared to other museums the propaganda element is scaled down. Well worth a visit.

Educational visit to the prison. This prison was a very eye opening experience. It was quite sad to read about what occurred in the past and see photos of it. It was quite educational and a great activity to do in Hanoi.

Interesting. The price for this museum is 30,000 VND which roughly translates to $2.00 Canadian, so the price was pretty good.Inside they have a lot of exhibits and displays about the history of the prison and the conditions of its inmates. It seems a lot of the prisoners were vietnamese revolutionaries who were captured by the French colonials. Very small prison cells with only shackles for the prisoners feet. Deplorable conditions for both female and male prisoners, it's pretty disgusting to think it was within use in the last century. There was even a guillotine for death row prisoners which is pretty medieval for the place and time! One thing I've noticed about all the museums we've visited it they're all very biased against any colonials "Americans, French etc." which is probably justly so, but I'm sure some of the inmates probably committed criminal acts. NOT to say the French had any business in Vietnam colonizing, as they really didn't have any rightAnyways overall it was a very interesting museum with lots of information that I had otherwise been ignorant about. Good English and Vietnamese translations on each display. I'd recommend visiting this museum if your short for time and want to see some of the best ones.

Fascinating. The kids enjoyed this although they were a little scared by the torture section and guillotine.
It's a fascinating, if somewhat ghoulish review of the prison's history.

Hanoi Hilton!!. This was an interesting place to visit, and i would suggest that all visitors to Hanoi check this place out.There is no doubt that there is some bias involved in what is being said, but this is true or every similar attraction across the globe.The place is quite big, and a good walk through can easily take over an hour.

Not much to see . After visiting the teoul sleung prison in Cambodia I was disappointed with hoa lo prison. Though walking through the museum you do understand the history, only a very small part of the prison is still there today. It's worth going if you have the time, but if not, you are not missing out on much.
Great history. Great to see history being preserved, they have lots of information and great exhibits. Worth going into and looking around.

The Best Museum in Hanoi. We really enjoyed this Museum coming from the USA. My dad was in the US Air Force during the Vietnam War, so it was really interesting to see the prison where our POWs were kept. Learning about the history of oppression of the Vietnamese people was important and learning about the significance of this prison to their own culture was eye opening as well. I think it was 20,000 VND or $1. Can't beat that price.

Well worth a visit. This was part of our tour and I am glad we went. Interesting the variety of prisoners kept there, the setup of the prison then and now. They have good displays nd information. Well worth a visit.
Hanoi. Great sad little place. Must visit will only take 45 mins to an hour. $2 aussie. Open til 5pm i think by memory.

Good little museum. We didn't want to pay extra for the guide book but think you need it as it's quite confusing trying to find the next room to explore. Not all the exhibits were in English which was a shame however an average museum to spend a couple of hours in

Very interesting . Went here during the day and it's bigger than I expected. Was interesting to see the history of the place during French and Vietnamese rule. Does get a little propagandaish at the end but still a great thing to see.

Good, but hot. The prison was very interesting and had English pre-recorded translations which made the trip more interesting. the only fault is there was (to my knowledge) only two rooms with aircon and all the other rooms had fans which were blowing the hot air around. Apart from that really good!

The Hanoi Hilton is not the whole story here. This museum is well presented with authentic and designed artifacts and displays. It tells the story of the prison from its initiation under the French to the time of the US war. Most of it focuses from its early days through to the war of independence from the French with a well presented portion near the end about the US pilots. The government rhetoric is kept to a minimum (although some of it was a bit much). Some of the photos are priceless as many of us remember so much of this it is really interesting to see actual photos from some of these times. Seeing John McCain's flight suit kind of brought it to reality. The cell block was eerie. So was the guillotine. If you go, spend some time reading and viewing much of the information presented. It will give you a better sense of the history during the colonial era and US war. Only part of the original Prison has been preserved but what has been is worth seeing.

A sobering insight. The Hoa Lo Prison is almost split into 2 sections. Firstly, the grim conditions preserved to show off the prison in French colonial times to hold the Vietnamese revolutionaries. Secondly, how the Americans were supposedly treated if captured as POW's in the Vietnam War. Extremely contrasting in their depiction here and it was a little lopsided. The conditions the Americans were subject to I highly doubt were as good as mentioned here.However, a very interesting prison/museum. Only costs a few dollars and is on the southern outskirts of the Old quarter. Certainly well worth visiting.

Wouldn't want to stay here. . This was a great place to visit, great reading about the history and watching the footage. It was really interesting going through and learning about and seeing something that I had heard about.Well worth the visit and at only 30,000vnd it value for money.

Hanoi Hilton. The Hoa Lo Prison is a site saturated in history. While the site focuses on the atrocities committed by the French towards Vietnamese prisoners during colonization and glosses over the same acts committed by the Vietnamese against the American prisoners incarcerated there in the 1960s and 1970s. Even with the less than objective perspectives presented, the prison is a must see for any visitor to Hanoi - just be aware of the serious nature of the attraction.

Interesting for adults who like history. From the Old Quarter we had to take a taxi to get here with our children. The prison was quite small but had some interesting displays, particularly the photos of the American POWs enjoying their Christmas celebrations. The kids found it quite dull and so our visit was brief but we found it worthwhile overall.
Worth a visit. Very interesting. A place of sad reflection. Though rather annoying to have some people joking and laughing and chatting on their phone :(

What an experience!. The Hoa Lo Prison is well worth a visit as it makes you realise what some people went through in their lifetime.So the French were horrible towards their Vietnamese prisoners and the Vietnamese were nice towards their American prisoners?

Need to See. The Prison now is only a very small area compared to its original size. There are tall modern buildings where most of the prison used to be.Apart from this its still sadly reminds you of the futility of war, the French influences and of course and the some 300 airmen who were shot down over Vietnam. You can spend several hours watching the videos, photos snd comments on display.

Excellent, Educational and well worth it. I went with a tour guide who took me through and explained objectively the history of the museum. It was definitely worth doing as I am interested in war history.
The Prison of Hanoi . It was the prison built by the French to keep the Vietnamese political prisoners . Later it was used by Vietnamese to house the American POW's .

Interesting history and an easy 1 hour visit. Nicely recreated experience and plenty of interesting information in English, Section on the French colonial period and Vietnamese resistance is good. The smaller section on the prison's use in the Vietnam war for captured American pilots is almost comical in its obvious propaganda. But an enjoyable 1 hour visit.
Saw on a tour. I enjoy seeing this sight. It only takes about 30 minutes to walk through. But very interesting. English translations are fantasic.
more good history. A must see for new comers to vietnam and if you are looking to pick up on Vietnam history. If the walls could talk...

An insight into Colonial Rule. Well worth the walk to find this museum. Shows the history of French rule and how justice was administered during the period.
The museum occupies only a portion of the original complex, but is an important reminder of the way Vietnamese citizens were treated.
Former POW prison - Hanoi Hilton. For those interested in history, this is a good stop. Many Prisoners of War had spent several years here. A solemn place to reflect on past wars.

Very interesting! Must see! . We visited here a few days ago and it was definitely a must see! The things you see are unforgettable. Treatment of prisoners back then was cruel and unbelievable to see. Would highly recommend a visit.

A Learning Experience!. I learned so much from my guide about the Vietnam war! I say John McCain's flight suit and the unbelievable conditions of the prison for both Americans and the French before us. An ABSOLUTE must do when in Hanoi.

Informative. This is an interesting stop. There is not much guidance through the prison, and it's a self-paced walk through the prison with placards on the walls. There is no guide or audio tour. I don't think we spent more than 30 minutes or so walking through the entire thing.

Not the Hanoi Hilton anymore. The prison where US Serviceman were held during the Vietnam War has a lot of Vietnamese history but there were only two or three small rooms which mentioned the US Serviceman. Also, the propaganda displayed in these two or three small rooms was crazy no matter what your political beliefs.

Educational. Interesting for museum buffs. Very cheap entrance fee for what you get. It's really sad to see how cruel humans can be to fellow human beings. I was amazed at how some of the Vietnamese prisoners were so resolute in their cause. See the actual prison cells of those who were on death row, and those who were kept in isolation. Don't miss the scale model of the prison. The museum is just a fraction of the what the museum is today.

All should tour this facility to remember the war.. An emotional place to visit. Impactful for me. Most revealing what the French did to the Vietnamese prisoners and how the Vietnamese treated the US airmen imprisoned there.

Short and sweet. A really interesting place to learn more about the conditions prisoners have suffered under - especially Vietnamese freedom fighters but to a lesser extent Americans later on. The museum is very accessible and takes about an hour to go through - it's cheap to get in to so can only be recommended.

Family Visit. Our family found our visit both interesting and educational. Our 14 year old son even got into it and he is hard to please when it comes to visiting museums.Yes, as others have noted there is a level of bias involved in the presentations. However. growing up in North America there was no shortage of propaganda from the other side. Definitely worth a visit and it certainly opens your eyes to some of the hardships the Vietnamese have had to endure from external forces.

Totally worth a visit. Fantastic . The entry fee is so cheep just 30000 dong or $5 AU and woeth every cent . We spent a good 1.5 hours just looking at all the displays . And can only imagine what went on here . And only a 4 block walk to the women's museum .

The reality of the Hanoi Hilton. This prison has a long and dark history and can serve to educate younger generations about the horrors of war. It is a tale of two wars. During the war for independence, the French colonial masters imprisoned the Vietnam people. During the the civil war the Communists imprisoned the Americans fighting to support the south Vietnamese. Strong on graphic depiction of the torture and horrors of imprisonment as well as ideological propaganda, this museum provides insight to a perspective foreigners would not otherwise understand.

If this is your thing you will be captivated.. Interesting perspective. Ensure you know a little background history before you visit this place.Very much a one sided exhibit.Plenty to see and read and do not be afraid ot venture a little of the guided path. If you see a tour group come though try and avoid them as their noise can ruin some of the ambience.

A great attraction. I didn't know what to expect visiting Hoa Lo Prison but it was wonderful. The signage was very informative and easy to read and the memorial artwork was spectacular. There are lots of great photographs following the modern history of Vietnam and the Vietnam Wars which gave a good overview of the country's political situation generally.

Brilliant insight to historic vietnamese life . What a reveal. Understand who really controlled the Vietnamese and the price they paid. It wasn't all about the US. Spend some time here and gain a real insight to why the lovely Vietnamese people had such fight to want to have and Hold their own country, rightly so!

One of my favourite sights in Hanoi. Found this such a raw experience, from the broken bottles in the tops of the prision walls to the stories of the prisioners throughout the display. A must visit for Hanoi.Do not purchase any souvenirs here as they are expensive, much cheaper on the street/markets.  We were lucky enough to purchase our tickets as a group of young teenage Hanoi school students who offer free tours to tourists happened to arrive. Such a great group of kids explained so much to us just to expand their learning on vietnam history and strengthen their english.

Interesting experience. The old parts of the prison that remain with the addition of the statues of the prisoners make for a very eerie, harrowing experience, especially the death row section.It was interesting to learn of the horrible conditions that both the men and women prisoners were kept under. There were a few original items used by prisoners, and then the original sections (as mentioned above) but other than that, there wasn't a whole lot to it.Entry was cheap along with the guide, so was a good activity to take up an hour or so.

History well captured. The prison is worth visiting. The history is well captured and the prison has a rich story to tell. Though its sad to realise how much blood waste shed, the pain that the convicts had to endure to realise the dream of being free. The place is well preserved.

Worth visiting to get a feel for Vietnam's history. This former prison is very interesting and well worth a visit. If gives you an insight to Vietnam's colonial history and sense of its struggle for independence from the time of French occupation to the war with the US. Expect to see the propaganda photos and films made by the government to depict the treatment of the US prisoners of war - but this is nothing new if you think of 'PR' materials we have seen from other countries at war. Our tour guide told us that he became aware of the bias in the materials presented around the US prisoners of war especially since John McCain visited the prison and gave his account of the living conditions at the prison during his time.The prison is a harrowing experience but go with an open mind you will learn a great deal.
Worth a visit. Gives a unique insight into the French and american atrocities and how forgiving the Vietnamese are.30000 dong per person

Interesting and sad. It is sad to read about what the French did in Vietnam, but it is also very interesting (to say the least) to see the bias in the way the story of the prison's history is told. The Vietnamese government is great, America and France evil, and the treatment of prisoners by the former, perfect.But it is worth a visit, especially considering the price, and if you go in prepared for the propaganda, you will emerge having learned a reasonable amount.
Historic propaganda. Moving when you see how much so many sacrificed. Room on US soldiers decorating tree, playing ball, raising chickens etc. Angered me but I realize that is just propaganda.

Hanoi Hilton. I think if you're American, French or Vietnamese this is a must see. For those interested in the prison's history during the French colonial era or the Vietnam war it is fairly informative. If you just want to see the Vietnam war go to the left, the right is mainly the French stuff. John McCain's parachute and uniform are on display with a number of other American things. Glad we went.
Sad but very interesting visit.. Although sad to acknowledge the cruelty of the human being, the visit is extremely interesting – don’t miss it. You’ll need around 1.5 hour for the full visit.

Another one sided view of Vietnamese history. According to the blurb, the prison was built by the French where they tortured Vietnamese political prisoners. Later it was used by the North Vietnamese who treated captured US bomber pilots to a life of luxury hence the nickname "Hanoi Hilton". This is completely at odds with common sense. Check out the Wikipedia article for a less biased view.

Back to history. Informative exhibition of historical relics are housed & displayed from the days of French colonialist regime including the life of American POW in the 20th century. The French-influence architecture of the building itself exude an interesting attraction with construction materials being meticulously selected by the French and some imported under strict quality control all the way from France.
Interesting history. I think this place is a must to see. Very interesting how Vietnamese prisoners were treated under French occupation and how American prisoners spend their time there.

Penal History. Although part of the original building has been demolished to make way for a modern high rise development, the remaining part of the prison is sufficient to provide an excellent overview of the dreadful conditions in which prisoners were kept in the early part of the last century. Examples of communal cells, solitary confinement and death row are well preserved and documented. A guillotine used to behead several people is in situ and throughout the premises there is excellent narrative of the historic events which led to incarceration . Modern history is also covered as many US war pilots also found themselves finding time in Hoa Lo Prison. Well worth visiting. Allow around 2 hours. Entrance fee VD30,000.

A must-visit. Very interesting and informative - a must-see for anyone visiting Hanoi. The route was well marked and the information was written in such a way as to give a clear and chilling picture of what life was like here without being too wordy. Good video presentation too - again, not too long but message gets across. Suitable for young and old and a thought-provoking lesson on man's inhumanity to man.

An eye opener. We decided to go to this place to see exactly what people went through in this prison. It was very bleak and did not only house men but there were women quarters as well. There was also a death row. The way they depicted this prison was by having life like models of men showing you exactly how they had to live in this god forsaken place and you could really feel their pain through their eyes, it was very clever the way they showed you how life like these prisoners were. We are glad we went to see for ourselves how surreal and inhuman these political prisoners were treated. It definitely was an education.

Worth visiting but needs to be followed up with own research. Worth doing (a short walk from the women's museum) but you need to take some of it with a pinch of salt - very different to the accounts you read online. That said, it's good to see it and get a reference point before researching. The audio section as you enter the first room on your right is well worth the 5 mins to get the basics. Displays are well done albeit upsetting.

impressive. the war is still "alive"in Vietnam. Here too an image of war and of a people that survived terror and oppressionSome parts I would consider not fit for children - too sad, too much cruelty

Worth a visit if you are in the area. . Worth a visit if you are in the area but I wouldn't go out of ones way to visit. As one would expect the information on show is very one sided and I didn't agree with one of videos which specifically stated that the Americans deliberately bombed schools and hospitals. It showed images of dead women holding babies. Whilst I don't agree with aerial bombing it is enviable that innocent civilians will get caught up in cross fire. It is this type of proganda that instills hatred against the west.
worth a visit. We went round the prison and found it interesting well worth a visit, more so if you are into the history of Vietnam

Good for an insight into French Colonialism in Hanoi. The exhibits made the brutality of the prison under French rule come to life. It also made me better understand then how that same level of brutality may have been inflicted on the American prisoners held in the same prison later. The section dedicated to the "good treatment" of the American prisoners by the Vietnamese is worth looking at, at the very least to give a glimpse into the narrative being used in Vietnam.

Interesting visit. It's odd to see this historical site nestled next to a high rise hotel with premium shopping.The museum has a good flow to it and some interesting artifacts. There's good insight into the history of the French occupation, which takes up much of the prison.However, once it gets to the time period tied to the Vietnam War, the propaganda becomes more obvious. Literally, they talk about how well US POWs were treated (given special Christmas dinner and service, plenty of access to medical care, etc.) with some staged photos as proof.I know every country does that to some degree, it was just jarring to witness.

Great history lesson for me.. I wasn't fully aware of the French impact on Vietnam and the Vietnamese people during the their occupation before my vacation.The section of Hoa Loa Prison that has been preserved to narrate this piece of history is well done and is definitely worth a visit when in Hanoi.

Confronting History. Visited what is left of the "Hanoi Hilton " as became known during the Vietnam war.However the prison goes back to the french rule and includes the guillotine which is still there with photos of the victims.The conditions in the prison must have been horrendous and include punishment cells with shackles etc.Well worth seeing for the historical aspects and the brutality of humans.

Please Come and Pay Your Respects to the Colonized Vietnamese. If you go to Hâ Noi, then you must do the prison pilgrimage just to pay your respects to the Vietnamese and what THEY suffered under French rule. Before the Americans were locked up here and made it infamous, the French were in control and many an unruly Viet died here. It's an eye opener to the savagery that the French put upon the indigenous people. It's no wonder they turned to communism to free themselves from almost 1,200 years of being colonized and treated like slaves in their own land.

Historical Place. Hoa Loa Prison was built and used during the French occupation.Then after February 1954, the Vietnamese Government used it, principally during the USA-Vietnam war, where a lot of famous American pilots were jailed!If you like history (as I do) it’s a place to visit, giving you good ideas of what happened during thus long years of war.
good to see how bestial all people can be. this prison is OK for visiting, not too raw. But interesting to know how local people could hurt, because of their spirit to be free
I would give it three and a half. It's a museum. So if that's your thing I'm sure you would love it. Not really my thing but I thought it was better than a lot of places like this.

Go see for yourself. Forget about the propaganda, just pay a visit there to form your own conclusion. There's simple instructions to follow on where to turn that makes the visit easy. Check out the guillotine and the cell they hold people before execution. Worth a visit, estimate to spend ard 2 hours there.

Good way to kill a few hours. This was perfect for someone like me who has a bit of a nerdy side when it comes to this kind of thing. Gives a huge insight into how prisoners were kept, tortured and killed. And gives great detail about the American prisoners who were kept here....including Senator John McCain.

Worth a visit. Interesting but somewhat biased prison museum which tells the story of what the prison was used for over the years.Built by the French, it housed many revolutionaries who were kept chained up in awful conditions and confined to dark cramped cells. A French guillotine is on display there which was used for executions at the prison. There was also a drain where some convicts escaped through the sewers.During the war with America, the prison was used to house American pilots and other prisoners of war. According to the museum they got treated with absolute luxury and it was nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton
A different perspective of history and Vietnam war. It's a good place for people who are interested in knowing a bit more about the history and Vietnam war.

Powerful and moving. Must see part of Hanoi. Takes you through the history of the prison from the French colonialisation and through to the Vietnam war. Allow 2 hrs to see and appreciate the history and be moved by the accounts within

Contrasted treatments or propaganda?. The `Prison' is not very far from my hostel but the streets in the Old Quarters resembled a maze and it took me a much longer time to reach my destination than I earlier thought. The front façade of the Prison has a very French architectural look. It was constructed by the French colonialists who were in Indo-China to exploit the resources. The Prison appears very well-maintained and clean. The area is not big and is in fact a prison museum with very informative and illustrative exhibition panels, video clips and artifact displays of prison life during the colonial days and in the decades of the Vietnam War. The French built this prison and used it as a chamber of torture to weaken the will of the revolutionary movement. Many hardcore revolutionaries arrested were thrown into this prison and suffered inhumane treatment and eventually perished under impoverished conditions though some managed to escape. It was interesting to note that an Almond Tree within the prison compound testified to the miseries suffered by the revolutionaries and nourished the heroes with her leaves and fruits. The aged old tree must be a witness to the historical fact. I do not think there is any propaganda to blemish the French colonialists. It is historically factual that they were repressive and cruel in their treatment of the Vietnamese revolutionaries. In their futile attempt to hold on to powers, the French colonialists think that the best way is to exterminate those who dared to challenge their rule. It was silly to try to reverse the wheels of history when the locals learn to be masters of their own fate. The second part of the exhibition related to the treatment of US POWs. In the name of democracy and freedom, the Americans dumped millions of explosives and bombs into Vietnam. Some of the imprisoned US pilots were confined to this prison but were treated with proper medical care and lived in humane conditions unlike the cruel way the French colonialists tortured the revolutionaries. The imprisoned pilots were also immediately released to the US government when the communists took over power. From the many photos shown, the US POWs enjoyed recreational activities and received regular and proper medical check-ups and care. Was this political propaganda or facts? Maybe those POWs who survived could answer to this question.I looked at the aged old almond tree that still survived to this day. It must have seen much of the misery in the Prison. If you are in Hanoi, you should not miss this Prison.

A thoughtful experience from the Vietnamese point of view. Hoa Lo Prison (aka the "Hanoi Hilton") was better laid out and presented than I expected. There is a logical walking tour that is easy to follow and has English explanations and videos. The "statues" of prisoners are very moving, as are the stories of the prisoners themselves. We spent about an hour inside and it was very interesting. I would recommend it to any visitor to Hanoi, especially Americans who might come away with a different version of history than they are used to.
Worth the Dong. Really enjoyed visiting the Hanoi Hilton. So much information and a very structured museum. Definitely do not need a tour guide for this one.

Worth a visit. We did not have a guide and I don't feel one is needed, there are sign postings and some short videos around. The path to follow is easy to navigate on your own as well. The focus of the prison tour is to portray the ill treatment of Vietnamese prisoners by the French. The mention of this prison being known as "The Hanoi Hilton" to US POWs is not until the end and minimal. This is worth a visit. The fee is (30k dong as of April 2016)

Fascinating look into history. I was unaware of the history of Vietnam before the American War but the prison helped explain some of the history and prompted me to read up. Well presented and made you aware of the horrors of an occupying force

Very interesting museum. This is one of the few museums in Hanoi that is open on a Monday. We spent about one and a half hours visiting the museum which is well laid out with extensive poster boards detailing the history of the prisoners incarcarated in this prison. Much of the prison has been demolished but sufficient remains so you get a good idea of how it looked when it was fully operational. This is a good way to fill a bit of time on a rainy day.

Well worth a visit . Well worth popping in if you have a hour or so to kill in this busy city. You follow the arrows and it takes you round the whole place. Very interesting although maybe a little one sided in some aspects.

Must see. For Americans, this is the Hanoi Hilton and prison where American prisoners were held during the Vietnam War. But it was built by the French, and has wonderful elements of French architecture, and the emphasis of the exhibits is on poor treatment given Vietnamese prisoners, during the French colonial period and war. The descriptions seem biased, but the exhibits bring to life what it would have been like for a prisoner. It's not until the very last rooms that any mention is made of the use of the prison for Americans and the descriptions make it sound like a pleasant stay. John McCain's uniform is on display and a photo shows that he visited the museum, as did President Clinton and others.

Intresting. Great collection of history, very informative. So cheap to get in and provides great value for money. The amount of information provided is high and very intresting, items on display and cells show a sad history of the jail
Worth a visit . A well laid out and informative museum. Recommend visiting. Don't bother hiring a guide as it's not necessary.........

Well presented history. Glad we went here. A lot of effort was made to have this prison/museum presentable to both locals and tourists. I received a good history lesson here, found out much about 20th century Vietnam of which I was previously unaware. Well worth your time.

Historic experience . Had a good experience at Hoi Lo Prison, an interesting way to get an insight of the Vietnamese culture, while discovering French and American influence. In fact, senator John Mccain was kept as prisoner at this prison for 5 years.

Interesting . We really enjoyed visiting the prison. The entry is really cheap and there is a lot to look at. Reading all the history and viewing the cells and torture equipment was sad but eye opening. We spent about an hour at the prison and are glad that we went

Good for History Lovers. A short visit to this very good arranged old prison is advisable,really I think this place is good start point to be acquitted with Hanoi;s history.Of great interest for me was a sewage hole that was used for escape from the prison by the prisoner.

Confronting. The cruelty imposed on the Vietnamese by the French during that period was deplorable. Thank goodness that is in the past. A very sobering reminder of mans ability to be totally non caring of another's suffering. How anyone escaped from that place is just amazing.
Good tour. Located near the centre of the city. A great exhibition of the history of Hanoi. Gives an understanding of the city.East to get around and all is well explained. Some good video material.

Fascinating as much for the curators' psyche as for the museum content. It was the same compound. When the French ran it for Vietnamese revolutionaries, it was hell. When the Vietnamese had the run of it for shot-down US pilots, it hosted Christmas celebrations. I've been to a few prisons around the world but this is the first I've seen so schizophrenic, and interesting for that reason. Spot the picture of John McCain. Can be done in about 30 minutes. I don't think children will enjoy this much.
Hoa Lo Prision. Myself and my partner went and had a look at Hoa Lo Prison during our holiday in Vietnam. The Place has some really interesting history to it and is worth a visit!

Worth a Look. This is really worth a look to help the rest of the world shed more light on what the Vietnamese people have endured over the last two centuries only to make them a stronger people today.What is quite amazing is that the Vietnamese people still have such a kind & welcoming nature after the treatment that they have received by other nations during both war & peace. The two main Nations that over ruled & attempted to split this this country in two are proudly independent republics which seems to be the most ironic. Perhaps they should both fund some sort of liberty statues for the Vietnam harbors to celebrate their freedom
Worth a Vist. Not as good as the war museum in Ho Chi Minh City, however still very interesting. Cheap entry, not many people there, easy to get around.

Interesting place to visit. We spent a morning here. My children found it quite interesting and we talked a lot about what has happened in Vietnam over the last century. The exhibits are well presented and information is in English.

A grim but interesting place. We spent a couple of hours here and it hightlighted the brutality of such places over the past century and a half. Not very uplifting but if you are interested in history definitely worth a visit. Keep an over mind on the written information - it is told from one side only. Worth researching for yourself after your visit.

must visit.. need n want to learn more.
u must visit here even if u have no interest on history.
that will be first step.

Interesting but upsetting . Such a fascinating place, but it can also reduce you to tears when u see how the prisoners were treated, particularly by the French. Mostly about Vietnamese prisoners, but also a very interesting section on American POWs during The Vietnam War. Fascinating photos of Hanoi after the Americans had bombed it.

Definitely worth looking . Not too far a walk from the old quarter and definitely worth doing. Very interesting to see some more history about the first indochina war as the majority of other activities is on the USA conflict as opposed to the French. Not very expensive

A must visit to understand Vietnam's history. The place can give you goosebumps! The prison has been turned into a museum, which gives details about the suffering and hardships the Vietnamese faced during French colonialism and during the resistance war against America.
