You must visit to understand the violent history this beautiful country sadly faced for many years.

Grim reminder. One of the most powerful emotional experiences to be had in this city - what remains of this horrible place has been left as a reminder of what the Vietnamese people have had to endure at the hands of the French. Unsentimental, awful.
So much history in one place. Didn't have any expectations of this place before we went but it turned out to be amazing. Learnt a lot about Vietnam here, would totally recommend it.

One of those places you must visit. Was very interesting and informative, learning about the hardships and fate experienced by Vietnamese revolutionaries imprisoned by the French rulers. Guided tours available for invaluable information. The site of the guillotine is spine-tingling; to know it was actually used on human beings and imagining yourself in their place is very thought provoking.
Interesting history. Interesting history. Would be worth reading up about this before you visit and I don't recommend taking small children.

Highlights colonial past. A visit ensures we dont forget what the Vietnamese have had to endure under colonial power. The French like many other colonial powers oppressed the inhabitants and this prison shows some of the cruel ways of doing that.

Great insight into recent Vietnamese history. The prison is definitely worth visiting during a stay in Hanoi and offers a great insight into the recent history of Vietnam.The only criticisms I'd have is that it focuses mainly on the French colonial era and doesn't have as much on the Vietnam/American war (only to tell you that American prisoners were treated with an almost luxurious stay). Also a significant section of the prison has been demolished in order to build a large tower building in the prison grounds.The prison is extremely interesting and is well worth a visit. Bring a guide if you can!

Inaccurate waste of time. It wasn't the one sided propaganda and skewing of the truth that was disappointing, it was the inaccuracy of the displays and information.Being an engineer, I was amused by the building materials on display that date to 1896. The Vietnamese had products and building techniques that were not invented until the 1950's - 1970's. Truly amazing ? Or fitting with the whole tourist TRAP....Also the fact that the site is now a hotel/apartment block is testament to the quality of this attraction.My advice, read Google on the truth and don't waste you're time with this ridiculously flawed place...

Interesting history. The prison is very interesting, worth getting a guild or reading up on it before hand to just understand a few things. There is audio around the prison to tell you about the details of the prison.
The only way to understand Vietnam and their people.. It's a chilling reminder as to how strong people's convictions can be.Worth a visit it's full of history.

Watch out for taxis outside. Enjoyed visit to the prison, not too large and lots of information. Our visit was spoilt by the taxis waiting outside which I used to return to my hotel. Driver put on the meter but it was not the correct rate , as it was want first time getting a taxi in Hanoi I did not realise they had ripped me off until I asked at my hotel.

Maison Centrale. Great visit to find out more about the history of Vietnam. Well laid out with models of people in prison cells. A bit spooky really. Interesting views of the experiences of the American pilot prisoners. Centrally located in nice area from which we walked back to hotel in Ma May, Old Quarter.
Very well done and interesting. Not at all like a museum and very defiantly has a reason prison feel to it. It could be a be jarring at times but the kids found it very interesting (9, 10 and 16).

Interesting historic prison. A nice prison with lots of history and cheap entrance 30k for foreigners and 15k for foreign students. The prison that remains isn't huge, but there were a few cells that had been nicely done to show how they would have been used. A death row block, women's block, mens block and information surrounding it's use during the Vietnam war and holding US pows. Not the best prison I've seen in the world vs. Alcataz and Freemantle, but worth nipping in if you are in the area.
Interesting. Really interesting to discover a part of vietnamese history, obviously the museum is at the glory of Vietnam but was interesting to understand how vietnamese resistance was organized.

Great experience. Decided to take my daughter by rickshaw to the Hanoi Hilton (prison). Eye opening. The prison tour enabled both of us to really appreciate the experiences of prisoners under French rule and then more recently under Vietnamese rule when American pilots were held there.The cells must have many awful stories especially under the French. While mostly accurate the history has been recorded with a slight tilt towards current ruling party, but then that happens across the world.
Worth the visit of you have the time. As per other reviews , the prison tells the Vietnam war from the Vietnamese point of view. I wouldn't make it a "must do", but worth a look.

The Hanoi Hilton". Only cost a couple of bucks to enter and well worth it. One needs about sixty minutes to see everything. It's in surprisingly good shape. Most of the locals only know this place as the prison, so you should ask for it, vice HH.

Not worthy of a visit. . Went to the prison only to find out it that half of the prison is now a hotel. You can walk through it but it focuses on the struggle against the French. It's all about the Communist leaders who were imprisoned there. It shows little about prison life and virtually nothing about the Vietnam (American) War and nothing about the Hanoi Hilton. A great disappointment.

Worth a visit . There's plenty to read on the history of the prison as you walk around. It won't take up more than 1-2 hours of your day but it gives a great insight into what the Vietnamese had to endure. Each bit of info is in three languages so if English isn't your first language there are other options which makes a change to most of the places I've visited in Vietnam. We had problems finding it at first, but if you get yourself to the Hanoi Towers Shopping Centre it's just down the side of it.

Highly recommended visit. This place has such a majestic presence, despite having been reduced in size due to modernization (and practicality). The prison museum was very well designed - you learn a little bit about each period in its past life and the flow of information from room to room made sense. The exhibits were clearly marked and thought provoking. This prison played a major part in Vietnamese history, and it was helpful to learn their take on the French occupation and the ensuing war. Highly recommended for those interested in history and historic places.
Emotional..... This was very interesting and touching. Very emotional. Sad to see that people were treated so poorly.
Sobering. A difficult place to visit but one I wanted to see. Propaganda sanitizes and downplays the treatment of American soldiers here.
Very Interesting and Informative. Was very interesting to see the Hanoi Hilton and learned a lot about the war and previous French occupation.

Worthwhile visit. Worthwhile experience to gain a deeper insight into the history of the Vietnamese and just some of the hurdles they have overcome in the last century. My admiration for these people just continues to grow.

Really interesting and thought provoking . Really interesting and thought provoking.
We really enjoyed this as it shows and tells the chequered history of the prison. Lots of English with some exhibits only in Vietnamese. It takes about an hour or two to fully appreciate it. Very cheap too and a good way to spend an afternoon especially of it is hot.

Historical. Definitely worth a visit if you know, or wish to know about the history with France/Vietnam/USA. My father was in the Vietnam war so I was very interested in the pictures and pieces on display.

tragic tales. after visiting Hoa Lo Prison, my eyes were opened even further to the tragic tales of these resilient Vietnamese people, it was a real eye opener for me as I had never known about this part of the countries history
Thought provoking and sad.. Smaller than I thought it would be but had a powerful impact on me. Different perspective but a part of history we all need to remember.

Good piece of history.. Walked here from hotel. Everything was pretty cool good way to kill time. Cheap tickets but not much too see. Takes maybe 30 minutes to an hour. To walk around an see everything.
Interesting visit. A pretty sobering experience and lots to take in with the exhibits bringing the narratives to life. A really interesting place to visit with lots of information.

The Hanoi Hilton. Very interesting and sad at the same time, some good exihibits and gives a real feel for what the place once was at the time. Highly recommended visit for those interested in the struggle.
Definitely to be visited. One of the more interesting places on our tour of Vietnam. Brings back memories of the war times. Somber place but I would consider this a "must visit".
Very interesting. We went here with a tour and found it very interesting and very sad at the same time. We went with children and they were interested, but not for very long.

a lot to learn . Hoa Lo prison bring us back to the war time.
We learned a lot in this museum.
There are pretty a number of Tourists to visit this place.
I recommend to go in the late afternoon to avoid crowded.
There is no dress code, entrance fee for adults is 30,000 VND
It is allowed to take photo in the museum,

If you have time!. We went there today, it is actually pretty interesting place. It give great insight to the French colonial back ground and further on in the tour it touches base with the war against America. It gives the Vietnamese account, which I think is important to hear from both parties.There is a fee of 30,000 vnd per person. It takes maybe an hour or two to see all.

Well worth a visit. We debated whether we would spend time in this museum but we were very glad that we did. It gave a good insight into the history of Vietnam outside of the Vietnam War. The displays were informative, well placed, easy to follow and interesting. Happy we made the trip.One tip - when buying our ticket the lady sold me an information booklet. I asked if it was needed or whether there were displays and she said I would need it. You don't - unless you want to bring the information home with you.

Interesting part of Vietnam history. The Hoa Lo prison is most known for it's role in the Vietnam war. While being used to keep captured American pilots, it is much older and has been also been used by the French. Interesting thing to visit if you in Hanoi, but expect the guides to give a certain interpretation of the very sad history of the Vietnam/American war.

Propaganda, but interesting. This newly opened museum is very interesting and a fun example of Vietnamase propaganda. Most of the museum focusses on how evil the French colonial power was towards the Vietnamese. A smaller part then tells about the prison's use during the Vietnam War, where the Vietnamese were so very nice and kind to the American POWs.
Museum. Found this pretty interesting and only a little gruesome! Lots of photos and definitely lots of propaganda

Worth a look. This was a great little museum, and tole the story of the French well, however most of the prison has been sold off our time. I would recommend a visit while in the area. (The war remnants museum in Ho Chi Minh was much better)
Interesting. Interesting to know a little more history on the prison. Very interesting make sure you take a guide with you

Interesting Prison. This was an interesting historical place to visit but I feel there could have been a bit more to see as alot of the cells were empty and we just seen the same manikins throughout the building. Still I was surprised at some if the facts I learned though not convinced it was completely unbiased. Overall still a good way to spend an hour for 30000 dong a ticket.

Chilling. A well structured and organised museum that only costs about £1 to enter yet was full of information about the prison and prisoners over the years. The footage and information about the Vietnam War was interesting and very poignant.

Excellent, Harrowing. Used by the French for Viet Minh Political prisoners and later dubbed the 'Hanoi Hilton' by the American POWs. Very Informative and graphic regarding its earlier years, however a lot of propaganda regarding the Americans' incarceration.

Prison life under French rule. If you are interested in learning about prison life under French rule then this is for you. There is only a bit about more recent years - a few photos of surprisingly happy US prisoners eating their Christmas dinner and playing games!
Prison visit. Well worth the visit. A good insight to the history, and the experience under the French occupation.
Worth a visit.. This prison is worth a visit, probably only need to spend an hour or so, but very interesting. This is the sad side to Vietnam. Cheap to get in.
a must see in Hanoi. a sobering view of prison life in " The Hanoi Hilton". A good account seeing life from " the other side".

Very much from the Vietnamise point of view. There are displays which show the experience of the Vietnamise under French occupation. At the very end of the museum there is just one room giving some information about the imprisonment of American airmen during the Vietnam war. However do be aware that throughout the museum the text supplied is clearly propaganda. That said it is still worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton worth a visit. As someone who remembers the Vietnam War as a teen, this is a must see museum. It gives visitors valuable historical information about the role of the French colonizers and their treatment of Vietnamese citizens as well as the prison's role in housing American POWs during the American (Vietnam) War. Of special interest to me is the interpretation of these events and the propaganda produced to show favourable treatment of American soldiers.

Very educational, and not just for Americans interested in our Vietnam War. It's the Wandering Yank here. I had read John McCain's autobiography years ago, and knew some of the history of American POWs' experiences from other sources as well, so I was very much looking forward to seeing the legendary "Hanoi Hilton".Most of the history explained relates to the pre-1954 period, when the prison housed various revolutionaries. The conditions were obviously grim - the guillotine on display is one example of the French response to some of the worse characters.Be prepared for the propaganda in the American POW exhibit - the happy prisoners playing basketball, opening Red Cross packages, playing checkers...I don't think so. I'm glad I went if only to see John McCain's flight suit and parachute.Definitely worth a visit to anyone interested in either the colonial history or the Vietnam War era.

A visit with a different view. I had visited this place years ago and was overwhelmed by the horror this place had created for so mnay.This time I was a little more "hardened" and took in and read a lot more. One previous reviewer complained that there was a lot of propaganda and to a certain extent he was correct.We are suppose to walk out thinking that the French were monsters and committed constant and unspeakable crimes against the Vietnamese whereas the Vietnamese were utterly respectful and humane with the prisoners they captured during the American War.I think both streams are a little exaggerated and the truth lays somewhere in the middle.Either way, this place is a good place to see mans inhumanity to man.

Informative but slightly bias- of course!. Lots of propaganda here in writing but a good prison museum with enough information to keep you interested. Been to a few prisons before and this one is well kept.

MUST SEE. For any Baby Boomer this is of significant interest. And probably for others as well. Not much of the prison is standing but what is there is certainly enough to get an idea of what it was like. Most interesting to me was the photos and captions related to the Vietnam war, or the American was as they refer to it in Vietnam. Just a great place to visit in Hanoi

Page needs to be updated. This page can be improved and provide accurate information to the visitor. The address is correct. The phone number can be updated from the ticket picture I have submitted. Opening hours are missing and they are: 08:00 to 17:00. Finally there is an admission fee and that is: 30,000VND.

Interesting & worth visiting. Learning about the prison is really interesting, and for $1 entry it's hard to say no. The only thing I would recommend is reading up on how the US prisoners were really treated as the propaganda about that is ridiculous.
Other than that, it's highly recommended

worth seeing. Interesting place to see and to read about what happened, I am glad I went to put it all into perspective. It doesn't take long to look around and there are other things to see nearby, I would suggest making the effort.
Hoa Lo Prison. I never knew about the misery inflicted on the Vietnamese people from both the French and the Americans and the bravery and strength of these amazing people . An education .

Hanoi Hilton. We had a few spare hours and the consierge suggested a visit to Hao Lo Prison. What a moving experience. The treatment of the prisoners in this prison was horrendous. Not a happy place to visit but certainly worthwhile.
History learned. Situated in the middle of Hanoi, small place to visit. Will take most an hour, cost 30K dong per person. It is interesting to see this is part of the Vietnamese history.

Heavy heart. It's so nice to see human mistakes honored. We must remember In order not to repeat the past. This prison is a reminder of how cruel one human can be to another; conquerer over the conquered. This prison gives me great pause and humility; a sense of shame. A question keeps coming to mind. Why must one society force another to adhere to its values? As I grow older I appreciate human differences more. This tour isn't for the faint of heart. Nearly brought this grown man to tears. People...love your neighbors and celebrate all the cultural differences we humans have. This place is a must see.

A little too obvious.... While the sufferings of the Vietnamese people under the French colonial occupation are shown quite realistically and in a sober way, the treatment of US soldiers in the so-called "Hanoi Hilton" is obviously heavily embellished. The war remnants museum in Saigon is in this respect much more factual.

Vietnam wars. it is truly worth paying a visit. I am a vietnamese who is interested in vietnam history esspecially the wars against 2 big countries France and Ameria. I myself saw the pic of how political prisoners were treated, how horrible the wars are no matter where they are.

Great visit!. Interesting visit learnt alot! We spent around 1-2hours here! Visiting Hoa Lo prison is a reminder of man's inhumanity to man. The prison shows the horrific role the French played in shaping Vietnamese history as well as the Vietnamese response to the American attempt to interfere in its civil affairs.There is a clear sign posted route around the prison, information in English which was also a bonus. Great artefacts.
interesting place. definitely worth a visit if you have an hour to spare. well laid out museum. some metal steps up to upper floors.

Interesting . Took a tour of the prison. Very well presented not much information but enough. Interesting learning about the prisoners and their lives there especially the US Pows. Would recommend, it's near the centre.

Interesting take on history.... Well worth a visit. Plan 45m to breeze through, 2.5 to read and see everything. Guidebook is worth the extra few dong. Good exhibits in English, Vietnamese, and French. Some authentic artifacts from the 1890s through the American War, as they call it here. Their version of the history is an interesting take on events...

Hanoi Hilton. The French first used the prison to house dissidents, both men and women, who opposed French domination. Later, it was used by North Vietnam to house American soldiers during the Vietnam War.

Mind-provoking and better with a tour guide. More westerners than locals visiting this place. The whole display was kinda depressing given the dark history. They had audio guide but didn't work. Better go with a tour guide who will share his/her insights and help you better understand the whole site.
NOT RECOMMENDED for families with kids.

Eye opening. Interesting walk though history, Good place to understand some of the history of this town and see what they have been through. Entry was around 60k for 2 people or 80k including guide book. Spent 1 hour slowly walking around and reading everything.

This is the prison where John McCain was held. Our tour guide who is with us for 12 days is also Vietnamese who was born after the war in the north central area. Nothing was said about John McCain but rather about the French and what was done to the Vietnamese prisoners who were held there. It is graphic and rather unnerving. My husband was also in Vietnam during the big Tet of 1968 but he was able to handled this. This is not for everyone.

Great Museum. Of all the historic areas of Hanoi, the Hoa Lo prison had the best 'journey' through the exhibits, and there was a huge amount of information provided in Vietnamese and English. Information boards placed in all areas of the prison were interesting and accessible, they documented the history of the prison well. There was first exhibits of the French Colonial time, and then a separate area denoting when the prison was used for American Prisoners of War. We left the prison feeling very informed, and also moved by the exhibits. Well worth a visit for the tiny entrance fee, which is about £1 per person.

Propaganda run riot. Quite rightly showed how badly the French treated the Vietnamese during the revolution and the deplorable conditions that they were kept in. When you got to the American prisoner section then everything changed. They showed how wonderfully they treated the POWs and had them pose for photos to prove it. I think that everyone knows that that was not totally how it was. However it was still very interesting to see and I would recommend that you go but keep and open mind.
lots of historical information!. So much history of the French and Vietnam War. loads of pictures and more information than one can remember but very eye opening!
Not the best Hilton I've been to - but certainly not the worst. Not a lot of bells and whistles but a good visit if you enjoy the history of the area - expect to spend 30-45min here.

Good to spend a short time. The museum was good enough to spend about 3o minutes. I wnet there on a raining day, so did not enjoy much. My friends loved the place, so everyone having different opinions about one place

Visit to Hanoi Hilton Goal. The exhibition provided a stark and confronting history of the struggle of the Vietnamese people's during the French Colonial occupation and the Civil War . The Exhibits were detailed and informative and challenged visitors emotions to the reality of prisoner treatment at the Goal. The exhibit dedicated to the American involvement in the War gave an insight to the bombing of Hanoi and the capture and treatment of American prisoners - interesting to view War from Communist view point. Worth spending 2 hours.

History. The role of Vietnam in history is fascinating. When visiting the prison you learn so much more there is to Vietnam than just the last war. Definitely worth the visit, even though the info is a bit tainted.

Very good museum. This old french-then-vietnamese-prison present a very interesting insight of the french and american war. The second part is almost propaganda but still good to see. Cheap and near the cathedral

Interesting but very sad, glad I went!. This is worth visiting and although it was not high on my list of things to do I am very glad I made the time to go. It provides you with incredible insight of what humans can endure! In saying that I also appreciate how many did not survive these inhumane conditions. It doesn't take long and we spent about an hour but left knowing a bit more about the history of colonialism and war and the impact that has had on the lives of the Vietnamese.

No need a guide. This was the only museum we visited and it was enough. We arrived at about 930am which was a good time as it got crowded later. Several tourists came with guides which I felt was redundant as there are more than enough English signs to explain the exhibits. I got to know lots more about the history of Vietnam through the videos, although one room felt propoganda-ish. This place is worth a visit! We spent about 1.5 hours here.

Over one hundred years. For US visitors, this is the "Hanoi Hilton" but that was about ten years of a 100 plus year history, most of them as a French colonial prison. A good stop and well worth the time. The adjacent hotel replaced about two thirds of the prison

Hanoi Hilton. This was a pretty interesting visit while in Hanoi. The history is an interesting. Some parts are a bit disturbing. If you are very into history I am sure that this would be higher up on your list.

Historically fascinating place. We were on a day tour of Hanoi when we went to the Hoa Lo Prison. I highly recommend having a guide when you visit here. Our guide told us the history of the prison from when it was built until what is left of it present day and this made the visit so much more interesting. There is examples of the cells as they were used originally by the French to hold Vietnamese prisoners (in atrocious conditions), and an area also viewable as it was during WW2 when the Americans were held here. It was one of the highlights of Hanoi but the guide's stories were what made it come alive.
Pleasantly surprised. Definitely don't miss checking this place out if you're into old buildings. Well documented stories and atmosphere to relive a time of horror and atrocities.

Interesting but not high on my list. The museum is located beside Hanoi Towers Residential Apartments and shopping centre. It exhibits and photographs give a history of the prison and the Vietnamese struggle for independence and an insight as to how prisoners there were treated by the French and the Vietnamese. It was interesting but with limited time in Hanoi, would not be high on my list

A Worthwhile Visit. Our first day in Hanoi included a long and fascinating walk from our hotel (Intercontinental Westlake) through the local back roads next to West Lake, and then down the myriad of hectic streets in the Old Quarter, passing Hoan Kiem Lake and finally finding our final destination (after some trial and error) at Hoa Lo Prison.The prison was a worthwhile visit. A token entrance fee (30,000 VND each), followed by interesting yet somewhat politically slanted insights primarily about the oppressed lives of Communist patriots against the French in 1930-45....also "humane" treatment of American POW'S (including John McCain) at "Hanoi Hilton" in the 1960's. I definitely recommend this short 30-45 minute visit as part of a full day walking tour of the Old Quarter.
Must see. This was a great place to visit to put the country's history int context. Although only prt of the original remains, it is informative and gives another perspective of Hanoi.
Impressive!. Impressive visit! Must see! One of the better things to visit in Hanoi . You also van see the Vietnamese - USA war true the eyes of the Vietnam people.

1 hour is enough. If you are in the area, then I would say drp by this museum.If not, I am not sure it's worth taking a short trip to get to it. Only a very small section of the prison has been preserved and the english translation is somewhat poor. There are documents there that are only available in French and Vietnamese.

Important visit but difficult. Obviously visiting a prison where not only American POWs but also Vietnamese who opposed French colonial rule were kept in horrifying conditions is not "fun" in my book. I'm glad we went but wouldn't want to do it again on a return visit.

A Powerful Reminder. Visiting Hoa Lo prison is a stark reminder of man's inhumanity to man. The prison shows the brutal role the French played in shaping Vietnamese history as well as the Vietnamese brutal response to the American attempt to interfere in its civil affairs.
Must see. We visited with the kids, and it's really must see if u around. Make sure u have some Time, to see the post war from local view, and see what the local government present.

Harrowing and thought-provoking . So glad we came here. Graphic and harrowing material which has been dealt with sensitively and thoughtfully. Well worth a visit to see just how bad things were in the prisons.

Interesting piece of history . This was a great place to visit to find out about the history of the struggles of Vietnam between 1880-1960s. Plaques on walls in English and gives a great insight into the prison life at the time

Must see !!. This is where the French and then the Viet Cong kept their prisoners. Exhibits focus on the mistreatment by the French of the local population and then the incarceration of the American pilots etc. The museum is well kept, clean and has a path to follow, The exhibits are very well displayed and a credit to the Government. They include an escape story, actual photos, pilot suits, recreations and cells. Be careful, like many attraction sin Vietnam - it opens early and may close for lunch similar to the Military Museum.

It's reputation creates a must visit, but could be more interesting. Not much of the site remains, what there is has been turned into a little museum with a good amount of photographic and written info. Very few actual items, most of the exhibits are reconstructions although a working guillotine does remain.

Hanoi Hilton. Well worth the 30.000 D entrance fee.Built by the French to hold Vietnamese patriotic & revolutionary fighters and then housed captured American pilots who were shot down.Barbaric torture was used toward the Vietnamese, but the treatment of the Americans was shown to be good(propaganda!??)
Worth Seeing.. Certainly a place you want to visit, but do not expect much. The presenations were factual and treated the US GI's and flyers with respect.

A must see. This was the Hanoi Hilton. The French designed it and had every thing made in France. I can't imagine anyone making it out alive and to think woman we in there to. I think it is a must for every one how cruel we are to each other. Take what they say with a grain of salt. I think they were a bit bias
Not quite what you would expect!. This was once a prison, but not really much to see other than cells that were once occupied by prisoners.

Quite interesting. This prison-turned-museum informs you about Vietnamese history and the wars and skirmishes the country has been involved the past 60-70 years. There are quite a lot of informative posters, but you'd probably have to be very into Vietnamese history if you'd want to read everything there is to read :) The prison part is rather chilling...Entrance fee is 30,000 VND and at this price it's definitely worth a visit.
Prison visit. Was something to do on a rainy day in Hanoi, whilst exploring the city and other attractions. Was about an hours visit.
Eye opener. Interesting to get another perspective on historical events. There are always 2 sides to every story!

Interesting not exciting. Because its image is associated with the war you need to see this attraction. It will add a third dimension to everything you have ever read. You have to take the way they said they treated prisoners with a grain of salt.

Hanoi Hilton? or French colonialism?. This is what is left of the old Hoa Lo Prison from the French colonial days. Or if you are more focussed on the US war Hanoi Hilton. Gives you a good insight into the beginnings of the Vietnamese Communist party under the French, but if you want some generalised information on the time the US were there save some of your visit for the end of the tour. That is where there are 2 rooms set aside for some of this detail, with a couple of videos running a loop.

Ok but wasn't wow. Visited here today and was a little underWhelmed and thought that I was going to experience something very emotional and historical. But was a little ho hum.Only visit if weather is poor or you have 5 + days in Hanoi

Historical spot. Everyone tends to think of this prison as where American POWs were imprisoned during the Vietnam War. It was actually built by the French during their occupation of Vietnam to house Vietnamese prisoners. It does have some relics left from the American POWs, but to the Vietnamese, this is a symbol of what they went through when the French occupied their country.

Very humbling. Quite a tricky place to find if you are following your hotel map, we circled the area twice the other day and could not locate it easily until a fellow traveller on another trip told us exactly how to find the prison and marked upon our map.I have to say I had no inclination to go to the prison, it was my husband who had an interest in visiting. Half of the prison is no longer there and has been replaced by a hotel. There is a small fee to enter and you are asked if you would like a tourist book at the time of paying although she didn't tell us we had to pay for it - allbeit pence in our money however this is not the point. Our fellow travellers told us they had their book for free. So should have been 60 VND for 2 persons we paid 80 VND.There are a lot of boards with photos once inside and some glass boxes containing remnants and relics of the days the prison had "guests". As I said "not my thing" at all and quite honestly found the whole experience rather depressing and a bit creepy. Photos of heads in baskets, the actual guillotine on show, the dark dingy cells and a tatty old bed which American soldiers used to sleep upon - all rather awful.I wished I'd stayed outside whilst my husband walked around - there were several long faces sat in the courtyard looking subdued after the experience, it is the history, it shouldn't be forgotten however maybe it should also come with a warning too before entering.
Interesting history. We enjoyed this site. Interesting history and good information in English. Not too crowded and cheap entry under a pound each. Well worth the visit.
Worthwhile tour. Great visit which shows in excellent detail the pain that the prisoners would have went through. The room with the guillotine brings to reality the terrible past.

a must. Hoa Lo Prison is a must when in Hanoi, it affords the visitor a broad understanding of the history of Vietnam over the past 150 years or so.Chilling artefacts and a real insight into conditions offered to political prisoners and then US pilots.
Insightful. Interesting history of prisoners of war. Can make your visit short or long depending on how much time you have.

A must see. We visited twice, once with friends from our tour who were American veterans and once with a local Vietnamese guide. Recommended as a way of learning about the violent century the Vietnamese people endured to achieve a life that most of their visitors can take for granted.

Interesting perspective. Visited with a guide as part of a Hanoi tour. Really interesting perspective on the French colonial rule and the American war. A bit lost on our children (6 & 8), but worth a visit nevertheless

Recommended. This is a surprising good family tour and gives an insight into the political history of Vietnam. Conditions were appalling as you would expect but interesting. It is difficult to imagine anyone surviving the conditions or being able to escape.

Nice place to visit!. We wished to visit this place during our trip in Hanoi and it did not disappointed us. The prison is quite small now compared to the past but its exhibitions were really meaningful and we learned a lot of the things we had never heard before.

Very poignant. Very well setup and done - even for those who are not interested very much in history, this attraction will get you hooked and you will leave the place wanting to learn more about Vietnamese history

Very interesting view of Vietnam's history. This shows the life of political prisoners under the French control and then of the American pilots during the Vietnam war. Very interesting to see this recorded from a Vietnamese viewpoint.

Emotional visit . This old prison has been done to show what life was like for those held there. You do not get a full feel of how horrific it was for them until you read the descriptions and study the statues. You must go.

Interesting highlight into prison life. Very cheap entry fee, 30,000 Dong, just less than a pound per person, got to wander around for however long you like. There's options of a guided tour as well. We just did it ourselves, and bought the little guide to take with us too.
We found it easily and all the artifacts were translated into French and English.
Hanoi Hilton entrance with Happy New Year banner (!?). There is surprisingly little to see here, but it is an important stop nonetheless. Broken glass acts as barbed wire on the top of walls.
Very interesting. Plenty of history in hoa lo prison and not only does it focus on the plights of the prisoners but also a wider historical context.

A tale of the grim history of war and colonisation . This is s museum in part of the prison built by the French to keep any of the locals quiet who were keen to kick them out and get their country back. It's a sober reflection of just how appallingly all colonising powers could be.
Also shows its use housing US POW's in the American/Vietnamese war.
What an eye opener. We really enjoyed the prison. It was a real eye opener. The things prisoners went thru is amazing. Only about 20% of the prison remains. Definitely worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton. Well I'm pretty sure the Americans who had the misfortune of staying here had a far worse time than the propaganda would have you believe. In trying to cram too much history in I feel like this place has lost its (mis)charm....didn't feel particularly nasty altho I'm sure it was. Only 30k dong so no harm sticking your head in and having a look around....

Worth visiting . We only needed about 30 minutes to walk through and see everything comfortably. Only costs 30k to get in and is interesting enough. Always fascinating to see the Vietnamese perspective.

An interesting museum. Only part of the prison remains and the tour mainly focuses on the French occupation of Vietnam. A life size guillotine can be seen. The prison was nicknamed the "Hanoi Hilton" by USA pilots who were detained here. Sadly there is a very one sided propaganda film. Where is the truth in all of this?
Interesting and eye opening. Well set out and easy to follow. Interesting and sad information, but recommended to see how people on death row and even normal inmates were treated

A very interesting place. The Prison was first used and built by the French. It has exhibitions about the French involvement in supressing the Vietnamese people and the terrible conditions that the prisoners were kept under. There are also exhibitions about when the American servicemen were kept at the "Hanoi Hilton"There is quiet a lot of propaganda and the films are obviously staged to show how everything was wonderful for the detainees. It is still very interesting however you get the feeling that not all that is said is the truth. The English translations are interesting the French translations are far more accurate. Hoa Lo is well worth a visit
Must See. Top of the list for a return visit to Hanoi - the history and stories behind this former prison do not just tell you about the site itself but the wider history of Vietnam. Excellent.

Worth a visit if you have a couple of hours. Very interesting to read about the history of the prison. There is a video (English subtitles) at the end of the visit that would be better to watch first so when you enter the prison turn left instead of right, go out into the courtyard and up the stairs then watch the video first - then follow the normal route to view the prison
The Dark Times Revealed.... One of the must visit location in Vietnam. You can really see the suffering of Vietnamese freedom fighters and how the French invaded Vietnam.Must see... you won't regret.
A must see. A great historical place. Reminds you of the savage part of humanity and the senselessness of war. Also learn of certain facts we in the west did not quite knew.

Vietnam trip . Lots of reflection and soul searching.
This is a must see if your into history and war. Reflect on humanity and see the remains of a prison that housed Vietnamese and Americans in different era's and the way they were treated and tortured.
Plan on about two hours.

Interesting and worth a visit . This was an interesting place - but I still don't know whether the US pilots had as good a time there as the Vietnamese would like you to believe.
Could do with a bit more information - but really interesting

A look back. A look back of the history of this place and dark ages of the French occupation of Hanoi through to the Vietnam . Plenty of reading material and displays to look at. Well worth the visit easy walk from the old Quarter.

A must See. It's a very interesting spot and one you should certainly see. Definitely has a propaganda slant to it, but it's hard to dismiss what was done to the people of Vietnam. That said, they treated the prisoners equally bad, but that is not apparent given the rose-colored glasses version of the tour.
Hanoi Hilton. Very sobering but we are very satisfied we visited the prison where Senator John McCain spent 5 1/2 years, and many other of our soldiers also we're there.

Well worth it. This prison has a lot of history both from the French colonialism and American Imperialism Wars. Well worth a visit. Demonstrates the struggles the Vietnamese people have been through during it's recent history and the conquests over its invaders.

“Amazing History…But should not happen”. This is one of the most impressive museums we've ever visited. Perspective of revolutionary prison was excellent; they gave us a lot of things about the painful history with imperialism. I do not want to mention anything about the war was over. I just pray for a peaceful world & the war will never happen. If you want to learn about history & war, you should come here!

Check This Off Your List. The Hanoi Hilton is a must see because every one, and I mean everyone back home will ask you if you visited this place and if you say no, they will stare in utter disbelief. Were the French Colonialists Cruel? Yes, Yes, and Yes. This was a hell hole for anyone unfortunate enough to get locked inside. Walk into one of the cells and close the door and imagine spending the last year of your life here. Thanks France.

Part of Vietnamese history that can't be missed. Good museum. All people should visit it and go slowly through the exhibits. We’ve learned a lot. Can't even imagine what Vietnamese people went through.

Needed more time to look round. Very interesting, especially to see this part of history through the eyes of the victors, well laid out and gave a good idea of how it must have been, interesting exhibition.

Propaganda to the limit about Hanoi Hilton. I don't know why I was not expecting this, but it was totally different. There was very little about the American pilot's imprisonment except for how nice the Viet Cong were.

Hanoi Hilton. Interesting visit, if only for how inhuman the conditions were there. I found the American bit about the airmen who were interned there very interesting as I had just visited the B-52 museum. Somehow managed not to pay to get in, just followed behind a tour group that had just arrived!

This is a must see if you're a western foreigner visiting Hanoi. When visiting here, observing and reading about the way prisoners were treated made me feel a better understanding of the Vietnamese people and they have evolved into what they are today.

Informative. A really interesting museum which clearly presents the Vietnamese perspective on French occupation and American invasion. Entry is really cheap and allow a good hour to peruse the displays.

Sobering insight to French "colonialism" in Vietnam. This prison was constructed from French materials and was used for prisoners of both the French colonial administration and American pilots captured in the Vietnam-American war.
Provided an interesting perspective on the origins of the Viet Minh and Viet Cong, and the appalling treatment of political prisoners by the French.

A sobering visit.. This prison was in use during the Vietnam war and a lot of the prisoners were brutally treated and the conditions were horrific, being shackled to each other and half starved. It was called the "Hanoi Hilton" and eventually closed in the 90's.

Very interesting but a one sided explanation I thought.. Looking at the exhibits and the explanations attached to them the 'picture' that was painted to me was a one sided summation of over 50 years of the country being subject to domination and attempted domination by predominately two other countries which did not work.A number of the exhibits made you realise how precious our freedom is and how wonderful it is to have it.

Interesting and worth a visit. . Not on our original itinerary but guide said worth seeing. I agree. A bit tongue in cheek with the propaganda video (the imperialist American bombs). Known as the "Hanoi Hilton" as the American pow's were kept in luxury - I think the opposite was probably the case. None the less, very interesting.

Not much to see if you're looking for the Hanoi Hilton. The prison exhibits are more focused on what the French imperialists did to the Vietnamese prisoners there....there's one small room that shows American POWs...and as you can imagine, it's very one-sided (claims that the Americans were treated well, etc)
Amazing. Spent many more hours here than I thought we would. Amazing guided tour - must do this. The history is astounding and the visit is confronting.

If you know anything about the Vietnam War you should see this.... This museum aka Hanoi Hilton is must for those who want to learn more about the time of the Vietnam war. Please keep in mind that you are in a communist country so their view of the war are not those who fought against them. So it may not be what you want to see or hear. However, I believe if you keep an open mind you can learn a lot from the list.

"The Hanoi Hilton". This was the name given to the Hoa Lo prison by American prisoners during the Vietnam war. The second half your visit will tell you, from a Vietnamese perspective, about the prisoners and their time in Hoa Lo. This follows the first part where you see and hear all about the French and their treatment of the Vietnamese in the prison.It's not pretty and at times sobering but fascinating in that it opens up questions that need answering from another viewpoint.

Great museum full of history even if that's not your thing!. Super easy to get to if you're staying in the Old Quarter (as long as you have mastered crossing the busy streets)! At such a low price my boyfriend and I didn't have super high expectations, but were blown away by the exhibits. They have clean washrooms as well, and a cute little gift shop right in the middle. Would recommend to anyone who wants to spend an hour or so learning about French/American/Vietnamese history in Hanoi!

Scaring but especially for a german an experience, because of our own history.. Impressive in a scary way. Worth a visit but only with good nerves. Was hard to see the similiaritys to the german concentration camps.

Great Tourist Attraction. we thoroughly enjoyed our sightseeing trip through Hoa Lo Prison. Everything is set out perfectly, easy to follow and very informative. Done from the perspective of the Vietnamese, it is interesting to see the two sides of the war (american vs Vietnamese) and puts all the trials of the vietnamese into perspective.
well worth a visit. While it presents a viewpoint based on the Vietnamese experience of the French and American wars, it was a very interesting place to visit

Very Interesting but..... This is a very interesting prison/museum about its history during the French occupation and is very graphic in its depiction of those times. I enjoyed the experience but it shows a whitewash of how Americans POW's were treated during the Vietnam War. It is still worth a visit.

Informative. So much history some sad some uplifting. As a visitor to this lovely country this was a great starting point. Although only small due to building on the site it was very informative of the country's history.

A meeting with human pain - that made an impression.. Walking around I thougt "Even torture is a scill". I found the presentation of the period with amaricans war-prisoner to be more propaganda than facts, but that itself was an interesting observation.

Very interesting. The prison experience was surprisingly good ! The tour around starts by explaining how the prisoners were kept and treated whilst the French colonised Hanoi and then the second half explains the usage and keeping of American prisoners during the war. Well worth the entrance fee !!!
History Visit. Definitely worth a visit for those that love there history. Makes you see for yourself what the prisons were like and how much we appreciate things now.

Hanoi Hilton. Sarcastically known by US POW's as the Hanoi Hilton, the Hoa Lo Prison is now a museum.
An average attraction - nothing great!

Highly recommended while in Hanoi. I recommend this to anyone who's mildly to greatly interested in Vietnamese history. It's a moving experience you should not miss in Hanoi. Don't buy the brochure at the ticket stand, it's all written down in the museum.
A peek into history. Not to be missed. The guillotine here gives the chills. The vietnamese spin on everything (bordering on propaganda) makes this an interesting place to spend half a day.

Informative, clean, well-maintained exhibit of French Prison.. I visited here to view the history and experiences of the US servicemen held here in the lat 60's and 70's. There is a section devoted to this part of the prison's history, however, most of the exhibits are about the French period and the Vietnamese people held here as political prisoners. It is worth visiting, however, as with most of the "marquee" tourist sites in Hanoi, it gets too crowded to comfortably walk and read the history. I don't know any way around this problem----- there are too many tour buses coming to the attractions now and it makes a relaxed viewing of anything impossible.

Every American should go here. Having two members of our tour who served in the war here, it was indeed a moving and insightful experience. One can just visualize our guys in the small, stark cells here. Keep an open mind and reflect.

Worth a visit . We spent a few hours exploring this iconic place. It is well laid out and each exhibition is described in English - sometimes a little lost in translation. It is within walking distance from the old quarter and costs just 30,000 dong on entry.

An informative and sobering look at Vietnam's history.. This was an incredible place to visit. Seeing how the Vietnamese people endured against the French colonization/occupation of their country was truly eye-opening and made me understand a bit more about maybe how and why the Communist party prevailed during the Vietnam/American War in the '60s & '70s.
Impressive. This was impressive and choking to see how we have been treating this people during a past not too far away. I was almost ashamed to be French

Worth a visit but lots of propaganda. This is an interesting way to spend a few hours. When we went, several school groups were there, so it was loud and hard to get up close enough to read all the exhibits, but we could still get a sense of the place. It is interesting the way the VN government portrays history...their prisoners were treated terrible by the French, but the VT treated American POWs wonderful. Rewritten history at its best.mm

Well worth a visit. Having visited lots of prisons around the world, I'd have to say this was not the best visit I have ever had BUT there was still enough information and history to make this stop well and truly worthwhile if in Hanoi.

Reginald and Ocilvinora. A must see for anyone visiting Hanoi, especially if you want to know about what actually happened there when the French built this prison. Some of the things on display could make you wonder about the extent of cruelty that the people of that country had to endure.
Very atmospheric. We found this to be most informative and the exhibits to be a high standard. Most thought provoking.

Heavy topics in historic locations . You should definitely take the time to visit if you're in Hanoi. Although it can seem fairly one sided at times, the prison gives a great deal of information and does a good job of helping you begin to understand what the Vietnamese people have endured. I did not find it graphic nor hard to see in the least (especially when compared to some other museums showing the effects of the "war of U.S. aggression"). A necessary stop if you want a well rounded visit to Vietnam. Eerie and heartbreaking.
The building is the best part. Seeing the Hoa Lo Prison building was interesting - but the exhibits were just okay. Wish they had better signage / explanations / multi-media.

The Hanoi Hilton - what more can I say. Our trip to Vietnam, and Cambodia was a combination of great beauty side by side with great horror. Ha Lo Prison was a lesson about the horrors of war and how prisoners were mistreated. I can't say I "enjoyed" my visit but it was an indispensable experience.

Atmospheric, 1 hour maximum. This is a very worth while attraction, whatever the portrayal of the exact history! I wish my own country was more patriotic and didn't constantly panda to being politically correct. If you can see past any propaganda then it's fascinating to see the old cells arnd artefacts, very well pierced, something like 90 pence entrance fee. Toilets perfectly acceptable and location easy to find, central. The taxis that wait outside, despite looking official are not the official ones and are three times the price, although still super super cheap

A must see!. This museum was really well done with very professional displays and information readily accessible. It is surprisingly large (don't miss the upstairs displays in two buildings) and easy to navigate. Although well-known as Hanoi Hilton for its time as a prison for captured USA pilots of the Vietnam War (including US Republican Senator John McCain), most of the display is about it's time as a French prison for Vietnamese 'patriots'. The prison features a guillotine and other tools of torture, and paints a very bleak and dark chapter of Vietnamese history. The dedication wall (carved / caste images of prisoners) in the courtyard is excellent and poignant.Well done attraction and highly recommended for a 1-2 hour visit.

very confronting. I was appalled at the treatment given to prisoners. Found the prison very depressing personally, I could not enter most of the exhibit rooms. But overall I can see the need for the museum.

Sad and a little scary but a great tourist attraction. Part of a group tour we visited the Hanoi Hilton as locals call this prison. It has wonderful history and interesting stories of those incarcerated there as well as life sized mannequins portraying life as it was lived in there. Not much fun for the inmates.

Worth a visit. This museum is really amazing and worth a visit. To know more about this country, about the history of this country you really gotta visit here. Some of the area are still remain untouched and quite scary sometimes.

The Hanoi Hilton...At The Top Of My Boyfriends List Of Places To See In Hanoi. And I am so glad it was! Even though much of the original structure is long gone, the painful feeling of what it must have been like to mostly the French and American prisoners remains within the walls.Allow at least 90 min. It's history that reminds us of how cruel war is.......Don;t miss the propaganda room where it is told that our soldiers were allowed to prepare their own holiday meals and decorate a Christmas tree..Ha Ha!

Great museum covering both French colonial period as well as some of vietnam. The museum was well laid out and gave a stark depiction of prison life for dissenters of the colonial French rule. French imprisonment of government protestors reached its height in the 40s and 50s. It also outlined the start contrast to the way the American POWs were treated in Hanoi during the war. They appeared to be treated very well and the name Hanoi hilton was accurate

a Prison. it is still easy to imagine a prison here in spite of the freshly painted walls. In general it reminds of other museums-former prisons -memorials to hard times for a nation so you've seen something like this before you can probably skip it. On the other side, there are some interesting pieces of art, a lot of information and a real guillotine a few meters high, though of course it's quite depressing to really immerse yourself into the atmosphere.

We learned so much!. This is our first time to Vietnam, and honestly didn't know much about the country or its history. So upon arriving here we wanted to see at least one of the history museums. With the help of trip advisor, and the great reviews, we chose this one. And we were not disappointed.The whole museum takes around 2 hours to walk around but most definitely worth it. We used our student cards so got tickets half price at 15,000 dong. We learned a lot about the wars with both the French and the us, and even got to see inside the cell blocks and dungeons. Half of the original prison has been knocked down, but what's left is still very interesting (and upsetting) to see. There are plenty of signs written in Vietnamese, English and French, so hopefully you will understand a tleast one of them. Take the time to listen to the audio devices and to watch the short videos. They were some of the best bits. Don't miss the upstairs exhibitions (we almost did).One of our favourite things to do in Hanoi and a great start to our trip!

Important, interesting and informative afternoon in Hanoi. This is without a doubt a recommended stop for anyone visiting Hanoi, but it should be absolutely mandatory for any American. The war in Vietnam, or the "American War" as it's referred to there, not being a high point in the American military complex, this is a topic largely glossed over in American education. A visit here is truly eye-opening, putting into context and perspective the long history of a people brutally oppressed for centuries. I walked away with a much clearer understanding of "Uncle Ho" and what he means to the Vietnamese people; if you can, do this before you visit the Mausoleum. The exhibits are well done and thoughtfully presented.
Good time was had. This is a must see when In Hanoi. It's a great perspective on what some of the prisoners had to face while in prison.

An interesting visit. This is well worth a visit, just a short walk from the lake. Costs around 30k Vietnamese Dong which is very reasonable.Some interesting information about Vietnamese prisoners under French rule which was quite horrific to see. Each of the exhibits is trilingual (Vietnamese, French and English (although some of the English translations are a little off) all of the information is clear to read).There is also a section on US POWs during the Vietnam war which definitely has a slightly different slant to it although was maybe unsurprising given the nationality of the museum.All in all, an interesting way to spend an hour in Hanoi.

Interesting. Only one wing of the original prison remains and is preserved as a museum. Most of it is dedicated to the treatment of political prisoners during the French colonial period. Almost nothing about the time when it was known to Americans as "Hanoi Hilton". Luckily we had an excellent guide who knew more than what we saw.
Interesting place. We stopped here on a group tour and it was pretty interesting. I honestly learned a lot about Vietnam and its history. Worth a stop if you are visiting Hanoi.

Not using their potential. The was an decent site to see. You get a little feeling of how life was in the prison, but only little of the original compound remains. Most of the signs take a very one sighted point of view on the American war.

A do not miss while you are in Hanoi. Learning about the horrors the Vietnamese prisoners suffered at the hands of the French is an important part of the history of Vietnam, a pivotal part of their path to the modern. US POWs were housed here, as well - this was the Hanoi Hilton. Perhaps the story of their time here has been sanitized a bit, but there is education to be had here.
Awesome . This was my one of favorite sites in Hanoi. The prison is very interesting and it was a surreal experience to walk through. I highly recommend stopping to see this site

Well worth a visit.. This was part of a day tour and we are glad we visited. It gave news slants to events that we had lived through and the site was clean and the story clearly presented. We would certainly recommend to others.

Worth popping in!. Not a massive museum goer but it's worth a visit if your in the city for an hour or so. There's a lot of readable content, all of it very interesting but there's a lot of it! If you choose to read it all that is. I believe you can get a tour guide that will show you around through tour agency's but I didn't bother. It was cheap as chips and parts really do paint a picture of what it must of been like, especially the death sentence cells!
How Lo Prison. We really enjoyed this attraction. Well worth visiting. Easy to walk through with a wonderful displays. A great historical building.
Don't miss. Fascinating place to visit and see the brutal conditions in which prisoners of all causes were held, escaped and died.Give yourself a good 2 hours to take in all the sights and sounds

An Interesting View into the Past. The infamous "Hanoi Hilton", a must see for anyone with a couple of hours to spare, albeit somewhat shocking in the details of the levels of brutality employed in some areas, so not for the overly sensitive.

Kind of depressing as I guess prisons should be. Not particularly impressive museum overall but it provides a sobering reminder of Vietnam's history of conflict including the American War. They depict the treatment of American POW's as a wonderful experience. Somehow I think John McCain's account may be more accurate.

Interesting . The museum provides information on when the prison was opened by the French and how prisoners were treated, showing a few prison cells, stories of prisoners and some artifacts. It also shows how the American prisoners were supposedly treated when captured.

Pretty confronting. This place is creepy and confronting but at the same time well worth the visit. I shudder to think what it would be like at night, but during the day it can be a serene and tranquil place...until you get to some parts of the compound, that is. My friend and I had a guide accompanying us but if you are a solo visitor, you will still get a lot out of it.
Confronting and sad but essential to see. We found this very confronting and sad but it's essential to see and understand the history. We had a guide which really helped in explaining everything

Gut retching . It is hard to believe the way humans can treat one other.This prison shows how hard life was behind closed doors at the 'Hanoi Hilton'It's graphic and sometimes a little hard to see/ hear how life was, but it's an important part of Vietnam's history and struggles

Interesting from historical side. Very much worth the visit, easy to get to within walking distance from Lake. Main focus on French persecution and mistreatment of Vietnamese people who were just sticking up for their rights as citizens in their own country.Clearly the Frogs were very harsh masters.Small segment on US invasion (as referred to by Vietnamese) and much crap about how well the US pow's were treated and these political influenced views spoil an otherwise interesting visit. Really Vietnam, do you think the people of the world believe this rubbish you have put out here.

Interesting spin... for $1.35 it's hard to complain, all things considered.. I find experiences like this to be deeply personal. The entrance fee is only $30k Dong which is roughly $1.35 US. I spent about an hour here on a rainy day checking out the exhibits and trying to imagine the reality. Things seem a bit glorified and glamorized and the press photos are shown along with some of the harsh realities. It's hard to imagine what life was really like here during the Vietnam war but I can't imagine it was as nice or as clean as depicted. War is brutal and the museum shows a bit of it, but hard to imagine the thoughts, smells, experiences that happened here...

Part of an oppressive past.. A fitting reminder of a period where Vietnam was trying to find its own way but being dictated to by others. Cruel in its use, it shows mans inhumanity to man and depths we can fall to.

Worth a visit. Very cheap to get in. Found this an interesting place and learnt a lot about the prisons history. The prison had explanations in English to read and life sized exhibits of prisoners as they would have been kept. It was easy to understands the shocking conditions they endured. The prison was certainly worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton. It's hard to rate attractions like this as they are important monuments to horrific events. Like Andersonville or birkenau or the like. You can probably skip this attraction if you are Vietnam War-ed out which can happen if you've already visited the war museum. Again the government tends to underplay the cruelty here but there's some interesting artifacts and you can see where people were held and understand how terrible war is.

Worth to check it out. Me and my Husband were on our first visit to Vietnam..with four nights in Hanoi we had plenty of time to stroll and checkout attractions around Old Quarters. Hoa Lo Prison is a good place to visit for those interested in History and understanding the culture. You probably need about 45 mins to an hour..costs 40VND per person.
Must go!!. First time going to a prison museum and I was very impressed! It very graphic, informative and organized. It has videos to see and audio to hear in 3 languages, English, French and Local.

American Pilots Held Here. Popularly called the Hanoi Hilton, this prison's most famous guest was now-Senator John McCain who spent over 5 years here after he bailed out into a Hanoi lake. The prison itself was built by the French to house enemies of the colonial government. The conditions were horrific, although 2 rooms of sheer propaganda show American pilots smiling as they played chess, decorated Christmas trees and enjoyed holiday meals. Today the prison is a museum.

Worth a trip. This prison was also known as the "Hanoi Hilton" during the Vietnam War. It was originally built by the French to house Vietnamese political prisoners and was then used to house American POWs including John McCain. It provides good historical background regarding the French colonial period as well as much of the world's reactions to America's involvement in the Vietnam War. It does, however, present a slanted version as to the conditions and treatment given to the American POWs.

Historical prison, worth a quick visit. The Hoa Lo Prison (or Hanoi Hilton) is worth a visit if you are interested in the history of both the communist resistance against the French colonialists or the later aggression by the US. While the perspective is definitely that told by the victorious side, it is still a fascinating place to visit and a get a sense of the barbaric conditions that the communists were held. You don't need a guide to visit here if you speak English, as there are clearly written panels explaining all of the exhibits.It will only take you about an hour to visit, but it is centrally located and close to other places of interest. I would recommend as a place to visit as part of a tour of central Hanoi.

Interesting but not amazing.. This place is somewhat interesting but just that. It doesn't take s long time to walk through and it was an interesting place to visit knowing that John McCain was a pow there. The display are well presented. I wouldn't saying was a highlight of the trip but is worth visiting if that's the type of thing that interests you.

The Hanoi Hilton, a surprisingly good visit.... Visited the prison with friends on a tour, which proved very educational and informative. The Hỏa Lò Prison was used by the French colonists in Vietnam for political prisoners, and later by North Vietnam for U.S. Prisoners of War during the Vietnam/American War. During this later period it was sarcastically known to American POWs (mostly U.S. airmen) as the Hanoi Hilton. The prison was partially demolished during the 1990s, though the gatehouse remains as a museum. One famous prisoner was previous presidential candidate John McCain. The museum is small and usually busy with videos played on a loop, so a guide is unnecessary. Depending on the weather I would advise taking: Sun Screen, Water, Camera, Hat or Umbrella.

Prison is modest in features & about French subjugation. I expected something different after a long walk to find it and bought a guide since I read that there was little posted in English. Tip: Forget the guide, everything is in English. There are only a few rooms. It tells the story of the years of Indochina and French occupation. The Hanoi Hilton story has a video and 1 1/2 small rooms with some b&w pics. Not much about its use during that time period. I probably wouldn't recommend it now that I've seen it but hey, its part of the history that is important.

Very interesting visit. Had heard of the 'Hanoi Hilton' so decided to take a look, a very interesting history and the way the tour around the prison is set out is very good, some fascinating facts are revealed as well as some dark fact about what happened here during both the French and American wars. Well worth a visit.

History comes alive. Excellent museum detailing the harrowing lives of prisoners under harsh French colonial rule, as well as USAF POWs held during Vietnam War - although some of this was clearly propagandist

Interesting if brutal history. Built by the French to hold approx 450 prisoners it swelled to 2,000, mostly political, prisoners by the 1930s. Later, during the 'American War' it was used to incarcerate American pilots who named int the Hanoi Hilton.Much of the prison was demolished but enough remains to form this small museum.It sets out to contrast how well the Vietnamese treated the Americans compared to how badly the French treated the Vietnamese. Draw your own conclusions.

Surprisingly good. . I found it informative and educational. If I was American, I may question if a more balanced and objective slant should be given to some of the commentary, but if you go with an open mind and realise this is still open-wound living history, it's a good couple of hours away from the gorgeous chaos that is Hanoi.
Odd to think of it as a tourist attraction. Like many prison tours it opens your eyes to how people are treated who's only crime is to disagree with the powers that be

SAD & INTERESTING VIETNAMESE HISTORY!. Very well presented prison museum giving visitors an easy to understand history of Vietnam’s past with France, and then the USA/Vietnam war. Good visual displays with easy to follow captions. Sad history & an amazing testimony to the kind & forgiving nature of the Vietnamese people.

Sad place. This is the down town prison used by the french and later on by the locals. Only a small portion remains today and its full of sad stories about the war and those who were captured. By contrast there is a section called the Hanoi Hilton where the American prisoners of war were housed. It is so named since the claim is that the Americans were treated luxuriously after capture. Visit this place if you are interested in History.

Fascinating, represents the indomitable spirit of Vietnamese people. This museum mostly shows how the Vietnamese people fought the French for their freedom, with a smaller section representing the American-Vietnam war. The information in this museum gives a historical context for anyone visiting Hanoi, so they can see how the modern culture has developed and been influenced. The parts about the American-Vietnam war are also fascinating, even if they are pretty one-sided, as it shows another element of this culture and its government. I left this museum feeling I had a deeper appreciation of where I was.
Interesting visit. Must see museum gives good insight into the history of the prison not expensive to get in spent the whole morning taking in the sights

Interesting. Was a bit sceptical when I heard the guide advise how great the Americans were treated (the reason it was called the Hotel Hilton), and given brand new shirts and trousers and brief cases etc, and how the Vietnamese were shackled up to a dozen or so in a cell. Very one sided, but nevertheless, part of history and some of the displays were pretty awful on the way the prisoners were treated.

I've been to a lot of prisons.... As a former Correctional Officer prisons hold a special place in my mind. And not usually a good one. But this museum was well put together and the account of what happened here and the timeline was accurate. As a historian I appreciate that. They even have john McCain's jumpsuit from when he was captured and held here. I got the feeling a lot of guests didn't want to hear about what happened there. But history is important. Worth a visit.

Interesting visit! . Having heard about the "Hanoi hilton" from my childhood just had to visit here when in Hanoi. Was very interesting and informative and well laid out. The story may be a bit one sided but nevertheless sobering and food for thought. A must see if in Hanoi

A very memorable visit.. We got a very thoughtful memory and a useful lesson of Vietnam`s history by visiting this Museum; former Hoa Lo Prison, much because of our very knowledgeable guide, THOA, from `Hanoi Urban Adventures` that gave us very good information and also time, to think of all horrors that took place here. We recommend a visit here AND our guide as well!
Eerie place. This place was very eerie but full of history. The conditions that the prisoners were kept in were in humane and very sad to see. Well worth a visit

Nice building, average displays. It was interesting to visit such an historical site but the displays were average. It was a pity that a large part had been demolished and an ugly building erected in its place.
The sculpture/mural was excellent. Worth a visit but dont allow more than an hour.

Very informative, worth visiting . It's not expensive to visit and it's very informative and well laid out. There is slightly too much information condensed in the first few rooms. The prison cells are really educating and moving to understand how these prisoners were treated. Well worth visiting whilst in Hanoi.

Grim and big on anti-American and anti-French Communist propaganda. I was a bit shocked that people were taking 'snaps' - even using a flash - when looking at tableau of severed heads in baskets, people being tortured. This is a serious place telling a serious story of hardship, determination and the eventual overthrow of tyrannical European masters. This is where the Vietnamese Communist Party was born, in the north. Ho Chi Minh was a prisoner here, he taught his disciples here, in secret. You'll learn a lot about torture and being fettled.There's a more contemporary exhibition of the time Hoa Lo housed American airmen shot down during the Vietnam War; they referred to it as the Hanoi Hilton. John Cain the US senator was held here and they still have his fliying suit. There are photographs of the generosity of the north Vietnamese who gave gifts to the airmen before they were eventually released. If you want to learn more about Vietnam, you should travel south to Saigon/Ho Chi Minh City where the citizens weren't so pleased at being overthrown by the north and having Communism imposed upon them. Northern citizens are considered careful, hard-working and they save money for the future. They consider the citizens of the south to be wastrels and pleasure-seekers, non-savers who don't plan for the future.
History of Hanoi. easy to navigate, just straight forward museum of how things were during the resistance during French colonization.

Sobering review. Spent over two hours at this place. Being Australian and old enough to remember end of Vietnam war reviewing political prison information from the opposite point of view fascinating. Vietnamese people so resilient and interesting information about two well-known American politicians when they were prisoners of war here. Horrific history re the guillotine. Well worth visiting.

The other side of the story. Sure prepare for a bit of Propaganda, but to the victor the spoils, History isn't really re-written here, but it does demonstrate the barbarity of the French Colonialists and then the bombings from the Americans, it's a good story and very well worth the visit.
Historical interest. Very interesting place for learning the contemporary history of the world. Memories for the very recent time

French Colonial n Vietnam US history explained . The combination of history is well explained by images n pieces with a few video reels.Enjoyed the tranquillity of the rememberance garden - certainly worth a visit n a few fridge magnets not seen elsewhere in Hanoi.

A perspective on history. The prison is an interesting view into the war and political history of Vietnam. It is a somber reminder of the real victims of war that has ravaged the country. It includes a monument to the leaders of the communist party and a perspective on the treatment of foreign prisoners of war. It is a reminder that there are many losers with any war and different views that should be considered.

Striking insight into cruelties of mankind. A visit to this old French prison in Hanoi gives a graphic insight into the cruelties inflicted on prisoners even in the 20th century as well as a well explained section about the care of US pilots captured in the Vietnam war. It is well laid out and explanations are clear. A visit takes about an hour and is recommended.

hard to tell what is real or propaganda. Nice building, interesting to see. Explanations are very partial, so hard to tell how true they are.
Less "hard" to see than expected, everyone can go, and no nightmare to be expected.
Nice visit if you have plenty of time in Hanoi.

Remains of a prison. Basically a museum of the prisons during the French colonisation and it's related horrors and some of it , is of the parts used to house captured American pilots during the Vietnam war.
