This part is also jokingly called the Hilton hotel to highlight the liberties extended by the Vietnamese to the American prisoners of war.

Mr. This is a must visit for people interested in firstly the French occupation and then the American invasion of the late 1960s. I was amazed to see the American fighters so well looked after by the Vietnamese jailer
and were allowed to play sports as excretion.

A somber reminder of the Vietnam war. The 'Hanoi Hilton' as it was nicknamed (not to be confused with a Hilton Hotel up the road), this was were many prisoners were kept in torturous conditions during the war. You can view the different sections and cells, as well as items on display from the era including prisoner clothing, shackles, and the gruesome guillotine. Not for the faint of heart, it is still an important memorial to see of the not so distant past history.

Not much to see. I'm sorry to give just two stars, but there really wasn't much to see here. Lots of plaques to read with some reappearing photos, a main room with shackled mannequins (the highlight), a smaller room with two cells and a few artifacts. I just expected more and was disappointed.

A unique insight into the history of Vietnam. This museum tells a number of stories including the Vietnamese version of the American invasion. The cells have been left as they were with lifelike models and there is even a guilotene that the French used to behead local dissenters.Difficult access for wheelchair users due to the historic nature of the building but very logical progression between the rooms and good multi-lingual videos

The 'Hanoi Hilton'. An interesting and thought provoking insight. OK, firstly this place is a great tourist destination. It is mostly preserved buildings, so you can get a real feel for what it was like when it was operational. The only thing that you need to do is take the propaganda with a grain of salt. The prison displays are roughly divided into two parts - the French occupation and the American war. The prison was built during the French Colonial era, and was used by the French to imprison political dissidents and anyone else causing trouble for their regime. The bulk of the prison displays and information are more historical and focussed on this era of Vietnam's history. It starts with a description of the people who were displaced by the French in order to build the prison, and ends with a visit to the guillotine room, complete with one of the originals! The rest of the displays are from the Vietnam war era, (the American war as it is referred to here). A common flavour throughout the prison displays relates to Vietnams' struggle through history with being occupied at various times and their struggles against their oppressors, culminating in their ultimate victory. You develop a real understanding and sympathy for them here, although as I said earlier you can't take everything literally. Overall though, I would definitely say that no visit to Hanoi is complete without 2-3 hours at the Hanoi Hilton.

Scandalous. Whilst it's certainly acceptable to contest historical narratives, and indeed, for nations that have suffered under colonialism and invasion, it's essential, the portrayal of the Vietnamese as nothing more than heroic and innocent victims of historical misfortune, who themselves took no part in atrocities, is astounding, hypocritical, and wholly lacking in credibility. The majority of what's left of the prison (rather ironically, the remainder is now a plush 25 story serviced apartment building), is dedicated to the horrendous treatment of Vietnamese dissidents by the French colonialists. This is all done in an unnecessarily hyperbolic manner, that detracts from rather than emphasising the cruelties endured by the prisoners. There is then a large section celebrating the leadership and heroism of the leaders of the CPV who were imprisoned at Hoa Lo, but a lack of similar recognition for any of the more everyday people who entered and never returned. Without wishing to deny or diminish the role of these revolutionaries, narratives of the ordinary fighters involved in the struggle (or even those who were falsely imprisoned), would've added a far more interesting and palpable strata to the museum. The small section dedicated to the female prisoners goes someway to address this, but generally, the tone is very one dimensional, didactic, and context free - nothing is ever put into perspective - a huge failing for a place of remembrance. This second section is quite simply unconscionable propaganda. I'm not American, but I left feeling extremely angry at the manner in which the infamous 'Hanoi Hilton' was presented as a model prison, where the prisoners were treated with great kindness by their hosts, and even educated as to the ways of Vietnamese culture, as they spent their days playing chess, cooking, and whiling away the hours until they could head back home. It seemed surreal, a joke, which I kept expecting to be revealed as comparing the then propaganda against contemporary accounts. But the punchline never came, and the American POWs still face the indignity of not having their experience represented with any degree of accuracy at a monument purporting to be there as an act of remembrance for all of its victims.The final section is perhaps the most interesting part because it doesn't exist: how the CPV treated its dissident prisoners in Hoa Lo right up until the mid-80s.

Interesting, but of horrifying too. Was interested to see this place since American prisoners were held here. John McCain was held here too and he is quite famous now. A lot of anti-American propaganda displayed. The treatment of the Vietnamese people by the French during colonial times was pretty bad according to what was written and shown here. They show cells with mock prisoners in them. It was a pretty gruesome place for the prisoners.

A glimpse of their history. this is an interesting place specially for the people who loves knowing the history of the places they go to. But it is kind of sad and disturbing knowing how people are treated during the war. That room where there is an artwork showing how the prisoners are being chained is really scary for me. I can't even look at them fearing I might dream about it! There is also this tiny whole where I don't think my head can even fit, and they said that the prisoners tried to escape from the prison thru that. ooh, my dreams, forgive me! I like the videos presented there and giving information about the war. The only thing is that you won't feel like it really is a prison and that really was the place where the captivation took over since it's in the heart of the city and when you look up, you'll see tall buildings hovering over.

Mans inhumanity to man. What remains of the Hoa Lo prison (aka Hanoi Hilton), has been converted into a museum. Some of the original prison cells have been preserved including the death row cells. Life size models in manacles show what a terrible experience it was during French rule.Most of the area tells the story of the French occupation & the liberation fight. The other area shows the imprisonment of USA pilots during the Vietnam war. The French occupation is particularly gruesome. It's 30,000 dong entry & is worth a visit

Hanoi Hilton. The French built an incredible prison to incarcerate, torture and kill the Vietnamese people. Daring escape by a very few led to the revolution to free the country from French rule. Used to house American prisoners during the conflict. Parts of the museum are difficult to deal with emotionally.

A Must For Americans. If you're an American traveling through Vietnam this is a must see. Although the amount of information is primarily about the French control of the prison, there are a couple of small buildings that detail the capture and imprisonment of US Pilots-- including Senator John McCain.

Propaganda. There is definitely a lot of history here but it is unfortunate that it has been turned into a propaganda exhibit. You would believe that US POW's were staying in a 5 star resort & treated very well??? Huh ?

Biased but yet interesting. Of course you have to visit "Hanoi Hilton" while in Hanoi! It was painful to visit the old cells and imagine how it must have been to be prisoned there. However, the propagandistic information signs gave us mixed feelings. It's interesting to take part of the extremely biased stories, but at the same time it feels uncomfortably. According to the information provided, the vietnamese revolutionaries stayed positive and friendly while in prison, despite being tortured by the French barbarians. This could be compared to when the american pilots were prisoned during the Vietnam war: they were treated extremely well. Actually, their standard was even higher than the average vietnamese person's!I think this propaganda unintentionally makes this museum really interesting. The propaganda is of course an important part of the vietnamese culture, and its interesting to get this side of the story about the Vietnam war.

Fascinating. I thought this was a really interesting museum and well done throughout. There were some audio features throughout, but only one in each language and they are quite long if you have to wait to use it. It would be better with personal audio guides, but even with this small complaint, it was very good and I would very much recommend it
Very enlightening. A good place to visit, still all seems to be the fault of the imperialst Americans so steel yourself for a one sided view.

Very interesting but also a little disturbing. The prison dates back to the time of French colonial occupation of Vietnam. It has interesting exhibits and photos from that time. One groosome exhibit is a guillotine used to behead Vietnamese political prisonersMany will find the exhibits relating to the American War the most interesting when American airman were held captive here. The nicknamed the place the Hanoi Hilton. One exhibit is Sen John McCain's flying suit from the time of his captivity.

Propagandistic but interesting. As most of things in Vietnam, propaganda is at the heart of all exhibitions. The Hoa Lo prison at least provided an insight of what happened during the colonial times. Main elements shown are photographs and some dungeons, recreated with full size replica of prisoners.

lots of history here and plenty of stories, but information given is a bit partizan. definitely worth a visit if you're interested in this sort of thing. Lots of history from the french occupation through to the US conflict. Not as much info about the conflict with the US as we'd hoped and most of the prison is no longer there, but still enough is standing for you to get that feeling of "a lot of things really went on right here". The information given is clearly quite one sided, (which is fine, they're entitled to that for sure) - but worth doing some extra reading afterwards for a more rounded view if you're bothered. Only 20,000 each to get in so very cheap really and worth it for something to do and learn bits and bobs about what happened and some background history of vietnam.
Introduction to the rich history of Hanoi and Vietnam. It was our first taste of Vietnam history and it was really enlightening. Worth the long walk at 11 degrees Celsius from Hoan Kiem Lake!
Communist propaganda. They portrayed the treatment of American prisoners as if they always treated with great with living conditions like a nice hotel.

Interesting.... It was interesting to see the Vietnamese perspective on the war and how they treated POWs. I learned a lot about the French colonial period as well. It was very crowded and the English translations were not very good. I would recommend a visit though.

Prison life. If you've got an hour to kill it's worth taking a look, but don't go out of your way to see the place. There's not much of the prison left, and it's very (overly) nationalistic in the way exhibits are presented throughout - especially the American POW area where it ignores how badly they were treated and just shows propaganda of them having Xmas dinner and playing basketball. I'm not American, but I found it quite embarrassing,Also, a lot of the English speaking guide tools weren't working when we visited.

Interesting. If you love history and more so about the Vietnam conflict, then I recommend seeing it.Most of the complex has been renovated or rebuilt w/ only a few rooms being original.The history is interesting. Won't see the real cell that John McCain was in, but will see a room with American items. A video is also shown depicting the outline of the war.Also other rooms or cells show photos of prisoners or variety of torture methods.One room has souvenirs or Vietnamese knick knacks for sale.Took no longer than an hour.

Fascinating history. The horrors of French colonialist rule in Vietnam materialise through clever exhibits that bring the prison 'to life'… The prison can be explored in an hour or less. Well worth a visit.
interesting museum. Went with my wife to see the prison and we both enjoyed it. Learnt about what some of the vietnam people had to go through for independence.

Highly interesting. Yes, the prison museum is biased. If you go into the prison knowing that, then you will enjoy learning the history behind it anyway. No matter what, you leave with a stronger understanding of Vietnam's history, and that it was an awful place for anyone there. They have done a great job of preserving this piece of history in an interesting way.

Hanoi Hilton. This prison was first used by the french colonial power to inprison Vietanmese during colonial time and the French war, and then the Vietnamese used it for American soldiers (pilots) during the American war. They named it Hanoi Hilton. There are exhibitions, celles, lot of information in text and photos. It is presented by the winnerside, so it is not objective of course, but a memorial of cruelty of colonial power and war. For an outsider it is a way to understand Vietnam and its history better.

The other side of the story. The section concerning the American War was a joke. They said the locals were living a difficult life while the POW's were decorating Christmas trees,getting parcels from home, and being so well treated......

Very Interesting.. Even though there is only a small part of the prison remaining, the prison has been designed to give visitors real feel of what the prison life was like and the cells and conditions prisoners had to live in. MY 10 and 6 year olds were fascinated.

Really upsetting. This is not for the emotional or sensitive person. The savage acts of cruelty that took place here are very shocking. You have to remember it's from a communist perspective. Nothing is mentioned of the Americans who were imprisoned here.

Not what you think it is. One expects that this is infamous Hanoi Hilton. Very little of it is devoted to the American servicemen who were imprisoned there; it is much more about the history of the prison and the injustices and tortures done to the Vietnamese by the French. As expected, it is a one sided view, but probably no worse than the one sided view our government espoused during the Vietnam war. It is well worth a visit, and will take about an hour to see. The area of the prison has been redeveloped, and only about 6 rooms or so now holding displays still exist.

Informative . The prison costs 30k VND, the information provided is a mixture of photographs, models, display cabinets, text and audio and video- a good mix. It has some amusing propaganda mixed in with the information provided. Definitely recommend.

Worth the $1.50. Don't expect to see the cell that John McCain was held in and there is quite a bit of propaganda but if you're of a certain age, a visit to the "Hanoi Hilton" is worth the price. However the cyclo- rickshaws will try to take you to the real Hilton Hanoi a few blocks away.

Interesting Site and History Opportunity. This visit was important in learning more about the history of Vietnam and learning about the perspective of the Vietnamese government to French and American involvement. Worth the time and small entrance fee to view the exhibit. The videos (with English captioning) were most insightful to me.
Sinister!. Old French prison, also used for American pow's. High level of propaganda, worth one hour visit. Have a look at the photos and movies

Interesting. A little one-sided but quite well put together and interesting enough for an hour. Some model displays and some pictures of plenty of narration in both English and Vietnamese. Be aware of the scammer taxis that operate outside - stick to the bigger cab companies.

Sobering Place. We visited the 'Hanoi Hilton' with our guide whose father had been in the Vietnam War. It is a sobering place especially the information regarding the cruelty when the French were in power. It's also interesting to see the propaganda relating to the American Pilots who were held there.

Special place inside Hanoi. I was amazed because this site is quite special. Inside the capital of Vietnam, i don't think Vietnamese could maintain its struture with many special evidences from the war period. Highly recommend!!!

Bloody truth of the vietnamese war. For all the history buffs this is must go..It takes you to all the hardships which was enforced upon Vietnamese people by western powerhouses. Statues, Jails, Portraits and even audio recordings are present. A well maintained war site.

Incredible History on Display . It's both fascinating and depressing to walk through this hell on earth that has a miserable history of horrible treatment of people for over a hundred years from both the French and the Vietnamese during their wars.The displays are quite attractive in terms of learning about what happened. One can on,y imagine what it was like for the American POW's imprisoned there.The propaganda films showing how well the prisoners were treated shows how twisted the truth can be.Highly recommended

Worth The Visit. I enjoy history so it was worth the visit. The part where they kept the Vietnamese prisoners was still intact but not so much the part where they kept the Americans. You do get a feel of what it was like to be there, alhough the propaganda of how well they treated the American prisoners was a little disconcerting. I enjoyed the info and photos of how they got John McCain from his crashed jet since he was the most famous of the American prisoners. Well worth the small entrance fee.

Much no longer exists (torn down for a hotel), but still interesting. There is a small entrance fee, but do not expect to be able to see the cells where the American POWs were held. Those are gone. However, you can see much about Vietnamese prisoners held by the French here (in total barbarity). There is an exhibit about the US POWs, but it is total propaganda indicating how well they were treated. I am glad that I went, but it still was somewhat disappointing.

Worth seeing. Takes about an hour. Hard to believe all of this happened relatively recently. Will have to do some more research myself... I was doubtful as far as some of the info was concerned... that the Americans prisoners were treated as well as they are portrayed in the prison information... not sure why Americans were even involved. As I said, I am interested to do my own research now. This prison has got me asking alot of questions...

Very interesting visit. This attraction is worth a visit. Entry price was minimal. Not much of the original building itself is left though which is sad. Best to do your own research on the events that took place in and around the building before you go. Interesting nonetheless.

Interesting and haunting at the same time.... For US citizens, this is very interesting and at the same time moderately uncomfrtable, however, I feel it is well worth a trip for all. Somewhat slanted view on things, but nevertheless a haunting reminder of history.

Hanoi Hilton a step back in time!. This prison was built by the French who tortured Vietnamese who resisted them. Would we have gone to war for the French if we had known what they did to the Vietnamese people?

Learn the brutality. I think not the whole prison is still intact. Perhaps just a partial as what I've seen from its mini model of the actual prison. I suggest you get a guide for your visit. Pretty interesting history.

Interesting and worth a visit. The exhibits in the prison were really interesting and while depressing to see how humans can be so inhumane it was thought provoking. Shocking to see that women and children were also imprisoned here.

Significant Historic Site. 80 % of prison land was taken for development by city. What remains is well worth the visit. Displays are in Vietnamese and English. This info gives a good insight into who was kept there and how they were treated as prisoners. It's right in town and very easy to get to.

Very interesting. Could spend many hours here, was very interesting as I didn't know much about the French and American war before coming to the prison but it was a real eye opener and very interactive rather than just reading. Only 40000 dong to get in and worth getting the 20000 dong information book to read

Like many other Vietnamese museums.... ...this one also lacks an appropriate presentation of the prison's history and information provided is rather decent. However, parts of it are interesting, such as the very detailed story of American pilots inmprisoned here during Vietnam war.Anyway, it is only 30k Dong and if you pass by on your way to the women's museum it is definitely worth it to step in.

Thought-provoking. To Westerners, the "Hanoi Hilton" is remembered as the place where Senator John McCain and other soldiers captured during the Vietnam War were imprisoned. Only a couple of small displays here chronicle that time period, and what there is paints an unrealistically positive picture of prison life. Most of the museum, though, is devoted to the facility's earlier use by the French colonial administration as a place to incarcerate, and sometimes execute, political prisoners. If you visit, you'll leave with a much better understanding of the Vietnamese struggle for self-determination.

Interesting, but lacked information. I enjoyed the prison visit, but I would have liked more information and stories. I don't think the exhibits were very well presented, it felt a bit disjointed at times. It was difficult to make an emotional connection with the people that were imprisoned there, and I would have liked to hear more about the human side of the story. Perhaps a guided visit would have been better!

A very interesting visit. A very interesting place to visit, with some great surround areas to explore too. I didn't have as much time as I would have liked to look around, but what I did see was fascinating and I don't think it really needs too much time to see everything.

Good Vietnam History Lesson. Good tour not too far away from the Old Quater and good price for entry at 30000 VND each. Explains the history of how the French treated the Vietnamese for around 55 years in this area, very informing. The tour also explains how the prison was used to house Amercian pilots shot down during the Amercian/Vietnam war. Well worth a visit just a shame the majority of the prison has gone to make way for a tower block!

A must do in Hanoi. Very informative "museum". An eye opener of the human spirit, though some propaganda in play here. Nonetheless it is something every visitor of Hanoi should make time for. Plus as bonus it was very clean, including the bathrooms
Worth a visit!. This was a very interesting and informative trip! Definitely worth a visit. They have a lot of info to read and it's all translated into English for us tourists!

Not on main to yes but worth taking time to visit. Can be harrowing some of the reading but the Hanoi Hilston is worth the walk to see. It's close to the posh shopping area of the French Quarter so take an our out of your shopping to see. Entry fee only about £1.50.

Quite confronting. This is a place that you will have mixed feelings about after visiting. The way that the prisoners were treated and the pictures of the actual prisoners is a little disturbing. To see pictures of the heads of prisoners that had been to the guillotine next to the actual guillotine used left a chill down my spine. Anyways, still worth a visit to understand some more of Vietnam's history.

Confronting but really worthwhile to see. A really interesting insight into tragic recent times in the history of North Vietnam. The displays were good and your could get a sense of just how harsh it was. Also details of the amazing courage the North Vietnamese showed in protecting Hanoi.

Interesting Visit. I spent around 1.5 hours here & found it very interesting. the information ranged from the building of the prison right through to the use during the Vietnam war with USA. Good amount of information & exhibits including some first hand accounts of experiences in the prison. Definitely worth a visit.

Very Intersting visit!. Most of the original prison is gone, but a substantial portion of the prisoner areas remain on display. For Americans the prison is remembered as a place for capture American pilots (the "Hanoi Hilton"). However, most of the displays at the prison have to do with the French atrocities against the Vietnamese people starting much earlier. Inexpensive to visit and really worth the time and money if you are familiar with that era at all.
Interesting but not mind blowing . This was fairly interesting and is quite sad however I didn't find it mind blowing. I don't regret going but I don't consider it a "must see".

Excellent. It was really interesting to see all of this and how they kept them chained up. You can even get to stand locked up in one of the cells. Really horrible feeling when they close the heavy cell door.Great day would recommend

Reasonable price but bias . Entrance fee was 3,000,000 each which I thought was good.It's very interesting to see the real prison.But I agree with some of the other comments the museum seemed very bias.
Amazing. I came here in the tour and it was amazing.A bit scary for me but my friend loved it because he like to understand the strategy Vietnamese used in the war

Worth a look, a cheap quick history lesson. Perfect for a quick lesson on the history of Vietnam and the suffering the people endured, not worth a cross country trek but if your in the area it's a great way to spend an hour or so

A very eye opening experience; albeit a little bias. Thoroughly enjoyed my walk around Hoa Lo Prison. I'm not a history buff, so I virtually knew nothing before visiting. I bought one of the information books they sell at the ticket booth, and read the information in the book alongside the information in each of the section of the prison. Definitely very interesting and eye opening. Very sad. However, I feel it was somewhat bias ... But if you keep this in mind when visiting, it's easy to get over.

You can see a real prison!. Old prison made by France, you can see real prison along with some miniatures of people and history behind, also there are videos for you to watch with English subtitle to understand more about Vietnam history.

Very interesting. Dont miss it!. Take your time here, and try to get a real understanding of what happened in this prison with the french colony and their fight against independence. It is amazing.
The space itself is quite small therefore take your time and what they have done to make it into a museum is great.

Bit disappointing. Probably my fault, but I've expected more. "It was hell for Vietnamese prisoners under the Western rule" .I totally believe that. "It's been boy scout camp for western prisoners under VC". Bit harder to swallow.

Not worth a special trip. There is not much left of the original prison so it depends heavily on photos and literature to try and convey what it was like,there is lots of propaganda in there as we so I didn't feel I was getting an unbiased view about how the prison was run, it was quite interesting but not worth going out of your way to visit
Edifying!. Myself being from Vietnamese descent, it was nice to know more about my ancestors history and to show it to my fiance, even though I can understand the truth is sometimes hard to bear.
Interesting insight into the French occupation. Guillotine and al - depicted the cruelty of the French during the occupation. A little about the American war as well. Very good value for money
Hard place to visit. The exhibits and history of this prison make it a tough place to visit. Not a big place but interesting to see after hearing so much about the "Hanoi Hilton"
Powerful. The prison museum is shocking and well preserved. Really worth a visit. The crimes commited by the Vietnamese army are obviously glossed over but otherwise it was very interesting.
Good section on American War. Good but short section on American War. Most of the prison focuses on French and political prisoners. Don't need too much time to see this one but worth a short trip.

Great experience. Really enjoyed this tour, it had some nice photographic records and did a good job at providing English descriptions. You don't really ends a guide to do this and can do it on your own.

Hanoi Hilton. The sign over the door reads Maison Centrale, reflecting the French heritage of this prison that originally housed political dissidents and later American airmen. Only the main prison building remains. The quarters where John McCain and others were housed have been replaced by a modern highrise.

Well organized - learn Vietnam's perspective of the story. Even if you do not have a tour guide, you can visit it self-paced as all signs are in English. You even get a booklet that provides further information. There is a small courtyard where you can rest for a bit between inner buildings. You learn a lot about things that you would otherwise never know and this prison's story is an important phase of Vietnam's history.

Bit grim but very worthwhile . Unfortunately the majority of the site of the former prison has been given over to a luxury tower block, somewhat spoiling the poignancy of the visit.However, the oppressive nature of the French Colonial prison still pervades and the death cells and guillotine make it clear how brutal that regime was, forcing men to escape through tiny gaps cut in iron bars in the sewer system!Really enjoyed the section devoted to the Hanoi Hilton phases when US airmen were held here. A lot of frankly laughable propaganda but it does show that NVA were all over their corporate communications way before the West and, indeed, they are still doing s better job.Not light hearted but an important piece of history not to be missed.
Glad I wasn't incarcerated here!. This prison/museum was interesting, but my knowledge of Vietnamese history is scant so I did not truly have a grasp on the background.

Sobering, insightful visit. We visited this prison with our Hanoikids tour. Very interesting to see the two phases the prison went through. Highly recommend going with a local, our guide was great, unbiased and very informative.

Interesting visit. The prison was just next to where we were staying - Somerset serviced apartment. Very interesting visit to the museum. Gives a well-rounded perspective of the Vietnam war with alot of historical artefacts displayed.

THE Hanoi Hilton. Joke aside, this is a mind bending tour... very interesting and shocking (at times) to see, hear, and read about the history of this prison from Frecnh colonial times until the Vietnam War era. More interesting and eye opening is to view it from the eyes of the Vietnamese and what they were shown during the war. Much different than what we saw in the US. A lot to take in, and very emotional.

Fact or fiction?. Visited the site wanting to see the Hanoi Hilton.On arrival we were guided through the history of the prison from French rule through to the housing of US pilots during the Vietnam War. It is hard to believe how the French treated Vietnamese men and women for not agreeing with the French view. Depending on the guide will you be able to leave with a balanced view. Our guide was fine but as a youngster she was able to give a versionAcceptable to the party when it came to the treatment of US airman including John McCain. The reasons for their treatment whilst imprisoned was down to the indiscriminate bombing of North Vietnam. The sentence uttered "if you are in prison you cannot expect to be treated well", gave a true understanding of what went on. It is ironic therefore that the heavy criticism of the French was not evident in their own treatment of the U.S. Prisoners. Worthwhile visit but unlike many similar sites in Europe does not give a full picture and is clearly selective in what it says.

Interesting to see the building but don't expect too much information. We were glad we went here, but it was a propaganda exercise offering a biased view. If you take what they say with a pinch of salt and check out what happened here independently it's worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton... The Prison. The prison showed the poor conditions the Vietnamese prisoners endured during the French regime in Vietnam. It's sad the French still used the Guillotine for executions until 1932!
Insight to the past. Walking through the museum offers a good insight into the last 100 years, or so, of Vietnamese history. And it takes a fairly short amount of time.

So Biased it Hurts. If you are going with the intention to tour the prison because of it's role during the Vietnam War, you will be disappointed. The Hoa Lo Prison was built by the French in the early 1900s to imprison Vietnamese revolutionaries, so about 90% of the prison is dedicated to their struggle. There is 1 room dedicated to the Americans there during the Vietnam War. I have done significant research and study on the American POWs in the Hoa Lo Prison, and unfortunately the Prison does not reflect ANY of the hardships the POWs faced. Granted, these hardships were in the hands of the Vietnamese. I understand that the prison is going to show the Vietnamese point of view, but the way they articulated and displayed the American experience in the Hanoi Hilton made it look as though they spent 7 years in a Vietnamese themed Disneyland. All that to say--make sure you do your homework before you go so that you know what is the truth about what happened there during the Vietnam War, as you will be misled if your only source of information is from the exhibits.

Chilling. Built by the French to lock up the so called 'trouble makers'.Made them in such degrading conditions, women locked up with their children. Men put in stocks held by their ankles, women with yokes around their necks.Then it became a place where the captured Americans were kept. conditions were much better but it was still a prison and you don't get good food in a prison. Known as the Ha Noi Hilton.
Excellent presentation.. Really enjoyed this museum, well laid out displays. Gave us a great insight into the earful past of this notorious prison.l
Boring. The museum just didn't communicate the story of the site very well at all, so i found it rather boring, could have been so much better.

Interesting Point of Interest. The Hoa Lo Prison is also know as the "Hanoi Hilton" by John McCain.It is now a museum and offers a full history, from the North Vietnamese perspective of the prison and prisoners. Built by the French during the colonial period, the methods of torture include a guillotine and leg shackles. Terrible things took place there. A fascinating and complete account. But there is a lot to read and some improvements might include more interactive exhibits.
A Prison with an interesting history. Visit this Prison to experience where John McCain stayed as a Prisoner for 5.5 years during Vietnam war.

Very intriguing!!!. This place is great, it really gives you a sense of how the prisoners were kept and the conditions they suffered. Plenty of information given in short segments and 'paints' a big overall picture. Plenty of objects and items to see as well as the cells.

Thought it was the Hanoe Hilton but was a lot more. This prison was named the Hoi An Hilton by the USA pilots shot down and captured by Vietnam Con. It dates back much further as a woman's prison when the French were in charge. The women were politely prisoners and the way they were treated was horrific.
Experience . Definitley worth seeing, its an experience to see how life would have been lived inside the prison. Of your on a tight budget there is no need to buy the guide book

A Sad Look Back!!!. War is hell and this place is a reminder of that adage. It is definitely a one sided view as you might expect but the fact remains it is another vivid example of man's inhumanity to man!!!

Interesting prison. Tough place to visit. Definitely interesting. Go if you're a history buff or would like to know more about the history of the prison, especially during the Vietnam war. Very one-sided portrayal of the war. That's expected. There's an exhibit about how well the American POWs were treated, allowed to play basketball, celebrate Christmas, etc. There are lots of photos and videos of this fair treatment. However, we know from the memoirs of some of these POWs (John McCain most famously) that not all was "peachy" at the Hanoi Hilton.

A Two Hour Step Back in Time. Towards the end of our four days, we were starting to struggle for activities to do. Decided to swing by the prison which was a short walk from our Old Quarter hotel. Part of the original prison had been torn down, but the remaining portion had been rehabilitated into a prison museum depicting its history during the French occupation and then the Vietnam War. We honestly had low expectations but found it to be educational and interesting. There's a definite bias against the Imperial aggressors here in the museum descriptions, but we expected that (note that angry/happy music choices in the different rooms). That doesn't mean anything though, as the front desk was incredibly pleasant letting two of us aggressors in. Don't expect to make a day trip out of this, I felt we digested it pretty well in about 2 hours.

Good example of man's inhumanity. There are no signs to show where the prison is and most of it is now taken up with a large multi storey building on the site, which can misdirect you from finding it. Though once inside the prison allows you to see what conditions where like for the male and female inmates, appalling. They have the guillotine in one room that can send a chill down your spine and dummies in some cells so you may understand the cramp conditions. As other reviews have stated there is quite a bit of propaganda, which is expected, but does not detract from the experience. Cost 30,000VD each
Interesting. Worth a visit for an hour or so. Some interesting stuff to learn here - although the American propaganda about the visiting GI's was a joke. Made it out to be like a holiday camp
For the history geeks. If you're into your history, especially that of the vietnam war, this place is a great place to visit. Also known as the Hanoi Hilton during the war by Americans

Insightful and interesting. This is a must see if you're visiting Hanoi. It doesn't take too much time, it's relatively small, but worth the visit. It shows both aspects from the revolution and the Vietnam war agains the Americans. John McCain's uniform is here, among other artifacts.

Haunting! . I wasn't sure I wanted to visit the Hanoi Hilton, I'm really glad I did! The suffering that went on in there is well documented, you just can't imagine being in there place, the poems and letter they wrote before they were executed I wish had been translated, I would have liked to have read them. Worth a visit even though it is quite morbid.
A Must See. If you are in Hanoi this should be on your list of places to see. Save your money n time n don't bother with the National Museum

A Symbol of Colonialism and War. This is well worth visiting. From the cells used to house VietNamese during the French and Japanese occupation to the historical artifacts and photographs of Americans held here during what Vietnamese call "The American War"

Very interesting. Amazing to think how bad they were treated all those years ago. They even pulled up an old drain on display the actual one a prisoner dug underground and crawl under the drain system

Learning more history . We went there for learning more about the history and to get the "feeling" how people in prison had it. It was very nice to see, but next time we will have a guid with us. Then we can learn more. But still a must place to go when you are in Hanoi.

Interesting Enough. I found Hoa Lo Prison interesting enough, my husband not so much. I guess it depends on the person, perhaps it will give you an insight as to what happened here, perhaps not, it also depends on who is telling the story and what you believe. I would recommend it if you have time, you only need and hour to walk the circuit.
Prison of colonial French. This place shows what was happening the conditions of Vietnam under the French.I felt a little bit horrible.But it is an interesting place with a few price.
thought provoking and interesting. Startling look at the prison that originally was used by the French, then the Vietnamese. Calls into question how prisoners were treated.

Interesting yet freaky. I enjoyed visiting the prison but it also freaked me out abit...after reading the history and knowing what went on there, Seeing the cells and how prisoners were kept etc was educational yet horrific. Good entry price at just 30,000vd spent about 1.5hours there..
Good to see . Worth a visit if you're in the area. We spent about an hour there and that was enough. Interesting historically and the entry fee is small.

Important history, but full of propaganda. The museum that has been made of the section remaining from the old Hoa Lo Prison ("Hanoi Hilton") is a reminder of the tragic events that have occurred in Vietnam's history. The museum retains some of the original character and artifacts from the prison era, although the area describing conditions of the American pilots who were held there grossly mis-represents reality. The local tour guides also offer a very skewed point of view, which has been influenced by government propaganda. It is certainly worth a visit as it has extreme significance in the shaping of culture and history, but consider reading some historical accounts of the prison to go along with the visit.

Its not Alcatraz.... Typically political, with some nice spooky features like a model guillotine & statues of pretend prisoners.Took about 30 mins. to get around - a reasonable boredom killer. Doesn't tell a story like it should - such an interesting history in this country, its fair to expect more.Could be a lot better, hard to recommend as is.
Makes you think . Worth a short visit if your in the area. Its cheap to enter, like most things. Covers a dark part og the history

Good Historical Place. Prison Hoa Lo Prison in Vietnam is known terrible and filled with melancholy story, the prison was used to torture prisoners of war brutally.
They make some sculptures as the reenactment of historical events that have occurred there. Also there to tell about some of the resistance who had could escape through the drains.
A great way to learn history.

The "Hanoi Hilton". Firstly a prison of the colonial French, and finally of the communist North Vietnamese, the exhibits show clearly the barbaric conditions of the place... under the French! Judging by the photos of the American prisoners of war they show, it was more like a holiday camp under the communists. It is clearly biased (and very unsubtly so), but it is worth a visit. (It's also where the American Senator, John McCain, was held prisoner.)

Worth an hour or two. The entry fee is next to nothing and it will take around an hour and a half to walk around and get a feel for the place and the stories. As you would expect the displays and presentations are very bias towards the victorious Vietnamese and less positive towards the French and Americans so a pinch of salt is needed when reading to get a more balanced view. That said still very much worth a visit. Dont bother with the guide book (pamphlet) they offer you when you buy the tickets unless you want it as a souvenir. Pretty much all the information in it is repeated on boards as you walk around the building. Toilets here are pretty good too.

Propaganda. We left the museum after a very short time. A load of propaganda..it is probably true that the life in prison was horrible for the Vietnamese inmates but it is very hard to belive that the Vietnamese were so nice and lovely to the American inmates..Sorry but we did not buy that

Harrowing. This is a really interesting place to visit (also known as the Hanoi Hilton). It was really difficult to stop and read about the horrors what were inflicted its inhabitants over the years. I am glad I went (I think) but the images and stories have stayed with me.

One-Sided Presentaion, but Still Worth Seeing. My wife and I visited the Hoa Lo Prison on a Saturday in mid-January. Tickets were 30,000 dong each ($1.33 or 1.23 Euro). The exhibits explain how the French imprisoned Vietnamese here during the colonial era - then how the Vietnamese later imprisoned French and Americans here. The information seems a little one-sided (for instance, there is information about the "excellent" care and conditions for US Senator John McCain while he was a POW here - when the reality is that he was beaten and tortured). So - definitely visit since this is important history, but also educate yourself about the rest of the story.

An insight into history and conditions. Part of the Hoa Lo prison has been made into a museum. Opportunity to walk around with interesting fact boards in local, English and French language. Probably 46-90 minutes is sufficient time depending on how interested to you are in all the information available.

Interesting for Short Visit. I went there with my Hanoi Kids guide; it was interesting to see Vietnam’s perspective on the Vietnam War and the prisoners they held. I also learned a lot about Vietnam’s history under French rule.

Great museum. If you only go to 1 museum in Hanoi make it this one. Really interesting with good explanations of the history all the way round and little prior knowledge needed.Also enjoyable is the level of bias in the retelling of history, it's a great example of 'history being told by the victors', in this case the Vietnamese.That said it does not takeaway from how interesting it is.
Great museum. Thoroughly enjoyed walking round the prison exhibit and found it extremely interesting, it was a good wet weather activity

Good site for quick visit. I wanted to see where the American POWs were held. I got there right when they opened and I had the place to myself. I got through the whole place in about 40 minutes. Signs are in English. You definitely see the Vietnamese side of things. A slanted perspective for sure. Glad I went. Could use an audio tour. You don't need more than an hour here and probably can do in 30-45 minutes.

good experience here. I do not know this place until we have visit Hanoi 4 days. It amazing for the history estiblish of this. We are really has got good experience at Hanoi. Only one time here and not good for childrens

More than just the Hanoi Hilton. Yes, there is John McCain stuff here, but the museum sugar coats the experience of American POWs. However, the information about the prison's colonial roots and the experience of the Vietnamese under the French was unknown by me, and it is horrifying. Quite moving

worth the goosebumps. I read many reviews and they all said it was highly recommendable to go and they were all right. You will spend 1-2 hours here. If possible grab a personal tour because there is so many interesting information about this place. Take your time while you here to read and listen to the information provided. You will learn so much and how the Vietnam war was in the days. It gave me goosebumps and to see what these people went though is so sad and scary. Tickets cost 30,000VND but if you're a student bring it along cause it costs much more cheaper.

French vs Vietnamese treatment of prisoners, a victor's view. This was a fascinating journey to a place known by most Americans as Hanoi Hilton, only to find it was more important to the Vietnamese because of the French incarceration of Vietnamese political prisoners there. The trials that the Vietnamese underwent are readily documented-the appalling conditions, the executions by firing squad and guillotine (the guillotine actually used for these executions is there for close inspection). The section on the treatment of American POWs was unfortunately so inaccurate(no mention of literally years of solitary confinement, torture, attempts to use the prisoners as propaganda tools) , that it makes one wonder how many of the incarcerated Vietnamese were actually there for being run of the mill criminals and not for political reasons.It does what a good historical museum should do, makes one think and makes one want to read more about it. A must see.
Interesting. Very cheap (30k) and interesting. Easy walk from the Old Quarter and nice if you have an afternoon free. Took me around 2 hours to go around.
Scary but interesting . It's a very interesting visit to the prison. Especially if your interested on the war and all the different angles of it.
Worth a visit. Most of the exhibition is focused on the treatment of Vietnamese political prisoners by the French.It's also interesting to get a Vietnamese view on the Vietnam War.Well worth a visit.

History. Hoa Lo Prison is a historical relic and was built by the French colonialists to hold Vietnamese patriotic and revolutionary fighters. It was also use to hold criminals and American pilots who were shot down during their war. Whoever like to know about the war history of Vietnam, it is a must visit place.
interesting insight. The prision is worth a visit if you want to learn about history of hanoi. Doesn't go into hanoi hilton as much as I would have thought though

Good to know!. Well-kept, clean, pleasantly set up together shows with an alternate point of view than we as Americans see things. You'd never figure that our POWs were tormented brutally there from what these presentations depict. I left away exceptionally appreciative that my father, who's prepared and flown with some of those caught, never served in Viet Nam.

Gruesome and interesting. The old guillotine is a bit gruesome to see but this is a fascinating historical prison. The McCain stuff is an obvious highlight but there's quite a bit of interest here including from the French occupation.
Interesting visit. Very interesting visit To learn about Vietnam history and war. Some pictures and remakes about terrible prisoners lifes can impress
Enlighten . Spooky draw you own conclusions propaganda or not ??? I know which side I am on !Do you after a visit a must to see. Put this on your list to see while still you are visiting

Hanoi Hilton. As an American, this was an interesting stop. The prison focuses on the horrible treatment the Vietnamese prisoners suffered at the hands of the French. There is a small presentation re: American pilots held by the VietCong. The americans are presented as a happy bunch playing basketball and smiling. It is interesting to hear from the other side, but take the propaganda with a grain of salt.

lame. a museum with very little inside of it. cool that its in the actual prison but there aren't any cool artifacts and the narrative doesn't dive into any specific (interesting) stories.essentially a wikipedia page IRL.

Historic Hanoi. What an interesting place to visit and wander around. Learning the history and the stories from Hao Lo Prison was an very surreal experience. It is exceptionally presented in whats left of the prison and definitely worth a visit when visiting Hanoi

Good but not super chilling. The museum was very interesting, however it didn't exude that 'dark' vibe; given the prison's history. I was very informative and I'd recommend anyone visiting Hanoi to go. It doesn't take too long to walk through, and hour at most.

Done in one or two hours. It obviously has an historical significance, but i ve been to other prisons which have been more interesting. It does have a couple of highlights and its cheap, so not a bad thing to do.

Understanding the history. It was correct to visit the Hoa Lo Prison to understand some of the history. The tour was easy to navigate around and a recorded loop telling you about the place, available in English and I maybe in Fench also??? ( only two headphones available, likely not enough). Enough things to see and worth a visit.

History interpreted. It's always interesting to see history from another point of view. It may appear to be propaganda, but if you look deeper the facts appear correct and only the interpretation varies. Worth the time and small expense.
History. Visited here recently and found the history very interesting. The display is detailed and very informative. Worth a visit.

Interesting; propoganda. Well-kept, clean, nicely put together displays with a different perspective than we as Americans see things. You'd never guess that our POWs were tortured mercilessly there from what these displays portray. I came away very grateful that my dad, who's trained and flown with some of those captured, never served in VNam.

An important place to visit. This was a very moving experience. This museum demonstrated the pain and suffering of the Vietnamese under the rule of the French and then how the space was used during the Vietnam War. Many interesting exhibits and information. We took a rickshaw from the Old Quarter but we walked back. It was an easy distance to stroll. The entrance fee is very small and the information booklet is worth buying as it gives a great deal of background information.
Very nicely done. The Vietnamese have done a great job documenting this historical place. Displays very well done and informative. Well worth the time.

Worth a visit . Easy to get to and very interesting. Entry is cheap so why not right? The video portraying the living conditions for the American pilots is quite amusing when you find out they were treated a lot worse.

Colonial torture and recent history. Th French built the prison (known as maison centrale) for political prisoners and when you see the pictures and the story told you see the torture inflicted on the inmates. The mobile guillotine is still there. The prison became a breeding ground for the Communist party - at least 5 general secretaries of the party spent time in the maison centrale. The Norh Vietnamese used the prison for US POWs and it became known as the Hanoi Hilton. The American experience - compared to the colonial part - is shown as barracks which may not reflect the horror that was experienced by those who were kept there. If you are after first hand experience: John McCain spent 6 years there, he talks about his experience in his book 'Faith of my Fathers'. He was treated so badly that he was not expected to surcvive the experience. I left with the feeling that the colonial experience was depicted in all its brutality while the subsequent use during the Vietnam War was seen as a place less harsh. It is impressive, a large part was demolished to make space for the Hanoi Towers. There is a small courtyard to sit in the shade and to reflect. It was on my itinerary on the basis that the Vietnam War was the first war which I followed as a current event, not something I read about as history.

Multiple eras of sad history. Its good to know at least a little of the history hear before you arrive. The Vietnamese people that are in charge of this site tell a very biased story of how well they treated prisoners. Many countries tell a biased history and omit key facts, and so unfortunately this is what you will deal with here. That said the Vietnamese people in general are very welcoming and friendly especially if you make an effort to speak their language a little.

Wow . The prison has a long history going back to French colonial times and ending with the American war. From what is shown there were extreme atrocities by the French towards the Vietnamese revolutionaries. They still have one of the guiliotine that was used displayed here.
Only a few rooms remain. They focus on the place being a French prison. Most of it torn down for an office building. Not worth the time unless you want a picture in front of the gate.

Hanoi Hilton. this is a very interesting place, and a good place to visit on a rainy day. most interesting naturally is their take on history. its very different from our story. Factually I learnt a lot, there were stories that I had not been told and was oblivious to. Naturally propaganda is at play but none the less definitely worth a visit

A sad experience. The remnant of the Hoa Lo prison is available as a tourist destination. However it is just a fragment of the original prison as most of it has been destroyed and replaced with a shopping centre.There is a miscellany of photos of people suffering, but I did not think the presentation was balanced or helpful in understanding the use of this prison during the several different eras through which it was used. Most presentations were dusty and seemed to be neglected, even though the place seemed quite busy.On balabce I do not think this is worth the effort.

Eerie but a a must see!. Long endless damp dungeons, scary stories and the history of a developing country's brave struggle -- The Hoa Lo Prison is a must visit if you have patience and are looking for some soul searching and not just pretty pics during your trip. The museum chronicles the crude and inhuman ways in which the Vietnamese were tortured in prison by the French, their living quarters and the most ghastly of them all -the French guillotine. While there isn't an audio device offered at the museum, you can buy a small booklet that details the museum exhibits and watch some of the video stories being played out in different sections. The museum also was home to American soldiers for over a year till the treaty for their handover was signed post the war -- their living conditions being far better and humane than the living conditions for the Vietnamese in the same jail. This place oddly reminds me of Dachau -- the latter being scarier and creeping me out completely with its almost eerie silence and dampness. Would certainly recommend a visit to Hoa Lo, if not for touristic inquisitiveness but to honour those who gave up their lives in war and after.

Vietnam version of facility over 3 wars and many years. Limited portions remains of the Hoa Lo Prison (Hanoi Hilton). Most of the review is of the Vietnamese prisoners from the "French War". There is some review of the "American War"

Interesting "history" lesson. This was an interesting stop and taught us a lot about Vietnamese history, and also about the propoganda of Vietnamese history. Reading the depictions of how Vietnamese people were treated by the "cunning imperialist" French and then the "cruel" Americans...certainly provides another perspective!

The Hanoi Hilton-a different perspective. Much of the exhibits in Hoa Lo Prison revolve around its history and the French treatment of prisoners.However as an American I was more interested in the portion of its history that occurred during the Vietnam War. We called it the Hanoi Hilton.It was interesting to see John McCain's flying suit as well as pictures showing his capture.The Vietnamese government's take on this prison is very different from America's. Exhibits depict the prison as almost being a "county club" for captured American POWs. This has to be contrasted with a replica of an American prison at the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City. There the Americans are portrayed as barbarians.Moving forward to today I found the Vietnamese people to be extremely friendly toward Americans.
Certainly interesting. Similar to other prison museums. Plays up Vietnam's awesomeness, as to be expected. Certainly worth a stroll. Interesting history!

Gotta see to understand the history. The fabled prison of the war in Viet Nam. You meet the people and look around the country---and ask yourself---"what was that damned war all about?" A tour of this prison gives you a perspective and clarity to some of the stories you heard about what was going on during the war. As horrific as it is/was, it is a landmark which should be seen by all visitors.

A must see. Definitely worth a visit to this famous site in Hanoi. The layout was really good and made navigating through the prison a breeze. There's a lot of interesting history here as well and everything is clearly explained. Would recommend to anyone visiting Hanoi.

Sobering. A chance to see a part of colonial Indochine. It was pretty sobering. Also contained in the Prison Museum was a section devoted to the American pilot POWs. Interesting. I would recommend visiting.

Propoganda but still interesting . The museum is confronting on war. The war against the French seems to have the strongest language in terms of the displays. For the American war, the stories on the well kept prisoners and the global opposition to the American involvement (East German protests ??) tests the truth. For a counter argument John Mccain's piece on his internment over five years is an interesting read.A good 90 mins though.

Not to be missed!. Long history of oppression, not only the French but the Japanese. Then there was the Vietnam War, which the Vietnamese call the American war. American pilots captured during the Vietnamese War were kept in Hoa Lo and known as the Hanoi Hilton! A must see in Hanoi!

The famous 'Hanoi Hilton'. Had we not heard of the Hanoi Hilton, we would not have visited it. Most has been demolished, with a large apartment building having been built on the land adjacent to what's now the tourist attraction, where John McCain and many other U. S. flyers were imprisoned and tortured, kept in small cells, etc., for years. Now mainly a No. Vietnamese propaganda sight, showing smiling U. S. prisoners, etc., as well as the leg irons by which they had been confined to their beds...at least those lucky enough to sleep in dorms rather than small cells. The guillotine is also an interesting site. Along with the many photos of prisoners' heads after their separation from their bodies. Not much of a gift shop. But worth the half hour to see what's left of the joint.

Otherwise known as Hanoi Hilton. This is a must see of great historical interest. The period when this was a French prison for the anti colonialist groups is more important than the period when captured US pilots were held here. Of course, history is always told by the victors so propaganda is at its highest level.

Must see for Americans. Keep an open mind and know that our government has their own propaganda videos. The pics of our captured soldiers playing volleyball and being treated so well was fascinating. Who knows how true it is; ask McCain.

Worth a look. The original wall with broken glass sets the scene for this tourist attraction. Walk though cells which are dark and in original state with excellent notes to read, especially the section on Vietnam/American war. One of the few places you can visit without a local guide. Check it out!

Educational and gives a sense of the history of the area. This was both fascinating and sobering. It was originally built over the site of a village with temples and the story goes that the French colonialists made the village move elsewhere so they could build their prison. Many Vietnamese were imprisoned here by the French and the conditions appeared to be deplorable. It reminded me of visiting the concentration camps in Germany. Here we saw the guillotine that was used to execute prisoners, complete with a photograph of some heads which was a bit grisly.After viewing the cells there were some rooms then that talked about the American war from the 60s-70s which I found very interesting. There was one room dedicated to photographs showing many other countries protesting American involvement. Then another room talking about the number of pilots that were shot down over Vietnam. Then one last room showing photos and videos demonstrating how well the Americans were treated in Hoa Lo.

Ok to pass the time.. This could be a real eye opener about the colonialism in Indochina. Sadly there's not a lott of feeling behind the exebitions. A walking stick is described as a walking stick. Thay have a lot of objects but they don't tell the story behind them. Maby better in other languages, but the signs in English are really poor.
Interesting with a bit of propaganda. Good display of the prison's history during the French colonial area but lack of the "Hilton Hanoi" story during the Vietnam war

Very good for people who are interested in History. You have to pay a nominal charge to visit it. Felt sad to see how the prisoners were kept here. Very educational. A must visit for people who are interested in history. Very easy to access if you are staying in Old Quarter.
UNBELIEVABLE BUT TRUE . Worth visiting to see what happened to inmates but most importantly the Americans held for many years - hardships , disease , executions - very lifelike & informative 🙏

Interesting but bias. The prison was very interesting and well set out. It he. Information regarding both the French and American war. It is hard to know what is true being a westerners but it seemed that it was full of propaganda. There were nice gifts to buy and it was good to see the other side of the stories.

How Lo Prison . My family visited Hoa Lo prison on a city tour and we really enjoyed our visit. We have all seen several movies that involved the prison ( 'Unbreakable' being the most recent). Very interesting history, although it made the U.S. POW's look like they were at summer camp during their captivity.

Top attraction in Ha Noi. This is a must see attraction in central Ha Noi. This is a prison complex that has held both Vietnamese and American fighter pilot prisoners during different periods of its history. There are several written displays that helped visitors understand the different periods. It is a very important part of local history. Highly educational for visitors. There is a small snack area and there is a fee to enter. Spent about 2 hours. Very good for rainy day. Went in March, 2013.

Interesting from Vietnamese Perspective. This is the "Hanoi Hilton". It emphasizes the French occupation and what the French used the prison for more than the American prisoners. It was built by the French and the Americans gave it the nickname that it has today. There is a small portion at the end with photos of American prisoners -- all smiles and laughter. Different perspective than what American viewpoint is.

Needs a stomach of steel!. Only for the brave hearted souls, who choose to venture here! The stories and recounting of the atrocities need a stomach of steel to digest! It is disturbing to say the least, but well preserved and tells a heart wrenching story, one to be known to the world! A well curated and informative museum.

Insightful historical tour. The prison mainly covered the history behind the use of the prison to imprison political prisoners. There were pretty graphic installations on exhibition such as the guillotine and detention cells - so visitors with kids may wish to take note. There was a section on the Vietnam war and recordings of American Pilots POWs praising the Vietnamese government for good, humane treatment during their stay in the Prison (personal discernment on the intended political statement is at own discretion...). Overall is a good insightful visit.

Interesting. We almost missed this but ended up going on our last day in Hanoi. Very interesting, a lot of information about Vietnamese history from the french occupation to the war. Can be somewhat confronting though.
intersting and shocking all in 1. this is a must see if your visiting Hanoi, Best to have a local guide or private tour to get the most out of the experience.

Interesting but only limited perspective. Was interesting and shocking. We had a local guide with us with whom we discussed a lot during the visit about the museum and culture. Otherwise it would have been less exciting

Interesting. Worth seeing. Probably not a "must see" though . Worth a visit. We visited this as part of a few hours with a cyclo driver.
Very interesting prison and conditions. Interesting story, perspective and history.
The size of some of the escape routes are astonishing!
Expect to spend 1-2 hours here.
3.5 / 5
Worth a visit.. Although the museum/prison is very one sided (Vietnam perspective) it is still worth a visit. Very well put together.

Really interesting and well presented . This is one of the better museums we visited in Vietnam in terms of presentation and interpretation in English.
The prison has a really interesting history - we enjoyed our visit.
Interesting. If you are into history and reading you will not be dissapointed. I can recommend this place along with the other museums. You can do most of them in a day or two.

Hanoi Hilton (Hoa Lo Prison ). Worthwhile visit of what remains of the original prison run during the French colonisation. You get a good idea of how barbaric conditions were from the cells, leg irons and guillotine.Some of the exhibits are of course biased towards the martyrs who resisted the French without any explanation of their "crimes " . Chilling to think the place was still operational until fairly recent times.

Terrifying yet mesmerizing. This place is a must see if you are into the history of the people. I always thought the French reasonably civilized. But my goodness what they did to the Vietnamese people was disgraceful. Mind you the Vietnamese treated their own people very badly too. The visit made me realize how lucky I am. War sucks but the stories here are fascinating and it's definitely worth a visit.

Very Interesting, Informative & Sad . This place was an eye opener for me. I learned a lot. Some of the things you see broke my heart. Very organized displays.I believe it was $3 total for 2 of us. You can buy a booklet at the front to follow along with the exhibits for an additional $1.
Good for an historic tour. Looking into the depths of an ancient prison, this museum offers an insight to the goings on in prison life back then.

Very interesting but very skewed. Absolutely fascinating place and very well laid-out and translated museum, but basically pure propaganda. Much is (rightly) made of the atrocities committed by French gaolers and American bombers, but it's resoundingly silent on any ill-treatment of American pilot POWs. Indeed, all photos are of the American pilots playing volleyball, having Christmas dinner, several of John "I was beaten so badly in Hoa Lo that I can no longer raise my arms" McCain looking perfectly content. Worth visiting, but research both sides of the story before going.

A thought provoking site. Well preserved collection of political prison used by french colonist during Vietnam invasion. The video and audio archive at museum takes you back centuries to actual site. Must visit place if you interested in Vietnam history.

Interesting . This is an interesting place to visit. It gives you a look at what POW'S had to endure here and also the Vietnamese during the French occupation.
Worth the 1-2 hr time it will take you.
The Hanoi Hilton. Certainly worthy of a spot in your itinerary if you are traveling to Hanoi. You will be given a Vietnamese prospective on the Vietnam war.

Worth the visit. Although this tourist attraction information has been sanitised by the Government censor, it is still worth a visit for the in depth coverage of the suffering of the Vietnamese people under French colonial rule. The Emphasis is 90% on this with only a short "extra sanitised" version of the excellent treatment given to the US pilots incarcerated there in the "Hanoi Hilton". One could be forgiven for wondering why these pilots ever wanted to return home!
Interesting view on prison life. Interesting museum showing life in the prison. Use models and photos to depict how it worked, but nothing too graphic.

Don't miss this thought provoking place. The story of this prison, from French colonial times to its days as the infamous 'Hanoi Hilton' during the Vietnam war, is very well presented with display boards, exhibits and videos.
Must visit. You cant go to hanoi without visitng la prison. It only takes 30 minutes or so. You can take nice pictures inside with the statute prisoners
Do Visit. A worthwhile attraction to visit especially to learn more about the history of Hanoi. About an hour max is all you will need with cheap entry.

The history is amazing. It's incredible to actually learn about the history of this incredible country at the Prison. Steeped in history, it goes through the story of the French and American battles. Definitely worth a visit when in Hanoi, and only about £1 entrance. Well worth every penny

Checked in for a look at the Hanoi Hilton. We went for a tour of the prison with a guide and found the place to be a top visit. I didn't know alot about Vietnam's past, only bit's and pieces about the war, but it was really interesting learning about their accounts of events. Also how earlier prisoners about a centuary ago were treated and punished at the prison. We enjoyed having a guide with us, but didn't feel it a necessity, as we spent a couple of hours just reading the descriptions of each exhibit and watching the few videos on offer through out.

History.. 30.000 to enter, inside you have all videos and all history about the french colonization, you must to be prepared to see same truth. The museum its very nice, clean and with clear explanations about culture. Nice to learn about Vietnam history.

Heartbreaking, but worth a visit.. was a good place to go but heartbreaking to see how people were treated during those times. The prison has lots of information in many languages so is suitable for everyone to visit

Worth the visit. The Hanoi Hilton is definitely worth visiting if you're checking off the major tourist attractions in the city. There's plenty of pictures, information and re creations. Gives you a pretty good idea of how grim it would have been to be imprisoned there. I was surprised to see John McCain's flight suit on display, I had no idea he was imprisoned here. There was also a guillotine on display which was used to execute Vietnamese prisoners. Not the nicest place but very interesting.

A visit to Hoa Lo Prison, aka the 'Hanoi Hilton!. This prison was a 'must-see for me as an American who did 'not serve in the Viet-American War but wanted to know more about the 'North we fought. I did not know how much more infamous this prison was prior to that war; built by the French Colonial rulers of then, Indo-China, where colonists were treated very harshly, including torture and execution for rebelling against their colonial rulers. For military and history buffs, well worth the time.

Sobering insight into Vietnam's past. Interesting historical location that gives visitors a firsthand glimpse at Vietnam's French colonial past and its war with America. It's therefore worth a look.The displays aren't fancy or earth-shattering, but they simply convey the nation's troubled past.

Very interesting. The prison is filled with interesting stories about the prisoners and the way they were treated. It's very sad to see how they had to live.You'll need some time to get to all of the rooms and read through and look at everything

Hanoi Hilton worth a look. Still wondering whether the designation of Hanoi Hilton was sarcastic or actually an appreciation after the horrors of the prisons out in the jungle. Quite an eye-opener and worth a visit.
A must see sobering experience.. Whilst some of the sights are a bit gruesome I think it is important to understand the history of this great country.

Interesting visit. Interesting visit during our time in Hanoi. We went in with open minds and learned a lot about the history of the prison. We weren't disappointed since we had little to no expectations. The portion about US POW's was filled with ridiculous propaganda, but we weren't surprised by it.

A great tribute to the rise of modern Vietnam. Greta remanent of what was a much larger prison complex built by the French colonialist in 1896. It was used extensively by the French powers to hold captured and arrested Vietnamese nationalist leading up to the eventual withdrawal of the French in 1954. Subsequently it was also used to house American prisioner of war during the Vietnam War. The displays are quite graphic and aside fromthe scenes of torture, the descriptions of the daring escapes are amazing.The message of the rise of the nationalist movement and the politics of communism come through strongly with many of the early activist being imprisioned yet still spreading the message and achieving solidarity within the confines of the prison.The real guoilletine display is a harrowing reminder of those harsh days.Its a great tribute to the rise of todays independent Vietnam.

Small but very well done. I spent an hour walking through the museum. It was the prison where John McCain was held during the war and has been called the Hanoi Hilton. Part of the original prison is now a modern high rise complex. What is preserved is respectfully presented with original equipment and rooms. Many pictures with stories and two videos with English subtitles.
Very moving. It was well worth the visit. It was sobering and sad to read how people were treated. It felt very eerie and was an experience worth the visit.

Worth a visit. It's about 15 mins walk from Old Quarters, quite easy to get to if you follow the map. It costs about 30,000 dong to get in, they'll charge you 20,000 dong for a booklet that you will not need unless you want it for keepsake. It's quite dark and eerie, well duh, it's a museum about the prison. It gave me quite the insight on how life was during the war and how the Vietnamese were treated. I felt that the flow could have been better? You can do it within an hour, I believe. The Temple of Literature is pretty close by, so you can walk there after! About another 15 mins walk.
very memorable. Reminded me a lot of the Vietnam war with America. Prison's are always sad and many emotional feelings comes alive

Interesting History, good trip. Interesting historical site which highlighted the hardships Vietnamese prisoners went through at the hands of the French. They have some preserved cells, single person and multi person, which were very eye opening to see. When it moved onto the Vietnam war history and how the prison was used to hold US pilots, it seemed very bias and tried to make the Vietnam government look good and essentially, perfect. This site is in Vietnam however, and I am an American so I could be bias as well. Overall, I'm glad we went and could learn more about one of the largest war prisons of its time.

Very important as an American to see this. Very interesting to see the "Hanoi Hilton" From the early French to the North Vietnamese using this place as a prison.
