They present the "American" war from their point of view and show how "well" they treated the US prisoners. Sad place but very important if you are at all interested in history.
Worth a Visit. Often these places are little more than some form of propaganda tool, however this is worth a look. It is not huge but it is interesting.
Visit . Well worth a visit to this historic place. Very informative and interesting to get another perspective.
Interesting. Interesting information on the "hanoi hilton"A bit of a random layout. Not as much left in the original state as I expected.

Interesting and disturbing. This prison has a dark history. Interesting to visit but you can feel the negative vibes in the guillotine room (they still have an original one). Worth having a look - takes no more than an hour. Perhaps follow it up with a visit to the lake of the restored sword temple which has a very peaceful feeling!
Interesting. An interesting place to visit. It's great to understand history of the country you visit. More details on the exhibits would have been nice to aid our understanding.
Interesting . Interesting to see , not too big can do In under an hour. May have been better with a tour guide. Found most of the artefacts a bit under whelming but some interesting like the cells
depressing. Quite a bit of propaganda in the info here but in any case it showcased mans inhumanity to man and that all war is a waste of life.

Quite upsetting. Our guide told us of the atrocities the French had perpetrated there and the photos we saw were of American prisoners decorating a Christmas tree or eating a Christmas dinner! But seeing the cells and knowing how hot it must have been was dreadfully sobering.

Important historical attraction in Hanoi. Very interesting former prison in Hanoi. The fact that the prison was used by the French during the colonial rule and was then used during the Vietnam war. Apparently the Americans kept here were treated quite well hence the name Hanoi Hilton but our guide and the exhibits are quite biased and pro government so it is hard to know .

Fascinating and well put together. . Really enjoyed my visit here. It's been beautifully restored and thoughtfully laid out. Takes less than an hour to go round and isn't too busy. A must for those interested in history.

Good View from the "other" side. Being an American, we were interested in seeing this prison and the history behind it due to it being famous for housing one of our U.S. Senators as a prisoner of war - John McCain. The museum was very well organized and had an interesting layout. As you walked into prison cells and saw pictures of what went on there, I learned a lot of history. It is a very worthwhile stop on the tourist trail and, especially if you are a history or Vietnam War history buff, it is a must see.
Hoa La [Hanoi Hilton] Prison. An essential visit in order to understand the extend of the Vietnam war and the effects on its people - poignant and honest interpretation of the horrific war.

A must to see in Hanoi. I am sure that every single westerner who visits Hanoi walks the grounds of the “Hanoi Hilton.” Although quite disturbing when one thinks and sees historical accounts of the “things” that went on in Hao Lo Prison, it was fascinating to see the cells, displays, read the info and observe the nation’s point of view the American War in Vietnam. It’s a small exhibit and definitely worth some time – about 35 to 60 minutes should do it. Cost 30.00VND. Kids under 12 free.

Sad History at the Hanoi Hilton. Built by the French who dominated colonial Indochina from the mid nineteenth century till their defeat by Ho Chi Minh's Communists in 1954, the sign over the front door says "Maison Centralle" (Central House). Most of the prison was torn down to make way for an apartment complex, but the remaining section concentrates mostly on the barbaric conditions the French subjected their prisoners to. There are also several rooms dedicated to the prisoners (mostly American flyers) captured during the 60's and 70's. Visitors should provide their own balance to the Vietnamese narrative.

Very interesting historical place. Although the museum has a definite pro government bias in the narrative and descriptions, it is a very significant historical museum that deserves to be visited. We enjoyed our visit, which was very informative and gives you a good perspective on the living conditions of the prisoners and its importance in history.

Best prison I've been to lately. Quite nice building with a very interesting history. Somewhat horrific at times, but an important place to visit to find context for a lot of Vietnam's recent history.

Awesome . Tells u a lot about the hardships Vietnamese people endured ..it's sad they were ruled by so many others ..and their grand fight for freedom.It's gory almost to see the criminal injustice inflicted upon them .Here one sees the actual prisons in which they were kept in rather decrepit and morbid conditions . A small video..tons of photos that spell.their lives in hard times .Do visit .it is a must for knowing their recent appalling history .

If you are into war history... cant miss this!. I was intrigued as to what this place was and so glad I had a look into it, the POWs were held here during the vietnam war and faced a lot of suffering, there are a few famous american names on the displays here - i learnt a lot here about the war history

frightening and educational. Right in the middle of town, this museum tells the story of this prison's role through the history of Vietnam. This is the infamous Hanoi Hilton. There are grand flourishes of Communist propaganda through the narratives especially concerning the American/Vietnam War. Read closely and add the edited history of Communist mass killings and aggression to the narrative on your own.
Instantly flashback to this prison in use.. It's easy to imagine the prison still functioning, stop by to remember and honor the history, for better or worse.

"A very historical site and I will remember it for the rest of my life". Hoa Lo prison is well-organized and it deserves to be a must-come attraction in Hanoi for people who are interested in history.For some people it may be a bit scary, but for me, Hoa lo prision represents quite well the wars in Vietnam and helps me a lot to have a clearer look about them.I highly recommend this prison for people who are visiting Hanoi to know more about the city and the Hoa Lo prison-the prison in the middle of the city!

Probably the most interesting museum in town. Yes, I know it's a sight of astrocity: you won't feel good. Yet, as a museum, it serves its purpose. One of the few museum in town that is really fully narrated in English and thus I found it easy to follow tbe story.Yes, one needs to be self reflexive too as the official narratives are rather propaganda-like. But it's so obvious that few visitors would walk out without thinking.

Medieval Prison Experience. Look past the biased reporting of history of events, this is a prison where to look and feel has been retained such that it sends shivers down your spine at times. Don't miss it
Worth a visit. The prison visit was interesting and worth going to. Obviously there is some bias but that is understandable.

A moderately interesting propaganda vehicle . Of considerable historic interest as a record of colonial justice and the use of incarceration. However fails to differentiate between the justice system ( was it fair,advanced brutal - we will never know Instead we are treated to a full onset of propaganda which debases the whole purpose of the museum. Why on earth would the American airmen want to go home to their nasty brutal country when they were having such fun at the generous treatment they received here! There is enough historical fact available not tone little this subject so

The Hanoi Hilton. What a great moving experience, from the days the French occupied Hanoi to when American prisoners were held there, you can feel the torture. Maybe Trump should visit to see what a hero is.

Very interesting - not just for history!. Worth a visit as is incredibly interesting especially if into history, the understanding of France's role in modern Vietnam and the American-Vietnam war. The layout isnt brilliant and information could be better presented but at the end of the day, it has been kept well preserved from its days as the Hanoi Hilton. It is heavy with propaganda (go get em Uncle Ho!) and whilst I found this fascinating in itself and something that should be experienced, might not be enjoyable for everyone.

Interesting. If you're in Hanoi, definitely talk a walk through the prison. Knowing McCain's take on his time there, we were very interested to see the alleged propogana and it was quite interesting to see their side

Eye opening. This is a must. Learnt so much about the conditions prisoners were kept in (Vietnamese and American). Quite surreal to see the prison cells and to learn the history. Seeing the guillotine actually gave me goosebumps.
Very educational. You learn a lot. Just do it you will not be disappointed. It offers so much history that you never knew

Hoa lo..... in downtown Hanoi, it is a fairly small museum and can be easily covered in about an hours time. much of the original prison has been torn down to give way to this museum and some of its exhibits include instruments of torture, tiny solitary cells...most of them dating back to even the french colonial period.

Interesting. An interesting place to visit. It's interesting to see the bias in the description of history and there are a lot of interesting photos and films. Seeing some of the cells and the guillotine sends shivers down your spine. It's quite small so it won't take long to visit.
Interesting . Went here because of all the stories we have heard about the Hanoi Hilton. Cells were a bit grim. Has a definite Vietnamese spin on all the signage and explanations.

Hanoi Hilton. The victor gets to write history. After 100 years of brutal French colonisation, then the Japanese followed by having to defeat the US and their allies the Vietnamese have every reason to hate westerners but even here we found forgiveness. Only a small part of the prison has been kept but what there is, is well worth seeing.
Good. Was a good visit. Although a lot of stuff translated. Documents and poems were not in english which would have helped.

Biased. This prison is well worth a visit but keep in mind there is a definite point of view. The VN portray the terrible treatment they received as prisoners of France. The US prisoners are portrayed very differently. They're shown have a good old time playing basketball and playing cards. I don't think it was anything thing other than hell.

A moving experience. Didn't know what to expect from our visit here - found the cells particularly moving and imagined what it might have been like to have been imprisoned here. Must have been very difficult. Would have liked more time however we were on a day trip so our guide moved us on! You need more than an hour here - we had about 30 minutes!

Very interesting, a few signs missing in english but thats it. Really interesting museum, we went round with a free tour which was good. The tour guides with the museum probably have a little more information - a few of the signs were missing in English but we got the jist. A bit of an eye opener about the history with the French, possibly a little bit weighted in the portrayal of each side but that's to be expected I think. Very visual. Definately worth a visit
Nothing Spectacular. Nothing spectacular & certainly not an attraction for young kids. Interesting, worth a visit but not something you must see whilst in Hanoi.

Propaganda . Interesting to see, but be warned, the Vietnamese downplay the American prisoners and flat out ignore the torture. The museum focused more on the French treatment of Vietnamese prisoners.

Interesting...but..... Do some reading before you go. I'm sure it would've made a little more sense and I could've done some more Thinking behind it. Was $30,000 dong to enter exhibit and another $20,000 for booklet! Which is optional. It's really interesting although tells one side a little stronger. It relates to the Americans being in quite a cushy prison, whereas shows the Vietnamese side as quite horrific! Some parts are a little intense! English, French and Vietnamese sound systems to listen to parts of the exhibit. Don't get a guide, easy to do your own thing! There is a cheap souvenir shop there too!Happy visiting :)

Very interesting exhibits, quite morbid and dark. After visiting the Museum of Ethnology, we spent about 45 mins here viewing the exhibits and watching the documentaries. Some of us found some of the segments of the exhibits a little too morbid but it was a museum depicting the lives of the prisoners after all. Nonetheless, a very interesting insight to the lives of the prisoners during the Vietnamese War.

Different perspective . A small museum, with some truly heartbreaking exhibits, detailing the brutality of the French colonial period. The section on the Vietnam/American War was particularly interesting. Told from the perspective of the victorious North Vietnamese Communist regime, it included a display of former US Presidential candidate John McCain's flight suit. McCain was held in the prison with many other US pilots who had been shot down in and around Hanoi. Not a lot of interest for younger kids but for anyone looking to broaden their understanding of the history of Vietnam, it's s must see.

Informative, but I was hoping for a John McCain exhibit. I probably should have read more about this museum beforehand, but I went in expecting to see US Senator John McCain's prison cell. Unfortunately, probably due to diplomatic reasons they didn't really show his cell. Still, it was pretty informative and humbling to see the conditions under which prisoners had to survive.

Interesting but allow at least an hour. We arrived at 4.30 and made it through most of the exhibits .. I think. We were hurried out the door from 5.05. There are strong themes of propaganda. First is the righteousness and determination of Vietnamese prisoners of the cruel French. Many of these prisoners later became communist leaders well positioned to write their own history. Second was the wonderful treatment received by American pilot prisoners from the North Vietnamese.I'm not in a position to challenge the veracity of either of these themes but the message is clear and repetitive in ways that beg question.I would have liked more time to pore over the exhibits. Certainly some of the physical hardships are clearly communicated visually.Well worth a visit.

Interesting, but only if you have time or a particular reason to visit. There is quite a contrast in the descriptions between the way the French treated the Vietnamese and the way the Vietnamese treated the American aircrew held there. Informative signage.

Very Interesting Exhibit!. What an eye opener this place is. Saw how prisoners were kept in small cages as well as different torture techniques. Also learnt a lot about the history of the vietnam war. Definitely a must visit!

Much more interesting than expected.. Some have the idea that this is mostly about American prisoners who referred to it as the "Hanoi Hilton". That is a part of the history, but only part. The prison was built by the French 120 years ago and the information is mostly about the Vietnamese political prisoners, men and women, who were held there until the 1950's. There is a definite slant in the presentation towards the communist prisoners. There is no doubt that it is the Vietnamese communist government version of events. But some of what makes it interesting is how they tell their version of what happened. But beyond the propaganda (which all countries engage in) it is a sobering a fascinating place to visit.
If you are in Vietnam for the first time.... If you have been to the Ho Chih Minh one, this is similar but on a smaller scale. Only diff is John McCain was here!

USA POW gallery is the reason you should see this museum. The Prison itself is rather lacklustre, and redone in a way thats quite cheesy. However, if you watch the videos and the POW exhibition in the second half of the museum it is worth every penny. It is highly biased. If you have any idea as to the history of how they were actually treated in Vietnam, you will find this very very interesting.
Hilton - Prison. This place was a very interesting place to go and see. A better understanding of history. Certain parts of this prison was sad to see. But overall I like it.
Difficult Attraction to Visit. Wow. This was a difficult exhibit to see. If you are sensitive, you may not want to see this intense exhibit
One day tour. Not very big or much to see. Luckily had our own free tour guide to explain things . Hard to see the conditions they were forced to live in and the treatment .

Educational. This can be a depressing though interesting experience. As can be expected the whole facility is not meant to be attractive but informative.The write-ups are quite down on the French who operated the jail until they lost the war and then the Vietnamese took over.There were photos of American pilots who were interned at this facility, looking well-fed and cared for.Worth an hour and US$1.

Interesting small museum. Small museum, but really interesting way to spend an hour. 20 min walk from the old quarter. Most interesting exhibit for me was John McCain's flight suit and the old death row cells. Chilling.

Visit with a grain of salt.... Hoa Lo Prison is an interested site of historical importance. The current site is only one small area of what was originally the much larger prison complex. There is a lot of original items on display such as a guillotine that was actually once used. The old cell blocks have more or less been left in an unrestored state. Although the Hoa Lo Prison had a lot of information to read, I found some of the information to be plain incorrect. Unlike the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City that was factually correct but had spiels of propaganda, Hoa Lo Prison has parts that are propaganda driven but factually incorrect. There are photos of American Prisoners enjoying a Christmas meal with placards saying that they were never mistreated whilst imprisoned. When you read the recounts of American prisoners who had spent time at Hoa Lo, you will learn that this was not the case. Nonetheless, this is still worth a visit.

An Impressive place . Being a Vietnamese , I went there, I felt socked and moved into tears when I entered Hoa Lo prison. I saw a lot of statues and they describes about Vietnamese prisoners who suffered a lot terrible things in war from Americans. I felt so painful and proud of our generations in the past . They sacrificed for peace of country today . You will get know more about history of Viet Nam when you come here . It's an amazing place to explore.

The Hanoi hilton!. Some interesting details to read about in the prisons murky history. There were fascinating displays about the US pilots held here during the Vietnam war - their experience seemed far pleasanter than previous residents!!A good way to spend up to an hour - my older kids were also interested.

History buffs. If you are interested in the Viet Nam War or John McCain, this is worth a visit. Also referred to as the Hanoi Hilton, this prison held American POWs during the war.When you enter the massive gates, ominous music plays in the background. The rest is a maze; cells with sloped floors so the blood rushed to the prisoners heads when they tried to sleep causing excruciating pain and delirium, John McCain's flight suit and Christmas decorations.The propaganda is overt, like the Christmas cutouts the prisoners "joyfully made to celebrate their beloved holiday". The locals are very aware of this blatant propaganda. The sculpture wall is very effective in representing the sunken souls of those held in this place.

Glad we had the time to visit.. As mentioned before, we had a local map from hotel & just planned a few walking tours in Hanoi. The Hao Lo Prison or Hilton Prison, was worth a couple of hours, from the hussle of city..

Propaganda Outlet with some interesting history. Was pretty interesting to see the French guillotine and John McCain's flight suit, that being said the majority of the information is historically inaccurate and mostly communist propaganda

Worth Visiting!. This is worth visiting. It makes you understand insurgency (treat prisoners badly, they will hate your forever...the French were cruel). However, the exhibit on the America Pilots was revisionist. I'm sure the America POWs have a completely different version. We visited on Christmas Day and it was touching to see the Christmas Day art work of the American pilots. Having grown up in Virginia Beach during that time and been in school with many POW/MIA/KIA children (and at the airport when the POWs returned) it really is heart breaking and brought back a lot of memories of that time. But, the victor writes history. I will ensure I take all my visitors to see it.

Good Experience. Lots of history provided, not just of the jail, but also on the history of the French and Americans in Vietnam. Can walk through at your own pace which is nice so you can spend as much or as little time in each section.

Interesting but deceptive. It was interesting to so this place with so much history. The exhibits were fair, nothing special. It only takes 30 min or so to see everything. I was disappointed to see such clear distortions regarding the treatment of the American prisoners. They portrayed them having fun, playing ball, celebrating holidays and even giving them good bye presents. I am fully aware that there are always many sides to events in a war. After reading many first hand accounts from former prisoners, I don't think their depictions were at all similar to the horrors people experienced at Hoa Lo. A "museum" should contain factual information (even through the eyes of the resident country) but not outright propaganda. My advice: it's worth seeing but do some independent reading before or after you go (there is still censorship of the Internet in Vietnam).

Fascinating history. Known mostly in the US as the "Hanoi Hilton" where John McCain and many others were imprisoned, this is so much more than that. No US servicepeople died here, but thousands and thousands of Vietnamese did as it was used previously by the French and by the Vietnamese against their own. While it's depressing to see some of the places where prisoners were held, this is necessary to an understanding of some of the history here.

weird to be visiting a prison, but so worth the visit. This was something my friend read up on, but it is so well worth a trip. Historically strategic and incredible to read the stories and the information about the 'Hanoi Hilton' as it was nicknamed

History. We walked to check it out from
Old square. Easy to find. Worth the small amount they charge. No guide needed as they have very good signage and explanations

Informative attraction . LocationJust next to Hilton Hanoi. Walking distance from the old quarter. EnvironmentFull of history write up of the prison and different type of the area in the prison. To your surprise it is a fraction of the remaining of the actual prison many years back. Some place feels kind of eery especially the place where they kept the death sentence prisoners. But it's rather interesting for those who likes history. Price 30000 Vietnam dong (usd$ 1.3)FYIJust a small museum. A short tour that takes about 10-15 mins without much reading and 20-25 min with reading

Sobering look at the colonial history of Vietnam.. You meet the Vietnamese people who are so friendly and outgoing and then you go to this french prison and reflect on the history and how bitter they could be. It is a testament of the resiliency of these wonderful people.

A reminder about the tragedy of war, a must visit. Certainly not the most pleasant places in Hanoi, but a must place to visit to soak up history and the darkness of war. A very small remanant of this prison is left, being used to imprison the French, before the Americans. The larger part of the prison was torn down to construct condos and upscale office buildings, but the Vietnamese maintained a corner of the block where a portion of the prison exists. The tour is self guided, a very slanted view of how the Vietnamese treated both the French and the Americans--but afterall, both countries were interjecting themselves in someone else's affairs. But the props, the prison cells, and environment are authentic. Hoa Lo is located centrally within the Old Quarters, and within easy walking of many of the hotels.

Interesting . One of the places of interest with more things to see. There r real cells (empty) as well as wax man size exhibits to help you imagine life of prisoners of war. Try walking into one of those cells and imgaine how the prisoners would have felt. You will prolly feel your hair stand.

A trip I won't forget. This was my favourite stop on the tour I took part in. My knowledge was limited before going along, which probably made it more enjoyable for the learning! There is a definite slant to the descriptions and writings, obviously not in favour of the French. I think, all in all, the presentation of what it was like being there in prison was great!

New lesson about Viet war. The prison now is just a museum of 10% what it used to be as a prison. We had a good time learning about a period of time that we never know before and also the other facts from another side we used to get in News and books.

Well worth a visit. It's certainly worth coming here if only to compare the contrast with how well the Vietnamese treated the POWs during Vietnamese war , with how appallingly the French had treated the Vietnamese in former colonial days.

The lessons from the pain in the past. The first day that we arrived in Hanoi, we couldn't do anything much because 90% of the museums were closed but there's only Hoa Lo Prison that opened on Monday. It's very sad place to see but it's a must see place as well. You can learn from the pain of these prisoners and you will see that the war never ever made things better at all.
Interesting place to visit. Hoa Lo Prison is a nice. It intrigued us during the visit. The place gives a good image of how prisoners' living condition were like.

Interesting history. This prison was built by the French and was a horrible place for the citizens who resided there as shown by the displays. They are very well done. During the "American " war it imprisoned American soldiers who were captured. It was nicknamed the "Hanoi Hilton" and we found it interesting to see the contrast between their reports of prisoner treatment and what was reported in western papers of the time. Well worth a visit.

Interesting History. If you want to deepen your knowledge of Vietnam History, this is the place to go. The cost of admission was about 40,000VND. If you have some time, and are interested in learning more about When the French occupied Vietnam, the Reunification and the French Vietnam war, I would recommend that you visit Hoa Lo Prison.

Hanoi HIlton - worth a visit. A useful perspective on the struggles of the Vietnamese population under the French regime and the prison where American soldiers were kept during the Vietnam war. The historical commentary is somewhat biaised as you'd expect but interesting none the less,
A must for anyone interested in the Vietnam war. Lots of interesting information and photographs about the war . You really feel a sense of history here.

A bit shocking and patriotic . Thr prison is certainly worth to go to, although the point of view is obviously very anti-french and pro-vietnam as can be expected. A small area is also dedicated to the prisoners of war during the Vietnam War, they must have been really well treated. ;)

Check out the "Hanoi Hilton". This place is small, which I like in a museum, and you can do it quickly. Well-curated. Interesting and creepy. Highlights include the massive guillotine and also John McCain's Air Force jumpsuit (supposedly). Good quick stop on a walking tour of Hanoi.
Quite interesting. Worth a visit. interesting to understand what happen in Vietnam. obviously this was a dark time but this is part of their history

Touching place worth it to be visited. The Hoa Lo Prison (ironically called Hanoi Hilton by the American prisoners) is a sad piece of history for Vietnam but it is definitely worth a visit as it is very informative.It is pretty far from other landmarks, and I don't recall there are interesting places or restaurants in the area. Just grab a taxi, go there and spend at least 1 hour. You might end up staying there for almost two if you want to read all the explanations.The Museum is well explained in English as well and there are many materials to read.Recommended going there prepared. The old movie "Hanoi Hilton" is not a masterpiece and is not for sensitive people, yet it gives you an idea (from the US perspective) about how US prisoners used to live there. Before the US prisoners, the Vietnam dissidents to the French rulers were hosted here.
Where Senator Mccain was a POW. Not that impressive, kinda sad to see what conditions POW endured. Were told the Vietnamese never visit this.

Ideal for history lovers. This was a place to detain and torture Vietnamese revolutionists resisting the French during the colonial period. The displays are well organized with real size stone figures to depict the life of the prisoners during the time. There is also a real guillotine used to execute prisoners on display which was a bit eerie to see. The museum can be a bit depressing but definitely worth a visit to learn more about the painful plight of the Vietnamese people and their struggle for independence.

Offers a different perspective for the French and Americans. This museum offered a nice tour through the historical perspective of the Vietnamese people and their oppression by invading countries such as the French (in the last 1800 to early 1900s) and then the Americans (during the Vietnam/American War). It is an cheap museum to visit and offers a long walk through the old prison (original built by the French colonizers and later turned into prisons or schools as the current times demanded). You can see how brutal the conditions were for the locals, and, (again from the vietnamese perspective) how kind they were to the US prisoners including John McCain. You will have plenty of food for thought once your tour concludes.

Informative, easily accessible. Went on a Sunday morning, which was relatively empty. There was only 1 tour group and about 2-3 other tourists like myself. Entrance fee was 30 000 VND for adults, and 15 000 VND for students. Advisable for students to bring along their student passes so that they can get the discounted price (yes, international student passes are acceptable). I found the Hoa Lo Prison a very informative attraction. Very detailed explanations of its functions when Vietnam was a French colony, and when the Vietnam War happened. The cells were preserved very well, and you get the eerie and gloomy feeling when you walk into them, especially the death row cells. I learnt quite a bit about what happened in Hoa Lo Prison during the Vietnam War from the documentaries, though some info was framed in a one-sided manner. Rather accessible, about 20 minutes walk from Hoan Kiem Lake.

Not for the Sensitive. You can still feel the fear and the pain of past prisoners. You should visit it if you're interested in Vietnam's history. Built by the French Colonialists who were cruel to say the least and then home to many American Pilots who were captured during the infamous Vietnam War.
Interesting place. It's a historical place with a lot of displays and explanations.Love the atmosphere there.It would probably take you 1 - 2 hour there.

Powerful monument, but poorly designed exhibits. This is a powerful place to visit in terms of understanding the history of war and conflict in Vietnam, but it's not a well designed museum. The exhibits are underwhelming in terms of content. Go if you have time, it won't take long, but don't go out of your way for it.

Interesting. Hoa Lo Prison (or the Hanoi Hilton as the Americans named the prison) is an interesting place to visit and learn what we shouldn't do again. Shocked me, makes one realise how cruel human beings can be.

Reminds you of historical atrocities. Well worth a visit to capture some of the French and of course Vietnam war history. This really is an awful prison but well worth a visit to learn about the history of Vietnam and Hanoi.

Very interesting. Interesting and informative. Good exhibits with life size dummies depicting the restrictive conditions the prisoners were kept under. An actual guillotine complete with basket to catch the head, serves as a gruesome reminder of "less civilised" times. The building is also quite beautiful itself.

Should Not Be Missed. This was a very informative attraction, I learnt a lot about the prison and what it was used for during war time in Vietnam. The site was well structured and was well maintained. Please visit this site if you are in Hanoi.
eye opener. was quite an experience to find out the realities of what the vietnamese ppl were gg through and the whole journey towards their freedom (made me cry a bit too lol)
Visit to Old Quarter. It is virtually a pub street with numerous pubs & bars & restaurants & many lodges a must visit for every tourist;surrounded by many tourist attractions

An interesting visit especially if it rains. We booked a free tour to take us here. It was interesting to see the cells and hear the stories of how prisoners lived and also how they escaped. On the whole it was interesting but i wouldn't go out of my way to come here and have to compete with the tour groups for floor space.

Chilling. I visited many historical prisons before and this one is no exception in sending shivers down your spine.... The foolishness of men controlling men. Anyway a trip down memory lane and a picture of how things used to be with Foreigners receiving better treatment than others...

Cheeky hour's visit . This was an interesting way to spend an hour. It was only 30k VND to get in and there was tons of English information available, dotted around on plaques. You could actually go inside a cell and see what it was like to be imprisoned in Hoa Lo and models demonstrated how prisoners wore shackles and other tortuous devices.Once again, as with the Cu Chi tunnels, I found myself grieving for what the Vietnamese have suffered. Thousands of politician prisoners, protesting against French rule, were executed here. However, all the historical information on display agrees, though, that the captures communist Viet Cong were defiant until the last. You can also see some propaganda, including video footage, of how captured American pilots were treated during their imprisonment.

Was either this or Ho Chi Minh museum. It was an informative visit - learnt about the beginnings of the prison which was meant to detain Vietnamese rebels opposing french rule. Many artefacts and murals depict the situation faced by those imprisoned. In the Vietnam war, it was used for the detention of American pilots. Photos show devastation of bombings and the comfortable environment as portrayed by North Vietnam, which the Americans called the prison as "Hanoi Hilton".

Worth A Visit. This is one of the places one should visit. Labelled as Hilton Hotel by some... it's a place where prisoners were detained and tortured during the French Colonisation. The items on display are very informative.

Do not forget to visit this. This tells all about what happened in Vietnam.You will spend here more time than you expect at start (I did)Everything is very good explained and tells the story (horror) to the detail.Time : I spend 1 to 2 hours.
Review on visit to Hua Lo Prison. We arrived there half n hour before closing, which iis quite a rush. Ideally, you may spend an hour,.

well worth a visit. If you can, go with a guide such as Hanoi free walking tours, as hearing more about the torture, living conditions and escape attempts made this tour very interesting and worthwhile. Not sure I believe the mentions made and photos of how well the American prisoners were treated. h
Interesting visit. Though provoking visit. Easily accessible museum located in the Old Quarters. Worth a visit if you are interested in Viet history.

Eye opener. It was an eye opener to the sufferings of the prisoners.
Many things to see and learn about "Hanoi Hilton"

Interesting piece of history. Gives a good perspective of the conditions experienced by prisoners during that time period and a reminder of the cruelty of human beings towards other human beings. Just be mindful that information shared here is told only from the Vietnamese perspective and can appear quite slanted at times.

Interesting . This was the only Museum we could find open on a Monday. It was interesting enough, however a guided tour or headphones with recordings would make it a better experience. Our kids are 9 and 12 and this occupied them for about an hour or so.
A chilling reminder of the past. Well presented museum - although some of the historical information was a little one sided and not entirely true
Impressive. Impressive as lot's of innocent prople have lives there under horrible circumstances and also died there but not my kind of my cup of tea on a holiday.

Put this at the top of your list in Hanoi. Great museum, and it's well laid out (which isn't always the case in Vietnam). Worthwhile experience as to how soldiers struggled to survive during the war. This museum is centrally convenient and takes approximately an hour to visit / walk thru
Interesting . Found this visit really interesting, only 30,000 to go in (I think) & lots to look at, can spend a good few hours in here. Everything is well explained in English.

Interesting, but be careful what you believe!. The museum is situated inside the remnants of the actual prison used by both French colonialists and North Vietnam army. It covers the history and treatment of the prisoners held there. It was informative and definitely creepy and confronting at times. However, some of the information is clearly biased, especially in regards to the American POWs.
Frightening History. This is the infamous Hanoi Hilton where US airforce captives were held during the war. It's gruesome history under the French was an sye-opener.

A little light on info. For 20,000 dong, it's worth a pit stop at Hoa Lo Prison if you're near by. It displays an interesting mixture of artefacts and parts of the building are still original. It takes under an hour to read all of the information although there is a booklet that you can buy at an additional cost. Interesting enough but not worth a special trip.
Interesting. It has a lot of details.. It has been restored in a very nice matter. There are a lot of demonstrations and guides.. It is worth visiting. It needs a hour of your time

A good Vietnamese account of the 1945 revolution and the War with US. Some may see the exhibits here as propaganda, but I see it as a point of view of the Vietnamese. A good source of information to understand more about the revolution for independence and the war with US from the Vietnamese point of view, but you need to be able to sieve out the facts from the sentiments.

A great little museum which tells a good story . We paid this museum a visit as most of the others were closed on a Monday. Definitely worth seeing, good to see the conditions people survived in during the wars. We spent about an hour there, and saw it all. Shame that only about 20% of the museum remains, although they made very good use of the space that is left!

Interesting insight to the past . We only went into this museum as it was pouring with rain outside and our hotel room wasn't ready. We were pleasantly surprised - it's a very well organised, informative museum with interesting displays and good access to areas of the prison such as the cells. It's a relatively small museum so worth taking an hour or two out of the day to have a wander around.

The Hanoi Hilton !. La Maison Centrale built in the French era is a quite gloomy prison with dioramas depicting scenes of brutal treatment of dissidents during the French occupation .It was nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton when John McCain was captured & interned there during the Vietnam War .The is a sinister industrial era guillotine in one of the rooms on display !

stirring. This museum is worth visiting as it shows the era before the Viet Nam war when it was a French colony where political prisoners were kept and excecuted.During the Viet Nam war American airman were imprisoned, there is a lot of photographs and video to see.

Interesting and informative. This place is a good way to spend a few hours. There is lots of information to soak in about the prisons usages throughout history with some focus on captured American pilots. The cost was inexpensive so go there and check it out

Good overview of conflict from North vietnamese perspective. Well organised museum with interesting relics from American pilot's prisoners occupation. Museum keen to show they did not ill treat the prisoners.
Worth visiting. If you are into the history and how wars can teach us, this place is worth visiting. Some sections are a bit creepy.

Visiting this interesting French prison. We have spent a good hour with @Hanoi eBuddies in the prison (with them is so much better and it's free). The prison has been really interesting showing all the torture instruments used during the 19th century and part of modern history crossing the beginning of the cold war.

Spine Chilling and Historical. This place was both spine chilling and historical for me. It gives us a vivid image of how revolutionaries suffer for a cause they believe in by putting the country first. It also made me realized that colonial scars are too deep to heal in time. Salute to these legends.

I arrived in Vietnam only to find this real history of Vietnam !. From our hotel to Hoa Lo prison is not so far then we could walk through and it gave us perspective figures of the history of Vietnam and the individual tortures would never be able to understand and it is a must see. It's a new experience for us. And it was interesting visit about the history and how long it had been used for a prison were quite interesting.

Really interesting - for different reasons. It's pretty gruesome going through the main part of the prison, learning what happened to the Vietnamese prisoners during French colonial times. The whole feel changes though once you get to the displays about the American POWs and just how amazingly kind their Vietnamese hosts were to them. I have never seen a better example of history being written by the victors!
Powerful. A truly powerful place to be, with so much information about Vietnam's history. The feel of the prison is very real and very strong.

Interesting place.. It is a old prison used by the french in the past. Interesting to know its history through out the period of french colonist to Vietnam war however the place is small and not much things to see.

A must see in Hanoi for Americans. Very interesting museum in terms of its history with the French and as the "Hanoi Hilton" housing American POW's. I was fascinated to hear the official Vietnamese version of the war and to contrast it with the American version I grew up with. It brought home that point that "history" is based on perspective.

Horrors of inhumanity. This is a must-see if you are in Hanoi. You will experience the conditions the prisoners lived in plus see torture devices and a real guillotine. A sad reminder of the years of the "American War."

Also known as Hanoi Hilton. I, as an American, was disappointed after hearing so much about the Hanoi Hilton. I though the prison was strictly for POW's during the Vietnam was, but it was a French prison built in the 1800's during their occupation of Vietnam and 99% of the displays and information is devoted to the French mistreatment of the People's Party prisoners. Very little is dedicated to the American POW's but that was a very small time period in this prison's history.
Wow,. Amazing what happened to people back then. A must see if you have time. Cheap and easy to get to. 10-15 walk from the old quarter.

Interesting and informative. Enjoyed our visit here - lots of interesting facts and also a good insight into what being locked up here would be like. It was a plus seeing the cells here which was very moving, and you can visualise what it must have been like to be be held prisoner here.

Vietnam perspective on a bleak period of history. Visiting this prison provides a valuable insight into the history of Vietnam both during the rule of the French and during the Vietnam War era of the 60's. Although the information may have bias to it many aspects of the prison provide a valuable insight as to how the French treated the local revolutionaries. It is interesting to hear the other side of the Hanoi Hilton as the US POW"s referred to Hoa Lo Prison. In all probability the truth lies somewhere between the two sides versions. What is informative is the presentation of prisoners in chains, in cells that were overcrowded, etc. The presence of the guillotine and its use in decapitation provides the gruesome reality that befell many of the prisoners under the French. Although the prison is only a fraction of its original size it provides a more than adequate insight into the conditions that prevailed when it was in use. The murals in the courtyard are very interesting artworks. Well worth a visit.

Fascinating. Very interesting displays. From John McCain's flight suit to the period pictures, lots of interesting artifacts that give you a sense of the history from a Vietnamese perspective. Very informative. Definitely worth the $2 CDN admission!

Very interesting. I came here after reading tripadvisor reviews and I was not disappointed.Very interesing learning the history of the prison and seeing the conditions that prisoners would have been subject too. I am not normally one for history but this place has some fascinating stories to tell and a lot on display. The only negative that I found was that the text on some of the information boards were very small so I found many people including myself would be right up at the sign trying to read it. Overall good experience.

Torture epitomised. Called Maison Central, this prison was used by the French to imprison political prisoners during their 100 odd year rule of Vietnam. Very well preserved. The way the prisoners were shackled to their feet (iron shackles used then are still there and in good shape) etc is heart wrenching ; None of this will pass the test with any of the human rights organisations today. Worth visiting to understand history and to figure out what the Vietnamese went through

Propaganda at its finest.... The museum was clean and in very good condition but the viewpoint was clearly one-sided (of course). The first half was on the French occupation and how horrible they were treated as prisoners (very sad if the information was true) and the second half was on how great they treated the US POWs. Having read and heard the stories of the US POWs held there...this portion showed footage of media manipulation and was designed to show them in the best light possible. Another note, the data at the prison didn't match the data showed at the Vietnam Military museum...at least make sure your stories match. History is history and it's disgraceful to try and spin any of it to ones benefit. It's worth a visit but only if with the understanding and open mind that it is very one-sided.
This was a eye opener but very interesting. We visited the prison with a group and i found it very interesting these things are not usually in my taste but I found it very interesting
An eye opener. A real shock coming the apparent treatment of Vietnamese prisoners by the French to the treatment of US servicemen by the Vietnamese. Assuming photos aren't posed for!

Educational. This place is small. I was expecting to spend a bit more time learning but there's not much to see. But nevertheless, this place was educational. I learned a bit about the cruelty of the French doing to the Vietnamese prisoners during the Vietnam revolution. It is a bit morbid sight and quite depressing when you walk around and visit the rooms. I walked over here from pretty much the Bia corner area, it's not necessary close but on the other side of the lake but still walkable. Overall, the ticket is cheap and this place is worth checking out.

A well kept timeline of Vietnam's war history. If you're interested in learning about the various wars the Vietnamese people have been through then this is a good exhibition to see. It covers both the French and American wars.

Interesting place to visit. The Hoa Lo prison showcases the history of the area, from it being a simple Vietnamese village to a prison built by the French colonists to the prison being used to hold American prisoners during the Vietnam war. The prison very much glorifies the Communist movement and put in a bad light both the French as oppressor and American as aggressor. Interesting place to visit.
Interesting in parts I did learn something. A good trip especially on a rainy day. It was an informative visit but I not sure how much was based on facts or evidence.

Surprisingly good .... Having visited a number of museums from Saigon to Hanoi I found this to be quite interesting. I didn't realize it had been a very old prison prior to the Vietnam war so conditions were very poor. It is a fraction of the original size but has good exhibits, pictures, etc. and John McCain's capture suit among other things. The early rooms depict the horrific treatment of the early prisoners (Vietnamese, captured by the French who were shackled and guillotined). Following those rooms are the rooms devoted to American POW's during the Vietnam war. As usual there is a one-sided perspective to a multi-dimensional issue. The museum takes great pains to document what excellent treatment American prisoners received in this prison, being given cigarettes, Christmas celebrations, ample recreational opportunities, medical treatment etc--almost like a vacation!. They do actually have photos of some of this...so it reminds us there are 2 sides to every story and this is theirs.

A lot of information. Went on a self guided tour. A lot of information I previously did not know. Though it is rather one sided in terms of the views. A key draw was that John McCain's flight suit that he was wearing when captured, was on display. Overall spent about an hour and a half in there and that was at a faster pace.

An interesting insight into French Colonial History and the Vietnam War. A grim reminder of what the 'Hanoi Hilton' looked like and what the US personnel must have experienced when shot down and captured during the Vietnam war. Even grimmer was the insight of what happened to the Vietnamese prisoners who clashed with the French colonials. Definitely worth a visit.

Interesting and well-documented museum. We enjoyed the visit of the ancient prison. The atmosphere inside puts you really in the context and some rooms were difficult to see without being moved by what happened there.We also appreciated the pictures, texts and other material that were exposed. It helped to better understand the history.We recommend to visit this prison if you stay in Hanoi, even only for a little time.

Worth Visiting. The prison is worth visiting to get some picture of the history of Vietnam. The conditions for inmates were horrific! It was good for my teenage children to see some realities of life at the prison. However having said the exhibits were good but you need to keep a very open mind about how history was depicted especially the recent war. It seems the government has their view of events and how prisoners were treated. It is good to get a different perspective which I found interesting. However I don't think they are not conveying all of the information. It is worthwhile to visit the famed Hanoi Hilton for your first visit to Hanoi.
Worth a visit. Keep an open mind as recent history in particular the Vietnam war has two sides to it Conditions were terrible in this prison

Interesting and educational. Learn a little about the recent history of Vietnam. We didn't have a guide, just walked around and read the information about the prison. It's a little biased from the government's side but it wasn't a nice place for the inmates and you need to know history to stop it from repeating.

Interesting. The story of the prison is presented from the viewpoint of Vietnam's communist government so expect a lot of not so subtle messaging throughout but definitely worth the visit as this place is an interesting part of Vietnam's history.

Okay. The Hoa Lo Prison was okay, however, it was somewhat disappointing.The lighting in some areas were dismal. I think the information was limited regarding the history of the prison, one would realise that the prison was not only for political inmates and this was not reflected in the information provided. Still worth the visit.

Nice exhibit . Our first stop in Hanoi as was close to our hostel, arrived at 8:15 so very early, paid 30k each plus 20k for a guide book.
The exhibit was interesting and informative, felt it could have been more interactive though. All in all felt I it necessary to learn about a key era in Vietnamese history.

Interesting and good english signage!. Though it may be rather one sided, it is still one of the best things to see in hanoi. The english signage and translations made it interesting and tourist friendly ( unlike the Ho Chi Minh Museum).

Best museum in Hanoi. I found this museum very interesting. I had John McCain's original flight suit on display when he was captured. Many propaganda photos/posters which were not surprising. You'll probably only spend an hour here, but I still found it interesting. I would recommend it. There's an Indian Restaurant not far from here that was very good.

Not As Expansive As I Imagined.. Worthwhile for an 1-2 hour self-guided tour. Provides both the colonial French Indochina history as well as post French history of the US personnel presence in this just off the "Old Quarter" former prison.

Not Just the Hanoi Hilton. Most Americans know Hoa Loa as the "Hanoi Hilton" where pilots who had been shot down were incarcerated during the war. Its much more than that...and to the Vietnamese, it a shop of horrors pressed on them by the French colonialists. when you learn the true history of this place it will give you a whole new viewpoint. The American experience is nothing compared to what the Vietnamese endured as their patriots, both men and women were exposed to torture and death at the hands of the French.

Grim. Euphemistically termed 'Maison Centrale', this museum offers a view of the ghastly circumstances endured by prisoners. The dim lighting probably reflects real-life conditions at the time, as the walls were painted black. Displays of male prisoners shackled by one ankle on a communal bed, day and night, were matched in horror by the smaller cells for female prisoners. Outside, 2 exhibits of underground sewers showed the courage of the inmates, who used these as escape routes, with varying degrees of success. There were 2 short documentaries which told a different story of the American invasion of Vietnam, from the Vietnamese point of view. Depending on who you believe, they could represent the truth or propaganda!
Horrifying history. A must visit to understand the history of Vietnam and the people's battles. Very sobering and thought provoking.

Short trip to know more about Vietnam. It's an old prison, if you would like to know what happen during the Vietnam war to their political, it's the place for you to find out. I only spend 1 hour to walk through here, the entrance ticker is 30,00dong for foreigner. After visit here, I feel bit moody about what they did during the war, let's stop war and be peaceful.

Step back into the history that made Vietnam what it is today.... A rainy day activity that provides great insights into the times of the French occupation and the 'American war'. Everything is well explained in English and it gives you a sense of how tough life was in these times for the Viet people. Some mild propaganda but at an acceptable level.

Propaganda is not dead, but historically interesting. When you walk into the prison, most of the information is on the French and how they used it to hold in political leaders. The information is interesting but also worded in a way that smells of propaganda, plus the area on the treatment of Americans is questionable at times. There are some images that some may find confronting but overall it's a place you must visit when in Hanoi as it does tell of an important part in Vietnamese history. Easy to get to as well.

Was interesting . We walked here from old central an did it without a tour guide, if your English isn't so great then maybe u can book a guide. Was interesting to read a watch a short film on these scary times. Worth the money an worth getting away from all the haggling an honking hahaha... My partner loves to read about the wars also so he very much so enjoyed, is a pretty good read I'd say
Very interesting.. Great place. Inexpensive, easy to find, and has some incredible historical pieces. A must-see for anyone travelling in Hanoi.
What a Life. Had a private guided tour of "hanoi Hilton" and found it very interesting and also sad. Well worth the trip to visit.

Here the street names of Hanoi come alive. To start with, the prison is called Hoa Lo, not Hoa Li. As many official tourist sites in Vietnam, you have to try not to get irritated by the propagandistic style. If you manage to do that, a visit to the Maison Centrale, built by the French at the end of the 19th century, is well worth it. The exhibitions are done much better than simlar ones say 20 years ago. Information is in English and French and an informative booklet is available. The information gives a good idea about what life was like here for the Vietnamese revolutinary fighters. It is interesting how they managed to continue their communist teachings inside and apparently managed to keep up their spirits, despite the harsh conditions. Some managed to escape through the sewage system, but many died or were executed. When you have lived in Hanoi for some years, like I have, it is very interesting to see the pictures and read the stories about all the men (and some women) that have streets named after them, not only in Hanoi, but in all cities of Vietnam.There is much less information about the time the Viet Cong held Americans prison here during the Vietnam war (which the Vietnamese call the American war!). Although the Americans might not have lived under such a harsh regime as the Vietnamese did under the French, the short film about their 'happy' life in the 'Hanoi Hilton' seems very unlikely. A more realistic impression would have added to the otherwise interesting visit.

Propaganda but still interesting. The Hanoi Hilton Museum is a big propaganda piece. Nevertheless it's still interesting and a shoking part of history. If you keep up a critical point of view it's worth visiting.

Worth the time to visit. The prison is a sad visit. It is certainly worth the time to read the information as you are walking through. The history of the many conflicts is interesting while sad to learn. We did a bit of reading before our visit which was helpful. Some of the information given at the museum is colored by the tellers so it is useful to have some detail before you go. It does take quite a bit of time to read everything but it is worth the time in my opinion.

A must for anyone interested in modern Vietnam , especially the Vietnam war. You must visit this museum if you want to understand more about what Vietnam has had to endure from the French and the Americans. However, be prepared for two problems - it is hard to find your way round the building, due to the lack of good signage, but do persevere and don't miss the section about the US prisoners-of-war. Which leads me to the second problem, namely that the story of these GI prisoners is thick with propaganda; you would think that the American pilots were in a holiday camp ! They may well have been treated much better than the French treated their prisoners prior to 1954, but I think we need to hear testimony from some of the prisoners to make a judgement - I will now go and research that ..........

Depressing but interesting. As expected the prison was depressing, complete with small dark chambers, guillotine and propaganda from the communist government. They have photos of US soldiers playing volleyball, decorating Christmas trees, etc which everyone knows is staged and not what really happened. Nonetheless it was an interesting tour and worth the stop. It also gave a little history of how the French imprisoned the local population there but not sure how much of that is accurate either.
Interesting history. At this place you get the chance to find out things about the history of Vietnam and Hanoi. Worth a visit, but not too exciting!

Interesting landmark, especially for Americans. The Hoa Lo Prison (aka Hanoi Hilton) is an interesting take, especially for Americans. The narrative emphasizes the cruel use of the prison by the French imprisoning Vietnamese. The last couple of rooms exhibit the American's stay at the "Hanoi Hilton" and it's an interesting contrast. John McCain (now Senator) may have a different interpretation of the care he was given than the one that the prison presents. It made for a very interesting discussion with my daughter. Well worth a visit.

Predictable but interesting. The Hanoi Hilton is a predictable propaganda piece. French treated us inhumaley. But we treated teh American humanely. Still lots to learn and it is certainly an interesting piece of history.
Very interesting. Must go and see. It is very moving.Information on prisoners & how they were treated.The prison cells.Lots more. Just go & see for yourself its worth it.

Worth a visit. Ok, it's a little too patriotic in the sense that the french were evil, the US soldiers were treated better than the Vietnamese were and the Vietnamese prisoners never lost faith in their country, their cause and on each other. But it's still worth a visit. It's a good history lesson, and some bits are horrific. With the items, the copy of the prisoners in real life size and some of the cells still intact, it really makes an impact.
Best untill today!. This museum deserves the title museum. We've been to Vietnam Military Museum. What a joke! This was way better.

Touched and wonderful visit. I used to be a tour guide when i was in university but i don't know why i never had the chance to come to this place until this November. Hoa Lo Prison was built by French to arrest and capture the revolutionist lead by Ho Chi Minh President. Even Women and Children were there, i felt so bad when i go there and bursted into tears when I saw that. I know for sure that would be even more terrible than what I saw at that moment but it hurt a lot when I read and hear more during my visit.

Amazing History. The Hao Lo Prison is recommended for all to get a sense of Vietnam's recent history. It's hard to imagine that not so long ago, the prison actually housed prisoners in horrible conditions. It doesn't take much to walk the prison and is also a short distance from the old quarter.

Not Just the American War. Best known to Americans as the Hanoi Hilton, this illustrates Vietnam's long, complicated and violent history. Sen. John McCain's flight suit and story are here, but it is only a small part of the exhibit. The Japanese War is represented, but most compelling is the Period of French Occupation. It gives most Americans a different view of history.

Good place to visit.. Vietnam has a rough history of the communism and this place is another good one to show you how they imprison the political prisoners, how they live and escape. You can walk to this place from the Hoan Kiem Lake not so far.

Well maintained piece of history. The prison is located on a quaint street. They will let you in for a reasonable fee of about 30000 Dong. Inside you will be able to see, listen and experience the life of the prisoners both Vietnamese and American during the war. Very interesting place for historians and interested tourists

Interesting .... We did enjoy our visit to Hoa Lo Prison. There was lots of information to read and we learned a lot about the war. The garden part seemed almost too beautiful to be a prison, and some of the information seemed a bit bias. But overall worth a visit!

Pretty good. This was a nice and cheap museum worth a visit. We spent about one hour at this sight. Interesting facts about the prison with a few interesting pieces such as the French guillotine showed in one of the rooms. A good exhibition if you want to learn more about how the French people treated the Vietnamese people.

Thought prevoking. Quite a eye opener, seems the French treated the Vietnamese abominably guillotining prisoners and putting them in irons in isolation or crammed into airless rooms. Seems the yanks got good treatment from the Vietnamese after their pilots were shot down over Hanoi while dropping thousands of tons of bombs on the city. Well worth a visit to get an insight into past history of prison which became known as the "Hanoi Hilton"..........

A "captive" experience. Real interesting history of the facility, started as a colonial French prison to what is commonly known as the Hanoi Hilton. The story is more focus on the use during colonial time. On minor display are from the Vietnam era, including the flight suite of John McCain. A must visit.

Thoughtful and informative. This was an interesting place to spend an hour or so, mainly for the insight it gave into the long struggle for Vietnamese independence. For that reason, it probably helps to have read an outline of Vietnamese history in the 20th century first. The exhibits are well set out and with English captions. The large detention room filled with life-size models of shackled prisoners was particularly effective in dramatising the conditions that the prisoners endured. The section dealing with the prison's use for holding American prisoners of war is relatively small and, as other reviewers have noted, is put over in a somewhat different light, but is still fascinating for all that.
Interesting place. This prison is a worthwhile place to visit for perspective on the French colonization period and the Vietnamese viewpoint of the American War.

A great lesson in propoganda. The prison has been reduced to about 1/8 of what it originally was (with the remaining area now a shopping mall!) but it's still a very interesting place to visit. What will be most interesting to North Americans is how the history of the war and the prisoners is depicted, even today. We were told how the American POWs were so happy to be in this prison and how they were treated so well they didn't want to leave. We heard how the brave Vietnamese people fought on and never gave up even as they lay dying they were fighting. Of course this flies directly in the face of the pictures of shackled prisoners and the stories of moldy food and sickness everywhere. If you go thinking you'll see the actual cell where Sen. John McCain was held, it's not there. That area of the prison is where the shopping mall was built. But there is plenty more to see. It's definitely worth visiting.

Must visit historical site!. It's a must visit place ! So rich in history and there were moments where I literally felt goosebumps looking at the statues and their videos. Worth the time and money spent!

Sobering and quite interesting. The displays of what went on there are not pleasant, but it's real history. The section covering the American POWs has a propaganda film that makes their stay sound like a pleasant resort, with good food and fun activities.

Prison Propaganda . This is very interesting to visit if only to see the way the Vietnamese government would like you to view the "American War in Vietnam". Most of the exhibits are dedicated to the time when the prison was owned by the French and the terrible times the Vietnamese revolutionaries suffered there. They are keen to point out that while incarcerated the communist prisoners never lost their resolve, despite the harsh treatment they received and were, of course, eventually victorious. A few rooms towards the end deal with the treatment of the American POWs that were housed there, some for as long as 6 years. These exhibits try to explain how well the American soldiers were treated and how many of them had come around to the Vietnamese (communist) way of thinking before they left (a stark contrast to the reports of torture and extreme hardship from the POWs themselves). Worth a visit but don't expect an even-sided treatment of events here.

A must do in Hanoi. You need to come with an open mind and the realisation that there will be an understandable favourable slant to the Vietnamese point of view. The place is full of history and it certainly has piqued my curiosity into 20th century history. I left with the sense there was a lot of pain and heartache suffered within it's walls. You need to visit this place. When you buy the tickets, which are about 30000 dong each they will ask if you want a guide book which is an extra 20000 dong. The book is worthwhile getting but it is not really a guide book.

Hard to find but worth looking. This prison is tucked away on a side street so not very obvious. Look for the tour buses outside. The displays are well done and thought provoking. Not to worry; it's not a house of horrors, but it does give you a good feel for how awful conditions must have been for the inmates. Once inside, there's more to see than you'd think from looking at the building from the outside. Entrance fee was 30,000 VND.

The atrocities of war. It was interesting to hear the Vietnamese take of the 'American War'. Most of this famous prison is given to the history of their fight for independence from the French and the terrible toll it took of so many Vietnamese revolutionaries. The old guillotine is a stark reminder of what took place all too often here.

Transparent propaganda. I am not a big fan of prisons as tourist attractions. It is certainly true that the Vietnamese have, for centuries, suffered greatly at the hands of outsiders but the exhibits here are so transparently propaganda that it hard to know what is true.
Strong Vietnam. Was shocked! This war is make me feeling bad. I was learned a lot about the war. The Vietnamese , they're strongest!

Historical gem. I visited with Hanoi Kids and I think you can learn a lot about Hanoi's history by visiting this place. Some things are harrowing but it gave me a sense of the history and background of Hanoi. If you have the time this is a must see attraction.

Best time I've had in a prison . Mostly just to echo the other comments about this place, it's great value so you can't go far wrong and the initial part of about the French occupation is really informative and there are lots of surviving artefacts however the second half about the American POWs is really mental. They're trying to convince you that it was a holiday camp and it tells you more about Vietnamese propaganda than the war.

One of the most interesting places in Hanoi. I'm wondering why people rate this place not 5 stars. Personally, I think this is more than worth a visit. It is really interesting and a must-see! The photographs and real video footage is absolutely great.One of the best museums/prisons/places to go in Hanoi!

Probably something that everyone should see - but way overrated. Much smaller than we expected. Turns out that they demolished a large portion of the prison some years ago to build the Hanoi Towers which is now located adjacent. Some photographs and some reproductions of living conditions, but mainly we just thought it was a giant propaganda machine that didn't really teach much about what actually happened there. I mean seriously, there is an entire room dedicated to how great the American POWs were treated - pictures of them having Christmas dinner and singing songs. We all know that isn't true. Now i'm not saying that the American's didn't also do some terrible things - I'm just saying that if we're going to call it a museum then it should be factually correct from both sides. We probably 'had' to visit this - but we were terribly overwhelmed.
Reflective and Educating. A place that of course is not for fun but learned lots about the history of Hanoi and what they Vietnamese people have endured over the years.

Great museum. Interesting few hours . We spent around 2 hours at this museum. It is very easy to walk to and cheap to enter. There is a very dark and sinister atmospheric place to capture what it was like as a prison. Lots of interesting information in English and interesting rooms as exhibits to look at. Explains lots about the French rule. Well worth a visit!
interesting view. it was very interesting to see another point of view even if some of it felt a bit like propaganda, was a good way to spend an hour in hanoi
Nice. Nice visit, really cheap, the time goes fast ^^ nice to see how stupid we were, Frenchies and American
Worth a visit!. Spend your time here to know and understand the difficulty during dark time of vietnam people. It will make you appreciate what you have now and appreciate humanity
grim but important. important to understand impact of colonial rule and rebellion against it also interesting to see a different perspective on their american "guests"

A bit one sided. So this was interesting to see and read about as they have information written in each room and photos. The story is very one sided but that is expected. It cost about $2 each for entry, they add the brochure in the price without asking so if you don't want you have to ask for the money back.
HANOI HILTON. The true horror of the place was so well presented. One could envision what tortures prisoners must have gone through in that dismal place.
Interesting experience. My first foray into the American War was interesting and enlightening. It's a good way to spend an afternoon in Hanoi.
A Place of History. A place where American pilots were captured by Vietnamese during the Vietnam War. Entrance fee is about VND30,000 per adult. Worth a visit!
hoa lo prison visit. It was an interesting visit, cheap entrance, the information is bias so take it with a pinch of salt, but still a good place to see

Interesting take on French and American Wars. An escape for the bustle of Hanoi in a cool and sheltered spot. A good museum with lots to see for 1.5 hour visit. A little sceptical about some of the material posted about treatment of captured American pilots during the Vietnam War but take it with a pinch of salt.

A great way to learn about the past.... Managed to finish up here... A pound to enter. A good walk around with plenty to learn.... watch for the propaganda towards the end of the ground floor walk... and how wonderful the US PoWs were treated... very 'enlightening'
Spend a good hour here.

A WAR PRISON EXPERIENCE. Dubbed the 'Hanoi Hilton' by the captured American pilots during the Vietnam War, this Hanoi museum offers unique insight in one of the darkest corners of Vietnam's centennial war history against French colonoialism and the later US intervention in Hanoi's showdown with Saigon regime. The prison was one of 5 maximum security prisons, built by the French, becoming the filthy, disease-ridden hell for many of Vietnam's prominent revolutionaires, including 5 Communist Party Secretaries and later VN president Duoi Moi. Decades later, American war prisoners suffered at Hoa Lo, including later senator John McCaine and Pete Peterson, who came back to Hanoi i 1995 as the first US Ambassador to postwar Vietnam.Though, somewhat propagandistic, definitely worth a two hour visit, with many unique photos from the French as well as the American era.
Very worthwhile!. Very interesting and good to spend a few hours there learning of the history of the prison and how they were treated and very cheap!

Hanoi Hilton. It takes the dubious nickname of the Hanoi Hilton but Ii doubt if it was a luxury hotel when it was under the French regime! It does give you an insight to how harsh prison conditions have been in the past.Be warned the properganda machine is in full flow when you see photos of the American POWs decorating Chrismas trees etc. An interesting fact that I wasn't aware of is that the Amercan Senetor was imprisoned there.We spent about 1 hour there . It is not expensive to go in 30,000 Dong approx £1 UK or $1.5 US

Prison from French to American history. The museum has a large section with local prisoners by French prior to 1954 the American prlsoners. Very detailed written in English about what happened here. Only a small part remains a museum and the rest has been changed to commercial building. For those who remember the US Vietnam war, there is lots of information . It surprised me that there was not picture of Jane Fonda in the international photos of protest against this war.

Moving and humbling experience . A great museum and a humbling reminder of how the Vietnamese have suffered over the years. Highly recommend. We went here having visited the Ethnology Museum a few days before and it was interesting to follow the cultural history in this way.
Very well done. Great insightful place to see the history of the "Hanoi Hilton". If you're a history buff and want to see the Vietnamese take on the Vietnam War, worth a visit.

Very informative. Interesting and informative. Very harsh conditions but I am sure that was the norm all over the world for prisons at that time. Vietnam has done wonders to rise above all their tough times and invasions bye different countries over the years.Commendable that they are such a friendly lot of people after such harsh times. The thing that gets me a lot is that tourists and visitors expect so much and cannot give people and staff a smilie and a hello. What is the world coming too. Think it is quite cute as the nickname is "Hanoi Hilton" as the Hilton is right next door
A way through history. Shows how French treated Vietnamese rebels. And how rebels escaped through very narrow gap. Very educational. Must go.

Meaningful. This is a must visit if you're in Hanoi and wanted to learn about the history of the city and the country. I didn't know that the U.S. senator John McCain was once held prison here and I was shocked! Seeing those prison condition made you shiver. On a few occasion it brought tears in my eyes simply watching the video clips. It wasn't as scary or disturbing as the s-21 in Phnom Penh.

Interesting place. Very cheap to get in give yourself a couple of hours, it's very interesting to see how they treated the prisoners they even show you the stories of some of the American soldiers which were imprisoned there . Well worth a visit no pressure just go round at your own pace.

Stupid One Sided View of History.
