I did learn something about the harsh treatment of Vietnamese political prisoners by the French colonialists and the formation of the Socialist party and that was interesting.Although i am not American, i had read John McCaine's biography and was interested to see the Vietnamese perspective on the war and their treatment of American soldiers. Ok it was a stupid war and America started it but how can they dare to pretend that they treated US pow's really well at that prison. It's sad that many people might believe their lies.

Unfathomable. Cannot imagine anyone surviving even a few days in this hell hole, let alone weeks, months and years. Kudos to the government for dedicating so many resources to presenting this important facet of their colonial experience, and making it so vivid and real for visitors. While most of the space is devoted to the 80 years of political struggle that predate the War with America, there are a couple of galleries devoted to the 'American' war. The captions and explanatory texts however need to be viewed through the prism of government self-justification.

Very informative, hard to swallow the propaganda!. There are great exhibits and lots of pictures and overall it was a great experience. But it was hard to read the outrageous propaganda posted everywhere. I guess if the museum is in your country, you can re-write history.
Whitewash. There is an incredible story of brutality here but they try so hard to sanitize it that it has a boomerang effect

Checked in to the Hilton and then checked out straight away!. Possibly not quite what I was expecting, but very interesting nevertheless. I had expected bars with beer and wine, not iron bars across windows....Joking apart, the French history was fascinating, with a guilotine that said it all. The simple displays acted as an excellent backdrop to all the things that went on here over the years, culminating in the American Chapter at the end.Very interesting to overhear Americans who thought this would all be about the Viet War. Er no, there was much more history than the period 1965-1975!A must see for a couple of hours. I would say enjoy, but that would be totally crass.

Very interesting museum. This place is a terrible symbol of the French colonialism in Vietnam. The Vietnamese have transformed its remained (most of the prison no longer exists) in an interesting museum showing photos, torture instruments and illustrating the life of the prisoners. A full part is devoted to the time when American pilots were hold prisoner (referred to as Hanoi Hilton by them). The museum is well organised and explained although as in many places one could regret an obviously too biased view- pro socialist propaganda of some explanations.

Be prepared for the propaganda. Most of the prison has been knocked down but a little has been kept. You can visit the cells and see a guillotine used by the French up to the 30's and photos of the results! US pow's were detained here during the war and there is photo evidence of how well they were treated, unfortunately it is the communist version, please google for the truth. You will only need half an hour here.

Interesting way to spend a morning. We visited the prison on the last morning of our stay on Hanoi, as we had a few hours before we moved to Ha Long Bay. I had read several reviews so knew what to to expect. I was pleasantly surprised on the amount of information in each room there was to read. It was rather chilling in places and I knew there information on the Americans staying there was rather limited and painted a rather different picture from the information on various internet sites. Some of the Audio headphones didnt work which was a shame as the information on the one we did use was informative. The entrance is off the main road so we did miss it to begin with, so be aware if following Google maps.
Very interesting. This is a very interesting and informative venue and it has lots of relics to see. The prison grounds are all seen during the self guided tour and it's pretty reasonably priced.

Hanoi Hilton Hoa Lo Prison. The Prison is pretty easy to find,and walk to as its south west of Hoan Kiem lake, on No1 Hoa Lo street. Open from 8am to 5pm every day and it cost 30,000 Vietnamese Dong to enter in June, which is about £1 Sterling. It was very hot walking around you can buy drinks but there's not a cafe on the site. The museum itself is very interesting to walk around, and with life size human dummies looks a bit eerie. Information boards in English tell about the history of the site and how different regimes have used the prison. There is a room dedicated to American POWs of whom John McCain is the most famous. One of the must see sites in Hanoi
Very educational. A sad but great insight to the history of Vietnam, Would have liked a coffee shop or refreshments in the memorial area.
Hanoi Hilton Visit. Although not much remains of the actual prison, the exhibit is quite good at explaining the purpose of the jail and the things that went on there. Worth a visit.
Must see. This was an excellant, eye opening exhibit. Don't miss it. It was one of the highlights of our trip. Well worth a visit !!!

Definitely a must visit. You can try new experience by visiting this prison. The building is original prison from the French colonialism age, go inside and feel how was the Vietnamese struggled during that era.. it feels so real, and eerie at the same time

Good way to spend an hour or two . Interesting history with a lot of visual creations to bring the past to life. Many people mention how biased they are, and that there is propaganda everywhere, but to me it seemed more a case of translation than intentional deception.

something if you like to know about world history through the eyes of the Vietnamese. Little cost for loads of information, well set out and very interesting. You should see the way prisoners were placed by the Vietnamese military. It has a real ambience about it a must see a good hour of easy to move about information, some wheel chair access not all
Interesting. Make sure to visit before 11.30 or after 2pm, as it closes for lunch. Interesting place, information available in English.

Interesting, although boasting propaganda. Very realistic, with interesting stories and a relatively preserved facility. The only thing that's bold is how the information has a string taste of propaganda. Still I'd pay a visit, very interesting.
Good. I found the visit to Hoa Lo Prison interesting. It is a pretty dismal and gruesome place with an awful history.

Interesting historical site . I left with more questions as the information was a bit misleading as to who was the enemy!
I really enjoyed looking around and imagining what life must have been like for them.
Recommend a visit. Reasonably priced, not good access for people with mobility issues.

Very realistic. One of the best war type museums that tell the stories very well of the captured prisoners. All very realistic with informed staff and a real sense of atmosphere with good displays and interesting storytelling.

disappointing. I was not interested in the oppression of the Vietnamese by the French, but instead interested in the American pilot experience of the VN War. Only 1 small room was devoted to this and it showed only pictures of happy Americans playing basketball, exchanging Xmas gifts and having a rollicking good time. I know this was far from true.I regret the time and money I spent.

Quiet space - overcast. Museum depict a prison honest with much dungeon where the captive soldiers, many different sail prison with gruesome instruments of torture, should go noon evening will miss more,

Great for any history or war buff. This museum is great for anyone who has an interest in the Vietnam war. It shows the conditions the Vietnamese communists were held during from French colonial days and includes a guillotine the French used to execute communists. The jail also has a section where american POW's were held including John McCain the American senator they actually have his flight suit on display. As with all museums there is a bit of propaganda and glossing over of some of the atrocities committed by the Vietnamese and a big focus on crimes committed by the Americans in the name of "Imperialism" as they put it but it is an extremely interesting museum I would definitely recommend.

Here you see the vietnamese history of the last 60 years. A real eye opener. We knew a lot of the history of Vietnam, but her you see what the colonial countries really did. We were very impressed and are still astonished that the local people more look to the future as we are doing.
Informative. Good place to get familiar with the period during French times. However, at times a little boring presentation, some speakers did not work.

Walk back into the past... First up, Its a paid attraction. 30k each and 20k for the Hoa Lo Prison booklet.Its a bit spooky here, Has a lot of the old Jail still left intact.. Lots of information and stories.. I enjoyed the part near the end about the US Pilots who were held captive here. Its a great read!You can easily spend 2 hours here. Its very well worth it and worth the read too!
Great to see. Easy to get to and well worth the visit. This is very reasonably priced to get in. Good half day activity.

Eye Opener. We walked to Hoa Lo Prison from our hotel in Hang Quat street.
It was still early in the morning and there was not much crowd. We went to visit the prison cells and it was as if we were transported to the era of few decades ago......
It is worth the visit.
Spare 20 minutes?. If you need to fill 20/30 minutes then well worth a visit to understand the different uses of the prison from early uprisings to POW detention.

Really interesting place!. Going to prison isn't usually on the top of my to-do list whilst on holiday but I wanted to come here to learn more about the local history. Good layout and exhibits, informative displays and helpful staff. Really worth going to.

Hanoi Hilton. This focused more on the persecution of the Vietnamese by the French, there were two small rooms about the times of the Americans pilots being imprisoned there. Not a lot of information about that time.
It was good to visit.... It's worth a visit to get a condensed understanding of some Vietnamese history if you have time to spend.

The Hanoi Hilton - Very Interesting. The Hoa Lo Prison is better known to westerners as "The Hanoi Hilton' which is the nickname given to it by American prisoners held there during the Vietnam War (or The American War as is is known in Vietnam). Some of the prison that existed in the past has been demolished but what remains of this old colonial building has now been turned into a museum. Most of what is on display documents not its use for American captives but rather its use by the French colonists who imprisoned, tortured and executed many Vietnamese during its long history. Inside many of the rooms are presented as they would have been in colonial times with waxwork prisoners bringing the story to life. The horrors of the prison in those times is well portrayed and documented. Many appalling instruments of torture are on display and the reproductions of the give a chilling insight into the Prison's past.In contrast, the section displaying the part where the American pilots were kept goes out of its way to show how well they were treated with old photos of the prisoners smiling and playing games. I am sure it was not all fun and games but there is a stark contrast between the Vietnamese treatment of the Americans and the French treatment of the Vietnamese.Overall, the prison is well worth the visit and is very well presented.

Fascinating history. The prison is now reduced to a small section as parts gave way to modern high rise buildings. A fascinating history of Hanoi which shows firstly the Vietnamese were jailed here, then the aamericans. A must visit if your visiting Hanoi.

Cool history. It was very interesting to see the history of this place. I was well planned out and they kept enough of the prison to get a good feel for what it was like. Also not to busy so you didnt have to worry about other travelers getting in your way. Bathrooms where clean and it is well maintenance other than the speakers to hear some information. I also feel like they held back a bit on the details of what really happened in the prison. Worth a visit.

Prison life. Visited Hoa Li prison on a wet Monday morning, one of the few "tourist attractions" of Hanoi open on Monday. It was well presented with local, English and French notes. We also bought the small guide book which was well written. The prison depicted a harrowing time for the Vietnamese patriots, whereas the American captive pilots seemed to live quite comfortably. A large proportion was destroyed to create the Hanoi Tower which rather overshadows the area. Worth a visit

Worth going but don't expect a lot. Good to go for historical value but highly slanted interpretation and poorly translated English. Focused far more on French occupation than housing US fighter pilots during the Vietnam war.

An Experience . Visited here as part of the Windy 500 Goes Global tour. 14 in the group including an 8 year old. I've visited a few prisons and former concentration camps around the world. This one seemed very sanitised in comparison to Tuol Saleng in Phnom Penh or Auschwitz. About an hour is probably long enough. It's an interesting place. The small, cramped cells, the guillotine and the photos of how prisoners used to live are all interesting. Notices are in various languages including English.

An interesting 3 hours. Hidden away, on a quiet Sunday morning we stopped off at Hoa Lo Prison, better known as Hanoi Hilton.. It was a hot day and little facilities.. But well laid out and quite interesting...
HOA LO PRISON HISTORICAL RELIC. History of Vietnam, if you like to know about vietnam's "world war" ,here is one of the place you have to visit.

Fascinating History in Hanoi. So much can be learnt at Hoa Lo Prison, I would recommend you not miss this attraction.Easy to find and cheap to get to by taxi from Old Quarters.Remember to buy an entrance ticket before going in!

French = bad, vietnamese = good. very 1 sided view on the history, french occupation shown as oppressors and the prison as a worst place on earth, same prison during Vietnam war with us supposedly turned into prison friendly .. a lot of propaganda not entirely in line with the historical truth

Interesting . It's worth a look. Very interesting and informative. It's a pity a lot of the prison grounds are gone to give way for high rise apartments. Close to Hanoi centre so no need to get a taxi if you are based there.

Glad we visited. Well organized and easy to follow, captions in several languages. We did a self guided tour which was fine. Shows both Vietnamese prison life under French occupation and a whole wing dedicated to the Vietnam War and treatment of American POWs. Glad we took the time to see it.

Educational. Interesting place to visit and learn about Vietnam history and how the Vietnamese prisoners were tortured. It's quite eerie to see the prison cells. Highly recommended if you are into history.

Sobering. The prison has been much reduced in size in order to make room for several high-rise apartments. The museum is largely dedicated to explaining the treatment of the Vietnamese by the French and provides a very white-washed version of the life of American pilots held there. For US tourists, one should remember that the cells shown and depictions of abuse were used during the American War by and upon those referred to as Imperialist pirates and criminals. However, the official descriptions assurance visitors that the Americans were so well treated that they called it The Hanoi Hilton in recognition of their five-star accommodations. It is a sobering place to visit, but one should do a little research first in order to gain an appreciation for the courage if these prisoners.

Eerie experience. Well preserved landmark in Hanoi. Seeing the living conditions of the prisoners was creepy and educational at the same time. In my opinion, you can skip the organised tour and visit it yourself. They have infographics and some rooms show videos to give more insight on the place.

"Hanoi Hilton". This site is an interesting place to visit and is a bit sobering. Certainly presents information from the Vietnamese perspective. Displays have English captioning so you can easily read them.

Educational but a bit grim. To learn a bit about the modern history of Vietnam, this is an interesting place to visit. Although it is now a museum, it was used as a real prison to hold prisoners so it is quite grim seeing the actual prison cells! Admission is cheap, is open Tuesday to Sunday and it is within easy walking distance to the old quarter.

Only if you are into history. 30,000VND. Time spent 45 minutes. 22 pictures taken. It's within walking distance from the city centre (20 minutes). Lots of reading and some audio visual. Frankly, it's difficult for those without firsthand knowledge of both the French Occupation and the Vietnam War. Else, skip it.
history. good displays and most informative with some very moving sections. displays are very well set out & well signed.

Visiting the Hanoi Hilton. The Hoa Lo Prison is more famously known as the Hanoi Hilton that held many American captures during the Vietnam war. The tour was very interesting and told how the prisoners lived and also tourtured during their captivity. Many rooms and original pictures are displayed throughout the tour.

Very interesting. We had our own local tour guide when we visited here recently, sadly we arrived late in the afternoon and we were being pushed through very quickly by the staff. But we did see everything and with the local guide we got a lot more info about the 'Hanoi Hilton' Well worth a visit to see the way prisoners were treated and the conditions they were forced to live in.

Eye opening!!. Difficult to find at first as we walked from our hotel. Once finding the prison it was all amazing experience and eye opener about the history of prison and how badly they was treated. 100% worth the trip. Must do in Hanoi.
Worth a visit . The museum really leaves an impression, with some of the cells on death row remaining for you to look into.

A heavy and serious place. If you're not solider or history lover , I will not recommend this place for you . It's way too heavy . Most of the room is creepy with fake man . If you insist to go , remember go with at least 2 friends .

Central Prison - a must see.. I still can't believe this was the equivalent of a couple of dollars entry. We walked from our hotel in the old quarters and were blown away at the conditions at which prisoners used to live, and more so at how some managed to escape. I won't give too much away and ruin it for you but needless to say it is definitely worth a visit when you're in Hanoi. It could be quite confronting, and will probably make you count your blessings so be prepared to walk around slowly reading all the descriptions and absorb it all.
A sobering experience. Seeing how the Vietnamese prisoners were treated was a very sad and sobering experience. Not a happy place that's for sure.

Good price and very interesting. Compared to a few attractions in Hanoi, I found this the most interesting museum. It has a lot of pictures, artifacts, explanations and rooms where you can get lost in Hanoi's history. Worth a visit.

A must see place on any visit to Hanoi. Very interesting place to visit full of historic reference (with a touch of propaganda thrown in).The many incumbents over the years seemed to have a very tough time indeed. Much of it has been maintained in it's original condition which adds to the experience. Of particular interest is the section dedicated to the American aircrew that were held here in the "Hanoi Hilton". There are some artefacts from their stay and even the airsuit and plane parts from John McCain's plane that was shot down in a nearby lake.Like all visits in Hanoi it's not expensive, about 100VND (£3).Well worth a visit and recommended.
Perfect to improve our historic knowledge. Hoa Lo Prison is impressive.A lot of picture, explanations, souvenirs in each room to teach us History.Really interesting.

Interesting and ok for older kids too.. We wanted our kids to learn more about the history of Hanoi, and Vietnam, and not just all the nice tourist bits. They (aged 8 & 10) found the visit interesting, were a little saddened by the hardships faced by the prisoners, but were not upset by it. There is one section you can avoid (with the guillotine in it) if you are worried at all - we adults took turns being in front to vet the material/displays beforehand and this worked well.
Depressing. Visiting the prison gives you an insight of the prisoners of war and how they were treated. Well worth a look.

Cheap entry, very interesting, worth checking out!. If you're into prisons and museums you should definitely check this place out. Cheap entry and it's quite interesting. Allow between 1-3 hours and double check the opening times as many places in Vietnam close for a few hours during the day.Enjoy and happy travels x

Informative. We walked to Hoa Lo Prison from the Old Quarter and then on to the French Quarter thus making the loop round the whole Lake. The walk was worth it as you had time to stop where and when you wanted. The Prison had a feel to it and gave you a chance to things from a different perspective. Worth the visit

So so. We came here as per Lonely Planet's recommendation. Located a short walk from the Old Quarter, the Hoa Lo Prison requires a 30,000 Dong entrance and around an hour to visit if you want to stop and read all the signs. It's a very simpleand dark building, which shows the history of the war in a propagandesque way - "how the American soldiers were wonderfully treated here and they then realised their mistakes and felt bad about treating the peaceful Vietnamese people they way that they did". Wouldn't do this attraction again.

different views. By touring what I knew as Hanoi Hilton, they made it look like it was a resort for the American airmen, by showing pictures of them playing soccer, basketball etc. but again this is a one sided view, it showed the types of clothes the airmen were released with, and the terrible conditions they lived in, well worth visiting

Okay . From out city tour we decided to make a trip here, inside we saw old pics from the Vietnam war, relics and chambers were prisoners were kept, i think the highlight of the trip was John Macains war uniform and pics from his capture, for a 1 hr tour, i think i learned something

Lucky not to be imprisoned!. Very interesting tour. Cannot believe human beings could torture another human being in such in humane ways.
It made me realise how lucky I am to be living today!
The Hanoi Hilton. Winners get to write the history. Told how wonderfully the American airmen were treated during the Vietnam war

Highly recommended for teens and adults. All the signs are in English as well as Vietnamese and there are points where a speaker system is available to hear audio commentary in English, French or Vietnamese. Extremely interesting and at points quite moving. Not suited for very young children though as the suggested tour is quite extensive and quite respect is a must.

The History, Propaganda, and John McCain Package. If you're in Hanoi, it would be silly to not stop here. The prison is conveniently located (I don't think that was done with tourism in mind) and requires approximately 1 hour to visit. As most of the other reviewers note, it's a propaganda machine, which is interesting by itself. Most of the prison focuses on the French occupation, when it was used to house Vietnamese revolutionaries (I believe that's their self-coined term). A smaller section is devoted to the American's held during the American-Vietnam War. This is where John McCain's flight suit isOverall it's an easy and convenient history lesson. Entrance fee is VND$30k.
Piece of history. Interesting place to learn about French colonization of VIetnam and some propaganda about how well American pilots were held there.
Worth the visit. Quite a gruesome place to visit, but you really do get to understand what it must have been like for those that were imprisoned there.

Vietnam War History . One of the most important attractions in Hanoi. I believe it's a must see attraction. In this prison you can watch Vietnam Wars History from the 1900 when the prison was built by the French until the American war against Vietnam. It's a sad period of time for the Vietnamese and I hope we learn from History to stop War everywhere.

Powerful but... At times a moving tribute to all those that were kept there and perished, but at other times a bit of a mish mash of pictures.There is often a modern feel to the exhibits that show and explain what gained in the prison.
Forget It!!!. Rather touristy, hardly looks or feels like a prison anymore. Instead, donate your money to Amnesty International or a Vietnam Vet fun of your choosing.

Nice museum. On of the best and most infomativ museums we visited in Vietnam, and pretty cheap as well.
Definetly worth a visit!

Fascinating insight into the life of prisoners!. The prison has various exhibits ranging from the lands original use as a village producing earthen wares, through to its time as a prison used by the French for Vietnamese revolutionaries, and finally it's use for American POW's. The main historical value comes from it's use as a prison by the French. Various remnants of the history remain including a guillotine. There's plenty of signs and information around the rooms to give you an understanding of what went on there.I'd say it's well worth a visit!

Dark but interesting. Learning about a city's past was very important to me and I am glad that our tour guide from Hanoi Free Tour Guides brought us to the Hoa Lo Prison. In here you can learn about the city and country's dark history under the French. Some of the exhibits can be a bit disturbing so it was good that we came in with a good mood. An interesting bit of the place was the videos regarding the treatment of US soldiers who were POWs at the prison. A great deal of effort was placed to emphasize that they were treated well by the Vietnamese. Another interesting bit was the photo exhibit on how the other then communist countries supported North Vietnam in their fight against the US. If you are a history buff or appreciate seeing things used in the past (whether for good or bad)...this will be worth your time.
More interesting than anticipated. interesting to read and see perspective from Vietnamese about the war. Even though some of the stuff seemed like propaganda it was well worth a visit

Boring. I was expecting way more from the prison, I expected it to have been maintained almost exactly as it had been originally so you could really get a feel of what the inmates went through. It was badly organised, I often ended up in rooms I had already been in by accident. And it's portrayed incredibly one sidedly.

Must view Man's inhumanity to Man..... The infamous "Hanoi Hilton" as depicted in the film of the same name or "Maison Centrale" which was built by the French during colonization in the 1800's. Modernisation in Hanoi has seen the greater part of this old prison demolished to make way for concrete and glass, however what is left has been restored or preserved and is a MUST SEE when in Hanoi. This is a stark reminder of the cruelty meted out by the French against Vietnamese citizens, who opposed their dominating rule of law and invasion of their country. Of course this is where the US pilots of the American War against 'Communism' were incarcerated and tortured.Death row, the original 'portable' Guillotine, women's cells, admin. and other such facilities of this dark place are worth a visit to enlighten visitors to the atrocities that went on behind these walls in the middle of Hanoi. Entry is about $3 AUD and worth every cent. Allow at least an hour plus to take in the atmosphere and read all of the graphic history.This is a must see and for reasons only known to tourist companies, this historic sight seems to have been omitted from most of their touring agenda's.Don't leave Hanoi without visiting the Hanoi Hilton.....

Part of the American War period. Home to many American Prisioner of War captured during the mid 60-70's period. US Presidential candidate John McCann was a resident. A must see to start to understand the 2nd Indo-China war.
Scared Prison. I used to watch some prison scared in somewhere but there is one the scared prison I think if you can see and listen to many stories about the war
Hoa Lo Prison. A must do if in Hanoi, it will make you appreciate exactly what you have and what time you are living in
Interesting. This really opens up your eyes,I found it quite upsetting. Glad I went though.To think this happened in the 1900s. Well worth a visit

Interesting piece of history. This was one of the highlights in Hanoi for me,the history of the place is brutal and not many would be able to take the abuse that the in mates suffered here. To be honest the French did not come out of this period in time with much glory. It's amazing to think they were still using the guillotine in the 1930's.well worth a trip and a hour of your time.

Good to learn about the US - Vietnam relationship during and after the Vietnam war. Very informative and well structured prison tour - which you don't need a guide for since the description is all well written in English.The highlight (I guess) of this attraction is McCain's capture as a pilot during the war.
Worth a visit. We enjoyed our walk around the prison 30k entry is cheap and it's very confronting in some areas, we walked there from our hotel easy walk from lake area

Central to the Vietnamese struggle for independence. I read a lot of reviews (particularly the "1" rated) before I went to Hoa Lo. Many talked of propaganda. What would you expect? Tell me which country doesn't use propaganda? To me, the propaganda is part of the story.It is a little repetitive, but you can understand it when the people were put through such hardship.They do like to pretend that they were really nice to American POWs, but we all know better and it is a pretty thin attempt that would have worked on many people before the internet.

Worth a look. Went here as part of our tour so we got the Vietnamese version of French colonisation and American bombing. Seems the American pilots spent all day playing volleyball and writing letters to home. Very civilised??Has one of only two guilotines brought to Vietnam for executions.Cell life looked particularly brutal for the locals under French rule.Worth a look.

Striking but very one sided. . This place is worth seeing, but be aware that as much as the conditions they portray were horrendous, the way they are described very much resembles the propaganda language used in the communist regimes across Europe in the past. That said, the exposition itself is very well done.

Shocking . They really don't leave it any details on the history this place, it's really shocking to read and learn in detail the horrors bestowed on these people. History should never be forgotten, so it doesn't get repeated. Worth visiting to pay respects to Viet nam

A worthwhile visit. I learned a lot particularly as the French colonist rule was not something particularly taught in school. A great insight into the history of the Vietnamese struggle and suffering. I think the American part is certainly propaganda but it's interesting to see what they have to show overall. My visit is five stars with a Hanoi Kids Tour Guide providing us with even more depth and knowledge of history during our visit, but for others touring the prison on their own, there is no audio or detailed explanation on certain things shown so hence the four stars.

interesting museum. Interesting & informative museum. They provide map, short movie and english text in all rooms & collections to make visitor understand about vietnamese history, especially about the French occupation, Vietnam war, and how its prison used to hold Vietnamese prisoners, particularly political prisoners agitating for independence who were often subject to torture and execution. For entrance fee you need to pay 30.000 VND

Interesting but well worn. A very interesting place to visit but it's a shame that some of the information audio was not functioning properly, sadly we got ushered out at full speed when 5 PM came round so allow plenty of time and no later than 3.30 if you want a leisurely visit as there is a lot to read.

Average. Shows a decent amount of history but doesn't have a 'prison' feel
Newly painted etc, more like a museum
If you have the time head over, short for time don't stress

Interesting Place. So Barbaric the "Hanoi Hilton" the USA pilots called it during the Vietnam War.
Most of it has been demolished but sufficient remains to see what it would have been like
Really interesting. A must see for everyone. You get to see a lot of information of what happened there during the war. On walking distance from the Lake. You don't need a taxi ..

Hanoi Hilton!. Another don't miss in Hanoi! See John McCain's uniform and cell. Also, the prison was built by the French when they colonized Vietnam. It was a very informative tour and I'll leave it at that.

modern day propaganda. An interesting hour spent here, focusing on Vietnam's struggle with French rule and the Vietnam War.What I found most interesting was not what had been presented, but how it was presented, particularly the Vietnam War. The account of the war and their treatment of American POWs sits at odds with what was reported in the West.Worth a short visit.

Really interesting. A really interesting walk through the history of the prison and it's occupants. The English text panels are well written and the mannequins are eerie but well placed. It's open in most places so quite hot. There are fans but aim for a quite day. I went on a Tuesday morning and there were about 20 - 30 people wandering about.Entry was 30,000d plus 20,000d for the book (which you don't need inside but is an interesting souvenir).

Interesting place. The prison has a lot of history so definitely worth spending an hour or two walking around and learning about what went on there. Vietnam's history is fascinating and this prison played a significant part throughout the years.

Interesting museum. I guess out of all the museums I visited in Hanoi this one stands out as it is "real"! In the sense that there were real people who suffered and were killed/beheaded in this prison you can almost "feel" what happened here not so long ago!!
Very Interesting. Very good representation of what was a truly terrible place to have been incarcerated. Don miss the Guillotine used under the French rule of the prison

A chilling insight to Vietnam's history. Known as "The Hanoi Hilton" by the American P O Ws who were imprisoned here in the 1960s and 70s Hoa Lo Prison is a stark reminder of the terrible history of Vietnam right back to the occupation by the French in the 1920s to 50s History buffs will find this fascinating.

Interesting and imformative. Did this early in our stay in Hanoi which gave us a great grounding on knowledge of Vietnamese History, especially the French occupation and Vietnam war. Found it easy to do a self guided tour. We walked from the old quarter about 1.2 kms paid 30000 VND each to get in and spent about hour and a half there. All displays had English translation and we found it fascinating.
worth a visit. Just to see how prisoners suffered and locked up with very bad conditions even it was a prison, we only saw one third as the rest of prison was demolished for redevelpment

A qualified thumbs-up. You have to begin with curbing your expectations. Museums in Vietnam (especially those that relate to war history) are heavily propagandized, so naturally you'll walk away from this place feeling like the French were really brutal to the Vietnamese when they ran Hoa Lo, but the American prisoners were treated very humanely. So be forewarned.Having said that, I've seen worse examples, and you do get a sense of the place and learn about some interesting historical episodes. Most of the original prison has been uprooted for the sake of progress, but some of the buildings are still there.If you are here already, interested in the place and want to cross it off your bucket list, by all means stop by. But don't fly here just for this.
A must visit. Great place to visit to get a Vietnamese perspective on the whole Vietnam war. Good information and some great pictures.

Interesting to see, but learn your history before going to see it. Since it is such a famous place we didn't want to miss it. With that said there wasn't much here, and there was a lot of misleading information about the treatment of prisoners. It looks like the Americans captured where at summer camp, while the French who used the prison before the Vietnam were very brutal with the Vietnamese prisoners. Sad that the Vietnamese people actually believe that crock.....

Interesting!. The prison gives you a sense of the impact the North of Vietnam felt in terms of foreign intervention. This focuses on French intervention and how they suppressed Communism. There is also a lot on the Vietnam War and how American POWs were treated by the Vietnamese. Worth an hour of your time. It costs $30000 for an adult (less than $2 US) and kids were free.

Interesting look from Vietnamese perspective . Interesting history going back to French colonial times and the conditions that existed through its use as a prison for US pilots during Vietnam War. Definitely biased descriptions regarding the treatment of the U.S. pilots. Worth the visit.

Hanoi hilton. It's set up is good and they show u the horrible things the people had to endure. Don't get me wrong it's a horrible place in history but it's in the idea of the socialist revolution, I hoped it would be more objective and more explained then it was. All in all a good start to get an idea.

It is a great history list !. Our city tour which was including the Hoa Lo Prison and where could gave us perspective center of the Vietnam history after thousands of years. It is a great place and you must see when you visit Vietnam!
Eerie insight into Colonial Vietnam. Very interesting & sobering look at yet more atrocities visited on the Vietnamese people in their recent history.

Propoganda plus!. The history of the prison when it was under French rule was interesting. However the depiction of life for Air Force pilots incarcerated during the Vietnam war is pure propaganda. The history of the place is depressing but it is part of our history like the gas chambers and the killing fields. Not a glamorous history but true!

Interesting history and views. This prison was built by the french in 1896 and used by them until 1954. American pilots that were shot down during bombing raids in Hanoi were kept here 1968-73. I wasn't sure what to expect and usually avoid war related historical places but this place was interesting. The treatment of Vietnamese prisoners by the french was appalling but I was surprised by the display of photos of the American prisoner pilots having their christmas dinner and enjoying literature and television. Quite a contrast considering what I had learned of the Vietnam War. Interesting in any case.

Sombre. I wish I had read more about the American and French wars before I went to the prison but nonetheless got a good sense of it while I was there. The models of Vietnamese prisoners helped portray a mood and feel for what it must have been like for these absolutely brave men.

Chilling and fascinating!. Learning a lot about former Hanoi through this prison was fascinating. Americans are taught a slightly different version of the happenings during the "War", and it's enlightening to experience knowledge told by the exhibits here.

Interesting. There are alot of things to do in Hanoi but I'm glad I visited Hoa Lo Prison.The entry price is reasonable and there are a lot of displays to see and take in.It depicts alot of torture and atrocities that occurred there so beware that some things might not be everyone's cup of tea. This would be a must see for anyone interested in history.

Sobering. The goal exhibition is very well presented. There is plenty of information that is written in English as well as Vietnamese. It is a very sobering visit and of course is explained from the Vietnamese point of view. I am not sure if American tourists would feel comfortable visiting the prison, but it does give an idea of the terrible conditions the prisoners faced.

Come to Hoa Lo Prison, come to see strength, spirit of Vietnamese under the French colony. When you go there, I guarantee that you will not only find a lot in Vietnamese history, time of French colony and American War in Vietnam, and their deadly torture to Vietnamese prisoners; but also find and admire spirits, strength, intelligence of the prisoners to together overcome the hardship.

Biased but interesting. The prison was built by the French to house Vietnamese prisoners and then used by the Vietnamese during the American war to house American prisoners. So know your stuff beforehand because the Vietnamese overemphasize how bad it was under the French to the Vietnamese people and underemphasize how bad the Vietnamese were to the Americans.
Great museum. Really enjoyed this museum. It's a great representation of the prison, its history and inmates. Well displayed and great translations
Interesting place to go.. It's always interesting to see things from the other side. If in town go check it out. Reasonable entry price.
Informative. Walking through the Hoa Lo Prison gave us perspective of the history of Vietnam. The torture individuals faced is something we would never be able to understand. It is a must see

First time in prison!. This prison is open to public and you have to buy ticket at the entrance for 30,000 VND. You can walk from the Old Quarter to here! It's a self guide visiting, you just have to follow the directions of where to go next inside the prison. There are plenty of descriptions and stories to read, and also things to see. It's a new experience for me! You have to spare around 1 and a half hour inside there.
Thought provoking. I'd say this is the best museum I visited in Hanoi. It is small but covers a lot of ground through shocking atrocities.

Impressive to see this place!. interesting if you are interested in history. the quality of information provided can be disputed in terms of authenticity vs what we know about the treatment of POWs during the Vietnam war.

An interesting lesson in Vietnamese history. I was amazed to find out how the people of Vietnam were treated or more so poorly treated in this Gaol. my only previous knowledge was of the US POW that were sent here during the war

Remains of the Hanoi Hilton. the American POWs held here nicknamed this prison the Hanoi Hilton. The part of the old prison that remains is open for tourists. It's a grim place and quite graphic so it is not somewhere to go if you want upbeat. The treatment of prisoners under the French was barbaric. None of the exhibits of the American prisoners detail any cruelty at the hands of the North Vietnamese but this is the usual " the victors write the history"

Excellent. The hoa lo prison is something I had never seen before. Some parts of the museum actually gave me the creeps, as it felt so true! The scenes revived and it was a unique experience everyone should have!

Great site bit sad though. Amazing set up help you understand more about part of Vietnamese history, perhaps someone said it is bit bias but well, it is a chance for you seeing other sides views and it all real about the part of Vietnamese history and how people proud of their own history

Worth a visit.. An interesting insight into French regime in Ha Noi. A section is also dedicated to the US captives during the Vietnam war. It's all well signed with English language or subtitled films to watch.
very interesting. Nice place for 2 hours spending. The American pilot exhibition and the differences between the french treatment was interesting

Interesting but brutal. The Hoa Lo Prison was well worth the visit, it gave a lot of history and understanding as to how much the French controlled the country, their punishments were severe. We were fortunate enough to meet one of the ex prisoners who managed to escape with 10 other prisoners through the drainage system. It was an honor to meet him and listen to his story, difficult to understand the conditions they survived in, and not many did survive, but very interesting to learn some of the countries history. Worth a visit.

Interesting perspectives. Did not really know what expect - confronting in parts - but not like the war remnants museum in hi chi minh city. Not really for children. Would have been better to come here alone.

Hugely informative.. I was truly amazed at how visiting this revealed the diversity and hardship of Vietnamese history in the past century. The things that have happened in this part of the world over the past few hundred years are shocking and show just how evil the human race can be. The history surrounding this building can be felt as you enter the front gate, well worth a visit.

Extremely interesting . Quite an eye opener. Wow see Madam Le Guillotine. The one that was actually used. My God us humans are a pretty cruel species. The war in the 70's and the home version. I am sure there are 3 sides to the truth and outcomes. But all in all it was an American blunder. Worth a visit.
Well worth a visit. Very interesting and gives your a real understanding of the hard times prisoner endured, easy to work your way around the many displays and will be around a 1-2 hours experience

Historically interesting. Very intertersting if you like you're history but much of the documentation only translated from veitnamese into french or vis versa. Didnt get the english audio tour which was probly my bad. Worth a quick visit
very interesting, very confronting. Very interesting and confronting historical visit. What terrible conditions those poor prisoners must have endured.Well worth the visit

Something Different. If you are looking for something a bit different to go see Hoa Lo Prison is certainly it. The prison is presented extremely well and shows both its history under the French and as where American POWs were kept. The view of how American POWs were kept has certainly been romanticized, however when you look at the way a typical Vietnamese family lives I can understand the general view that the Americans were given the very best of conditions.I wouldn't say the hour I spent at Hoa Lo was the happiest of my life, however i am very glad I went

very somber place to visit,but well worth it. Great place to visit to learn how the Vietnamese were treated in prison during the french running parts of Hanoi30,000 DONG entry fee,20,000 for guide book.recommended.Recommended visiting time,2 hourd

Interesting place to visit. We heard about this place by chance over lunch talking to other tourists. We were very glad we made the trip. It was a fascinating place, plenty of interesting displays both about the Vietnamese prisoners during the French occupation and also the U.S. Pilots during the American war as it is call in Vietnam.Well worth a side trip.

Must see in Hanoi. This is definitely worth the time for a visit! Great to see that it has been remembered even though such atrocities were committed here. The conditions the prisoners must have endured here can only be imagined. Guided tours or do it yourself, it is a Must See when in Hanoi. Depending on how interested you are could could easily spend a few hours wandering around reading all the information and seeing the old prison.
Worth a visit. Extremely interesting, very sad, and knowledgeable. Very well displayed with loads of information. Worth a visit

Delivers an interesting perspective. An interesting site to visit but not an overly extensive experience.From a History perspective the museum looks at the French experience as well as detailing the experiences of American pilots who were imprisoned here during the war.The prison was sarcastically given the nickname the 'Hanoi Hilton' and after visiting I could certainly imagine why.
Very interesting place to visit. Interesting place to visit. A lot of propaganda, facts & disturburbing images. The guillotine was huge, much bigger than I thought it would be.

Informative historical account. This prison although now drastically reduced in size from its original construction gives an informative history of the conditions endured by political activists and criminals throughout its inception. Very informative.

Great glimpse into the history of the prison.. Great glimpse into the history of what it was like for the prisoners and the shocking conditions that they had to live in. Good place to visit if you have a few hours. I also recommend bying the brochure which was about $2 as it gives you more detail.

I guess the victor does write history for those that are too dumb to do a google search..... Propaganda is always ugly. The assertion that US servicemen were well treated in Hoa Lo is utter nonsense and yet the videos shown depict happy and healthy POW's enjoying Christmas and playing chess. The reality is that the guards at Hoa Lo had a mandate for torturing downed pilots, and torture they did in spades. This is a nasty place filled with lies and propaganda. I guess the victor does write history for those that are too dumb to do a google search....

Well worth a look.. Very interesting and informative. Not bias like the Ho Chi Minh museum.Good look into Vietnamese history.It was used once by the French to Imprison Vietnamese communists and then again by the Vietnamese to imprison American pilots shot down over Hanoi. Conditions were very different during these two periods!Costs 30,000 VND and well worth it for about an hours look.

Astonishing Revelations. This prison is a grim reminder of the pain and suffering endured by the then prisoners under French rule and it became a place where the resistance movement was probably mooted. The prison was over crowded and unfit for housing three times more soldiers than it could hold. It was also referred to as the Hanoi Hilton in jest.During the Vietnam war many American POW's were held in this prison by the North Vietnamese.The were put through all forms of torture to gather information as can be seen by the way the prisoners were locked up at the ankles

Very informative. I liked the fact that this museum did not just concentrate on the Vietnam War & the US prisoners interned there, but covered the full spectrum of the prison's history including during French Occupation.

Must-go for history buffs with reasonably detailed write-ups. There is a general heaviness and darkness as you experience the place. There is a definite feeling of suffering and pain as you slowly soak in the environment. The exhibits (such as the 'actual prison cells') contained life-sized figures that enabled you to fully visualise the actual suffering of the people who were once held there. The prison also had (deliberately deconstructed) half-broken down walls which enabled you to see the real thickness and width of each cell wall. Generally quite a graphic place (in terms of replica life-sized figurines) and the write-ups were relatively detailed. Can be covered in 30 mins as the area is quite small. Follow the signs and the route to cover the full prison is quite foolproof.
Must. It may not be a beautiful tour but is has great historical value and walking in the prison and looking into the small cells with chained mannequins will put things in perspective.

Interesting. The museum looked well preserve, as it is the real prison that was used in both vietnam wars. What is funny to see is the manipulation about the big suffer of the vietnameses during the french hold, and the "luna park" prison and nice conditions for the american prisoners during the second war. It doesnt feel too right but this is about patriotism

One hour in Hylton Prison. Very interesting building and exhibits at Hoa Lo Prison. Good to see how conditions were for the unfortunate people who were imprisoned there.A must see in Hanoi and only needs one hour of your time.
Good to see - 1 hour. Must see - only takes an hour of your day. Close to other attractions. Interesting perspective for a westerner
Vietnam POW history and more. It's good to get another countries' point of view of the Americans and how well they were treated during their stay at the "Hanoi Hotel".

Well describes vietnam history. Wether you are into history or not, this museum is a must in your list of places to see in hanoi. The admission fee is 30000 dong and i dont think you need a guide as every part of it is described clearly. The museum perfectly depicts the situation when the museum was still a prison. You can sense how things were at those times.
Interesting. Nice place for 2 hours spending. The American pilot exhibition and the differences between the french treatment was interesting.

Guillotine. Interesting to see how folks where kept locked away for years &the daring escapes some made out.If you are interested in the Vietnam War it shows objects from POWs including pilot John McCain and other pilots.

The statue of the prisoners look so real!I was so scared. The very good place to learn about history of Vietnam,especially about the French war and American war.I was impressed by the way they fought during that hard time

Well worth a visit. The prison was built in the late 1800's by the French to house Vietnamese political prisoners. In 1913 it was extended to hold 600 prisoners but at times up to 2,000 prisoners were held there. Many well known Vietnamese political figures spent time here during the 30's and 40's and the conditions were pretty appalling.The displays show the architecture of the buildings, how prisoners were held, the isolation cells, torture and execution tools as well as sewer pipes used as escape routes.The Vietnamese used the prison during the Vietnam war to hold POW's. What is interesting here are the displays of this era where propaganda has kept in showing a happy and comfortable environment. The truth lies somewhere in the middle of what both sides depicted.Only a small part of the prison remains today but it is well worth a visit. It is within easy walking distance of the Old and French Quarters. Entry fee is VND30,000.

Very interesting, must vist. A very good museum. Given the politics surrounding the history of this place, the time that the prison was used by the French is much more well documented than the time the Vietnamese used it to hold US POWs.

Very thought-provoking. I found it invaluable visiting here, to get a sense of what the Vietnamese people endured under French colonial rule and the barbaric conditions that prisoners were kept in. There is an interesting exhibition on how America POW's in the Vietnam war were held by comparison. Some good video and graphic photos. Even making allowances for the propaganda in this and all other exhibitions, it makes it more remarkable that the Vietnamese people can be so welcoming to their Western visitors.

So so. I was with a student ambassador tour guide when I visited the prison, so he was able to add more to this tour to make it more meaningful. I definitely think it's a must-see, but it's a bit anti-climactic at the same time.
Worth the visit . Very interesting and well put together. Fun to walk around and see the different rooms and such. Definite must see

Interesting museum. Inexpensive entry fee and an interesting museum. As other reviewers have said you have to look past the propaganda written in their guidebook but there is no taking away from how brutal this place must have been. The US Airforce section is pretty interesting with a special exhibit made of Sen. John McCain's flying suit taken from him during his capture and incarceration in the prison.
Eye Opener. You can get a real sense of what prisoners when through in this prison. Smaller than you think as only a section of the prison remains but would recommended to see

very good visit, informational. nice place to spend at least 2 hours in. well maintained, gives you a good idea of a part of vietnamese history, what they went through and accomplished eventually.documents and records the treatment of heroic locals by the oppressive french. also has a american invasion section. go for a slice of history, your respect for this country will grow.
Realistic portrayal of history. This is the place where Senator John McCain was held during the Vietnamese War. It is very descriptive. Be sure to see the video on the second floor.

An inspiration of courage and a change of perspective. A good way to see the atrocities of Vietnamese colonial past. As much as the displays are eerie, it somehow shows the strength of the people by surviving this and coming out to the streets in revolution. An interesting section to see is the American POW section where photos of smiling POW were displayed accompanied by texts about how well the American soldiers were treated during their capture,and even called the prison "Hanoi Hilton". Makes us think of the different perspectives of the world.

Decent. It's a pretty small museum. Spent about 1.5-2 hours. Would recommend this place if you like museums. It was interesting to see certain areas of the prison, although it was quite disturbing. Most of the exhibit was dedicated to the French colonists and their treatment of Vietnamese political prisoners. There were only a few exhibits on the American POWs, with pictures of smiling prisoners playing board games. But these seem to contradict some of the accounts I have heard. Overall, this place gets a 7/10

Insightful. This prison is definitely worth a visit for those who want to learn more about what happened in Vietnam during French colonialism and how prisoners were treated. It was an interesting experience, you can even see life like sculptures of prisoners throughout the museum and see how the prisoners lived.
Very informative. Good to see the history. Very informative and easy to read. Pleasant to walk thru, quite confronting in a few place.

Eye opening! Thought provoking. Well worth an hour or two if its a bit hot or its raining. A bit of history that happened not so very long ago. Not for the over sensitive because it tells it like it was. Everyone should go and see this if only to make us less complacent with our own society

It's a museum. I visited War Remnant Museum in Ho Chi Minh before, and therefore found around 30% of the informations/stories have been told in War Remnant Museum (like Guillotine, corpse basket, American bombing photos, American PoWs photos)The other 70% of the stories emphasized the Vietnamese resistance war toward French colonialism (before 1945). So you will still find new things in this museum.What I really like is the main entrance of this museum - "Maison Centrale" and you really need to take a good picture at this entrance - as there's no good photo object at the museum (unless you want to take a photo of the readings). I spent about 1.5 hours in this museum. Tip: There's a photo of John McCain when he was captured as PoW in this museum.

A very good experience.... We came here without a guide but it is easy to get around. We purchased a booklet in the ticketing office that gives sufficient information. I highly recommend this place when you have more time in Hanoi.

Hoa Lo Prison. Emphasis on French colonial time there & a little about the Vietnam ("American) war. Heavily biased of course, & not reflective of the history as i know it. Did not really like it , although some of our co-travellers did so.

Ok to visit. Small exhibition of whatever left of the old prison. Most of the prison was given up to develop a luxury Hilton hotel We felt it became mostly propaganda as how bad French were to Vietnamese and how good Vietnamese were to the captured Americans.

Interesting. Very interesting and informative although some parts you have to really think about what they are saying for example the wall with qoutes of the last words before execution. These words have only been remembered and passed on by word of mouth. But nevertheless an interesting tour.

If you're pressed for time, skip this. Recreated prison environment with Vietnamese propaganda interpretation of the American war. Very staged and somewhat historically inaccurate. Better off reading about the subject and spending time elsewhere. If you have a ton of time or it's a rainy day, then go see it. Can see everything in around 1.5 hours.

Interesting historical site. Very interesting (although at times depressing), with different sections dedicated to the French occupation and the Vietnamese war when American pilots were held here. I had not appreciated that women prisoners had also been held here. Some of the photos and stories of individuals held here were very moving.

History revised. The famous Hanoi Hiton is a must see while visiting Hanoi. Don't expect to get a true and factual portray of the treatment of American POWs. According to the Vietnamese it was very different that what we have been told by the former inmates over the past 40 yearsA visit to modern Vietnam is fascinating. The people are warm and friendly. You must however keep an open mind on the war era.

Sobering. Not a fun place to visit but a very important piece of colonial history. Although it is often remembered as the "Hanoi Hilton" from the time it was used to house American POWs, it was originally built by the French for Vietnamese criminal and political prisoners. Some of the displays are unsettling but if you wish to have a better understanding of the Vietnamese people and their history the prison is a must see.

Usual Vietnamese bias. Interesting enough to visit, well laid out and info boards in three languages. A lot of information on the prison during French rule, but rather unsurprisingly little on the American War, apart from one room describing how well the American POW's were treated. The usual bias you come to expect from museums in Vietnam.

Interesting Place. Very interesting place with a dark history. Lots of info in English about the French and Vietnamese use of the prison. Has a guillotine on display that was apparently used on Vietnamese political prisoners during French occupation - a very creepy object.

Interesting but confronting!!. The Hoa Lo Prison was one of those things I was 50:50 to go and see and also take my kids. The visit was well worth it. The history of the prison from French control through to the 1970's was definitely eye opening and confronting. For me kids I went from almost pulling them out, to deciding to let them go through it. The result was them realising how lucky they are to have the lives they have.

Very interesting . Very interesting and informative. I wish I had more background knowledge in general of the Vietnam war. As a Canadian we don't learn about this war at all in school so my knowledge was quite limited. My time at this museum would have been alot better if I had a better grasp on the events. Still worth the visit.

Prison museum - Hanoi. Nice setup, catered and information available in 3 languages (Vietnamees, English and French). In one and a half hour you can have a good overview of the usage of this prison in course of time!

Not nice but certainly interesting. The Hoa Lo Prison is right in the city and is not a nice place to visit.Only part of it is left as the remainder has been replaced by some modern buildings. Hopefully they will keep the prison as a reminder of what happened for future generations.The conditions are terrible and the stories and information are very interesting and moving.

Very interesting.. A very informative insight into the history of Vietnam and the prison. There is plenty of information and well designed illustrations to keep you entertained for a good few hours. Entry is also very cheap. Good half day trip.

Interesting view of former cruelty. Inexpensive entry fee to a very interesting place showing a lot of cruelty and how bad the inmates were treated by the French. It also showed how well the US pilots were treated and provided a lot of anti US sentiment. You need to consider the biased information when visiting.

French Imperialism. This city centre prison concentrates alot on the period when the country was marshalled by the French. It doesn't portray the French colonialists with dignity whatsoever, with terrible conditions and treatment of the vietnamese. How the prisoners escaped from such a small sewer is mind boggling. The guillotine in one of the rooms is menacing.There is a feature about the US pilots which were kept there during the vietnam war, though I can't see how they were submitted to same conditions as the vietnamese previously.
Best museum in the city. A sobering experience. Very detailed displays, lots of English. Absolute must for Hanoi museum goers.

A worthwhile and moving place to visit. As with all the sites and museums in Vietnam which focus on the French colonial and/or American/Vietnamese War period, one knows to expect a presentation of the facts which is slightly one sided and this museum is no different. That in no way takes away from the worth of Hoa Lo, and we feel the couple of hours we spent here were thoroughly well spent. Approximately 80% of the exhibits are given over to the time during which the French used the prison to hold those elements of the local population who were pushing for change, with the remaining 20% given over to the period following independence when the term Hanoi Hilton was coined and American airmen were held here as POW's. Whilst all the exhibits have captions in Vietnamese, English and French there are a number of documents from the period of French rule which are presented in their original French form and only translated into Vietnamese. This is something of a shame as the little French we know hinted at some interesting content, the bulk of which was lost on us. We Googled the 'Hanoi poison plot' and also read up on the perspective of American airmen regards their treatment at the prison over a coffee immediately after leaving. Time spent reading up on these ahead of a visit to the prison would be time well spent.

Very interesting and moving.. Whoooo! Excellent experience. I went twice. I especially enjoyed the American POW area that showed John McCain's parachute, jump suit and helmet. Very moving. The next day I hired a motor bike taxi and went to the spot here his fighter jet crashed.

Interesting and s. A must see attraction in Hanoi, quite confronting especially the death rooms however they really only one side of the story. I doubt theUS pilots had quite as good a time as they make out but still worth the visit

only if you have the time. I visit the prison on the day that I stayed in Hanoi. I was a bit disappointed, most of it does not exist anymore, and the listen to explanation in each room didn't work. I also believe the show a very political approach.

A place worth for visiting. After the Sapa & Halong Bay trip, I came back to Hanoi. My friend suggested me to visit Hoa Lo Prison if I have free time in Hanoi. This place will never disappointed you if you are interested in history. Hoa Lo Prison is well maintained. In here, you can learn about the history of this prison back to French colonial era until Vietnam war. It is interesting because the history is based on point of view of Vietnamese. And I cannot say whether it is right or wrong, just depends on how do you look at it.Anyway, it is a place worth for visiting if you have time in Hanoi. The entry fees is cheap, just 30k Dong. And if you got student card, it is just 15k Dong.

Needs to be visited. It was a concise way to learn about the history of Vietnam's occupation by the French and the later war with the Americans. It was very well organized in a easy to find look location. Some parts were confronting though

A specific point of view... but interesting. This is definitely an interesting place to visit. Its well laid out and full of information. Gives the history of the prison when used by the French to imprison vietnamese rebels and it is a bit harrowing. The death cells are particularly shocking. The writing is a little embellished but not historically inaccurate. It also has an exhibit of the prison and its use to hold American POWs during the Vietnam War. This definitly felt a little false. With staged pictures of the prisoners celebrating Thanksgiving and setting up a Christmas Tree. But still interesting to see. Overall worth a visit if you are interested in the history.

You Need a Tour Guide !. The prison Museum Is really interesting - but the translation and description for things and periods is really bad ! There are some audio guides but they don't work at least not when we were there. Make sure to get a guide and Will make the difference ! Entry was about 30

A different point of view. Many people comment on the over the top propaganda but what would you really expect.They have to try to counter the propaganda from the other sides.I found the Prison self guided tour to be well organised and presented with lots of information (and a fair amount of propaganda (though mostly factual - it's just the way they put it)).We are glad we came - always good to get another view. Cheap too at 30K per person.Allow at least 1 hour and probably 2.We walked there from the old quarter in around 30min.

Excellent. Very thought provoking ecperience but take water as its very hot inside. They allow you to take pictures but there was one I felt I couldnt take so a little selectivity may be required. Overall well worth a visit.

History update. Nicely set out museum. Good to learn about the history of Vietnam and the role reversal use of this prison. Built by French colonialists to incarcerate Vietnamese but later used by Vietnamese to house US pilots POWs. Not very child friendly if you have kids.

Small but interesting. Most of the prism was destroyed to make a high rise. A small section is left. Lots of propaganda. The show the horrible conditions of the prison when the French used it to house Vietnamese. Then they talk about how nice it was after and the great care they took of the US prisoners. They even mention John McCain how how well he was treated. I think he might disagree. Worth a visit though

Haphazard tour with plenty of politics. I was very interested to visit this prison so was sad to see that the self led tour didn't seem to follow chronologically very clearly, and there was little background info. The politics in the explanations was quite obvious and took away from the historical value of the place.
Well worth the visit. . Great way to spend an hour or two in Hanoi. Good clear explanations of all the exhibits and history of the prison. Cheap price and we'll kept.

If you are interested in historical prisons, this one is certainly one to see..... As creepy as they are, we like visiting historical prisons, and this museum certainly is historical. Built by the French, I believe, and many of the original prison cells are perfectly preserved. It is also known as the "Hanoi Hilton" as it briefly held American Pilots during the Vietnam war before they were distributed to other prison compounds outside the city.

Great place to see in Hanoi. Really good place to check out when you're in Hanoi. You can learn a lot about vietnam and the experiences during the french occupation. The part about american POWs is pretty short and does present it pretty much like they were at a holiday camp!

Worth the visit!. As always, prisons are always good for some morbid tourism. Interesting place to learn about the wars that have plagued Vietnam over the years and the treatment that was given to the PoWs

Dark, grim, but an insight on life then. It's quite grim to say the least, but one of those necessary reminders of the past. I would say that it matches the theme of most of the other Vietnamese historical reminders filled with propaganda. If you have the time you should go check it out.

A must do!. A good insight about colonial treatment of locals and their struggles, and then about the American war. Interesting if not upsetting for the faint heated, but definitely worth a visit to remind ourselves of the darker/sadder side of Vietnamese history. Tons more interesting than the war museum etc.

Fairly interesting but not incredible. As we have found with similar places in Vietnam, they assume a prior knowledge of the whole event and focus instead on smallest details (lists of names of prisoners who died, specifics on places that were held etc) without first giving an overview of the war or event it belongs to. English audio stations were all broken and a lot of the sources were displayed only in their original French, and Vietnamese translation with no English. However it is fairly visual and therefore thought provoking to walk around. Go if you are at a loose end, and maybe read up on it before-hand. Entry 30,000VND or 15,000VND with valid student card

Hoa Lo Prison. as fascinating as this walk through was, it left me rather saddened that we can be so cruel to each other, not only by Vietnams once Colonial Rulers but also by the wars that followed.Cheers

Well worth a visit while you're in Hanoi. I'd read about Hoa lLo prison through a travel app and thought I'd go and check it out. It's literally around the corner from the Vietnamese Women's museum so you can combine both in a morning or afternoon. The history behind the prison is incredible. First of all is was predominantly used to imprison Vietnamese inmates when the French invaded and tried to overrule the Country, then later it was utilised to house U.S and soldiers Vietnamese traitors captured in the American war. It's barely changed from those days of torture and the despicable conditions prisoners were subjected to and were forced to endure. Architecturally itself, the prison is impressive, you get a real sense of menace and if the walls could talk!!! There's a lot of information about the history of the prison and how it's changed through the years, along with sculptures, photos and manuscripts that will leave you fascinated. It's a must see place to visit in Hanoi and only a £1 entry fee, you'd be doing the City a disservice by not making the time.

Sad history of vietnamese people; must know. You do not need tour guides for this, the displays have english translation.Reasonably priced. Me being a history buff, it was a must visit place for me. If not i wouldn't see if people would like to visit this place, moreover it was very sad history revealed here which many people would not like to see especially on vacation.It gives you an insight into French atrocities which was dis- heartening, which i was unware of till i visited this place.
Vietnam History!. When you were inside of the prison you will see all about the Vietnamese life on french war! You must see it when you visit Hanoi and think about their life!
Interesting . My two friends and I went to the museum today, it was very interesting! A must see place! I learnt a lot about the history of Vietnam

Moving and unsettling. This is a must see in Hanoi. Very sobering. It's rather well laid out overall. Quite educational especially about they period where the French abused so many Vietnamese....Who then in turn abused others. The cycle of abuse laid bare, but with not much self awareness.

Worth a Visit. This museum was actually bigger than what I expected. It was interesting learning about the revolutionaries. Saddening how they were treated, especially in comparison to the US prisoners.
Interesting place. The first place we went to when we came to Hanoi. Historical place, a must see one just to understand a little bit about the war but more about how they saw it, the point of view..
Hanoi Hilton prison. Glad we went but definitely a somber experience. As to be expected, a little propaganda heavy. Displays have English translations so a guide is unnecessary.
Fascinating. this place is fascinating and a must visit, gives a great insight to the people and how they where treated, very reasonably priced too, make sure you visit

Trace back the recent history of Vietnam. Visiting the prison is not only an opportunity to recognize the horrifying experiences that the Vietnamese had under French occupation, it is also provides a glimpse into the "American War" as it is termed in Vietnam. It was a unique chance to delve into the cruelties that the Vietnamese experienced at the hands of the United States and in turn, how American POWs were treated in Hanoi. All in all, it was an extremely insightful experience, and provides a useful context for exploring this beautiful country.

Well worth it. I give it four stars because I found it personally very interesting. The museum has two parts- one before 1954 and one after. If you know your history and the conditions in Vietnam post 1954 with the communist party... You will find this museum VERY interesting in terms of how history can be written differently according to which country you stand. For example, Americans called this prison the "hilton" of Hanoi according to the museum because they got to enjoy it so much.... Overall super interesting to see how the government decided to present all this information. Bring critical mindset with you.
Good Prison. Worth a couple of hours of your time if you have a few free. An interesting insight into how the Vietnamese were treated and how the building was used historically.

Try to visit if you have time but not high on the list if you have lots to do. Reasonably priced entry fee - children under 15 free entry. Interesting to read about how the French treated the Vietnamese people. No surprise that it is very one sided.

Worth the stop. The prison was easy to find, interesting and informative. It took us less than an hour to walk through all of the museum and the cost was reasonable. Even though I was familiar with the history of the prison during the war between Vietnam and the U.S., the exhibits cover the entire history of the prison. During my research and on some local brochures it was mentioned the prison was closed during lunch, however it wasn't when I visited.

Worth a visit. It was good to visit the Hoa Lo Prison. It focuses mostly on how Vietnamese were treated during the French occupation. The bias is obvious of course with all descriptions over-praising those captured particularly when they were somehow affiliated to the communist party.Well worth a visit though and well presented too. A big pity that what's left of the prison is dwarfed by the high-rise buildings around it.

Very nice yet very creepy. The place itself was generally nice, well maintained that also had a lot of interactive ways to present itself to visitors that don't have tour guides. Creepy because there were places inside that had scary prison cells that was accompanied with horrifying sound and lighting. More like a scare house to me haha. But overall a good place to visit when in Hanoi.
