an eye opener . this was worth the 20min walk from my hotel (approximate). learn and understand how prisoners of war were treated at the time they were incarcerated here. both Vietnamese and later on the Americans.

Interesting Visit. While in Hanoi we visited the Hoa Lo Prison. It is an interning visit and as other people have said, have a fair bit of propaganda on display. All that aside the Prison does give you some insight into how the prisoner lived and the conditions they where held in.

Just Spooky. A majority of this place has been demolished only a small part has been retained as a museum. It is mall enough for one to go through within an hour. Of note is the guillotine room which still contains its original equipment for beheading the prisoners and this is just plain spooky. The place also displays the quarters for male and female Vietnamese political prisoners.

Short trip full of emotion. If you can't visit Con Dao island or War Remnants Museum in Hochiminh, this is the place you should visit when you looking for history trace of Vietnam War. Cold, dark but still can feel the soul of the prisoners...
Must go. Very interesting and a must see in Hanoi when you visit. We found the tour short yet very informative.

A really interesting gem in Hanoi. We were told about the "Hanoi Hilton" by the hotel and we are so glad they did. A very cheap entry fee of 30,000 dong is well worth the money as there are many interesting exhibits including a guillotine. It is really sad to see how cruel the French were to these beautiful people, and yet how nice the Vietnamese treated captured American pilots during the war. Just a pity most of the actual jail has been demolished to make way for a tower block, but still an excellent museum and well worth a visit. there is a beautiful memorial to those patriots and revolutionary people who died in the prison

Enlightening Visit. Here you get to know a part of the Vietnamese history most people don't know about. The way the french tortured to intelectual people in Vietnam who were revolting against french occupation. It really enlightened me on how things happen at that time.
Another part of our Southeast Asia tour. It was an informative place to visit. Only section of the building left from the original building to see but it was interesting.

Enjoyed the Propaganda. I had always wanted to visit the 'Hanoi Hilton' and we were pleased to fid it in Hanoi during our visit. Unfortunately about half of the original building is gone but the remaining section was interesting. The info regarding the French colonisation period was good and informative, unfortunately it looses all credibility when you reach the section regarding the Vietnam War and US Prisoners. The propaganda does cloud the mistreatment of the US Prisoners but it is still worth the time to visit.

Definalety worth a visit.. Incredibly enlightening into what happened in Vietnams rarher tumultuos past. Depicting the lives of vietnamse and foreign prisoners.I sure some young kids would find it a little scary, but my son loved explororing the prisonEverything in english , though the headphones didnt seem to work

An interesting insight into an old prison. This is a small museum of a section of a prison for the Vietnamese during the French occupation. It is an interesting insight into the conditions of the prisoners and their attempted escapes. It is well setup to give a slightly eerie feel. It is quite a one-sided account of some details, but worth a visit. It is quite small so it is easy to complete a visit to this attraction in an hour or so.
Our Vietnam Holiday July 2015. Very sad but informative to learn of the atrocities that happened during the war, but great for history buffs, I did enjoy very much.

A Must see - for all the RIGHT reasons. Most people come here thinking this is the Hanoi Hilton, but you will leave realizing that this little snippet of history is meaningless in the real significance of this house of horrors. A prison built for political prisoners by the French, this "hell hole" was designed to break men (and women) and to get them to stop their subversive ways; the nerve of these Vietnamese people wanting self rule! If in Hanoi, you MUST visit this remarkable site.

Interesting if not the full story.. This is the gaol that the French housed their Vietnamese prisoners during their conflicts, and the treatment described is confronting. It is also where the North Vietnamese kept the allied prisoners during the Vietnam War, and their claims that the prisoners were treated like they were at the Hilton, hence it being referred to as the Hanoi Hilton, really stretches the bounds of credibility. Despite that it is still an interesting piece of history to visit.
Very interesting. The history of the place from one side and the story from other side.Amaising decoration and the ability to transfer filings of the past.

Hanoi Hilton Prison. The museum/prison has life like displays of people, and their life in the prison. Each room had displays on life in the prison. Quite graphic and very sad to see how people were treated. Lots of different room and displays - good information provided on each display. Sections for the Vietnamese and the USA soldiers. Was worth the visit to see and was not expensive.

Massively Eye-Opening!. This museum is well worth the 20,000 dong to get in! It doesnt look like much from the front but is actually a maze of exhibitions inside. They cover the history of the prison from creation right through to modern day and you really get a feel for what prisoner life would've been like: HORRENDOUS. Easily spend an hour here reading over all the information and quite easy to find with a basic map

A little peace of history. I am not a huge fan of museums, but this one is just the right size with a good balance of information, pictures and artefacts. The prison is an incorporation of essential parts of the country's history, which I find extremely interesting. All in all a good experience.

intereresting and very sad. The prison has some very intersting displays and information.it is a very opressing place and sometimes very morbid.Give you a real insight into how horrificly the vietnames were treated by the french colonies

Disturbing experience, as intended. Important historical site. Was once a pottery village, which was destroyed to make the prison. You can walk through the cells and see statues shackled as the prisoners were. It is very disturbing to see how people were kept here. However, it's an important site for understanding the history of the area. What remains of the prison is fairly well kept.

It worths a visit. It was the first time I have been to Hoa Lo Prison despite the fact that I have lived in Hanoi for 19 years. The prison provided us with a lot of amazing photos about the Vietnamese's battles against France and United States, how they fought and how the prisoners were treated during these times. I got to know more about my country's history with my American friends who were on a visit to Hanoi. Highly recommended for tourists!!

You should go!. A scary feeling for the first time I was in this prison. The view with the music thrilled me and put me in the past time more than 50 years ago. I understand more about how hard of the War between French and Vietnamese. If you went to Hanoi once. Please let visit Hoa Lo prison and make your different feeling between a modern city.Thanks!
Not a must visit. The interesting part is the area where is explained how the French treat the Vietnamese prisioners.The area about the American pilots is just propaganga...

Interesting. One sided view of the wars Vietnam have experience but always interesting to see the other side of a story. Was very interesting to see how prisoners lived over the ages and under different rulers. A map of the area would be useful, there were sign posts but not brilliant.

Not as expected.. I was looking forward to this prison museum as I read it was a prison that held American Pilots and other prisoners. There was very little about the imprisonment of American Pilots, maybe 2 small rooms, so my bf and I were quite disappointed as we were both most interested in seeing this part. The rest of the museum I thought was pretty average too. I've been to other prison museums and they were much more exciting and had more of a prison feel rather than a museum feel. Overall, there's not much to do in Hanoi anyway... so this is kind of somewhere you have to go or there'd be nothing else to do.

Extremely moving!. Of all of the places that we visited across Vietnam and Cambodia, this was one of the most moving for both myself and my wife. An amazing place with very well created models, all with emotional expressions upon their faces. Just amazing!
Interesting and good exhibition. This museum was wery interesting. This is first museum we visited in Hanoi that have a good exhibition with English translations.
Interesting and insightful. Highly recommend, really worth the visit to understand more of Vietnam's history and the subjugation prisoners experienced and the conditions they were in.

One of the most interesting places in Hanoi. I had mixed expectations before going to Hoa Lo Prison but once I got there I got blown away. The museum is divided in 2 sections; when it was ruled by the french and the Vietnam war (Hilton) prison. Both of the areas are amazing, but I was impacted with the French part of the prison. I learned a lot of history that I wasn't aware of before. I would strongly recommend this museum to anyone.

Interesting if rather biased. Would benefit from some western input on exhibiting and interactivity perhaps (though I'm not a fan of everything being the same in different countries). Just felt there was more of a story to be brought out. Felt the way the messages were put over undermined the information - with regard to the fortitude of the Vietnamese under the French and the care for the US pilots in the 70s. Some propaganda could be expected I guess.Glad we went. Very cheap 15000 done, children free.

Hoa Lo Prison. Hoa Lo prison is a must when understanding the history of Vietnam. It is sobering to see the conditions under which the prisoners where housed and the treatment they received from their subjugators.

Worth seeing destination in Hanoi. I went with my friend, a group of young people want to know more about history. This prison was preserved well though people just chose to remain a part of it. Visiting here gave me a huge amount of knowledge and invisibly taught me how difficult our ancient had tried to keep the peace for our nation. No matter who u are, a vnese or a foreign visiter, if u like to see insight our nation, just spend time here. Finally, discover by yourself!
Worth a visit.. Interesting and well worth a visit - allow about an hour. There are a number of rooms you can walk through and some photographic displays - sobering is the real guillotine!
Worth a visit. Very well done with displays.Quite small so only took an hour. difficult to find but worth persevering.

A time in Vietnams History. Visiting Vietnam and Hanoi was so interesting.... Of course there are portions of the history that we all would like to forget but it was very mesmerizing to actually be here where so many disturbing actions took place... History is not always pretty but for those of us who love to travel it is important to see different facets in all countries... If you are in Hanoi please visit...

Well presented. Nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton as it is felt US POWs were well looked after it is clear this was a very cruel place in earlier times. The modern memorial is strangely uplifting. Worth a visit to understand more about the impact of the war in North Vietnam.

Not for the faint hearted..... Prepare your self for the terror and horror, blood, drastic images, darkness, claustrophobia and pain prisoners felt... I had an urge to run out and leave it all behind, almost had a panic attack after visiting the death row cells on my own...

interesting to visit, but propaganda. If you have enough time in Hanoi this is an interesting place to visits, but do not expect something very authentic like the prisons in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Furthermore, the information presented in the prison here in Hanoi felt more like propaganda than the actual history to me.

Interesting to see . Ghigliottina room the most impressive area of the prisono exhibition.You can find also the uniform of senator usa mc cainn whose plane was hit dyring vietnam war and imprisoned there.
Insightful glimpse of a dark period of time in vietnam. Insight into a dark period in vietnamese history. Well maintained and explanations in English helped get a grasp of the horrors for prisoners.

Impressive. The museum is very impressive and gives you a great overview about what has happens: both in the late 1800s and later on during the Vietnam war. The pictures and stories are a little bit 'subjectively' written but still trustworthy.
Interesting. We've enjoyed this museum as it gives a good insight in the history of the prison. The statues/ dolls are a nice touch

A new perspective. The museum is one of a number in Vietnam that present a different view of the history of the country to that most westerners will have seen. It may appear unbalanced but one suspects that the Vietnamese may harbour similar feelings about the traditional western view. That there is a different view and it is presented clearly and without much attempt to soften the message simply makes the difference more stark. And that is no bad thing as it challenges you to understand that all peoples in conflict have their own beliefs and desires. The museum makes good use of the remaining prison layout and buildings with the story being told from the building of the prison through to the present day. It is a bit shabby in places and some more details would be useful but the meaning is clear in most cases. Take a slow stroll round and you'll spend an hour or two gaining some understanding of what the local people feel they have been through. And some of the evidence is pretty clear, some less obvious. This is a museum for people who want to be given something to think about and worth it for that alone.

Well worth a visit. Definitely gives you a better understanding of what the people went through during the war, it was very cheap to visit and easy to walk to from the old quarter. Very informative and lots of items to see.
Worth Seeing. It was worth seeing Hoa Lo Prison. It holds so much history. Whatever your political point of view it is a must see.

Very disturbing. We found Hoa Loa prison a very moving place to visit, largely because it was so disturbing. To think that human beings were imprisoned here under such dreadful condiitons. Prone, legs shackled, in dark and almost airless rooms, insufferably hot. To stand where they lay and to try to imaginethe horror! To think that this was done by a nation priding itself on being highly civilised, and that it was done for no possible good reason, but rather simply in the interests of money and power. With apologies to Madame Roland, 'Oh France, what crimes were committed in thy name!!'.
Just waste of time, money and energy!. Don't bother even getting close to this place. You can completely ignore this place and I assure you that you haven't missed anything!

Very interesting but more information would be great!. My friend and I visited the prison having not studied the Vietnam war in any detail at school. The prison itself was in good condition, containing lots of artefacts, and also had lots of models/sound effects recreating the life of the prisoners. However, having possessed little in-depth knowledge of the Vietnam War, we feel that we would have benefited from some more background information being given to us and I think this would have further enhanced our appreciation of some of the artefacts/recreations.Otherwise, it was very cheap to enter the prison and is definitely worth visiting!
Well worth a visit. it was very interesting to see part of the old prison. There's lots of items from the Vietnam war and the French colonialist regime in Vietnam.
Really fascinating. It's old and a bit shabby but worth a visit and a fascinating museum. You get a great insight into the Vietnam experience over the last century.

Worth the visit.. A slightly harrowing visit if you try hard to emphasise with those who experienced time there! But well worth it. Suitable for all ages, this shows the struggles the Vietnamese went through when under French Colonial rule, and the horrible conditions they were kept it. It also highlights the strength of spirit of those incarcerated there. A must see for those interested in history!

A tale of history. Fascinating tale of history. Regardless of what side you are for or on, what angle you look at, you can not deny a certain powerful point of view of this museum. It reminds me a little bit of the Carnavalet without those beautiful courtyards. One thing comes across for sure: life of a Vietnamese during colonial time is worth next to nothing!

good option, allow 1-1.5 hours. Interesting experience, especially for an American tourist. Though not all the displays are 1:1 with the understanding of the events, still a good experience and well kept displays
Hanoi Must Visit. A must visit place in Hanoi - helps one understand the freedom struggle and also the atrocities which were subjected to the locals.

Worth visiting is attached to womens prison. only part of the prison still exists, however worth the time to visit as there is re model of the prisoners in the original cells and this makes it easier to vision what the prisoners endured as in space wise , only need 1 hour to visit as it is not a big place
Interesting look into Vietnam . The museum is a great insight into the lives of the Vietnamese that were imprisoned there. Great exhibitions, films, and real life artificers really hit home

Well worth a visit. A very interesting experience giving us a better understanding of the involvement of the French in the life of Vietnamese culture. We had guides with us (Hanoi Free tour guides: excellent) but I think audio guides were available.
Worth Visiting. Very interesting, a shame only part of the prison remains due to the construction of a high rise tower next door. My favorite artifact was seeing John McCains flight suit.

Also known as "Hanoi-Hilton". Save at least one hour for this place to see the history. History of French occupancy and American invasion, everything can be seen. The clothes of American presidency candidate John McCain also can be seen. Nice films of that era are constantly projected.
Good place to learn on Vietnamese histry.. This is a must see destination if you will to know about Hanoi charming and culture.hundreds of interesting story is waiting for you.

Half interesting and about the prison, half propaganda. This is an interesting place to go and visit. The information about the prison and actually getting to see the rooms etc where things happened was well laid out and good to see. However after a little bit it turns to very biased information which used emotive language which has no place in a museum, in my opinion. Also, it was factually inaccurate when talking about the conditions the American prisoners were kept in - it seemed too good to be true and a quick google when I got back confirmed this.Still interesting to go and see but keep in mind the bias etc when reading the displays.

Well presented. Well worth a visit the information and stories collated by those who run this place are very interesting in that it puts a different perspective on the war issue from the American side

Interesting and odd.. Prison tour we found a bit odd ,we think thatthis was because we experienced a different version of what we fed via media ,but still an interesting place to visit even if it does get busy
Moving. As an American who lived through the Vietnam War, I was very moved visiting this infamous site. It is quite well done as a museum, but a bit hard to follow the time line of its history.
Interesting . Provides some interesting historical background, but it could do with more depth and narrative - a few more anecdotes would be good too. Might be worth doing with a guide.

Look past the propaganda and it offers a good recent history lesson. An easy and pleasant 20 minute walk from our hotel in the old quarter, Hoa Lo Prison was on our 'must-do' list while in Hanoi. Everything is well presented, albeit from a biased perspective, and flows in a logical way. Like Tuol Sleng Genocide museum in Phnom Penh, it is chilling to be inside a place where torture and appalling conditions were endured in recent history. We took our seven year old daughter who was not at all fazed by anything she saw, even the guillotine, but it might not be suitable for all young children.

Though Provoking and Informative. Highly recommend a trip to the Hoa Lo Prison - it takes visitors from the days of French Colonial rule (and independence) right through to use during the Vietnam/American War. Gives a really good overview of the conditions and history of the city.Like all these things, it is slightly biased but that is to be expected and doesn't take anything away from the experience. It's definitely a more graphic and less sanitised version of history than you would get in Western Europe which is refreshing - though beware if you have particularly sensitive young children.

Good to help understand some of the history which has shaped Vietna.. Very good place to visit to understand at least part of the history of Vietnam. Well organised displays with a good range of photos, audio and films.

Worth a visit. Expected a little more from this visit, however it was definitely worth while. Hard to believe conditions prisoners had to endure, particularly women. Modest entrance fee for a good tour. Max tour time we'd estimate at 1hr 30mins

An interesting perspective. The cells and exhibits are, like any primitive jail, sobering and confronting. The varied use of the facilities for prisoners during different occupations and wars provides a good cameo of Vietnamese history through colonialism, insurgence and war. Exhibits like the guillotine and American PoW suits add to the context. One of the really interesting things was the exceptionally biased write up of the American PoWs experience in this, the "hanoi hilton". That just added to the experience for us, but others may find it grates.

Interesting visit. It's amazing to see how recent the war still is for the Vietnamese and you get to also see a little propaganda in action in this place.
Definitely a great place if you're interested in history and war. You also get to see how John McCain lived in the "Hanoi Hilton".

I would really recommend a visit here- takes at least 90 mins. A fascinating place to visit, especially if you were around in the 60s when the USA pilots were imprisoned here. But lots more history here than just that era.
Short visit. Since i had a free day during my bussines trip, i decided to visit this museum. It is small but it is very interesting. Definetely worths a small visit.

how sad if continuous to walk..... how sad if continous to walk....
Sad to listen to how fellow humans were treated but essential for the Vietnamese to continue to tell the story ,this is a war but how sad to saw the movie of the childen in there.
A must see in Hanoi. Great visit a must see also info on famous US prisoner, plenty to see and also a lot of info in english

Hanoi Hilton - Prison. After seeing the Vietnam wall of rememberance in Washington DC this opens your eyes as to the öther"side and their suffering. It literally brought tears to my eyes and reinforced my belief that war is just so fruitless and there is never a winner! So worth a visit

An interesting stop. Interesting to visit this gaol, and definitely an eye opener to see things from a different perspective, other than what we learn and know. Although I do think there is a lot of propaganda in the way they tell their story. Well worth the visit, just keep an open mind. It was easy to find and navigate our way through.

Interesting . The prison used to be much bigger, but in any case it's quite representative of how the prisons used to be. If you have gone to "The rests of the war" Museum in Ho Chi Minh, it's quite similar. In any case it's an interesting visit.

"Hanoi Hilton" . This is where US Senator John McCain and other US pilots were held, and before that VIetnamese prisoners of war. Most of the original compound has been sold off and developed, but you still,get a good taste of the horrific and tortured conditions endured. Think heavy iron ankle straps with a single one-hour exercise and bathroom break a day. The guillotine room was especially grisly.
Well worth a visit. Interesting and informative. Just walking around the prison gives visitors some understanding of how horrific conditions were for prisoners. Well worth a visit.

Very Educational. We visited on a weekday.
This preserved and refurbished section of the original prison is quite the informative museum. Gloomy in areas but vivid nonetheless exhibiting/describing the conditions/life of inmates.
Worth a visit

On the list, in a fairly boring city. Hanoi isn't the cultural capital of anywhere - but I like it, so far. The prison isn't far from the lake and costs 30 000 dong each (children under 15 free). Ignore the communist bull and propaganda, and it was fairly interesting. I laughed when I saw how they described the treatment of the American pilots - as "temporary detainees" for upto 10 years and the photos of healthy pilots being released in 1973 and photos of prominent American prisoners - none mentioned that Sen John McCain was hung up by his thumbs and can't raise his arms above shoulder height due to the way he and others were tortured. I can understand why the Vietnamese would feel so angry towards the pilots, who had caused catastrophic loss of life - but no one should treat prisoners so badly - whatever the crime.
War museum within a prison. It is a very interesting and worthwhile visit but if you have been to other war museums it won't take too long to look around.

The Hanoi Hilton. The Americans named this The Hanoi Hilton, I think Conrad would have something to say about that.It's quite harrowing in parts, it does give a very good insight in to Vietnam's history, much about how they were treated under French rule and of course how they treated the Americans (Seemed a bit like Pontins only cleaner) it was quite biased, but you would expect that. Well worth a visit, very educational.
Worth A Short Visit. Worth a look. Very sad to see how the Vietnamese people were treated. Only need to spend 1 hour here, but definitely interesting to see.

Brief but insightful. The first part of the museum was a very shocking insight into the brutality that the Vietnamese endured through the French rule. The second part of the museum concentrated on the American Prisoners of War, and although I am definitely no history expert I can't help thinking that the it was a very biased view of how the Americans were treated. Overall an insightful museum, though it only takes about half an hour to get round.

Interesting prison. We stopped by the Hoa Lo prison, and spend an hour and a half. The prison is fairly interesting with some nice exhibitions and the information is alright. It was interesting to get an insight to the prison life and conditions of the inmates during war-time. Admission is cheap and you do get a view of the historic events of Vietnam, which was interesting.

Eye opener. I found so much information to read - in English or French - and exhibits or videos to watch that my wife and daughter got quite irritated waiting for me. Like any historical exhibition it presents a specific view with the colonial French being depicted as villains with no redeeming points, Vietnamese resistance prisoners being absolute heroes and American POWs being receipients of inconceivable generosity and kindness. Fascinating though. But maybe arrange to meet those members of your party less interested in 20th century history somewhere afterwards.

Interesting, but not because of the history.. Interesting, but not because of the history; because of the tainted reality... Evidently the French were cruel oppressors of communist political prisoners, but when those "freedom fighters" held US pilots, it was like a day camp with games and beds and lots of free time.

Sad endictment on humanity. It's hard not to be moved when visiting this prison - to think that humans could be treated in such inhumane ways is beyond belief. A confronting yet informative visit - worth the effort.

Prison of Patriotism and Propaganda . Hoa Lo was a really interesting visit. As with Uncle Ho's mausoleum, a huge reason for its interest is the presentation of the content which talks a lot of the suffering of patriotic Vietnamese against the cunning and atrocious enemy (the French). Much of the museum focuses on the treatment of the Vietnamese at the hand of the French and the glorious resistance of men who went onto become leading lights of the Communist Party. Captions are in Vietnamese and English, so you get a detailed if wholly non objectives reflection on the war.The museum then takes a turn and has two rooms which document how well American troops were treated during the war. It seems that the statements Americans made under torture (which praised the treatment the NVA were providing them with) have been used as the foundation for this part of the exhibition. Because of this, alongside seeing some of the appalling conditions, Hoa Lo is well worth a visit. As with much of Hanoi's politically infused tourism, watch out for the propaganda, but use this to get more insight into the North Vietnamese mentality.

Sad memory of the past!. It's a way of knowing Vietnam's past and possibly bridging that to the present as events are all related. Very interesting to know their colonial past under the French...Very good learning experience.

Harrowing but a must do. This is quite a small museum as only a small portion of the prison remains, but nevertheless it took us a half day to complete. As well as its use during the Vietnam war there was a lot of information about its use by the French, which was particularly interesting.

Mixed feelings about this place.. I was really looking forward to visiting this prison and seeing first hand the things I'd learned about that took place during the Vietnam war. About 90% of this museum is focused on how badly Feench Colonists treated Vietnamese prisoners. Only two rooms were dedicated to the U.S. POWs who were kept there for years on end, and almost all of the displays were propaganda that Vietnam put out during the war to showcase how comfortable and happy the US pilots were while there. Do your research on how the US POWs were actually treated before you go. Otherwise, it was well laid out and lots of well written English signage to read. The guillotine and the cells where death row prisoners were held were really macabre. Worth a visit, but do your research first.

Depressing but Informative. We visited Hao Lo Prison May this year. I'm into history so a visit to this place is a must. The place was interesting and informative but depressing at the same time. A glimpse of Vietnam's past.

Interesting and a bit eerie. This was the most informative and interesting museum I visited in Hanoi. The layout was very good and the explanations were clear, informative and written in perfect English. Wit every official/ government exhibition in a communist country, facts should be taken with a grain of salt (I was particularly skeptical about the explanations of the lavish treatment of US POWs held there), but otherwise a very goo museum, sharing an important part of Vietnamese history.

Amazing. It was a bit impressive but amazing. There i could learn a lot about the wars in Vietnam and also how this prison worked during those hard days. The route inside the museum is very clear and easy to follow not to lose any detail. Go and enjoy this amazing museum!!

A bit disappointing. Don't really know what I was expecting here, but it wasn't as interesting as I'd anticipated. There was a power cut whilst we were there, so couldn't see some of the interior exhibits - wish they'd informed us of this as we were going in and we'd probably have visited another time

Hanoi Hilton-Unique perspective. Although I felt the prison was very interesting to visit you really need to take your time when you go through to read through what occurred there. I was there two hours. The Vietnamese people that were kept in the prison endured terrible treatment. With that said I question the accuracy of how the American pilots were treated during the Vietnam War, it is presented as if the prison was a very comfortable place for the Americans. Just my opinion.
Honest history. It's very interesting to see how the prisoners where treated and "housed". The entrance fee is fair and the prison itselve very informative and well looked after. Worth a visit.

Worth a visit. The best touristy thing we did in Hanoi (better than both the War museum and the Temple of Literature). It traces the history of the prison from housing Vietnamese political prisoners considered a threat by the French, up to it's use during the Vietnam War when it housed captured US servicemen. A notable prisoner from it's latter use was John McCain (US Republican Presidential Candidate - lost to Obama first time round) whose flying suit is on display - he crash landed in the Hoan Kiem lake close by. Some of the exhibits can be a bit grisly (seeing the guillotine was quite chilling) but all are interesting and informative. As with most touristy things in Vietnam it cost pennies to get into.
Interesting. I knew nothing about this prison and found it quite fasinating. So many prisoners in such a confined place. Treatment would have been hell. Interesting place to visit, glad we went

Lots of information about the occupation of Vietnam. Fascinating place to visit detailing the French occupation of Vietnam and later the capture of the American pilots in the Vietnam war during the 1960/1970s.

worth the visit but prepare for a twisted perspective. the museum talks about the cruelty of the french, remains silent about the time when it was a 'pure vietnamese' prison and illustrates to extension how well american prisoners have been treated during the war. so the real value is at the meta-level. it illustrates the lack of willingness to strive towards an objective representation of history. visit the museum but at some short reading on the other perspectives (american angle) before or afterwards. it's the prison where former us president candidate john mccain has been kept for about 6 years.

Scary but touched. The prison is located in the middle of a busy business area. It's hard to image that there is a place that so many people were suffered torture and painful executed right behind modern buildings and big hotels nowadays. You can not image how cruel people can treat their enemies (also human beings) with chains, (variety of) cells and guillotine then French must be one of the best experts. It's easier to breath if you are from Western countries but with Asians, sometimes it is really touched our hearts. I mean it. You will started to understand some parts of the very complicated war named Viet Nam.People often skip the upper level where located the list of all the people were imprisoned here, many of them after free from Hoa Lo held important positions in the Communist Government (some until present). There are limited services for food and drink but that's not a problem with a city like Hanoi, easy to find somewhere around. Interpreters are available or you can simply use the headphones at exhibitions place. Advise to spend around 2 hours and you can visit the Indochina Court nearby where people were judged (with no lawyers) before being put in prison during Colonial time (now is building of Supreme Court of Vietnam)

Nice Place for a couple hourss. The prison's history is nothing short of fascinating. The museum has great displays, with all signs in good English. The history provided here is good, although they certainly do exaggerate how well American POWs were treated (what did you expect?). Not a place for kids. Great for a couples hours out of the sun and definitely worth the money.

Enjoyable museum. Found this prison/museum very interesting. As this was my first stop in Vietnam I didn't have much knowledge about the fight for independence. Really informative for newcomers to Vietnam history.

Easy to find glad we didn't miss it. How can anyone suggest they enjoy a visit to such places but it was done fairly well with an obvious bias to Vietnamese prisoners. How can we ever understand the harm people can do to others yet we see it repeated over and over. The prison housed so many people in such small places the heat alone must have been terrible. Some of the sewage drains which people escaped from are on display as most of the prison has been knocked down for housing developments. What is there is shocking but well presented. It probably only takes about a hour to walk round so could be fitted in to even a very short stay in Hanoi. Glad we went.

Interesting place. Interesting place to go if past treatment of people is of interest to you. Sad to listen to how fellow humans were treated but essential for the Vietnamese to continue to tell the story.

The "Hanoi Hilton".... not that interesting. A prison, a historical prison ok. Depressing like all prisons I visited. I am somehow happy I have seen it but was a bit disappointed by the lack of interesting information there. Not sure how accurate the info is either.... So after wards to lift up my spirit, I went for lunch at Amato, a small restaurant serving european food on 1a Trang Tien, right next to the back entrance of the Hilton Hanoi Opera Hotel (not the prison the real hotel! ;)
independence. It made you stop and think about the challenges that Vietnam has encountered to achieve their independence.
A sad chapter. Known by all as the 'Hanoi Hilton'. An informative historical site. All politicians should be forced to visit it to understand the futility of war. The history was well presented.
Nice museum. Another top notch Vietnamese museum. Only need 1-2 hours to take it all in. There's an...interesting display on the Hanoi Hilton enjoyed by US servicemen.

Prison Visit. The experience of visiting such a famous prison was quite surreal. When I was walking through the prison cells, it was as though I could imagine how the life of the inmates when they were locked up there. I realized that many of the prisoners were political prisoners in the war years. And also the American pilots that were locked here were also given very good treatment and freedom as compared to the other local Vietnamese prisoners. It was truly a mind blowing experience and a place to visit if you have never visited such prison museums before.

Decent way to pass an hour. The prison is a bit of a maze but has some interesting information to offer. Visitors are left to themselves to wonder about and read as much as they want to. If you have the time it's worth a visit, but it wouldn't be at the top of my list of things to do in Hanoi.
Average. As tourist attractions go, it was average. There were a lot of historical info but lots of it is repetitive. Still, you'll have to go just to say you've been there.
don't expect too much. it's not bad but you wont be wowed nothing above the average it's ok .. keep it for last if you have the time .
Alcatraz in SF and Hoa Lo in Hanoi. If you are interested in History, this place exemplifies the struggle and pain the vietnamese people went through to achieve freedom.

A " have to do whilst I. han. A " been there and done that" sort of visit. Dont really like doing jails, but you have to do this to get a feel of Vietnamese history and gain a better understanding of colonials days. Worth a visit on that basis alone.

Must see to learn more of Vietnam war!!. Hoa Lo Prison was a prison used by the French colonists in Vietnam for political prisoners and Later by North Vietnam for prisoners of war during the Vietnam War.You dont need to spend a long time visiting the Prison (1 to 1.5 hours is sufficient) but I highly recommend to add to your itinerary of places to visit. Seeing photographs, and statues of prison life and how it would have been like to be put in confinement in a small, pitch black room is torture. Its chilling, yet you also see a large section of where the Americans were captured (later released). Its soo interesting to learn more of Vietnam War! I thoroughly enjoyed the visit.Some basic info:Hours: 8am to 5pm (closed 11.30am to 1.30pm for lunch)Cost: 15,000 VND

Good to see but I wouldn't believe everything you see!. This prison has well presented displays and a well planned layout (good flow while walking around). There is no doubt the Vietnamese suffered at the hands of the French and it is an excellent place to visit to understand this part of history. However, the section on the American War should be taken with a pinch of salt. I highly doubted the Americans had as good a time as was depicted in the pictures. Christmas dinner, playing basketball, medical treatment and big smiles? While I expected a bit of propaganda, this section went to the point of being unbelievable!

Evidence that victors write history. A fascinating museum, and definitely worth a visit, but the interest is not in finding out what actualy happened, but on the spin they have put on it.It's definitely one sided, but still interesting and worth experiencing!

Very moving to see the cell rooms. I wanted to see the prison to gain a better understanding of the war. To see the cells and torture weapons was very moving. Definitely something to visit while you are in Hanoi!
Very Dark and Humbling. This is a very somber place to visit. It is very important to visit Hoa Lo to have a better understanding of Vietnam's history.

Definitely worth the visit. A very interesting slice of Vietnamese history within walking distance of the old quarter. From the bottom of the lake it is less than 10 minutes walk. The presentation of the prison is tastefully done. Be sure to be courteous, many people undoubtedly suffered greatly here

Propaganda at the "Hanoi Hilton". While I knew it would be ridden with propaganda I still left feeling a bit outraged. I thought there may be a bit about how they keep this museum open to teach people how terrible war can be and how inhumane it all is ( like the killing fields in Cambodia).. but it just glossed over all the brutality in which the Americans endured. McCain even said the flight suit is a fake and his was destroyed while he was beaten and taken prisoner. Many memorials to the Vietnamese who died at the hands of the French - but none for the Americans who were tortured and killed.And no the prisoners were not fed a Christmas meal -- it's all staged photos.
One to visit. Its a little hard yo find if you are walking there but wonce there its very interesting. So glad that they keept a small part of the jail and its well easy to follow around.
Not just your average prison. Well worth the trip.Many interesting facts about who has been imprisoned here over many years and why.not just all reading plenty of displays and pictures

Emotional. Unsure if attraction is the correct word to describe this tourist place in Hanoi, for me it was a moving insight into Vietnam's chequered history. The displays are plentiful, some very graphic and others too realistic higlighting the atrocities that one human can inflict on another. The memorial garden is a beautiful reflective addition to this historical place.Be mindful to check your change before you move way from the ticket office,

An interesting museum. We love walking round museums and this one was fantastic. A really interesting place with a lot of pro-Vietnam propaganda. There are loads of English signs and it is well laid out. Definitely worth a visit

Definitely worth a visit. A fascinating tour - highly recommended for history buffs and those interested in the Vietnamese/American war. Despite the scorching conditions, my husband and 2 kids really enjoyed this tour. Allow a minimum of 1-2 hours to really do justice to all this museum has to offer.

Nice piece of history . Visited on a rainy Tuesday afternoon. Was not very busy. Was a good overview of the history of the museum and its uses. We did find it to be a bit biased by times. Lots of souvenirs throughout.

Interesting. There is not many things to do in Hanoi, so i think it is worth to go to see the Hoa Lo Prison. The historical explanation is really interesting and the cells that they kept are really fascinating. Both the French occupation and the Vietnam occupation sorties during the Vietnam War are really interesting.
One word: GREAT. Educational and interesting. Must visit when you are in Hanoi. The entrance fee is 30.000VND and for 20.000VND you can even buy a little booklet so you can read it at your own pace.
good condition museum. this prison likes a museum and it reminds us about the war time and what prisoners had to suffer as well.

Interesting and impressive. The first part of the museum concentrates on the abuse the Vietnamese prisoners endured during the French rule. This part is really impressive and sad, especially the isolation cells. The second part of the prison focusses on the American war and the POW's that where incarcerated in Hoa Lo, along with the obligatory propaganda. It's an interesting visit and well worth the time/money!
Worth a visit. Very interesting place , did not find it too gory, in fact was interesting to see how well they treated the Americans during the war

Haunting, eerie, and fascinating. Well worth a visit, particularly in terms of gaining an understanding of the Vietnamese experience during French occupation. If you're looking for tons of detail about the US situation during the Vietnam War, be prepared to look at things from the other side of the equation. The displays are evocative and informative, and you come away with a much broader understanding of Vietnam's ongoing struggle for self determination. If you visit this museum in conjunction with the also excellent Museum of the Revolution, be prepared to have your mind opened. We got approached on our way out by a taxi driver that proceeded to try to rip us off, so keep the Hanoi taxi rules in mind! http://www.travelfish.org/orientation_detail/vietnam/hanoi_and_surrounds/hanoi/hanoi/23

Both interesting and Disturbing... This prison, Otherwise know as the "Hanoi Hilton" was built by the French to house Vietnamese political prisoners during the French colonialism era. It later became a prison to house captured American Prisoners of war, the most famous being John McCain, displaying his uniform and some photos.I wouldn't normally visit a prison Museum but it seems to be on the list of things that Americas see when visiting Hanoi, so I decided to check it out.

An interesting look at what prisoners may have endured..... Since I really enjoy historic buildings, I found this extremely interesting. There were many displays that replicated how prisoners were held, prison cells, and surrounding rooms.

Tour it so you can say you were there.. Victors write the history books. According to the present management they treated the captured Americans such as John McCain very well. Nonsense. And of course the captured patriotic Vietnamese prisoners from previous wars were treated poorly, as I am sure they were. This place is worth seeing just to be able to say you saw the infamous Hanoi Hilton.

Very interesting, creepy cell displays!. Spent a few hours here and walked from the old quarter. It's open all day unlike some of the museums which close for a few hours so be aware of this before you set out. Very good history of the prison, and they've kept the old buildings and cells which give it a real feel. Some funny fake people on display, and not much information in English but you get by. Very interesting display on the American soldiers staying there from 1968 onwards. By the information that is presented you'd say the soldiers had a great time and were treated like royalty, but other sources and accounts suggest that they were horribly tortured and mistreated. Overall a good visit and worth a few hours.
Hanoi Hilton. Worth a visit. Displayed well whilst still retaining the atmosphere. Interesting to read about the Vietnamese and American experiences there.

Authentic displays. This place was extraordinarily interesting and a little confronting. It is quite a simple museum (don't expect high tech displays) and I think this adds to the authenticity. I visited early morning when it was quiet which gave me time to read to notes for the display and reflect on what happened in this place.
Fascinating. Great to learn some of the history of the Vietnam War from the Vietnamese perspective. Definitely a worthwhile visit!.
A Piece of History Not to Forget. A somber yet revealing historical testimony to the human spirit, not just for American POW's but also the the Vietnameseduring the French Occupation. A must see!
Worth a visit. So pleased we went, very informative and eye opening. A definite must see when in Hanoi as gives a good insight into prison life at the time!

Cool Museum . My wife and visited this museum because it was recommended to us by some fellow travelers. It was pretty cool to see the original prison and read about its history. I would definitely recommend to visit if you're a history buff but for my wife and I it was just kinda meh.

A Different Perspective of Propoganda. 90% of the museum is dedicated to the heroic communists who kept ideologically pure until their final breaths under tyrannical French rule. The remaining 10% was dedicated to the humane temporary housing for American POWs that the heroic communists "rescued." For me, this museum was interesting because it provided a different perspective of the "Hanoi Hilton." It was worth going to, but seeing the horrific conditions people were kept in was definitely unsettling.

A good introduction into Vietman's recent history. A must to understand how the French persecuted the Vietnamese. Also you see how the captured American pilots were kept in Hanoi. Some you feel is propaganda because they show them eating Christmas dinner - what about the rest of the time?? Butyou can blame them because before capture the American pilot would have been on a bombing mission

Fascinating visit. Went here on our first full day in Hanoi.Anglo-French family of four either two teenagers.We all learned a lot & found the visit fascinating.Recommend the booklet available at the ticket office - provides good info on origins & history of the prison. Only 20k dong. Exhibits & visit examine both French era & war with USA.Captures interest of adults & teens alike.Yes, it is true that comments are somewhat biased but it is to be expected. An equivalent museum in France or USA may be equally one sided.To those critics out there, get over it! This museum is nonetheless thought provoking & informative.1:30 to 2 hours, I would say.

Not to be Missed. An experience that should not be missed when visiting Hanoi. Only part of the original "Hanoi Hilton" remains, but it has been very well maintained as a "relic" with excellent exhibits including John McCain's flight suit from when he was rescued after his plane was shot down.
Ha Noi Hilton. If this place does not make you wonder why people can be so cruel than I doubt if anything else will.Be prepared to be sad!

Little did you know.... You see, those bad, bad French people set up a colony in Vietnam and suppressed the locals for decades. This prison housed many of those freedom fighters, as is well-documented in about 90% of the tour's posted information. Incidentally, after that the bad, bad Americans bombed innocent people so their pilots had to stay here as well. Lucky for the pilots, they were allowed to play basketball, read the mail, socialize, and were reminded of the kind treatment they received in the very same rooms the locals were once not so kindly treated in. Moral of the story: this place is a very physical reminder not to get yourself locked away in a foreign people's prison.
Interesting Visited. This Place telling the old story of Vietnam. It was good if you bring your children to let them know how beautiful their life.

Worth a visit. A well laid out tour which also has some audio stations, 30000VND per person which is worth the visit. The signs are in English, and you move round the different rooms, cells etc, which have exhibites from people who were imprisoned within. It shows how harsh the conditions must have been. If you have the time it is an education and worth the visit.

Real education. If you want to get a real insight into Vietnamese prison usage and living conditions under the French and Vietnamese pre war and wartime rule then is an excellent way to do it. Informative, a bit scary in sections for kids as it does give a true picture. Really glad we went, took us about 2 hours to walk around but I do like reading all the formation. Highly recommended and cheap as usual.

A great insight into what life would have been like.... If you have a few days, it is definitely worth a visit. Some parts of the prison feel a little too 'done up' to suit tourists but overall, it was an eye opening experience that sheds light on how far Vietnam has come. Although the country is still behind, it's sometimes hard to believe that they only started allowing tourism in the early 90's. FYI, the toilets are surprisingly clean.

Worth a visit. Located in the Old Quarter, it is easy to locate this museum & worthwhile to spend some time there. The exhibits provide plenty of information on the tumultuous periods in Vietnamese history, good if, like me, you do not really have a clear picture of Vietnam's past.

An eye opener. If you like history this is definitely worth a visit. It's an interesting account and display of the treatment of political Vietnamese prisoners during the revolution against French occupation. It's a small but informative museum that does not overload you with too many facts.

Worth going only if you have a spare hour. It is an interesting museum,well preserved but quite biased. Lots of information and pictures on the walls,you can see how the cells looked like and what were the conditions in the prison. I've been to better ones though. Tickets are around $2 per person.

Interesting visit. I thoroughly enjoyed this visit as I felt that I learned a lot about Vietnamese history. There was a lot of detail in relation to the French and a smaller amount about the American war. The conditions in the prison really made you reflect and think about what this place would have been like during the revolution.

Interesting.... Very informative, and even spooky. Had the chance to see how both Vietnamese and American prisoners were treated.
I am impressed at how clean they maintained the prison and public toilets in the prison.
The Hanoi Hilton. I had to visit and pay respect to my brothers in arms who were incarcerated here during the Vietnam War. It was a bittersweet visit.

Powerful Place. Although fairly small Hoa Lo Prison is packed full of history as well as interesting individual stories! The different prison cells used for men and women during the French colonisation and US prisoners in the American War are impressively well-preserved and with the help of cleverly placed wax figures give you an eerie insight into the prisoners' experience! The information boards and displays are very easy to follow and provide quite an emotive backdrop to the different parts of prison which make it a more intense tour. For this reason I would advise leaving a good couple of hours to visit the prison as you'll feel compelled to view each room very carefully!

Hanoi Hilton. This is a fascinating old museum otherwise known as the "Hanoi Hilton" where many an inmate were held at transitional points in the history of Vietnam, whether fighting against the French, or during the "American War" (Vietnamese War). There is lots to learn about in the prison regarding the history of Vietnam. The most fascinating part for me was learning about the Vietnam War pilots including Senator John McCain and their "stay", which puts the war in a Vietnamese context and gives a very different viewpoint into history.

Super interesting. Very interesting site full of history (even if full of inevitable propaganda). The old cells give you a nice perspective of life in Vietnam under the french, and the McCain exhibit was interesting. Make sure to buy the (very cheap) booklet at the ticket counter--it provides a lot of useful historical background in English. The museum in general has lots of English direction, so you'll be fine without a guide. We spent easily spent two hours here.

Good, but biased. In general, meuseums in Vietnam are not great at teaching and explaining what exhibts are meant to portray. This does an alright job but the obvious bias in the information provided undermines reliability
Eerie feel. Although very wellPresented and in beautiful condition, Hoa Lo Prison had a sad and eerie feel to it. Some of the displays are very graphic and a feeling of hopelessness pervades the site

Worth it. This was the first museum that we went to and one of the best. Yes it was a little depressing but any prison is not going to yield happy thoughts. There was many interesting photos of John McCain here too.

Not all prisoners are treated equally.. Sad to see how the French and VietNamese treated their prisoners and that so many were willing to fight to overthrow the French. The American prisoners of war had an easier time and better treatment than vietnams locals. My impression of viewing the exhibits.

More interesting than you think!. To get away from the Hanoi heat, we ventured to the prison. There is so much information here, about when the French had control and would torture the Vietnamese and then when the Vietnamese had Americans there. Lots of photos, videos, etc. Make sure to look up at the tops of the walls! Broken glass is cemented into the top to make it impossible to climb over.
Interesting. Interesting place and worth a quick visit. Good history and learned a few interesting things about what happened in that prison.
Great history. A great place to go to learn a little about the strengths and struggles of the Vietnamese people back when the prison was operating.

Visiting History. Really wanted to see the "Hanoi Hilton." Most of the original prison is gone, but the history is still there. Learned a lot about french colonialism in Vietnam and the early use of the prison. Then of course, more recent history from the Vietnamese point of view, with American prisoner of war.

Worth the visit . Not the longest or greatest tour, but we enjoyed our trip to the prison. There were some great displays and informative signs around the place, and it makes you wonder how on earth it would have felt like to be a prisoner within the building. I do note a lot of the information was one sided, but it was interesting to see communist views in action. Worth the visit.

Fascinating historical place, yet very sad - the famous Hanoi Hilton.. Visited Hoa Lo Prison (dubbed the Hanoi Hilton) during our visit to Hanoi. The prison details the atrocities the French inflicted on the Vietnamese and the incarceration of the Americans during the Vietnamese/American War. Some parts are depressing but so fascinating at the same time. The cruelty of confinement has to be seen to be believed. A really interesting part was they had the flight suit and parachute of Senator John McCain from when he was captured during the Vietnam war and contained in the prison. You can feel the history and the pain in the prison, quite eerie at times.

An insight into Vietnamese history. This museum is well worth a visit. It is smaller than I imagined but still holds a wealth of information. It is interesting to see how early the Vietnamese opposition to the French started. The contrast between how the French treated their Vietnamese prisoners and how the Vietnamese later treated their American prisoners is also fascinating (although possibly a little exaggerated). I also appreciated the chance to see how the war affected North Vietnam differently to the South and it was good to be reminded that the Americans never had control over Hanoi. If only they had followed the French and left the Vietnamese people alone...

Interesting and informative. Provides a really good insight into both French and American conflicts with Vietnam and the Country's response to both these periods. The 'American' room was particularly good with photos, video and items collected. Not a lot of English translation however and very hot when we were there.

Well worth a visit. We went without any real expectations, and found the experience incredible. The most fascinating part of it was the differences between the French and English translations (really bizarre), and the rooms talking about the Americans' experiences in the prion (which they nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton). The rooms show US soldiers putting up Christmas trees/receiving gifts - totally going against the horrors that US soldiers have documented. Our first experience of real propaganda in Vietnam - which was fascinating!

Living (if unpleasant) History. I think it's important for people to see how unpleasant we have been to one another over the years. Really interesting to read John McCain's first person account of his time there (available at US News website) and compare and contrast to the propaganda narrative presented at the prison.

Interesting and informative. Reasonable entrance fee (30000 VND). Takes about 11/2 - 2 hours to go round. Most signs have English and French translations. You learn about the French colonial history - building and using the prison, then a little about the use of the prison for American POWs. Takes about 30 minutes to walk from the Old Quarter. Worth a trip.

Scary but worth visiting . It was little scary to see all the place, but from historical perspective it is worth visiting, for sure. I would recommend you to go there with tour guide who can explain about the place well.

One of the best museums we visited in hanoi. Museum was compact and well laid out, it only took about 45 minutes to go around. Museum showed how the French treated Vietnamese political prisinors in their rule, also had a good section on American pow that were kept there during Vietnam war.

Great Museum. We really enjoyed our visit to this museum. We learned not only about the history of the prison itself but also the history of Hanoi and the War. This was the best museum we visited in Hanoi. Highly recommend. It will not take a long time go to through the entire museum. It is well worth a visit.

Very good and interesting prespective. I have read the history books, but never thought Id have the opportunity to see this myself. It is a very well preserved, albeit sanitized, view of a POW camp. The displays are educational, and a very interesting spin on life in the prison and how prisoners were handled. John McCain's flight suit from his capture is on prominent display along with other artifacts from the long history of this facility as a prison going back hundreds of years. A must see, if nothing else for another perspective of history..

A must see in Hanoi.. The Hanoi Hilton. I was there several years ago with my uncle that flew B-52's during the Vietnam war. Since I could only select August 2014 as my date, I did. However I was there several years before that. This is a amazing place. They have done a good job at maintaining the prison as an attraction for that neighborhood. We got lucky as they where just closing up and our driver talked them in to remaining open for us. We had the tour of the place all by ourselves. This is a must see if you go to Hanoi.
interesting. very interesting, it's a shame it has not been left alone. That development has taken it over.The guillotine was quite spooky to see

One of the most historic sites in Hanoi. Though the demonstrations are good, I must say it is better to have a tour guide or someone who knows very well about history to visit this Prison-museum.We understand better about the war days and the spirit of Vietnamese after visiting the site.
Very powerful and cautivating. Museum is great shows how the prisoners were really treated... its sad but REALLY interesting! I will totally recommend it

Never thought i'd see the Hanoi Hilton. This was a stunner for me, i grew up hearing about the dreaded Hanoi Hilton and was even more amazed at the first thing on display is John McCain's flight suite and helmet...Wow talk about a moment in history

Must see while in Hanoi. Very interesting portrayal. You can clearly see the Vietnamese hold their vitriol for the French, vice the Americans. John McCain's flight suit was an interesting site as well.
Interesting memories. A bit of history up close and personal well worth the effort. It tells much more history than just from the Hanoi Hilton days. Very friendly staff and shops.

Facing our history as an American. I grew up during what the Americans call the "Vietnam War" but what the Vietnamese refer to as the "American War." Going to Hoa Lo Prison aka "Hanoi Hilton" and being given a tour by a local tour guide was an interesting and sobering experience. We hired a tour guide (highly recommend that one does this) who was able to give a thorough historical account of the prison that was originally built by the French to imprison the Vietnamese. It was then converted to imprison Americans during the Vietnam War. Seeing pictures of people such as Senator John McCain when he was first captured as a POW was powerful. The area is not that large-one level- and a self-guided tour is easy to do because there are several things to read. Having a guide with us allowed us to asked questions and for there to be a give-and-take exchange of the history of Vietnam and the cost of the occupations (by the French and the Americans) on the people of Vietnam.

Interesting but Biased Exhibition. If you are in Hanoi you should go have a look. It's only 30000 VND to go inside. The placards and exhibits are well kept. There technically is a dress code but people were not following it. I think if you are visiting a place where people were executed you should at least put on a pair of trousers. I went with my dad. They had John McCain's flight suit. It was pretty cool. I would go again.
Hanoi Hilton. A somewhat biased view on the incarceration of US prisoners during the war. Very interesting to see (what remains of) the insides of this notorious prison.

History hours. Place is worth to visit if you want to get overview of hard times for local people. you can visit many rooms in this prison and read useful information. I expected this area to be little bigger, but its good enough to get good overview of prison life
History. I love going to countries witha story to tell and Vietnam has one. It is great to see what is left of the prison and get an idea of the conditions of what it was like many years ago.

Fascinating visit to the "Hanoi Hilton". A must see!. This was a fascinating visit. Even our 8 year old found it interesting. Being American, it was even more fascinating to see and read the comments about the American POWs (Senator John McCain being one of them). Keep an open mind- and remember that that the winners write the history books.

Definitely worth visiting. The museum focused almost entirely on when the prison was french owned and how the Vietnamese resisted mightily. It was interesting. There wasn't much at all about how the Americans were detained there. That was fine with me though. It was a great history lesson.
History of Vietnam. It is a great museum. You can see how the vietnamese people had to cope with lot of difficulties for earning their freedom.

Sad place. It's worth a visit here even though we found it hard to fathom inhumanity to fellow mankind.
Not only dedicated to the Americans but also the French involvement in the country.
Small cells, good explanation in English and some photo opportunities.

Very interesting, sometimes shocking. A good place to visit in Hanoi. The prison has had a long and nasty history. There is a lot to learn here. As an outsider coming here some of the information seems very propaganda influenced (especially about the treatment of the U.S. Soldiers as opposed to Vietnamese who were detained here) but that being said, I could be wrong! I am very glad we came here, give it a look. Entry was 30k VND

Interesting spot!. Enjoyed visiting the infamous 'Hanoi Hilton'. Very poignant displays including sculptures and an amazing garden mural. Very harrowing to see the guillotine used by French colonists. The only problem is the info is very biased towards the Vietnamese side in a sort of cringes way, quote a communist take on events, which is understandable to a degree. Just take some of the descriptions with a pinch of salt!

Interesting & Much to look at & read. Hoa Lo Prison - you could spend a whole day there - so much to look at and read. Many photos, weapons and recreated scenes of the suffering experienced during the fighting French, North & South Vietnam. If into history - absolutely worth visiting.

Hanoi Hilton. This is a very good museum. It isn't all about the American POWs - and it shouldn't be. There are a couple small rooms related to them. It is a very sobering experience overall when you see how the French treated the Vietnamese during the colonial period.

Interesting. Within walking distance of the Old Quarters and close to other tourist attractions. Interesting to see how the prisoners lived. Self guided tour with signs in English too. Lots of items and photos to explore.

Great insight into a difficult past. The place is set up well and has lots of information on Vietnamese and American prisoners. Would recommend listening to the earpiece in the second room of the tour as it's very informative. Fans all the way round to keep you cool in the heat of the day. I think they might hold back a little on how American prisoners were treated but that's probably to be expected. A must see when in hanoi.
Propoganda Central. The history of the prison makes for an okay time. The propoganda over the whole place is much more interesting and worth a visit.
Hoa Lo Prison. Great place to visit. Interesting to read about how the prison has been used and read the Vietnamese side of things.. .....there are always two sides!

. A real eye opener. A very moving place to visit and realise how very inhumane the human race can be towards each other.
Shocking to see the way we can treat even our own countrymen and women. A real eye opener and worth an hour of your visit in this city.
Absloute must for all Americans. each time I am in Hanoi I allocated time for a visit. The history is quite poignant and the exhibits quite disturbing, especially the ones from the "American war."

Interesting and informative. It was an easy walk from our hotel in the old quarter, it was really interesting to wander arounder the old prison and the information was clearly presented and informative. It was easy to imagine how the prisoners lived (and died) here. Well worth taking the trip there.

Must see if you are American or French. Very interesting. As an American I found the sections about the American War most interesting though the majority of the museum is centered on its use by the French Colonial government to imprison insurgent patriots.(and for propaganda). The flight suit worn by now Senator John McCain when he was pulled from a lake within 2 miles of the prison is on display.
Well worth a visit! . One of the better museums in hanoi as all the information is translated into English and French! We bought the tour book for 20 dong but it isn't needed. Entry price 30dong.

Just ok. The lonely planet and tripadvisor oversell this IMO. The cells are interesting in their brutality, the guillotine is cool... The most interesting part of the tour is the English descriptions.

Well presented. The name of this museum is rather descriptive, this is an old prison that has been turned into a museum. However, it is a virtual history lesson at it's best. There are other prison museums around the world that are more horrific but this one presents the Vietnamese history in a clear and logical way.You can expect to see garments and items of prisoners and guards, pictures and scripts, isolation cells, a guillotine and the great room where over 25 prisoners would be chained next to each other on each side of the cell. Definitely an experience that will make you feel grounded.

Wow this is eerie.. Hard to imagine the way people were treated in here...they have the actual cells and an original guillotine that was used on some of the prisoners . quite a good museum of American prisoners articles. The show how some 300 odd prisoners broke put through a sewerage pipe big enough as you thigh. A really interesting place to go to .

Really enjoyed this. I really enjoyed this visit. It was very well done and really made me understand the babaric (in my opinion) incarceration that many had to endure under the French. The part of the museum dedicated to USA POW was interestng in terms of perspectives. I thoroughly enjoyed this visit and learnt a lot, but one does need to go in with a critical mind in places.
Rather creepy. Its always creepy being in a place were you know bad things have happened. Unfortunately Vietnam has an abundance of such places. I certain would return again when back in Hanoi.

Interesting place, well worth a visit.. This museum is just a fragment of the original prison, most of the original area now has a skyscraper on it. Unlike most Vietnamese museums this one actually had a bit of narrative and gave a good account of the prison's history. Like all museums in Vietnam there's a healthy dose of propaganda but don't let that detract from the experience.
Disturbing but Interesting. Hard to believe man's inhumanity to fellow man . Almost need to see it to believe. Hard to look at , hard to look away See it!!!!

Realistic. Definitely worth a visit - well preserved/ restored prison to enable an understanding of the response of the French to Vietnamese resistance and the conditions of prison life which is also no doubt similar to those experienced in many other locations around the world. The treatment of US POWs is also covered - with a slightly different emphasis

Creepy prison museum that gives you goosebumps. I am not a big fan of museums. However, Hoa Lo is not just any other museums, it was a real prisons where thousands of soldiers were tortured in, and some never got to see the outside of the notorious prison again. Entering the dark cells alone, I immediately felt a chilly sensation on my back. Deeper inside the cell, there is a guillotine with a rusty, yet sharp blade, the only shiny item in this hell-on-earth. Standing in front of the guillotine, one cannot resist but to imagine the numbers of lives it had claimed in its "heyday", the blood split and the intense screaming in fear and agony associated with this men-made beast of death. Yet, it gets to out-live most of its "old residents". Today, it is still sitting there, intact, in the dark of Hoa Lo, mocking the visitors, startled, nervous and "creeped-out". Hoa Lo, a more horrifying experience than any haunted house could offer.
Historic-mania. One of the best place in Hanoi is this attraction. The entrance fee is just less than 2 dollars and it has lots of exhibits displaying the life in Hoa Lo Prison in the past.

Interesting place. Surprisingly, I struggled for things to see and do in Hanoi and so decided to go and take in some history at the old prison.It is interesting and quite sad too. Of course there is lots of propaganda but that is only to be expected as it is what the Vietnamese experienced at the hands of the French. Having said that, their narrative of how they treated the Americans was very different! Again, that is to be expected.It is interesting but I did expect a little more.
Good place to looking history. This is the first time i have been in hanoi, i were amazing to see a part of history in Hanoi. You can see how the people alive at that time.Recommend to all tourists

Interesting historic building. Well worth a visit and it gives an insight into some of the history of Vietnam. It is within walking distance of many of the hotels in the Old Quarter & takes about an hour to walk around. It makes you realise how hard the Vietnamese people have had to struggle against the French & the USA. Apparently it is closed on a Monday.

Scary to think of people were incarcerated in this place. This is a must to see when visiting Hanoi. You really get a feel for the people who were incarcerated in this place and wonder how they survived, OMG. Entry cost is cheap, and its within easy walking distance from the old quarter. Check out the book stand, they have some amazing books by vietnamese written in english and vietnamese. Put aside a couple of hours if you want to read all the information.

Amazing experience. For about $2 each we were blown away by the history of this place. You get a real sense of what prison life was like for both the Vietnamese and the Americans, and how different differently both sets of nationalities were treated in this prison. The video footage was very interesting as were the pieces that were on view. I would highly recommend visiting this prison, we were very impressed!

interesting place to go. Hao lo prison is definitely an interesting place to visit especially for just 30000 dong. lots of information in english but could do with some more explanation about inmates, maybe they arent allowed?

Worth a visit.. Interesting place to visit. Well explained and worth your time.
I found it interesting to see in what very harsh conditions, mainly political prisoners were kept.
Later, during the war the Americans were kept here as prisoners of war in very different conditions! Hence the name Hanoi Hilton.
Historical place in hanoi. It is one of histotical place in hanoi. If you visit this place, you can know more about how the vietnam's people survive for life and fighting for independence...

Worth Visiting. Had a good look around the prison. Not expensive for admission (30k?) And no need for tour guide. Displays heavily bias, especially regarding McCain etc but still very much worth a look. Can be done in an hour or less.

Hanoi Hilton. Built to house +400 in mates but at its peak had +2000. The prison brought home the number of troubled times the young Vietnam has had and their complexities. On our visit there was a US soldier who had spent 6 years in the prison during the "American War". Well worth a visit.
Interesting. It was very interesting to see how the prisoners lived in there. Definitely worth a look - great stories and pictures throughout to look at

Sobering!. This isn't a happy place, but it is well worth the visit. Fascinating insights into the underside of Vietnam's history, particularly the French colonisation and the American war. Its compact enough to do in an hour or so.
