Interesting but just a tad slanted. It's an interesting place to see though most of it was torn down . like a lot of Vietnam museums, they don't give a lot of context.

Interesting and thought provoking. Hoa Lo Prison is quite a haunting place to visit. It outlines the oppression and ill-treatment of Vietnamese prisoners by the French over many years but claims that Americans pilots were well treated when incarcerated here during the Vietnam/American war. A biased commentary but still worth a visit.

Eye Opener. This is not for the faint of heart. You will see two examples of mans inhumanity to man. Most of what is shown the conditions faced by the Vietnamese under French occupation/colonialism. Prisoners leg shackled to a wooden platform, forty or more to a cell. One shared open toilet. Temperatures over 100 F. Death by disease and/or torture the norm. Women prisoners in a separate cell. Basically the same conditions. Then you will see some photos of captured American airmen and hear lengthy discussion of how well they were treated by the Vietnamese. They can't or won't answer questions or respond to comments about that part of the Hanoi Hilton's history.All in all, a gut wrenching experience.

Cool site. This site is much more than the fabled 'Hanoi Hilton'. The site helps contextualize the history of the Vietnamese people under French colonial rule. The site is worth checking out. Oddly, there is a bookshop where you can buy a lot of iconic world literature, I.e. 'On the road', by jack Kerouac.

Hard to fathom. Worth a walk through. A brutal history quite well displayed and documented. I don't mind that it was hot, although there were fans and some air conditioning in parts. In some ways you could imagine the hardships in the heat, particularly in the death row cells and women's section. When you look at the sewer escape route you can hardly believe the tenacity, bravery and endurance these people must have had. Extraordinary!

Interesting but biased. The information is enlightening but biased. The acts "against" the Vietnamese people are shown in all atrocities and the apparent "good treatment" of the US prisoners seems to be a bit too good to be true. It is still worth a visit.

Interesting History. Yes, you will get people saying that the display in this prison does not accurately reflect the true conditions at the time, however I recommend you attend this prison with the view that this is only one side of the story and the truth lies somewhere between the Vietnamese and American versions. Then you can come to your own conclusion about what occurred taking into account this and other museums you may visit (Women's Museum etc)
Rattling.. A dark part of local history. And a must if you want to uncover this amazing country's history. An amazing part of Hanoi history.

Hoa Lo Prison propaganda. While the prison has a long history, including the internment of the Vietnamese by the French, the depictions of the US war ( as it is called in Vietnam) are completely bias and pure propaganda. Only a portion of the prison remains as most has been demolished for a new development, but the remaining portion appears to be representative depiction of the prison. Only two rooms are associated with the US war. One is a collection of photographs and news articles depicting demonstrations against the war from around the world and the second room includes photographs of US prisoners that show the prison as if it were a summer camp. There are pictures of men playing cards, playing volleyball and decorating a Christmas tree. All of which is totally propaganda and untrue.

Provides interesting history. The information about the prison was a bit disjointed but was interesting to give some overview of the French occupation and treatment of prisoners and then the American prisoners although it does appear to provide a slightly biased view.

worth a visit. This prison was dubbed as the Hanoi Hilton by the POW's who were unfortunate enough to be incarcerated here. It bore silent witness to the cruel side of the conflict. It is now just another attraction a part of that sad chapter in history and all that occured within its confines during those turbulent years.

Propaganda ploy by the Vietnamese. This museum is a great example of the propaganda tactic the Vietnamese government used during the "American" war and now still visible in present day cities. The museum tells mostly of the struggles recieved by the Vietnamese people from the French, which is interesting to see. But they takeaway the facts of what American soldiers endured in the prison, saying they recieved "great" treatment from the Vietnamese. Even the flightsuit of John McCain is fake said so by himself. Overall this was a waste of my 30,000 dong and hour. Really wish the Vietnamese would live up to what they did for their citizens to know.

Visit for the history, not the displays. As the exhibits explain in some detail, Hoa Lo was built by the French and served as a tool of repression during colonial times. Certainly the cells - complete with leg shackles - were incredibly inhumane.By contrast, the prison's later role as the "Hanoi Hilton" is dealt with briefly and incompletely. As other reviewers have observed, there are some fine examples of propaganda on display.Worth a visit - but for the buildings and history, not the displays.

Interesting bit of history. . Only a small part of the building stands with a big building and a scooter parking garage sitting where the main part of the prison was. The part of the building that was preserved has a nice museum with great displays but the propaganda presented was laughable and straight out of Moscow or North Korea.

good for learning... After seeing many temples...we went here.. and my kids really excited here..,more interesting than temples, cause they never see how the prison is...
There were many rooms here..so we could see how they felt inside...

Interesting to see the other perspective. We are Americans, and it was very interesting to read the perspective of the other side in this museum. There is also a lot of Vietnamese history here as a prison prior to the American War, that makes it interesting for the local people. We were glad we visited, it is a short visit.

The Vietnamese perspective. Very interesting view points of the American war from the Vietnamese perspective. Of course, I expected to hear a white-washed version of the treatment of American prisoners of war, so take it all in and remember that this is Vietnamese history, not American history. All in all, a very grim reminder of the realities of war and the treatment of captives and political prisoners.
Interesting. Interesting seeing the war from the Vietnamese point of view and how they want people to see it. Could use air conditioning.
Hanoi Hilton. Hanoi Hiltonthis was known as in the American war it's where they kept a lot of the prisoners of war.. interesting place.. again we had a good guide

Well worth the visit. Located a short walk from the action of the Old Quarter, the Prison entry is very reasonably priced at 30.000 VND - children are free - there was a small fee for taking photos.Allow approx 1 hour to visit the prison - there is much history regarding the inmates and conditions they endured. There is a small souvenir shop on site.

Hoa Lo prison tour. This was included with urban adventures Uncle Ho residence et al tour. A gruesome reminder of the colonial french repression of the local agitators as well as the more friendly Bangkok Hilton terminology

Interesting perspective. Interesting to listen to history of Vietnam encapsulated at this prison. Be prepared for hefty dose of propaganda on treatment of US POWs. Clearly the French set the rules of engagement and role models for prisoner treatment The quarters for USA POWs has been demolished and Al you get to see of this era is a series of propaganda photosWorth a visit to understand both sides of the coin but needs more English explanation

A piece of History. We visited with our own personal guide from Hanoi Free Tour Guides. She was very knowledgeable about the history behind the Hoa Lo Prison which gave us a better understanding of the history and the treatment of the Vietnamese prisoners . Some of the stories we found a little confronting.

Sobering. For those who remember the 60's this place is part of those memories. Was very moving to actually visit the site, although has changed a lot since then due to redevelopment, and see first hand. The displays do good job explaining the history through the years. Lots of good displays but needs better sound equipment for the displays that have audio accompanying.Well laid out and nice that flowers in courtyards to add air of calm. Do wish had known about memorial area to have brought flowers to leave. Nice in a place of so much sorrow to have a place of peace and reconciliation

Intersting piece of colonial history. There is not much left of the prisoncomplex but what is gives a good overview of the history that place has in vietnamese history.It covered the period under harsh french rule. Only prisoners from the prison told about when Vietnam became independent was the american pilots.

Worth seeing - plenty of history here!. It cost about 25K Dong to get to this place from the old quarter area near Hoan Kiem Lake. Entrance is 30K Dong per adult and 15K per local student. Children aged 7 and 5 are free. Guide books cost 20K Dong. We came with hanoi kids who talked us through the tour. You get to learn about the history of the prison built originally by French to house political prisoners. Children are likely to be disengaged throughout the tour but are still able to hold attention for specific sites/rooms. The vietnam war section is worth seeing. After the prison consider visiting the Quan An Ngon Restaurant - another 30K Dong at most to get there from here.

Fascinating to hear another perspective. Liked: price. Very reasonable. Lots of good info, easy to follow self-guided tour.Disliked: random gift shop with no clear link to prison. Also would have liked info about where entry costs were going...

Very moving, if in Hanoi make time to visit.. A really interesting museum and you really get a taste of how the French treated the prisoners in here.The museum is half the size of what the original prison was originally but you really get a feel of how depressing it was to be held here. They have lots of information and have kept a lot of the cell blocks the same. The most eerie part for me was the guillotine!Definitely visit the museum if you are in Hanoi, it's a must!

A must for Americans!. Otherwise known as the "Hanoi Hilton" to Americans, the vast majority of this prison tour is dedicated to the oppression of the Vietnamese people by the French, who shockingly crushed the Vietnamese people, and in doing so, created the Communist movement that ultimately defeated the French and kicked them out of Vietnam. Some of the museum is dedicated to what Americans are familiar with -- the place where numerous POW's were held during the Vietnam war. It is interesting to see the treatment of the POW's from the Vietnamese perspective, which is basically that, considering that the captured pilots were looked at as mass murderers of the innocent Vietnamese, who just wanted to have their own country after years of colonial oppression, the pilots were treated very well. We know the other side of the coin, i.e., that the POW's were NOT treated well, and were kept in very bad conditions, but looking at it from the Vietnamese perspective, they feel that the POW's were lucky to be alive, considering what they were doing to the Vietnamese people. We came away from it realizing the skewed version, but having a new understanding of the Vietnamese perspective.
Very Interesting. Well worth a visit. Suggest you get a guide (very cheap) to explain in detail the history over the centuries. Also provides some revealing details and facts about the Vietnam war.

Reminder of history.... We had a visit here with our Hanoi Kids tour. They knew so much and really explained it to us. It certainly is a history lesson and sad reminder for us all. Worth a visit for sure.

Interesting insight into the prisons past.. The Hoa Lo prison was on our list of places to visit during a day long tour of Hanoi. The visit was definitely well worth the time and our children found it very interesting too. We were luckly to also have a very knowledgeable tour guide from Hanoi Free Tour Guides that made the visit even better by explaining the history of the prison and how Vietnamese prisoners were treated in the days when Vietnam were ruled by the French.The displays and models in the prison were very good and helped us understand what life in the prison was like. Very eye opening!Well worth a visit if you have the time.
Been there !. Not much of the prison left unfortunately, but worth the visit to see how these prisoners were treated in comparison to others of the time.

First stop on the hanoi tour. Recommended attraction. Not large but a must see. This is the famous hanoi hilton and while it does tell the story of the french oppressors of the brave vietnamese (they seem to still like croisant and baguette here) it is a great place to see and should be on all hanoi itineraries.

Interesting and Confronting. The "Hanoi Hilton" has a story that must be told.... history must never repeat itself. The prison is a must see as it tells a horrific story with great detail....no trip to Hanoi would be complete without a visit to the prison which brings a realism and history lesson that is important to remember. Maybe a bit too confronting for children.

worth a visit. within walking distance of old quarter and an easy detour from the majority of other attractions definitely worth swinging by. Probably 1-2 hours at most you could spend here, but definitely a well preserved piece of history with enough written information and exhibition-style pieces to keep it interesting.

Hoa Loa Prison Musuem Hanoi. Nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton, this place (only part of it was preserved) was a sad reminder of the sacrifices arising from war and political conflicts in the past... you can't help but imagine the painful footsteps and cries of the inmates whose feet stepped on the grounds in the past, the untold stories of many heroes and folks...
Interesting. Very interesting to see a part of Hanoi's history. Slightly confusing to find, but worth a look if you have the time

Memorable Experince. Highly recommend this as a stop when visiting Hanoi. Lots of history here. Some of the images and displays can be sad, but highly worth the visit. It's unfortunate that most of the prison was demolished. But you still get an understanding and appreciation of the entire prison and its history.

You really should visit for an insight into the background to the revolution and Vietnam war. The buildings are what is left of the original Hanoi prison, where French enprisonened objectors to their occupation and then later home to us Air Force pilots ( including a now U.S. senator) during the Vietnam war. A good introduction to the official view and history of conduct during the Vietnam war, which is an amazing background to the very different and rapidly developing country you visit now. Vietnamese people are justifiably proud of their history and how they have come through some aweful oppression at various times. It's also an interesting insight to how that history is taught. Do this and the chi chi tunnels and war museum both in Saigon, to Understand the country you are visiting!

Brilliant. Well worth a visit and cost only 30,000 dong, very informative and for us the best attraction in Hanoi. (And we did the city tour) we visited here on the second day of our canceled halons bay trip! It was a Fifteen minute walk from our hotel (the Morgan's) excellent hotel in the old quarter.

Slightly propaganda but still enlightening. A cruel journey through the treatment of Vietnamese prisoners during the war. The prison itself has been prepared very well for tourists to take a tour through the various rooms and remnants from the war.

Well laid out, very educational.. Cheap to get in, there's a small English guide book you can purchase at the ticket booth but the displays throughout are also in English (we survived fine without a guide but I'm sure they could provide you with another perspective).Well laid out using the old buildings which make it more realistic. Covers the period from when Vietnamese were prisoners, escaping through sewers through to it's time as the "Hanoi Hilton" holding American pilots. Leave at least an hour or two to have a look at all exhibits, more if you want to go further in depth.
Interesting Site. Provides an interesting perspective into the French Occupation and the imprisonment of political prisoners.

Interesting and quite recent history in the making.. Very confronting. An interesting place to visit to learn about the rather recent history of Vietnam. Some great photo opportunities and the information provided is well done.
very special. First time, i came here, i could say " oh my god". I admit Vietnamese soliders was so resilience, they didn't scare what they have to face . I love Vietnam
SAD. it's really impressive to visit this prison, even try to think in the past time and how many people suffered.

Worth a visit - interesting. This is a small, but interesting part of Hanoi & Vietnams history. Felt that it could have been marketed more / displayed better to give a fuller picture. It's all set out in Vietnamese, French & English. The cost is VND 30,000 with concession at VND15,000 so don't forget student/Senior ID! Took about an hour to an hour & a half to go round.

Must Visit!. This museum was my favorite in Hanoi. It houses tons of history, is small enough that it's not overwhelming, and its incredibly informative. I would highly recommend visiting the prison during your stay in Hanoi.

Cool - take it with a dose of salt as a lot of propaganda. Pretty cool and interesting. Take it with a dose of salt as they cry persecution from the French but at the same time show that they had great compassion to the US POWs. We know that is not correct and it is just a lot of propaganda. Just take that into account.

Good use of the prison. It was great to see the prison being used to show the history of it. The museum is well set out so that you follow the arrows and see and read everything in the correct order. There is also a good use of video and other media to add a bit of variety.

The infamous Hanoi Hilton. You are able to walk through and see the cells and disgusting inhumane treatment that was endured by the prisoners -- including US Senator John McCain. Amazing to think that people can do this to each other. And unfortunately it hasn't stopped e.g. Abu Ghraib and Guantanimo.

Very well presented; a worthwhile historic trip. Of all the museums that I visited in South East Asia, this was one of the most well layed out, and most informative. Each part of the prison has plenty of well presented information to guide you along the way, and to help you understand the history of the prison and what went on there. It's well worth an hour of your time to slowly walk through, read, appreciate, reflect and understand.

Very moving experience. Hoa Lo Prison was very factual and interactive. Great insight into the influence of French imperialism in Vietnam. It also included information on Americas war with Vietnam. Found the prison cells to be emotionally moving as they display life size model of prisons lying and sitting in them.

Different Perspective. The Hoa Lo Prison gives a different perspective to the Vitnam war. Previously I only had the view from the side of America as deoicted in the Vietnam war movies and books. A visit to this prison gives a view from the persoective of the Vietnamese people.
Very Interesting. An interesting look at the history of the famous prison in Hanoi from both the French Colonial times and the American-Vietnam war.

National shrine. A shrine to the heroes of the Vietnamese liberation struggle. Man, did these people suffer. To be approached respectfully. A small area commemorates some Americans who were imprisoned here, too. Bizarrely, most of the prison site is now a luxury housing development. Would you want to live here?

Spend about half an hour here. An interesting exhibit made more real by the guide that explained it all to us. We were disgusted by the way the prisoners had been treated during their time there, especially the torturous techniques which opened my kids eyes. This museum is not air conditioned and you really don't need more tan half an hour to an hour tops to get around it so its a good fill in activity in between others.

A must visit. This is a truly fantastic place to visit. There is loads of information and some very interesting exhibits. The cells are very well set out with how the prisoners were kept. The presence of the guillotine showed the terror that the prisoners would of thought. Each person will take away what they want after visiting the prison.

Excellent on both older history and the U.S. War. An excellent explanation of the prisons uses by the French Colonialists. Possibly more relevant to many visitors is the section on the U.S. War which is equally interesting both for the artifacts and the somewhat one sided view of the era!

Great value for money. At 30,000VD entry (less than £1) this was brilliant value for money. Very interesting and different from a lot of other cultural experiences in Vietnam, we spent well over an hour looking at the exhibits and reading all the information. Lots of visual aids too. Great to learn about the history of Vietnam from a different perspective.

Great experience. The prison is a great way to get an insight into a country with so much history. Tickets cost 30,000 dong pp. great for all ages and an easy way to fill a morning or afternoon around Hanoi.

Interesting!!. Really interesting place with information in Vietnamese/English/French. Takes around an hour to have a good look around this place. Really cheap at 30,000 dong full price, 15,000 dong student place. So glad I went!

Should see this if you have time. A serious look at the conditions under which prisoners were held by the French during the colonial period and later by the North Vietnamese in the Vietnam War when the place was known by the Americans as the Hanoi Hilton. For me the French period was more interesting although Senator John McCain's flying suit is worth the once over! He was there for 5 years suffering torture on repeated occasions. It's well worth visit but does have the potential to offer a much better experience if the interpretation were improved and as a previous poster said, if it were more engaging.

Gruesome in places but thought provoking. Lots of information and exhibits. Well set out with cells made up to represent conditions. Information in English. Guillotine still makes me shiver. You have to pay for toilets!

Go if you have spare time, not on the top of my list . My friends and I went on our last day of Hanoi as a way to kill time as we were told it wasn't anything spectacular. It was alright, the prison is set up well for tourists and they have recordings for several different languages which is great. If you have time spare or are interested in learning if go, of short on time I wouldn't worry though.
Interesting take on history. The Vietnamese have a very interesting view on their history. Its always intersting to listen to others views.
Worth a visit :). It's a bit of maze! I feel as if I missed a room or two. There is plenty to see and much to learn about the prison.it cost 30,000 pp (2,000 parking)

Loads of info but lacks engagement. Hoa Lo Prison has a huge amount of potential. The level of information is superb and the exhibits are impressive. It is fascinating to be able to walk in the footsteps of those who have spent there. However, in my opinion I feel as though it could do more to engage with visitors. There is a real gruesome element to the prison's history that it doesn't quite capitalise upon, despite the presence of a guillotine. The exhibits rely on a lot of reading so perhaps an audio guide would be useful which would free visitors to walk around more. If you have the time to visit it whilst in Hanoi, definitely do so. It is a window into a world of which I had little knowledge.
Worth a visit. We visited here as part of our city tour - it is worth a visit - we found it very interesting. There are a lot of photos from when the American pilots were held there.

Interesting on several levels. Really interesting to see the Vietnamese perspective on 20th century history through the lens of Hoa Lo Prison and its different uses throughout its existence. It is up to the visitor to take away what he/she wants from the exhibits. History is full of terrible episodes, but for me the saddest part about the whole experience was that half of the prison has been demolished to build a giant hotel that looms over the prison, like it's trying to drown out the past. It doesn't take too long to go through the prison, about an hour. I brought my 1 year old and we were able to experience the whole place before she got really cranky.

Small but good. We basically went here because we passed by on a hot day and were looking for a place to chill. It turned out to be better than expected! Not huge but pretty informative. It was interesting to learn more history especially about the French colonization.

Truly the number one sightseeing option. Really interesting to see the conditions of the political prisoners of Vietnam. Tiny beds and. Prisoners were shackled in the beds. Also interesting to see in what conditions the American pilots were kept during the war,
History of Hanoi. We visited the prison and all found it very interesting. The history of Vietnam with the French and Americans was quite inhuman. Only a few dollars to get in, so worth a visit.

Sobering but educational visit. Short walk to the museum and cheap entrance fee. This is a very sobering experience but one that I feel everyone visiting Hanoi should experience. It is a stark reminder that it was not just the "Vietnam" war or the "American War" (depending on your perspective) that deeply affected the Vietnamese. It is a reminder that the French imposed harsh treatment and atrocities on the Vietnamese. The Guillotine made me shudder. Very informative.

Good way to spend an hour and learn some history. This museum is mostly about the time that prisoners spent here during the first Indochina war between the Vietnamese and the French. It walks you through each room in the prison and each station is written in Vietnamese, English and French. There are a few stations with audio recordings also in these languages. There are two rooms dedicated to the American war and the prisoners (including Senator McCain) that were held during that time. Cost of entrance was 30,000/pp.
Interesting. Plenty to see, including some gruesome photos. No need to buy the pamphlet, the informtion is written in the prison.

Very moving & educational but watch out for the propaganda. Very informative for the £2 entry fee! It was one of the best prisons I've been in, with the statues seeming ghostly & lifelike. There was a heavy propaganda piece on the treatment of American prisoners 'the best service the Vietnamese could offer' but you take all of that with a pinch of salt. Really enjoyable & educational day

Another cruel history of humanity. There may not be much displays in the prison but each prison room makes you think about war, cruelty, anger, and whatever bad things humans do to each other. Sometimes museum like this can bring out the message of positive humanity such as perseverance, courage, and mercy. For me the overall impression is more negative than positive. Be prepared for some propaganda as well.

very interesting site. It's just a short walk from the Hoan Kiem Lake at the Old Quarter. For 30,000 dong, we got a good glimpse of the war history in Vietnam. I liked the way the prison was restored. There were lots of informative pictures (most of the narratives were very long), diagrams, and 3D models. Some areas were creepy and sort of disturbing (like the dark death row cells). But I guess I still liked it better than traditional museums. Would recommend this one for curious and non-traditional tourists, maybe :)

Interesting alternate perspective . The important thing to remember when looking at ANYTHING (literally anything) is to remember someone paid or worked to make it exist. Therefore, it's interesting to consider the motives and how that frames what you're seeing. This is true for anything, but especially museums and cultural institutions (and ads, but that's a different story). The prison museum here is presented for local and foreign tourists by the government of Vietnam. As a result, it unsurprisingly speaks from a pro-Vietnamese perspective, especially in support of the current political system and leadership. Again, not necessarily a negative thing and certainly not unusual for an institution to speak through the lens of its own country / company / mission. However, it's important to keep in mind as the messaging of the museum is two-fold:1. Vietnamese political prisoners were treated horribly by the French but were able to prevail anyway2. American POWs were treated well in spite of the awful war waged against Vietnam(And recognize the word choice used throughout the museum: imperialist, comrade, etc - not neutral language choices that are tied to specific perspectives)I'm not going to argue anything in regards to the validity of the French, Vietnamese, or American ideologies or actions. But I think it's good to remember these exhibits are all presented with a purpose and it isn't an objective analysis of what happened. Plus, from a historical perspective, there are a number of differences between the French / Vietnamese political prisoner situation and the American POW situation. One is time and numbers. The earlier (French political prisoners) was a much large quantity of people and earlier in time for a longer period of time, so inevitably that affected the resources and quality of life standards compared with housing less POWs in a more modern era. Second is that the French were actively in power in Vietnam at that time and were persecuting local threats to their power -- which explains (not excuses) the harsher standards. On the other hand, the Americans were imprisoned while the Vietnamese held power, and they were highly visible in terms of being known about to an outside world. They were an important political tool for Vietnamese and US relations, and it benefitted the Vietnamese government to treat them moderately well and especially to create photo ops to use to show their benevolence towards the American prisoners to their Vietnamese citizenry as well as the world. However, it's important to remember (as we should all well know given our almost universal individual experience nowadays to stage and take photos) that pictures aren't reality. Thinking about who took it and why is as important as what's in the photo. So it's definitely worth a visit as well as a reminder to think critically about what we see (and don't see), and to question the messaging we've heard before -- recognizing that every story has multiple perspectives and just as many versions of the truth. If you're suspicious or critical of this presentation of history, keep that in mind the next time you read something you agree with and remember that others may find it just as biased.

Well worth a look around. The Hanoi Hilton has a good mixture of history, historic buildings and artefacts and personal stories to make it an enthralling visit of a few hours. Amazing stories of escape and sad histories of those that did not. Worth a look

Very interesting and a must see to understand more about the Vietnam War. For the equivalent of £1 (30,000 dong) we found this place to be a little bit of a hidden gem. Although we only spent around about an hour here we found out a lot about the prisoners and the circumstances surrounding their capture and in some cases their escape. You are free to roam the prison at your own pace, make sure you do not miss the upstairs area as we almost did. The American prisoners area is the most surprising. Having been treat slightly better to Vietnamese prisoners you can see their art work such as images of Santa Claus as they tried to make their time more bearable. Would highly recommend if you enjoy historical places.

Very interesting - lots of propaganda!. What we refer to as the Hanoi Hilton is now a museum mostly pertaining to the French War. The last area was dedicated to what the locals refer to as the American War. One room was filled with photos of war protests that took place in America and the other room showed photos of how well our soldiers were treated! Smiling faces, basketball games - very happy times. I think our men that spent time there would disagree.

Very interesting. We did a tour of this prison with a local guide who had lots of stories to tell us, however there is also plenty of information available to read.You can walk through most parts of the prison (some parts even have aircon) and see displays and artefacts such as one of only two guillotine brought to Vietnam by the French.It also has extensive information of the American POWs that were kept there.Very interesting.

Interesting. Glad we visited, although it is not "enjoyable" so to speak due to the nature of it, it was well displayed for tourists to learn more and gain greater insight into the history of Vietnam.

A must do in Hanoi!. The entry to the prison is 30,000 VND and well worth it. The english translations are good and the prison is well ventilated even in the summer so you don't feel like you need to rush through. The images and history of the prison are detailed and can elicit emotions, especially consider how local people and the US soldiers were treated so very differently.

Really worth the visit. from the nearby lake we walk 5 minutes to this historical place and it's all worth it. we paid 30,000 dong for the ticket each.the feel inside is different, first time for me to see an actual guillotine machine...it creeps me out! this is a must visit!not to mention the excellent air conditioning which is actually a relief from the heat outside

Centrally located history lesson. The so called 'Hanoi Hilton' is centrally located and easy to get to, if you are a student don't forget to show your student ID for cheaper a entry fee. The prison was filled with history and information about inmates to the history of the buildings.
worth a visit. the prison is worth it for a visit its only about a £1 for entry its good but very sad to see how the people were treated in the old colonial days

A simple prison in the middle of the city. The so-called Hanoi Hilton in the olden time where they house prisoners. Many artefacts and replicas of the situation in the prison. The coolest part were the drains.

Make sure you read up on the history before you go. The prision museum has been set up by the vietnamese and tells their story. Quite rightly as it is their country. However, as my history is not that great O would have liked it had I read more on more perspectivds leading into my visit.They have put together though a good museum with many harrowing parts.Make sure you check the opening times before going.

Woah woah. It s not first time i had being there with my tourist to discourvery Hanoi. So woah to say XIN CHÀO in Vietnam in different felling. Go back to John Mccain Period. Let's say: GOOD MORNING VIETNAM.And of course. All of my tourists who enjoyed our Hilton Prison trip this time did not stop their curiosity at the first sign to the end of entrance in this signseeing area.Guys, you should take taxi or bus or maybe Xe Ôm if you are being in Hanoi central now. Taxi price from: Hoankiem lake - Central distrist about $2, Xem ôm about 50.000 đồng.Entrance fee: 20.000/ adult, 10.000/ child. Opening time: 8h00 a.m to 17h00 p.mJack - English speaking Tourguide in Vietnam.

History. We spent quite some time walking, watching the audios and experiencing the small rooms where prisoners were kept. A shame they have cut the prison back to a smaller venue, Garden out back you can sit and reflect what history is around you and what people endured whist be in captivity.

Hauning. A very haunting place that showcases some of the hardships the Vietnamese have endured. While not a very big area, the displays are well detailed and very insightful, in particular the areas detailing the French rule. The area talking to "The American War" seems to be more a propaganda area than anything else, however it was still very interesting to see this point of view. Very well done & a must in Hanoi.

Visiting the Hanoi Hilton. Although it has been reduced much from its original size, it was quite an interesting place to see. Looked quite grim for those imprisoned there. Got to see pics of John McCain when he got to be a 'guest' there. Enjoyed getting to see this after hearing of the 'Hanoi Hilton' for many years post the war.

Haunting. This is a really informative and harrowing experience. For a completely impartial account a book would be best but to see the building itself, it's function, how the prisoners lived, and survived, this is the greatest chance you could ask for. There is something surreal about being in a building where other people have been and suffered years before you. It's really eye opening and one of the most interesting things we did in Hanoi. If you can walk around the city and do a tour of as many of the institutions and museums you can, bearing in mind the opening hours (many close between 12-1), and when taking .

Interesting part of history. Well worth a visit. By far one of the more interesting sights in Hanoi. It is a little full on, quite sad in many ways to see how prisoners were treated. A real eye opener.
Small part of history in mid town. Visited the pave with hanoikids and it was quite a good visit. Simply designed with information to read as well everywhere. Good for an hour visit.

Really interesting . I went to the prison yesterday as I had heard lots of good things about it. It was really interesting to walk round and hear about the prisoners and the conditions they lived in. I would definitely recommend this. Please note the wording on some of the information as it is very one sided.
Chilling. Something that should be seen. An in-site to what Vietnamese people have been through. Possibly not a trip for the younger children but for the older ones, yes.

Confronting and historical information. Its a must see when you are interested in history but then again really confronting with the things they did here. Its a proof that the Western nations who once ruled here were not that nice to the people. Especially now with the horror we see from the war in Syria and Irak..well the ones who say its cruel did the same things in the past. Torture, beheadings, small prisonrooms to drive people crazy...not something to be proud of. The Vietnamese people have been suffering alot thats for sure. See the real story here.. But bit sad that the biggest part of the prison was destroyed to build a hotel/office.. Lucky they saved this part for history.
Real eye opener. Remember the US propaganda of this prison during the Vietnam War? Well take a trip to the prison and you will see what it was really like

Haunting - a must see. A worthwhile visit during any stay in Hanoi - this is an excellently maintained former prison (The Hanoi Hilton) which has a melancholy, humbling atmosphere. The displays, videos and other items on display are extremely thought-provoking. Not an uplifting site but one that will certainly incite interest.

Ok for the History. Although it is steeped in history there is a strong theme of propaganda played throughout the prison trying to let visitors believe that the USA were cruel and harsh and the Vietnamese in the conflict were peaceful, placid and caring to the USA war detainees, it all appears to be a little one side given that my father-in-law was in the air force in Vietnam during the conflict and was able to give me insightful information as well but all in all a great visit, if your in the Old Quarter then try and walk there, it's a bit of a walk but manageable, especially stoping along the way at some great coffee shops and food shops.

Creepy~. There was one room with life sized models of prisoners. That was creepy. Other than that it was quite informative. I wonder what the French and Americans feel when they look at what their forefathers did to the Vietnamese. But that's all in the past. Cheers to a peaceful future. Only complain is that the place is too small. If you are not one for reading then walking through the whole place will take you 10 minutes. If you do read up and watch some footages will take you about 40 mins.

Confronting. Man's inhumanity to man; very confronting, that's the 'Hanoi Hilton'. No one speaking, just the occasional whisper; occasionally a click from a camera. Torture, executions, crammed cells, barely any light; quite a few escapees from this place too. Well worth a visit, just to try and imagine what was going through the minds of the inmates. No wonder the French were held in less than favourable regard by the locals.
Informative and slightly disturbing. informative place, educational, the conditions they kept the prisoners in were horrendous along with the torture etc.worth visiting

Creepy, but too small. Most of the exhibitions will give you creepy feeling from being in a confined black-coated room. Very informative. A bit disappointed that most of the prison were destroyed and rebuilt as an office building (Hanoi Tower.)

Worth a visit, but not for the faint hearted. I certainly gained a better insight into politics and war in Vietnam on visiting Hoa Lo Prison. I found some of the torture, living conditions and death sentences quite shocking. The fact that anyone, and there were quite a few who succeeded, ever escaped from there is quite incredible. But it does help give yet more information to build a better rounded knowledge of Vietnam's history. Worth a visit.

A Monument to a Tortured Past. Once you have visited here you will understand why the local people wanted rid of the French. A fantastic Exhibition that is a must see in Hanoi. Pretty confronting at times but that is what the place was. Very well done with everything in Vietnamise, English and French

An eyeopener.. Being of a generation which could have been forced to go to fight in the American War ( my country resisted USA pressure) I knew of the "Hanoi Hilton".. The prison is much more than a place where American servicemen were held. The French colonial power does not come off well in this place. Barbaric, uncivilised behaviour cannot be justified and I take my hat off to the strength of the Vietnamese people. The section on the American prisoners is also very interesting too albeit a little sanitised I feel. Well worth a visit.

Interesting but sobering attraction. I didn't know much about the Vietnam War prior to visiting Hoa Lo Prison, however the prison was an interesting but sobering introduction and I would recommend a visit if you have time.The prison building itself is quite well set-up for visiting, however an audio guide would be a welcomed addition for hire.

This information gave me a better understanding.. I had very little knowledge of the history of Vietnam. This was an eye opener. The displays were in English. After some information of the French occupation I had more understanding of the war in Vietnam. Obviously the information was a bit one sided but it's Vietnams history so their story.
Worth a visit. Good afternoon looking around. You got to admire the Vietnamese and how they looked after the Americans so well. Not sure if many other people would have shown them as much kindest

Loved the history. If you leave here without chills down your spine i would be very surprised. One of the most interesting places to go in Vietnam and definitely worth the few dollars to walk through it. Loved it and there's most certainly spirits in the death row and solitary confinement cells. The artifacts are basic but interesting but it's the feel of the place that I'll always remember.

Amazing. One of the best sights in Hanoi, absolutely a must-see if you are visiting the city. You should probably set aside an hour to two hours to visit this site. While we were warned about the level of information censorship, the site nonetheless makes for an interesting visit (though doing some extra reading in advance is useful, if you would like to learn more).
Sobering visit. Excellent displays and sobering viewing on the inhumanity of occupation.A must see The horrors of the French occupation is a lesson is history that needs to be remembered

History of Vietnam. My time in Hanoi was short but I picked Hoa Lo Prison as the only city attraction I'll visit. I didn't spent much time but sufficient enough (30 - 45mins) to pick up the essence of the museum. All of the exhibits are presented in English and the overall the information could feel a little one-sided (defending Vietnam war heroes) I can understand why. Pro: The place is very modern and clean, but looking at the cells still gives me the creeps.Con: The museum is really small, 80% of the actual prison campus has given way to local development which I felt is a pity. Would have participated in the museum tour if time permits.
Very informative. Interesting, very informative. Within walking distance form the old quarter. Lots to look at. Displays were all in English .

propaganda. Vast majority of it is devoted to the horrors of the French occupation and not to the war. he U.S. section was relatively small, and filled with propaganda. They've completely misunderstood the aim of a museum, to tell history from an objective point of view. Sad in a way because they could have made this really interesting and told a bit of their history as it was.

Hao Lo, History in the Writing. This well known prison has a very dark history, particularly during the struggle with French occupation. The history depicted in the prison is predominately about that time. There is a small section about the Vietnam War when the prison was known as the Hanoi Hilton, that section being particularly sanitized for political reasons and frankly no quite believable.The exhibits are a combination of actual parts of the old building, some murals depicting the struggles of the Vietnamese, some not so pleasant photo's, the odd guillotine and remembrance of some that lost their lives in the struggles with the French.Worth a viewing for its historical content, ignore the later politics

Interesting and educational. Worth a visit and is within walking distance of Old Quarter. Well presented history of the prison from older French times to Vietnam war era. Thought provoking when you see how inmates (male & female) were treated and you realise how horrific it would have been to be shackled all day etc inside. A bit of licence was taken, I think, with depictions about how well the US airmen were treated when imprisoned there. I have a feeling that it wasn't all that much fun. Keep an open mind here.

A Must See!!. Located near the Old Quarter. Very interesting information within the prison walls. Very good English explanations. Some haunting displays but worth the visit. You get a very good idea of what it was like to be a prisoner at the prison.

Always good to hear a different view. The best things about this place:
Open Mondays
Very few tourists at this time of year
FREE English guide (give tip though) who was very knowledgeable!!!!
Exhibits clean, in English and well done
Admission price comparable to other museums
Con:
A little one-sided, but that is okay.
Was pleasantly surprised!!
Histories. amazing and important view into the history of Vietnam. Never forgot to learn from the past, vietnam is moving forward, strong impression from this place of pain and sorrow.

Interesting. Only the main block remains after apartments built on the rest. However, worth a visit and well set out, kids will enjoy. The book stand inside at the back garden has some good English books on Vietnam at reasonable price and nice rest stop with a cool drink.
interesting. well displayed, but at least what's related to the so called american war.. i suppose the information is partial. so anyway it is interesting but i expected more history, more accuracy.

The Hanoi Hilton...really?. When you visit, you learn the history. If you lived in that history, you know how to separate the truth from the "less than" the truth. The walls show off pictures of our fathers, husbands, brothers, and friends who fought in the "American War" as they called it, and stayed here until the end of the war. Go..just to see.

Worth a visit. If you are staying in the Old Quarter it's an easy 20minute walk to the prison. Well worth a visit. Well set out, displays are very interesting and the information plaques are in English as well. Lots of history.

Quit an amazing place. Many about the use by the French in the early part of the 20 century. Very little about the American airmen in the 'Hanoi Hilton'. Some pictures of John McCain. Well worth the visit, good English descriptions. Cost was 30,000 local. Clean toilets also for the ladies I was told.

Our brief stay at 'The Hilton'. Some quite gruesome imagery awaits. Interesting to see and wouldn't want to miss it off a trip to Hanoi. The tour is fairly well sign posted with English translation pretty much everywhere.
Excellent museum.. This shows the sad history the nation suffered under different occupations and a must see. Very well presented.

'Hanoi Hilton' and its history. Most people know of the gaol as where the American pilots were incarcerated during the Vietnam War but its history goes much further beyond that to the time of the French colonial era. Much happened and the atrocities that happened there spurred the Vietnamese to strive for independence. Very moving and touching stories of patriots who sacrificed their lives for their country.
Hanoi Hilton. Interesting tour of the prison (called the Hanoi Hilton by prisoners who was held there during the Vietnam war)
wow. they tore down most of the hanoi hilton and left this up for tourists. very pro north vietnam. but really interesting historically
Not to be missed. Well worth taking the time to visit. As a mid 50's guy I have a lot of news related memories of this place and it is a realistic restoration.

Nice to visit but I wouldn't want to stay!. Definitely worth a visit. See how the prisoners were treated throughout history. May need to take in some of the information with a grain of salt. Still very interesting. I was there in May 2014, a great time of year to travel around Vietnam. I wasn't able to select this time option on trip advisor!
A must see. When you want to know and understand a little bit of Vietnam's turbulent history this is a must see. It is also interesting to read the 'other side' of the history.

If you are from the U.S. you've heard a lot about the Hanoi Hilton. There was very little here that dealt with the US involvement in the war-here it's called the "American War" and what you'll see is ONLY how exceptionally well the U.S. prisoners were treated. You mutter a quiet "Propaganda" to your husband as you walk by the photos.

Impressive. Impressive to learn about the history of this place.First a French prison where Vietnamese rebels were suppressed, afterwards a prison in which POW's of th Us were being held and treated well, despite of alle the atrocities committed by the enemy at that time. Leaves you speechless.

Somewhat biased. This was well worth visiting. The commentaries about how badly the French treated the Vietnamese contrast with how well the Vietnamese treated the Americans. Photographs of Christmas and Volleyball games with health looking Americans were quite a surprise.

Good way to spend couple hours or so. . Hoa Lo Prison was a great place to visit. History about the impact of the French in Vietnam and the Vietnam conflicts. The way of life for the prisoners, the attempts and success stories of these escapes
poorly exhibited. It is a creepy and sad experience to look at the exhibits. After the visit there it became clear once more that history books are written by the victor.

Interesting. It is very interesting and presents the history of hanoi. But I got goose bumps imagining how the prisoners we're treated at that time. Shows the true spirit of the Vietnamese people. There we're a lot of exhibits and the kids were able to learn more about Vietnam's past history. And still the pains and sorrows that war brings.

Interesting. I don't love museums, but this is definitely a place that you need to see while visiting Hanoi. It was interesting to see the portrayal of the American's lives that were kept there vs the portrayal of what we've been told in the states.
Interesting and well presented. At the time I visited it was not crowed, so had plenty of time to look at the exhibits. The exhibits were plentiful and well presented
Very interesting. It is an interesting piece of Hanoi history if you can take the partys propaganda. Go in with an open mind and lots of compassion.

Important historical site. This is a disturbing place, but important to visit if you are interested in Vietnam war history both the war with the French and the American war - you will certainly see a different perspective on events that may be familiar.

Free Tour Guide. We were offered a guide on our visit and it transformed our visit. Our guide took us on a private tour of the whole of the prison and made the stories come alive. The prison, although covering a smaller area than when originally built, but still allowed you to get an understanding for the terrors it has housed in the past. Very thought provoking.
The history of misery. I feel miserable life in prison.It is indeed sad that there is no freedom in the past.

Prison museum. The prison was built from 1886 onward by the Colonial French to house political prisoners. In its day it was the highest security prison in Indo-China. During the Vietnam War it held American POW's. Most of the prison was demolished in the 1990's but the gatehouse remains as a museum. There are many interesting but poignant exhibits including 3 murals in a courtyard.I was informed the prison is closed between 11.30am and 1:30pm but cannot confirm this.

Worth a trip. Short walk from the lake, definitely worth a trip to see. History of the prison is well laid out with some interesting exhibits, covers several periods of political prisoners. Pretty one-sided but interesting all the same.

Dull but meaningful. This could have been a great venue with lots of emotional impact. But it's marred by lots of puffery and self-congratulation about the glorious, selfless patriots who fought the tyranny of the French and Americans. Yes, every nation gets to write their own history: Too bad the Vietnamese decided to tell their story in such dull and predictable terms

If you have spare time. It was no doubt horrible times however, it comes across as very biased information, I got tired of reading it. If you have the time it could be worth a look, but I think there are more impressive things to see in Hanoi...
very interesting. history of the brutal french colonisation of the Vietnamese people. As well as the prison to house US pilots captured during the Vietnam war who named it the Hanoi Hilton.

Not for the feint hearted- but brilliant.. A fantastic museum that gives you an insight into Vietnam's complicated history.
From the brutal French occupation through to the incredibly humane treatment of US POWs, Hoa Lo gives a gives an honest and digestible account of its varied past.
Well worth a visit.
depressing french. yeah ...leaves little to doubt about why they fought back against white people ...the guillotine is a nice touch

Worth a visit. We decided to pay the old prison a visit. I'm so happy that we did. Although most of the prison has been demolished, what is left of it is really worth a visit. There is a great opportunity to see the effects of the war, the living conditions of the prisoners and the people who played an important role during the war.
Hoa Lo Prison. This is a nice place to visit for the understanding of what the vietnamese has gone through under french colonial.

Another Veiw. The visit to the Hoa Lo prison started with a Cyclo ride to get there what an experience (not what I expected) a must do for every traveller. The prison had a different veiw to the one that we in Australia had been told about, It showed the humane why the POW,s (shot down US pilots) were treated in the eyes of the Veit Cong, who's right visit and make your own mind up

Worth checking out. Interesting museum even if the information is a bit propagandistic, which is common in Vietnamese museums. Good range of displays, pictures, and all information is in English, French, and Vietnamese. Could easily check everything out in a couple hours maximum.

Presented well for English speaking tourists. The setup was polished, however it appears it is being neglected. Still, the displays are informative and little video clips. Only one section remains of the prison but it covers most of the original setup. Minimal entry fee, easy to walk to but be prepared to pay for public toilets.

They concentrate on the French. This was the prison used by the French to house Vietnamese " trouble makers " The conditions were bad & you see that.This is a also known as THE HANOI HILTON of the American war as it is referred to. There is little to nothing showing how the U.S. prisoners were held but you can assume it was just as the Vietnamese had been.It is a must visit in Hanoi

Shocking & intersting. 1-2 hrs maximum to be spent here .... Some shocking stories & images . The amount of propaganda mentioned is umm well shocking to be fair . Some interesting pictures and layouts to be seen . If your Interested in Vietnam war you need to see the Chi Chi Tunnels for a real feel of Vietnam . One thing is for sure no matter your nationality you wouldn't want to be locked up her !

Well presented museum. with its focus on the Vietnamese struggle for freedom from the French colonists the Hanoi Hilton puts the struggles of the American war firmly into context.... In the history of Vietnam this was just a short brutal incursion by invaders who failed to observe the provisions of the Geneva conventions while the Vietnamese did.... It's good to see history written by the victors and very sad to see some very brave Americans trying to come to terms with the horror the bombing campaign and the use of chemical warfare agents did and continues to do..... Watch the video presentations they are an education in themselves

Touching and important to see. ONe might hesitate to go as it is a hard piece of history. But the museum is very well organized, the exhibits are good and it is important to see for oneself the suffering of this piece of history--not only the American POWs who nicknamed it Hanoi Hilton, but also the Vietnamese revolutionaries who suffered so much under the French and were imprisoned here. Their bravery and persistence really come through. It is also so moving to see that first one group and then another could repeat cruelty. It gives good perspective that a casual tourist could miss on the long struggle of this country. My young adult daughter really found it eye opening.
Prison. Worth a visit, it doesn't take too long to walk around.Interesting stories, saw how people were kept. Also cool to see some release stories at the end.

Wouldnt want to be shut up there. A very interesting museum with some useful historical videos about the Vietnam war. Well maintained and signs in English as well as Vietnamese. Definitely worth a vist
The horrors of the French. Amazing experience to see what the vietnam people where treated and their fighting spirit to survive.

Alternative Perspective. I enjoyed thoroughly how the exhibition tried to bring out the fighting spirit of the Vietnam people when they were jailed and abused by the french people. And how they turn the tide around by making the jail a school of ideological teaching. This greatly aid in the revolution and independence of the country from the foreign forces. It gave insights into the life they were being treated and how they felt even when being sentenced to death. Eventually, it showed the people were pleased when they took it over from the french.The second part of the exhibition showcase the vietnamese using the same prison but this time, to put the American soldiers in it. They have justified that their retaliation was based on well founded need purely to respond to the threat of the U.S. They showed how they have cared for these pilots who were kept in this jail and how they treat them with kindness despite what they have done.Two things worth thinking about: One, how did the Vietnamese that were placed in the jail kept the spirit going despite the apparent oppression in jail by the guards. And two, how true is their point of view in comparison to the story the American have shared on their end about their soldiers. Before jumping into conclusion that it is propaganda, it is important to review the various articles and documents again. And this is something I'm looking to do. :)

Must see. amazing place with memories of the French colonial time, the prison in some points kept very well and fills like a now days real prison with the gilutine and other tools used to force people to stop the resistance against the French colonialism

Excellent Museum. The remains of the "Hanoi Hilton" now house a very interesting museum. Displays are clearly labeled in both French and English as well as Vietnamese. You get a sense of what prison life was like under French colonial influence as well as during the American/Vietnam War, from Vietnamese perspective. The museum isn't huge, you can see it in a couple hours. Worth a stop if you're in Hanoi.

A disturbing visit. A part of history but a little disturbing for some visitors with some of the photos and items. The very cramped cells and photos of guilloting and other cruel practices may not appeal to many visitors.

Spooky and humbling. Quite and eye-opener to see what prisoners had to endure while in captivity.
The displays and dioramas as well as what cells etc were left gave a good indicator of that the prison must have been like.

Worth a visit. With all the museums and things to see in Hanoi, this one is worth a visit to learn a bit of history about the city and the war. It shows things from an interesting perspective and gives a good snapshot of what life was like for the prisoners.

Great learning experience. We visited with our three teenage children and all felt we got a lot out of this museum. We had a guide (a Hanoikid tour guide which we highly recommend) which added to the experience, as she was telling us things we would not have known by just strolling through. There are two rooms dedicated to the American prisoners of war, but much of the history in the museum is focused on prior time periods when the French held Vietnamese communist organizers. The museum is also in walking distance from the old quarter.

Worth a visit. This prison museum is worth a visit. It's well set up, with the lights and the music/ voices in the background. It makes to sad story more real. Nice information bords. I've spend there at least one hour.

Sombre Reminder. We took the electric 'golf' buggy tour for an hour and we stopped at the prison. Our visit certainly brought home to us the suffering that the inmates endured. You need time to wander and to read the posters but the prison is well worth a visit. We particularly liked the little garden area., a peaceful place in what has been a place of suffering. We left knowing more about Vietnam history.

A chilling reminder of man's inhumanity to his fellows. Certainly worth a visit. The French colonialists were brutal in their punishment of dissenters, and the images displayed are disturbing. But then we came across the section and photos dealing with captured Americans, and it would seem that treatment was so much more genteel. Certainly there may be an element of propaganda involved, but it is a fact that the Vietnamese did not brutalise American captives like the French did.American gallows humour: Hoa Lo Prison was nicknamed 'Hanoi Hilton'.Go and have a look - not pretty, but a fact of life.

Great historic overview. The structure of the remaining prison is very intriguing, with high, thick walls. It would have been a magnificent sight in its day, sadly the events that went on inside these walls were not so magnificent. The various points around the prison provide an informative overview of the horrible struggles the Vietnamese were subject to during the French reign, and also of the prisons use during the Vietnam war. We consider the title given to the prison by the U.S. "Hanoi Hilton" is quite suitable given the difference between the way the French treated the Vietnamese and the way the Vietnamese treated the U.S. soldiers. Was also very interesting to see a bit of history about the U.S. Senator John McCain who fought during the Vietnam war. Recommended but maybe not a place to take children under the age of 13 as they may not appreciate or understand the history.
Impressive. Went here yesterday with my friends. Entrance is 30.000 dong and its defenitely worth it. Try the headphones in the museum for extra information/detailled experiences from the prisoners.

So poorly organised. We walked and walked to get to Hoa Lo and frankly we needn't have bothered. Aside from a few prison cell doors and some accidentally lovely lighting, it was a wasted trip. There is no real signage. The literature on the walls goes on and on about everything but the facility itself. Even coming from India, where museums are monumentally badly done, this was a disappointment. As for the guillotine that's supposedly somewhere on the premises, don't even try to find it. We tried and failed, and ended up in a random room on the upper level, watching a vague documentary on the revolution in a red-carpeted space that looked like it had been done up by Kim Jong-Un.
Worth a visit to remember... The Hanoi Hilton was a sombre reminder of the gruesome realities of war. Interesting exhibition that was pretty well put together. Worth a visit..

Really well done museum. Definitely drop by Hoa Lo for at least an hour. It's an interesting place with exhibits on both French occupation (Vietnamese inmates) and Vietnamese control (American inmates). You do need to have your propaganda radar out but it has some interesting information and exhibits, including a french guillotine
very informative. you could almost feel the fear of the inmates, chilling experience and very authentic. The prison was also home to US prisoners of war

Slice of history about the Bastille of Hanoi. This is a place for those interested in the gruesome history of Hanoi under the French colonial rule. The Hoa Lo prison was the Bastille of Hanoi, just like the Cellular Jail in Andaman was for us. Interestingly, the construction of the Hoa Lo Prison was completed in 1896 - the same year Andaman's Cellular Jail constructed started.

Hanoi Hillton. I like the place for its history and its infamous role during the Vietnam War. While the place is very well kept and informative, it is a bit disappointing that a big portion of the complex have been torn down and developed into an commercial complex. What is left is probably ten percent of its previous land size.

This is worth a visit while in Hanoi. Built by the French to imprison the Vietnamese underground movement, we learn a lot about the cruelty of colonization. The prison has implements of brutality including the guillotine, which we have only seen in photographs. USA prisoners called it the Hanoi Hilton. A very interesting museum

Very informative . Go around the Hoa Lo prison and read some of the stories in your guide. It is very interesting to see how terrible they treated the Vietnamese prisoners compared to the American prisoners who even smiled in some pictures from back then! Especially the few escapes that happened are really interesting and you can even see the sewers they went through and the clothes they wore!

Interesting place. Fascinating to see the different interpretation put on the Hanoi Hilton and set out well with a clear run through the various rooms. While you do sense the Party zeal for the revolution here you cannot also fail to be impressed with the national spirit that gained independence from two mighty Western countries. Worth a visit.
Interesting. Found that the set up was confusing, could of had more information to displays. There was bias to how good they are, but that's to be expected. Overall an interesting place to visit

I wasn't going to go, but glad I did. I had not planned to go to the prison, cause I thought it would be a downer. I found myself nearby and decided to go. It gave me a real appreciation of the struggles for independence.

Not on my 'Must See' list. Interesting to a point - but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit. Very politically pointed (especially towards the end of the tour). This prison was recommended to me by my hotel staff as in the Top 3 attractions. Good way to fill in an hour if you are in the mood.

A good half mornings visit. The site is much smaller than the original but still holds some sites that recall the obvious misery that went on there.There is plenty to see and read, I found the prison model and the accompanying naration very worthwhile and interesting.If you are staying in the Old Quarter it is very easy to walk to and take in the lake on the way.
Grim conditions !. A very intresting visit seeing the conditions the prisoners had to endure the models were very life like not for the faint hearted
Average. No where near as confronting as HCMC's prison. Compared to HCMC's prison this was luxury conditions.But I guess if you have not seen many prisons, its worth a visit.

Sobering and powerful. A look into the sobering reality of colonialism, imprisonment and war. This place is different from a typical museum stop in that it makes you feel something. Sadness, despair, futility, confusion, but in the end thankful for the freedom and life I am granted outside those walls.

Hanoi Hilton. The Hoa Lo Prison as best known as the "Hanoi Hilton". It was built by the French to imprison political prisoners during colonial times, but is now best known for housing American POWs during the Vietnam War. The prison was substantially torn down after the war, but a small part remains as a museum.We are not Americans, but even we were bothered by the overt, over the top, politicization. The prison was worthwhile seeing because it was the notorious "Hanoi Hilton", or, was "famous for being famous". Other than that, there wasn't much to see unless one is interested in photos of historical fiction.
I was like.... is this it?. We found it overpriced and poorly laid out. The exhibits are poor quality. We preferred the War Museum in Ho Chi Minh much more.

Well worth a visit. we were on cylo things at the time so we just popped in for 10-15 minutes, but you could spend longer and have a proper look, or just do what we did, which was like a skim over the pictures, it felt very 1 sided...

Very impressive. It was a really powerful museum. The information was really interesting and gave great detail. You get spooked when looking at the models of people in the prison. A really haunting but brilliant place to visit. A must go.

Small but interesting place to visit. What you see is only a small, leftover part of the prison. You can see a picture at the entrance what used to be the original prison built by French colonialists. It is a creepy and sad experience to look at the exhibits. American prisoners under Vietnamese probaby had a better treatment there compared to the vietnamese prisoners under French colonialists. Dont forget to look for the exhibits related to John McCain.It is part of the Vietnamese and American history, so it is worth a visit.

sad. Very sad and quite depressing, but then again I'm not the sort of person who enjoys looking at torture even if it's reconstructed portraying the past.
Big mistake for me... Hanoi has so much more to offer.

Worth a visit to the "Hanoi Hilton".. The Hỏa Lò Prison was a prison used by the French colonists in Vietnam for political prisoners, and later by North Vietnam for prisoners of war during the Vietnam War when it was sarcastically known to American prisoners of war as the "Hanoi Hilton". Some of the prison was demolished during the 1990s, though the gatehouse remains as does some of the rooms & courtyards the prisoners were kept in. There are also some photo's of the American airmen who were kept there.

Worth a visit!. As my hotel was right next door I decided to pay the old prison a visit. I'm so happy that I did. Although most of the prison has been demolished, what is left of it is really worth a visit. There is a great opportunity to see the effects of the war, the living conditions of the prisoners( a huge eye opener) and the people who played an important role during the war.

Worth a visit to understand more of Vietnam through her history. It helps me to understand more regarding the history of Vietnam through the colonisation and how the French being related to the Vietnam. Besides, it shows how a traditional prison look likes in the past and life of the prisoners, not forgetting to remind us how the Vietnamese fought all the way through the world war. p/s: Students with valid student ID will obtain a half price of ticket fee. Appreciate that.
Not bad. Interesting to see, but how entertaining can a prison be? You can get through it in under an hour easily.

The Real Hanoi Hilton. If you are Vietnamese, American, or French and you have any interest in history, you have to visit Hao Lo Prison. They've preserved only a portion of the original prison, but what is there gives you a good sense of what the prison was like under both French and Vietnamese control. It's not large -- an hour or so should be enough time unless you really want to soak it in. Words really do fail me when I try to describe the haunting experience of actually walking through the prison. If you've been to Alcatraz you can relate, but this was deeper for me. There is an artistic touch to how some of the cells are arranged (including some with "manikin" prisoners), and for the most part it enhances the experience without feeling artificial.Be warned - the storytelling is rich with propaganda: the French were nothing but blindly cruel, the American POWs were treated with nothing but kindness, and photos of POWs "enjoying" the generosity of their hosts are painful -- you can see the fearful forced smiles on their gaunt faces in the photographs. But even that aspect enriches the experience. My teenage daughter who is interested in world history found that to be the most interesting part. That said, do a little research before you go, so you can balance out the various versions of history.John McCain's flightsuit being proudly displayed - with stories of how his captors saved him and provided excellent medical care - caps off the experience.

Portrayal of torture of Vietnamese by French is hard to view. This is the "Hanoi Hilton" where John McCain and other American POWs were held. Most of exhibits focus on torture by French of Vietnamese "anti-colonialists". Guillotine displayed. Treatment of Americans by North Vietnamese during the American War was understated and apparently whitewashed. Read some history about this prison before visiting.
To understand history of Old Vietnam through the wars.... The prison is very educational to understand what was prison life during the wars they went through.

Interesting visit!. Interesting museum to visit, our two boys (10 and 16) enjoyed it even that at times a bit depressing. Interesting facts, many photos, and you get to visit the prison cells, quite daunting!

Worth a visit. Only a small part of the original building remains but it it is more than enough to give you the flavour of what it was like as a whole. The artifacts are few but interesting and it is the documented history and the building itself that were the highlights for us. Take some of the propaganda with a pinch of salt but there is no getting away from the real oppression that historically took place resulting in incarceration in this grim place. The US war is quite a small part of this jails history.

A mixture of feelings. Small museum with an interesting exhibits from the french occupation and treatment of prisoners. The information on the American/Vietnam War largely differs to accounts I have read regarding the treatment of US P.O.W's etc.

Really interesting. We really enjoyed walking through the prison. There was so much to read and look at and the place is really kind of intense with how they present everything. Some parts where really graphic and made you understand the conditions. Really well presented. Dont bother with a translator guide you can buy at the ticket booth though, everything has English underneath it.

Must do in Hanoi. The Hanoi Hilton is a must do in Vietnam. Although there is definite bias in the exhibits (the French inhumanely imprisoned Vietnamese resistance here, yet the Vietnamese were "kind" to American POWs). Although I have read accounts of their time as POWs, it was necessarily gut wrenching to see both the facility and a sterilized view of the conditions to fully understand what life was like in the Vietnam War.

Good for a quick visit. This was high on my list of things to do in Hanoi but wasn't as exciting as I thought. It is good for a 30 minute visit. It seemed a bit staged - not like the real thing I was expecting. At least 50% was about the French imprisoning the Vietnamese there - which is true but I wanted to see more about the American POW's there and that aspect seemed a bit phony.

Interesting and slightly eerie!. The Hoa Lo Prison was a really interesting museum/experience that I was glad we spent the time doing. I recommend going early in the morning as I suspect the crowds might gather later in the day. We had the whole place to ourselves pretty much, so we wandered around as we pleased. The place isn't too big, so you could wander through the whole thing in an hour while being able to see and grasp everything. Or you could spend more time and not be bored! It's definitely a must see if you're in to history (actual jail cells and a real guillotine are just some of the sights.)

Interesting place. This place isn't to big but it's a nice place to spend around an hour. There is some nice exhibits to show you what conditions were like and also some information from the Vietnamese side of the war I hadn't seen before. After only really getting the western perspective of the conflict you really do get to see why the people of Vietnam fought so hard to drive out the French and US troops.

Good place to learn history of Vietnam. Once you have been there, you notice the place is not that big. You will finish walk in less than an hour.
