But it is an eye opener on how Vietnam people fight for their indepence. P/S: once we are in the women prison, one kid suddenly cried and do not want to enter that section. It make us scared as hell.lol.

Well worth the visit. My wife and enjoyed our visit which gave us an insight to the cruel conditions the prisoners endured.It maybe smaller now than the original prison but still gives good information and viewing of many rooms.
Inhumanity. It gives a lot of emotional history of the country, also it has been well looked after and makes for a sobering visit.

An inhumane place. The story of Hoa Lo Prison is a story of poorly treated people, regardless of nationality. Horror from all sides in all wars, and an important place to visit in that regard. After the visit there it became clear once more that history books are written by the victor.
Better than expected. The Prison demonstration all got Vietnamese, French and English so it is easy to understand and most of the house have AC, so traveling there is quite good.
History Lesson. We got one of the Hanoi Kids to give us a tour of the prison, real eye opener. A lot of history in this small prison, well wants left of it.
Quite booring. 10 minutes in there are enough and the things you see could even be googled. In my opinion not worth to spend 30.000 VND

Wouldn't want a stay at the Hilton Hanoi. Real eye-opener on what prisoners went through during the French occupation and the 'easy' life American pilots had in the prison. Great information in good English.

A chilling reminder of days gone by.. A most interesting place indeed, it dosen't take one much effort to feel the raw terror people locked away in this prison would have felt, the story of the escapes people made is also a testament to the strength of the human sprite, i'm not so sure if the American POW's (mainly Airmen), would have told of many happy stories even though most of the photographs depicting them in the prison always seemed to be ones of happiness and recieving aid items etc.Well worth the visit.
Sad place. This is a sad place, showing once again mans inhumanity to man, no matter who is in power. It is smaller than expected and can be seen within an hour.

Worth the trip being so close to town. Although only a third of its former size, they have done well to give you an insight into what life was like for prisoners staying there. Many exhibition rooms, including some with life sized mannequins explaining how prisoners were treated, and also scale models of the original prison. An interesting trip, and opportunity to take some cool photos.

Good place to visit. I'd heard that this was a good place to go and I agree, it is. It gives a lot of history of the country, especially from a political stand point.Glad I went, the video on the second level of the second building is worth sitting through.If this review is helpful, please tick below:

Mixed feelings - but worth the visit. As a daughter of a Vietnam vet, I really wanted to see the other side of history. The history of how the Hanoi Hilton, heartbreak hotel came about was not expected. There was a small piece about the Americans that stayed, more was about the French and the Vietnamese prisoners. There was a small entrance fee, spent about 1.5 hours there. Include it on a day downtown.
Sad painful history. I left with tears in my eyes, I was very affected. The lifelike figures really brought the history of torture and torment to life. The place still haunts me.

French Colonial Prison. It doesn't take long to do justice to this small museum as much of the prison complex was demolished to make way for the Hanoi Central Tower Building in 1991. Enough remains, however, to get an idea of how Vietnamese who rebelled against the system were punished. The sign over the main entrance is the very same used in the 19th century and the guillotine can still be seen in one of the galleries. Tiny solitary confinement cells have been preserved as has the courtyard where American prisoners were allowed to take fresh air during their confinement. They jokingly referred to this prison as the Hanoi Hilton, and according to the propaganda machine, they were treated relatively well. Don't miss the small older part of the museum where tiny barbed wire containment cages are exhibited. Chilling instruments of torture.

Full of propaganda, like most museums in Vietnam . Hard to tell what was lies and what was truth. Also difficult to see what was actual prison and what has been renovated over for the tourists. All in all a disappointing visit, no need to make it a priority if you're in Hanoi.

Hanoi Hilton. They've made a good effort in retaining the building and recording the role this played in the History of Hanoi. We were surprised to find it was located next door to our hotel - I fact the lions share of the prison site was sold to build the Hanoi Tower and the Somerset Grand.
Very interesting. My second visit but less was open this round, last time you could go into the smaller cells which were upstairs. Still a good place to visit!

Good Tour. Visited the Hanoi Hilton as part of my Hanoi tour and is well worth the visit. The way the vietnamese were treated by the french is graphically displayed with mannequins to demonstrate the poor conditions and ill treatment that the inmates faced. Only half the prison now remains which is a shame as this building has so many stories to tell.

Historical Hanoi Hilton. This is my second visit to the prison. The first was four years ago. It has in places had a refurbishment. Not the cells but the displays and interpretation displays. The movie does not paint a pretty picture of the French colonialism. I am glad those days are over. If your in Hanoi it is worthwhile to visit. It only takes a few hours and costs 30000 dong. If you found the review helpful please let me know.

A glimps into a terrible time for the Vietnamese people. Very informative about the conditions during the French colonization and the war vs. USA. We had the pleasure of guides from Hanoi Free Walking Tours giving us even more information and drawing parallels to the current time. Worth a visit but do now expect to spend more than 1-2 hours there.

By chance visit to Hoa Lo Prison. This visit wasn't included in our itinerary but we requested and our arranged for us to visit there. It was very much worth a visit since it makes one feel how awful war could be and I value my life more after the visit. Vietnam has changed a lot since those days. And the visit makes me wonder why peace on earth is one of the hardest things to achieve. The culprit --- greed ?

Sad, but interesting. Very interesting, just a small section of the prison remains to visit, but enough of it to get a good understanding of how it was. Very sad, seeing how the prisoners were treated. Was well worth the very small entrance fee.
See beyond the propaganda. The over-all experience was worth the visit as long as you do not take everything on the explanation boards too seriously.

Emotions run high at Hoa Lo. This is the place where the French colonists tortured and guillotined so called 'rebels' and Vietnam's natural leaders. It is a moving place to visit, and probably a must for any visitor to Hanoi. There is also a film on show, which contrasts the conditions in which American prisoners of war were kept, these being surviving pilots of B52 bombers, shot down. The Americans were treated well, given good food etc. If only the French had done the same with their captives. The Vietnamese are a very forgiving people.

Scary Place but worth a visit. Worth a visit to see how the conditions were when the prison was used by the French Colonials to house the Vietnamese rebels in the late 19th and early to mid 20th century.The prison was also used to house US airmen shot down over Vietnam. The museum goes out of it way to show how well the US airmen were treated when compared to how the Vietnamese were treated by the French. Unfortunately there is a lot of propaganda - but as they say "Only victors get to write the history"

Fascinating Visit. This prison and it's history helped me to start to understand the Vietnamese people and their past. They unfortunately learned from the French and used what they learned on Americans. Plenty of propaganda here, so go w an open mind. You will learn about their history nonetheless. Good visit.

A must see. It was interesting to see the prison, right in the middle of town. Although the war was very controversial, to say the least, there was definitely a bias in the portrayal of how the American prisoners were treated.

Hanoi "Hilton" Is Not To Be Missed. Very Informative Tour. The prison is now a well designed informative museum that offers insight into prison life before and during the war. Hoa Lo Prison is also known as the Hanoi Hilton, coined by POW's during the Vietnam War. The museum recreates how inmates were treated demonstrated by lifelike statues. The men in shackles on small beds, torture chambers and even a guillotine from the French coonial days werre on display to curb anyones thoughts of breaking the law while visiting Vietnam. There was a small display dedicated to the women prisoners and I found the stories about these women very intriguing. The most interesting and somber part of the tour was the prtion of the prison dedicated to the captured American pilots during the Vietnam War. One of these POWs was John McCain and his uniform is on display. The Americans were said to be treated very well. This was astonishing, given the destruction and casualties depicted in the horredous video being played. There was no anti-American sentiment at this museum. I have heard other war museums are different in this regard, and that is why we opted to avoid those places. But the Hoa Lo Prison is an excellent stop and our favorite part of the Hanoi City Tour.
A must see. Atmospheric, sad but so interesting. A part of Vietnamese history that every visitor to Hanoi should see.

Shame half of this building has been knocked down!. We visited this museum the other day and found it quite interesting but we saw only a fraction of the original prison as there's now a hotel on the original site. Worth visiting though.

Interesting but not great. The prison is a nice example of what really happened during the first Indochina War and French colonialism. Unfortunately many of the documents that are written in French are just translated into Vietnamese and not English. It's a good place to go and get the feel for the cruelty of colonialism but it doesn't teach much about that time.Entrance fee is 30,000D and the booklet with a bit more information is an additional 20,000D and not really worth it.

I curse modern buildings. Only a wing of this important site remains. Best known as the Hanoi Hilton to outsiders, was built by the French as general and political prison. The US POWs clearly did not get the same the treatment as the French empire dealt out to the locals. In fact while being a POW is hard at the best of times, they were obviously well fed, healthy and clean.Well documented frighteningly awful as the well used Guillotine testifies. A must see.

Very Interesting. We went to Hoa Lo Prison in April of 2015. It was our first stop in Hanoi. It was a sobering and interesting experience. Having read much of the American history of this prison I was anxious to actually see it in person.I wasn't aware that much of the original prison has been given over to other uses, the part that is available for touring is much smaller than the original footprint. There is a quietness to the whole place and clearly the presentation of information is from the Vietnamese point of view. It was interesting to learn more about the history of the prison.Seeing the prison cells, the guillotine and some of the other torture devices was definitely something I wouldn't have wanted to miss. Go early in the morning and allow at least two hours, but not much more unless you plan to read every document and photo.

Interesting, but haunting. In my opinion this is a must-see in Hanoi. It is not pleasant experience to learn about all the tortures the Vietnamese people had to go throuh in their history but you get the facts told from another point of view, which is interesting.

Worth a visit. Not much left of the jail but enough to give you an idea of what it must have been like to be a Vietnamese prisoner under the French or a (happy according to the exhibition) American prisoner under the Vietnamese. Definitely worth a visit.

An eye opener. Their are places that one visits that have a foreboding sense about them and this is one of such places.it is worth going to see to get a sense of the Vietnamese history right back from colonial days through to the American and Vietnam war. I would recommend a visit

Different Picture of Hanoi. We really like visiting prison as they tell a different story of the city and people. This is mainly dedicated to the time of the French occupation but even so it is very revealing. There's a couple of rooms dedicated to the American prisoners of war but along with other places we visited is very slanted towards the good deads done by all.

Worth Seeing. We arrived with a guide for a tour around this infamous prison. It was a shocking insight into colonial history and its latter use as a POW prison for American pilots. The views expressed are well, a little biased; almost suggesting that for American pilots Hoa Lo was closer to a holiday camp than a prison. Accepting a slightly polished view of history in some respects, it still served as a powerful reminder of the brutality of colonial power and the terrible conditions endured by its inmates, both men & women; often for no other reason than wanting freedom from oppression.Worth a visit.

Worth a visit. It was worth a visit for our family (9, 13 &16 yo). Gave a historical insight into the prison and local area history. Interesting to read the perspective of the Vietnamese in relation to the French occupation (a grim one for those who were incarcerated) and how kind the Vietnamese system was to the American prisoners... Good to hear other perspectives than just the western one.

Need to see. Need to go with in walking distance of most hotel you really do not have to pay for a tour easy to buy tickets and go on your own Over half of the prison has been taken down for the high rise on the side but you get a good idea what is was like

Worth going. One of the few history-telling places we went to. I think the place tells a story with the statues of the prisoners as well as pictures. Some of the descriptions are rather propaganda but that's the same with any country recounting history. Worth going.Bring your student card even if you aren't from Vietnam because many attractions have student prices despite the already-cheap entrance fees.

A part of the history that many desire to forget. Hoa Lo Prison is a part of the history that many would like to forget. But we must not. As tough as it is to face the past, this once was the hell on earth. Entering this Prison, now museum is, yes, I will admit, a little awkward to many of my foreign friends - I still believe for this generation of travelers, we need to know what once happened. It's really hot inside in the summer.

A telling reminder of Vietnams' Colonised past. Very moving as it chronicles the History of Vietnams struggle to be free and independent.The Prison was built by the French in the late 1800's to house, torture and at times Guillotine Vietnamese protestors and Freedom Fighters.Chilling sculptures, Photographs and exhibitions display the misery they suffered.There were also very interesting exhibitions and photons of when it was labeled the "Hanoi Hilton" by captured US Pilots during the "American War".Definitely worth a visit if you enjoy Modern History and the Vietnamese struggle for Independence.

I cried when i was here.. HoaLo prison reminded me abt the War, i couldnt immage that vietnamese people had to face with the dead like that. Watching the documentary, i saw american warrior destroyed my country..it hurted me so much! I love Vietnamese. They were so brave even infront of the Dead. Hope there is no wars in the world!
Worth seeing . A lot of emotional history here, so a pinch of salt occasionally needs, but definitely worth seeing. The big front door alone has character, but the contents can be a bit harrowing.

Great historical experience.. Hoa Lo Prison is an eye-opening experience for tourists visiting Hanoi. The prison museum contains much of the history of the occupations of the Vietnamese people and war history of the American and Vietnam war as well.

Nice piece of history.. We love touring old prisons and something we have done a lot of back home in Australia so we jumped at the chance to visit the Hanoi Hilton - we attended with a guide from Hanoi Free Walking Tours which was a great addition to the tour. He was able to provide us further information beyond what was on all the signs etc. and was truly passionate about sharing Vietnam's history. It is unforunate that a large portion of the prison was destroyed to make way for modern buildings but what is left is certainly worth seeing for the history, living conditions and treatment of prisoners. It is also cheap to visit only 30,000vd per person which is great. Well worth a visit for anyone in the area!

Worth a visit, but not the most balanced view.... We enjoyed our visit to the prison, it has been well looked after and makes for a sobering visit. It's also very cheap (about 15,000 VND I think)It's not the most balanced historical site, and I'm sure when you go you'll understand!

A bit awkward. The guard selling the tickets kind of ruined the visit for us.Overall it's always strange to visit a jail. Regardless they have John McCain (former US presidential runner up) flying suit from when his planned crashed. Pretty sure it's a mausoleum for Americans in town :)

Worth a visit. Very central and easy to get to. Well worth a visit even if it's just to see the appalling conditions prisoners were kept in. Some videos about the Vietnam war make interesting watching too. Entry fee was 30000 ding a little over s pound, an absolute bargain. Walk round takes about an hour

Worth a visit!. Interesting and generally well kept place. Lots of pictures and artefacts from the american war and the guillotine was cool to see. I'd wonder how accurate the portrayal of life for American POWs during the war is though, makes it look like a happy place for them!The 30k dong entrance is worth it, plus 20k if you want an English guide book which has some interesting history in it but isn't really necessary for the tour. When we were there we saw other people with tour guides which might have made it easier to get more information.
Well maintained historical building. both interesting and sad.Information is given in English and French appart from Vietnamese 'what else can you ask for.

Interesting piece of history. Well worth a visit - informative and eye opening. Interesting to see how the French mistreated their prisoners, as well as how the prison was used during the Vietnam war.

Fascinating not just because John McCain was there. I've heard so much about the "Hanoi Hilton" that I felt compelled to visit. Aside from the arrestingly beautiful brick entrance greeting us, we appreciated the discrete guiding arrows to allow us to understand the history better. The darkness of what it once was can be relieved and there was a bit of a foreboding nature to it not unlike any other ex prison turned tourist attraction especially at the room that houses the death row inmates. It helped though that there were pictures of its former occupants and their letters and other mementos of what life was like back then coupled with a brief write up of them. I have the admit the English translation here is much better than those found in the Army museum.The only thing a bit jarring is the fact that there is a souvenir shop in between the cells that we were checking out. It'd be best if the souvenir shop is up front after all the cells are done.

Big Letdown. This is one of those must see monuments in Hanoi but it is not well presented at all. Apart from the complete lack of information for the exhibits, there is nothing to guide you around the museum. Would you believe it, I missed seeing the infamous guillotine and a couple of the dioramas on the premises. Comsidering the prison is steeped in so very much history, it is a big letdown.

Nothing bad to say. The prison itself is long gone except for the gate house which has some cell blocks and death row available to view. Easily done at a slow pace in 45 mins. Great history and if you love a story of fighting the system and civil revolution check out this place. Enterance fee is about $1.50 USD per person. No need for a tour guide all signs have multi languages.

It was OK. Interesting from a historical point of view but lots of spin about what happened here during the war. Interesting to find out how badly the Vietnamese were treated by the French - makes you understand why they were so keen to govern themselves.

A definate thing to do. Great did not know what to do on our last day so looked on Tripadvisor and read the rewiews so glad we did. This is a must to see, and done very well the conditions that people had to endure is amazing and you wonder how anyone survived.

Vietnam hero.. This prison very famous in vietnam, we go to visit a lo of area so this area bring for us remmeber our time ago the war, we were usually feel the amry in vietnam that is so Better more than U.S.A. they dont have anything But they were winner.

A must see if you are visiting Ha Noi. This prison is famously known as the Hanoi Hilton, named so by the US airmen shot down and captured during the Vietnam war. The most interesting thing here is the propaganda video they show featuring the airmen's time spent in the prison. It's fascinating after 40 years they are still showing this and keeping the propaganda going. If you were a local visiting, and if you were of the mindset that communism was the nest thing for the country, then I have no doubt you would believe the video's story. Hopefully with the internet availability these days, even locals would do some research to realise the video is merely an interesting part of history and far from the actual truth.The prison can be viewed easily within 30 mins or less if you are in a hurry. You don't need to buy an english guide as all the signs on the displays feature both vietnamese and english on them. The bulk of the museum covers the late 19th century when Vietnam was still part of French Indochina. It was a gruesome place to say the least.
Interesting, if you ignore the propaganda.. An interesting insight into Vietnamese history. A little overdone with the good Vietnamese-bad Americans, but understandable considering.

Disappointed. Exhibits were well sign posted with explanations written in different languages including English. The best part were the cells where death row inmates were held and reading about escapes from the prison. More photos than anything.

An insight. It was very interesting. Our 10yo was a little disturbed but well worth seeing. Only a small part of the prison remains as most was sold off and they built a huge hotel. We used Hanoi Kids to show us round.

Harrowing, yet informative. The prison was an exceptional place to visit as you get to learn about the lives of people who were imprisoned and the terrifying conditions they faced. Although it is full of propaganda and can be argued is biased, it was worth the time - and there were no queues!

Worth a visit. Prison used by French for Vietnamese and later by Vietnamese for American pilots. It has three parts, two on the ground floor and one on the top floor. Ground floor is divided between Vietnamese and American parts. They show well the difference in how inmates were treated. Most of annotations are in three languages ( Vietnamese, French and English) so you don't have to buy the book at the ticket office to get an idea what was happening there. John McCain was there after being captured by Vietnamese. Some sculpture in the patio. The annotations have a nicely put propaganda which gives the place a socialistic charm You would need 1-1.5 hours to see it all. I don't think the place is suitable for small children, would be ok for teenagers. Walking distance from old quarter and the Lake.Souvenirs shopCloses at 17h Cost 30000 VDN

A must visit. A short walk from the Old Quarter. No need for a tour. Small charge to get in. Quite disturbing to see how brutally the prisoners were treated being put in the shackles etc. Not a place for children. A must see to understnd the history of Vietnam. Also called the Hanoi Hilton by the American pilots.

The remnants of the old prison. Not that much of it remains, an office block covers much of the old site, part of which is now a memorial. The exhibits in the prison offer an interesting point of view of its history. Entrance was $1.5US and took about 1.5 hours to look around.

A deep experience. The conditions of this prison were frightening for us as travellers, how the prisoners felt would be beyond comprehension. Rooms open to view so you felt what the prisoners would be feeling. Informative and well presented.

Worth visiting. Family and 3 children visit 1 hr. Everyone really enjoyed this - many signs were in English, you don't need a guide here. Really helps in developing an understanding on the nationalistic pride evident in Vietnam, their fight with the French for so long.
Hanoi hilton. Felt this was a brutal and difficult place to visit. The building itself is in contrast with the brutality that occurred inside.

Worth the visit!. This is the prison otherwise known as the Hanoi Hilton (but when asking for directions, ask for Hoa La Prison or you'll get directed to the Hilton on the other side of the city). Only a portion of the hotel remains as an apartment complex now occupies most of the former footprint of the prison. A line of buildings about a block long remain and the displays are interesting and thought-provoking. They cover the whole history of the prison going back to its origins under the French in 1896. It was later used by the Vietnamese as a prison and during the war, it was used to house American POWs including John McCain, whose flight suit is on display.
great palce. visited with my family 1 hour here. It amazing about this prison between central of city. Recommend for visit when you come to Hanoi, Vietnam
Hoa Lo Prison.Hanoi. Very well organized museum that actually tells a storyVery difficult conditions of prison life of Vietnamese prisoners

Classic architecture housing a brutal, sombre past.. This museum is walking distance from the Old Quarter. The French architecture with the black and white tiles in the entrance, is quite a contrast to the story that unfolds within the building. The museum depicts the fight for independence , by the Vietnamese people from the French Colonialists.The museum has a second section devoted to the imprisonment of US pilots during the Vietnam War. In the first section, there is a gruesome guillotine on display along with some macabre photos of beheadings and other cruel forms of torture such as leg irons. The building is dark and the cells small . To be incarcerated here with rotten food , disease and no sunlight, would have been beyond my imagination.The second section has a display of photos and video of captured US pilots life in the prison. John Mc.Cain's flying suit and parachute is on display.It is an interesting insight into the decades of brutality that occurred in the prison.Definitely worth a visit.

Thought provoking. A visit to this prison certainly gives some insight into how the Vietnamese were mistreated by the French, and also an interesting account of how the American pilots were then treated by the Vietnamese.The original prison itself has mostly been torn down to make room for a hotel, with approximately only 1/3 remaining but what has been left gives you enough to understand the history of this prison.The layout is clear and easy to negotiate. We didn't have a book or guide but purchased a small tourist book at the entrance which, along with the signage inside, gives substantial information.The cells are harrowing.The majority of this museum is on one level with occasional single steps but easy to negotiate.A full independent tour took us approximately 1.5 hours which we walked to from the Old Quarter.It's worth the visit!!

Not to be missed. We visited here as we thought it would be interesting for the kids (aged 9 & 6) and it was literally just round the corner from our hotel. I am so glad we did as it really exceeded my expectations. We were probably here for a couple of hours in total, could have spent longer without the kids reading all of the information. The displays are very well executed and give you a real sense of what prison life must have been like. Kids enjoyed it too, although some of displays could spook smaller children or those who are particularly sensitive as they are quite eerie in parts.

Interesting and enlightening.. This is on every tourists list. It's a well laid out museum telling a terrible story of French oppression of the Vietnamese people and one of the detention of American pilots during the Vietnam war. Interesting and enlightening.

Insight . Very interesting, clean and well laid out. There may be a slight exaggeration on how many U.S. war planes were shot down and captured! and bias towards their treatment of American pow's. Actual relics from the 1890's political prisoners' escape routes - how on earth did they get out of there ? It beggars belief what the human mind conjures up during incarceration.

Fantastic and spooky!. We immediately wanted to visit this place when we came across it on a stroll. We were not disappointed! It was very eye-opening and very spooky at some parts. They had these scary dummies displayed which may scare little children. The place is full of history, and names of all the famous people who were held in the prison, including political prisoners and those who escaped. It's a must see! It was a highlight of our trip in Hanoi.

Disturbing but worthwhile. I was hesitant to go here but it is part of history.It was pretty disturbing to see how the French treated the Vietnamese with the shackles and the small cells where even women and children were crammed.It was also interesting to see the propaganda that the Vietnamese put there of how "nice" they treated the American Airmen. For example, if you look closelyat the pictures of them eating or playing chess, you can see that their uniforms are rather too large so you know they were not fed well and had lost weight. Also remember that John McCain cannot lift his arms above his shoulders due to the torture he endured so please do realize that the pictures and movies of how nicely the Americans were treated is simply propaganda.That being said, it was very interesting to see what is left of the prison as it certainly has a lot of history attached to it.

Touching visit of Hoa Lo prison. This prison helps us to understand the Frenh's way to treat the vietnamese prisoners and how particularly the Vietnamese women were treated.We learn also how several prisoners escaped this prison.
Fantastic, very eye-opening!. Highlight of Hanoi! top tourist attraction, very well put together, very interesting and captivating.

Somber side of Viet Nam's history. I was initially reluctant to visit the Hoa Lo, but decided to do so anyways... and was glad that I did. The life-like exhibits of the schackled prisons are quite sobering, as are the testimonies about the conditions inside Hoa Lo, from those held there. As the current facility is a portion of the original place, some of the cells have been moved -- and these still evoke grim reactions, as you peer into them... Be sure to also visit the upstairs rooms as well... The Hoa Lo is a worthwhile museum to visit, and to learn about this somber side of Viet Nam's history.
Harrowing!!!!!. A really informative place detailing the horror prisoners went through whilst here, although they seemed to look after the US pilots fairly well
Prison Museum. Great little museum which you can comfortably do in about an hour and a half. So interesting and covers French colonial period and the American/Vietnam war.

Eerily creepy but worth a visit. Just don't bring children that old enough to understand and be spooked. The plaster replicas of prisoners in shackles comined with the creepy piped in music made me think this is not the place for kids. But an interesting look at the horrors of the prison mostly for the Vietnamese and an interesting glimpse at the propaganda of the Vietnam War in this the nicknamed "Hanoi Hilton"
Worth a visit. It is interesting and worth a visit if you're in the area, we visited the Museum of the Revolution first which I'd recommend to fully appreciate a visit here.

worth a visit. This is worth a visit although it is only a small part that remains. Well explained on each exhibit. Found that it was very bias on the Vietnamese side. Firstly there are explanations of political prisoners that were kept there before going on to american airman....you really do need to take most of what is said with a pinch of salt. But it is worth a visit
Worth a visit. It's very well done, took us about 2-3 hrs to get around, takes you through a large part of history . It's only a small part of the original jail.
Hoa Lo prison. It is an excellent place to visit and the history is provided in English and French? Do not be taken in too much however about the treatment of the US prisoners of war.
Too much propaganda. Everything is well organized and clearly labeled but the message that the French were evil and the Vietnamese were remarkably kind to American POWs was a little overdone.

If you're a history lover,. It's a very interesting place, even though to say interesting makes me feel guilty. The good thing is that you can learn how the vietnamese try to preserve even the dark history and how they tried to be their own again. It's a place to visit if you want to understand Vietnam better.

Stomach Wrenching. Glad I did a tour of the Prison. Entrance is 30,000 VND per person and you can get an English tour book of the history of he prison for 20,000 VND. It makes you feel sick to your stomach what people had to ho through and the torture they were put through.

Very interesting and sad.. Good to know this history, it's obvious the Vietnamese went through some very tough times and this museum is clear about that but I'm so disappointed that half of the prison was torn down to build a high rise.

A good one to pass the time. Nothing especially revealing here. The tone of the exhibits changes starkly between the section covering French treatment of the Vietnamese and the Vietnamese treatment of the Americans.

Interesting place to see in person. Amazing place to see in person. It's hard to believe that people have been kept here under the conditions that they describe. Very interesting to read about the escapes and the different periods of history when the prison was in use.
Very interesting. Interesting attraction to visit. Very poignant. Would recommend to visit. PROS: well organised. CONS: none.

Fascinating. Visitors get a nice glimpse at how hard life was for captives when they visit this small prison museum. Especially horrifying were the isolation chambers.
Be ready for a heavy dose of patriotic propaganda - but, to be fair, what country doesn't have that?
A short walk from the Old Quarter, totally worth an hour or so.

Fascinating. For those who lived thru the Vietnam War (or as they say in Vietnam, "The American War,) this is an absolute must. It's fascinating and important though the exhibits in the Presidential Palace in HCMC are far more informative and compelling.

A bit boring. I thought this wold have more of the original prison to look at so you could get a feeln(like Alcatraz) but there were mainly pictures of aWhat seemed like Americans having fun doing activities. Seeing how the Vietnamese were treated was sobering however with life size models shackled by the leg. I had questions though about their life in prison and how long they were shackled etc but there was no further info
History. The place where American prisoners were kept during the war & where the French imprisoned & tortured Vietnamese. Not a nice place but real history

A Sobering Presentation. This museum is a "must-vist" site while in Hanoi. It presents a very sobering but somewhat limited perspective of the horrors of war and occupation. The French and the Americans have left many fingerprints on Vietnam and this venue presents many of them. It tends to focus more on the French-Vietnamese history than on the American war. Truly, the prison must have been a dark and hopeless place for the male and female prisoners there. I felt the "Hanoi Hilton" part of the walk-through was presented quite clinically and sterile from the horrid stories I have read in the past but then I also recognize that government perspectives on its conduct is inherently misleading too. The architecture was interesting. The prison is now situated in what seemed to be a thriving part of Hanoi. Very happy I took the time to visit Hoa Lo Prison.

Extremely Interesting. To see how inmates were treated was a shock. Human rights back then didn't exist. We saw the history from when built by the French Colonials in the late 19th Century to when American airment were held there "Hanoi Hilton" as it was known.A must see and very cheao entry !!

Historical place with biased point of view. Had to visit because of the history but please be aware it has a biased view point. They spend a lot of time telling how brutal the French were to the Vietnamese when they were in charge but do not tell about how brutal the Vietnamese were to the American pilots when they were in charge. Remember, history is written by the victors. On the plus side, the toilets were clean.
Worth a visit. Easy to find from the old quarter. Reasonable entry fee. English translations. Hanoi history so worth a visit.

Two sides to every story. The Hanoi Hilton or Hao Loa Prison was interesting. The museum focuses on the brutality of the French to the Vietnamese during their long war. There is a small portion dedicated to the American POWs and the propaganda is interesting to read if a bit over the top. All in all a worthwhile visit.

Interesting and well worth an hours visit. As it is within walking distance and if you have the time this can be a good destination to enjoy a different tourist site. As the story evolves you will be engaged and understand the horror and cruel treatment the prisoners endured. Hanoi Hilton is presented in a way that makes you want to hear an American pilot's version of it.

ABSOLUTE MUST SEE!. Both me and my boyfriend were born well after the Vietnamese war had ended, so neither of us knew much about the politics of it all or who was fighting and what caused it. We had a free day on Hanoi and were staying in a hostel in the Old Quarter. We walked to the prison via the perimeter of the lake. It took us a while to find the entrance as we had been given a poor map. The tickets were very cheap. Inside the prison there were arrows to direct you along the suggested tour route and information boards are in Vietnamese, English and French. All of the information boards were easy to read and very useful and both me and my boyfriend learnt so so much and the atmosphere really touched us. All in all we had a fantastic couple of hours at the prison museum, toilets, drinks, snacks and souvenirs.Highly recommend you go see! Absolutely fascinating!
Interesting place. This is an interesting visit if only for the propaganda of American POW enjoying Christmas lunch and playing basketball. Make sure you see John McCains flight suit.

Really fascinating place. the Hanoi Hilton as it was called by US POW's but first used by the French in their long war with Vietnam in the early 1900s (until 1954). What an eye opener to the conditions the French imposed on their prisoners. Some great exhibits but the cells and shackles and photos are eye opening. Luckily the Vietnamese didn't treat the US POWs anything like as appallingly. Even has John McCain's flying suit (apparently)

Excellent is not a word you should use for this prison. You need to go and see this prison for yourself Words cant describe it and only the people who were incarcerated here most of which died could tell you what it was like. This is where the American John McCain was held during the Vietnam war and survived.

Great place to visit. Opens your eyes to the colonial past - some really horrific things happened here during the French times - also great set of exhibits about the US pilots held in the war - great bit of propaganda from the Vietnamese

Interesting visit. We visited the Hoa lo prison with not much knowledge of the Vietnam War but found it very interesting. The view of what happened was horrific however very one sided (of course it would be though, any other country would do the same). We learnt a lot and then went off and did our own other research of the war.
Eye opener. Learned a lot and was an eye opener. Interesting to see how the American prisoners lived during the Vietnam war.

Hanoi Hilton (Hoa Lo Prison). Really well worth a visit for anyone with an Interest in the Vietnam War or French ColonialHistory.The death row cells and Guillotine from the French occupation give you a real sense of fear and terror that the inmates must have endured.The displays and artifacts from the American Pilots that were imprisoned here is very impressive. A thought provoking place indeed. Thomas K.

Hanoi Hilton. Worth seeing, just to see where John McCain spent 5 years a lot of propaganda. Some of the pictures about the American troops looking to be so happy we're pretty much staged. It still is a communist country.

very interesting exhibition. I found this exhibition incredibly interesting and although very sad subject matter I really enjoyed walking around and learning about the history of the prison. Thoroughly recommend this, very easily reachable from the centre of the city.

Propaganda time. Way too much propaganda which underestimates the intelligence of visitors. Claims about the amazing treatment doled out to American prisoners are not backed up by prisoners" accounts so the pictures of " happy " prisoners decorating the Christmas tree , leave a bad taste. Not much of the original prison is left so not really much to see

An eye opener to the cruelty of occupation. The french built this prison to contain the enemy of the occupation. Conditions were incredibly harsh, and no bones are made about the vietnamese feelings towards the atrocities this place facilitated. I'm not sure the historical depiction of how US captives during the vietnam war were treated is entirely accurate. Worth a look.

Was expecting more.. This museum comprises a third of the original Hoa Lo Prison compound (the rest of it has been torn down and the land is now occupied by high rise buildings). The exhibits were only mildly interesting. You can see everything in about an hour.

Somber Thoughts!. While travelling in Vietnam, we have visited a number of museums and sights that tell a very vivid story of the war years in the country. There are so many stories and each one brings about many somber and humbling thoughts and reflections. The presentation is extremely well done- a very worthwhile visit.

Fantastic but only with a guide!. Had a great time visiting this former prison and learning about how the prisoners used to live and the torture techniques used against them. Make sure you get a guide or else it will be a bit boring. Ask for a guide as soon as you walk in at the office on the left! Keep in mind a lot of what they say is very biased (its hard to stomach that all torture techniques stopped once the French handed the prison back to the North Viets, and to be told that American PoWs were treated like kings). Still a great attraction though, worth a visit!

Thought provoking - but not in the way the Vietnam Government intended.. Interesting insight into the terrible, subhuman conditions political prisoners were held in during the French occupation. The rooms devoted to the imprisonment of American POWs were clearly a propaganda tool, and left me wanting to find out more about the actual treatment of these prisoners. Worth a visit.

A must-see place. We found this really interesting museum and very well organized. Many explanations in languages official documents. Of course, full of photos, videos, objects and coins to visit that will make you feel the horror of colonialism and the Vietnam War.
To see if you want to discover the history of Vietnam and Hanoi city. Are planning at least one hour
worth a visit. Very sombre - as are most prisons. Good history and worth a visit. Hard to find though not far out of town. 20,000dong entry fee

A small remnant of its former self, but also ridden with propaganda. A small remnant of its former self, perhaps too small -- the prison doesn't seem to convey much of the scale of the life/atrocities that went on here. Toward the end of the tour you'll find a Vietnamese propaganda room/video or two, which I found distasteful (and I'm not even American).

lacks of information - not very informative. Not really a place to visit if you have only 2-3 days in Hanoi.. the city is full of other great places, lakes, restaurants, beer corners and other sites...

A travel back in time. Eerie to go through the prison cells knowing a lot of people have died there.
Very well organized museum that actually tells a story.
Informative reality of Vietnamese history. Informative visit. Greater understanding of Vietnamese history and the struggles of this nation in earlier generations.

Prison propaganda. Dominating the displays in this museum in the over stated version of the benevolent role the North Vietnamese played in the capture and treatment of the American, and other, pilots shot down and put into this prison.

Wow. Would have been a terrible place. Could only imagine how horrible this place would have been. Another reminder of the terrible conditions during war time the Vietnamese endured and they had alot of war time. Not sure about the American war propaganda. I don't think it would have been all roses for the captured soldiers as portrayed. Worth a visit if this is your thing.

Hanoi Hilton Prison. If in Hanoi you cannot miss this place. It gives an insight into the French colonial rule and still house a guillotine. Its use as a prison for US airmen during the Vietnam War doesn't get a great deal of coverage other than saying that they were very well treated -

Get ready for the spin.... I was disappointed in 'Hanoi Hilton'. However, entry was only 30,000 VND each (about $2 AUS), so no real harm done if you don't enjoy it.It is filled with propaganda. They present a very one-sided view of the Vietnamese 'revolutionary fighters' and American prisoners of war who were imprisoned there. It didn't feel authentic at all - the interior looked like it had just been repainted and looked clean and tidy. There are very few artefacts on display, and those that are, are in pristine condition. We also purchased the tour guide booklet upon entry (only 20,000 VND), which contained interesting and insightful information. However, most of the content in the booklet is displayed on signs in the prison.

Hard to believe. We didn't see anywhere they talked about housing U.S. prisoners, but we know they did, but it was interesting to see. It doesn't take long to go through. You can read information in English, so you can go through without a tour guide.

Why are the Vietnamese so forgiving?. This prison and its history of the cruelty by the French is startling - propaganda about the happy Hanoi Hilton for American soldiers who were captured is almost funny. Anyone interested in history should visit this place.

Interesting. We were fv sure what We expected to see at the prison, but We wete disappointed. Only cost $30,000 VND per person to enter, so you may as well go but there really isn't much there to see. You will walk through the prison and see the cells the prisoners were confined too but the rest is just like a museum and a gift shop and it didn't really feel like we were in a prison at all. Still, for the price you may as well go.

WOW - the history. A very historical place with lots of relevance. We were there for 1 1/2 hours and I could have stayed longer. Also known as the Hanoi Hilton, it's hard to believe the horrors that went on here with the French and then the VC.

The American Exhibit Is Over The Top. This sight is a worthwhile stop on your trip to Hanoi. It can be visited easily in less than 2 hours. Walking through the dark halls and thinking about what it must have been like imprisoned here is a sobering experience. Knowing a friend of a friend that was imprisoned here (an American pilot), the American exhibit and how are prisoners were treated is laughable. According to our source, the time they spent behind bars was a horrible experience. Pick up the inexpensive visitors guide at the ticket window (worth a view Dong/you don't need a guide). When you read it, count how many times the author says "patriotic and revolutionary fighters"-I got the point being made.
Worth a visit. The Hoa Lo Prison was quite interesting and really gave you a feel for what the prisoners must have endured there. Worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton. I didnt realise this prison was built and run by the French who also had a lot to answer for on the poor treatment of Vietnamese. Didnt expect to see a working guillotine!!!!! Apparently the American prioners faired much better here, hence the name.In my view well worth a visit, its well laid out and makes you ask a few questions abou mans inhumanity to man!

An Eye Opener. The conditions that prisoners were kept in were horrific. There is a huge guillotine on display, the solitary confinement area is dark and dank... A number of prisoners escaped in a variety of ways, and I enjoyed looking at the map of the escape routes and reading the stories about the escapes. A real eye opener as far as the effects of war on a population...

They won the war so I guess they can use propaganda. very one sided- laughing GI's having fun Christmas dinner- but also interesting with regard to the time the French were there. One place you should go!!

where you can find war crime and feel proud of freedom our previous generation achieved from colonization in the past. Well, this is a place if you travel in Hanoi. It is located in center of Hanoi, near Hanoi Tower, Melia Hotel, Hoan Kiem Lake - Sword Lake with named "very French" - Maison Centrale. This prison provides you a full understandign about pain and bravery of patriote prisoners and crime of prison controllers via materials, tools, cloths, guillotine, ...I bet you will be tear and moving for it.
history buffs will love. It was pretty neat but most of it is gone, definitely worth checking it out if you're a history buff.

Great for crime buffs. For 40,000 VND (about £1.50), there isn't a reason why you shouldn't go, and if you are into your History about War and Crime then definitely go! Learn about the political prison and what happened inside. It isn't a big place and I went round in just over an hour.

Don't Miss. I remember growing up and hearing about this Hanoi Hilton but didn't know all the history behind it. The prison was full of information and it really made you think about how all those people felt and what they went through.

ACTS OF ABSOLUTE CRUELTY AND ATROCITY ON DISPLAY. A visit to the Prison will enlighten you on how Humans can be Cruel and conduct atrocities on Men, Women and Children without remorse.Human rights violation, Torture, suppression & Cruelty is depicted in the Prison, now a Museum.It kept me wondering how Human a greatest creation of God can be so Cruel and Brutal to innocent fellow humans.But one thing is for sure, only Humans are capable of such cruelty.

Does not leave a good taste when you walk out. Its very depressing when see what people do to other people in a time and at a place where human rights did not seem to exist. And where goverments, that claim to be the advocate for democracy and freedom today, have commited crimes, that seem to be forgotten. This brings it back in mind.

Did not go in as you had to leave your bags at the front. I would have loved to go in and have a look, but you cannot take bags inside, and I was not that comfortable to leave my bag at the front with my passport etc. If you want to look in here, travel light, I am sure it is well worth a look.
get a feel for what really happened in this prison.. There are a lot of stories in this prison which give you a better understanding of what happened. Worth a look.

It's a sad place but good to visit. This is very interesting. The prison dates back to French colonial times, but also housed US prisoners of war. It's basically really sad, and just dreadful to think how cruet humankind can be to each other. But none-the-less it's really interesting and worth a visit.

Great insight into the past of Vietnam . Having been travelling in Vietnam for a while now I've been to several museums around the country however still didn't really feel I knew/understood what actually happened and why Vietnam's history was the way it was however this museum cleared a lot up for me. The exhibit is not only of ornaments from certain times but there are also very clear statements with why the ornament is important and what is was used for which made this museum a very good insight into the history of Vietnam.
Hanoi Hilton is no luxury. Women were badly treated by the French colonist. They were tortured, starved and murdered just for something they believed in

Intresting to see what war damages people. I was a little shocked like all prisons I like to see the art of prisons on walls. It was washed off americans treated better than I thought they would be but alot of other sad stories there worth a visit seen more intresting prisions luck I have never spent time in one but its good to see the history

Known as Hanoi Hilton during Vietnam war.. Yes, a bit sobering to see were humans are treated inhumanly. Worth the visit if only for the realization that the prison was built and used before the Vietnam war for the Colonial French to imprison Vietnamese political prisoners. Prisoners were both men and women.

An interesting place for a history lesson.. Although only a part of the original prison remains, the displays and information give a good insight into the history of the museum and it's more recent notoriety as the 'Hanoi Hilton'.

Enjoyable and interesting but not a 'must see'. If you have spare time in Hanoi worth a look even if just to to tick it off the list.
Some interesting history explained here but told with such blatant propaganda it almost became amusing towards the end.
It is kinda contrived and not as authentic as had hoped for, but still worth the trip if you have spare time.

Biaised but interesting. The various texts that are around are more interesting than many of the exhibits. It is fascinating to see how the words chosen are all anti - French and American and laud the socialist state. Not a huge museum - about 6 rooms and a shop. Early rooms are based on French use and later rooms on how the then communists looked after he US POWs very well.Worth a visit.

Interesting Hanoi history lesson. The prison currently costs VND 30,000 to get in - about GBP 1 - and whilst it's not that big to walk around and can be done in an hour, it is good value for what you learn. The prison was dubbed the "Hanoi Hilton" by the Americans but it's history predates this by a long time and you can learn about its history under the French authorities, the solitary confinement cells, the escape attempts - many of which were successful, and the separate quarters for the women prisoners.You won't need to devote more than an hour or two to this prison as it's not a big site, but it is definitely a good way of learning about some of Hanoi's history under both the French and American times.

Very interesting...and upsetting. If you are of a sensitive nature I wouldn't go as it gives you a very good impression of the evils of war. Having said that I would recommend it as an educational visit that we should all see for our selves in the hope that these kind of human behaviours will never be repeated.

Worth a visit. As an american, it was interesting to see the Hanoi Hilton where John McCain and other American flyers were housed. The history and how long it had been used for a prison were quite interesting.

Worth visiting. A thought provoking museum which shows the barbarity of prison conditions under French colonial rule. Some very good display material and photographs but understandably a very biased view - no mention of the torture of Americans by the Vietnamese.

Great history lesson for some. I took my husband to Hoa Lo Prison and found he learnt so much from the tour. He hadn't been exposed to many stories from Vietnam or the war and I saw that he got a lot from the tour.We did need to research some facts after the visit because everything favours the Vietnamese however, it was a big eye opener.

Patriotic progaganda. I visited with my kids and it was a great opportunity to show them how countries cast their history to emphasize their heroic moments and gloss over their less noteworthy episodes. The sections on the cruelties inflicted upon the Vietnamese by the French colonials were sobering and the courage of Vietnamese freedom fighters was inspiring. By contrast, the section chronicling the incarceration of American POWs was, by turns, a helpful reminder that America has inflicted real suffering on other peoples “in the cause of freedom and liberty", and yet, the same displays comically overlook the same cruelties that the Vietnamese captors inflicted on the POWs. The photos of American POWs gleefully opening their Red Cross packages, or engaging in healthy productive activities like playing basketball and growing their own chickens, are so obviously staged and long debunked by the prisoners themselves. And yet, it is a good educational experience to see how history is recast and manipulated, and well worth the price of entry if kids learn to ask if our own country doesn’t do the same with its history.

Should visit. This will take an hour, no more and probably make you think for a lot longer. A good history lesson if not again a somewhat one sided view of history! It has been well restored and maintain and shows a life few of us thank god have had to put up with. Yes go, we had a good hour there. There is a fee but not much.

A grim but moving visit. The so-called "Hanoi Hilton" is a must visit for those interested in the history of Vietnam. Built by the French in the heart of Hanoi it is a testament to their severe penal system, especially in their colonies. The prison covered a much bigger area in the past, but what is left is enough for visitors to get an idea of it's past: the original prison guillotine brought from France: the condemned prisoners' cells, where they were shackled night and day: the communal cells, and the tiny, darkened, punishment cells, all with life-like dummies representing the prisoners. Most of the exhibitions are based on how the French treated the Vietnamese, and in particular the revolutionaries, but there is one room dedicated to the U.S, pilots that were held there "in the best possible conditions" according to the information board! You decide! A sobering, but interesting visit

Interesting if you have some spare time. Most of the museum is devoted to how it was used by the French to imprison Vietnamese. However, there are a few rooms that showcase some pictures, artifacts, and highly biased/propaganda influenced commentary on the history of the prison during the Vietnam War. The photos of the US pilots laughing and playing games with the captions explaining how happy they were when they were there were so ridiculous it was hard not to laugh aloud. It was easy to walk through, wasn't too crowded, and did a good job with replicas to paint a picture. As others have stated in their reviews, you can spend as short or long of time as you want or are interested. I don't think it would take more than a few hours if you were to read every caption available. It was also close to good shopping areas, which we walked to after we left.

war remnants. the place is not that big, enough for a short 1-1.5 hour learning abt the Vietnam war, the people, the living conditions in the prison. they have a really good documentary in the last room, must watch

Moving. We found this a very moving experience. However one can't help noticing that it only represents good things that were done for the prisoners. I feel sure there is a whole other side not depicted here.

interesting but not incredible. i used my australian drivers license and pretended it was a student card to get a half price entry ticket, yes its low but if i paid 30,000 dong for entry i would have only given this a 2 star review. whilst it was interesting it was too re created and hard to take it all in. still worth a visit however.
Good for a few hours. Hoa Loa prison tour was a fun way to spend a few hours in Hanoi. The museum is well done, with good information in english and french.

Interesting and Insightful. This was a very interesting museum. It's an incredible historic landmark and the museum has plenty of information regarding all of the Vietnam War and the French occupation era usage of the prison. Definitely worth an hour or two to peruse through. We had a guide who took us through the museum, giving a bit of good insight, but ultimately moved too slowly for several of us who walked ahead and read the placard materials.

Nice Historic Museum. This site is well presented and organized, and is a pleasure to visit. One could spend as little as 15 minutes walking through, or an hour or more. The history is well worth the time.

Hanoi Hilton. This was a great museum to lean about some of the history of Vietnam. No need to buy the guide book as there are signs and film clips in English throughout. The propaganda is certainly one sided and I now wish to research the treatment of American POW from their perspective. Well worth a look.
Interesting but not a must see. It was interesting, not maybe not our best memory from our stay in Hanoi. but if you have time, it is worth doing it

Interesting - haunting and thought-provoking. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Hanoi. The exhibition is clearly set out (the narrative bias is equally explicit but, hey ho!) and there is a great section toward the end about the capture of US pilots (again to be taken with a pinch of salt).

Interesting History. This was very interesting!. It is something you must see if you are any kind of a history buff! I found it quite interesting that this was actually established during the French Vietnam war and the French were rather barbaric to their prisoners!e

Totally one sided but it's expected. Ofcourse it's gonna be one sided it's Vietnam but still worth a visit, cheap and easy, the captions under some pics are actually comical and seeing other peoples reaction is funny. If in Hanoi go!

Interesting place to visit. The prison is an interesting piece of history and it's definitely worth a short visit. They try a bit too hard to send the message that American POWs were treated well and humanely, but oh well. It doesn't take away from the experience.

Grim, but it's what really happened. This was the political prison set up by the French colonial powers in the late 19th century. The reality it depicts is grim in the extreme, right down to the guillotine, which was used frequently and often on those who tried to oppose the colonial masters. It is not for the faint hearted!
Very Eye Opening. It was a bit creepy and confronting at times but a must see to understand Vietnamese history. Learned a lot.

2nd best Museum I visited.. People say propoganda-y. I say the Vietnamese people have every right to be.I learned more of french atrocities and the prison itslef. The layout was great and I saw the lot in 40 minutes.Sure the American POW stuff seemed a little staged and POWs were not always treated the best here on both sides.Still a fascinating site. Worth a visit for sure.

History is written by the victors. Read many threads about this place and propaganda. I don't believe there is an absolute truth. One thing is for sure and that is this place is rich in history. I won't write too much as it may detract from the visit. I really enjoyed it. I went with an open mind and found it disturbingly gripping throughout.Enjoy

Lot of propaganda. Still very interesting and must see in Vietnam
Must see for the history buffs.
Lot of information on treatment of the prisoners prior to the Vietnam war.

May be disturbing for some but well worth the Visit.. Firstly, one must remember you are in Vietnam and the museum is going to be presented from a Vetnamese viewpoint. This was a real prison, and is presented as such, with the iron beds and chains to secure prisoners still in place as well as the actual guillotine used by the French, during their long occupation The French treatment of the Vietnamese was totally barbaric.The pictures and explanations (in English) add to the history. While the treatment of American prisoners seems to be too good, the pictures and film showing the destruction of Hanoi and the casualties to innocent residents from the American bombings does merit watching. Draw your own conclusions. The Vietnamese people have definitely moved on. During our two weeks in Vietnam we did not have one bad experience (except for crossing streets) and on the contrary found the people to be very friendly and restaurants helpful and very appreciative for our business. Just be very, very careful crossing the streets. Whether you are American, German, Vietnamese or any other nationality, cars and motorbikes DO NOT STOP for pedestrians. Crosswalks are meaningless.

Interesting insight into Vietnam prison. I wouldn't have missed this experience. Much smaller than I had expected as half of the old prison has been knocked down to make way for modern building. I would agree with other reviewers that the Vietnamese have only told their side of the story of the war with US but I guess that is to be expeced. What I hadn't realised was the French treatment of Vietnamese prisoners in the 1950s. Some gruesome relics.

History is written by the winners. A must see in Hanoi. The Vietnamese civil war from their perspective. Unpleasant like any prison but ironic that only patriots wer tortured by the French under horrible conditions but when taken over by vc it became a country club!

Interesting but false!. This museum shows realistic and harrowing evidence of the brutal treatment of inmates by the French colonial settlers. It also contains very false propaganda about the supposed humane treatment of US POWs during the Vietnam conflict; in truth they were routinely tortured, as a quick search on Google will reveal, and the photos of smiling USAF pilots putting up Christmas trees etc were posed. Do not believe all you see!

Shameful... I am not even american an I came out feeling very annoyed at what they had displayed as the prison.The bang on about how harsh the conditions where for the Vietnamese under the French, but when they look at the capture of the Americans apparently they gave them souvenir's on there release it was that nice for them..

Great Insight to the Past - "Hanoi Hilton". This a a great place to visit to learn about the past treatment of prisoners and referred to by American prisoners as the "Hanoi Hilton". Very easy walk from the Old Quarter.

Hanoi Hilton. This museum is one of the most harrowing I've been to but gives a good idea of what the conditions were like for prisoners right up to an including the Vietnam war. I do think that the relative luxury enjoyed by the U.S. prisoners compared to earlier residents, may be a little over exaggerated!

Great museum with shocking facts and communist propaganda!. The exhibitions at Hoa Lo Prison are pretty well arranged and you learn a lot about the occupation of the French as well as about the Vietnam war from the perspective of Northern Vietnam. The whole museum is packed with lots of communist propaganda but it's great to watch and it's a good contrast to the American propaganda about the war period. It was also shocking to hear and see the barbaric methods used by the French to treat and torture prisoners not even hundred years ago. There are lots of photos and also a guillotine shown in the exhibition which was used until the 1930s to head revolutionaries...

Interesting insight. Very well maintained. Detailed information on interesting facets of the prison's history. Very biased towards Vietnamese take on prisoners and their conditions and treatment. A must see to gauge own opinion and attitude.

Interesting and open on Monday. I know others have commented on it being highly propagandized, but guess what; history is written by the winners. Most of the museum focuses on its use by the French as a prison during the colonial and French War periods. There are two rooms devoted to its use by the Vietnamese to hold captured American pilots. The first focuses on the American bombing campaigns against Hanoi and the second displays an overly rosy view of their lives in the camp -- staged photos of games and smiles. Nevertheless it's interesting for me an American to learn more about the French colonization period and to see the bombing campaigns from the other side. Expect to spend an hour or two and go on a Monday if in town on that day as it one of the few museums open.

interesting, but definitely sad =(. This was definitely a very interesting experience for me, reading about how the prisoners suffered, and looking at the conditions prisoners faced. I appreciated the fact that they had life sized "people" as well, to paint a better picture. However, as I left the prison, I felt quite depressed.
Worth seeing. $2 entrance and very interesting to see. A walk through history as seen through the Vietnamese perspective. Affirms today what loving and forgiving people they are

Very Disappointing. I already knew that I was in Vietnam and had been to museums that are filled with propaganda and are very biased. This was the most telling example of that in all of Vietnam.It starts out by being "greeted" by a soldier just staring us down. Then we walk in and see the horrible treatment by the French of Vietnamese political prisoners. They go into detail how the French mistreated them. Then miraculously, the prison became a Holiday Inn as American prisoners were there. American prisoners were treated to their favorite sporting events such as basketball, volleyball etc... They even allowed them to play chess and make Thanksgiving and Christmas turkey. How nice the Vietnamese were to our American GI's right? Ask John McCain if he was treated so respectably. They have his pictures and uniform as trophies. They are sick! Then you are treated to a nasty little video again filled with such lies. Aren't Vietnamese people embarrassed by this distortion of the truth? A little child can easily see how horribly they present their lies. I'm ashamed I went there!

Interesting take on history. Covers the history from being a French colonial prison to its use during the Vietnam War and its conversion to a museum. Although the commentaries on the placards are far from neutral, just the place alone sets the tone of brutality and repression.

Moving and inspiring. Built to break and subdue resistance, this French prison instead allowed its prisoners to express their resolve and preserve their dignity with defiance. As well under the VC it allowed Americanservicemen to experience the costs and limits of bravery and obedience. Finally as a mere relic of a part of a building now almost swallowed by an office towers it too shows a kind of defiance. Ps the sculptures of the Viet Minh are wonderful.

The Sad part of Vietnam's past. We visited the Prison in Hanoi and was over whelmed by the tragic circumstances the Vietnamese people experienced during the war. I had to take a seat in the courtyard during the tour to reflect on what they had been through. It is a place to visit if this is your first time to Vietnam to truely understand what they have endured.
Sad. Sad. Tripadvisor wants a review to be at least fifty charracters but all I can say is sad, sad, sad.

Dissappointing. This museum is actually very well done, as it chronicles the various wars fought by the Vietnamese. However, if you are expecting to see many references to the US participation in the Vietnam conflict, they are sadly lacking. We had to ask for directions to find the (to us) obscure wall that had pictures, documents, and very anti-American videos. We were warned of this; however, so it was not a surprise.

Full of bull stuff... . I grew up in a communist Czechoslovakia. As a kid, I was fed the same propaganda stuff that is all over the walls in this museum. The language & choice of words are all vs imperialist enemies of the comrades & heroes & political prisoners under the French occupancy and American invasion etc etc. There are two sides of the story of course and in here you'll only find the one that is preached by Vietnamese government comrades. I once run away from the communist rule, while this was the first time since 1989 that I was again in a communist country. Made me feel awful & I struggled to keep quiet & polite. I'm not saying don't go though. If nothing else, it may make you realise how far certain countries moved on since the fall of Iron Curtain in Europe and how things are still going strong in Vietnam.

Interesting. Great to see how the Vietnamese see the history of this location compared to the Western view of it. Disappointing that so much of it was torn down to accommodate new buildings but they've done very good in preserving important pieces to look at.
Misfocused. Prison has very little about the Vietnam war but rather the mistreatment of the Vienamese at the hands of the French. Could easily be missed

Hao Lo Prison. Whilst the majority of reviews consider the prison a interesting and educational experience, I found myself frustrated with both the poorly written English and the one sided (and somewhat distorted) view of what happened in the prison. There is no denying it is a harrowing and interesting place but I left feeling that the prison was simply a propoganda front. Wasn't overly impressed but would still recommend going, you just have to know what to expect.

Interesting, but not as expected. Don't go expecting to see where they held Americans--this is THEIR museum and it is from their perspective, about their struggle for freedom of oppression...as it should be. I learned a lot...worth the time, but do not both with the book they sell.

Interesting History & Propaganda. This visit was so special with the wars we wage from the US to other Middle East countries today - and this was a historical part of our past US mistakes in other countries. You could still hear and see the prisoners - US, Vietnamese, French - all in the prison areas. The pictures were graphic and yet interesting, and so educational for all levels and ages. It was so sad to see how many women were sent here and killed. It's something to see in Vietnam before it is destroyed - for it is a sad part of US and Vietnamese history that we need not repeat. But it also let's humanity and our world leaders know how strong the human body and spirit is. Wow.
Must visit. It was very interesting to learn about what transpired at this place. Highly recommend the visit it will as you will not be disappointed

A Sobering Event. A well-done view into the life of the prisoners through time....American pilots, Vietnamese protesters and brave women. Makes one think how lucky we are to be on the outside looking in

Interesting but....... History is always interpretive so I entered Hoa Lo expecting some "interpretation". While the exhibits for the pre-1960's period were very well done, the imbalanced nature of how the stories were told made me skeptical and annoyed by the end of the visit.
Hanoi Hilton. a historical destination with a very convenient location, as it located in the center of town,. A Prison that went through a few different regime.
Brings history to life. A must see if you are interested in Vietnamese history. Shows in grim detail how cruelly prisoners were treated regardless of their "crimes" which were mostly political.

Grim and depressing. Doing a tour of Vietnam is very interesting and enjoyable,but some of the tourist attractions are pretty grim and depressing,such as the Cou Chi tunnels and the Remnants War Museum,the Hao Lo prison. Is no exception.Although the original prison was demolished and only the gate/entrance remains they have recreated the buildings as they were.Many of the shackles etc have life size models locked in them for authenticity,man's inhumanity to man never ceases to amaze me. Reading some of the information boards you will be aware of the propaganda portrayed.The prison was nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton,but it neglects to inform you how the Americans were tortured to praise their captors.

Interesting and haunting. Really interesting visit detailing the use of the prison primarily for political prisoners but also for misdemeanours. Information in English. Conditions harsh and degrading. There is also a section about how US pilots, who had been shot down, were housed there and apparently treated exceptionally well. Gift parcels and letters from home! Christmas dinner.

Creepy but i love the history behind it. One of the best museum ive been to. It is so informative, it has videos and audio in every corner of it. A must visit!! Make sure to take some time to read it all :)

Strong Stuff but Important. Much of what once comprised the "Hanoi Hilton" has been torn down but one section has been preserved as a museum. Americans naturally think of it as the prison that held a group of American pilots during the Vietnam War. Its role as a site of gruesome torture and execution by the French of native partisans during the time of French rule may be less familiar and is far stronger stuff. As a commentary on the arrogance of colonialism and the grit that drove the native population to struggle for freedom and independence, it's important to visit. It will make you think about history and the current day as well. For me the most incongruous note - bizarre and jarring - was the mat at the front door that said "Welcome" in English. If it had been there in the past, and I'm sure it wasn't, it would have been the last emotion that would have entered the mind of a prisoner condemned to enter. Go here. It's important that you do.

Anti French, pro Vietnamese. . Even with a limited knowledge of the French occupation of Vietnam and the Vietnam war, it was almost laughable the portrayal in the written material of the French treatment of the Vietnamese and the Vietnamese treatment of the Americans in the same prison during different eras. Make up your own mind, but I found the whole experience biased yet still interesting.
