Hao Lo Prison. This was very interesting, reading all about how the prisoners suffered and looking at the conditions prisoners faced. When you leave the prison you feel very sad.

Interesting. This museum portrays the turmoil and hardship of Vietnamese prisoners during their numerous wars. It clearly shows how poorly they were treated. During the Vietnam war many American pilots were imprisoned here. My understanding of their treatment is somewhat different to how it is portrayed.

Interesting Prison. was interesting to learn of its background as started as a French prison who displaced the people that originally lived there. Some gruesome images and the American section was a little hard to believe that the pilots actually enjoyed being there. Worth a quick visit.
sobering experience. if you lived during the Vietnam War, this is a must see. Small and uncrowded, it gives a glance at what the prison was used for during the past 100 years.
History!. This is a place with a tremendous sense of history and refection. Very moving and well done. Surprisingly, emotional.

Enough left to give an idea of times past.... Most of this notorious prison has been demolished (to allow the construction of a multi storey hotel).but that which remains is sufficient to give a very good idea of the conditions that prisoners were kept in. Built by the French to house (mainly) Vietnamese revolutionaries. Well documented in Vietnamese, French and English it will take you at least 40 minutes to cover the exhibits or up to 2 hours if you like to study in depth.My visit co-incided with the end of the Tet (New Year) celebrations. The irony of the Happy New Year banner above the entrance was not lost.One word of warning. There are 2 souvenir shops. The one in the courtyard sells the usual stuff which includes sets of Vietnamese coins. Fine if you think that includes UK pennies, Euro cents and Thai Bahts!!

A little different than what I expected. While I knew about the Hanoi Hilton I did not know that it had been for many years a French colonial prison with Vietnamese prisoners many of whom were dissidents or rebels. We had a guided tour but could have used an extra one half hour to spend reading some of the descriptions. This museum gives a quite chilling account and view of French colonialism. The guillotine room is very moving. The use of the prison for American POW's is much less emphasized, but clearly this was not the place to be incarcerated.
Okay. Was interesting to visit but lacked display material. Don't expect to spend much time here but if you are stuck for things to do then give it a go. Easy to find.

Well worth a visit. The entrance fee is real good value at only around one pound. The prison more commonly known as the Hanoi Hilton through it's association with the many American pilots who were imprisoned there during the Vietnamese War in the sixties. The majority of the exhibits show the period when the French ruled the country. It shows many examples of the inhuman treatment shown by the French to suppress the Independence movement in Vietnam. The most chilling sight is a guillotine situated in the death row arm of the prison. It leaves you cold!

History comes to life. As Americans we liked hearing some of the history from the Vietnam point of view. Seeing hoe the French treated their prisoners was disturbing. Along with the museum of war history one realizes how long Vietnam has been fighting.
Thought provoking.. Factual information available from colonial days to the American "war". Also known as the "Hanoi Hilton".

Historically very interesting and engaging. We went as a family, with kids aged 1-12 yrs. Although the experience was somewhat sombering, it was the most reading my 12 yr old son did the whole Hanoi trip, he was really interested in it. Good perspective provided on French and American periods of prison operation. Highly recommended for a couple hours.

Frightening reminder. Once through the tall dark doors of this infamous 'Maison Centrale' built by the French colonial authorities in the late C19, you are in all that remains of this once large prison complex. There are lifesize models of shackled prisoners, tiny condemned cells, whips, shackles, torture instruments and a guillotine.Vietnamese political prisoners were held here by the French, and their tiny stature is apparent from the pieces of narrow sewer system on display through which some made their escape. The emphasis of the displays is French inhumanity, contrasted with the supposed humane treatment of USA airmen held here in the 'American War' - they nicknamed it the 'Hanoi Hilton'.Well worth a visit, if only as a frightening reminder of inhumanity - and forgiveness, watching both French ann Americans touring round.

French architecture. This is the prison that housed the American pilots dubbed the Hanoi Hiulton. Much more of the museum is dedicated to the horrible way the French treated the Vietnamese people when the country was a French colony. There were 2 rooms dedicated to the time when the American pilots were "guests". They display the flight suit John McCain was wearing when captured. They focused a lot on the humane treatment of those pilots. I'm sure there are two sides to that story! It was very interesting and definitely worth spending some time there. Fee of 30,000 Dong for entrance.

A good history lesson. Dont miss this tour.....it has excellent history that really isnt all that long ago. the signage was adequate in english. What we found was that Vietnam was good for a general history lesson.

Not as much history as I expected. I had higher expectations for this place. It was almost as though they were only telling one side of what happened in this prison. You can't tell me that the American Pilots imprisoned there were having fun and playing games all day and not once questioned for information.....

Hanoi Hilton. Fascinating look at what remains of a once extensive prison before a skyscraper was built. It shows French colonial treatment of the population in an unflattering light and eerie models show how prisoners were treated. The photos of the American prisoners who named it the Hanoi Hilton is an interesting piece of propaganda particularly Christmas.

A must for anyone visiting Hanoi. Interesting to see this once infamous detainment center now used as propaganda tool by the current Communist government, against the historical French colonials and American "imperialists". The exhibits are of course all one sided, but very informative. My favorite was the display of US politician John McCain's military uniform, from when he was captured by the North Vietnamese and imprisoned at Hoa Lo.

vive la petite fifference!!. the dark prison, where the French occupants of Vietnam held and tortured natives is a solid evidence of the bad times of imperialism. the prisoners where kept in unhumane conditions, in excessively over-crouded rooms/cells. the prisin was used later, during the war against USA to cature americam pilots who where prisoned in very good conditions, private beds, good food and cothing. seeing the difference between the cells and conditions in the same prison is overwhelming and teaches a lot about the history of Vietnam, the empires that invaded ti the country

Another Example of Recent History. So sad to see the terrible things that people do to one another. This is an historic place but would not recommend for children under 13. There are graphic illustrations and models of prison conditions and tortures.

Historic Museum-Hanoi Hilton. It's eerie walking into this place then you appreciate it's dark and horrific history of imprisonment, torture and death.Mock exhibitions of prisoners shackled to dorm beds, the quarters of the damned, and the original 19th century French guillotine-the real thing with portraits of the Vietnamese victims during the French occupation portrayed for posterity.
Nice to see. I enjoyed this. They called it Hotel Hilton for the American Prisoners as they were treated well. Sad to see how badly the others were treated.

well done. disturbing. Worth a visit while in Hanoi. They succeed in gving you a sense of what prison life must have been like. Amazingly, there is an enitre room/exhibit dedicated to 'how well US POWs were treated during the Vietnam War (?!)
A must visit. A great place to visit full of history and facts not far from the old town silk street is great but be we're of the bikes .
Scary. Hoa lo was very scary place but it gonna good for someone wants to discover the how was Vietnamese war.

Well kept. It was an educational tour for me. Glad we checked it out. Place was clean. We walked back to our hotel and saw good restaurants. There is an American BBQ place along the way that is newly opened. We didn't eat there but we checked the menu and looks interesting. Spoke with the manager who is a Swiss, she's very friendly.

A "must see" site - better known as Hanoi Hilton. The exhibits are very well done. Ignore the "rewriting" of historical facts and you will be moved by the way this museum captures the treatment of prisoners in the French Colonial time. The charade of the Red Cross visit to see the downed US airmen is plain for all to see.

Sad historical site. Thought provoking, includes the guillotine used by the French to execute Vietnamese revolutionaries. Excellent learning experience, historically & politically. Shows the resilience of the Vietnamese people.

Interesting. Strange to say but visiting a prison was interesting, most of the original building dating back to the french colonial times has been demolished ,so what you are visiting is one corner of the original one. Still enough, quite harrowing the stories portrayed and chilly atmosphere stills pervades the place.

Interesting war history and perspective. I visited this museum on my one and only day in Hanoi and I'm so pleased I did, it was eye-opening and very thought provoking. You see lots of artefacts from the war, particularly during the French imprisonment of the Vietnamese, and there's also a gallery of pictures from the Vietnamese imprisonment of the Americans - interesting to compare and contrast, read between the lines on some of the descriptions. You don't need a guide, it's all in English. I didn't buy the guide book and don't feel I lost out on anything. Would thoroughly recommend when you're here.

Excellent and thought provoking. Went there expecting to spend an hour there but ended up spending much longer. Thought provoking in the extreme. Don't go to Hanoi and miss this one. Be happy you can leave and not have stayed there as a "guest".

The better museum of Hanoi. Most Hanoi musea are simple, old-fashioned and not very well designed. However this museum is still authentic and they didn't alter much. You can breath what went on there in the past. The stories are controversial and the Vietnamese claim they have the facts right. For sure the stories are great to listen to and one can make up there own mind what really happened there. The Mc Caine flightsuit is an attraction to most Americans. Its is for sure worth a visit and easy to reach by foot from the old quarters of Hanoi.

Hanoi Hilton. Probably worth a visit for historical buffs but it is dark and sad. Do recommend a guide as this was a French Prison before it held the American Prisoners during the Vietnam Conflict. The guide will give you a better perspective.

Great place to visit in Hanoi. This prison was great to learn about the history of the prison and its part in the Vietnam revolution and Vietnam War. Fair price, don't need a guide as much is translated to English. Would recommend when spending some time in Hanoi.
Must view. A different perspective on prison life and although heavily biased very informative.Certainly worth the visit and lots of images on what must have been a very hard existence

Definitely worth a visit. Really nice layout and provides an excellent insight into how things have been for the past 200 years in Hanoi. you don't need a guide for this but bring water. Interesting section about former presidential candidate John McCain. There is also a guillotine which is pretty intimidating up close. I really enjoyed it and so did my partner.

Definitely worth a visit. This museum looks real than anything else. I was very sad by time I had finished seeing this place.. U must visit this place n see everything, take ur time to actually do this place slowly..

Unique and Fascinating!. A fascinating museum prison tracing colonial French roots to the American War. Very educational. Well presented with lots of items and displays and entertaining propaganda. Sad and dark, but a must see.

Hanoi Hilton. You can buy a small booklet at the entrance, which I read whilst going around & read again a few days later.The museum is well-constructed and has perfect English translations, so no need to hire a guide.It was fascinating to read about how some of the prisoners escaped, about the village before it was a prison, and also about the US prisoners here and how they were treated.

As all prison museums and again original. Just a smaller part of the original prison is left, still showing the most important elements. Prison museums are always remainding us about the dark side of the human nature. This one is no exception yet original as "witnessed" decades and various rulers.

No need for a guide. You don't need a guide to visit this place. Many of the artifacts have English translation and you could go through the whole thing in an hour or less. Disappointed again by all the crap souvenir shops within the prison. They have $2 US bills made of gold-colored paper. The best part was seeing John McCain's flight suit. It was also interesting to see how much better the Americans were treated versus Vietnamese.

Definitely Worth a Visit!. We found Hoa Lo Prison to be one of the most informative sights we visited throughout all of Vietnam. There is alot of history to learn in the building, so allow at least 2 hours to visit in my opinion. We actually walked to the prison from Old Quarter quite comfortably. There is alot to read and I found the history quite disturbing - barbaric treatment of the Vietnamese by the French compared to the Hanoi Hilton treatment of US pilots by the Vietnamese. They have done a great job making the site engaging, I learnt a lot and would definitely recommend a visit whilst in Hanoi. We went without a guide and found there was plenty to read and learn already! However eaves dropping the guides they did have some interesting tid-bit facts to add that we didn't know. Either way, totally worth it.

Hanoi Hilton history update. Well preserved piece of history, remembering the days prior to its occupation by US airforce personnel. Impressive mural tribute in 'garden of rest' , remembering the fallen from the civil war. A different angle from that presented by western press.

Sad But A Must See.. This is only part of the prison as the rest of it was taken down to make way for the development next door. We were running a bit short of time and our guide was rushing us along and we would have liked to have spent more time reading the information etc but did appreciate it anyway. Lots of history and the damp smelling cells made you try and imagine how it could have been. I don't think I could ever really imagine the terror, pain and misery the occupants suffered for having actions and thoughts that did not fit with local government. Well worth the visit and highly recommended.
Enlighting visit. We spent approximately 2 hours walking around and reading the history of the prison. Very informative and emotional.

It is interesting to visit and listen their point of view......... There is more history than we expected, but mostly dedicated to tell the tourist their side of the story during the 100 years of the French occupation and the reason for them to start the Vietcong movement. I must say that they forgot the legacy given by the French during this period creating a new alphabet to start their own language and the architecture. There is a little area dedicated to the American pilots held in that prison and treated like royals......in comparison with the way Vietnamese were treated by the French.

Significant evidence from magnanimous history. I arrived Hoa Lo Prison one sunny day in the summer together with my fellows. We were on a cycling excursion seeking history facts for a team competition. However when entering here, our feeling of competitiveness no longer survived because of so truthful the reality. In front of us were historical artifacts of both Vietnamese and American people. They were so reflective and obsessive about our national war, our national human and magnanimous tradition of fighting and protecting our country against invaders in the 20th century. What impressed me the most was images of life of Vietnamese prisoners which is manifested by statues locked in sllavery unable to move but sit all day. While the colonial empire made all efforts to diminish human's will by torture and punishment, our national heroes never gave up but followed Ho Chi Minh's ideology driven by absolute independence and human rights protection. Thanks for introduction of some tour guide that we followed during searching artifacts' images for our competition we had gained deeper understanding of history and its manifestation in here Hoa Lo prison. Some of my friends even got obsessed by the image of a guillotine. Anyway, we had learned alot and felt more proud of our people. Just wanna say thank you for everything!

Dramatic history. I suspect many U.S. visitors expect to learn about the "Hanoi Hilton" aspect of this place, but it is so much more. Visitors learn about the complicated French colonial period, and the persistent Vietnamese impulse towards nationhood.

Well worth a visit. it was a great place to learn a bit about the history of Vietnam. A lot of what was said needs to be taken with a grain of salt.e.g. They were very badly treated by the French while in prison here but they "really" treated the Americans very well !!

Some history, worth a Look. It takes about 15mins to walk from the old quarter to the old prison. The majority of the old buildings that formed the prison complex have been replaced by new build apartments however there is enough of the old 19c building and cells etc to get the picture. Essentially the French controlled the area from 1850s to the early 20thC then the USA trying to stop communism fought the Vietnamese from 1954 to 1972 bombing the indigenous population killing and maiming hundreds of thousands of people then being defeated, sound familiar? Anyway the museum is interesting and worth a look, one can't blame the Vietnamese nationalistic slant on the descriptions. The exhibits are poor compared to European standards of presentation.

Historically Significant. One of the most important exhibits in all of Vietnam it's significance is often overshadowed by the US-centric nickname "Hanoi Hilton." But, way before war with the US French colonists built this prison. It represents the oppression of the Vietnamese people; the shocking horror of prisoner treatment is something all of us should remember and reflect upon.

Very informative.. We learned so much about the French and Vietnamese struggle for control of Vietnam. We had expected that the museum would mainly focus on the American prisoners of War that were incarcerated here. That was just a very small part of what was presented here.
A must-see. This is a must-see stop in Hanoi. It is a great way to see not only the history of part of Vietnam, but also how they viewed other nations and peoples.

Very interesting historic site.. Very interesting historic site. Helps you understand important features about the history of Vietnam under French domination and also during the times of the war against USA.

A surreal experience. This was a very educational and surreal experience. As an American it was interesting to see the Vietnamese stand point of the war and where they kept our POWs. Also to see how far back this prison went. It is defiantly worth the walk through, easy to fit in on a day of sight seeing.

Thought provoking. Please visit this prison as it is fascinating to learn some hard to absorb facts about the French occupation and more recent war. It is interesting to note that John McCain visited and donated memorabilia during his presidential campaign given the one sided nature of the information displayed. This is not standard tourist sightseeing but none the less a "must-see".
You must visit.. Heartbreaking to be there. Must see to really appreciate life and how valuable democracy is...there are so many lessons here.

Most of the Prison Is No More. We visited Hoa Lo Prison, a/k/a the "Hanoi Hilton", where U.S. Airmen were interred during the Vietnam War (which the Vietnamese call the Second Indochina War - for very good reason)Only a small fraction of the prison remains, including the original entrance with the sign "Maison Central" over the door. The first section is devoted to how the French tortured Vietnamese prisoners who were captured during the First Indochina War (1933-1954), a/k/a the Vietnamese war for independence from France, focusing on the fact that prisoners were shackled to the floor and fed rotten food. The second section is spent focusing on how well American prisoners were treated during the Vietnam War. This ignores the actual conditions in the prison, and also ignores torture of Americans in the prison during the conflict.Note that only a small fraction of the prison remains. Most of the prison, including all of the cells where McCain, Peterson and others were kept, was demolished in 1992 to allow construction of the high-rise building adjacent to the prison.

We enjoyed it.. We really enjoyed looking at the museum and all their displays. There are signs by every exhibit in English, Vietnamese and French so you are able to understand what the displays are about.If you are interested in history then give yourself some time to look around and read all the displays. It wasn't crowded when we were there and it was a pleasure to walk through.

Historically significant but only considers the Vietnam view.. This is a small museum but for US citizens (not me but I still found it interesting) and anyone interested in what the French were supposed to have done it is probably a must see but you need to be ready for the too obvious propaganda.
Historic. Interesting if you are looking for historical spots. Also very interesting to hear about Vietnam from a different perspective. Very cheap as well. Worth a trip.

Confronting and Claustrophobic. The information is interesting, also a little one-sided. I hated the mannequins they used to portray the inmates, they always caught me off-guard. The rooms are all square and black and just get smaller as you go in. The are some pictures of the beheaded heads around the guillotine which threw me a bit. Being there really puts the stories into perspective though.
Hilton hanoi. Well laid out. Mostly regarding french occupation. Humbling to see how much torture was done to Vietnamese people. So sad. Minimal display about US - Vietnam war

The "Hanoi Hilton". This was a very interesting visit to the jail. We watched propaganda movies of the history of the jail and when the vietnamese took American soldiers prisoners. it was an insight into the way they think about the Vietnam war. During the French occupation of Vietnam, they put a lot of vietnamese people in jail and treated them very badly, guillotining many and starving the rest. The Vietnamese however, are proud that they treated the American soldiers well! In their words, they were not mistreated and were happy.

A must on your itinerary. Take time to visit this museum/prison. The place is best know for housing U.S. pow's and most notably John McCain, but many others. A lot of propaganda photos showing how "well" the pow's were treated. Prison also has a greater and broader significance for being a place of torture for many dissidents dating back many years

Informative Museum. This prison has a lot of history and it is well laid out with good displays. One of the few places to have French and English on the boards with the history of the Museum. Well worth a visit.

An excellent sight to visit in hanoi. Incredibly glad we chose to visit the prison. It was an incredibly informative tour (no tour guide required). Seeing the guillotine was quite confronting, actually most of the tour was confronting. It's incredible how the prison was used and what the prisoners endured here.

Chilling. The portions of the Hoa Lo Prison that remain have been turned into a museum, mostly geared towards the French occupation and the Vietnamese that suffered here. The American pilots held during the Vietnam War are included as well, but only as a small portion. It was very interesting to me to learn about the French occupation and the horrors suffered here by all inmates. That huge guillotine in the Death Row section really gave me the chills.

Mostly pre-American war. This prison museum contains mostly photos and artifacts from the struggle with the French, in particular the Vietnamese prisoners and their French jailors, including a guillotine. It documents in some detail how the Vietnamese were mistreated and tortured. The documentation of the prison's use to imprison Americans is interesting, though minor, and consists mostly of photos and propaganda. It goes on at length with the American prisoners playing games, decorating a Christmas tree, singing songs, and just having a good old time. Not a complete waste of time but keep your expectatios low.

Ho lo prison. Very interesting learning a bit of history from the French occupation to the American war, the photos and objects on display were good especially senator John Mc Cains uniform when he was captured

Gruesome. This site is worth a look. It was very daunting though to read the stories of the prisoners that were housed there is putrid conditions. The Guillotine still stands and the life like figures are hauntingly real.
A must-visit historical place. The atmosphere is quite to make visitors deeply feel the War's consequences. It's very true to say that Hoa Lo prison is a place to visit in Hanoi.

Convenient version of history.. This is the infamous jail dubbed the Hanoi Hilton where American Pilots were kept and tortured during the Vietnam conflict all of which you will hardly find noted in the prisons exhibits. Interesting all the same but inform yourself before going so you can decide for yourself.

The Hanoi Hilton. but as others have pointed out, its of much greater importance given it symbolises the cruelty of the French occupation and explains much about a long struggle that preceded Ho Chi Minh. I thought it was well laid out and while it won't Wow! you it would be odd to be in the city and not visit here.

Good lesson on propaganda. The sight provided a great example for our kids regarding the influence of propaganda throughout the world. I have had the pleasure to listen to three US military prisoners held at the prison during the Vietnam war and the visual provided a great perspective.

The other side . As an American I have been exposed to the story of the war with mentions of the "Hanoi Hilton ". It was strange to see it. And to see the exploitation and oppression of the Vietnamese people during the French occupation put much of what I had heard into a different context. If you are an American, you should go. And keep an open mind.

An Interesting trip around the iconic "Hanoi Hilton". The Hoa Lo Prison (or Hanoi Hilton as the USA captured pilots from the Viet Nam war named it) is a interesting look around a the remaining part of the prison. (Much of the old exercise yard/Prisoner cells has been built on in the past 40 years) Self tour reading signs takes about an hour and a half, 3/4 looks at the Vietnamese oppression during French colonial days when it was a prison for political prisoners and any anti French colony activists. Interesting to see a real French guillotine. Remaining 1/4 is based on the prisons American hosts during the war with America. An enjoyable morning, having heard so much about this iconic prison prior to arriving.
Very moving. Terrible the conditions people had to endure, worth seeing to get the whole picture.Gets quite busy so if you want quiet time to reflect go early.

Hanoi "Hilton". Was nice to get some history lesson when visiting there.First feeling when entry to pot room was that this is not so good, but it got better. Place is not s big so couple hours fir visit is enough.

Interesting perspective. As other reviewers have noted, it's a little hard to get a real sense of what the prison was like from the way it is now presented, but there's a fair amount of information here, and getting Vietnamese perspective on it is pretty interesting. Whatever one thinks about the presentation of the war, there's certainly a lot of enthusiasm presented for today's normalized relations between the US and Vietnam. Not an unmissible destination, but also not a bad way to spend an hour or two.No need to buy the English guidebook at the ticket window -- it's not especially helpful or informative.

An interesting look at The Hanoi Hilton. An easy walk through some restored and original parts that were to become known as The Hanoi Hilton. Originally a French prison torture prison and death sentence prison for Vietnamese"political prisoners" and eventually American Soldiers is an easy brief tour. Interesting and doesn t take long at all if you are in the area.

Hanoi Hilton ~. A great part of the museum is devoted to the French occupation and their atrocities committed. The section on Americans detainees (ie., John McCain) shows a favorable treatment of the U.S. prisoners....Not sure this is entirely true...but, the Vietnamese had to spin it their way.

emotional tour. Hoa Lo Prison takes you back to the american prisoners in Vietnam. the tour is very emotional and touching. all the pictures and the statues there help you understand what happened there.the entry price is very cheap, so you dont have a excuse. must visit there.

Known as Hanoi Hilton. Hoa Lo Prison was originally used to detain political prisoners and formed part of a Northern network of ‘unjust and cruel prisons’ which included Cao Bang, Son La, Lai Chau and Hai Phong. it must have been desperately cramped and miserable conditions. i spend a lot of time here to learn about it and know more about vietnamese history.

Worth a visit. Cost about $1.50/person for entry. Not that well organized, but then again it's small enough that you can just meander around and basically check out everything. There's a lot of history here and it was fascinating to imagine it at different periods, whether that meant the French imprisoning the Vietnamese or the Vietnamese imprisoning American POWs. Not as emotionally 'dark' as Cambodia's torture museum or killing fields, for anyone who's ever been to those places. And that's probably a good thing.
somber place. As an American put prison in larger perspective. Spend some time. Don't rush through. John McCain is featured

Glad we stopped. My wife and I visited this historic prison in the afternoon - surprisingly not too many visitors were there and we were able to learn about this prison's interesting (and sad) history. We visited this prison before going to the Women's Museum, they are pretty close to each other and both are certainly worth your time! It's somber, but the museum is well-done.

"Hanoi Hilton" is part of history. The major part of this museum deals with its use as a Vietnamese political prison during the French colonial period. There is also an exhibit that presents their idyllic version of captivity of American pilots during our war there. No matter how rough it actually was for them, it was indeed a hotel compared to its former horrific use under the French. No visit to Hanoi would be complete without seeing this part of modern history.

a good place to fresh up the history. the 2 films of each about 20 min is good for the memory, if some have forgotten what happened.It is very moving to see the life of the American pilots during their relatively short stay.
Interesting war museum. Learned a lot when I came here. Items and statues are well presented. It is a must when you come to Hanoi. "Hoa Lo" or Hilton Maison

More than Senator John Mc. Prison built by French in 1896, to house "revolutionaries" (VietnamesePeople resisting French control). Most of the history of this prison surrounds the VietnameseResistance to French control, which is historically significant. Americans may only have a reference to this prison as the "Hanoi Hilton" popularized as the prison where downed US pilots were held from roughly 1966-1973, including John McCain. 2 rooms in the prison document Geneva Convention based treatment (although many memoirs by US pilots held there counter this position), so one should research further to put this point of view in context. Well worth a visit, if you are interested in the logistics of imperialism and resistance.

History's Stark Reminder. This is a must-see for anyone remotely interested in exploring aspects of French colonial rule and the Vietnamese revolutionary response to it. Read your books first to understand the relationship between the early anti-French independence movements, the Viet Minh and later the revolutionary forces which fought against the Japanese, the French, the Chinese, the Republic of Vietnam and later the Americans.Speaking of Americans, several of the US pilots captured in Vietnam since the early 1960s, were held at Maison Centrale aka Hoa Lo or "Hanoi Hilton", among other locations. There is an exhibition space that features videos, artifacts and photos of the American War and the POWs. History buffs, including those researching peace movements or contemporary US-VN relations will find the display fascinating. Not least because visitors can see first hand what many western Cold War scholars often refer to as "communist propaganda".People who have marched against the recent Iraq and Afghan wars may find some of the photos of the international anti-war demonstrations fascinating. The Hoa Lo Prison staff are friendly but few appear to engage visitors - and that's a shame. It would be terrific to have a resident Vietnamese historian or former Viet Minh revolutionary who could serve as museum docents.

Interesting. The history about the french and the revolutionaries seemed to be very detailed and interesting. It wasn't disparaging to the french. As an American, however, I found the last room that discusses American POWs to border on the verge of comical. I didn't realize American POWs had it so easy =P

A REAL INSIGHT INTO HISTORY. A visit here is a must for any visit to Hanoi. The conditions under which the French imprisoned people were horrific and inhumane. Within a short time here you can appreciate way the North Vietnamese hated the French and were unrelenting in there pursuit of independence and the elimination of any foreign influence or forces. However it should be remembered that the Vietnamese also used this prison for POWs and the history has been written by the victor. My wife and I found this a moving experience.

Interesting insight into colonial era. Interesting activity easily accessible by foot if staying in the Old Quarter. Kids entry free. Contrast between French and Vietnamese fascinating and a great way to teach the subtleties of propaganda!

Interesting and thought provoking.. The entrance fee is minimal and we had a guide book , giving details of the history of the prison.
When you look at the history of Vietnam the prison is and was part of it.
Well worth a visit.

Bit disappointing. What was there was interesting but not as good as I had hoped. Many old photos and a roomful of models of shackled prisoners. Could do with a re vamp as I guess many people would expect more

Vietnam's wartime history under one roof. This place showcases a detailed account on the history of Vietnam, especially during the war times. There are also some interesting exhibits on life in the prison, e.g. overview of the prison cells, life-sized exhibits of prisoners, as well as tools for punishment.

A somber haunting place. Although the Vietnam authorities have not wasted the opportunity for propaganda this is a graphic reminder of the brutality brought upon the Vietnamese during French colonial rule. It's a must visit!! My view the Vietnamese were diets abused by the French then the Americans and then and still the communists yet despite it all by betray no animosity
Interesting trip. Well presented history with much info in English very relevant to Vietnam war. Easy to find and walk to

Historic. Used to be biggest prison in the whole Indochina, now among the smallest. Lots of its area has been taken over in the name of development. Next to the prison is Somerset Resience. Entrance fee of 30000 VND Per person. Since there is not a big area, you will finish the tour within 30 mins unless you are planning to sit down and watch the video. Visiting this place reminds me of my visit at the prisons during the war. Worth a visit although I think the fees is a bit steep.

Chilling. A lot of propaganda about how the Vietnamese view the Americans during the Vietnam war. Apparently the American prisoners were treated like visitors although one video said they did have to learn jobs like regular Vietnamese people do and showed the prisoners sweeping the yard. The rest was about the atrocious way the French treated the Vietnamese rebels and how great the American prisoners were treated including getting gifts when they were released. It is a very sad place to visit but a must see. Only 1/3 of the original prison remains.
Not a must do. Some interesting exhibitions, but nothing really memorable. Went there for half an hour in late afternoon and did not require more time

Interesting!. Interesting to say the least, looking at the models of how life was in this prison, seeing pictures and how the prisoners dug holes to escape... Gave me the chills to see the ladies quarters those were lady spies that were caught when the French were ruling Vietnam. Go see this place!

Poignant visit for those of us who grew up during the Vietnam War. Sad, depressing, sobering, and still muted from what it really was at the time of its use. They emphasize how bad it was when the French imprisoned their patriots, and how well the Americans were treated when it was their turn to be the guards. It all has to be taken with a grain of salt. Still, I am enriched by having walked through a few of the spaces that remain as a museum.
Viet Nam 2015. walked past the door to the prison 3 times before i went in and it was very good it centered on the french period of history

Small and very average. We were very interested to see this museum and it's portrayal of Vietnam's past encounters with the French and the US, however it is confusing, propaganda filled and not very informative. The prison itself is also very small as not much remains of the original structure and artifacts. However, it is still very interesting to see how Vietnam presents the 'information' and to learn how the prison was used at different points in time.

Harrowing yet so memorable. although only a section of the original remains, much has been made of the remaining space. The exhibits may not be as interesting as the commentary which gives excellent insight into the working s of the prison and what the Vietnamese suffered at the hands of the French. Slightly disingenuous about their role in American POWs, but equally interesting and testament to their magnanimity

respect for the men who survived. Much of the original prison was destroyed in the mid-1990s but the "Maison Centrale" and some of the original French colonial walls remain within the museum.The exhibits focus on the prison during the French colonial period and include a guillotine room and the prison cells used for Vietnamese political prisoners.After seeing this prison, I have nothing but respect for the men who survived their ordeals in this place during the Vietnam War

What an experience.... Went as part of our tour with Avalon Waterways. What an experience, not only to see what American POWs went through, but also their own people. Gave me a whole different perspective on the history of the country, including the Vietnam War. Well worth the trip.

the other side of history. Interesting to learn about Vietnamese history through the events of this historic building. You certainly see history in a different light then western People are used to. Who is to say what Version is more biased/true? The history Charts most interesting, some of the displayed items were rather random, but they did have a guiliotine and John McKains flight suit! Would recommend having a look, not expensive. Would be better if they had more audio presentation.

Worth seeing if nearby. Having visited the war remnants museum in HCMC I felt mentally prepared for this museum, however it missed it's mark. There are some interesting displays and things I wasn't aware of, however again biased against the U.S. and propaganda of their "great" treatment.It is interesting and if not going elsewhere in Vietnam it is worth a visit, however it didn't present much information I hadn't seen elsewhere or in a particularly interesting light.

Go but with an Open mind. Again a very difficult place to visit when you are faced with the horrific realities of how one human being can treat another. It is worth the time to go but emotionally challenging. Be careful of the uneven floors and stairs. I would not recommend this for people with poor eyesight as many areas are very dark.
Historical. Excellent job sharing the turmoil of the French Colonization and how the people of Vietnam fought to stay independent. See the second on our heroes who were shot down and imprisioned.

Overshadowed by new building. What is remaining of the prison is fascinating, which even includes the original Guillotine used in the prison. However, roughly three-quarters of the prison has been swallowed up by capitalism (surrounding new development), very sad to see but this is Communism giving way to Capitalism.Hypocritical that throughout the prison, the Vietnamese explanations demonise the "French colonists" for building and using the prison for Vietnamese political prisoners, but later the prison is used by North Vietnam for POWs during the Vietnam War.Still worth a visit!
old prison and history. great memory about this prison ..you can see about histories during war in Vietnam ..Its nice to look but not nice to stay :)

Educational. A very interesting musuem that details the treatment of Vietnamese prisoners held by the French Colonialists. It details the horrific treatment they received and is quite thought provoking. The section detailing the caring treatment of US POW's is a bit of a stretch with pictures of Christmas Tree decorating and lunches.

A prison makes me obsessed. When I and my husband went there, we had lots of complex feeling. We realised that Vietnamese people had to faced up with many difficulties during the period of war.They had to suffer a lot of savage punishments from French colonialism. We also saw the way that Vietnamese treated well to American soldiers. After going to Hoa Lo Prison, we really had unforgettable memories

My favorite site in Hanoi. Easily my favorite site in hanoi. Interesting to learn the history of the building from rhe French occupation and the human suffering and perseverance there. After independence, American soldiers were kept here under much better circumstances. The section detailing this is also very interesting.Overall a must see site while visiting in Hanoi. It's a short walk from city center and best visited with out a guide.It is well set up with displays in English, however i recommend buying the guide book for an additional 20,000 VND.

Hoa Lo. brought us back to many years ago, when Hanoi was quite quiet, empty and very few people on the street. Too much things changed now. You guys must see this place, you will have a better understandings about Vietnam.

Learned a LOT of History. What a way to learn about the struggle for Vietnamese independence, and the horrific conditions that individuals who were incarcerated there had to endure at the hands of the French.Having been born and raised in the USA, I took great interest in seeing the exhibits related to the "Hanoi Hilton" era of Hoa Lo Prison during the Vietnam War, but the highlight for me was the early history of the prison, dating back to 1886.DEFINITELY worth a visit.

Sobering experience - very interesting. We visited the prison known during the Vietnam War as the "Hanoi Hilton". A lot of it is recreated, but you really get the feel for the horrible conditions and torture that took place here.It is good for everyone to see firsthand what happens during war. Maybe it could bring about Peace.

Somber place. It is pretty small but crowded museum. You can see the cells and some of the torture methods. There is a beautiful memorial worth visiting. You are seeing this museum through the eyes of the "other side" so it is a bit depressing but worth the visit.
Grim but important. Putting propaganda aside, it highlights some of the cultural battles leading to the Vietnam war. Worth visiting from an historical perspective. Small entrance fee.

A sobering look at French Colonialism. This, like the War Museum in Saigon, is an attraction for those who are willing to put your happy vacation aside and take some time to reflect on man's inhumanity to man! I highly recommend taking the time to reflect upon this tragic period of Vietnam's history.

Interesting and well-done exhibits. A very eye opening museum with well-done exhibits. I am not sure that I have ever before seen statues so effectively used to portray prisoners. Definitely worth the hour it takes to tour and the 15,000d cost.
Worth a Visit. I have now been twice to this attraction and really got a lot out of it both times. It is very informative albeit a little bias so read between the lines.

Hoa Lo Prison A.K.A. "Hanoi Hilton" as described by those who stayed there during their imprisonment, was a real eye ope. Hoa Lo Prison A.K.A. the "Hanoi Hilton" as described by those who stayed there during their imprisonment, and was a real eye opener into the way the French colonists treated their prisoners.My main interest in going there was to see the prison where John McCain and other U.S. prisoners spent time in prison during the Vietnam War. What I learned was a great deal more! These people were subjected to the worst conditions imaginable by the French colonists in the late 1800's including torture, beatings, inhumane conditions beyond belief, starvation and beheadings. On display is the actual guillotine used in these horrific punishments! They also had on display, relics, memorabilia, artifacts, letters from the prisoners, uniforms, and more to view. Many Vietnamese political opponents were placed here as well. This place is well worth the visit if you are interested in prisons, the Vietnam War and viewing the conditions these unfortunate people were placed in.  Be forewarned, you will be viewing what the POLITICAL PARTY in Vietnam wants you to see. There are films running in place, depicting war film footage of American troops bombing their country. Newspapers from all over the world showing different nationalities protesting our occupation in Vietnam, including our own people. It also states that our prisoners were treated fairly and shows pics of them playing basketball, playing chess and smiling, etc. Not really reality, from testimonials from our own prisoners who stayed there. Propaganda for sure. I guess I'd be pissed as well, if someone came in and bombed the hell out of my country!. The war is over, and most of the vietnamese have forgiven the past. Worth the visit for sure!

the "Hanoi Hilton". As a former sixties era war protester this was really something to see. Although it is a small slice of its earlier footprint, the exhibits are done very well and really bring the whole era into focus.

Hoa Lo prison. The prison was a sobering reminder of the horrible things that happened during the war. The displays and information given was informative and gave us insight into the perserverance of the vietnamese and how far they've come. Definitely recommended.
Badly organised with little information in English. A part from two rooms remaining from the old prison, there is not much of historic value and not much information in English.

Important Place If Interested In The War. This prison was built by the French in the late 1800's and most of the exhibits relate to that time frame. A smaller section is dedicated to the time it was used to hold Americans during the Vietnam War. As you might expect, the presentations paint a very different picture from the experiences the returning American prisoners underwent. Visiting here can be a moving experience if you knew someone held here as prisoner.

Interesting, informative. This prison is the famous "Hanoi Hilton". It was quite macabre as you would expect. There was a guillotine on display (actually in use historically!) and the cells where the death row prisoners were kept. There was also a short documentary about the US POWs who stayed there. I would recommend a visit if you have 2 or more days in Hanoi
A glimpse of the past. If you have a few hours to spare and very keen to indulge in the past involving torture of humanity, this well preserved but depressing site can be your cup of tea.

The atrocities never end!. I was glad that we had a chance to visit "Hanoi Hilton". I was naive about how the French treated the Vietnamese. I guess that you have to remember that whenever there is a colony situation it will never be in the nationals best interests to fight, for they will never win. The methods of torture never get any better. Can only hope that people keep this in mind and never repeat! It is worth the visit.

Go if you want to understand Vietnam. It's really impossible to understand Vietnam, the Vietnamese people and Hanoi, without knowing a bit about the history, and Hoa Lo Prison is a good place to learn about it. Here, you'll learn about the role that the French played in their lengthy occupation of Vietnam, and the conditions that led to the rebellion and eventual victory by the Vietnamese people. You'll also learn, from the Vietnamese perspective, about America's war in Vietnam. Prisons aren't cheerful places to visit, and Hoa Lo is no exception. However, the exhibits are informative (in Vietnamese, French and English) and it offers an insightful look into Vietnam's modern history. Allow at least a couple of hours to take it all in.

Glad we went. Husband, son and I visited and found it very interesting. To actually see how the prison looked and treated people was mind blowing. The French actually used a guillotine and that was something we didn't know. We were glad we went
A good spot to stop by, not a must see. Mostly Movie exhibits. Takes a good amount of time to see it all, but browsing through the prison gives a good glimpse into the past.
Worth the trip if you have a spare hour. We went mid afternoon so it was not too busy which was nice. Informative, easy to find your way through to each area. Not too depressing..
Interesting. I found this museum to being very interesting. I thought it was well done. I liked the statues which I thought gave us a very good view of what prison life was like.

Interesting spin on things. Interesting to see how they depict how the french treated the vietnamese people vs. how the americans were treated. Although it is a biased view it was interesting to see people that we now know today (senator Mccain) and how they fit into vietnamese history. Its a good 1.5hr stop in a city filled with so many historical places to see and learn.

Not as good as I thought it would be.. It was interesting to read the 'Vietnamese version' of history (like the great treatment of the prisoners .... John McCain was tortured regularly - so much that now he can not raise his arms above his chest level ....
Propaganda at it finest. As much as the exhibition in this museum are pretty good and well-maintained but I'd feel I only learn one-sided story from this place.
Unsettling, but worth a visit. I found it unsettling to visit this museum, but it is definitely worth a visit. If you are interested in history this is a must see!

Worth a visit. Best know as 'The Hanoi Hilton', however the U.S. prisoners during the Vietnam war is only a very all part of this prisons history. Vietnamese were subject to horrific conditions by the Frenxh. Check it out.

A place i never want to come in my real life. it is a prison, Hoa Lo prison seems to be very famous because it is located in center of Hanoi capital. it was used by French colonists for Vietnamese political prisoners. visiting here, i directly see the difficulties and miserableness of historical people as well as many types of torture applied by aggressors. i hate the war and really admire Vietnamese people.

History from a different perspective . We visited Hoa Lo Prison (the 'Hanoi Hilton" from the war between Vietnam and the U.S.)It was interesting to learn that the prison was built by the French in the late 19th Century. The empasis of the exhibits was the mistreatment of Vietnamese by the French, with particular focus on political prisoners. Many of the political prisoners turned out to be leaders in the Communist government which won freedom from the French in 1954.There is a section if the museum telling the story of the war with America and treatment of downed pilots housed in the prison. The first part of the exhibit provided insight as to the perspective of Vietnam. The second half portrayed the "excellent" treatment of the pilots by their captors. The exhibit portrayed life in the prison for those men as fun, relaxing and educational. That is a far different narrative than is presented by the men who suffered incarceration there.A visit to Hoa Lo Prison will help you appreciate the strong value the Vietnamese people place on self-rule.

Worth a look, the US POW section is hilarious . For less than a pound, (30,000D), it's worth a look but realise it's a place full of policial bias.The US POW section is ridiculous and makes it sound like the prisoners held captive there were in a spa & health farm rather than a prison.Interesting to see and learn something about the nasty events that took place but the obvious bias makes you wonder what of it is actually truth which is a shame.
interesting. very interesting place to see sure it has all the propaganda one would expect but interesting none the less lots of photos of the destruction the americans caused during the war
Not pretty.. I thought it was very real. I probably didn't like the reality, what the colonials did to the locals, all in the name of development.

Guillotine.. I found the exhibiting of a gullotine revolting and disturbing along with some "product", pictures alongside. Whilst the history needs remembering this was too much in my face.I would have preferred not to have visited Hoa Lo.

Gruesome. Important to see if you intend to travel and visit the killing field as it is referenced . Not particularly clear or sophisticated in its messages . It provides stark images of some of the horror of those so detained during Pol pots reign
Intersting. Well worth a look the walk back to the old quarter is a great inside view of the life in the city as a cross-section

A little lost for detailed information. . Not much information available or many cells to see. I thought I would be seeing a historic jail but instead it looks repossessed as a Museum and most cells are bordered up and used as offices or storage spaces for tools. The education was a little weak on detail. Still for 20 minutes of entertainment for $30,000 Dong (US$1.50) it was a time filler.

interesting museum worth a visit. Americans know this prison as the Hanoi Hilton, where John McCain was held.It's an interesting museum that is definitely worth visiting, and there's no need to bring or hire a guide. The exhibits are in English, and fairly self explanatory. Anyone with a reasonable knowledge of the Vietnam War will be able to put the exhibits in a proper context, recognizing that this is how the "other side" viewed things.While some of the exhibits would benefit from a little modern (interactive) technology, the entrance price was cheap, and the museum kept my interest for a good 45 minutes or so.
Very interesting. Very interesting and informative prison where US prisoners of war were held during the American War. Some old film footage and details of people who are still alive today.

Must see place. It locates 30 minutes by foot from Old Quarter. The entrance is around 2 US$. Initially, this prison used by French colonists in Vietnam mostly for political prisoners. Then it was widely used during Vietnam War.

Interseting but be prepared... ..for the propganda. Theres not much of the old Hanoi Hilton left either - most has been sold off to buid a hotel. Some interesting old prison artefacts including John McCains flying suit.

Good Picture about old poeple. Hoa Lo Prison in hanoi city will tell for you know have so much about vietnam hero. will bring for you have so much information vietnam historic. we are feel they were GREAT POEPLE! Because we understand if vietnam dont have some hero poeple, and vietnam dont have freedom.

disturbing and interesting. Its creepy to be in this place given its history. Somewhat disturbing but very interesting at the same time. Think twice before bringing younger children here - or be prepared to explain what the giant guillotine was used for. This is a nicely done museum and doesn't hold back so don't expect a sugar-coated experience.

Just a glimpse into Vietnam dark history. Located just on the outer of central Hanoi, 10-15 minute walk from the top of the Lake Kiem. Entry fee is 20,000 dong ($1 US) and it take you through the prison history. It starts with how the French used the prison to house communist during the indochina wars, and later how the Vietnamese used it for American pilots. It's interesting the contrast between how the French treated the Vietnamese prison badly, and how the Vietnamese treated the Americans well ( far from the truth). Never the less worth a look if you have time to look into the darker past of Vietnam. Leave around 90 minute to do the whole prison.

A real eye opener. Most people come to Hoa Lo prison to see it as the 'Hanoi Hilton' however the prison shows its use by the French colonialist and the brutality that colonialists can employ to keep their colonial power. Some may walk away from the prison seeing the displays as 'propaganda'. However, if you take the exhibits at the prison at face value it helps you to understand the Vietnamese war of independence against the French and the 'American'.

How cruel can you get ?. We went to the Hanoi Hilton to really see how the Americans were treated - looks as though they had far better treatment than the locals under the French regime - so on death row you have to be manacled hands and feels and do your business where you sit and no getting up and down - these were brave people and some people back in history have a lot of sorrier to say now. Women didn't fare much better than men there either. Got to see it to believe it.

Informative museum. This was surprisingly good, we learnt quite a bit here even though it was ironic to us that the Vietnamese were treating the captured US war pilots to well. It seemed almost like a propaganda. This was an interesting museum.

Good to kill time in Hanoi. This was interesting historical place to go in Hanoi if you have some spare time on your hands and don't want to go far from the city. It shows the atrocities that the French inflicted on the Vietnamese during French Colonial rule and it was quite brutal, but the explanation placards could do with more detail. In contrast the prison was also used to house captured Americans during the "American/Vietnam" War which seemed was depicted as a lot more nicer. I didn't go with a guide but there were others there that did and their guide was basically plugging the propaganda and there were some Americans there that also refuted as due to their knowledge of the treatment of Senator John McCain who was imprisoned there. Still interesting in a historical sense
Well worth a visit. If you want toknow more about the French colonial period this is a good place to visit. But the commentary on the US VietNam war appeared to be leaning towards propaganda.

Definitely not a "must see". The prison was built by the French and nicknamed " Hilton Hotel" by American prisoners during Vietnam war. Its a reminder of atrocities that happened there and how cruel human beings can be.

Very interesting but pure propaganda. History is written by the winner so understand the party line of how good the North Vietnamese were and how bad the United States was. As opposed to John Mccain's story, the treatment of US POWs is shown to be kind, almost fun-filled with plenty of food and good treatment. the US is the "imperialist." Get over any outrage and absorb another side of history. To accent the horrid nature of the West there is depiction in great detail of how horridly the French treated the Vietnamese during colonial days. That takes more study on this reviewers part but does. It does give perspective to the fierce resistance against the French and then the US.

Interesting insight into the past!. The Hoa Lo Prison is a fascinating insight into crime and punishment under French Colonial rule. The Hoa Lo Prison represents some of the cruelty and oppression faced by Vietnamese people under the French colonial leaders. The prison is both dark and oppressive and provides visitors an insight into the living conditions faced by prisoners. The prison includes a number of sculptures, photographs and artifacts to help tell the history of the prison. The rooms dedicated to Vietnamese imprisonment are both powerful and evocative and really make the French leaders seem both cruel and singled minded. In contrast, the two rooms that represent the American POWs are much brighter. The history is presented in a very Vietnamese light and all recounts are positive and almost lighthearted. If you forgot where you were visiting, you may believe the Americans were staying in a hotel dedicated to the Vietnamese culture and history. This representation is interesting in itself. It is a reminder that history is merely a recount of events that can be presented in very different ways. In addition, it is interesting to see the photographs and uniforms of the POW staying in the prison and to imagine how their experiences differ from the stories offered in the prison.
Hanoi Hilton. Small everything, cells, courtyard, wards, was expecting more, more photos would have been appreciated
Very informative. Good historical overview of conflict in Vietnam, and the function of the prison over time. Information is conveyed in French and English as well, as Vietnamese

Step into the past. This prison - only a part of the original complex - brings the past to life with compelling displays that include one of the two original French guillotines, and striking sculptures of the men's and women's quarters. Definitely worth a visit.

Grim, but well worth a visit. Good insight to colonial past of Hanoi, very good exhibitions and you can get a sense of conditions. The American prisoner section seems a bit to contrary to be entirely true but we'll worth a visit, I got the short written guide which was interesting read.
Must Go. This prison was really interesting and sad. A definite must do to understand more about Ho Chi Mihn and Vietnam's recent history.

Lots of atmosphere, little context. The remains of this facility are a fraction of the original building, but what remains provides a sufficient look at what went on inside. I spent a dollar for the official guidebook at the ticket booth, and it has a goodly share of facts, but little legitimate context--Vietnamese imprisoned here during French occupation are invariably revolutionary heroes, none of them thieves or murderers. POWs of the American War had a good old time, free to play basketball and visit on outside church during mass in civilian clothes. Etc. That said, definitely worth a visit.

This place has been made dull by propaganda. Their really isn't much worth visiting here for. The place's history has been completely whitewashed and, in the process, been destroyed.
Don't bother going in - the doorway is the most interesting part.
Good Photo ops. Ok to see some propaganda on the French colonialization and the American war. Makes you wonder how some of the prisoners ever survived.

Interesting and depressing place. The Hoa Lo Prison, or as Americans like to call it "The Hanoi Hilton" is definitely an interesting place. They've converted part of the original prison into a museum. There isn't much to see in terms of exhibits, but it's cool, and slightly depressing, to walk the old corridors and see the cells where many political prisoners have died. The story is on Vietnamese political prisoners during their struggle for liberation from the French. So if you are expecting to see more about the Vietnam war, you will be disappointed with two small rooms dedicated to the American POWs and their very nice stay in Hoa Lo. Overall an interesting place, but can definitely be skipped if you are limited on time.

90 mins well spent. Spent 90 mins here - someone said 10 mins so it shows what interests some and not others.It's well done with models, audio, artefacts and jail cells. Can be shocking The video is well worth it as it shows actual footage Went late afternoon and it was readonably quiet. Imagine it could be busy if tour groups r going through as each room is quite small.

You should go - but.... I would recommend touring Hoa Lo. Prepare,however, for a heavy dose of propaganda. 80% is about the great patriotic war against the French the final 20% is anti-American. It is not surprising just needs to be said.

Just a "prison". I don't understand why this place i a must see of the city, its just a prison. There have been and there will be prisons in every country all over the time... You will see all the atrocities committed in this place, and yes the french were heartless during the colonial period, but also the British, the Spaniards, the Dutch, the Germans, the Japanese... For the American area, was interesting to learn that McCain spent some time there.

Very interesting. I found the museum to be very interesting, even though most of the exhibits and explanations centered on the French incarceration of Vietnamese political prisoners, there is a small section that refers to the Hanoi Hilton, and whilst it is very politically one sided, it still provides a very good insight into what it must have been like

"Hanoi Hilton!". This infamous prison was first used by the French to hold political prisoners and later by the Vietnamese to hold the POW of Vietnam War. It is gruesome but historical. It is nice to hear stories from the Vietnamese perspective as opposed to the Western media!

Hanoi Hikton. This, now museum, has a long history beginning with the French building it. The exhibits are interesting and eye opening. We had heRd so much about the prison while the Vietnam war raged and it was good to have the opportunity to visit
Moving. The whole experience was moving to think people had to survive these conditions, well worth a visit. Very informative.

Hanoi Hilton. The brutality that the prisoners endured from what they call the "American" war was startling. Leg irons in the 20th century. Sad and depressing all around. It's important to remember this war. It's especially sad to think of the ordinance dropped on Laos in our CIA undeclared war. So sad all around.
A must see. The vietnam being such an important part of the world history, the prison visit provides just one such piece of it...

remind you to the American war time. been there as part of my vietnam tour on november of the 2014 - the place is nice and show a collection of things that american have been used against the VC. the music they play is just full of feel of panic. nice place at all
Must visit!. Its just so steeped in history that I consider it a must visit. Be prepared for some gruesome images. Preferably go without children.

Forces one to assess. As far as uplifting experiences go, this isn't one. As a museum, its pretty basic. The anti-colonialist, anti-imperialist anger is still clearly and understandably evident in the text of the toursit booklet and numerous signs. Considering the destruction caused to this country by so many over the 20th century, the surprise is that the rhetoric isn't even more angry and biased. The displays are static (not surprising in a prison) and rather unexciting. A guillotine used by the French is on display and grisly. The courtyard is eerily like that at Kilmainham in Dublin. I found this an interesting site in its very genuine feeling about the treatment of inmates who were, depending on the time and the viewer, revolutionaries or terrorists, liberators or invaders. This is an opportunity for westerners to assess the now fading recent past. Entry cost VND20,000 pp, booklet also VND20,000.
Prison. Actually only part of the old French prison remained. While one of the highlights due to immense suffering by Vietnamese people, the place itself is not that interesting.

Impressive Museum, absolutely worth the visit. This was well done. It clearly depicted the harsh conditions behind bars in this Vietnamese prison as well as a clear history on the uses for this facility over the years. It would be hard to leave this museum without feeling humility and gratitude for not ever spending time in Hoa Lo Prison. It is a great experience and well worth the visit.

Worth a stop if you have the time in Hanoi. Very interesting and educational. It's a self guided tour with descriptions in English that thoroughly explain the different areas of the prison and some of the history of Vietnam and Hanoi. It is definitely written from the Vietnam point of view and in the area describing the Vietnam (American) war, it's slanted to sound more like Vietnam was at war with the US, instead of with North and South.

what a joke. Not surprised at the propaganda and lack of honesty this prison represents, this country was just full of it. This place will make your stomach turn and really question what is wrong with us all as humans. The ticket ladies just glare at you (you know, how dare you go to their museum) and there is a security guard in the room about American POW. There were basically no other security guards on site, as if they know people are going to get pissed at the blatant lies in that section of the museum OR they just don't trust foreigners to not steal (incredibly ironic in this country)

A little underwhelming but worth a visit.. The "Hanoi Hilton" has been reduced from its original size but what is there is a good glimpse at the dual role the prison played from the early 20th century up through the Vietnam War. The unique perspective that you are presented with is worth noting, history is written by the victors. This was a symbol of colonial oppression used to hold an imperial aggressor's POWs.

A worthwhile attraction to visit. The prison gave us a clear picture of the terrible experiences that occurred in this prison. The information was extensive and helped us understand the terror this time.

Hanoi Hilton. Hoa Lo Prison was a great museum. Only part of the prison is left standing, but the presentations in side span it entire history. It was interesting to hear about the French construction for the Vietnamese and their treatment, . And also how American's were treated so well. We find historic museums with a bit of propoganda to be very interesting.

Worth it for the "propaganda"!. A fabulously restored building, with a very interesting history. My favourite part is the photo story of the American pilots who were kept there during the American-Vietnam war "being treated so well". Take what you read with a pinch of salt!

Different perspective. It is worth visiting the Prison to get a different perspective of how the local Vietnamese people viewed different aspects of the war. It is definitely worth taking the time to visit to get this insight.
Worth the visit!. Great place to pick up essential parts of vietnam's history ranging from the colonial days to the war against the Americans.

Another prison. Bad things happen in prison. The French built it as part of their colonization of Vietnam. Bad things happened and they are depicted here. After the French left, the North Vietnamese took it over. They gloss over what they did to those opposed to to Viet Minh as well as Americans. The victors always get to write their version of history. If you don't mind the dark side of the human condition, go ahead, but take the political dogma with a grain of salt.
Hanoi Hilton. Was interested of the historic. Love the architect as well. But should has some one to explain more detail

Hoa Lo Prison aka "Hanoi Hilton" by US POW's during Vietnam War.. Like most prison visits the Hoa Lo visits leaves you with an very eerie feeling, The somber music, claustrophobic cells, and in particular the recent use (1970's) of this as a prison brings home to you what prison life was like from colonial times right up to the Vietnam war. Conditions were very poor so some of the explanations can be distressing to people. During the Vietnam War, the prison complex was sarcastically nicknamed the "Hanoi Hilton" by the American POWs, in reference to the well-known Hilton Hotel chain probably why the Hilton Hotel in Hanoi goes by a different name!! This is my third time to visit hanoi but my first time here . Some of the areas in the Prison and some of the photographs are not suitable for small children. It's very reasonable to get in , children are free and if u don't have a guide with you buy the guide book at the ticket booth it's only 20000 dong ( about €.78 cent) .USA Senator John McCain was held here when he crashed in a lake in hanoi during the Vietnam war, his flight suit and parachute are on display. All the artefacts on display and any aurally have English and French translations . Worth the visit, behind the Somerset Grand Suites and close to old quarter so add it to your to do list for Hanoi.
Interesting history and perspective. Very interesting. Especially having a chance to understand then war. Of course it was from a Vietnam perspective.

I was Impressed.. John McCain was imprisoned here after his plane was shot down during the Vietnam War. The pilot prisoners lived quite a cushy life in the prison, while any other prisoners suffered and it was clearly evident that they suffered a lot. It is worth seeing the museum just to somehow fathom what it was like during war time.

A very sombre place. Heard about this before we left for Vietnam and made it something to do on our list and glad we did.
A little bit of propaganda came to into play but if you can put that behind you as we did, we found this to be an extremely interesting visit and very enlightening.
A must see visit. It was well worth going to this exhibition and prison site. The impact is quite strong and yet it left me wondering if it was not just a bit one-sided, albeit I can understand why.

An educational destination. As a local tour guide I always recommend my tourists visit this site. This is a great place in Hanoi where you can learn more about History of Vietnam especially French colonization period and Vietnam war. I don't need to say more about this prison since many people reviewed it with great comments. Just saying that this is my top recommendation to visit in HanoiTIP: If you don't have a tour guide to go with, buy the info book at the ticket desk, a great guide book with full of information about this prison (only 20.000vnd = 1$). Notice that this is not suitable for kids.

The Vietnam War famous Hanoi Hilton. A visit to Hanoi almost requires a visit to this very historical prison which had been in existence for many years prior to the Vietnam conflict. It was made famous by holding Senator John McCain for many months. There are areas which are interesting and some which are not, but overall, the experience, the photos and statues depicting the harsh treatment of the prisoners is well worth seeing. I give it four stars as it is not as well maintained as It should be and most of the original prison is not maintained at all.

Interesting piece of histoey. I enjoyed the visit I had as it was interesting to set foot in such a historic prison and for $1 usd it's a pretty good hour or two. There isn't that much to see but well worth a look, it's an easy walk from the lake.

Worthwhile visit. The prison is very interesting from an historical point of view - most if it is dedicated to the period of the French occupation (1874-1954). There is a small part dedicated to more recent history - the American-Vietnam war, when the U.S. prisoners, mainly shot-down air-men including John McCain (2008 Republican presidential nominee). You can see his air-suit. They nicknamed it the Hanoi-Hilton. Obviously the footage and commentary is from a Vietnamese view-point, so expect a bit of propaganda and keep an open mind. My young guide, in all innocence told me that the nickname Hanoi Hilton came from the fact that the prisoners were so well-treated. See the non-Vietnam viewpoint here - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hỏa_Lò_PrisonEntrance Fee: 20,000VND: Opening hours: 0800 - 1630hrs.
A must see!. I really enjoyed my visit here. Very informative.The layout is easy to follow and it's well worth reading all the information.
Another interesting place to visit in Hanoi. Two minutes by taxi from the Old Quarter. Will probably mean more to those who are old enough to remember the Vietnam War.

A good place to see some of the history of Ha Noi.. A very interesting place to see the Vietnamese view on the "American War". There is a lot of propaganda but mixed with some great original photos and documents. Worth a visit.

Worth a look. An interesting insight into Vietnamese history. Probably not for very little kids - a couple of disturbing photographs and a dark mood (enhanced by ominous music throughout the displays). Make sure you back up this visit with some unbiased information regarding the American POW's.

Well designed and very informative exhibition. While it's a shame that half of the old prison complex had to make place for another faceless shopping and apartment tower, the remaining part has been turned into an informative and well-designed exhibition about the long history of this prison. Why some history buffs might think that parts of it are a bit over-the-top, this museum has managed to keep my kids (3 and 7 years) captured and asking questions they wouldn't ask in just another boring museum.Also, I was surprised by the propaganda - or better, the lack of it. It's certainly not unbiased, but I usually expect much more propaganda, esp. in a socialist country...

Not just your ordinary prison. This one is quite special.
