It was built by the French in the late 1800s, and contains one of the two guillotines that they used to dispense "justice" to the Viet rebels during their occupation.Having seen a number of prisons around the world I wasn't expecting too much of this, but I was impressed by the detailed information plaques and the variety of exhibits. The exhibits relating to the US airmen who were held there seemed unduly sanitized, and it's not too difficult to find the US versions on the web, but they still gave an interesting account of the Viet view. It's not necessarily a must see, but does give a good impression of what life was like under the French occupation as well as under the US bombing raids. I thought the claims of having downed over 4,000 US aircraft was heavily exaggerated, but again, on checking the web, the US combat losses (inc accidents), were certainly over 3000....far more than I had thought.

Interesting Visit. The prison museum is larger than I expected and has a very long history, all of which is well detailed throughout different areas of the site. My favorite exhibit were the photos of Vietnam era POW’s at various times performing different activities during their captivity. It’s easy enough to see pretty much the entire site in a couple hours and worth a stop if you have even only a little time in Hanoi.

Historically interesting, especially the French element. Only a portion of the original structure remains and the part involving American pilots is misleading propaganda; but, the overall background of its use by the French against local insurgents was very interesting

Poignant to visit, good representation. Having read Faith of my Fathers by John McCain who was imprisoned there, I felt I had a true picture of what really went on here. There are pictures of the prisoners playing games and having read mcCains account I can see how the events as he had said were staged at appropriate times for the press. Never the less...the guillotine, the tables with shackles, the tiny dark cells, all give the visitor a feeling of isolation and suffering so many had to go through. There is a section of sewage drain that several escaped from on display and many pictures and McCain 's actual flight suit, helmet and parachute. One should not miss this.

Interesting visit.. One of the cheaper sites to see, with great information. You can hire a guide but they don't seem to say much more than what is already written on the walls. We learned a lot from our visit.
Gives you goosebumps. You get to learn about the place where the Vietnamese prisoners used to be locked at during the colonization period. Very informative.
Very Interesting. Located about 20 minutes walking from the Old Quarter. Really interesting to understand more about the history of the country.

Touching, sad, interesting and inspiring - all in one. WOW! To see the darkness of French colonial brutality (I understand being British because we also have a dark colonial history) and the resilience of the Viet spirit. It somehow makes you understand why they are willing to fight against all the odd to be ruled by their own, no matter what the politics. The inspiring section dedicated to the US POWs is amazing, to see the generosity of the Viet people and their strength, including the photos of the visit by John McCain who was a POW there. The guillotine used the French was a bit depressing and the photos that went with it, I was glad to spend some time at a Buddhist temple after the visit to the Prison. Really worth a look though, highly recommended.

Hilton Hanoi. This was one place that we all enjoyed visiting. The prison has been kept very much the same as it was when it was working. My children (twins 15 and 8 yrs) really understood what it must have felt like for prisoners to have to live here. There is also a vidoe footage and museum pieces with information which was interesting to read. Well worth a visit.
Experience this. A sobering visit to the prison - gives you an idea of what the people went thru and the conditions they were in . Quite well maintained
Scary place. Well reconstructed. Wouldn't like to stay the night. Well worth a visit. Liked the whole experience.

Important Piece of History. It won't take you very long to walk through the exhibits here, but it's worth taking the time. I would recommend picking up the companion book that they sell with the tickets for an extra 20,000 Dong. It provides a lot more information about the history of the prison, and some of the significant people who have been housed there.

Important part of history. Wanted to understand what the Vietnamese people had been through in terms of foreign occupation and of course understand how past armed conflicts are presented in various narratives. It was a good learning process.

A Harsh History Lesson. A historical site, which has plaques around the site so you can learn about the history of the prison, or, you can tag along behind a tour, if you get lucky. Built by the French to imprison the Vietnamese underground movement, we learn a lot about the cruelty of colonisation. The prison has implements of brutality including the guillotine, which we have only seen in photographs. The final stages of the tour leads to the imprisonment of American pilots from the Vietnam War. Interesting and disturbing place.

It's alright..... For what you pay to get in to the prison it's probably worth a look. Or if you're passing by then take a look. However, there's not a lot to see there and I'd only really recommend it if you really want to see it and learn more about that era. If not, I'd recommend the other museums around HANOI . There are lots which are a lot better

A little too much propaganda for my taste. I understand that Vietnam is a communist country, and each country has its own view of its past and its treatment of and by others.However, having it appear that the American pilots who were held there during the Vietnam war were treated with kid gloves and kindness affected my barf muscle. The history of the prison as a historical monument and the history of the French occupation was chilling.

Interesting visit. This is worth a visit while in Hanoi. You can get an idea of how things were for the Vietnamese under French colonial rule. USA prisoners called it the Hanoi Hilton. A very interesting museum

Great history . We went for a look around cost 25,000 dong each to get in very cheap interesting to see the history of the prisoners and how they lived there were a lot if Americans there some for a decent period of time worth a visit if you are interested in history and the way the French ran the prison.

Fascinating. Even though there's some propaganda involved, this site gives you some idea of vietnam's recent history of French occupation and the American War. Dare you not to feel goosebumps as you walk along Death Row...

a historic view of hanoi old and new. Visiting the Hoa Lo Prison was interesting. I went alone, and took the museum at my own pace (I like to read just about every placard). I did it in about an hour. It opened my eyes to some of the inhumanity that has plagued Viet Nam over the centuries. And I think my dad would love the part documenting the POWs. Fun for all ages. haha.

Interesting but sad place to visit. I'm glad that I went and saw this prison, despite the upset of seeing the exhibits that were in there. Really informative, and well set out exhibitions to put the vietnamese prison history into context in relation to the french, and other countries whom had attempted to take over Vietnam. There are places where it was a little interactive, and quite dark and spooky. I'm not a big fan osf actually seeing the seclusion facilities, but you can go into them, and you also get to see the sewer in which vietnamese escaped from this prison, when the french had colonised Viet Nam. I wouldn't call this place kid friendly, or disabled friendly. And it has a nice little garden you can sit in, to contemplate about the prisoners that died there. I would recommend in so far as to get a perspective on vietnamese history, but personally for me, prisons aren't my thing.
Old history. internally as part of Vietnamese history .that made me eat the same people of Vietnam during the war

Haunting History. An interesting history shown but was very one sided and shows a lot of the horrible things the Vietnamese were forced to go through . Thought the parts of the actual prison we would see would be bigger but it was just little bits and pieces . Haunting images throughout and the actual guillotine they used was still there . Well worth a look , but it is a pretty quick visit .

Must See. The must see Hanoi Hilton, but I was disappointed in the display. Yes, the French treated the Vietnamese terribly, but I wish there was more information about the American prisoners and an accurate portrait of their time there.

A Grim Place. A truly grim place, of which only a fraction remains, the majority of it having been demolished to make way for modern office developments.What remains is grim, but certainly heavily laced with Vietnamese communist propaganda - how badly the French treated the Vietnamese (true) and how well the Vietnamese treated the captured American airmen in the 'Hanoi Hilton' (?), including John McCain whose flying suit is on display.BEWARE: the flooring is very uneven; one of our party tripped down a step and badly fractured her ankle, necessitating surgery in a Hanoi hospital and an early flight home.
worthwhile destination. Again did this with our Hanoi Kids travel mates.They were very interested in our view of the American War.A real eye-opener for my young teens.A must see while in Hanoi.

A reminder of the atrocities Man can inflict on his own kind. Although small, this museum lets one get a feel for the miserable conditions the Vietnamese freedom fighters had to endure to overcome their French colonial masters. Worth the entry fees

Lock them up if you dont like their politics!. Mostly about the cruelty inflicted by the French toward Vietnamese political prisoners who were incarcerated during the colonial period and some interesting propaganda about how well the American GIs were looked after when they were kept there as prisoners of war. Worth visiting
Somber place. The atmosphere is eerie as the route goes from room to room, from cell to cell. It's amazing to see John McCain's flight suit.

A Must See if You Remember the Vietnam War. We went here to see "The Hanoi Hiton." Much of it has been taken down and what remains seems to mostly be devoted to showing how the French tortured the Vietnamese. The rooms were were most interested had no electricity that day so we missed most of the display of where the American pilots where held captive during the Vietnam War. The presentation of that is, of course, skewed to be sympathetic to the Vietnamese. So, for instance, they compliment themselves how how well those pilots were treated...grew their own vegetables, had chickens, celebrated Christmas, etc. None of that was true; their conditions were horrible. Still, it was an interesting visit.

Of historical Interest. Better known for its Vietnam War nickname "Hanoi Hilton", it actually is more of a documentation of the French Colonial period and how they treated the local population with only one section relating to the American POWs

Interesting point of views . The displays mostly focus on the French with some on the imprisonment of the airmen from the Vietnam war. Interesting movies which depict them being treated like very well celebrating Christmas and playing ball in the yard. As sanitized as the place was I could still feel a chill in the halls and cells. A must see

A must see place. The prison is a must see place in Hanoi.  It shows you the history of when the cruel French invaders built an and tortured the people and the Way they treated the Americans with kindness during the war, an amazing people.... !
A slice of history. There were enough descriptions written in English which enhanced my understanding. There was an audio option near the start of the self-guided tour.

Worthwhile. The prison is very interesting to wander through. A must to do when in Hanoi, learn about and understand the history of the City you are staying in. We had 5 kids aged between 10 yrs and 17 yrs with us, they all found the prison very informative and a great insight to the American / Vietnamese war.

Interesting visit. The location is convenient to the Old Quarter and the self-guided visit was interesting, even if steeped in propaganda. The most distressing part included the alleged treatment the French colonialists imposed upon prisoners. The comparative treatment of US POWs during the Vietnam war was quite a contrast.

A must see for perspective. Very good only because of the sadness of the reason for its existence. Though I'm a Viet Nam Vet, I wasn't inclined to visit here. But being so near, I decided to show my wife the world I came from. The history did not focus only on the American pilots imprisoned there but also the earlier incarcerations and executions during the French Colonial days and earlier thus making its history even more emotions.

Subjective. The prison is worth a visit, it is an important part of Vietnamese history and absolutely interesting. Enough information is provided, through text, images, sound and statues. Be prepared however for twisted truth/shameless subjectiveness. The prison was lastly used in the Vietnam war to keep American POW's. These are stated to be treated as well as Vietnam could provide. They go as far as to leave out the sarcasm in the "Hanoi Hilton"-nickname, therefor claiming the POW's enjoyed it there.Conclusion: visit the prison, but be prepared for some twisted truths.

Worth an hour if in Hanoi. The old prison is worth visiting given its interesting history. It is of course quite disturbing, witnessing how inmates were housed. The place is full of propaganda that is almost amusing - basically saying that POWs were treated humanely and well by the Vietnamese whilst the French brutalised the inmates when they were in charge. Its a good way to spend an hour and is easy walking distance from the central area.

Good reminder of the past. This prison's size has been much scaled down from its original size to give way to commercial interests (the bulk of the space of the prison is now occupied by the Somerset Hotel) but it does not diminish in any way the significance of its past. It is a very good reminder of how things were 'handled" in the past. I was very glad to see the original guillotine still preserved in all its gruesome glory hahaha. One can only imagine the horrors that took place in this prison. A very good place to visit if one has the time.

Maison Centrale "Hanoi Hilton". Interesting exhibits but, as expected, very anti-French and anti-American commentary. There are exhibits on both sides of the central entrance and there is commentary in English. However, there are apparently no guides and no tours provided.

Originally Used By the French for Vietnamese. This is a must see! This prison was originally used by the French against Vietnamese political prisoners complete with guillotine. I was also surprised to learn that Vietnamese women and children were confined here as well. Conditions were beyond horrific. However, photos show American prisoners playing sports with claims that they were treated very well. (Pretty doubtful). Only a portion of the original prison remains, but it is enough to get the idea!

Decent way to pass time. With a small insight into a bit of the political history in Vietnam it created a good way to kill an hour or so in Hanoi. The entrance was 20k (but 10k if you have anything that can remotely pass as a student card) which is affordable. It was extremely interesting to see how well the American POW were kept, especially in harsh comparison to the Vietnamese rebellions in previous years. Don't expect to be blown away but it was enjoyable!
Really interesting. Interesting site to visit the old prison and see original cells and torture equipment. The signs are really good and informative.

Hanoi Hilton - Popular Site for American Tourists. Our Vietnamese guide always referred to it as "the so-called Hanoi Hilton", since its real name is the Hoa Lo Prison. Only one wing of the ancient prison remains, the rest having been demolished in favor of more modern constructions. Most of the prison is dedicated to re-enactments of the time that the prison was run by the French. The solitary cells, leg chains, and dark rooms gave the full sense of the horrid treatment of prisoners. Only one room in the prison was dedicated to displays relating to the American pilots who were held there from 1964 to 1973. The displays included pictures of the prisoners (including John McCain) writing and reading letters, decorating a Christmas tree, playing ping pong, etc. It was much more of a propaganda display than a historically accurate museum. After returning from the trip, I read McCain's biography "Faith of Our Fathers" to understand how the prisoners were really treated.Nevertheless, an interesting and informative trip, particularly if you have the services of a professional guide.

Interesting. Quite an interesting place to visit, although disappointing that the exhibits focus almost entirely on the French era and there is almost nothing relating to the more recent history when Hoa Lo was used to hold American airmen.

More propaganda than history. Most of the old prison is gone - torn down to make room for new buildings. What remains has been heavily sanitized and designed to support the Government's theme.Most of prison depicts the story of how the Vietnamese were mistreated by the French. There are two rooms that address American prisoners - and neither of those rooms actually had anything to do with the American prisoners. The theme is that US B-52 bombers killed Vietnamese civilians and then were shot down by brave Vietnamese soldiers, captured, and treated like royalty in the prison. It's stomach-turning - surely, no visitor would actually believe such nonsense. It's hard to know how much of what they say abut how the French treated prisoners is true given the absurdest propaganda used to describe the treatment of the American prisoners. It is a little like listening to N Korea tell a story.Bottom line - it's worth seeing because of the history - and it only costs a dollar to enter - but you won't need very long there.
Must go . Interesting exhibits! Also the prison cells show the treatment of prisoners then.. Useful to visit n a must go when in Hanoi.
Confronting. Quite a confronting place reading about the harsh conditions the prisoners endured and the history of the prison. There's a fair amount to see and is an enjoyable attraction.

Very moving. This prison was very well laid out and plenty of information available. It was very moving to think that people were imprisoned there for years. It was particularly interesting to know that American pilots were kept there when they were shot down
Okay. I somehow expected more on the American POW's and their experience there. It focused mainly on the abuse of the French on the Vietnamese.

You should go. It's cheap to enter. Should take 90 minutes to get a good understanding. There's a lot of history here, so take your time.Easy to reach. Jump a rickshaw and they will drop you off. No need for them to wait, as you will be in there for a while and you can easily find a taxi or rickshaw when you leave.

Very good historic spot. It is an excellent place to learn more about USA-Vietnam war and french colonial times. To view most of the prison it takes about two hours. Most of the information is written in English which makes the tour more worthy. Do not forget to carefully choose between given information as Vietnamese tend to give a biased historic facts at times.

Wouldn't Want to Live Here. The prison has been reduced in size to make way for new development but it still manages to shock with its photographs and displays. Conditions were deplorable at best--cramped, close quarters overloaded with prisoners and the cellblocks used to convince people to talk were inhumane. The most interesting aspect of the tour is the message it portrays--that American pilots shot down during the war were in an 'almost-resort'. However, that message was drowned out by the displayed uniforms that were a lot smaller than you'd expect.

Learnt quite a lot, but information is very biased.. This was the first place we visited on arrival in Hanoi. Our hotel was within walking distance. It only cost a few USD to get in & was very interesting. The Vietnamese are brainwashed into thinking that during the war with the USA that all pilots were treated very well. Apart from it being biased towards the Vietnamese Hoa Lo prison gave us an insight towards the real lives of the prisoners.
French atrocities. A damning reminder of French atrocities in former times. I was quite shocked by this account of French treatment

Hoa Lo Prison. We found this after a walk around the lake and a vietnamese coffee and spent about 1 hour. Some of the information was a shock to me but it is really interesting to follow the history of war through the eyes of the vietnamese people.

We learnt history here. We learnt history here, the sad part of history of Vietnam during French colony as well as during second World War. We learnt the miserable life of all the political prisoners being locked up here. We witnessed the fall and rise of Vietnam in different angle. Everybody knows Ho Chi Minh, the father of independent of Vietnam, but nobody knows all the warriors that fought together with father Ho for the independent of the country. Most of them died unhumanly, few of them escaped. Here, we re- learnt the history of Vietnam, the sad and sore part of it.
Very impressive historical museum. Seldom a historical site has impressed me so much after seeing the displays. Very well done to show how the prisoner life was by that time

Not exactly uplifting, but..... So it would be rare to find a prison museum that is uplifting, but given its history Hoa Lo (The Hanoi Hilton) is a must see. The tour does lay the official history on a bit thick, but you do come away with an impression of just how unpleasant it was to be locked up here.

Mostly devoted to French Colonial Era. Most of the exhibits and displays describe the suffering of political prisoners during the French colonial era (1896-1954). Internationally, the site is more famous for hosting downed American pilots during 60s and 70s, there are only a few rooms devoted to showing stuff from this period, and the displays and photos only show them as being well-treated, celebrating Christmas and exercising together. Not having researched the topic recently, I still know there's probably another side to that story that is being glossed over. In general I found the museum informative and somewhat depressing, clearly horrible things happened here, but overall the displays felt more interested in presenting a war-era one-sided propagandistic view of events instead of an even-handed view of history (i.e. were the political prisoners imprisoned for killing people which would justify their sentences? what were their 'crimes'?).

Very interesting place, with biased propaganda.. The place itself was very interesting, more precisely it's a must-visit if you're interested in Vietnam war, especially if you're an American. It gave me a more in-deep sight into the Vietnam War. But for god's sake, the propaganda here was heavily biased, it embellished Vietnam side too much.

What is Hoa Lo??. The prison have 1 number in Hoa Lo street, in the heart of hanoi city. It was builts by French people from the war to keep prisoner, it should be the important place, most of French want to be come here to discovery

Worth a visit, but be optimistic. It was a good museum to visit for a few hours, although the grounds itself are very small compared to what they once were. The ground has been sold to build high rise hotels. The museum itself is good and gives you an idea of what life would have been like back then, although it is very bias.

Propaganda...Good that we know better. The museum itself was worth a visit. The atmosphere was depressing and realistic. But the biased presentation was really shocking and somehow absurd. The propaganda makes the visitors believe that the Vietnamese were very kind to the American prisoners during the US / Vietnam war. If you just research a bit in more independent media, you will find out that this is just a painted picture.
Scary!. Showed what conditions were like under the French who were quite brutal in their treatment of prisoners, sometimes using Madame Guillotine!

Worth a look. Having a keen interest in Vietnam history, I was excited to visit this infamous prison. What remains of it is interesting enough, with some interesting exhibits of preserved artifacts, such as the original guillotine used by the French. The models and artwork are also worth seeing. Be prepared for propaganda however. Personally I found that the museum oversells the suffering of the “patriotic revolutionaries” whom the French had imprisoned and severely downplays the same treatment given to the captured American airmen. The prison would have you believe that the pilots named it the “Hilton” in reference to luxury, rather than sarcastically in the midst of daily torture.

OK but not that interesting. Part of the prison that remains is now a museum to show where the French kept political prisoners and later used by the Vietnamese during the American/Vietnam war. The americans in our tour group seemed very interested in the part where some american pilots that were shot down during the war were kept. For us, didn't find it all that interesting or worth a visit. Some of the modern art and sculpture around the place is very cool though.

I'm a big fan of Senator John McCain. Had to check this place out.. As a big fan of Senator John McCain and a die hard republican in the USA, I had to check this place out. I consider it a "must stop" when in Hanoi. They did a great job in restoring this prison. You can walk around and get a true feeling of what it must have been like to be a prisoner there. Very powerful!! Great photographs. Take some time out of your day and check this place out. You won't regret it!!

Very affordable . I would say over half of the prison and is about what happened during the French colonial era. Any time a prison still has a guillotine that has been used within the last hundred years, it bound to be interesting. As far as the U.S. led war, the following quote sums it up. "We are taught that b52s are used to bomb targets of extremely large scale or military complexes of tens of square miles. Such targets do not exist in Vietnam. I understand that b52s bombing in densely populated areas is to kill more and generate pressure!" Very interesting perspective.

Worth a visit. Not all that much left of the original prison. You can see the areas housing both the male and female prisoners while creepy, macabre music plays overhead. Sense of eeriness. Sewer grates that prisoners sawed through in order to escape. Old guillotine. Lots of details about the continued resistance against both the French and Americans. Skip the second floor shrine area to the patriots who perished in the prison but do enjoy the exhibits on now-Senator John McCain as well as another prisoner who became the first US Ambassador to Vietnam.

Fabulous Place About History. Been There For 2 Times And Still Love To Visit Again. Felt A Bit Sad To See How The Prisoner Were Treated In The Past, However It Was Great To Know. Inside The Museum, They Provide Some Information What Was Happing During The War. Some Pictures Really Depressing To See. Somehow, This Must Be A MUST VISIT. I Would Recommend.

Really good job.. I think they've done a very good job in turning this building into a museum. There are plenty of interesting displays and the guide book is worth buying for the extra information.This certainly makes you think about the other side of the story when it comes to Vietnam and in particular relations with France and the US.

Left with a heavy feeling. A must see when in Hanoi. The rest of the reviews say it all...that you should take all the info in the museum with a pinch of salt. I agree totally. I left the museum with a heavy sadness because I could sense the cruelty, pain, torture and suffering hanging in the air...can't really describe it...gotta feel it for yourself
nothing special. really nothing to see.Condition of prisoners can't be really undarstood by looking in what is left in that museum. Few things reminded me an "hotel" than a prison.
A must visit in Hanoi. Powerful statements abound here. Not always a pleasant experience but definitely a very interesting one. An essential stop if you are interested in the history of the country

very interesting. After reading some of the reviews, I wasn't sure what to expect. As stated in many of the reviews, most of the original prison is now a luxury condo complex. However, they kept enough of the prison to get a good feel for it. They do a nice job showing you a realistic view of how the prisoners lived. It is a bit disturbing but it is history and real. There is a section about the US prisoners and how they were treated. I believe that they put a positive spin on their captivity but that is what they need to do. I suggest it. It isn't too far from Old Town, only a few blocks from the south end.

good to see. Extremely busy when we visited but still worth the visit A good history lesson on the French occupation and the American prisoners Very tastefully done but I think it lost a bit of the feeling because of this

lnteresting and scary!. Important part of Hanoi history. Sad to see how prisoners were kept and no doubt tortured. Heavy but really worthwhile. amazing relics from the Vietnam/ American war including the suit the John McCain was wearing when he was shot down over Hoan Kiem lake.
What an experience. It really gives the reality to what happened in the war. The information was second to none and the detail of the modelling, fantastic. A must visit when in Hanoi.

Interesting in how biased it is. I'm into history and enjoy checking out museums in new places and learning their history. It seemed a given to go to Hoa Lo Prison on a visit to Hanoi. While I thought they did a good job of turning what has been salvaged of Hoa Lo Prison into a museum--it's clean, easy to follow, the signs are written in English--the bias regarding when the prison was used to house American POWs during the Vietnam War/2nd Indochina War shown in the photos and written on the placards was uproariously laughable. And yet that's what ended up being the most appealing aspect of the museum to me. I have learned quite a bit about the Vietnam War over the years from the education system in the States and my desire to seek out more knowledge and info about it through history books, shows, documentaries, a specific Vietnam class in college, etc. And, being an American, I've always seen it from the American perspective, which I'm sure is biased, but the bias here was just comical. Apparently the French colonists who imprisoned the Vietnamese revolutionaries (prior to the Vietnam War) were extremely cruel, and brutally tortured the Vietnamese prisoners and sometimes executed them. However, when it was the Vietnamese's turn to imprison American pilots who had been shot down, they were as sweet as pie. I am in no way suggesting that the Vietnamese prisoners were not treated cruelly and horribly, as I've no doubt that's exactly the case, but then to say the Vietnamese held American POWs in the way they described and provided "evidence" of was just crazy. There are several photos showing the American POWs playing volleyball, basketball and checkers, eating a veritable Christmas day feast, and watching movies. They portray the American prisoners as having a downright jolly time, as if they chose to be there and were treated like distinguished guests in someone's home. Interesting that a number of them later wrote about the horrors they faced and the cruelty that was thrust upon them during the years they were kept there. The photos, words and videos shown in the museum would make someone who doesn't know a) anything from the American prisoners' side and b) the horrors that are part and parcel of both war and POW camps would surely think the Americans all but fought tooth and nail and begged and pleaded to not be released in 1973 and instead live forever in the most glorious living situation complete with all the fun and games one would want and the friendliest, kindest service around. Again, having never seen a war museum from "the other side" and so blatantly from the other side, I found it really interesting. I guess whoever is writing history can, well, write the history.
Very interesting. Very interesting to see. It is too bad they have removed most of it to put up a hotel. Some of the photos are very emotional to view.

Worth a visit, but take it with a grain of salt. This purpose-built prison was originally constructed in the late 1800's to house Vietnamese dissident political prisoners, and often torture them. Many of those dissidents went on to later become Vietnam political leaders after the french departed. Then it became important symbolically to the Vietnamese, and it was used was as an educational center for dissident indoctrination/training. During the war with America, it was used again as a prison, this time for shot-down and captured American pilots. The propaganda today at the prison is syruppy with many references to how well the Americans were treated during their captivity...something that clashes sharply with reports from those pilots released later. Nevertheless, this prison is an important piece of Vietnamese history and should be part of your visit to Hanoi.
It was ok. This prison was created by French people, and served a lot during the war. It was nice to read about history but the prison in itself is nothing but exceptional.

interesting. The museum is was worth a visit and its historical importance is clear. The exhibits have fairly short explanations. As mentioned in the previous reviews there is a bias with the descriptions.

Disappointing and slightly inaccurate. I love Vietnam and its people. In no way is my review a reflection on their culture. I guess I had a bias (much like the prison itself) when going to the Hoa Lo Prison. After endeavors at the Killing Fields and S-21 in Cambodia a few weeks ago, from the hype I was hearing, I was expecting something hard hitting. Not the case. Seeing an old prison is neat in itself, but a good portion of it was sold or blocked off. The museum plays up the torture elements a lot more than what it appears as. The prison was used by French colonialists and this prison really is just like any other French prison during that time period. It's really nothing new or shocking that their prisons were notoriously uncomfortable and well beyond humane standards. Read the novel Papillion. But the prison really tries to paint a picture about the evil Frenchman targeting Vietnamese people. I don't think anyone condones the French attempts in colonizing Vietnam and imprisoning those who wanted independence, but something about it felt exaggerated and heavy on the propaganda. Once you get deeper into the war between Vietnam and the US, it becomes more prevalent. As a US citizen, it was an interesting experience seeing the war from the other side. It was humbling and embarrassing at the same time, but an experience worth going through. But then you get to the propaganda elements. They portrayed themselves as humane captors when imprisoning US soldiers, and they show footage of soldiers playing volleyball and just having a great time. They ignore the fact that John McCain has become somewhat popular for being a tortured Vietnam war vet who ran from president. As well, it doesn't take much research to see how many accounts there are about US soldiers being beaten and tortured at this prison. It's a little inaccurate on how they present the situation; near humorous. Overall, it was interesting to see, be it a little underwhelming. I wish it was a little more historically accurate and not a painted picture.

Worth seeing. Although the prison itself has been demolished anxd replaced by high rise/s and shops, the remaining gatehouse museum provides an interesting view of the treatment of Vietnamese prisoners under the French v's US prisoners under the Vietnamese. The 'take' on the rationale for its nickname "Hanoi Hilton" is breathtaking!

Not what I thought.... The Vietnamese did a great job explaining the prison. I wasn't sure in the beginning if I wanted to go but managed to make our way there. I was surprised as the prison was used by the French for almost 100 years before Senator McCain checked in. Hopefully the prison will never be used again, but to inform others like me. Worth the trip to learn about Vietnamese history.

Hanoi Hilton by any other name. A good place to start any tour around Hanoi, the prison was not only the place that housed the American POWs during the 60's war, but also was the place that various political prisoners spent their wretched time. Spend time to reflect the futility of war.

disappointing. This side trip was a dud. The guide spoke only of the atrocities committed by the French vs Vietnamese "rebels" between WWII and 1954. Very little mention of what transpired there from '67 to '73. A small room with photos of US military personnel in obviously staged propaganda situations gives a "Hogan's Hero's" type of existence when in actuality life at the Hanoi Hilton was horrific for physically and mentally abused American POW's.
Worth visiting.. Well laid out and informative displays with a lot of interesting photos from the time it was a working prison. US Air Force prisoner display is enlightening.

Very Interesting. This is a very good attraction, although a little biased in its point of view. It has documented the history of the prison since french occupation and particularly in regards to the Vietnam-american war when it was known as the Hanoi Hilton by the American POW's. We stayed for about an hour and found it very interesting.
Chilling. Despite some of the heavy hand wording the remains of the prison do contain enough information to give an idea of what incarceration was like there under the French and then the Vietnamese.
Hao Lo Prison. This attraction would do better to reflect history in a more rounded review of realistic events. The attraction may not have represented the overall history from a balanced objective.

A little biased . We heard from a tour guide that they had to renovate when the USA prisoners where brought there to make it a 5 star resort. Where the audio tape stated they increased the size for more prisoners. At the end of the museum they should a bunch of pictures of the Americans receiving medical attention playing chess and laughing. Take it with a grain of salt.

A Chilling Reality. Very interesting, yet chilling realism of prison life during the war. Very good documentation and history of what life was like in prison. No lines or waits and the price was great.

Interesting but depressing. Would be interesting for someone who wants to get an understanding of the atrocities faced by Vietnamese during prison. Though it is sad and tragic tale, it gives only one side of story

Infamous "Hanoi Hilton". If you are from the U.S., you have to go here to see where the Viet Cong imprisoned American soldiers captured during the Vietnam War (or, as the Vietnamese say, "the American War"). Relatively little of the original prison remains, as much has been torn down and replaced by condos. But there are still a few rooms left that serve as a museum: one room that focuses on the French occupation and imprisonment of the Vietnamese; several rooms about the Vietnam war and their American "guests". There is a fair amount of propaganda that is quite informative. Go. See. Listen.
Interesting. We visited this museum for an hour or so. We enjoyed learning some more of the history of VIetnam. It was quite interesting and worth our visit.
very interesting. very interesting to see. We also had the hanoi kids taking us there, but i believe you can do that on your own

Important piece of Vietnamese & America history. Even though Maison Centrale is only a fraction of the size it once was - it's now surrounded by high-rise apartment buildings and hotels - it is worth a look to learn more about the atrocities committed by the French during colonial times and see where American POWs - most notably, Sen. John McCain - were held until 1973 (in very different conditions then those depicted by the displays!)

What's left is fascinating. Most of this prison has been lost to development. What is left is still worth visiting. Many countries have an ex prison where the ex colonial master carried out their vile acts. This one is different as you arrive with stories about what the victor did in this place. There is some enlightenment but please remember that history is written by the victors. One day Abu Ghraib may face similar presentational challenges.

Historically Worth the Visit.. I went to honor the men who were held captive there. A small portion was devoted to the American POWs, most covered the periods before that. A good portion of the prison no longer exists and much of what does is poorly lit. Historically it is worth a visit, but don't expect to see much. My take away is the Americans held there were heroes who endured much for their country.
Hanoi Hilton. This was a very interesting visit. I wouldn't say uplifting but so interesting and sad. If you are a history buff, I strongly recommend.
Not to be missed. The remaining structures offer a good overview of the history of the prison, from French colonial times to the US pilots held there until 1973.

Interesting to learn about the recent history. It was good to visit the prison to unerstand and relate to vietnams violent past but most of the prison has been destroyed for other development only leaving a small sliver for tourists to visit. I wouldnt visit this with hindsight.
Very interesting but certainly has some propoganda involved in the presentation. The cells and movies were very interesting. Stories relating to escapes and the history of the jail is facinating.

Nickname "Hanoi Hilton". For those interested to know Vietnamese wartime History, this Hoa Lo Prisonis a must see. The site itself is the actual prison cell use during French occupationin Vietnam and American pilots were captured and kept in prison at this location.Nicknamed sarcastically as Hanoi Hilton, prominent people like US Senator John McCainwas in this prison, evidence by photos showing him injured in battle.Much in depth of what's happening from WW1 to WW2.I find this visit to be very meaningful and certainly is major highlights of my tourin Vietnam, besides, SAPA and Halong Bay.
Learn. GIVES YOU A VEIW ON WHAT HAPPENED IN THE WAR WITH THE AMERICANS. Does send a message on how Vietnam dealt with the struggle and how thy beat mass bombing.

The ugiliness of war. The front entrance seems like a pretty museum but if you entered, it seems to bring the disgust, ugly, evil side of how the French army was during the war. It was a prison not just for criminals but also for vietnam politician. I just cannot understand the need for such inhumane acts. The french army were pretty creative at torturing. Just the incline floor cell already disgust me but thats not the worst. Female prisoners or politician were kept here too.Pay attention to the years they spend there, it all less than 4 years and they died. I can imagine how much suffering it was and maybe death seems more a better option. Do book a guide (Eg. HanoiKids) so you can understand more. However most pictures tells a thousand words so even going on your own is fine. Note: Not everyone treat POW with evil tortures. The vietnamese people were gracious towards the american pilots they captured as POW. (The prisoners had been treated more than humane. They had luxury!) War is ugly, but people dun have to be.

Of some interest. Although this is of some interest would not make it my first stop in Hanoi. Found that the propaganda was in overdrive especially with regards the Vietnamese views of the American Prisoners treatment. It was interesting but feel that that Museum of Relics in Ho Chi Ming City was a better afternoon spent although it does give you an idea of how harsh life must have been.

Strange feel. My partner was very interested in visiting the prison,I found it quite a sad place but nevertheless very interesting.I was very shocked at the conditions the woman prisoners were kept in and the fact that they were tortured.Reality check !

Impressive little museum.. We went there as part of a tour. Unfortunately most of the prison is gone. The museum is housed in a small part that is remaining. Despite being small, it does give a bit of the feeling of how it must have been there. We found it very interesting to visit. Parts of the story are explained by pictures and photographs and artefacts. Some prison cells are rebuild.A rather creepy part of the museum is the room with the guillotine used to behead many prisoners. The last part of the museum describes the times of the American "guests". This part of the story is obviously a bit coloured but interesting to see.For us, unfortunately, it was on the end of our tour and we did not have to much time. I could have spend between 1 and 2 hours to visit this small but very interesting museum. In my opinion a "must see" in Hanoi.

Chilling. I am prone to emotion but can usually keep it in check, the conditions in the prison were horrendous but what really affected me was the cells for those awaiting execution. That whole area of the prison just felt so cold despite it being a warm day. I also found it interesting that an American Airman who had been held prisoner there returned to Vietnam as a US ambassador. A thought provoking and interesting place.

Nice little museum worth a look!. This is just a small section of the prison saved from the original - huge high rise apt building takes up the old prison.Refurbished to mainly show the harshness of the French Penal System in Hanoi. Small section on US prisons from the Vietnam/American War, but that's mostly propaganda claiming that the Vietnamese treated them so well!It was worth a visit for a view at history....especially interesting for Americans since John McCain slept here.

Seeing it from the other side. I really enjoyed this place, and seeing many aspects of Vietnamese history from their perspective, especially in regard to the early French influence and also the "American War".It can be a bit confronting, especially with a guillotine still set up, and the almost endless amount of propoganda about the American Imperialists, you just need to filter some of this stuff as it is very one sided an obviously incorrect. A quick look at photo's of the America POW's obviously "enjoying" themselves playing chess and putting up Xmas decorations and receiving first class medical care puts things into perspective. But once you start filtering and accept it for what it is , this is a fascinating place. There is no doubt that the Vietnamese suffered much during the Vietnam war years, and I don't want to get into a who was right who was wrong debate, but this in my opinion is a must see place. Give yourself a couple of hours, and see how much humans can hurt each other.

Only real part of Vietnam War in Hanoi!. This is a simple small snapshot of the war with America from the Vietnamese perspective. It was a real prison and what ransoms is authentic. It is a small piece of history.

A little curiosity, a little propaganda. From a historical perspective it was interesting. While I have no doubt there were many awful acts perpetrated upon the people who were kept there by the french, I have a seriously hard time believing that the American pilots were treated as well as you are led to believe during that part of the tour. We would recommend it.

Visit This Only If You Want To Be Reminded The Pain. The pain of war, especially the Vietnam War, is not a reminder that a lot of us want to remember and by visiting this site, you will be reminded of those painful years of war. Although much of this former prison dealt with the war against the French, there are enough displays that also dealt with the U.S. war against Vietnam. I would say visit this site if you did not live through the Vietnam war years like a lot of us did...

Good Summary. The prison gave a good summary of hiw the vietnamese people suffered under the French and the Americans. As this was an actual prison, it brings you to the times of prisoners' sufferings and the kind of hardships they had to face. It was very insightful and a good place to learn more about Vietnam's darkest years.
worth a look. definitely worth a visit. Some of the details are a bit more descriptive rather than explanatory but this place gives a great insight into the history of Vietnam.
Austere!. We only had a short time there so difficult to give a full account. What we saw was portrayed displayed well enough. It was bigger than we anticipated.

NOT your average Museum (or Jail). As an Australian, I had to bite my tongue over some of the propaganda that are right through the jail. However it is an insight into what the Vietnamese had to go through whilst the French were in power. It does highlight man's inhumanity to man in many cases and I totally felt more than compassion for the Vietnamese people. However the Government seems to have managed to change certain things around, according to the way they wish to be seen, not as it necessarily was!Other than this I would say, visit the jail and make your own minds up about it. It is rather confronting at times, but, sometimes things like this need to be!
A potent reminder of darker times. This is an extraordinary place: potent reminder of man's inhumanity to man and the sheer stupidity of war. It's impossible not to be moved.

Very Historic and Emotional Place to visit!. As an American, this prison is where our Senator John McCain was imprisoned for five years. It is a very graphic tourist attraction now and actually, does not tell the real story. There is a lot of propaganda in the photos and details! Still worth the visit!
Worth visiting, good experience. Easy to reach, cheap entrance, and quite interesting historical place, I'd go again definetly if I had to re do my trip.

Bit too much propaganda. Interesting enough to see, but way too much information on how the French ill treated the ' revolutionary patriotic' Vietnamese 'freedom fighters' during the Indochina period, and not enough unbiased information on how the American servicemen imprisoned were treated.According to this account, the USA service men were probably better off in this prison than with their families in the USA. Great food, football in the court yard, decorating christmas trees and having a generally having a great time. I think not. Time this display was updated to show how they were really treated in prison.Wiki states this:'The Hanoi Hilton was one site used by the North Vietnamese Army to house, torture and interrogate captured servicemen, mostly American pilots shot down during bombing raids. Although North Vietnam was a signatory of the Third Geneva Convention of 1949, which demanded "decent and humane treatment" of prisoners of war, severe torture methods were employed, such as rope bindings, irons, beatings, and prolonged solitary confinement. The aim of the torture was usually not acquiring military information; rather, it was to break the will of the prisoners, both individually and as a group. The goal of the North Vietnamese was to get written or recorded statements from the prisoners that criticized U.S. conduct of the war and praised how the North Vietnamese treated them. Such POW statements would be viewed as a propaganda victory in the battle to sway world and U.S. domestic opinion against the U.S. war effort. In the end, North Vietnamese torture was sufficiently brutal and prolonged that virtually every American POW so subjected made a statement of some kind at some time. (As one later wrote of finally being forced to make an anti-American statement: "I had learned what we all learned over there: Every man has his breaking point. I had reached mine.") Realizing this, the Americans' aim became to absorb as much torture as they could before giving in; one later described the internal code the POWs developed and instructed new arrivals on as: "Take physical torture until you are right at the edge of losing your ability to be rational. At that point, lie, do, or say whatever you must do to survive. But you first must take physical torture."'This is the message that should be shown at this prison - not the current propaganda, which is a disgrace to the memory of the USA POW's who served time here.
educational for adults. overall history with facts with no preaching on past injustices. Good garden area to chill in. A single dollar per person to get in.

Disappointing. The infamous HANOI HILTON as US prisoners of War once called it now only consists of one mere building block, all others had to make room for high rises and hotels. A piece of history lost...

Ticked the box, but not much to see.. Ticked the box, but not much to see.
You are likely to see on a tour of old Hanoi, but spend little time there.

Interesting History. We visited the Prison with a uni student from Hanoi Kids, and he was very knowledgeable about the history. It was interesting to see the different exhibits and imagine what the prisoners went through. We all enjoyed - though that's not the right word! - the section about the torture devices and guillotine. The section on the American POWs seemed to be a lot of propaganda, saying how well treated they were, over and over... Not quite in line with what I've read! It's a pity that less than half of the Prison remains, though I guess it's understandable when space is at a premium. Not sure I'd like to stay in the hotel overlooking the Prison! Definitely worth a visit.

Must See in Hanoi. Especially for Americans, this is a must see sight, but it's interesting, too, to see the pre-Vietnam War history of the museum and how many Vietnamese citizens were imprisoned and tortured here.

If you're into history, then this place would be cool. If you're a history buff then you'll likely find this place more interesting than others. It wasn't as informative as I thought it would be. Cool to find out that John McCain was kept there during the 'American War' as they call it. Would still recommend visiting

Good but beware one sided propaganda. Really well set out museum, very interesting visit, and well worth dropping out of the bustle of Hanoi for a peaceful walk through the old cells. However, the museum doesn't try to provide a balanced account of life in the prison, and should be taken as such - American PoWs playing pool and having a lovely time doesn't tall well with PoW accounts (see here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_life_and_military_career_of_John_McCain for a taster).All that said, I've no doubt that horrors were committed on prisoners of all nationalities here, during the colonial period and after, and you'll get a sober feel for their experience by coming.

Sobering Propaganda. As an avid ex-anti-Vietnam war agitator, the Hanoi Hilton was a bittersweet experience. Although it had been a prison, renowned for the tortures perpetrated on its inhabitants, for many years under French rule, I think most people remember it as the home for jailed captured US and allied fliers. Through exhibits-a guillotine, for example, and use of actual prison facilities, cruelty, hardship, and deprivation are depicted in the prison's early days. Journals, photos, and artwork show causes of death, notorious inmates, and the change in prison life through time. Much space is devoted to demonstrating how well allied airmen were treated during their stay. They are shown eating vast quantities of food, decorating Christmas trees, and exchanging gifts with prison officials. Official documents proclaim that US airmen were treated better than the Vietnamese people in general. Not so subtly, a common theme-one with which many of us, to this day, agree- permeates that section of the museum: allied airmen should never have been there in the first place.

Depressing but Interesting. The Hanoi Hilton means something to so many people who remember the "Second Vietnamese War" that it has to a "must" on your itinerary. It's a depressing but interesting visit especially to get a feel for the propaganda that pervades this country with a one party system. The Vietnamese were treated very harshly by the French when they were imprisoned here but the American airmen were very "lucky" to be imprisoned here because they were treated so well. The victor earns the right to write the history so I guess this is all to be expected. Despite the propaganda this is worth your time.
Chilling. Whilst the story of the " Hanoi Hilton" is known to many people the story of the prison when under French occupation of Indochina is harrowing. Seeing Madame Guillotine was especially so!
interesting. very interesting museum. they show a lot about the French and how they treated the Vietnamese in prison. you will not find a lot of information about the American war unfortunately.

Not too touristy to enjoy. This was a gem. Informative and do interesting but there were very few other tourists which is a massive plus for me as so many attractions are swamped these days, it's hard to enjoy. Very cheap entry too and a good one for if it rains as mostly indoors.

Educational but beware of propaganda. I've been to auchwitz, Alcatraz so although I had seen worse and different prisons, Hoa Lo is still one well worth visiting. Entrance fee was just vnd20,000 - less than usd$1. There was a contrast of how badly the Vietnamese prisoners were treated by the French and how well the American prisoners were treated by the Vietnamese. There's probably some truth in it but I felt they didn't really show the full picture. The prison is well signed and apart from the memorial hall for Vietnamese soldiers everything was well explained in English.

A must. It is always difficulty to give a balanced display of a place which has been used, and misused by so many different regimes. Hanoi Hilton, as called by the Americans, is overshadowed by a huge commercial complex, giving it an interesting contrast. The French guillotine needs no further explanation. Not a place to enjoy, but to give you insight into human suffering.

Interesting exhibition with cheap entry fare!. Do take time and visit this place when in Hanoi. Understand the history behind this prison and its significance to Vietnam. Within walking distance from the old quarters and other attractions, definitely worth your dollar.

It's Really about the French. It was eye-opening to see the prison first-hand. You can go into a solitary-confinement room and get a feel for the POW experience there. Completely built by the French to use against Vietnamese political prisoners, there are small death row cells, awful torture devices (including an oil barrel with a gasoline can sitting next to it), and something that looked like a bamboo torture rack. Seeing the guillotine there, knowing that it had actually been operational, was ghastly. (The lighting in the room casts an eery shadow onto the ceiling.) In several places, carefully molded statues depicted the Vietnamese prisoners. In one room, they lay together on a wooden platform with their feet locked in place by shackles. Only two rooms were about the "American War." John McCain's flight suit is hanging in a glass case in one of them. Looped videos in both rooms play scenes from the better (latter) days of the war, when the guards let the prisoners raise chickens for food, play games, and celebrate holidays. The display can tempt you to disbelieve the stories of torture reported by returning veterans that actually reflect conditions in the early years of the war. There is a serene memorial upstairs to hundreds of Vietnamese political prisoners killed by the French between 1908 and 1954. For each one, the full name (if known), year of death, place of origin, and year of death are listed on large golden tablets.

Difficult to find. This museum is quite a bit smaller than the original prison which makes it difficult to find if you are expecting a large building. Once you get there it is well laid out if a little one sided in terms of treatment of Vietnamese and by Vietnamese.

Not bad but.... ... the figurines are a bit unnecessary. Otherwise it's an interesting place to visit and catch a glimpse of the many faces of Vietnamese cruel history. Another interesting aspect are the propaganda photos of american prisoners having a great time :)

The Hanoi Hilton rediscovered!. You must visit. We know of this infamous prison because they kept the Americans there during the Vietnam war. So I was keen to visit. Im glad I did because I found out that it was a prison used by the french to keep the vietnamese rebels. It was also interesting to find out that prior to being a prison there was a village there that was totally eradicated. The cells are dark and with a heavy energy. The way they've done it is kind of classic/ironic.....you have to go through the whole prison and somehow are forced to learn about all the other history associated with this prison..and right at the end, tucked away in a corner a sort of 'by the way we kept the americans here but they were very happy here'. Total propaganda. But nevertheless a visit worth doing.
Brilliant. Excellent place to visit, highly recommended, doesn't take long to walk around, but very interesting, walking distance to most hotels!

Strange and fascinating place. I'd obviously heard about the 'Hanoi Hilton' through some research but mostly Vietnam War movies and wanted to see the place where Rambo had been tortured. It's not as intimidating now as I'm sure it once was but still interesting to walk around and see some of the pictures and read some of the stories. It's not a huge place either, I spent roughly an hour in there but for US$1 it was well worth it. The information may be a little skewed in that it details how Vietnamese prisoners were subjected to horrible torture when prisoners of the French but American prisoners appear to have been treated very well in comparison. Not sure I believe that but it's Vietnam's history and they have the right to tell it their way. All in all, if you're in Hanoi, you've got to see it even if it's just to say you have been.
Interesting visit. We really enjoyed our visit to the prison and seeing the terrible conditions prisioners had to endure. It was a very interesting trip and well worth doing.

The Hilton . Worth a visit when in the city, interesting and has good information inside. Keeps you busy for a couple of hours. Has a decent shop here where you can buy gifts. I brought some old money off a local outside the prison. In my opinion it's worth the small fee paid for entrance.
Gives you chill!. this place did give me chill. not in a spooky way. if you know the history then you understand it. Impressive building.

please visit!. Worth a trip to go see. Very informative, a little bias tho towards Americans and Vietnamese. Does not portray the full report on certain victims from america. A little early to walk around especially seeing the used guillotine and learning of the torture weapons that were used. I enjoyed the museum and found the upstairs memorial room very moving.

Interesting! . This small museum is dedicated to the prisoners of the former prison from the 1940s till 1970s. It shows some gruesome objects such as a guillotine and shackles from the French colonial period, but also provides some nice photos of the lives of the POWs during the Vietnam-American war. Although the museum is not in the best state (some stairs seemed to date back to the fifties as well..), it's not expensive so worth a visit.

Make the time to see this. While the entire prison is no longer there, they did leave enought of it to get a good understanding of the prison. This place is creepy and eary but none the less I still found it worth while. The cost of 20,000 was great value for money.
worth a visit. very sad, but so interesting to see and learn about this part of Vietnams history. tickets are cheap and easy to find with a map
Its ok. One can visit this place to imagine what it would have been once upon a time. Its maintained fine can be visited if one is nearby though I wont consider it to be a must see place.

Hanoi Hilton prison. This is a gruesome part of Vietnamese history, with torture and harsh imprisonment, perpetuated first by French colonists, and then by Vietnam Cong incarceration of Downed American pilots. The Americans gave Hoa Lo prison the name Hanoi Hilton, where Senator John McCain was a prisoner. The prison was mostly demolished, then restored in part as a tourist attraction.

Hoa Lo Prison. This is a must when you visit Hanoi! Modern history comes over you! The prison was built by the French colonialists in the 1890s and use as a prison for political prisoners, for Vietnamese people fighting for their freedom from France. Later in the late 1960s to the mid 70s it was used as a prison for American war prisoners. This prison is a part of our history!

Nightmare. Its a place you have to go its nickname was The Hanoi Hilton it shows how cruel people can be to each other ,i gave the title nightmare because i did not seep well that night .this was resent history yet they have forgiven and moved on with their lives.

Thought provoking. Its only part of the original 'Hanoi Hilton' but strange to visit a prison that held American pilots during the Vietnam (American) war.
A lot of propaganda still evident which is interesting in its own right.
Cheap to get get in and worth an hours visit,

Another excuse to sell the Vietnam War. A disproportionate amount of space dedicated to the Vietnam War, given the prison has significant French history. Exhibits were reasonably good but very dark so hard to see or photograph.

Very interesting museum. The place is very interesting and most of the displays are well made and give a good insight on the history of the place.
The only down side is that there aren't as many explanations in english as you would like but definitely worthwile

The 'Hanoi Hilton'. What is still left of the prison is split into two parts.First, it shows how brutal the French treated the Vietnamese prisoners and the second part is how well the Vietnamese treated the US prisoners.Some say the US prisoners were not treated well, I asked our local guide about this and she said the people working there understood that the prisoners were acting under instruction from their government so had no major issues with them.Regardless of whose version of events is true, this place gives a great insight into the Vietnamese version of events.It always amazes me how people can be so evil towards other people but I'd say this is a must visit museum.The rememberence garden at the end is a nice touch and drives home how recent some of these events were.

Must visit. This is an absolute must visit. Beautifully maintained and the stories definitely evoke a sense of the hardship that the Vietnamese have experienced and makes one appreciate their current success so much more.
One for the History Buffs. The Hanoi Hilton... used to keep USAF pilots during the war, very interesting place to go and see, its not a "fun place" its a place to acknowledge and remember.

A prison with so much history. We were aware of the 'Hanoi Hilton' label but the prison has so much more history. The Vietnamese truly suffered at the hands of the French. Some of the sign posting around the prison could be better, but we think we saw it all. There is even a guillotine on show. So much more than a few American prisoners of war. There is a level of propaganda on show but it's easy to spot.
Hoa Lo Prison. A great place to visit and read about the history and events. The cells are as they were and the surrounds move your emotions re the events that took place.

A Sobering Reminder of Vietnam's Suffering During the War. It wasn't on our to-do-list but we're glad we visited. Seeing the artefacts, photographs, videos and reenactment of the conditions then was a humble reminder never to take the peace we enjoy for granted. Being in the very same room as the prisoners then was quite eerie but it allowed you to have a sense of how they must have suffered during those tough times.

American travelers should visit. We visited several State run museums throughout Vietnam and all presented the exact same theme. You need to push yourself past that and realize all the horrible history this place represents. Walk through slowly, look at the pictures but realize the words you read on the walls and plaques were carefully scripted politically.

Get ready for the propaganda. the Hoa La prison...also more commonly known as the "Hanoi Hilton" has been partially saved as a museum ( a large skyscraper office building occupies most of the former grounds). It is interesting in its recounting of of the brutality that the French used on the local rebels. In the early portion of the 20th century...and it does show a lot of valid history on the Vietnam war...but the video of how well the prisoners were treated while there is quite misleading....especially when you read multiple account of the American flyers who were held there for years.

Hoa Lo Prison, a reminder of Vietnam's horrific past. The building itself is very interesting but its the displays that sent a shiver up my spine. There are room with shackles showing how the prisoners were made to lay on inclined platforms in the head down position with their feet shackled. How they were also made to live laying side by side on long benches. And when punishment was dealt is was harsh and cruel. This is a reminder of Vietnam's horrific past and not for the faint-hearted.

A clear reminder of the reality of war, torture and propaganda. It was one of the spots I really wanted to see. Having met both Ambassador Pete Peterson and Senator John McCain, prisoners at the Hanoi Hilton, it was very moving to reflect on their public service and the location that housed them for many years as prisoners. Senator McCain's military uniform is on display here. Most of the museum highlights French imperialism and the brutality of this place. Obviously a lot of propaganda about how well the Amercian prisoners were cared for.versues how the French treated prisoners. Now I have seen it. But i would not go back.

AKA "The Hanoi Hilton". Hoa Lo Prison was built by the French, housed Vietnamese political prisoners and during the US-Vietnam was used to house American POW's, including former presidential candidate John McCain. The American's referred to Hao Lo as the "Hanoi Hilton."Much of what is on exhibit deals with the French and how they mis-treated the Vietnamese prisoners. One of the guillotines is on exhibit. There is an area devoted to the American POW's. John McCain's flight suit, parachute and other effects are on exhibit as are the personal effects of other POWs.Hao Lo is worth the visit, especially if you are of the generation that remembers the US involvement in Vietnam

French prison, before bei g for americab war prisoner.. A place to see and feel the atricities of the French colonisation, and afterwards, during the fight for freedom, a prison for American pilotes. Very interesting to see, if you are interetsetd in histrory, and. arious peectives on it.

Interesting and a bit quirky. It's well worth a visit to the prison if you're in HaNoi, although it's not blow your socks off brilliant.The museum was quirky as it gave quite a different view to the majority of museums, edging possibly towards propaganda (although I do not claim to have a great knowledge of the occupation of Vietnam). The gist if the museum was that, during French imperialism the prison was run as a brutal regime, with routine torture and dehumanisation of the inmates, the vast majority who were all political prisoners fighting for Vietnamese freedom.This is contrasted with the US prisoners held there, who (it is said/indicated) were treated fantastically and it seemed to be more like a holiday camp than a prison.

Interesting perspective on French and US. The prison was originally used for the French to imprison VN dissidents. Based on the images and stories, the prisoners were treated abominably. On the other hand, when the VN used it for American prisoners, it was a hotel - beer, pool, cards - "no one wanted to escape." Truly points out no black and white in war.
Interesting. This was a very interesting place. Our guide was excellent and told us of the history and the treatment the prisoners received. Quite horrifying! Well preserved and a must see

Prison visit. Well worth visiting the prison (better than visiting the two museums that we visited). Some good displays showing what life was like for those unfortunate prisoners at the Hanoi Hilton. Only a small admission price. We walked from the old quarter. This place was where John McCain and other US airmen were interned.

A must see in Hanoi - Hao Lo Prison. Hao Lo Prison or the Hanoi Hilton as it is often referred to by Westerners is a must see. It is not as big as it once was but it provides a great insight to the conditions endured. The sculptures, pictures and stories throughout the site give you a chill but it gives you a sense of what POW endured despite a very one sided portrayal.
A little upsetting. To go here was upsetting to see true conditions of how people were treated but very interesting and a must do. Attraction cost $1 US dollar....20000 Dong...

Must see in Hanoi. Interesting point of views from the Vietnamese people on the French and American conflict. It shows American POW during the vietnam war having a decent life inside the prison. This is a different view from what 'western' society portrays. What was disturbing to me was the exhibit showing the B-52 bombing on civilian populations in Hanoi during the Vietnam war.
Awesome history. Awesome place to visit if youre into history! not a very big attraction but theres some seriously hectic looking sculptures and cells.
Must see. Nice to learn some history of this prison it's a good place to visit very cheap and within walking distant of lake
Informative. Very well done museum with great historical information. However, it is what you would expect from a prison......a bit dark and depressing. Well worth the visit, but with eyes wide open.

hoa lo prison. We walked from our hotel in hang bong street and found this place fairly easily with a map. Cheap entrance fee and a lot of information for your money. If you are interested in the history of this prison then there is lots to read and look at.

A bleak disturbing place. Well, prisons are never cheerful, to start off with! This is an establishment you visit to be told how the french tortured its prisoners. Leg shackles for every prisoner - both legs for most, one leg if you were ill. And you were hosed down with salt water after torture... probably to kill germs, as well as to rub salt to your wounds further. But I've seen bleaker prisons... Alcatraz, Nazi concentration camps, etc...

Very Moving. This museum is well done as there are many interpretive signs, all translated into English. The museum is presented of course from the Vietnamese perspective. That is, the French built the prison and were very, very cruel to the Vietnamese soldiers who were there. Stories of horrendous torture and conditions. At the end of the (unguided) tour there are two rooms that mention the American prisoners. The basic theme of those? The prison conditions were so favorable the Americans called it a Hilton (!!!!). In one room the flight uniform of Senator John McCain was on display as he turned out to be the most 'famous resident'. As an American AND a college student in 1967-1971, I knew the stories I had heard. I wore a POW bracelet for years...... So it was an emotional place to visit. If you have time for only one museum in Hanoi, visit here. The Ho Chi Minh museum is a waste of time in comparison.

Worth a visit, but manequins in cells were creepy. Actual prison during the war. Very informative, tells you the history of the war and how the prisoners were kept here in the compound. Well written and displays were good (apart from the real-looking manquins placed in the cells that crept me out). At the edge of Old Quarters, i spent about 40mins there. Worth a visit especially for the mueum lovers.
Worth a short visit. Only a small portion of the prison still remains however it is full of historical information. Definitely worth a visit.

There is room for improvement. When I visit a prison I like to be told a story and taken on a journey back to really feel & understand what these people went through. I felt like Hoa Lo was more a series of display cabinets with artifacts and excerpts, during our 1hr visit it didn't impact me like I had hoped.

Average considering its history. A guided tour is what we had hoped for but there were no signs showing if or where we could get one. The exibitions are bases around a small area of the prison and are limited in terms of information. The museum has a sense of, they decided to open it for the sake of opening it, then filled it with whatever items they could get their hands on. There are propaganda videos near the end of the self guided route showing smiling american prisoners eating big dinners and taught a good way of living during tough economic times for the vietnamese when im sure a lot of people were close to starving. These are a good watch and would recommend people visit the museum just to see these videos. You will get a good laugh out of it.

A must for History lovers. For me, this was an incredible place to learn about the history of Vietnam, because I didn't know about a lof of things I learned here. So much pain inflicted to these people in the name of Imperialism... Cheap, and totally worth the value. I've made the visit along with a free guide from Hanoi Kids, volunteer organisation that operates in this city, and I totally recommend it! But if you can't get a guide, if you decide to go by yourself you will not be disappointed!

Interesting but could have been better. When I visit a prison I like to be told a story and taken on a journey back to really feel & understand what these people went through. I felt like Hoa Lo was more a series of display cabinets with artifacts and excerpts, during our 1hr visit it didn't impact me like I had hoped.
Worth a visit. Interesting visit. Listened to a few USA war veterans who were also visiting and got their prospective.

Must see historical prison. I did not read about this prison before I went to visit so I did not realize how many freedom fighters died, executed by French during the colonial period. Vietnam suffered so much last few hundred years by French and Americans but still they bounced right back and opened their arms for trade to better themselves.
