Interesting. This is an interesting place. The history of the prison is part of the fabric of both Vietnamese and American history. The undeniable suffering is evident in the depictions of prison life and the conditions the prisoners faced. However, the room depicting the American Pilots time there is just a room of propaganda. There are numerous statements regarding the humane treatment of the prisoners according to the Geneva Convention, how the pilots eventually turned to support the Vietnamese cause, and belittling them saying they had to be taught skills even children should know. Go, absorbe the history, but be ready for the propaganda.
A Sad History. Well worth a visit. Vietnam has had a sad history but it's great to get the background on this beautiful country.

A place of suffering.. A sad story well told - this is well worth a visit. A very cheap entrance fee provides access to a wealth of information - from early French barbarity through to the incarceration of American air crew. Well worth a few hours of your time now, not a place you would have wished to have stayed in in the past.

Interesting. Although it looks like there is a certain propagandistic attempt by the authorities to show the guests that the American pilots were treated well (especially if you compare it to the treatment that the Vietnamies prisoners got at the time from the French colonialists.
Humbling experience. A must see! I would recommend to read about the history of the prison before going. There is a lot of information given while there. It is a truly humbling experience.

Definitely worth a visit.. Definitely worth a visit. But- be advised- the information is presented from the Vietnamese perspective, so if you can't handle a little bias then this probably isn't the best place for you.

Of interest to selected groups. An average museum of prison history but with limited interest to anyone other than Vietnamese and, perhaps, Americans. The propaganda was pretty blatant – wretched conditions for the poor Vietnamese by the French Vs the loving care and attention the Americans got when imprisoned there. Add to that a new display aimed to bolstering Vietnam’s case against China over some disputed islands. Pity to pay for it really.

Average museum. I really wanted to see this museum as a remnant of the war. It was small, since most of the original prison is no longer there. They do try to recreate scenes of how if used to be when the prisoners were keep there during the war and they do a good job of posting historical events of the time. I am glad I saw it, but it's not very big and won't take much of your time so if you are interested you might as well give it a go. Why not?

Worth a visit it's all history.. I found this a little confronting and every visitor will have a different view. Lots of information, pictures and the cell layouts really give you insight. We need to keep this kind of history around to tell remind the world - peace is better than war.

Misleading. I was extremely disappointed with this museum, it didn't give much of a feel of how the conditions really used to be, not in comparison with the other war museums I visited in Vietnam. Almost all of the annotations were in Vietnamese, and there were rooms after rooms dedicated to individual people without information about these people! I wished I hadn't bothered. Save the history museums for Ho Cho Minh City!

An experience of its own. It is definitely worth a visit, they explain in very fine and sometimes gory detail the French occupation in Vietnam, the construction of the prison and its uses. They then move on to explain its use during the American-Vietnam war. The models and layouts of the cells are very well done and much has been kept as it was. Although altogether is very bias.

Humbling experience. We visited this site and learned so much about the history of the Vietnamese people during the French occupation of the country (1858-1954). The unspeakable atrocities committed during that time are well documented for visitors.There is also a section of the remaining prison that has elements from the days when downed US flyers were imprisoned there during the Vietnam War. None of the actual cells where the US flyers were held remain. That part of the prison was removed when a massive new hotel was built on part of the ground occupied by the prison.Visiting the Hoa Lo Prison is quite worthwhile for the education and eye opening experience it provides.

a solemn place...during the French occupation. a casual visit turned into a very solemn visit. It shows how the during the French occupation of Vietnam the methods used by the French to punish any Vietnamese dissenters whether they were men or women. A dark disturbing place but a MUST visit for any historians and anyone that opposed the Vietnam War during the 1960's. The feelings evoked are how cruel human beings are to other human beings. Go do something uplifting after your visit here.

Too small. We expected Hoa Lo Prison to be much bigger, but most of the original prison is now gone. The displays themselves were informative and if you're interested in history then it's worth a visit. It won't take much time to see it all though. There are some original artifacts on display that make it more atmospheric and helped us to understand better how prisoners were treated during the wars in Vietnam.

A frightening reminder. A well organised museum showing the history of the area from its village beginnings to its development by the French, to its use to house American Bomber pilots. The use of the guilloitine during the French occupation is particularly chilling.

Propaganda With a Slice of History. A visit to Hanoi, or at least a first visit, needs to include this joint. This is not the whole prison, but just a corner of what was a larger complex. Thematically it is divided into three concepts: one outlining what a ghastly place this was for the brave freedom fighters for fifty years leading up to the expulsion of the French, next outlining what a wonderful place this was for the American aviators who stayed as honored guests during the American war, and finally a shrine to all the heroes of the revolution. Frankly, I cannot speak to the third concept, but the first two are interesting for their use of and manipulation of real history to fit the regime's rhetoric.The French, true to the traditions of European colonialism, were certainly brutal when it came to insurrections. I would not want to be incarcerated in the the conditions I saw there. In all the photos of the guard corps, only the very top echelon were European.I would also not want to have been incarcerated there as an American, no matter how humane it was. Or wasn't. Information boards tell of how men who had only ever been taught to rain destruction were given new, valuable skills like cutting hair, or possibly sweeping courtyards, and how they left with gifts and goodwill.There is no nuance in the story told by the prison, so it comes off as a one-dimensional narration, or more simply, propaganda. It is still worth seeing to appreciate what all the prisoners went through in as much it can be interpreted. The prison could be much more effective if the narrative were changed a bit, without becoming apologetic to the French or the Americans.

Could be so much more...but you get the picture. Almost half of the prison is closed and what is left gives you a taste and feel of what life was like, but that's about it. In saying that, the stuff they have on display is well worth looking at and well presented.

Little Gem. It was pouring with rain, we had a free afternoon, we looked at our site map and saw Hanoi Prison... thought why not?It was a very interesting place to visit. It's only small nowadays but the history is incredible. The models make it that much more atmospheric. The prisoners must have really truly suffered. Would reccommend to others!

Unique and full of history . The Hoa Lo prison is located in the French Quarters. By foot it is about 15 - 20 mins walk from the Old Quarters. This museum is full of prison history during the french colonization in vietnam. Some of the artifacts and prison cells on display are the actual prison rooms and tools used during that era. The museum is not very large as some portion of the older prison land has been converted to modern commercial building. Worth a visit if you are into history or just to learn more about the prison life during the olden days. Admission charge of VND 20, 000/person applies.

Confronting if a little poorly arranged. This place is a testament to Vietnamese strength of character and resilience under extreme conditions. The reference to white prisoners (propaganda) during the American war is unfortunately believed by locals, but is worth seeing and shouldn't diminish the horrors and cramping endured by Vietnamese inmates for decades prior.

Good for one time, not more. I went there on my walking tour from Hoan Kiem lake. A very interesting combination: an old prison-now-museum and high modern hotel-office building next to it. Nice exposition inside, but it took me only 30 min on a slow paste to finish it. One-time attraction.
Graphic museum. Be prepared to faced with the reality of this 'hell hole' of a prison but glad I went. The prison was well set out and very explanatory .
Well worth a visit.. Very impressive and attractive us. Easy to walk from other attractions. And these Hoa Lo Prison have reflected the past tragedies and the victories that Vietnam has tasted.
Historic. Well worth the time to read the experiences suffered by those striving for their ultimate emd. A histiric part of Hanoi

Histories with conflicts and prisoners. Between French and Vietnam, and between US and Vietnam. You can learn briefly with actual visit of the prison. Easy to walk from other attractions. Reasonable admission fee.
Interesting. Despite the fact much of the old prison is now gone, the visit is interesting if a somewhat 'different ' view of the prisoners and wars that have occured in vietnam. Worth a look
Interesting. Very interesting place well set up with information, a must to see. Video information as well. Would not have liked to be there back when it was open and being used!
Hanoi Hilton. Very interesting and well signed in English. An experience not to be missed. A step in the past to conditions experienced by American POW's and political prisoners.
Poor!. Nothing to see and very small of cause it was located in the central of Hanoi and close to Hoan Kiem lake

Interesting experience. We went here early in the day when it was quiet. The woman at the ticket booth tried to short change me, I'm not sure if it was deliberate or not but just check your change.Inside is an interesting account of the history of the prison going back through French colonial times. They have an impressive guillotine.There is a small area dedicated to the prison use during the American War.Exhibits are multilingual and give a good leverl of detail.
Surprisingly informative. We spent a good few Horst touring the Hanoi Hilton As it was named by the shot down US pilots It was worth the $1 entrance

A glimpse of the past. Vietnam has been through a series of wars and been colonized by the West as most of the South East Asian countries were. And these Hoa Lo Prison have reflected the past tragedies and the victories that Vietnam has tasted. The same walls have withstood the terrors and cries of the prisoners which was once held captives. Inside the Museum are the displays of the artifacts that were used by the prisoners of the past both the Vietnamese prisoners from French colonization and the American pilots during the Vietnam War against Americans. The old prison cells are displayed with some mannequin figures that will leave you to imagine on what was it like 100years ago. The Museum is just a part of what it was back then. But a big part of the Old structure was already turned into commercial buildings. If you are a historical and cultural explorer I would recommend this museum.

Average museum. I really wanted to see this museum as a remnant of the war. It was small, since most of the original prison is no longer there. They do try to recreate scenes of how if used to be when the prisoners were keep there during the war and they do a good job of posting historical events of the time. I am glad I saw it, but it's not very big and won't take much of your time so if you are interested you might as well give it a go. Why not?

Hanoi Hilton. We spent 12 Knights in Hanoi and one of the places we visited was Hoa Lo Prison commonly known as the Hanoi Hilton a must see for anyone visiting Hanoi and interested in the history of Vienam very interesting and well worth a visit

a place with many stories and histories!. La Maison Centrale or Hoa lo prison is so interesting place where i discover the stories about torture and politicals prisonners!i saw "the cachot" and "the guillotaine" and many stories!terrible places!horribles cellules!i listen also to the audio guide which describe the architecture in front of the maket of "la Maison Centrale"i advise you to visit it to know how much the vietnamian people suffred!

a piece of history.... not to be missed. I came with a group: they breezed through exhibits in less than an hour. to see everything, you'll need about 1 1/2 - 2 hours to see, read, watch everything concerning the history of the prison as used by the French and Vietnamese. well documented displays describe prison life from Vietnam standpoint, so come with an open mind...

Propaganda.. Photos and claims about US POWs show happy prisoners playing chess and volleyball, accepting fish and eggs for food, and gardening and raising chickens. The museum claims that the prison was called the Hanoi Hilton because the POWs thought it was as good as a hotel. This abject propaganda is in stark contrast to the stories of torture detailed in When Hell Was in Session by Jeremiah Denton, In Love And War by James Bond Stockdale, and other accounts by John McCain and others.
hanoi Hilton delivers the goods. This is a must see for anyone interested in the history of Vietnam, including the French regime. It is very interesting and well worth the visit.

Back into the prison... At first, I thought I would have skipped this place as I couldn't find it on the first day. However, I decided to go back and search a second time and I found it this time, entrance is in between 2 main roads, not that hard to find actually. Entrance fee is minimal at VND20K (USD1). The place is well maintained and there was background "music" to allow us to have a feel of how creepy the prison could be had we been locked up there instead. So it was not only adding to our knowledge by reading all the signboards with English translation but also adding to our experience. It is definitely worth a visit on a hot afternoon after walking under the hot sun in the streets for quite some time. This is a place for you to take a break and to revisit the history of Vietnam.

Provides a good perspective for Americans. This prison housed many Americans during the Vietnam-American war. However, the history goes back much further since it originally was a French prison for Vietnamese prisoners. We enjoyed seeing the facility to appreciate the conditions for prisoners during all phases of the prison's history. It was particularly interesting to see the exhibits regarding the American prisoners. Clearly, the Vietnamese government perspective of the circumstances is much different than that of our prisoners. Much of the prison has been removed and new condos have been built on the grounds. However, enough of it remains to enlighten those that wish to visit.
Interesting history. Worth a visit for an hour or two, it's not expensive and is very informative. Lots of it is in English too which was a pleasant surprise.

Incredibly sad. Tour of the prison is self guided, with exhibits detailing the brutality inflicted on the Vietnamese people by foreign powers with their own agendas. Gave context to the revolution and a peek at the history of its people. Informally arranged and little about the consequences of US prisoners of war once held in the same prison. One becomes keenly aware of the evil of all wars...

A must see - Hanoi Hilton. It's that name and association with US pilot POWs that has me interested in Hoa Lo. But the reality is that the history of the prison goes much further back and has a dreadful history of persecution of the Vietnamese people. The French as colonialists tried to break the independence movement and resorted to torture and killing within Hoa Lo to achieve that aim. Definitely worth a visit.

It was fine for $1. It was an alright museum to see. The general message was the French and Americans did bad things (which I wouldn't doubt) but the captures American soldiers were treated very well in this prison (which I don't fully believe).

Two hours well spent.. Slightly difficult to find as all the maps we had put it in an ever so slightly different place. An interesting insight to Vietnam's history and the life of the prison although as an English speaker not many of the pieces were translated which slightly limited some of the rooms.

Worth a look.. The prison is an interesting look at Vietnam history, including french occupation and the Vietnam war (or the American war as it is known by the locals). It only costs 20,000 Dong (about US$1) and is an easy walk for the lake area. We only spent around 45mins there because we were on a time limit, however we would have spent about another 30mins given the chance. I reckon 1 to1.5 hours would be plenty to check it out fully.

Interesting musem, but the setup was a little hard to follow. This is the prison otherwise known as the Hanoi Hilton, where John McCain was held. The prison is easy to get to and easy to access. Although there are directional signs, it is somewhat hard to discern exactly what the layout of the prison was when it was in use, what rooms were used for what purposes, and most importantly to us, where the American prisoners ate, slept, and spent their time. Most of the displays are well documented, some were only in Vietnamese, which we can't read. You do get to see a glimpse of what life was life for prisoners, and there are some displays with photos, mementos, and clothes and utensils used by the prisoners and prison employees of the time. This is definitely worth an hour or two of your time, especially if you were alive in the Vietnam war era.

Important part of Hanoi History. Hoa Lo Prison (otherwise known as the Hanoi Hilton) was built by the French to detain Vietnamese revolutionaries and then, during the Vietnam war was used to hold captured US pilots after they had been shot down.The prison now is a tourist location and is inexpensive, well organised and offers an interesting visit for an hour if you have any interest in this aspect of Vietnamese history.

War Remnants Museum in HCMC & Quoc Prison much better. What was most interesting about this museum, I thought, was the destruction in 1896 by French colonists of a ceramics village to build a prison. Examples of the ancient pottery tradition were on display. A lot of different angles are explored in the museum, although most of the physical prison is gone. We were especially interested to see where McCain was held but only his pilot uniform was on display. A few examples of the torture devices used by the French on Vietnamese anti-colonists. Very sad portrayal of the political prisoners' plight from that time. The slant on the US POWs made it look like they were having fun at a Hilton (playing basketball, chess, smiling). Yeah, we'll, John McCain and Ernie Brace's accounts, it actually was not a heck of a lot of fun. Excellent National Geographic video on the web provides an excellent insight into what it was like for American POWs. The death row cells were pretty scary for our 11 year-old. Inadvisable place for young children.If you want to get a deeper understanding of the prisoners' plight in the 1960s and 70s in Vietnam, visit the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City. It's excellent but loads of horrible images and torture devices so probably want to skip with young children. Phu Quoc Prison, in the island of that name off the southern tip of Vietnam is really good. Also scary for young children. Very graphic.

Pretty good. I thought that this museum was really quite interesting - but more so for looking at the building itself rather than the displays on show. The building itself is mostly not there any more - but what is left for the museum is still quite sizeable. Just looking at the walls and doors is very interesting (the creaking of the door window hinges is spine chilling).The english signage is commendable and much better than many other museums in Hanoi. However it is clear when looking around that there is quite clearly a pro Vietnamese bias going on. I don't know much about the Vietnam war compared to many as I am British and relatively young - but I know enough to know that much of what was on show was almost like propaganda.In a way though, it eerily sums up the political state of Vietnam at the moment - so in a way this was ironically just as interesting for me.

Worth the time/price. Interesting to tour the grounds of a place so infamous. All interesting to see a completely different prospective on the Americans held captive in the "Hanoi Hilton." This is of course the place where Senator John McCain spent 5 1/2 years as a POW and has repeatedly talked of the brutal treatment he and his fellow GI's received.See: http://thecable.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2012/01/20/john_mccain_visits_the_hanoi_hiltonI would not suggest bringing small children.
Very interesting and informative Museum. A well set out and informative Museum, that gives some very interesting snapshots of the horrors of Colonial french rule in Vietnam, well worth a visit
Should See. this is something you do not want to miss to see how the life was back then-very interesting to see the cells and read about the history

Well worth a look. Not too far for a nice walk from the old or french quarter and hanging out by the lake on the way. Inexpensive and a slice of history. Wander around for 45 minutes or so and feel the history.Can get a little busy with some groups, but still very interesting.

Confronting but very interesting. This is a must see to get some understanding of French rule in Vietnam. This is just what is left of a much larger complex. It is a confronting insight into the brutality of the colonial regime with some very interesting history. It is the 'Hanoi Hilton' of, the as the Vietnamese call it, the American War. The American airmen held there were treated much better by the Vietnamese than they were treated by the French.

worth an hour or two. glad i went to see the hilton not much left of it but certainly worth seeing the cells, photos and other documents it is part of the history of vietnam that every american should see

History is still there.. Felt it was indeed worth the time. You might want to couple this with The Women's Museum (probably the best laid-out museum we visited in Hanoi), as it is few blocks away. Many complain about the fact that the original site has been reduced greatly, but the essence, and its historical implications remain. The cells, mass, solitary and what constitutes death row are still preserved, as well as the guillotine. Additionally there seems to be some disappointment with the lack of attention placed on the US POWs, but when one puts the facility into a historical context, the usage as a POW camp vs. a prison for Vietnamese nationals under colonial rule is minimal.

Hanoi Hilton. Found that Hoa Lo started off a little slowly, but they need to establish how the prison came to be. Covering the period under French colonial rule was interesting and informative. A bit over-the-top on the amount of coverage given to liberation by the Vietnamese revolutionaries, but this is kind of anticipated. Found the info about the prison's time hosting US POWs fascinating, having known a little about the American side of the story. Generally well managed and well directed through. Interesting stuff.

Great experience . A very well preserved place that have me great insights on the conditions and experiences of the occupants in Hoa Lo Prison. Would recommend this place if you are visiting Hanoi. Won't take up more than 2 hours.

Interesting insights. . A well run and informative museum that outlines the French treatment of prisoners during the colonial period. You might be offered a guide but you won't need one as all displays are in English as well.

Maison Palace. This is one the of reasons we decided to visit Hanoi. There is only a small piece of the prison remaining, but it is a nice museum. We spent about 1 hour and have a much better understanding of the history and how the location was used in multiple timeframes for differing purposes.

Hoa Lo Prison. It was very interesting to get a full background on the history of the prison as I was unaware of the French involvement. It was quite shocking and sobering. It was fascinating to hear the Vietnamese side of the USA involvement during the Vietnam War.

Moving, well done, thoughtful museum.. We added this at the last minute to our pre-planned tour and our guide was surprised since we had children with us. Parts were a little rough for the younger one (age 9) especially and we purposely kept him away from one of the exhibits. But, it was a well organized, and eerily beautiful museum. I recommend it if you're visiting Hanoi, unless you are with very young, or very sensitive children. Our visit sparked some lively discussion with our kids, which turned out to be a good thing.
Hoa Lo Prison - interesting. Would definitely recommend going to this place. Interesting newsreels/footage. We were there during the low season, would not fancy this during high season.

A history lesson. The prison was well-presented but the memories it held of its time as a French prison for Vietnamese rebels and subsequently the "Hanoi Hilton" for American flyers were starkly portrayed in the cells and restraints used by their respective owners. Sobering stuff.

horror created by frenchs. this prison was built upon farming lands. the prison was used to house dissidents opposed to french rule.inhuman is the only word that comes to ones mind. typically a prison-small dark dingy rooms,dormitories,individual cells for isolation. the prisoners had thick metal ankle braces running the whole length of the platform upon which all daily activities had to be performed.many succumbed and were left there(as told by the guide) till authorities decide to take the body away.overall worth a visit to see what the so called civilized countries are capable of.
Hoa Lo Prison. Difficult, but important part of French Colonial history. A small sense of what life was like for US POWs...read between the lines. An important visit for students of history.

Deeply moving. This museum is a real eye opener into the history of Viet Nam.I found it very emotional and I learned a lot about the psyche of Viet Nam and their struggles for independence which is still threatened today.This would be top of my list of 'attractions' in Ha NoiOther reviews complain of bias... if you travel to other countries, they will of course each have their own perspective as do we. Personally I find it fascinating to hear another version of events.
Confronting. Hoa Lo Prison was confronting and a reminder that war hurts so many. The torture cells and and guillotine, left you wondering how could humanity be so cruel

Very interesting. This museum gives an insight into how atrocious the conditions must have been for Vietnamese who stood up to French domination of their country. You get to wander through the communal and death row cells and see the awful solitary confinement cells where prisoners were shackled and had to sit up unless they were able to tolerate lying head down on the sloping floor. To complete the catalogue of horrors, one of the two guillotines brought to Vietnam by the French is still there. There is a section on the US prisoners of war who were kept there too.
Quick visit. Only a small portion of it actually exists, so your gander around the prison is extremely short, worth it I suppose just to say you've been...
WWII History. Great to visit parts of the WWII history. Sad for what has happened, but it is the history of our world.

Interesting prison in terms of French colonialist punishment but depiction of US soldiers was laughable.. Well done depiction of life in prison for Vietnamese revolutionaries. But to depict American serviceman as enjoying their captivity is total fiction and a ridiculous assertion. Shame on this museum for its bias. Why not be more faithful to actual conditions for American prisoners of war.

Go have a look. Ignore the propaganda and look at the place for what it was a prison under several regimes and the way that prisoners were treated and dispatched via madame guillotine. Its orth an hour or two.

Part of the city's history left behind. You will visit a small portion of the original prison and the rest are now part of a moden complex of hotel and commercial tower. You will see the exhibits and hear the narration and learn of the horrors of this place's past.

Historically significant site. This site really made me aware of what the prisoners went through during their time at this prison. I think some of the pictures of the American troops enjoying themselves at Christmas time were questionable, at the least. This was no recreation center for the prisoners. It was horrifying.

This place must be haunted. Prison life in Hanoi surely was horrible. The death row is creepy. My hair stood up straight. You can smell the fear still hanging in the air. The museum is well looked after and exhibits are clear and well maintained.
The souvenir shops are ridiculously expensive.

A somber reminder of the past. An excellent tour with an informative guide taking us around the prison. To see the actual rooms and here the stories in the atmosphere of the prison was a chilling experience. Well worth visiting.
Hoa Lo (Hanoi Hilton). Small, it is actually next to the Somerset Grand Hanoi. I think it was built on part of the prison property. Not much left, but has enough to get the feel of it.
Interesting. Great to find atricles told from the Vietnamese point of view. Easy to find, close to HK lake and cheap entry tickets. Nice Memorial garden.

Interesting history. Only parts of the prison facility remain and you do get a sense of its tragic place in history. However, it was not well curated with displays and information coming across as largely unprofessional.

Hanoi Hilton. This French built prison provides an essential source for understanding the colonial struggles experienced by the Vietnamese people in the Twentieth Century, both during the French occupation and the U.S. Vietnam war, in which so many Vietnamese gave their lives in support of Ho Chi Minh's determination to achieve a united and independent Vietnam. Of particular interest is the guillotine left behind by the French and, of course, the flight uniform and various photos of Senator John McCain, as well as the metal bound log of American pilots shot down during the war, including the former Alabama Senator Jeremiah Denton. Being there inspires a poignant reconsideration of the unfathomable reasons the Americans were ever there. McNamara's apology is on sale in the prison bookshop.

Don't waste your time. I know that we shall not forget part of history (and even more the worst one to avoid it happening again), but this prison/museum is pointless. Cheap, disordered, shabby and creepy.. the only feeling you'll get from there is willing to escape as soon as possible. Only the small yard in the back looks more spiritual and respectful to me. I would not recommend this place.

Shocking how people lived. Easy to find in street. Bit of a maze of rooms and some can be crowded.Upstairs displays quite modern 'memorials' and wasn't quite sure about all the communist displays about the South China sea and the large pictures about the modern navy.Found what the French did more interesting and gruesome to see how they chopped prisoner's heads off...

Surprisingly !!!. Surprisingly We are a hotel employee sent here in an afternoon, it's just surprised the city center still retains the witness history during the war, many prisoners detained Where we do not go more and listen to tour guide recounts many emotions and thoughts about the war. We do not doubt the hospitality of this city and its people even though we are Americans

Interesting history, simple displays. It's very small but if out in are interested in the war history it is worth a visit. Displays are in English as well as Vietnamese. I liked it better than the military museum and the mausoleum museum.Pros: learned a lot about the war with the French, interesting to see original cells. Two rooms on the American war including john mccain's flight suit and some photos that were cool to see. Cons: it is only a fraction of the original prison, so quite small.

A strange place to visit.. This is purely based on personal experience. We found this quite an eery place to visit as the atmosphere was quite sombre. You do get a feel of how times were in here for the inmates. A lot of history about the place but not that much to see really.

Impressive History of Colonial Repression. A must see in Hanoi. It brings to memory that not only the US has a very violent history in Vietnam but also the French do. As it is an original building where prisoners were kept, tortured etc. it is very impressive.
Not much left but great history. A reasonable snap shot of past history of Hanoi during several wars. Worth a time out to get some perspective
Chilling. Another must if you can stand the propaganda. Quite chilling and well done.Mural on last wall is very powerful.

Worth the visit. Well worth visiting,even though only a small part is left. Shows the history with displays how prisoners were kept. From colonial times up to the infamous Hanoi Hilton times of the B52 crews from the war.

Must see in Hanoi. A great experience, surprisingly well laid out and very interesting. The models of the cells and prisoners as well as music added real atmosphere. Cool to see the guillotine. As always more working fans wouldn't go astray!

Confronting. Enjoyable but confronting. Well worth a visit. Very easy to find, allow at least an hour to walk through the prison. Graphic images and torture implements as well as guillotine on display.
intersting place. learning viet nam history and their bravery, and the war with american they deteined us captured pilots here

70s war. There was more about the war and the was prisoners it kept rather than real prison.
Was worth a look though and it was amazing how bad the people locked up had to survive.

Very atmospheric. Having grown up in the 60's and 70's we had heard a lot about the infamous 'Hanoi Hilton' throughout the Vietnam war. Whilst only roughly a quarter of the original now exists, what remains paints a very stark view of the horrors experienced by inmates. The dismay is brought to life by the use of dummies in many of the rooms on show, this brings an erie atmosphere as if you are actually watching dat to day life. The only other place which I have known which betters the Hanoi site is Auchwitz. Entry is very cheap and probably subsidised by the government to act as propaganda platform against the French and American conflicts. Well worth an hour or so of your stay in Hanoi.

Interesting but one sided. This is interesting part of Hanoi culture. Some of the stories which come out are only of the perspective of Vietnamese culture not world culture but overall very interesting. The section representing the death penalty is eerie and a bit confronting for young kids.
Very interesting. Very eye opening. This country has endured so much. Again being American and seeing the Vietnam perspective very interesting.

Bleak. Bleak place, not helped by the inevitable propaganda presentation - evil French colonists tortured and executed freedom fighters in unspeakable conditions (probably largely true), American pilots kept in luxury despite their dropping bombs (like to know more on that one)

Good but meh... This place was laid out really well, well maintained and super cheap entry and off street parking for a small fee of 2000vnd!Unfortunately I felt that not enough information was given, I left still not fully understanding what had taken place and why, for instance on one of the boards there was a photo of three gentleman that had been killed for their part in the 'great poisoning plot of 1908' granted, I could google it once back at my hotel but surely they should just provide the information of the whole story so that we can understand? Either way, it's still interesting at points (unfortunately again, a lot of the information that was supplied wasn't in English so we struggled a bit)For the money you can't really go wrong with a visit, just don't expect it to be overly educational.

Sobering. Everyone needs to visit Hao Lo to understand the strength of the Vietnamese people. Extremely well set out with simple explanations in English and French. A very one-sided perspective, of course.

Essential stop in Hanoi. This site spans the gamut of recent Vietnamese history from French colonialism to the Vietnam War. The prison has been restored well and includes quite realistic depictions of prisoner conditions, although they do go out of their way to say how great they treated American POWs in Vietnam which seems doubtful (full disclosure, I'm American). If you're interested in war and military history, this is a must see.

Thought Provoking. Really recommend a visit to the prison. it was originally built by the French colonists to hold Vietnamese revolutionaries. The conditions the prisoners were held in were not pleasant as prisoners were kept in a communal cell manacled to a long concrete bench. Within the museum are exhibits of weapons used to torture the prisoners and pictures and sculptures that show the brutality of conditions. The women's section of the prison was tiny as was the area where prisoners were kept prior to execution. There's even a guillotine in the prison which was used to behead prisoners.During the Vietnamese war the prison was used to house US pilots shot down. A number of US airmen were kept in the prison leading them to call it the "Hanoi Hotel". There was a real contrast between how the US airmen were kept by the Vietnamese and how the Vietnamese prisoners were kept by the French although I recognise this may not be wholly accurate.

Expected it to be bigger. We had hard alot about the old prison, but is was very small. The exhibition was good and created a good picture of the prisons conditions during the different was. Though it is was bit colored by the ponit of view.

Personally one of my favorite museums we visted. I really enjoyed this one as it spoke about the French Resistance in Vietnam. Every other museum I went to was about the US which for obvious reasons should be but was interesting to learn about the French. It was depressing like any war/prison museum is but insightful and some graphic images are kept in there.

History. It's just 20.000 dong so not even a dollar. For maybe an hour of pleasure. I almost walked away without seeing the American war prisoners section , sign posts are poor. Items are shown used by prisoners a lot spoons cups so avoidable.... I god some good titles to read from the book store Stanley karnow- Vietnam a history Robert Mason- chicken hawk Knowing you are standing in a place with so much history is worth the dollar but info is poor. Do not buy from the souvenir shop it's a rip off with items priced in dollars. The ticket to get in vs the prices are insane and are average lots of Vietnam and some hanoi items you could get in the streets for a better price ...

Hanoi Hilton. Interesting piece of Viet Namese history. Colonialism wasn't famous for being nice to the locals and the French certainly weren't the exception. No mention though of how American POW's were treated at the Hanoi Hilton. Not that the Americans had any business being involved in this conflict in the first place; but, that is another matter.

Must do for War interested people. The Vietnamese have done this really well. Gallows, historical rooms and modern presentations on the current Sino-Vietnamese conflict around disputed island territories, and other displays are all really well thought out and presented in English, French & Vietnamese.If you like Vietnam war and French imperialist info, visit here.The only 'negative' (which we just found fascinating to be honest) was the obviously slightly slanted presentation about the capturing and accommodating of US POWs during the Vietnam / American war. The conditions declared border on fanciful: how they shaped corresponding footage of smiling pilots we will never know! However we found the dubious nature of the exhibit as a great example of the pride of the Vietnamese people (or at least their government). It shows a side of the story that the west would rarely see.Overall well worth the admission ticket, & thumbs up to the authorities on nailing the exhibition.

A must see while in Hanoi. We spent a couple of hours in here. There are displays of how prisoners were kept in the prison. It was built by the French and housed many political prisoners long before the Vietnam War.
Great insight. Great insight into the horrific conditions endured by so many people. How can people treat each other like that?

Hanoi Hilton. For those of us who remember and lived through The War, this is a good place to visit... this was our 2nd visit, but for other family members they were surprised to learn that this prison has a much bigger and larger history for the Vietnamese people .. a bit one-sided in its presentations (!) but we had no complaints.. SEE IT.
Disappointing. It was ok, but have visited better. We were not allowed to enter a room which was showing a video to other tourists but no idea why not.

History review. If you are interested in history and war, then come here. You'll see how the war was like between Vietnam n France. Lots of visual and documentary evidence showing how cruel the french treated the vietnamese for ex: prisons, prisoners,killing machine,etc. worth a visit!

still good. I was first here in 1996 and the exhibition was a little more powerful maybe time has caused some of the exhibits to be replaced. Before you go however do take the time to read a little about the prisoners stories on line, as it is very hard to witness people exclaiming how well the american airman lived their lives here. Remember the information being displayed has been curated by the Vietnamese so you are doing a dis service to the previous inmates by only seeing one side. You can easily google John MaCain which should lead you to other stories.

Winners Write the History Books. Hoa Lo prison was on my must see list while in Ha Noi. We had the added benefit of a local guide who was both fluent in English and excited to share its history with us. History, that is, as it is taught in Vietnamese schools today. Our guide was a 25 year old young lady who couldn't have been more proud of her country. Rightfully so, but unaware of the true history of Hoa Lo under NVA administration during the Vietnam conflict. I held my tongue during our tour and simply absorbed all it had to offer. Even with the misrepresentations of American prisoners quality of life, it was a tour worth taking. Senator John McCain had been in Hanoi the week before our arrival. I'd sure love to hear his thoughts. Not sure if he's been back to Hoa Lo since his first 'visit', but his memories may not parallel the history presented today.

Worth a Visit. Worth a visit simply for this historical perspective.Limited exhibits and perhaps a limited perspective on much of what was presented. Actually made it interesting. This visit takes about 45 minutes to an hour tops.
interesting place if you love history. you must come here to understand more about vietnam war, about the truth. if you love history. i feel so bad because of French's treatment with prisons.

Slanted to Vietnamese side. It was interesting to get the Vietnamese viewpoint on the French occupation and the Vietnam War, but I don't believe that the American prisoners were treated like they were staying at a 4 star hotel as it was presented at the prison.
Very interesting. Worth a visit. Atmospheric, cells and guillotine are rather sinister. Events recorded of U.S.A. POW's are full of propoganda so read up about the war before you visit.

Interesting place. Frightening history for all occupants.. Only part of this prison remains. But what's left presents well. The warring history and occupations of Vietnam by foreigner invaders culminates in this prison, in some respects. Worth a visit.

Must go if you like history. If you love history, you must come here to understand more about war. Its a lillt bit sad but i did like this place, because it is the truth about what happened here just 40 years ago.

One will learn a lot about Vietnam's recent history. Located in the heart of French quarter, Hoa Lo is very easy to find. The once nortorious prison built by the French to detain ( mostly) Vietnamese political prisoners, then American pilots by the Vietnamese during Vietnam war, it has become a museum since 1993. It gives you a feel of what a prison is like and how prisoners lived. The original guilertine in the death cell section is the most striking part. The outdoor memorial walls with sculptures are worth a visit, too. In short, if you are interested in history, this is a must see placeFor Americans, this might be a hard place for them since the two last rooms displaying American pilots ' daily activities in the prison and a board of information and a documentary movie about " imperialist American" bombing North Vietnam. These are considered " one side information" by many Americans
Great. Great to see, bit biased but really enjoyed walking around and seeing this.Had tidy cells and mass cells loads of stuff to read. Overall would recommend

A good review of prison. Entrance Fee: 20,000 Dong (as of 9th Sep 2014)Pretty decent place and it is kinda scary when they show the dead cell. There is explanation of the history in english so do not worry. Overall it is pretty good experience.
Interesting and moving. We loved the "Hanoi Hilton's" display. Most interesting were the parts about the prison conditions. We spent a good three hours here.

Interesting. This is a prison turned museum that has a lot of great sculptures to depict what life was like for the prisoners. It definitely helps bring the museum to life. It was also very interesting to hear their point of view on the "American War" of 1955-1975 to say the least.

A must-see historical site!. Like others who have mentioned, this is a very educational museum and one will expect to spend at least 2-3 hours of slowly immersing oneself into the culture of what this place used to be. Try to come early as this place closes at 5pm!

Intesting visit. it was an interesting visit for me, I actually enjoyed going to museum and old prison ground, they have an uneasy feel that i didn't like but i still like to experience it.Senator John McCain was once imprisoned in this building and it was actually kind of tiny prison.However, it doesn't have scary feeling like old Melbourne Gaol, but the illustrations and some statues are kind of disturbing though.It is now in the heart of the city, so once you got out of the museum, you suddenly felt normal again.

Wouldn't want to stay there.. For starters, 2/3 of the original building has been chopped off and replaced with a highrise.The place is a bit dated and doesn't quite give you a true sense of the conditions that the prisoners had to put up with. Some prisons I have been in have an odd sense of foreboding and an eery quality about them. This didn't.

Quite enjoyable. As with all other monuments to history in any country, but especially in countries with less freedoms, take the history with a grain of salt. However, it is a facinating peek into the Vietnamese perspective of both the colonial period and the Vietnam War.

Come and see it if in the area. I visited this site more times then I can shake a stick at for the simple fact I spent 2.5 months in the hotel virtually attached to the back fence line. This is a good enough museum which shows the nasty stuff that happens in war. If you are expecting a view of the famous "Hanoi Hilton" which housed some of the US airmen shot down during the "American War" forget it. That portion has been torn down and "whitewashed" like it never happened. The museum shows what the French did to the Vietnamese political prisoners back in the colony days. Kind of spooky and it is an eye opener but best of all the museum is dark and cool and really cheap to enter so it's a great place to hang out during the hot hours (which is the entire day in Hanoi).

Very Interesting (and awful but pleased we went). We visited here without really knowing what we were going to see. Its well put together - the photo's, the information etc - but its pretty grim seeing how humans can treat humans.My 12 and 16 year old weren't put off by going - although they tended to look more than read.I want to say I enjoyed viewing it - but that doesnt sound right. Im definitely pleased that I went to this 'attraction'.

Worth a visit, keep an open mind. Visited here on a rainy day and managed to spend about an hour looking through the museum. I don't know a lot about the history of the Vietnam war, so was surprised by some of the information the museum displayed.My partner however is quite up to date on this history and pointed out to me that a lot of the information was very one sided and did not show a holistic view of what really occurred.Still, the displays were very interesting and it certainly sent a shiver down my spine to see the conditions the prisoners were living in!The museum is pretty easy to find and the cost is reasonable.Well worth a visit, just keep and open mind.
Good for a short visit.. Informative hour, if slightly one sided. But good to see and better than some other museums we went to in vietnam.
Interesting. This is a very interesting thing to see. Usually I'm bored with history and unimpressed. A little spooky and sad at times looking into the cells but worth a visit for sure.

The Alcatraz of Hanoi. There are only so many temples and museums that I can take. The Hoa Lo Prison was an interesting visit that got me away from the temples and museums.I am an American and felt that I should definitely visit this place. I was not disappointed. It is a major part of rather recent American history that does not get taught in our schools. All prisons are creepy and this one is no different. To see how the prison was first used by the French to house Vietnamese dissidents was eye opening. The conditions were deplorable. They have several rooms set up with life sized prison statues in cells and shackles so you really get a sense of the horror of this prison.After the French left Vietnam the prison was used in the American War (Vietnam War). The Vietnamese don't call the war the Vietnam War, they call it the American War. The artifacts that I saw that really brought the prison home were the pictures of John McCain and his flight suit. John McCain was shot down near Hanoi in 1968 and spent several years here.The museum paints a picture that life was pretty good for the Americans inside. They raised their own chickens and cooked their own meals. Played basketball and volleyball. Got to celebrate Christmas. I am not sure if the American soldiers that were held captive here would agree.All in all, you should check this place out if you have the time, especially if you are American, French, or a history buff.There is one review here by Pisith that says, "You will understand why Vietnamese Hate Americans." He could NOT be further from the truth. I felt nothing but love from the Vietnamese from HCMC to Hanoi. It is uncanny how friendly they were to me. I could easily understand it if they were hateful towards me, but that was not the case at all. I spent a month there and loved every single minute of it. My favorite thing about Vietnam is the people and the constant smiles they have on their face.
History of Hanoi prison. Excellent displays of prisoner life for early (French) to 70's (USA) Video's screens, model of complete prison, cells, and prisoners clothes to John McCain's uniform
Interesting representation of events. Even if you're not into history it is interesting to see how the Vietnamese war is presented in the prison. A lot of propaganda but it's worth visiting

Several Faces of Prison. Hoa Lo Prison, more "affectionately" known as the Hanoi Hilton, resonates with Americans as the place where John McCain and other US prisoners were held during the Vietnam War, but the prison was "home" to Vietnamese incarcerated by the French as well as by the Vietnam government. The various exhibits show how prisoners were treated and often tortured by their captives - guillotined in some cases by the French, chained in narrow quarters with other prisoners, with no toilet facilities or ability to move around. It seemed as though American prisoners of war may have faired better than others - playing games, exercising in the courtyard, and generally living in better conditions than others. Our guide talked about how his mother was incarcerated here, while he was fighting on the Ho Chi Minh Trail for the country. Authorities thought she might have hidden money and wanted her to reveal where. Exhibits are well done and give a good picture of the suffering different prisoners had to endure at different times in Vietnamese history. As you walk through different rooms, read the stories and watch videos and visual exhibits you cannot help but be moved. This is definitely a must for visitors.

It's a prison.. If you win the war you write the history albeit that this place is quite clearly barbaric. It is a place of horror, torture and murder. It was one of the best preserved places of history in Hanoi outside anything to do with Ho Chi Minh.Well worth the visit.
You will understand why Vietnamese hate american. The only thing I feel from this place are the hate of revolutionaries toward France and US army and the scariness of prison.

All depends on your perspective ;-). Quite large and maintained relatively well. Interesting to see how the bad French terrorized and tortured the Vietnamese, but how nice the Vietnamese were toward the Americans. They played games, had parties, made Christmas trees, from the looks of it it was essentially a summer camp. An Irish girl came up to us, pointed, and asked "is that true?" Umm, no. Brand new section on the aggression of China towards their territorial waters and islands was interesting as well.
A lot of propaganda, but interesting!. Well worth a visit - a lot of Propaganda about the American war, but I guess propaganda is all a matter of perspective. Some good videos

Eerie!. It's a very sad insight into the paranoia that colonists feel that they need to create such a place - particularly the guillotine...Interesting to see the apparent contrast of how the Vietnamese treated the American pilots they kept there...Worth a visit
Great experience. Despite dozens of trips to Hanoi this was the first time I had visited the prison. Memorable and should be a must do on your visit plans, an early start is recommended!
Historical. Firstly the prison was well maintained. Going through the prison was an interesting and humbling experience

Worth a visit. We visited here in our stay in Hanoi. The focus is mainly on the Vietnamese prisoners imprisoned by the French. The info is a little biased but you can see through some of that - one persons freedom fighter is another's terrorist!
There is also a small section on the US airmen imprisoned here in the Vietnam war.

Worth a visit if you have lots of time. The Hilton as the prison has been dubbed is worth a visit if you have the time, however if you are short on time there are plenty of better attractions to focus on. The fee is low , and you can complete the visit in less than an hour. Don't leave it too late to visit as the museum closes strictly at 5pm. The even started tuning off the lights in some of the rooms before 5pm. There is a good bit going on in the museum but it is very badly laid out and can be difficult to follow. The ground gives a good insight into how the prisoner were kept. However, the details of how the American pilots were kept is told from a very biased pro-Vietnamese perspective and needs to be taken with a pinch of salt. There are plenty of images showing American pilots decorating christmas trees and playing ball etc.
Grim and grisly. A grim and grisly reminder of events from the fairly recent past. Worth visiting to get some feel for the way that war was and is regarded by the winning side
Worth visiting. We walked here from our hotel and spent a considerable time in the Prison. It is an eye opener for Westerners visiting and highly recommended.

Echoes of the Hanoi Hilton.. An interesting place, well worth a visit. Bear in mind what the building was used for and the fact that it held many people of many nations. The history is well set out as you walk through, and may seem brutal at times, but then again, this was no Disney theme park! The Vietnamese people are very proud of their struggle through the centuries. You have to make up your own minds as to the light and dark of their story. Well worth a visit.
Interesting. Interesting museum, with plenty of English boards to explain about the history. Includes John McCain's flight suit (US senator) and photos of American prisoners of war

Another biased view of Vietnamese history. I liked how atmospheric this place was, and the memorial garden. Also like most attractions in Vietnam the entrance fee was cheap.However very much like the War Remnants museum in Ho Chi Minh the story is told in a very filtered way. American airmen were tortured here, yet in there display there is nothing but smiling faces, new clothes, and civilised living. Please take a very sceptical view of Vietnamese History throughout their museums
Worth A Visit. A very good museum. Very education, well laid out with the cell hall being very life like. It is not an expensive trip and should not be missed when visiting Hanoi.

Interesting. If you are in a rush, go visit other monuments first. We had 3 days in Hanoi, so we made our way there. It is interesting to see the Vietnamese point of view of the war. Americans and French, be warned, they will not speak well of your country. They have very good and clear documentary videos played in their museum.

A place to visit. A lot of history. A lot of food for thought, as many other places in Vietnam. From my point of view, a must do in Hanoi ... In the hope that history will truly teach us something, sooner or later, and things like these never happen again

Worth a visit but there are better attractions in hanoi. The prison is pretty bare, but the entrance fee is low and it is worth a visit whilst in hanoi. The grounds provide something of an insight into how the prisoners were kept/tortured. However, the details of how the American pilots were kept is told from a very biased pro-Vietnamese perspective and needs to be taken with a pinch of salt

The Hilton. I could see the reference by the prisoners as to why the gave it the name of The Hilton. What was left of the prison has been restored and created into a museum. This display of prisoners in concrete cells with leg irons depicts the treatment of the prisoners. Its reference to the American pilots that became prisoners and the continual showing of the bombardment of the country is a stark reminder of the concequences of war.See if you can

Not much too it!. It's pretty small and pretty average really. I think there are better sights to see personally and I love going to places like this usually. Kind of glad I saw it, but wouldn't have been too upset had I missed out. Overall I would say this was middle of the road for an attraction.

Neat!. I thought this was pretty interesting. There are lots of rooms with information. If it's hot, beware that there's no air conditioning. It got pretty hot in some rooms. You can visit where the American soldiers were being held.

Nice propaganda!!!. These guys along with the hermit kingdom (north Korea) truly outdo themselves. I think I couldn't stop laughing all the way round as countless examples of French torture and oppression of the Vietnamese were quoted. Yet the similar treatment of USA prisoners by same Vietnamese were not admitted!!! It looks like a holiday resort for them :p.Keep it up guys, we love your lack of sincerity and honesty, it's a genuine reminder to us of the bad old days of the communist states repression of truth and democracy. Lest we forget xxx

Twisted truth. This place has a cheap entrance fee which makes it bearable. The truth in hear I think is rather twisted with a lot of writers creativity. Unfortunately a lot of the exhibits are written in Vietnamese or French so you can't read everything and the whole place is modernised so a limited idea of what the place was really like. But it's not terrible and I don't regret going but take it with a pinch of salt.

A Viet Nam War Museum, from the other side; spare, yet powerful. If you are an American with a connection to the Viet Nam war era, interested in military history or the events that shaped Viet Nam, you should come here.Known to Americans as "The Hanoi Hilton", the place where U.S. fighter pilots were brutally imprisoned, the Hoa Lo Prison is now set up as a museum to what the Vietnamese call "The American War." The museum features a collection of historic artifacts from the war era, photographs with explanatory text in Vietnamese and English as well as some archival footage. The slant of the narrative is clearly pro-Vietnamese/anti-American, giving you a perspective of the war that most Americans lack, that of the Vietnamese defending their land against an American invasion. Dioramas recreate the conditions for a prisoner; they look pretty brutal, down to the irons on the ankles. For me, the high point - an emotional punch to the gut - was seeing U.S. Senator John McCain's flight suit behind glass.The experience is definitely no-frills/low budget, but powerful at the same time.

Interesting insight into French colonialism rule. Not much left of the original prison but still worth a visit to appreciate the Vietnamese view of colonial rule by the French and treatment of the locals - contextulises why there was such a push for independence and the rise of Ho Chi Minh to power.

Important. Especially important for Americans who lived through the time of the Vietnam war. It give a different perspective on what happened and what the Vietnamese lived through and worked toward during the war years.

Interesting experience. Learned quite a bit about the French occupation of Vietnam and the Vietnam War (called the American War). Definitely a good lesson in history but at times quite a bit of propaganda. But regardless would recommend a visit and it doesn't take too long to walk through.

A little dissapointing. To be honest, entrance is very cheap, so it may be worth your money. I'm not so sure whether it's worth your time though. The museum is inconsistant about providing English translations, which surprised me.
There's definitely more than a whiff of propaganda too. Still, for those interested, I suppose it gives some insight into the Vietnamese perspective of history.
Vietnamese Perspective on POWs. Very interesting, but some of the videos in the museum were not very convincing. Still, one learns a lot about modern Vietnamese history.

Great place in vietnam war. go to inside have so much documen about historic in vietnam and france , so much vietnam hore, so like that this place, if you have time come to viet nam, we are thinking you go to visit Hoa lo prison that so good if you like that about vietnam historic

past crimes. A chilling experience, inhumanity and desperation, utmost cruelty, have we all learned from it?
We need to.

Propaganda museum!. Our visit to this 'museum' was a total waste of time and money. The building doesn't really give you any insight as to what the prison would have been like as the structure has either been sold-off or modernise, the exhibits are rather poor, most of the descriptions and explanations are in Vietnamese with no English translation, and the entire 'story' of the prison has been blatantly used as a huge propaganda machine. I felt a bit cheated that I had paid money to visit a place which can so shamelessly lie to it's audience. How they can expect anyone to believe their version of how they treated American POWs is beyond me. I think the sole use for this museum must be for the Vietnamese to 'teach' their own about how they have suffered through the hands of various invaders through the years, but this surely shouldn't be for outside visitors to see. I guess it's interesting to see propaganda up so close and personal, that is about the level of the experience. I really wouldn't recommend this so-called 'museum'.

Interesting. Minimal fee of 40,000 dong. Interesting to see the prison cells and the small American prisoner exhibition along with John Mccains flight suit having been captured. A little bit of propaganda I felt but no doubt a terrible place to be held prisoner. Only a small part of the jail actually remains as what looks like a hotel is built on the rest. Worth a visit as a time filler.

Sadly disappointing. http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g293924-d311069-Reviews-Hoa_Lo_Prison-Hanoi.html There's not a great deal of this left most of the location has been taken over by apartments/hotel building. Even if you read all of the information boards you won't be here more than an hour at the most. There's no aircon in the building, but there are fans, so you will get some air at some points. Signposting is a little vague, but you get there in the end.99% of the visitors were westerners when we visited, apart from a uniformed contingent, who came into the American War room and pushed to the front. The privileges of rank I guess. The vast majority of this museum is not related to the American war (there are two rooms on that). There is quite a bit with information boards in English, but not all of it. If you've been to the War Remnants museum in HCMC, (to which it does NOT compare at all) then you'll recognize a lot of the photos too.We spent the majority of the time in the two American rooms, which talk mostly about the life of leisure that captured American POW's had during their stay in the Hanoi Hilton. You'll also get to see John McCains flight suit and lots of photo's of the great time they all had, plus several propaganda videos.Overall, I'm glad we visited, but feel disappointed with the "that's it?" feeling. Cost in August 2014 was 20k VND per person.

Study about Vietnam war!. We knew about Vietnam war and we visited here to learn many stories from communist warrior. The people had prison break through drain of the house. Let see at the yard, the French used to chop the head of prisoner off. Very disgusting !

Interesting and a bit scary. I like the fact that you visit the original prison, however it seems to me that is has been modernized and renovated so you don't really get the true feeling of the place. Also there is lack of explanation to the different instruments, pictures and items that are exhibited, which is a shame.

Hanoi Hilton worth the visit....almost. Full of interesting history even if it's a little one sided. But, who can blame them ,considering their history of occupation by the Chinese, French, and last but not least the Americans. It would have been a living hell for all that were held here, showing in no uncertain terms our capabilities of inflicting the worst kinds of punishment for our "enemies". All in all worth a visit, but not for the squeamish. Despite the guide books and hotel pamphlets saying there is no entry fee, there is ,altho it is almost nothing, around 20,000 Dong. The Guillotine that is on show there is worth the price of admission alone. The rest of the exhibits are a bonus .

The Hanoi Hilton a must see in Hanoi. The conditions of prisoners held here is confronting, the prison at various stages has been hell for Vietnamese political prisoners and American soldiers, there is so much to see here and it is a must for anyone with an interest of what it was like in Vietnam during the American War. We spent an easy 2 hours here, a great deal is in English and the area where John McCain's flight suit is worth the visit alone. There is a small USD2 charge to get in, 2 gift stores that sell all sorts of things, and places to sit and reflect.

Hanoi Hilton. This was not included in our tour but once we saw it on the hotel map as an attraction, we had to see it. It was well worth the walk from old quarters. This should be included as one of the local tour.

Another one to tick off the list. It's worth it if you are interested in the Vietnam War - and have heard stories of the Hanoi Hilton.That aside, there is a glimpse into the past and the French rule of the country.At the end of the day though a prison is a prison.I don't think it's a must personally but I did 'enjoy' it and it is interesting to see the other side of the propaganda war that was waged by both sides in the Vietnam War.

American and VIetnamese History. I'll be honest, I went to this place to see the flight suit the John McCain was wearing when he got captured by the VC. Ended up staying for over an hour because their was so much to see. It was eery and gruesome but fascinating and worth the dollar or two admission.

HORRIFYING PLACE. The conditions of the prisoners here would have been like a living hell.You see the cells and dummies, displaying who and why a lot of the policital prisoners were held here.One section was for the American pilots ( The Hanoi Hilton ) and there are many films and booklets, to purchase, giving a much different point of view about the wars.

Historic memories and sad. The french prison in early 1900, where the Vietnamese resistant fighters were held prison. It was sad to see how the people was treated, just because they wanted their freedom. It was however, very hot there, as no air con. Fee VND 40.000/DKK12/USD 2. Just close to Hanoi Tower

It'll wash your brain. Obviously not a nice place to have been.. By the time I got out of Hoa Lo Prison, I was sure the Americans had LOVED it in there. I know it was a one-sided view (from the Vietnamese side, of course), but there was not one bad thing about being an American in the prison, according to what I read. "What the hell were the Americans whining about?", I thought. Turkey dinner for Christmas, volleyball, basketball, billiards...jeez, it was just like the Hilton Hotel! Anyway, it is interesting to see, worth the couple of bucks to get in and get a view of kind of how it was like. Whatever, prisons are cool places to visit, but I wouldn't want to live there. Enjoy the historic relevance of the place and the fact that it is in the middle of Hanoi. Don't forget to check out the almond tree. I found one on the ground and carry it as my lucky charm now. It sure would have been lucky for the prisoners....but you'll have to go read why.
Locked up. This is a very interesting visit. A little/lot of propaganda going on but as an intelligent person you will see through that.
Enthralling. Really enjoyed the "other " perspective of the war and French occupation. Worth a visit and entry price is good

Mildly interesting. The infamous Hanoi Hilton! Somewhat disappointing, mostly because only a small part of the prison has been preserved. A tall office building now stands on what used to be the rest of the prison. A sign offered a personal guide for groups of 10 or more, so we joined up with other tourists to make a group. However, we were then told there were no guides and given no reason. Like other reviewers, we felt it was one-sided but that is not unexpected, and a lot of effort has been put into making the exhibits informative and interesting. Worth a visit if you're interested from an historical perspective.

Interesting and worth the visit. Might be worth looking up some history on this period before you visit as you may have a more balanced view. That said I'm sure our historians show a little bias to the West! The lighting is dark enough for you to visualise what it must have been like for any prisoner who spent some time at the infamous 'Hilton Holtel', the guillotine is particularly chilling.

A bit too much propoganda. I thought this would be better than it was. Much of the original structure has changed and there are many displays showing the heroic efforts of the North Vietnamese during the French & American occupation. A little too much propoganda

Historic place. You can find out more about the prison conditions in the past fr both Vietnamese when imprisoned by the French, and subsequently the conditions of American pilots during the vietnam war. It's very biased I must admit, but the atmosphere of the prison is dank and musty, allowing you to imagine what conditions would be like back then. 1-2 hours to slowly view all the exhibits around the museum,

Interesting viewing. It was good to look around the hanoi hilton although felt that maybe the museum is a little one sided in favour of the vietnamese but then it is their museum. Still extremely interesting to look around and gave you a sense of what it may have been like.

Interesting place. to visit. We walked quite a long way to the prison on a hot day but felt it was worth it. There are some interesting exhibits and information on signs. The cells were dark and eerie, with an old guillotine standing tall in the centre of the room.

Must see, but know your history. I wanted to visit the Hanoi Hilton after reading a book by Jim Stockdale. The prison mainly focuses of the prison's usage during French rule. Our guide gave us the party line on the prison's usage during the Viet Nam war. We listened, but knew the REAL story.

Newly Renovated, Worth the visit. Its worth the visit when you have the time and if you like history. The prison explains in details from the first time it was made, and who have been through the prison lock up. They have preserved some of chains and cells. Give it a go when you have the time. Not much tourist too.

Excellent little museum. You realise that Vietnamese communism started out in this place. It nicely charts the history of the Indochina rule (the French take a right pasting in this museum!) and then housed captured American airmen from the more recent war. We did this as a time filler because we were staying in the hotel next door and thoroughly enjoyed the visit.
Interesting trip. Interesting trip to the prison 1$ entry fee and was there for about an hour. Some good displays and original cells and detailed description of past events. All In all a good trip!

A quick but thought provoking visit. The museum is actually quite well set out in order for self-guided tours to be taken by visitors. A lot of pieces of history in the form of clothing, letters, etc, and quite a few good photographs to show what actually happened here. Definitely worth the minimal entry fee (around $1) and an hour of your time in you can spare it. I've written up a longer review and included photos here - http://ordinarygirlextraordinarydreamer.com/2014/08/02/hoa-lo-prison-the-hanoi-hilton/

no joke!!. my 'experience' of jails out of Europe came mostly from images like in 'midnight express' where jail is pictured like a compound where inmates walk freely, so I was really chocked to see the chains!!

This was okay.... This really wasn't all that interesting. More than half of the prison is now a massive hotel / apartment block.The part that is left has been changed significantly from its original interior. The artefacts on show aren't all that interesting and all of the letters and a lot of the explanations are written in French or English.The place was very small and not very well represented (especially when you compare that to War Remnants museum in HCMC) and having spent a whole dollar and half an hour inside I don't feel that I know any more about the place than I did before hand.It's a shame this is so poor.

Mostly Well-Done Museum. Most of the museum tells the horrifying story of Vietnamese prisoners held here during French colonialism. It's not an easy exhibit to walk through as it details torture and execution methods, but I thought it was well-done. There is a small exhibit on the American POWs held here during the Vietnam War and this section is completely misleading and portrays their time at the prison as nothing but excellent medical care and decorating Christmas trees. While it is interesting to see how the Vietnamese government chooses to present different parts of their history, be aware that what is presented in this museum is not the whole story.

Pretty interesting. I thought this place was interesting to see with a lot of history. But it is not the most important place to see if you don't have that much time in hanoi. It's a great way to learn about vietnamese history.

So interesting. Hoa lo prison explore the Vietnamese political prisoners many years ago. They have to experience the difficult life in prison, without many basic conditions for normal life such as food, clothes, water. If you want to know more about Vietnam history, Hoa Lo prison is a must see.

Hoa Lo Prison. This prison is easy to find and depicts life for prisoners during the war very well. It's a little confronting as the prisoners had it bad, but there is lots of information boards, dummies and a video to watch. We found it very interesting.

Interesting. We spent about 2 hours looking around and found it interesting. The museum is a lot smaller than the original prison but it gives you a good indication of what it would have been like. It is presented from the Vietnamese stand point. It would be interesting to hear some of the prisoners stories as well.

An important piece of history. Places such as this are important to preserve, I believe. Hoa Lo Prison has played a significant part in Vietnam's history, both in the French colonial period and during the war with the US. I found the prison a little difficult to find, but that was maybe just a consequence of my poor map reading skills. There was a small fee to enter, 15,000 Dong (about £5 or $7), and I spent about an hour and a half going through the part of the prison that remains, and found it an interesting, and at times moving, experience. Two sights particularly stuck in my mind: The gruesome guillotine used to behead Vietnamese revolutionaries during the French colonial period; and Senator John McCain's pilot suit and parachute. The latter's memoirs give a different version of events regarding the treatment of the US prisoners, as their treatment was portrayed to resemble life in a real 'Hanoi Hilton', the ironic term used by the US inhabitants of the prison then.
