However, if a pinch of salt is taken, then this is still an important place to visit while in Hanoi where much can be learnt about the difficult history of the city and the country. One impression I took away from my visit was the Vietnamese do not feel that they have been defeated in either of these two struggles. I find that Interesting, and continue to reflect on that perspective. So, a very worthwhile visit, and one that I would recommend to others.

Misleading!. I went to this place without reading much about the background. First it was interesting to look around, study the descriptions and stories of the Vietnamese fighting against French colonists. But when it came to the section where it stated on the entrance "the crime committed by the French" (or something like that), and then was led to a section with pictures and descriptions explaining how American prisoners treated nicely and taught about how to clean and take care of themselves like Vietnamese, it felt to me that it lacks of some consistencies. After the visit, I went online to look for some information of the background, and shocked to find out the American prisoners were in fact tortured badly in the prison, unlike what I read from this place. I feel that I paid to be cheated!

Worth a Visit. As a history buff i was interested in seeing the prison, then had second thoughts of visiting a place where the jailers treated our prisoners so horribly and is a now a tourist attraction.It wasn't what I expected, but I didn't know what to expect. It was interesting (?) to see how the prison was used by the French colonist against the Vietnamese who were starting the communist resurrection, Worth a $1 for the visit.

More like a museum now than a prison.. The place has an admission fee of 20,000VND per person and has pretty much been rebuilt to be a modern museum.Very interesting to see the Vietnamese side of the story and most exhibits are quite realistic and informative. Definitely not for the faint hearted.

Definitely worth the visit . This place is extremely harrowing, don't be surprised if you have a few tears. It's a great place to visit, in a nice a way as possible, it'll open your eyes into a little more of the history and you'll enjoy this as best as you can with the knowledge you'll get and the things that you'll see.Make time in your schedule to go here, one hour is plenty.
Vietnamese perspective of the war and surprisingly interesting for kids!. Good place to spend 1 hour. My kids are a teenager and pre- teen. Surprisingly, they found place interesting!
Disturbing. Another emotional place, detailing the way they were treated by the French. Take time to read the material accompanying the displays.

Hanoi Hilton. Not everyone's cup of tea but I enjoyed the visit - a truly awful place where I can only imagine the past horrors - the exhibitions convey this very well without being too gruesome. Some of the cells have been preserved and they emphasise the inhumanity of the French prison masters and contrast this with the hospitality extended to US POW's. It was amazing to see pics of McCain, and his air force jump suit is on display. Also quite blood chilling to encounter a fully functional guillotine !! Allow two hours and do visit.

1 hour should be sufficient. Do take note, despite tripad states that there's no fee for entry; it does have 20,000dong entrance fee.Like what some of the reviewers mentioned, some information indeed lacks of English translation( displayed in Vietnamese) though majority does have English. Should be spending about 1 hour of your time there.

Horrific and challenging. The place itself is only a slice of what was left after the rest was demolished to allow for land development. It does have a spooky feel to it though. Was shocked at how prisoners were treated here (pre war) and that they used the guillotine up until 1968!Found some of the Vietnam POW stories a little hard to swallow, but they had some interesting objects and remnants of the day. can't say I 'enjoyed' it per se, but it was very interesting.

impressive. Impressive visit to a historical place. Built by French colonialists and also used for captured US pilots during the Vietnam war. "Interesting" that untill today the site is used for Vientamese propaganda.
Interesting. Worth of visit, but very sad and partly unbeliveable: Cheap to get in and not too wide, so that even in Hanoi temperatures it's not too exhausting to go through

Great trip. The prison is very informative, definitely worth a visit whilst in Hanoi. You get a real insight to what prison life was like for them from the information boards and from walking around the different rooms in the prison.

Good, but honestly a Fraction Disappointed... Im a bit of a history nerd, so was a fraction disappointed to be honest. I dont know what I was expecting, but expected more. But that being said, my wife would not have huge interested in the history or the past stories, and she really liked it. So its very possible that my "bar" of expectations was just too high. I did like how they covered the lifetime of the prison, not just parts of the american war, while my eyes are clearly open that the government is doing a PR job, about how amazing they treated the Americans, while the french were nasty to them [and seeing how they did that with my own eyes was very interesting]
Interesting Visit. The prison exhibit is interesting to gather a glimpse of Vietnamese history and to see a Vietnamese viewpoint of the the American ware in Vietnam. It was worth the visit.
SCARY and interesting place. Very scary place, but also very itneresting. I think its a MUST TO SEE in Hanoi.Just maybe better dont bring kids here

really interesting. but also very sad. they have a room set as a replica of how all the prisoners lived, which is really heartbreaking the rest of the prison is like a museum with all the relevant facts and details. was very cheap to get in and worth a look at.

Propaganda Prison. The Hanoi Hilton was a propaganda prison during the Vietnam War (or American War depending on where you are from). And it still is. Although the vast majority of it is devoted to the horrors of the French occupation and not to the war. I'm glad I went but it wasn't a highlight.

Do your homework first. We decided to go on this tour because someone had described it as a 'must do'on any trip to Hanoi, and maybe it is. Maybe. The reason I say 'maybe' is because I feel that a little bit of prior knowledge is a prerequisite for any visitor. I will explain why. The impression that you are given is that the prison was built by the French for the suffering of the Vietnamese, and I have no doubt that it was a hellish place. The bit that I found a wee bit irksome was the almost small-print-like part of "oh, and we had a couple of Americans here but we made it a bit of a holiday camp for them!" I get that there are always two sides to a story, and somewhere in the middle is the truth, but when you have seen pictures of when the pilots were captured, in comparison to when they were released, there is no doubt whatsoever that they haven't been having as great a time as the propaganda photographs would have you believe. I think what I am saying is this - go on YouTube and watch a few documentaries about the Hanoi Hilton, then when you visit the place, trust me, read between the lines and it makes for an even eerier experience.

Worth seeing but could do with a bit of work. The prison is well worth a visit. As far as I could see there were no guided tours (same with a lot of museums in Vietnam). There are narratives as you move through the prison but I couldn't help feeling we didn't get the full story & significance of the place.

Interesting accounts of French occupation. Good insight into life under French occupation and 'rose' tinted view of treatment of American prisoners?Well presented and informative, guillotine is macabre!
Well worth a visit. Very interesting, learnt much and well worth a visit. As some have said there is an eerie feel to the place and you can almost hear the walls talking to you!

A slanted view made for public display. The French imprisonment of the Vietnamese was displayed emphasizing the atrocities committed. The Vietnamese imprisonment of the Americans was displayed as if the prisoners were attending some private, vacation getaway: basketball, movies, chess, happy times. This traveler hopes that someday a more factual display will be presented.

2011 visit. This is one place that has to be visited albeit a little depressing. The conditions of the prisoners was terrible and there is still the guillotine which they used to execute prisoners. There are lots of photos of how it was with explanations of the different conditions for the Americans and Viets. It's a place which is cheerless but has to be visited.

A different spin on history. As an American who grew up hearing tales of the "Hanoi Hilton," this was number one on my sightseeing list. You'll see John McCain's flight suit and other artifacts of the American pilots who were confined here, but the focus of the exhibit is on the French colonial period when the prisoners were Vietnamese who schooled each other on Communism while held captive. Still, you will come away with respect for those who endured this place, no matter what side you are on.
suprisingly good. We hadnt planned on going here on our walking tour of the museums in hanoi but it turned out to be very interesting... well worth the visit

Do not miss!. This museum has an interesting (albeit sad) exhibition mostly of the political prisoners during colonial times. You'll see the original prison cells and some personal items that the more famous prisoners used. The museum is well-maintained and overall a very interesting experience although a lot of information wasn't translated into English, which was a bit disappointing.

Interesting exhibition. Wasn't sure what to expect given mixed reviews but we found it very interesting. It looks at the uses of the prison by the French and the Vietnamese. Most things have an explanation/are translated into English making it easier to understand. Whilst the phrasing of the display boards is a little one sided, it doesn't detract from the experience. Well worth a quick visit.

A really good short visit in Hanoï. I went in this place having absolutely no idea of what it was (except a prison, of course). Contrary to other reviews, I never felt English information was missing.Many places uses mannequin to show how the prisoners were tied inside the prison.Just be warned that some places inside can be really hard to see for some people. I've seen a few persons cry when going out of the "Death row" part. This part is really well staged, giving a small idea of how bad the conditions were there.You might find some information is very biased, especially the parts about the US soldiers for which they show absolutely nothing but the best (and the worst for Vietnamese), just keep your critical mind active.

Worth a quick visit.. The visual displays at this prison were great and gave an insight into the life of the prisoners, however most of the written information was in Vietnamese only with very little English so it was difficult to grasp a full understanding of the history the occurred here. Keep in mind that TripAdvisor states there is no fee as when we visited, the fee was 40, 000 per adult.

Eye opening. It was definitely a good experience to come to Hoa Lo Prison to learn more about the Vietnamese resistance against the French. Not all plaques are in English however, with some only being in French or Vietnamese (although most also have English). What we weren't expecting was the bias against the American soldiers which was highly evident in the last half of the museum. Throughout the first half they spoke on plaques about the atrocities that the Vietnamese resistance went through. However in the last half they spoke about how bad American soldiers were for bombing Hanoi but how well they were treated while kept in Hoa Lo Prison. This is far from the truth as they were kept in the same cells and bound in the same foot shackles as the Vietnamese did all those years earlier. Overall it was an informative tour and quite eye opening to see some of the objects that were used and the death row cells.

Interesting. An interesting prison that gives you a mental image of what these prisoners may have gone through. I enjoyed seeing the holding cells and mannequins which represented prisoners. They also have lots of artefacts on display like a guillotine, old clothes and other things. Definitely recommended if you have time.

Hoa Lo Prison. This was a very educational look into life in a prison in Vietnam as well as a look at how the American POWs were treated during their time in Vietnam. It is a look at how lucky they were in how they were treated compared to the prisoners that had stayed there previously.

Worth a look. We recently visited this attraction in July 2014.Well worth the visit - plenty of information and displays around the place for you to get a feel of what the conditions would have been really like - especially in the solitary confinement cells or on death row.there is a large display about the american prisoners and it does depict how well looked after they were - but i'd take that with a grain of salt. I do think that it could have been worse for the political prisoners of the time - but hey, i'm not a historical expert on the subject.Conditions looked to have been fairly brutal all round.

Entertaining with children. My 2 daughters loved it!!, interesting , cool, scary...are their words. Worth a visit to break your shopping in hanoi. Interesting outlook on history.....guillotine on display... Glad we went.

Not to be missed for its history. I loved my visit to Hoa Lo Prison better known as Hanoi Hilton. It's one of those things you have got to do. It was a prison used by the French colonists in Vietnam for political prisoners, and later by North Vietnam for prisoners of war during the Vietnam War. The prison was demolished during the 1990s, though the gatehouse remains as a museum.

Interesting piece of history. The prison offers an insight into the history of Hanoi and the French rule that once reigned. The guillotine is still fearsome looking and displays are well put together. There is also some interesting insight into the way the American War was thought about in the North.

confronting for children. we were staying quite close to this prison and did the tour with our 9 and 11 year old daughters. There is a few sections where it is quite confronting for young and inquisitive children, but that is, after all, why we were there. Such an eye opener as to how blatant the propaganda is regarding the Americans.

I know its old - but jump into the 21st Century!... We were very keen to visit - but it was disappointing. The only interactive item has two headpieces in English - one of which was broken and the translation was almost incomprehensible. For not much effort on behalf of the museum, this could have been a fascinating insight into this rich historical museum. Yes, yes, its skewed to one view point but you expect that and cant care about that. I had hoped for a few more photographs and 'fact' ,and less clay models and questionable painting of walls. I didn't learn much or get much of a sense of the history at all.

Very touching. A must see. Although most of the prison has been removed for space, whats kept has been very well preserved and set up with plenty of statues to offer a first hand glimpse into the life of political prisoners in the past. Enough has been left to offer a complete experience. The prison is very chilling and touching, and makes one thankful for the lives we have today. A humbling and eye-opening experience. One of the best historical prisons I have visited.

Definitely add this to your "to-do" list.. I thought this would be a quick in-out visit, but twice we thought we were finished, and found another room with artefacts to read about.Very eye-opening experience, with a lot of interesting facts to offer. My only issue was a lot of the documents detailing events and life at the prison were only translated from the original French to Vietnamese. However everything else is fine. A great piece of history that we found really interesting and educational. A must see as far as I'm concerned.

Very insightful. If you're into history this is a must see. You get a real feel what life would have been like within the prison, whether it's entering a cell which you learn would have been cramped with 15 people or reading the literature.

An incredible look at Vietnam's history. Originally built by the French to imprison Vietnamese political prisoners, and later used by the Northern Vietnamese to imprison captured American pilots including John McCain, the prison remains largely intact with exhibits demonstrating the conditions kept during imprisonment. This experience was reminiscent of Robben Island and Constitution Hill in South Africa. It is always fascinating to see the way prisoners have been treated in various places at different points in history but certainly gives insight into the mentality of the Vietnamese revolutionaries as well as explaining how some of the people later considered heroes of the wars got their start. One can't deny the bias presented in some of the photographs and messages but at the same time you cannot get this perspective on the war in the U.S. This was an integral part of the trip from an educational and historical perspective.
Chilling.. But must see. This is a must see, but it's hard hitting stuff. I don't know how much of it is propaganda, but I do know that this has a dark place in the history of Vietnam.

Go with an open mind. I agree with other reviewers that some of the information is a little biased. However, the further I travelled in Vietnam, I realised that there are many versions and insights to War in Vietnam be it French, American, or Communism. This is one version. I was happy to have no guide and to absorb the information at my own pace

View-changing experience. We were thoroughly intrigued with the information and factual evidence presented to us during our visit to the prison. Our views of the historical context of the conflicts between the French vs Vietnamese and the US vs Vietnamese were altered by what we were seeing and this was confronting. The power of propaganda was highlighted for us all and it was definitely worth the visit. Both myself and my husband found ourselves questioning everything we have heard about these conflicts in the past, while our teenage son learnt much about the cruelty and manipulation of information during conflicts and war. The interior areas have split system air conditioning operating which helps greatly with the time we wanted to spend absorbing all that we were experiencing. Take plenty of cold bottled water with you.

Hanoi Hilton. We got in a little late so didn't have time to go through it too much. I guess a lot of it was demolished for the modern building next to it but what's left does represent a big part of recent history. It certainly shows that no ones hands were clean in the colonial and post colonial time. I wouldn't think it would rock many people's world unless you were aware of the details of the Vietnam / American war. but certainly worth a visit.
Chilling tales. Brilliant to go see, and some real chilling tales to be found, well worth a visit. the Hanoi Hilton, great storey about the escape.

Real history.. A visit to the "Hanoi Hilton" is a very moving experience. The prison is much reduced in size but what is left is well preserved and presented. Plenty of English narrative by the displays which makes this a very interesting place to visit.

A prison from the French era. Maison Centrale situated next to the Hanoi Hilton hotel. Also known as Hoa Lo Prison it was built in 1896 by the French to house Vietnamese political prisoners opposed to the French regime. A diorama in the prison shows how the prisoners were usually shackled to the floor where they could easily be beaten by guards. Vietnamese prisoners were also executed here by use of a guillotine which is displayed near the prison’s infamous dungeon. The prison was later used for American POWs, usually pilots caught when their planes went down. Most of the prison was demolished in the mid-1990s for commercial use. Only part of the prison exists today as a museum. The displays mainly show the prison during the French colonial period, including the guillotine room, still with original equipment, and the quarters for men and women Vietnamese political prisoners. An interesting exhibit here is piece of underground sewer door through which prisoners escaped from this prison between March 11 to March 16, 1945.
excellent. this prison so nice and that place save so much picture about the war of vietnam to france, special some video about so much vietnam hero, they are so hero and i like this place

Laced with proproganda. This museum displays definitely had a bias, which may offend some Americans. It also doesn't show as it was during the Vietnam War. Having said all of the above I was glad I visited. It was well worth the visit. I recommend it to ev

Well documented. A very interesting museum, well refurbished, you can really understand how it was during French colonialism and by Reading the text in French you can realice that it is not propaganda and it was really that cruel sadly.

A must see by all westerners. Went there with an open mind which soon turned to sadness after realising what the prisoners had to endure. War of any kind is a terrible thing as we all know it. Both sides suffered with heavy loss of life and limb. " How can any human being take another person's life ? Even in war everyone has loved ones left behind "

Gives you a small taste. As the place where John McCain was held, it was high on my list of places to visit. Much of the compound has been taken over by a Singapore Hotel so you get to see only a small portion. There is enough to keep your interest for at least an hour if you read everything and watch the videos.

Just propaganda. . I really dont know what I was expecting but it certainly wasn't that. The whole museum just stunk of propaganda. The dramatic contrast between the 'horrible' treatment by the french and the 'luxurious' treatment of the Americas was quite overpowering and frustrating. I do not doubt that the french treated the prisoners poorly but there is no way I can believe that the Americans lived it up playing guitar and basketball the entire time that they were there. If you're interested in seeing the propaganda for yourself go, if not then give it a miss.

Visit left me anger. I have to agree with the other reviewer who called the visit "over the top" in telling the history of the American's held here during the Viet Nam war. The photos made it look like a stay in a Hilton when history tells us different. The displays of the French use is equally unsettling.

Worth a visit. If you have time whilst in Hanoi this is an inexpensive yet interesting place to visit. You have the opportunity to see the cells the French held the Vietnamese policitcal prisoners in, there are lots of pictures and information to read. At the end is an exhibition about the Vietnamese capture of the Americans during the war in the 'Hanoi Hilton'.

Amazing. Dont miss it, it is a little bit one sided view, but is good to see how this was, and how the prison developed from the start. The French kept the Vietnamese in terrible conditions, makes Guantanamo seem like a pleasure camp.

No tour guides??. I arrived expecting to he asked if I wanted a tour guide, or be swarmed with people approaching me for a tour, but unfortunately wasn't. I think this would be a much better experience on a tour and just walking around and really board after board doesn't set the scene.Only a small amount of the ground remains now dies to local building. This tour was interesting but deff would suggest a tour guide.

Very interesting. Needed to fill in a an hour or two, so gave the jail a bit of a look, easy to find, short walk from Old Quarter. Lot of interesting facts but just a shell of what was quite a large jail in its day. Worth while to see

A historical place. Unless you're a history enthusiast, you won't find this place very attracting. It was formerly a prison used during the Vietnam war. The cells exhibit the remaining prison tools and furniture and some historical facts.
A half-an-hour tour for average travelers.
Eerie feel as you walk around. Terrible cruelties were inflicted here, and you can still sense the tragedy and pain. Take a local guide to enhance your experience.

Not what everyone talks about. The prison guardhouse is a museum to commemorate the replacement of a successful Vietnamese pottery facility by a French prison to house local dissidents. The fact that some American pilots were held there is secondary. Terrible place to be in

House of Propaganda. Ok I get it, there are two sides to every story. Seriously though there's a whole section of this museum showing photos of captured American Soldiers in the prison playing cards, playing volleyball, decorating Christmas trees, etc showing how well the prisoners were treated all the while calling the war the "war of American Aggression" I don't expect the Vietnamese to have the same view of the war as the US but this was over the top and ruined the museum for me.

Interesting and educational. My family enjoyed looking through the jail and found viewing the cells and solitary confinement areas confronting. My teenage girls were amazed at how poor the conditions must of been for inmates.
A must see. We really enjoyed going through the prison and reading about its history. We went late in the afternoon and found that there we could view the exhibits at our leisure.

Lots to think about. Of course history is written by the winners, so this 'museum', which is the preserved section of a jail first built by the French to incarcerate the revolutionaries seeking independence in the late and mid 20th century, has all the script that Vietnam wants you to hear. The French were brutal to them and the Vietnamese were model jailers to the American POWs. Suspect accuracy notwithstanding, it is undeniable that the French treated their colony with an iron fist. It is also pretty amazing how much of the American POWs was preserved. Even what they claim is John McCain's flight suit is there. Definitely worth the trip to reflect on how much Vietnam has suffered, being the unwilling battlefield and colony of China, France and the US over the last centuries.

Important Historical Site in Hanoi. This prison and center of torment throughout 20th century Vietnam is well worth a visit. The Hanoi Hilton part of the prison which housed American POW's is no longer there. It was torn down to make room for a 5 star hotel. The prison pre-dates the American, so one can see the French and Vietnam prisoner confinement cells and places of torture. Lots of propaganda films and signage, but it was war, and the Vietnameese were largely the victims over a period of 80+ years. Interesting place, and historically important.

Interesting place. It's definitely an interesting place to visit, though filled with propaganda in one section. The exhibits can be split into 4 broad parts: the French colonial period and the mistreatment of the Vietnamese, a section honoring the generals who were detained in there, a section honoring all the detainees in there, and a section on the humane treatment of the American soldiers by the Vietnamese in comparison with the cruel treatment of the Vietnamese by the French (although we know that that isn't completely true either).If you have about 2 hours to spare, and you're interested in the Vietnamese narrative of the American-Vietnam War, do take a trip down to take a look.

A really interesting museum. A grea tmuseum with some interesting history (highlight pics of Sen McCAin and his suit). The place is very hot (not much AC) - a really well put together museum with English translations. Check it out.

Full of propoganda. Although it was interesting to see, we did find the propoganda a little overbearing at the prison.
Worth seeing as it is so cheap, but not a massive amount to see.

Very interesting and worth a visit. We enjoyed the displays and information. We're able to take the kids there although they were quiet disturbed by the guillotine and pictures of severed heads - that took some explaining and reassurances... Good to see a Vietnamese perspective to the war.

Must see while in Hanoi. This visit takes one back through times of war, destruction, crimes and unfairness. It is an interesting visit to understand Vietnamese people and culture, what they have been through.
There are 2 sides of it, Vietnamese and AMerican. Keep an open mind while visiting both, as it is bias.

A place of torment.. Not sure how I feel about this place, I guess a lesson in history. The way people were treated is terrible. The way it has been setup is quite good giving you an understanding of what it was like to be jailed here. Well setup and somewhat interesting.
Fascinating. Hanoi Hilton is the nickname of this creepy prison. It is definitely worth a look if you'd like to learn about its history.
Scary. Keep an open mind with this visit as there are two sides to every story , I am glad that I wasn't locked up there !!!!
Must see on the visit!. It takes you back to the times of war and destruction. Very important to understand Vietnamese culture and its people!

Slanted, but interesting nonetheless. I studied Criminology at university, and I absolutely love prisons, and go to as many as possible overseas.Hoa Lo prison was one of the best I have seen. Despite most of the prison having been demolished, a fair portion remains and you are still able to see the cells, detainee living conditions and even the original guillotine.In true Vietnamese style, the first half of the prison shows how atrocious the French were, and how the heroic Vietnamese prisoners fought back. The second half shows how atrocious the Americans were, and how the Vietnamese still treated them very well anyhow.I enjoyed the John McCain flight suit, and the pictures of American soldiers in very solemn poses eg. "soldier decorates Christmas tree", "soldier plays tennis", "soldier receives mediacal care from trained doctor" etc etc. If you accept that the prison shows a very manipulated version of history, you will enjoy the experience.Personally I find the way Vietnamese operate official buildings and present certain information in museums a true experience in itself, and absolutely fascinating for westerners who are used to more objective presentations of historical events. just remember to do some of your own background research afterwards, it will make the whole experience that much more enjoyable.

Interesting history. I don't know if this is a fun visit but certainly memorable and the important. Great amount of difference in their accounts to what the released POWs said but that makes it important to read. Always two sides to every "argument" or war! It made us seek out McCain's account though and so my kids and I learned more about history. Plan about an hour here.

Worth seeing. We visited a few museums during our trip in Vietnam and this one was the most interesting, plus, it has A/C! You get a lot of context and plenty of information (even if it's biased in a "pro-Vietnam way). The few cells they show are fascinating. If you speak french it's even better since they kept a lot of documents from the French colonization era. Totally worth seeing!

Interesting. Interesting to learn some more about the famous "Hanoi Hilton". I think my favorite part was seeing the depiction of how US prisoners were treated during the war. It contrasts significantly from accounts given by former POW's, (e.g. there are photos of prisoners laughing over board games and receiving their departure souvenirs) but also goes to show everyone is entitled to their side of the story :). Worth the trip.

Hoa Lo Prison. A very sombre experience. We had heard of the "Hanoi Hilton" but had not realised the prison was set up by the French and were appalled at the atrocities the Vietnamese suffered during their occupation. The American war also is covered as it was used to inter American prisoners of war. The guillotine present added to the experience. The use of mannequins in displays also was mind blowing. Well worth a visit to see how prisoners have been treated.

Well worth visiting. The prison is in the central part of the city and the few remaining blocks of the old prison contain a series of exhibitions about the history and types of prisoners incarcerated there. It is an open and frank recollection of the conditions faced by inmates

Fascinating if a bit distressing. No holds barred exhibits of life was like for prisoners in wartime Vietnam. Some areas are very dark (literally)and watch your steps as there are some uneven steps and paths.

Difficult to see. As a Vietnam Veteran, History made me see it. Propoganda made it difficult to view. More about the militant Vietnamese people who were held prisoner, than the American prisoners. A must if you visit Hanoi just for the historical aspect, but as an American difficult to consume.

Stand in solidarity with the revolutionary hero's of north vietnam. I found this museum to be humbleing. As a revolutionary socialist I was blown away at the solidarity my comrade showed with the other inmates.A must when visiting Hanoi
Slice of history. Loved this prison. Was interesting to see the conditions of the prison and also see how they were treated.

Thoughtful. I was aware of some of the events that happened at this prison but not all. Especially the French influence. If you want to understand Vietnam's recent history you must visit. You will leave feeling somber.

Interesting place. We had local university students as guides. It made it all the more interesting and they were also willing to answer questions from other travelers. The difference to how the Americans were treated in comparison to the French a few years earlier is astounding.

"Hanoi Hilton"...Hoa Lo Prison. I didn't see this until I had been in Hanoi over 15 times. I'm the right age to reflect upon the American war in Viet Nam but never having been a big war buff I only went almost out of obligation. Not my favorite sight in Hanoi where there are so many more elevating things to see. It would just depend on how you felt about this moment in time. On the other hand it merits only about a half hour so what the heck. There are other more interesting sights nearby. The Citadel, Ho Chi Minh tomb, etc.
"Hanoi Hilton". Unbelievably grim. Extremely tough on allied prisoners- some for years. The French had used same facility to house their Vietnam prisoners yesas before.
Prison. have so much hero of vietnam at the war vietnam with france from 1945 untill 1976, have so much the video, picture about army of USA stay here at that year.
Hanoi Hilton & the Vietnam War. Looks can be deceiving. What a hell hole prison this must have been. Be sure to see every nook and cranny.

History that's a 'must' to see. We enjoyed looking at what remains of the prison and listening to the audio as we stood over the model of what the prison once looked like. The prison was full of history and atmosphere and something that needs to be seen to understand the history of the people and all that they suffered and experienced whilst incarcerated here. Some of it was heart breaking to say the least and put chills up my spine.... But I'm glad we went there.

Wish I would have known. Was surprised to see Trip Advisor ask me to review this. When I was in Hanoi, the tour guide I hired said "Oh, that building no longer there. Torn down." Now I see differently. Hmm... Now I'm kind of bummed.

The 'Hanoi Hilton'. A bit difficult to track down as it is on a side street. Well worth a hour or so of time to see the history of this prison from French colonial times to the 1960's where US POWs were housed

How brave Vietnamese people are. to be honest, even i'm a Hanoian as i was born and grown up here, i recently have visited Hoa Lo Prison. it impressed me so much. i have to admit that i feel very scary because of the atmosphere here. however, at the same time, it makes me so proud of my people, my country. It makes young people like us treasure what we've got today:)
depressing. I don't know why anyone would want to go? Big mistake for me. But I know some people like to look at this sort of stuff, like the cells and the stocks, not me.

Good wee trip. Visited few days ago with my daughter, well worth a visit - it's not huge, can be done in couple of hours. Very atmospheric and informative, if you're in hanoi pop by, only 20000 doing entry and worth every bit of it.

Worth a visit. A little spooky and interesting prison. Worth the entrance fee and it's worth a visit if you're in Hanoi. Probably the most interesting attraction of the ones we visited. (Etnlogogical, History museum)

Hanoi - Hoa Lo Prison - Different to the prison in Phu Quoc but same message. This was a really interesting place and fairly inexpensive at 100,000 Dong. Interesting in a number of ways. Firstly the set up is more like a city prison, which of course it is, but it seems like a relatively small prison whilst it covers many more conflicts in Hanoi's history beyond the American War. Secondly the building layout is intriguing. There's not so much a run of cells as opposed to various areas for different activities and as such the display areas and information do a great job of describing what went on when the prison was active. The other interesting issue here was for me to compare how the prison describes the treatment of its prisoners, particularly the American prisoners, with that of the prison we visited on Phu Quoc Island. Hoa Lo Prison was a north Vietnamese prison and so held, amongst many others, American prisoners. Phu Quoc was south Vietnam and held North Vietnamese prisoners. Now I fully appreciate that no one really knows what went on in these places unless you were there and I also am sensible enough to know that what is depicted in the west is also not necessarily true, but the contrast in how prisoners were treat from the north and south of this wonderful country, even with an open mind, is hard to believe. In Phu Quoc the North Vietnamese prisoners were caged and tortured as we are told whilst here they celebrated Christmas if we believe the messages and pictures on show. I find this hard to believe in both instances. Not necessarily turning this around the other way, but certainly not to the extent that the north Vietnamese are portraying themselves as being victims in one sense and humble peaceful guards in another. I don't know the truth with these places and nor will I ever find out. I am not for or against either side but would wish to have a little more equality in what is presented to me. A view maybe from both sides, something which I also found difficult to comprehend with the museums in Saigon. Still, this is an interesting place nevertheless and I enjoyed it really.

Haunting. Some of the cells are haunting, especially the death sentence block; there is a sense of dread when you enter the rooms with leg shackles and wooden benches. You get a real sense of how terrible it must be, trapped in a dark, uncomfortable, cramped space with so many others. The information about the rebellion and escape attempts was great. Seeing John McCain during the war and then revisiting after was surprising.
must see!. interesting site. experience the sad and tragic life of prisoners in the 1900s. you get to see the USA pilots POW during the vietnam war

Interesting & worth a visit :). The prison is situated not far from Hoan Kiem Lake where you can just walk there. The entrance fee is 20.000 VND per person. It's quite an interesting place to visit. I suggested all visitors came with an open mind. Grasp as much info as you can and filled in the void with other extras research or reading on your own. After the visit, I'm sure you'll have a little bit more knowledge about the prison and the history before you stepped inside the prison. Again, visit with an open mind :)

Please Spare Time to Visit. First of all, I want to acknowledge the reviews that says there is propaganda in many of the displays and captions. I love history and the only reason many people don't swallow the ones here as easy is because it's not at all subtle especially in stark contrast of what is being taught in the Western Schools. Yes, there is propaganda but I have no doubt there were some too in every school's history books so visit this place, read and absorb everything here with a pinch of salt because really unless you've lived it no one really knows the truth. Come here to learn about what the Vietnamese had to go through during the French Colonization and American-Vietnamese War.This museum is located behind Somerset Grand Hanoi - in fact Somerset Grand Hanoi stands on where more than half of the prison used to be. I've never found a clarification of where this part of the prison was intentionally taken down or otherwise.Upon entrance you turn right and you will be greeted by photos of the building during different periods, a map and a diorama. The original prison door is on display in one of the earlier rooms. Next is items during the daily lives of the prisoners, clothes, bowls, shoes, etc and the next room is where they kept the prisoners - two stages on either side of the room where the prisoners would sit and their ankles would be in chain. The toilet is at the end of the room - on a stage too. It wouldn't have been very pleasant for them. Outside there is the sewer doors on display, the prisoners went through this to escape - it is tiiiiiiny, probably about 20cm by 35 cm.Right after the souvenir shop is where I think where you can start to question the objectivity of the museum, they display photos from around the world where demonstrations were help in opposition of the war. After a couple more exhibition space it gets a little bit graphic where the guillotine is displayed.This is a very interesting museum to visit, I think it's a little pricier than other places of interest in Hanoi (we paid VND 100,000 per person, about $5) but I reckon this place is well looked after. It's a strong reminder that war never benefits anyone.
Very interesting. Would recommend for travelers wanting to learn about the history of Vietnam. set out in different parts showing the prison uses in different times.
Expected a bit more.... This place isn't bad considering you are only paying a dollar to get in. There are plenty of things to read and I would say it is worth visiting.

Worth a visit. It was nice to see, but don't expect anything authentic. Everything that's left is the building. The explanatory signs are riddled with propaganda. There is some memorabilia displayed and some heart breaking images. I would recommend going but I spent most of the time comparing it to my visit to the prison in Phnom Phen and it left this experience a little lacklustre.

Watch out for the fake American silver dollars. The museum itself is fascinating, propagandistic and brought me to tears as I looked at the photos of American pilots who were so very skinny during their incarceration. Watch out for the fake American silver dollars, likely imported from China, that are sold in the gift shop. My coin shop suggests that these fake silver dollars are sold to Americans all over China as well.

Interesting history.. What can i say, as someone who love history i really love this kind of place. The location is not really far from the Hoan Kiem Lake ( 15/20 minutes-walk). This place is small since they did some renovation but they keep some of the rooms like the way it is and so neat. It was nice to know the reason and story behind "The Hanoi Hilton" .

Favorite place in the city. We really liked the prison. Yes, we realize it's slanted, but that is okay. It was interesting to see and read the information. It's small, and takes less than an hour, but definitely worth seeing.

interesting building, some neat exhibits. This is a very well preserved building. They have some neat exhibits and great history. It would have been great if they had some audio tour. Would recommend if you are nearby. You can walk through quickly if you dont have much time.

Gruesom museum definitely worth a visit. This museum does not spare any details and is rather nationalistic. Very interesting history though and definitely worth a visit. Notice the anti-colonial sentiment.
Interesting. Interesting museum for an hour or so, as long as you take some of the information provided with a bit of a pinch of salt.

underwhelming. Was a completely underwhelming museum initially but - when it got to the section on women's prison cells- it got a bit eerie. Very slanted museum but did like the model of the original prison - it gave a sense of what the place had been.

Meh..... I could take it or leave it. I've do e a few prison tours in my time and this one is okay but lacking. The information is very Viet slanted and you know in your heart that it's mostly truth being twisted or that lots is being left out. Also, it's quite small, with only about 1/10 of the original compound surviving. You should not feel like you've missed out if you don't go there.

Hoa Lo Prison. I think because it is behind the Hanoi Towers, and easy to understand. It is a facility not so big, but it accurately reproduced the state of the camp of the Vietnam War era, because of its exhibition, it reminded fear of war, misery again. I think also in order to know the end of the history of Vietnam negative life has taken, and that we should visit.

Worthwhile, but don't expect much about American POW's.. I had visited about 5 years ago when there was a gallery depicting American pilot POW treatment there; it has now been removed and the focus is almost solely on the pre-1954 era.

Interesting prison with propaganda. I'd read that this prison was full of propaganda, and after visiting I agree with the previous comments about propaganda. They really do not like the French and I am now a little confused about why Hanoi holds its French heritage so dearly, but called French "evil" amongst other provocative phrases. It was also a shame as there was no real explanation as to why Vietnamese political prisoners were imprisoned here. The prison itself was great and is located in a lovely old building that has that colonial charm. For me the highlight were the cells for the condemned, I had stopped reading the propaganda signs by this time however I still found this part of the prison was really creepy. Well worth a visit, but take the propaganda with a grain of salt.

Valuable site to see. This site is know as Hoa Lo prison under French time where Vietnamese young leaders were kept. We at Cosmos Travel Vietnam Co., Ltd recommend this monument to our travelers from Australia and the USA. The museum is worthy for who served as veterans of America coming back for a holiday.

Pretty good.... This was an interesting site to visit. Old prison used by French colonists as well as by the Vietnamese for American POWs during the war, including John McCain. Much of the prison is no longer there, as there is a hotel that was built on the site, but a good portion remains. It was good and worth the visit to see the history and how life would've been like if somehow you got stuck in there!

Informative - but do expect a 'bias'. Some good displays here explaining how the prison was used under the French and then by the North Vietnamese as a prison for American POWs.All the exhibits are well signposted and plenty of English explanations. The overriding sense you are left with is that the French treated the vietnamese very cruelly and that the Vietnamese in turn were nothing but totally humane to the American POWs that were captured and held here. Irrespective of your belief of this, it is still interesting to see the story told in this way.The atmosphere feels 'heavy' particularly in the large cells where there were prisoners shackled together & there are some other exhibits of smaller cells which may make you feel somewhat claustrophobic. For the more squeamish do also please bear in mind there is a guillotine and some fairly explicit photography.
First Time Visit Maison. This is my first time visited the Jail in other country. I can felt the patriotic and love freedom via their display, photos and videos. Must visit no regret.

Best attraction in Hanoi. This was one of the best organised museums we visited in Vietnam and the best in Hanoi. It has lots of english explanations and is very interesting in its own right. The historical explanations are extreme propaganda and I question how accurate they are but, that kind of adds to the interest.

Interesting and informative.... We stopped by here on our way back from the Opera House area - the prison is not the original size it was, of course, but they have saved a small portion for the museum. Interesting and informative - they show how this spot was a pottery village at one time before the French made it a prison. They have displays for each time period - the village, the prison under the French, and the prison under the Vietnamese. A nice variety of displays and easy to go through either swiftly if you have little time, or slowly - reading the displays.

Super spooky. Very worth the visit!! It's warm inside, but they have fans all throughout.. It was much more spooky to me than Alcatraz, and there were rooms that felt strange to go inside but I would absolutely say it's a must visit on a trip to Hanoi!

its worth visit. its quite easy to find and entrance fee is also cheap. my first impression when i enter i thought i will find something more than i could imagine. a story of french colony in mostly tell you how french torture prisoner is heart breaking. its hurt to see how people tortured and yes its propaganda story but on the other side, the site are easy to learn, english description is almost in every corner and it on well maintenance . its one of good story to know when you are in hanoi.

Real history, annoying propaganda. This is only part of the more extensive prison that existed on this site, but it's certainly enough to get a feel for what it was like. The displays are well done and explanations are available in English for most. Signs guide you along a route so that you see all the rooms without getting confused.While it was surely a horrid place, the jingoism of the text on the displays got tiresome. Nobody doubts that the French were nasty colonialists and prison warders, but then the Vietnamese warders of the American pilots are portrayed as incredibly progressive and humane. Maybe they were. Who knows? The excessive partisan zeal in the descriptions detracts makes you wonder about the truth.By all means, give it a go. Hoa Lo is the real deal for anyone with an interest in history.

So so. It's cheap and quick to whiz around this place which is a plus for me as I get museum legs after a while. It's fairly interesting and most things re translated in English, except for the prisoners' poems and letters, which would make good reading. Lots of info on display but some of it isn't that interesting. Average.
Propaganda. As much as the exhibition in this museum are pretty good and well-maintained but I'd feel I only learn one-sided story from this place. Propaganda at it finest.
Worth Visiting. Visit to the prison is informative, and gets a person thinking about the harsh conditions inmates would have dealt with.
Worth It. Well worth a visit , some of the exhibits and images are confronting ,took about 45 mins to walk around prison would recommend this tour

Hotel Hanoi. This was the prison where the American Pilots were held. It was a gruesome place.Built by the French. Not a " Hotel" I would book a room in. You got a good idea of what life was like there.

History as explained by the victors. I was rather unprepared for the bleakness of the historical Hỏa Lò Prison in Hanoi. The place was a fascinating reminder of the suffering, and both mental and physical torture during Vietnam's long history. Executions were rather common (the guilotine gave me the creeps). The Hỏa Lò Prison was built by the French colonists in Vietnam at the end of the 19th century to hold their Vietnamese political prisoners who were agitating for independence. The French called the place Maison Centrale or Central House, a euphemism for prisons in France. When first built in 1896, its maximum capacity was meant to be 460 inmates but by the time the French colonists left in 1954, conditions in the prison had become so miserable that more than 2,000 people were held under inhumane conditions. During the Vietnam War, North Vietnam imprisoned the American POWs in the same building. Maybe the conditions were no longer as appalling as during the French colonial times but definitely, there were still torture, indoctrination, poor food and unsanitary living conditions. When I was walking along the corridors of this museum, I had to remind myself that propaganda was still very much alive in Vietnam today. After all, the Vietnamese were the ones that had chased out the French in 1954 and won the American War in 1975, and that was all that mattered to them.
Well worth a visit. Some images and talks quite moving and depressingBut definitely worth a visitExplains the history nicely and I learnt lots of new thingsWould recommend

Very Interesting and worth a visit. Went with Hanoi Kids and had a lot explained to us but mostly focuses on harsh treatment by the French towards the Vietnamese some photos very confronting. Worth a visit.

Yes, it's worth visiting - but.... There's no denying that this historic prison was the site of brutal mistreatment and oppression - the atmosphere feels heavy - particularly when walking through the dark communal rooms where prisoners were shackled together & the smaller areas that feature claustrophobic cells. Be aware that there is a guillotine, some graphic photos, and it's quite dark and "creepy" feeling in some parts. It's worth visiting because you get to walk throughout these rooms- and see some of the artifacts used during the French era & American-Vietnam war era. The descriptions are written in French and English, but they're short and don't give a lot of background information other than stating what each item was used for. As mentioned in previous reviews, you should also be aware that there is, unsurprisingly, a lot of propaganda, particularly when depicting the very humane treatment of American POWs. You will see black and white photos of them decorating a christmas tree, smiling as they send letters home, and being examined by doctors when ill. One of the most 'interesting' pieces was one POW's christmas artwork featuring santa clause on some sort of christmas train... if you've ever seen Vietnamese drawings, this piece matches the same very specific style of drawing most Vietnamese students are taught to draw in school. Overall, if you're in Hanoi and debating about going to the prison, I believe it's worth the visit. It's very close to the Old Quarter, historically significant, and it's certainly interesting. Other info: It's cheap ($2), air-conditioned (a sweet, sweet escape from the stifling heat), and it took us about 1 hour to go through (but could be done in 30 min.)

Interesting to have been, but not all believed. For many of we in later life @The Hanoi Hilton' conjures up all sorts of images so it's good to have been. For a very small museum (most of the prison has been built on by a tower block) there is a lot to see and it's very well laid out. Fascinating to see the pre-American war information. As our guides pointed out "keep in mind that you are only seeing one-side of the story". Still, a not to be missed part of any Hanoi visit.

Not at the top of the list. What you will see is a small part of the original prison, the majority of which was demolished in the 1990s. The most interesting part of the "prison" today is the propaganda you will see that emphasizes how poorly the incarcerated Vietnamese were treated under the French, and how well the Americans were treated by the Vietnamese when they were held here. Incredibly, there is a very old guillotine on display from the French period.

Worth the Visit. Went here after the Women's Museum and enjoyed this more, I agree that some of the descriptions on how the Americans were treated were probably different from reality. Took about 45 minutes to walk around and gave a good insight into how this prison operated.

Ha Noi Hilton. We were taken here by our guide and didn't really know what to expect. Not much remIns of the original prison. What got to me was the way the French treated the Vietnamese political prisoners including women and children. Barbaric! I found this place to be rather creepy.
Worth a visit. Only a small portion of the original prison remains, but it is definitely worth a visit. The exhibits are quite good, and the information is interesting.

Can't leave Ha Noi without seeing this. It's a museum of what used to be a prison, rich with history and details, you can't say that you know Ha Noi if you didn't take an hour to see the remains of this place and read every picture explanation.

Propaganda Central. Be ready to read some pretty derogatory comments about the POWs held here during the Vietnam War. A lot of consdecension detected...... some interesting information around the history of Vietnam. Could be skipped really.

Hoa Lo Prison - An Eerie Reminder of the past. Hoa Lo Prison or the "Hanoi Hilton" proved to be an eerie reminder of the past. Some amazing photos of the "Vietnam War" from the perspective of the host country. Though the building has been gutted from it's original form, recreations of cells and proxies of prisoners tell a dark tale of war where many people died. Photos of political prisoners and the torture that went on in these walls are ghastly. As an American, photos of our soldiers, even notable ones like John McCain seem very surreal. An excellent visit the elicits conversations of a very dark past. Well worth the visit.

Confronting. For me this prison was educational and confronting . It was commonly called Hanoi Hilton by American prisoners but was also used by the French to imprison Vietnamese . It is a interesting place to visit and worth the time as it is not far from the Hoan Kiem lake

Interesting propaganda. there are some interesting elements to this prison, but p[potential visitors should take everything in stride as many exhibits and artifacts have been produced to promote the country often lackluster human rights record

Historic prison in Hanoi. We visited the so called 'Hanoi Hilton' today and found it very interesting. The prison is small and well maintained. There are exhibitions covering many years including when it was run by the French to detain political Vietnamese prisoners through to when the Vietnamese managed it for the imprisonment of American POW's. Add it to your things to see and do in Hanoi.

Amazing. Even though there is not much of the old "hotel Hilton Hanoi" left it is still very interesting and a real eye opener as to how people were kept in prison. Cheap to enter and no pressure...take your time.
History displayed in a very communist way. The museum shows a very hard part of the history of Vietnam. But there is too much communist labeling everywhere....

Interesting kind of creepy!. Went here in the morning, as in early morning!
We were like the first visitors. The place was dark and the pieces depicts the dark past of the prison as well. Feels creepy to know that a lot died in this place.
A place that shows how Vietnamese political activists suffered but the American soldiers were pampered.

Definitely worth your time.. We walked from the old quarter to the prison. It was a beautiful walk around the lake and old streets. The prison itself has been restored a little but they've kept some of the original cells and other artefacts. Well worth the 20,000 VND to enter!

A little piece of history. This is a little (literally) piece of history in modern day Hanoi. Ignore the propaganda, come informed, and get touched by the feeling of this extraordinary place. BTW, I passed this small building (just a remnant of the original prison) several times before realizing that THIS is it. It However, it was still worth the visit.
An eye opener!. The Hanoi Hilton was a good example of how brutal incarceration could be in colonial days. Pretty graphic but a must see IMO.
nice. if you stay in old town its better you should take a walk from you hotel in this palace .if i not were there just unbilivable

Used against the Vietnamese and by the Vietnamese. It is worth a visit but not in the top of my list..It was built and used by the French against the revolutionary, and displays some methods of torture, and the hard life of the rebels that were captured. After independence, it was used by the Viethamese on the American war, intersting display about the pilots that were captured and a picture of John McCain. It was nicknamed Hilton Hanoi.

Insight into the past. Hoa Lo Prison tells the story of a tumultuous past and the Vietnamese struggles with the French occupation of their country. There is also information on the incarceration of US pilots during the Vietnam war. There is a real sense of Vietnamese national pride (and a touch of propaganda) shown in the displays but worth a visit.

Interesting. Interesting and somewhat informative and not very busy. I went only to see where Sen. John McCain was kept prisoner for so long …its the only reason why I went otherwise I would not have taken the time.

Really interesting museum. As with every museum in Vietnam this place presents a very one sided view of things but even taking that into account it ius still an interesting museum and definitely worth a visit. It covers everything from its original purpose right up to its use for imprisonment of American pilots and it is one of the better museums we visited during our 3 months in Vietnam.

A sobering visit. I found the prison haunting and was struck by the conditions prisoners were kept in. The mannequin-like prisoners brought the experience a little more to life. A good place to visit and learn some new things.

Not really sure what to think. I was pretty disappointed with the prison. The place is down right depressing and boring even for someone who genuinely cares about historical significance and has some reverence for the past. The exhibits are all disjointed and have very little explanation of what they are or how they fit together historically. Focuses more on displaying a collection of random artifacts than it does on giving an understandable chronological history of what happened at the prison over the course of history (Other than the fact that it was generally a terrible place to visit at any point in time including the present). Half the displays at the prison show artifacts indicating the horrors of the French colonial period, and then the next exhibit is memorabilia from the Vietnam war and celebrates the French as moral allies and supporters against the US. No explanation of how things changed. I would read up on your history before coming here otherwise you will find it just as boring, depressing and confusing as I did. There are much better ways to spend your time in Hanoi.

Worth a visit i. We went to Hao Lo Prison for a visit when we went to Hanoi. Very reasonable entrance fee, Think it was 40,000 dong. Very informative, i wouldnt describe it as a must see, but was glad we went. We were there under 1hr

Worth visiting. The prison is definitely worth visiting - it's interesting and fairly well organized. Definitely tells its story from a perspective that's completely different from the US perspective - it was a little hard to stomach the claims of how well the American POWs were treated. But still, very interesting. We were staying at the Somerset Grand next door, and were surprised (and a little disturbed) to learn that the Somerset is actually on the grounds of the prison - most of the prison was razed in the 90's to make room for a new commercial development, which includes the Sommerset Grand.
Very interesting and a little eerie. Definately worth a visit, it was very informative and interesting. The place has a very dark and sad feeling to it, and you can see why the more you see.

Interesting but under-utilised. A very interesting museum, has a lot of genuine cells, artefacts etc.I definitely think there could have been more information displayed. A lot of the rooms were quite empty and I came away a bit disappointed, I was hoping to learn a bit more than what I did. Most of the information I found I was already aware of before I went to the museum. Take the information on American POWs with a grain of salt. This section of the museum is full of propaganda, which in itself is fascinating, but there's always two sides to history and this museum takes a very one-sided view of its history.Worth a visit if you have the time, but not at the top of the list. And definitely worth doing some prior research if you only speak english as many of the exhibits were in Vietnamese or French.

Worth the visit. Hoa Lo prison did give me abit of a scare. Loads of stories on how prisoners were treated and brutally tortured. It has a dark ambience to it but it's definitely worth the visit and knowledge you learn.

Disturbing but Historic. The prison is worth a visit as it holds many historic moments that still live in modern man's minds. Although much has been removed, enough remains to give an insight into the horrors it held and the sheer terror felt by those inprisoned over time not just the Vietnam War but those Vietnamese who also lost thier lives at the hands of the French. There are cells to view, GI belongings, a used guillotine, and other methods as well as a carved wall and garden that is very moving.

An Interesting Experience. The prison displaces mainly the history during the French occupation as it was built and used by the French colonist. However, there's one section where it displaced a few of the items related to the American war and there it was a uniform worn by John McCain with a picture of him being captured.

"Must see" in Hanoi. The Hoa Lo Prison is certainly worth a 1-2 hour visit. I was there on an afternoon in April 2014, and there were only a handful of other visitors. The experience left me with a sense reverence for those who were imprisoned and suffered there.

Worth seeing and it's crazy to see all these. War is never a treatment for any mistakes made by politics and government. Seeing all the types of Torture they use on prisoners is just confirm my opinion on it. The staff from the box office to the guards inside are both very nice and polite. it's very creepy to see all these and the death cell, the isolation cell, it's crazy. I mea I saw these things a thousand times on the TV and movies but seeing it all in really life and being in these rooms are just all speechless for me you have to see it. It's such a different experience.
Very informative. Good display. One sided as usual but you expect that. Gives a good idea of the hardships suffered by the inmates

Chilling but well worth a visit. I cannot begin to imagine what it must have been like to be imprisoned there, especially with in the death cells and the dungeons. The guillotine and the rows of shackled prisoners in two of the larger rooms really brought to life the terrifying nature of life in the prison. Although it is a very interesting museum, the number of small rooms, some of which are upstairs, make it difficult to find one's way around. The comparaison between the way the French treated their prisoners during the occupation and the way in which the Vientamese treated the shot-down American pilots was very salutory.
prison of propaganda. Worth visiting to see the "other side" of history. Take it with a grain of salt like any "museum". Minimal price and interesting nonetheless.

to visit and realize how many aspect of colonialism were wrong!. Atmosphere into Hoa Lo Prison seems stuck at the time when it was in use by french !it really gives the right idea of sadness and torture! Visiting these places makes u see the hard truth.. the way that other civilizations abused of other people! Is worth to visit this place !!!
Worth the visit. Cheap entry and worth the visit if you a travelling in Hanoi. Interesting to see the conditions prisoners experienced.

know your history before you go. One needs to know the history of French Indochina and the history of the American Vietnam war before one goes to visit the maison centrale. The Hoa Lo prison gives a side of history filled with propaganda which is sometimes difficult to stomach. The French are depicted as cruel and evil, the American pilots emprisoned at Hoa Lo as immature little boys who like to play basketball and have fun. And the Vietnamese as either innocent victims of French torture or as fun-loving buddies who made the stay of the American pilots at Hoa Lo an amusing recreation camp. Pull aside the curtain of propaganda, and the visit of Hoa Lo is more than interesting. The building is well-preserved and one can get a feel of history in it. The prison is big and full of narrow alleys, a big courtyard and an upper floor. The guillotine is better preserved than the one at the Conciergerie in Paris. The open book store in the courtyard has a good choice of books on Vietnam. The entrance fee is 25,000 dong and I stayed for 2 hours to see and read all.

Well worth for only 20,000 VND. Entrance fee is only 20,000 VND per person and the visit was worth every dong.Nice exhibits providing insights into the lives of prisoners during two periods (1. during the French colonization and 2. during the Vietnam war).Visit takes around an hour so if you have some time to kill (or even if you don't), do head over and you will most likely not regret it.

THis is worth a visit. Well worth a visit. As noted in the other reviews, there is some propaganda to work through, however the reality of the place is stark and clearly shows areas of historic significance. Not expensive, and can be visited quickly if time is short.
Interesting. Like all things war related you will be given two sides to the story, the stories here are some I have never heard. It was interesting and sad too, but is worth spending time there

Interesting insight to Vietnamese History. Given the nature of the subject it is quite harrowing to see and be in the place of such tourture, nevertheless this museum is an important part of the histroy of the city and the country, and is definitley worth an hour of your time to learn more about it. I went with a local student guide and I think it really helped to have someone explain and elborate on displays.

Interesting but brutal part of History.. While not the original Hanoi Hilton cell blocks, the displays were detailed and authentic exhibits such as Senator John McCain's flight suit etc on show. 5 star hotel now next door on what would be the former prison cell blocks. A central courtyard area has an alter as well as so e sculpture relating to its grisly history.

A moving and highly educative experience. At first I thought the human figures held in the prison in manacles and so on would render it trite. But the opposite - it helped bring the suffering and cruelty to life. The guillotine was especially haunting. Focus on the days of French colonialism - no the Hanoi Hilton of US POWs.

Well worth a visit. I only went to kill an hour or so but soon became totally absorbed by the history. The entry ticket is very cheap and I was glad I went on my own as I could really concentrate and get a feel of the place. It does seem like a bit of a maze walking through it but should be done by anyone visiting Hanoi.
Worth a visit. Cheap and interesting, but bear in mind this is a communist country and everything you see if definitely sprinkled with a liberal dose of propaganda.

Interersting to visit this place in order to learn more about history. It's interesting to see it in order to understand more about history of Vietnam... You would need between 1 hour to see this place. Ticket costs 25.000 VND, you can get also English guide for another 20.000 VND.

Visually engaging, but lacks substantial background.. What was once a pottery-making community turned into a prison where the French imprisoned and tortured the Vietnamese during their colonization. While only a fourth of the actual building remains, the prison has been turned into a visually-engaging museum of what life was like for prisoners. 3D dioramas of prisoners, torture tools (including a guillotine), and other remnants of the prison's horrific past are on display. While plaques are located near all exhibits describing what you're seeing, you walk away with more questions than the museum answers. Some exhibits seem a bit propagandist, but with reason. A portion of the museum describes its use during the Vietnam-American War, when American B-52 bombers were shot down and their pilots were imprisoned. Nearly all American prisoners made it out alive, and were treated far better than the French treated the Vietnamese. Images of elaborate Christmas dinners and American pilots enjoying hobbies in the prison grounds make sure to point this out. Give yourself an hour here. For under <$2, it's certainly worth a visit. Reading the plaques and the way information is presented gives you an eye into the Vietnamese perspective on both French occupation and the Vietnam-American war, so spend some time doing so. A guidebook is available for about a dollar, which might be worthwhile in providing the background I felt the museum was missing.

history. this was less extensive than i thought. It has many documents and pictures of the vietnamese prisoners under the french. Some areas are pretty awful to see and then imagine people living and surviving there. The cells and execution are horrific. Also it is quite hard to imagine a village standing there not so long ago and being razed for the prison and now in the centre of such a busy city. Certainly looks like a "hanoi hilton" from the portrayal of the gi's imprisoned there. Well worth a visit to reinforce how crappy wars are and how brutal people can be to each other.
On the tourist route. Damning for the French and their colonialist presence in Indochina. Propaganda, but the photos speak for themselves.

Worth a visit to further your understanding. Now a tourist site, but worthwhile visiting to understand more of what happened to prisoners during the French occupation, and the war. In any similar situation in countries like Vietnam, important to remain objective but empathetic. Relieved it's no longer a prison!
Interesting. Slight commie bias, as you would expect but good experience and of purse the historical value of the place makes it well worth a visit

Hanoi Hilton. Wow - the early history of this place is fascinating, and the conditions were truly horrible. This tour provided the first hint of history perspective from the other side. There is an entire wing devoted to the US Air Force POW's and makes for interesting reading. The American and Kiwi's with us were gritting their teeth just a little reading the information provided. That said, this was a very interesting place to visit and the cost to enter is minimal.
mixed feelings. interesting piece of history but very depressing how inhumane and cruel the French colonialists were

Worth dropping by.. As it is so close to the Women's museum, it is definitely worth popping by. It is a the wide pavemented French Quarter, so is a welcome relief from the snarled up narrow streets of Hoan Kiem. It is another propaganda filled attraction, especially with regard to how the American POW's were treated (they had better conditions apparently than i did at my hostel!), but it is still quite an interesting place to visit to gain an understanding of what Vietnam was like during French Colonialism.

maison centrale. Built by the French in 1896 to hold Vietnamese patriotic and revolutionary fighters and more recently to house American pilots shot down in North Vietnam, the prison is definitely worth a visit to see just how inhumane man can be to fellow man.
Tragic history. Tour this prison also known as the "Hanoi Hilton". It is tragic to see how human kind can treat each other. This site will really enlighten you.
impressive. I was touched by the pictures I saw, to see how those prisoners has been treated was very sad. The museum shows very clearly about the history of this period in vietnam.

Compelling. French and American civilization on trial. Originally built by the French, this prison compels you to want to learn more about Vietnam's resistance especially to French Occupation. There is an actual guillotine on display as well as prison cells with restraints occupied by life size figurines set in the natural dim light of the prison as it most probably existed. The worst part is the hotel built on 2/3 of the site. i would have left the entire prison intact as a symbol to mans cruelty to fellow man.

A bit of history and propaganda. This museum is extremely interesting. It dates back to the prison when it was in French control and the way the French treated their captives in the colonial era. It provides an insight to the Vietnamese rebellion against the French and shows the cruel living conditions (male and female) in the prison. It also shows that the prison was not impregnable as there were many escapes through the sewer and storm water canals on the prison.There is also a section on the Americans that were held there during the Vietnamese/US War. The "documentaries" that are shown in this section describes how humane they were to the US airman that were unlucky enough to be captured in North Vietnam. According to the documentaries, it was just like being in a holiday camp. Hence the name given to it by the US servicemen - "The Hanoi Hilton". The recollections of US Senator John McCain (and others), of the US treatment and torture while in the prison are at odds with the documentary. The sculptures on the back wall are well done. It is well worth visiting the museum.

Interesting. This prison was very confronting to see the pictures and all the scripts about what happened in the prison. We caught a taxi there as it is on the outskirts of the old quarters and then we strolled back and took in the sights of the shops and parks along the way.

worth a visit. Interesting to go round and understand a little bit of the history of Vietnam and the see the awfull conditions they had to put up with in the prison dubbed the Hanoi hHlton by the Americans
Well worth a visit. We visited Hao Lo Prison on our first day in Hanoi. Really interesting with lots of information/photos and artefacts. Great to get a good idea about Hanoi's history.

Hanoi Hilton. Thought most of the French historical part of the information provided was very interesting.
Did not seriously believe the informayio regarding the treatment the US pi;ots who were detained here - the kind treatment provided by the Vietnamese people - di not compare to my understanding of the appalling treatment provided to them
