worth to go. It keeps a very small part of prison but i found it worthing to go. However, it shows the positive side of Vietnam a lot and how well they treated the US prisoner. And I have a serious doubt in it.

Interesting visit. Visiting a prison is not something you would normally consider but in going to Hoa Lo you learn something about the history of Vietnam (with maybe a slightly bias view). The exhibits are informative with information in English. During the Vietnam War American air crew were held there including John Macaine. There is also a memorial to the Vietnamese 'freedom' fighters.Your visit can be as short or as long as you like we were there about 45 minutes - there is a small fee to pay

Somber Visit. The visit happened on a grey rainy morning, which made the somber setting even more brooding. Not a very big place so maybe an hour's visit will do, but to me, definitely a visit to remind ourselves of the inhumane levels we can sink to, if we are not careful, in the name of serving "justice". Adequate English captions in the photos, to educate, but the displays are clear enough to show how low we human beings can sink to. An interesting visit for sure

Good visit for an hour. Interesting museum, with lots of photos and some original artifacts still preserved inside. I really liked the guillotine that they display there that was actually used by French colonials! Wow!

A must go place in Hanoi. A must go place in Hanoi. The historical building bring to your the prison story about political prisoners during French colonialism, and it also held American soldiers during the war and American soldiers named it "Hanoi Hilton" because they were very well treated in here.

Hoa Lo Prison. An interesting view of the conditions the prisoners were kept in during the French occupation and also the American prisoners who were shot down in the North of Vietnam. The museum was very warm and stuffy but glad we visited as would not have liked to miss this little gem of history.

Worth seeing if you have time. Came here at recommendation of my hostel when I had a free morning. The prison is small but holds information and exhibits on the history Hoa Lo. First when it held Vietnamese, and then when it held Americans - some of the exhibits are well worth seeing, and nearly all the signs are multi-lingual making it easy to comprehend. That said, compared so some war/prison museums, its not particularly memorable, and definitely not a must see if you're on a time limit.

INTERESTING VISIT. You can pay to get into this prison. it is situated near the Hilton Hotel.I would recommend a visit here it was quite interesting and you can walk around and look in the cells and it also has a video and items you can look at. We spent an hour or so wandering around here.It may be a little daunting for young children as they have dummy models set up in some of the cells so may be a bit scary.

If you have spare time, visit. It´s interesting, but compared to other popular sites in Hanoi I would prefer to visit other places.
It´s a historical site but I would skip it.
Interesting place to visit. Definitely worth a visit. Information is presented in English - the info about the Vietnam War is especially interesting.

Good to see the other perspective. Good to see the other side of the story.
Some of the escape methods looked intriguing and dangerous.

A few interesting exhibits on "The American War". This is the prison (the "Hanoi Hilton") where John McCain and many other American pilots were held during the Vietnam war. We went looking for more historical perspective on what they call "the American war" - There were 2 rooms we found that had information / exhibits on this period, but the rest was focused on the French colonial period (not as interesting to us). Also, the information presented was (of course) quite slanted to their political viewpoint, but we expected that.

Better than expected. Had heard that most of the prison had been demolished with only a small part remaining, so was not expecting a great experience. I was pleasantly surprised as it was interesting & large enough to give you an uneasy feeling of what it would be like to have been incarcerated there.
Nothing excelent could be in prison, but sad. Very valuable to see, but you have to keep your good mood.Guillotine, cells, tortures - what you can expect...

Must see prison. Unfortunately only some of the buildings of the prison remain today but what is there gives you a vision of the enormity of it in years gone by. The museum displays information and artefacts from the revolutionaries during the French resistance. The brutality and cruelty of the French is clearly depicted in the displays and information. There are also displays and information about the Vietnam War, referred to by the Vietnamese as the 'American War'. Interesting museum, highly recommended.

Interesting and sad . Interesting place to visit, at $1 to get in and an easy walk from old quarter it's worth the trip if you can stomach all the horrible stories of torture and suffering but an interesting insight into history, the history is given from the Vietnamese perspective and can be quite graphic. It didn't seem to have a systematic path to follow but had lots of sections tucked away so make sure you have a good look around so you don't miss any sections. Worth a visit.

Chilling and Powerful. I can't say it's an experience you can really 'like' but it was powerfully done. The section regarding the torture of the vietnamese by the French colonials is really not for kids - they have made it very atmospheric and it's pretty unpleasant. The section relating stories of the imprisonment of the American soldiers was fascinating - as much as anything to know how these events are learnt in Vietnam and hence what their version of the 'truth' is. A powerful experience for teens and adults.

the humility of the Vietnamese is here. So this is the Hanoi Hilton. Call it what you want...that's what we know it as. John McCain was here for 5 years. Only 10% of the museum deals with the Vietnam War with the US. Most of it is about the imprisonment of the Vietnamese themselves by the French. And what the French did... well visit and you be the judge. I've been to the Kilmainham Jail in Dublin, Prison in Port Arthur Tasmania, Dachau Camp in Munich and they all share a story of cruelty by man on man. Especially when it's political not real crime. What I really saw in Vietnam is they are not dwelling on the past and the war with the US... they are moving on... a better life that embraces a country that they want to emulate. Totally worth the visit.

More like a museum. The Vietnamese have made the prison area into a museum with staged exhibiits. There is John McCain's flyer outfit from when he was shot down. The history is well displayed and you get a good sense of the use of the prison from the french occupation thru the US war in vietnam. Worth seeing!
very interesting. Worth a visit interesting but also a bit depressing. Gives you an overall view of Vietnam war with USA and the mility personal they capture

Very thought provoking. Not an easy place to find and when asking for directions one guy was very unhelpful and told us it wasn't in the area where we asked him - it turned out to be up the road from where he was stood ! A fascinating place and a salutory reminder of the what happened during the Vietnam War. It is understandably anti American, and does not talk of the Vietnam war but the American War. Well worth visiting.
hoa lo. this place has many stories around vietnam war period. there is also an author which is vietnamese write about it and donate to yale uni.
Gives a good account of history. Not really a place to enjoy as such, but certainly a fascinating learning experience. It's clean, informative and the death row section quite haunting.

Interesting place. The prison had a dark atmosphere in some of the rooms displaying life-sized figures of Vietnamese prisoners in cells and you get a sense for how the prison was used through history (by the French and later to house POWs during the Vietnam-American War. The monument outside in the back courtyard is quite beautiful and a reminder of the effects of incarceration.

Hanoi 'Hilton' worth a visit. The prison is just outside the old quarter and easily accessed by taxi or even on foot. Not all of the old prison remains but plenty to see and the exhibits are well worth a visit. Many references are to the 'American' War and is certainly presented purely from a Vietnamese perspective which is not surprising. Photos, letters and clothing worn by John McCain (US Senator) after being shot down and rescued from the West Lake before spending time in the prison. The photographic exhibits would indicate the US soldiers were treated much better than the locals caught fighting against the French colonial rule. A large guillotine and several isolation cells have been preserved for posterity and give a fair indication of the treatment meted out. There is also a new memorial wall in the old courtyard.

Dark and dusty. Maybe this is deliberate but the museum felt very dark and creepy. Kids who like gruesome stuff will love this, lots of mannequins populate the tiny prison cells. There's a dungeon and a fantastic lit up model showing that once the prison covered an entire city block. Unfortunately the Somerset Grand Hanoi Hotel now towers over the scant remains of this important piece of history. Maison Centrale over the front entrance refers to its use as a prison in French colonial times from 1899-1954. It gained more fame as Hanoi Hilton during the Vietnam war. Next to the prison part of the museum is a 2 storey building stocked with photos and artefacts from the 70's. This is where you will see photos of US soldiers playing volleyball in the courtyard. Don't miss the large memorial wall at the back of the museum, in the remains of the old courtyard.
Too be seen. Great place to see but go through with open mind. Like all displays in Vietnam very political views given. It shows how the human race can be so cruel.

Great big of history. The prison is easy to walk to and offers a great insight into the Vietnam history you only need an hour or two but it's well worth the look and makes a change to the normal tourist trips
A bit gruesome. Very educational.... left the museum knowing and understanding a lot more about the conflicts in Viet Nam's History.
Hanoi Hilton. Very interesting museum about French & American wars in Vietnam. Seems a bit biased although hardly surprising. Well worth a visit. Allow 2 - 3 hours.
Good but unstructured. This museum is worth a visit if you like culture and history. Although the exhibit is good, the structure is confusing, and it's easy to "get lost" in the storyline.

Colonial and war history at the Hanoi Hilton. Must do for anyone interested in history and/or politics. Exhibits with commentary which is inevitably something of a propaganda blitz but in a way all the more interesting for that.

fascinating ..... on a number of counts not least the promulgation of history. as the saying goes, history is written by the winners and that certainly shows through here as others before indicated. Based on extensive reading, I think the descriptions of life under the French were pretty accurate. There was nothing relating to the Japanese that were detained here and the exhibits relating to the American prisoners was probably the greatest piece of propaganda I have ever seen (and i have lived in communist countries for years). Despite that, this was the highlight visit of our stay in Hanoi and definitely worth visiting. Just keep an open mind - and see the reaction of a Vietnamese person if you raise the question of other versions of the history

A great historical (sort-of) tour. Our visit to the "Hanoi Hilton" was much anticipated but better than expected. Although only a small part of the prison has been spared demolition, what is left is well organized and interestingly laid out as a short tour. It was interesting to learn of the history of the prison before it became famous for Americans as the "Hanoi Hilton". As expected, the "history" of the prison, vis-a-vi its American POWs was a complete and utter sham. Expect lots of propaganda and bashing of the American "Imperialists" and "Invaders'. On display is what is supposed to be Senator John McCain's flight suit that he was wearing when he was shot down and dragged to the prison, where he stayed for over five years. Only it is a fake, according to Senator McCain. Also, the constant claims that the American POWs were treated humanely and not tortured flies in the face of much evidence to the contrary. The POWs all claim they were systematically tortured and many have scars to prove it. While the museum claims that the French indeed tortured Vietnamese prisoners, they claim it was a regular "picnic" for the American POWs. They have staged photos of the POWs playing basketball and even decorating a Christmas tree. An online website review of the prison is recommended as it is a pretty accurate description. At $1/person, the entry fee is well worth it, in spite of the laughable propaganda job. As the saying goes, "History is always told from the perspective of the victor."

Worth a visit. I visited here last month hoping to learn about it which I did. I felt like more information would have been good. Gave me a good insight about how the prisoners were living there. The exhibitions were okay too. Lots of written information.Its cheap to visit and was easy to get to for me so visit if you have time.

somber insight. A chilling account how life must have been like for prisoners living in this notorious prison which was built by the French in 1896. It housed many political prisoners. Nowadays a museum, there is also an area showing a section to the American /Vietnam War where shot down American Pilots were brought here. It showed by way of photographs how they fared. You can judge for yourself when you visit.

More detail needed. We made a last minute tour around the prison as we discovered it was open quite near to closing time (having assumed it was closed as most museums do not open on a Monday) so it was a bonus to see around.Whilst the exhibits were interesting we found there was a lack or order and detail - particularly in English. Definitely worth a look though as you'll only pay US$1 to get in

Worth a visit. We visited the prison museum and found it worth our while. It really does give a good and impressive overview of how Vietnamese prisoners were treated under French oppression. Also a lot of photo's and a DVD covering the detention of US war pilots. A lot of the time we found the accompanying exhibition texts to be one-sided and sometimes downright hilarious, but we just smiled and moved on. All in all we found it very instructive, giving a good overview of important history..
Hanoi Hilton. I believe, anyone who goes to Hanoi should see this prison...built by the French for the vietnamese, taken over by the Vietnamese and used for US pilots who were shot down.

An hours behind bars!. Hoa Lo prison is an absolute must on your visit to Ha Noi. Memories of the miseries of French occupation, internal politcal unrest and the civilised imprisonment of American pilots are splendidly preserved and illustrated. Madame Tussaud-like figures now occupy the cells and holding areas once filled by inmates of bygone days. Fascinating graphics displays of clothing, utensils and documents make for an enthralling visit.

Worth the effort......just. Worth making the effort to see the 'Hanoi Hilton' but don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed. The US pilot stuff was interesting, but clear propaganda undertones throughout as you might expect.
Very interesting. I found my visit to Hoa Lo Prison to be very interesting and liked the way everything was laid out. It gives a great impression of how it would have been to be incarcerated here.
History , a must see of Hanoi. Very well presented. Makes you think a bout the human race. Was used even as a prison for the Us pilots. John Mc Cain wsa a guest here in the sixties.

Compelling Historical Site. No American visitor should miss this museum. Of course, they cleaned up the facts to give the impression that captured American pilots were humanely treated (only last week or two an article in the US papers reported the death of a POW survivor who blinked the word "torture" in Morse Code when he was shown on global TV news), but it is compelling nonetheless. It displays an odd affinity for America such as photos of a visit by John McCain, in spite of suffering from heavy bombing by US forces in the "American War" as they call it. Historically, the prison goes back to French colonial days when the Vietnamese rebels were subjected to some pretty barbaric treatment in this same prison. You can sense the resentment still felt towards the French, but not towards Americans. Odd, but welcome.

Interesting!. It was very interesting to see how prisoners were kept and treated in prison and Vietnam. I didn't know that this prison also held women but there was a whole side dedicated to the women that were imprisoned there. There was also a section about the Americans who were held there. It's a must see in Hanoi!

Goosebumps. Not as touristy-trodden as some of the other historical sites in Hanoi, this is a chilling example of the pain suffered by so many during the war. The structure has been updated slightly, but retains its authenticity, with things like the original guillotine and barely unchanged cell blocks. There is a somewhat hidden collection of 3 headsets in one of the first rooms, next to the diorama, and they are worth listening to. They offer a shocking overview of the atrocities that took place here.

Interesting experience. Spent an hour & half looking around, quite shocking the way humans can be so cruel to each other, and how anyone came out alive! Worth seeing even if there is a lot of propaganda!

Excellent experience. Well documented, photographic displays, informative signs, and real examples - can't ask for much more from a museum. There is a small entry fee but is definitely worth it, very interesting. The cells are creepy as any!

interesting, but slightly one sided. A very good way to spend a morning out of the rain and learn a but about different eras in orison history in Vietnam. Some stories, especially about US POWs treatment seem slightly dubious and one sided,but so do many displays in other museums.

History. Wasn't going to se this after some of the reviews, but like all wars each country puts its own spin on everything. Opened my eyes and I followed up with my own research, In the end I was glad I checked it out
Well preserved prison but heavy on the propaganda. Seeing the propaganda that comes with the prison is in itself a bonus. Good attraction, well maintained, polite and helpful staff.
Documents the dark side of colonialism. The prison gives the victor's view of history but was low key and provides excellent documentary and photographic evidence of a very difficult time.

Interesting Place to Visit. The Hoa Lo Prison has a lot of history. Part of the building (the Hanoi Hilton for US Prisoners) was torn down and replaced by a 5 star hotel. The exhibits show pictures of prisoners going back long before the Americans arrived.

Intersting insight into Vietnam's past. I found our trip to Hao Lo Prison to be an eye opening experience. Having not had much previous knowledge of Vietnam's past, with regards to the french or the Americans.  I found it to be quite a harrowing experience, however it was very informitive and educational. I would recomend visiting the prison. There is a small admission fee and then you a free to walk about the prison (what's left of it) at your own pace.

The Hanoi Hilton. We had a look through what is left of the prison, most of it is gone now and only a small part survives. Still interesting to see how the French treated the Vietnamese people in the very early part of the 20th century. There's also a few examples of the cells left including one for the prisoners on death row, very small cramped and damp, so life there would not have been pleasant. There's a section which details the internment of the GI"s who were kept there during the Vietnam war, well worth a look, just to say you've been to the Hanoi Hilton.Entry fee is around a $1.Well worth a visit.

Interesting for All. I am not a big war person, and was unsure as to whether or not I would find this museum too disturbing. It turned out to be extremely interesting and led me to read more about the French occupation of Vietnam. We visited on a Saturday morning and it was not very crowded, so it was possible to see all of the exhibits and read the captions with ease. The depictions of the lives of the prisoners were realistic but not too graphic, so it was OK for my 4 year old son to see them, although after the visit he talked non-stop about the guillotine so that my have been a little too disturbing!

Fascinating. Interesting to see recent history from a different angle! We spent well over an hour here and found lots of things to talk and think about. What were the conditions really like? Not sure now...

Slightly imbalanced view of the war. As you would expect, the exhibits in this museum are enormously biased, but it's still a remarkable place to visit. It's quite grim, so to a particularly fun place to be, but hey, it's a prison. It was quite moving at times but could have been a whole lot better with a bit of balance.

A place full of hardship. The hanoi hilton has seen more than its share and history of extreme hardship and horror. It is set up mainly to show the cruelty of the French to crush the early Viet Minh. The guillotine is a stark reminder of the altimeter fate of many freedom fighters. I am not bashing the French here as they were hard , cruel times for all. The hanoi hilton phase with unfortunate US pilots is a small annex but very important to those who suffered here and elsewhere. POW is a good read to study how these men suffered terrible torture and hardship. How Senator Cain came out so tolerant is amazing. Check out his signature in the visitors book.All prisons are tragic places but this one is very important for many.What is amazing is that they did not shoot the downed pilots out of hand and that they are so welcoming to all westerners today.I honour the Vietnamese fir their tenacity in the face of horrible bombing and destruction but I also honour the suffering of all the political prisoners that suffered in the Maison Central.:-(
History. The children like to wonder here and see how the American pilots had to endure while living here. Interesting and easy to get to if you are taking a city tour from the river.

A must see but not that exciting. You have to visit because you've probably heard so much about it but I didn't think it was that great. You get to walk around through quite a bit of buildings but it just wasn't that fascinating like I expected. I think they 'doctor' up how they treated the Americans to make them sound like they were doing us a favor.

A glimpse into a cruel past. I like the preserved sewer tunnel through which prisoners escaped and the almond tree they sat beneath. I hated the obviously special treatment given to American pilots interned during the war.

Worth a visit. Slightly spooky but definitely worth a visit. We were lazy and got a taxi there from the old quarter which was pretty cheap. Slightly imbalanced view of the war and america etc but lots of interesting things to see and read about. Good if you want to learn about a bit of history.

A must do whilst in Hanoi. I visited the prison this morning. It is a very sobering moment when one first encounters the conditions that the inmates endured. The prison delivers a lasting experience with sounds that just chill you. The memorial within the prison is beautifully done and the accompanying photo's add to the experience. One wonders how anyone could have survived life in there even for a short time. Again a reflection of mans inhumanity to man.

Interesting experience. I visited lots of prison in many countries. This one is not too small and u can spend around an hour here. They play horror music inside some of the cell display which is interesting and make it a bit creepy, lol. But anyway I like it. Admission cost HKD25,000

Lifechanging. Unbelievable! Have been to many prisons, but i did not expect it to be like this. Honestly I didnt think i would be so changed by the experience of visiting the place, but i was. THis prison was called 'hell on earth'. THere were guillotines! The torture seems like something from a Tolkien dungeon, not something of the last century!!!

More than just the Hanoi Hilton. A good history lesson in the life of this prison and its former occupants. It only interred US pilots for a short time. A very interesting look into French colonialism and the fight for independence. There was a contrasting depiction of treatment of the Vietnamese prisoners and the American pilots which I found amusing in a morbid way.

Worth a look. It was good to see the history behind the prison and the North Vietnamese take on what happened. You can spend a good hour or so walking through and there are quite a few information signs in English which helps (this doesn't always happen in Vietnam)

Worth a visit. Clearly full of 'Blatant Propaganda'
If you believe everything you read, the American Pilots were treated really well and were on a 'Summer Camp'
Still well worth a visit.

Modified Prison. I have been to many Prison museums around the world and I felt that Hoa Lo Prison were modified to cater to tourist and lack of it's originality. Perhaps it's the "eerie effect" that's missing. Not up to my expectation with the price paid.

Worth a quick look. Sobbing, weeping visitors made me walk thru the exhibit faster than I otherwise would have. Still, glad I visited. Some reviewers said that one must view propaganda before entering-- not true. Some things had the viet spin rather than the American, but what would you expect??
very recomended. so interesting and brilliant value for money takes a good 3 hours to walk through this prison and never boring highly recomended
Interesting. Appears very small, but you only see a small set up for visitors. Good descriptions about exhibits in english. Small children might not like it, but worth a visit for adults.
Fascinating and Relevant. Traces the prison experience from French Colonials imprisoning Vietnamese, to Vietnamese imprisoning Americans. Doesn't pull a punch, and is dramatic and moving.

Be glad you aren't staying here. This is worth the stop just for the propaganda (they make it look like the US pilots were at summer camp). It would actually be a bit humorous if it weren't so serious what happened here. Anyway, this french-built prison has had quite the history, none of it positive. Still, an important stop when visiting Hanoi.

Very good and interesting. You will needs 60-90 minutes to give sufficient time.Most exhibits have English translation.
Modest entry fee.

Benson Family. Visited late afternoon so was not to busy. Fascinating insight on what went on in this Prison. Some gruesome sights. Liked the parts showing the American Prisoners of the Vietnam war where they stayed in the "Hanoi Hilton"

Gruesome but intriguing. If you want to know about the war and its impact on the people of Vietnam, this is a must do attraction. It is gruesome and often shocking to hear about some of the things the locals were subjected to - but if you come to Vietnam and don't spend time to understand the war - its not done.This was the best attraction in Hanoi as far as I'm concerned.Not for the weak hearted.

Just a museum. It's just a fake building, not a real prison.
I expected to see a real prison and see the realistic and historic one but It was not that impressive.
I don't think It's a good idea to go there.

Nice piece of history. More than malls and parks, if I prefer either going to a spot of history in a place or country, or a natural wonder. Spots where customs and beliefs of the locals took shape. This one is just 20 minutes away by foot from Hoan Kiem Lake.Hoa Lo Prison was carefully preserved and taken care of that most of the significant items on display looked almost close to what it used to. Since it was located in the city center, only a portion of the original prison was preserved. However, it was carefully maintained and developed that it still provides any visitor a glimpse of the life and story of those who were incarcerated. It was a good piece of history, a story to ponder. Worth it!

Hanoi Hilton. I visited here twice. Once by myself and then again on a trip with my mother. I had always heard of the Hanoi Hilton with regards to the Vietnam war, but i never knew the background of the place. it was a great experience (both times!). highly recommend checking it out.

Be prepared for propaganda but definitly worth a visit. it is a bit sordid but it is interesting. there is quite a lot of information on the prison at the time of the French colonisation. the second part that details the use of the jails by Vietnamese to hold American officers held prisoners is...well...er...maybe less accurate? They depict that time as pretty much a summer camp for officers while there have been accounts by the same prisoners of far less pleasant practices in that prison.... But with a critical eye, you will still learn something.

A monument to man's inhumanity to man. Sometimes even those who remember history are doomed to repeat it. The prison was originally built by the French during their occupation to contain dissidents. There is even an old guillotine which was used for executions. Once they left Vietnam, the building was used to house POWs during the "American war." Given the intensity of the American air campaign, the mind can somehow comprehend turning the tables, even if the heart cannot. It's important to see sites like these to remember who we are and what we are capable of.
Hanoi Hilton at its' simplest. Most has now been torn down now and replace by a high-rise hotel. There are still traces of what it must have been like in the days when it held prisoners.

Really neat place to visit. My kids and i visited from Canada recently and having read several books on the topic in the past was anxious to visit the prison. It was well preserved and provided a good overview of the vietnamese perspective of the prison. Keep in mind there are two sides to the story and history like everything and just be open minded.

Worth a visit. Part of the standard Hanoi tour. Quite interesting to see where and how the prisoners were kept during the various wars including the Vietnamese war when American prisoners occupied part of the complex. Difficult to know if everything presented was as cosy as the photos suggest.

The Hanoi Hilton. Great time exploring this museum/jail. There's a ton of info regarding the original purpose of the jail before it rose to prominence in the Vietnam War. Lots of artifacts from the various eras of the prison. It is also interesting to read some of the subtle propaganda in the descriptions of certain exhibits.

Hanoi Hilton - Hoa Lo Prison. Our visit to the Hanoi Hilton, this past summer (August 2013), was informative. When you read how well "the guests" were treated, it boggles the mind. I must admit to thinking that the downed pilots who stayed at the prison for much of the war were not really feelin’ the country club atmosphere described by the posters and other literature at Hoa Lo Prison. Revisionist historians abound in Vietnam. Americans tourists with our pocketbooks full are welcomed with open arms in Vietnam, but the Hoa Lo Prison presentation speaks volumes about the real feelings for Americans, then and now.

Too bias. Although there is no denying that Vietnam has had its fair share of wars and the people are astonishingly tolerant of the Americans, this place makes it sound like it was a holiday camp here and everywhere for the American prisoners and all of the Vietnamese people were lovely to anyone they captured. It is very one sided

Worth the $1 entry. Only half the original prison remains, after an office block has been built on the other half. A good insight from a different point of view about the Vietnam war, and how the French were involved. Takes about 1-2 hours and still has some good photo opportunities.

Sobering. Interesting place to visit and learn about Vietnamese history from a different perspective. It covered both the French and American periods of "occupation". It is not "balanced" but given their invasion history perhaps that is understandable.

Better than expectations. Easy access, well laid out and interesting. A must see not only as the US 'Hanoi Hilton', but for the French war which we didn't know too much about until we made this visit. Enlightening.

Stark Reality. This facility dates back to the days of French Indochina and has a guillotine to prove it. And yes, this is the 'Hanoi Hilton' where American POW's of the Vietnam War were imprisoned, including US Senator John McCain. Viewing the section where the senator was kept has a 'propoganda' feel about it but what can you say about the 'stark reality' of any prison. The existence was anything but pleasant and the outstanding displays make that abundantly clear. Seems somewhat out of place but what a nice gift shop.

An emotional must-see. An honest insight into the appalling conditions and treatment endured by the prisoners. It is very hard to absorb but is a great way to really appreciate how far Vietnam has come and how well it has developed.

An interesting look into Vietnamese history.. Briefly...Vietnam is a nation that has experienced a tremendous amount of pressure and hardship from other nations.Hoa Lo, as physical space, is a small piece of its former identity and it doesn't take a bunch of time to tour. Of course, many Americans will come to see what our POWs experienced but all will benefit from learning that Hoa Lo, as a historical artifact, encompasses more than that moment in history.This all being stated, the place was a prison and not Disneyland. Visitors will leave with a deeper understanding of what Vietnam has faced over the years and respect the nation's strength, stamina and struggle. However, anyone looking to learn more about the American POW experience must see a visit to Hoa Lo as only a part of their education.
Very interesting. Only USD1 to enter and is well worth the trip. If you are visiting Hanoi then this is a must to go and see. Takes about 1 - 2 hours depending whether you read all the info.

Great meal, fast service, good prices. Many many choices- reserve ten minutes to plow through the notebook menu. I have eaten here several times, and every dish is great. Place is usually packed by 7pm. They open at 5. The salads are fresh, soups are delish.

Harrowing but fascinating. It's not possible to enjoy visiting a place like this - it's too harrowing. But it is a fascinating account of the problems encountered in Vietnam both from the French and the Americans. The exhibits are extremely well done - I'm pleased I visited.

Impressive, though quite propagandist. Spend about one hour visiting this museum. Entrance is VND20000. Throughout the prison, built by the French, several rooms exhibit different aspect of life in the prison. Clear information (in Vietnamese and in English) is provided all over the place, so one can easily explore the museum independently. Throughout the museum, information tends to be slightly biased. Interesting part is the two rooms dedicated to the American POWs.

Very small - underwhelming. I was excited to be going to see this attraction, sadly it was very disappointing. The most of what was the prison is now high rise buildings and what is left is a little space with mock up cells and lots of photographs of past prisoners (especially the american pow). Had high hopes for this place and it was just ok. Dont go out of your way to see it but if you are knocking around the area its worth 15 minutes of your time
Interesting place to visit if you have some spare time in Hanoi. Visit was well worth the 20,000 VND entry fee. Lots to see and read. Preferred this visit over the Ho Chi Minh Museum.

If you are interested in some Hanoi History!. This place surprised us. We had been looking for more recent history information and the prison has a surprisingly good display and info. Covers from French to US invasions. If you like history or just interested in some of their past - worth the visit. Incredible and sad, but we enjoyed it!

A moment from a dark past..... Visited here as part of a private tour. There is a lot of history and very realistic rooms with disturbing visuals. You really feel bad for the people who lived and died in this prison. The presentations are very informative and pretty biased in their "explanations" of their version of history. However, it is sort of expected.They did have pictures of U.S. pilots who where shot down and kept in the prison and even had pictures of those same U.S. pilots enjoying their time at the prison playing basketball and playing cards... yeah right! As mentioned, I was part of a private tour and I actually become frustrated by our guides "version" of OUR aggression and invasion of their country and how they were victorious against the U.S. She actually went out of her way to state that "our" agent orange was still causing birth defects to this present day. Needless to say.. no tip for her!This is a must see if you are in Hanoi, simply because of the history here.I advise to avoid if you have small children.

Interesting place to see. The prison was quite an interesting place to see, it has a dark history that, if your into that you will enjoy. Some really interesting/sad pictures, some very crazy things to see as well.

Don't leave the city without visiting 'Hanoi Hilton'. In Europe and the USA we probably know Hoa Lo Prison by the nickname 'Hanoi Hilton' coined while it was used from 1964-1973 to imprison US pilots captured during the Vietnam War. The prison was originally built at the end of the 19th century by French colonialists on the site of a craft village renowned for the quality of its earthenware. Some of these pots, dishes and kettles are on display. You'll also see the guillotine imported from France and the original entrance door with its huge locks and bolts which were also specially imported. I defy anyone not to be moved almost to tears by the sight of rows of shackled prisoners in one of the large detention rooms. These figures have been crafted so finely that they appear almost lifelike. The French reckoned the prison was the most secure in Indochina but even so 100 political prisoners escaped over six nights in 1945 and you'll see sections of the sewer through which they got away. Also on display is the flight suit worn by pilot Major John McCain (a future Senator and 2008 Republican presidential nominee). Photographs give the impression that captured US pilots enjoyed a comfortable incarceration so if you want an inmate's view of life inside the 'Hanoi Hilton' I suggest you search out McCain's memoir to read when you get home. There is an informative guidebook and plenty of information panels throughout the building, obviously written from a Vietnamese point of view. Putting the propaganda aside, a visit to this place is a stark reminder of man's inhumanity to man and I'd highly recommend it. Entrance is 20,000 dong (1 US dollar) and opening hours are 8am to 5pm every day including weekends and holidays.

A must see. Depressing, realistic and for obvious reasons slanted to the Vietnamese view point. You should not let that put you off visiting "Hanoi Hilton" to see the French built prison that only became famous outside of Vietnam for housing the American pilots. Definitely somewhere you would not want to be sent to and shackled. The guillotine is particularly harrowing and thought provoking Ensure you see the memorial out the back which is carved in stone - very impressive.
Good, but misinforming. was definatley worth the 20.000 dongbasically all Vietnamese propaganda, on how easy the americans had it in the prisonif your in the area visit it, youll be glad you did

Interesting, but a slanted viewpoint. Because of the history involved here it is an interesting place to visit. But it is important when you go that it is understood it is being used as propaganda. I am surprised how poor the English translation is, since it is an official museum. Information really needs to be updated.

Interesting place. My friend and I stumbled upon the prison after getting very lost in Hanoi. The prison has a lot of history and only recently has been turned into a museum. Half of the prison has been knocked down for a tower building but whats left is quite fascinating. The displays are in some detail and is easy to follow. Not everything is in English and the guide we bought didnt match the walking sequence of the prison but was a good read once back at the hotel. It is very cheap to get in and well worth visiting if you have a spare hour or two.
Beat the tour buses and go early in the morning. A sobering and reflective site that will leave you asking questions...why?Take note of the propaganda slant, but still worth a visit.

Very Informative. The artifacts and remnants are very informative on the details of the War. Though it was a depressing journey towards every chamber knowing people suffered and even died on the same grounds..

far superior to Army Museum.. i highly recommend this museum. it was very interesting to see the cells, the guillotine and the photos and artifacts, although it's depiction of life within the prison was pretty obviously bias. the museum really stressed how horrible the treatment of the Vietnamese were during the French colonization but acted as though the American POWs were essentially at summer camp. i'm not saying the information was false, but it seemed like a very dramatic difference in portrayal. i would also note that the museum doesn't really explain the larger pictures of the French rule and the Americans in Vietnam so a prior understanding of this would really enhance your experience.

Worth a visit. I visited the "Hanoi Hilton" originally 20 years ago, when entrance was forbidden and it was illegal to even take a picture of the outside of the prison. Five years later, on a return visit, my husband and I were allowed to tour the inside. Very interesting....saw John McCain's cell, saw how the Americans lived here (pretty awful!). Today, they have sanitized this place and removed most of the evidence of the Americans' experience. Today, the emphasis is on the treatment of the Vietnamese at the hands of the French. Still, it is worth a visit and another example of man's inhumanity to his fellow human beings.

Unimpressed. I was really wanting to see the prison, but I was disappointed when I got there. My poor husband was dragged along and hated that it was worse than he was anticipating. The propaganda on the Vietnamese side is a joke. Honestly, it wasn't worth my time.

Very Interesting. This was a highlight of Hanoi. Turns out John McCain was actually imprisoned here for a while. It showed the Vietnamese perspective of the war in regards to the soldiers, and don't be fooled about their 'nice' treatment, but remember what America did.

Known to Americans as the "Hanoi Hilton". While interesting, the museum shows only one side of the story in the case of the American prisoners. It was depicted as a place where all that the prisoners did there was play chess and basketball.
Worth a visit. Entry only costa a dollar (and less if you are a student). It is one of the better museums in Hanoi so worth a visit. Definitely another propaganda machine though.

Solemn. This is a very affordable (about 1USD/person) tourist site known to Americans as the "Hanoi Hilton." As an American, I was surprised to learn about the history of the prison prior to the American conflict with Vietnam. Only a portion still remains, but the exhibits were very thorough and had some disturbing images. On the day we visited, the electricity was out; adding to the solemnity. There is only a small section of the time the Americans were there and it feels a little skewed in it's smiling, happy prisoner images, but that is to be expected. On the whole it was very interesting.

Hanoi Hilton. Interesting to see and learn about the history of this site. Worth the trip and enlightening. Amazing how the inmates survived and how they managed to escape though the sewers. Feel sorry for the children that were born there. Sad but people need to know what went on there.

Worth a visit. We arrived late and only had 30 minutes before the prison closed, we still managed to get round the whole place but I would recommend allowing at least an hour.
You get to see a fair number of cells and other exhibits of interest, you also get a hefty dose of propoganda

Quite scary . It cost $1 (not $5 as mentioned by a previous reviewer). As a lone female traveller, i found it really quite scary how they displayed the prison with the dark lighting and statues of the prisoners. Maybe because it wasn't busy and there were maybe 2 other people visiting, but i was terrified to walk in the "dungeon" sector. It really was extremly bias (against americans) but you'll find it's like that at most museums in vietnam.

A must see. A must see where our POWs were kept in the city. It is shocking to say the least and no wonder no one could escape as it is in the center of the city with you standing out and no where to go.

Or called the Hanoi Hilton. A must see where our POWs were kept in the city. It is shocking to say the least and no wonder no one could escape as it is in the center of the city with you standing out and no where to go.

Hanoi Hilton. Worth a visit. Small cheap entrance fee and only takes about an hour to have a good look round. We walked there round the lake. Would have also visited the womens museum which is fairly near but we did not have time.

The 'Hanoi Hilton' as referred to by US Pilots in the Vietnamese War. Extremely difficult to find without a very large scale street map. We ended up asking a guard, who luckily spoke reasonable English. The museum is a small remnant of the original prison, and charts its history from the French colonial times to the end of the Vietnamese war. Another guillotine [the other one in Saigon] used to remove the heads of 'revolutionaries', with an unpleasant picture of 3 women's heads in baskets originally displayed on the outer walls. Some of the displays are quite harrowing.

Scary place. The prison is about as well done as you can expect to find for this kind of a place where many were torchered and died. It is depressing but something one should see especially if you are an American.
Interesting but biased. As an American, it was interesting to see how the museum addressed housing U.S. POWs. You'll have to see for yourself, but there is definitely some bias...

Interesting but a bit disappointing. Having read a lot and having met a number of POWs who had been incarcerated there, I was interested in seeing the prison, but they have taken most of the prison and developed it into Office towers. They have saved 4-5 room and created displays about being imprisoned there which are interesting but do not go into much detail.

Grim reminder of just how hideous humans can be. An interesting peek into a vile chapter in history - no-one comes out of this well, from the French colonists who built the prison and went on to torture and execute their Vietnamese prisoners to the Viet Cong who later returned the favour and imprisoned US POWs during the Vietnam/American War. A horrible atmosphere pervades, not helped on the day of our visit by an electricity outage so we viewed the exhibits by torchlight but, lest we forget our species' capacity for cruelty, places like this ought to be seen. How weird that developers should choose to build an enormous, modern tower block right next to what remains of this hideous place, on the very spot where so many people died in such appalling circumstances. Depressing.
very interesting. its still all very original , a tad biased view but hey ! beware for some reasons they all like to shut for long lunch breaks !!
Good to Visit. A great place to visit to experience some great vietnamese history. Cost approx $5 to get in but worth every bit.

Fascinating Look into a Painful Past. This is a must visit for anyone interested in modern Vietnamese history. The sense is somber and sad as a sight of a very brutal past. Most of the focus is on the French construction and use of this prison against Vietnamese prisoners. It is possible to visit cells and a guillotine and torture devices are displayed as well as a description of those held there. But be very cautious of the description of when the "Hanoi Hilton" was used to hold American airmen during the Vietnam War (American War to the Vietnamese). This portion was extremely propagandistic.

Better know abit of French or Vietnamese before visiting.. Smells like paint inside, so I felt nauseous..... and slightly down, which I suppose is how you'd want visitors to a prison to feel? In that sense I guess the prison succeeded.Remember to pay your respects at the memorial! :) It's worth a look. But many items were in French or Vietnamese. I can barely read French, and I don't understand Vietnamese at all..... so I walked away learning much less than what was available.

Prison with a long story. Was surprise about the cost of the entrance (only 20,000VND/1$).The place in itself is nice to see, and explain the story about the jail, from it's building by the french colon to use it as a jail to torture and keep the revolutionary opponents, to the actual time.Maybe a bit objective some times, but this isn't really a problem.The organization of the path to follow is messy, and you will probably find many times yourself in a middle of 2/3 different ways to go without knowing which one is the good one.Nice presentation about the death corridor.Main problem: many information/poem/text/... are in Vietnamese and aren't translated in english... I was feeling i was missing many things..

The Other Side of the Story. As an American college student who protested the "Viet Nam War," or as they call it, the "American War", this prison/museum provided the historic context of how the French tortured Vietnamese here and then the Vietnamese "held" Americans here - they just wanted to be left alone after more than a century of foreign occupation! A very well-done museum inside the historic Hoa Lo Prison.
this would be very good if it were not for the north bias. The photos of the American pilots in the Vietnam war and the French rule in earlier times.AM is best before the bus tours.

A jail by any other name.... The prison, call it 'Maison Centrale' or 'Hanoi Hilton', is a quick lesson in barbarity, whether by French against Vietnamese freedom fighters or Vietnamese against American POWs. Wikipedia claims Hoa Lo means 'fiery furnace' or 'hell's hole'. Visit and you can believe it.If you can stand the torture devices, a French guillotine, dismal cells and sombre lifelike statues of suffering inmates, you'll probably find a visit to the prison an interesting experience and a window into the Vietnamese perspective of their recent history.

A sobering place, but a must see. I am a Vietnam era veteran and a history buff. I was enthralled by the prison. My wife is a bit younger and is from the Philippines. While I noticed that I "edited out" the propaganda by both the guide and the exhibit, I had to reeducate my wife afterward. She bought it, hook, line and sinker. (I have some good books at home).I think that maybe because the average person in Hanoi is so nice, it is hard to believe anything bad about them. Anyway, I think that this prison museum is a must see.

Well Worth The Visit. The combination of artifacts, stories, and guillotine housed in the prison make for a very informative and somber visit. It is well worth it to watch the videos that are continually running in a couple of the rooms and last about 10 minutes. They take on the Vietnamese perspective of the conditions at Hoa Lo. The prison is in the middle of the city and while most of it was demolished in the 1990's there is enough of the prison left to see what the size of the cells, death row etc. The wall in the courtyard should not be missed. It takes about an hour to go through and is well organized so that you do not experience information overload. It cost 20 000 D or $1 US.
Interesting!. Worth the visit. Fun to see some more vietnamese propaganda. Worth spending an hour or two there if you're in the area, but not essential :)
Visit the prison. Gives you a hint of how it was to be inlocked at that place! Both foreigners and lokal people, also children. Warprisoners was treated different then others.
Did the French really do this?. Horrific tales and scenes depicted here. fascinating tour with good detail and some amazing photos and stories. Don't miss the tortures and above all the Guillotine.

Hoa Lo Prison. very interesting perspective on this place of great sadness. Built by the French to imprison VN freedom fighters and then later used by the VN to imprison USA airmen shot down. Being from the USA it was a somber visit, and made me try to separate propaganda from fact. Very glad that I visited.

Super interesting - definately a must see.. As an ex military man, I was really excited to see how the US soldiers and Vietnamese revolutionaries were treated in the Hoa lo prison. Entry was $0.50, the exhibitions were great and I really enjoyed it! Directions around the prison are a bit of a struggle, but everything else was really good!

A bit of history .... I guess you can't come to Vetinam without seeing some of the history and this gives you a glimpse into what happened in the prison during the French colonial rule and where the captured American pilots where kept during the Vetinam war. It is quite well laid out and informative.

Interesting. Firstly, i was surprised at the low ticket price, only 20000 dong, roughly$1. I thought the price was going to be at least 5 times that, so it was a good start. The museums layout is a bit tricky, as there are several nooks and crannies that contain exhibits, so make sure to explore everywhere, lest you should miss something. The photos and artifacts were very interesting, but an improvement would have been subtitles on the film they were showing at the american POW exhibit, instead of having to rent an audio guide to know what is being said. The commemorative area is beautiful, with the wall sculptures and altar. Also, the museum souvenir shop merchandise prices compare favourably with the normal souvenir shops. All in all, a good experience.

Be ready for a heavy dose of Propaganda. Me, the Canadian, was the one who wanted to see Hoa Lo Prison, not my husband who is American. I wish we had skipped it. While both of us have a strong anti-war sentiment, the dose of Vietnamese propaganda was repulsive, ie. their displays of "kindness to POW's" "we the Vietnamese treated our uninvited guests well". Whatever happened to the fact it was "the Vietnamese against the Americans" it was also the North against the South Vietnam? I went back to our hotel and read Senator John McCain's writing about his reality of time as a POW in Hoa Lo. If they are going to post so many photos of him in the Prison and his jump suit and personal effects on full display, he deserves to be able to share about his torture at their hands, no? Nothing is good about war, but I can't get over how Vietnam is so comfortable still spewing what is obviously Communist lies and propaganda. I regret spending money for the entrance fee.

A daunting experience. This place bought me to tears of the persecution that the Vietnamese undertook.I am sure the spirits still lived on. And one has to question how humans could have been so cruel. The strength of the Vietnamese people to fight for freedom shows us all that one needs to believe in ones own strength

The Hanoi Hilton. The museum was divided into 2 sections - the use as a prison by the French during occupation and the appalling treatment of their prisoners. Secondly , used as "The Hanoi Hilton" for the imprisonment of captured American pilots during the Vietnam war. The Americans were treated far better than the population they were bombing.

Not bad. There are some quite interesting things such as the guillotine and propaganda films and it is definitely worth a visit. However there's not a lot of information to explain the background and some parts are not translated to English.

Interesting but not well put together. I went as part of a group and had a private guide, so perhaps my experience was more related to the guide...my knowledge going in was about John McCain being here, and the Prison was so much more than that, so having some historical background would help. I did not see much in the museum as far as background history, but later there were interesting displays with adequate English notes about the American captives. I enjoyed other places in Hanoi more- so I would put this lower on the MUST list

Worth visiting but not amazing. Went with our tour guide to the 'Hanoi Hilton' with minimal expectations and left feeling a bit hum drum. It's a must see, but the prison itself is only 1/5 of the original compound as they've built a modern hotel on much of the original grounds (and no, it's not a Hilton).The descriptions are focused on telling the story of the prison when it was used by the French to imprison Vietnamese with some reference to the war with Americans. The guillotine alone was worth the visit as I've never seen one that up close.Overall, give it about 20-30 minutes when you're in Hanoi.
Interesting museum. This is an interesting museum, not only for the French history, but also as it was used for interned American soldiers. There's so many photos upstairs of prisoners,.

A memory from the colonial times. This prison, maybe more well known as "Hanoi Hilton" or "Maison Centrale" bears testimony of the colonial years when Vietnam was a part of the French colony of Indochine. And it shows that life was pretty hard in the colony, I guess that is nothing special for Indochine, but was pretty standard for all colonies.Not the whole prison has been kept but a part of it. Here you'll find authentic prison cells and photos from the time when the prison was in full operation. There is a guillotine on display and also stories of prisoners actually making the escape. As most of the history in Vietnam seem to be about the US war it is actually interesting to find a piece of history from another time!Please visit!
Prison. Very sobering however maybe a bit biased as I am unsure of the history of this war. Very interesting all the same and seems realistic.
Worth seeing. A bit of a biased perspective concentrating on its use by the French colonialists but definitely worth a couple of hours.
war. I was in high school and college through the Vietnamese war, so I was fascinated by seeing the "Hanoi Hilton". As I went through, I had to ask myself......who had the most propaganda?

Short but interesting (and cheap) trip. Enjoyed the visit here, but I admit that was mainly because we had a local guide with us, who explained things to us in a very interesting manner. This was a local perspective of the French Occupation period, so it was intriguing to know how the version of each country's story. How the local Vietnamese were tortured in the prison was quite appalling, but they also twisted the truth on how they treated their American POWs. There is an entrance fee, but it's only 20,000VND.

Educational. The Hanoi Hilton was not a place I looked forward to visiting, but I learned a lot about what our American soldiers went through and had a look at the Vietnamese point of view.  The display of the guillotine, which was imported from France, was shocking. I had never seen one before, and it brought back memories of Dickens' Tale of Two Cities.
Very interesting. Given most of the prison has been torn down, they have done a great job to preserve the remainder of the building and share the story. Worth a visit (takes an hour)!

Worth the time. It was interesting to read about occupation, imperialism, and war stories from the perspective of the " other side" . Sparse artifacts but enough to enlighten about the horrors that took place during the colonial expansion..

Worth an Hour if you Have It Spare. Interesting to gain a LOCAL perspective including the French Colonialism aspect. Growing up during the Vietnam period we were only exposed to the North American media version of what was taking place. Not to say that many horrible things did not occur in the prison but like the Killing Fields in Cambodia it is important to reflect on man's inhumanity to man.

The Hanoi "Hilton". The Hoa Lo Prison was a fascinating insight into the colonial influence and, in some cases, oppression of the indigenous population, and gives more of a depth to the history and culture of the region.This was also the site to which downed American airmen were incarcerated during the Vietnam War. While most of the exhibits have some English explanation, do understand that the events and information comes from a Vietnamese perspective, and is not always that which people of the West may believe or accept.An interesting way to spend an hour or two in Hanoi.

Interesting, but quick. Was expecting the Hoa Lo prison to be closed during the TET holiday, went the 2nd day of TET, and it was surprisingly open. It was interesting to wander around in the prison reading about everything that went on there when the french colonists used it, and also it's significant role during the vietnam war.I wish they would make more of the prison stay the way it was, without placing dolls in almost every room. It was interesting to ser the cells that were in their orginal state, but it's not a place to stay for hours.
Worth to visit. feb. 2014 accidentally visiting the haloa prison in hanoi. It was nice experience. A bit propaganda by the vietnamese but worth visiting.

Disappointing Inaccuracies.... The Hoa Lo prison was built by the French to house Vietnamese political prisoners. It was then used by the Vietnamese for American POW's during the Vietnam War. Not much of the expansive original grounds/buildings remain, but a scaled down model inside shows what it used to be. The museum is mostly to showcase torture/brutality of the Vietnamese political prisoners by the French, including a guillotine. A very small room is dedicated to the American POWs and shows games of basketball and happy Christmas celebrations. We were even told that the prison was a place to keep the POWs fed and healthy for the duration of the war. Having read a number of accounts written by these POWs which detail instances of serious brutality and torture, something does not jive. Those inaccuracies (which then led us to question the accuracy of the rest of the museum), coupled with the small size / dim lighting (it was a prison, so not surprising), I wouldn't say that this is a must visit in Hanoi. However, entrance fee is minimal, approximately 1 USD equivalent, and it's easy to get through in under an hour.

A place of political propaganda.. A lot of interesting history here, with a healthy helping of propaganda. Very little about the torture of US personnel during the American war. Lots about the nasty French though, definitely worth a look though
Must see. This was not part of our tour but our guide fit it in. It is well worth your time and pretty cheap to get in.

Good value. At 20,000 entrance fee, this is an interesting place. There's the option to buy a short guidebook for an additional 20,000, it's probably not worth buying as most of its contents are reproductions of what's already on the walls but maybe as a souvenir given that what is in the two souvenir shops didn't seem worth buying, to me, obviously.Covering mainly the time that the prison was used by the French, there is a clear, unsurprising, bias towards the Vietnamese held here, there are items that belonged to prisoners, and somewhat creepy figures in chains and cells.Most of the prison has been knocked down to facilitate Hanoi Towers.There is a small section on the US pilots held here as POWs, in the 'Hanoi Hilton', I can only describe the info on this as amusing, which is not to belittle those held here, nor the Vietnamese but the descriptions are genuinely funny.I'd recommend checking it out.

Worth a visit!. The "Hanoi Hilton" is easy to reach and worth a visit.It is very interesting to get to know about the history of this place.Of course, what happened to people here is horrible. However, the exhibition gives the visitor the feeling as if the Vietnamese prisoners had a very hard time (of course they had) while the American prisoners almost enjoyed staying there (I am sure they did not).

Sad and hartbreaking. This is a monument over how cruel people can be to each other. It is also a statement of how much people are willing to suffer in order to free their own country from the occupants.

History can never be forgotten. This was the second visit of our guided tour and a glimpse of humanities cruelty to each other. That the American soldiers suffered slightly less than the native Vietnamese is an eye opener.The strength of spirit would have been the only saviour for many. Glad we made the effort to view.
Impressive. Gives the idea of prisoners live at that time. Dont take minors inside!Hope they stop selling souvenirs in places like that, disgusting!

Pretty Horrific. Very well presented and gave a good account of what went on in the prison in the past - pretty horrific conditions. There were films showing of the war with the US - naturally biased towards the North Vietnamese, but nevertheless my first experience of realising just what did go on in that war and what the Americans did to the country. This place was known during those days as "The Hanoi Hilton" and they proudly display Senator John McCain's flying suit - he was imprisoned there. Definitely something you should see on a visit.

Thought provoking. Took us a little time to find this as it is tucked away in a side street.It was very informative and I learnt a lot about French history and Vietnam and the exhibits helped tell the history.The part concerning the American War I had to realise was told from a Vietnamese side and did not include the American experiences.I am not usually a fan of museums but I thoroughly 'enjoyed' this.

Must See. It won't take you long to walk around but you will uncover a lot of history about Hanoi and Vietnam here. I think you will find a new perspective of Hanoi after visiting and will only add to your impression of Hanoi. It's easy to walk to from most hotels in the Old Quarter.

No Ned Kelly. A bit ho hum, if you are all over your Vietnam Revolution then you will get more out of this than I did. The history that was presented in English as you walk around was very interesting but the prison itself is only a small representation of what was there originally and they have cut and pasted a bit to display as much as they can. The American pilots held here may have a different account to the conditions compared to what is portrayed. At a few dollars it is value for money, and as I said a very interesting place for housing those that dared to speak out but you won't leave Vietnam feeling like you missed out if you don't go.

Interesting, But Information Seems Skewed. Very thought-provoking to step into history at the prison. But the information placards and pictures seem to only paint the Vietnamese side of the story. There were photos of American POWs playing sports, receiving "packages from home," hanging out together -- all smiles all the while. I doubt this is how John McCain would describe his time there. Nevertheless, seeing the physical grounds was interesting.

Moving. The prison was so fascinating. The commentary gives a great overview of the political history of Vietnam. Unfortunately a lot of the quotes were only written in Vietnamese and not translated. If more of the writing was translated (or if there was a guidebook etc that went along side all the entries) it would be perfect. As you get round the museum there is more information in English. It is a very emotional place, I found. It is difficult to imagine the conditions that people were kept in when they were prisoners but the museum portrays that very well.

Interesting, a good break from Hanoi traffic. Allow around an hour, there are only a small number rooms left. The exhibitions are well set out. It's interesting that there are ample writings recorded which extol the virtues if communism, but no personal accounts from other prisoners. I think some honest reportage would go a long way in making this a more moving, less cynical experience. Still, it's a great respite from the ear bleeding Hanoi traffic.

educational. I wasn't much looking forward to visiting this, and although has some propaganda, it turned out to be very educational and made you wonder the circumstances. Some imaging were a little upsetting but otherwise a good place to spend an hour.

A bit of history. Worth a look. Not far from the lake so walking is ok. Only a small part of the old prison remains but a good job has been done to make it what it is today. Admission was 15000D and it took about 1 hour to see all the sights..

happy american pilot photos. this museum is very amusing. it was a prison the french built during their occupation, who treated the vietnamese very badly, - then the vietnamese took it over and used it to incarcerate americans during the vietnam war who "they treated very well and gave good food and recreation" that description on a plaque on the wall seemed to contrast with the "happy" faces on the photos of the american pilots they shot down.is a decent museum but like all attractions in vietnam, you have to try and see through the politics of everything and dont expect to get a balanced view from it.
Very moving. At the start we weren't impressed but the further we went through the more interesting and emotive it became, well worth visiting and very cheap fee to enter

As luxurious as being a POW can get. - if we are to take the Vietnamese people's words. Interesting museum located in a former French colonial prison. It shows the oppression of the Vietnamese people under the French and up to the days of the Vietnam war. There are a lot of Vietnamese-only documents and stories about local heroes - resistance fighters during the Vietnam War (or American War as the Vietnamese call it). There's an interesting video with footages of the damages of the war as well as of American POWs. There are also interesting pictures of the luxurious-by-POW-standards life (according to the Vietnamese, fact-check yourself) of the American prisoners, mostly captured pilots, during the war. Worth checking if you are in the area. It's close to the Temple of Literature and the Fine Arts Museum. I believe this museum mostly aims to instill patriotism in its citizens.

Nice try. I didn't intend to go there but after seeing it in a map, we decided to pay a visit around this place. The prison must have been renewed several times though so it didn't look as horrible as I thought it should be. At least, I wanted to see how bad they treated the prisoners there but this place just fell short of what I had expected. One plus thing is that this place is not touristic so it was convenient to walk around.

Propaganda 101.. Interesting place, and worth a visit. The propaganda is so blatant that it's funny, which is ironic in such a sad place. The first half is all about how bad the French colonists were to the Vietnamese - apparently. The second half is full of displays of how wonderfully the Vietnamese treated the US pilots imprisoned there. Not a word of torture and mistreatment, just how it was like a hotel for them until the war ended - hence the name Hanoi Hilton Hotel. For another side to the story you don't need to look further than Wikipedia.Propaganda aside, it is somewhere to visit when in Hanoi.

A look back in time at the Hanoi Hilton!. This was right next door to our hotel in Hanoi. It shows the conditions of the prison at different periods in time including the home for POWs during the Vietnam War. Get the guide book! A very interesting place to spend an hour if you have the time.
Depressing. Mans inhumanity to man never ceases to amaze me. Not huge amounts to see and it is very biased reporting on the event. But it is their country.

Worth a visit. It only takes about 1 hour to tour the prison. In it, you will find plenty of communist propoganda...but it is interesting to hear their side of the story. The museum is worth seeing, and the entry fee is incredibly cheap (10,000 Dong).

Great history. For those of us old enough to remember the war in Vietnam, this is a fascinating look at what was in store for hapless US pilots if their plane was shot down over North Vietnam. But perhaps more importantly, it is a chilling reminder of what the Vietnamese political prisoners had to endure from the French. Advice - get a guide (maybe Hanoikids, as we did), as for us having their commentary really made the visit special.

Interesting. Lots of propaganda - well it is in the North of Vietnam!I found the history of the French Occupation of Vietnam very enlightening - not the propoganda itself but the dates and the causes for revolts and uprisings and the parts of Vietnamese history we do not learn at school. We travelled with older children and the recreations / pictures brought the history to life for them.

Such a history. The French may have built it, but the prison was used right up to the US invasion. The amount of people who spent time in this tiny place is an eye-opener. Another vital piece of Vietnamese history.

Worth a look. Doesn't take too long. Interesting place, full of history. It's a good museum and is well maintained. The guillotine is creepy and the stories of the prisoners are moving. Worth a visit.
Don't miss. Don't miss. Gives you a wonderful view of what the flyers dealt with-citizens owe them a lot-very miserable place

Interest. Worth the short taxi ride. The museum has decent displays - albeit spun with propaganda. The history of the prison is focused on both the use by French to imprison the Vietnamese and the use by the Viet Cong to imprison POWs.

Really Worth Visiting. Hao Lo Prison is worth visiting just to see one of the famous French guillotines that they have on display. There are also some really great stories about prisoners escaping, and death row is still intact and on display too. Definitely worth the $1 entry fee.
Hoas La Prison. Well worth a visit, steeped in history its just a shame that half of it is no longer there as they have used the land to build on.

Hanoi Hilton. Very informative, very moving...
We learned a lot here and it gives you "chills". Great insight into how the prisoners were treated...
Do not miss it!
It's unbelievable how cruel the french were!
It's a shamed majority of the prison has been knocked down...

Informative with plenty pictures and exhibits. Great place to see how it was for Vietnamese prisoners during French occupation as well as American prisoners during the war. After seeing the pictures of American prisoners playing basket ball and enjoying themselves I now know why the referred to it as the Hanoi Hilton. Overall, a very informative museum with lots of historical significance.

Makes you wonder how barbaric humans can be. A very, very moving place. You have to wonder how the Vietnamese people can be so forgiving of all of the other nationalities who have oppressed them over the centuries. There's not a lot of information going on here but you certainly get the message.

Really worth going to. We didn't plan to go to Hoa Lo Prison, but we are so glad we did. As some of the other reviewers have pointed out, you 'll have to take some of the exhibits with a grain of salt, but overall this is a great place to connect with Vietnam's history. Even though not much of the original part remains, the museum I felt is very well designed and still gives you a good idea of what it was like and what has taken place inside its walls. We took our sons of 7 and 10, and although they couldn't quite keep their attention for all the many photos, they did very much 'enjoy' the overall visit and experience. Reading some of the stories of American POWs and their later work in the U.S. bridging the U.S.-Vietnam gap was inspiring.

John McCain and other US Pilots imprisoned here. This was a fascinating sight not even on our tour, but recommended by our guide once he got to know us. You will see the photos of John McCain and other pilots as well as the uniform he was wearing when he was shot down. Very disturbing life like models are imprisoned with cement feet cuffs, so beware of upsetting scenes. Very propagandist, but worth seeing to understand the Vietnamese people's perspective. Highlight of Hanoi and is nicknamed the "Hanoi Hilton" if you've ever heard that name.

The 'Hanoi Hilton'. A grim form of entertainment but I think you need to go. The large and gloomy prison, for which there IS now a small entry fee, was used by the French to imprison uncooperative Vietnamese in the colonial period and then its second incarnation to imprison shot down American pits in the Vietnam War. While I have every sympathy for the Vietnamese because their history of being invaded and abused by a wide variety of foreigners, the propaganda here is a bit blatant. Yes, I have no doubt the French treated prisoners here badly ( a fact brought to life by the array of life-size dummies in the cells and the looming threat of the guillotine in a room nearby) , but to contrast this with the alleged model treatment of American pilots is, well, just propaganda. One may well understand the anger felt towards these pilots but the so-called model treatment of these pilots was just for show- you only have to ask Senator John McCain, former presidential candidate, who had both his arms deliberately broken here. But the whole place gets its message of man's humanity to man across quite effectively nevertheless. And the extensive photography and collection of objects assists this well.

Must see to truly understand vietnam. Chartering the country's struggle for independence since colonial times, this interesting museum is on the 'must see' list in order to comprehend Vietnam as it is today. Well worth the visit.

A Must-see in Hanoi. We thought this place was very interesting, shedding light on the history of Vietnam both in terms of being occupied by the French and then the "American" War. Walking around the prison gives you the chills to think what it would have been like, and the commentary (all in English) added to the experience, even if so one-sided it almost becomes amusing - for example every time the word "French" is written it is preceded by a word such as "treacherous" of "barbaric", whereas every mention of a Vietnamese person has been preceded by a word such as "heroic" or "patriotic". However, this does not take away from this must-see place in Hanoi and only costs 20,000VND per person (about 60 pence).
