Learned so much!. Excellent - we really enjoyed visiting the Hoa Lo Prison and learning about the political prisoners and how they escaped. It was sad to see how they were treated and you almost feel like they are still there. It was also Hanoi Hilton, where the pilots shot down during the war were taken...interesting to see how they were treated. All ages will enjoy this site.

Inaccurate propaganda piece but worth a visit. The old French "Madison Centrale" housed political prisoners during the French colonial period as well as downed US pilots during our misguided misadventure during "our Vietnam War". The building is worth seeing and the history accurately presented if you can read between the lines. The video pieces at the end of the tour are "over-the-top" propaganda pieces that, I am sure, even the Vietnamese do no find creditable...borders on the comical. You don't need a guide here if you already know the history.

Visiting this place should be mandatory. An unadorned and raw examination of the French colonialists treatment of the Vietnamese liberation movement.
Also the exhibition from Hanoi Hilton time a god introduction to what happened in the War of Independence against the United States.
Hoa Lo Prison. Was good to see, good to learn about the history of the war in Vietnam, and what has happened since.

Hanoi Hilton - Eye Opening. This is the first place I visited that gave me a different view of the Vietnam War (or American War, depending on where you come from). Easy walking distance from the old quarter, the Hanoi Hilton is a great display of Vietcong propoganda.

Very interesting. I really enjoyed my visit here. I purchased a guide book which gives extra info (20000VND), definitely useful. The tour is well laid out and the exhibits are interesting. Frightening to imagine being imprisoned in those conditions during the French occupation. I visited with my husband and we had some very interesting discussions about the propagandist portrayal of the treatment of US prisoners during the Vietnam war, I don't think the prisoner's would agree with this view! definitely worth a visit.

Vietnamese and american prison. I liked this museum. It should how Vietnamese prisoners were treated inhumanely but it also showed how Vietnamese can show compassion to their American prisoners. The museum showed videos of bombing of Hanoi by the Americans. It also showcase how the vietnamese became united against the yanks. The museum was clean. The exhibit where prisoners will crawl in the sewer just to escape is quite compelling. An art piece with 4 thin men and one of them hanging caught my attention. The entrance fee was 20,000 dong for adults and 10,000 for students. This museum should be included in everyone`s itinerary.
Part of Hanoi history. Shows the turmoil that Vietnam has experienced and is now struggling to change. The countries that have taken Vietnam over and have been dismissed.
Entertaining. Good fun even if not really well organize. Very interesting to see and understand this part of history/colonialism.

Very informative, worth a visit. Took a while to find this place by walking, it is around the corner from St Joseph. Entry was around 20,000 dong per person. They really preserved the prison atmosphere and depictions of the prison's atrocities. No tourist traps here, well-laid out for tourists to take their time and explore the prison grounds.

More English Descriptions needed. I found the prison to be informative and it is horrible to hear of the atrocities that happened there. However some of the pictures and information are lacking descriptions and English translations and if I hadn't purchased the guidebook along with my ticket I would probably still be a little lost.
Good to visit and realize how much this country people suffred. They have been colonized by the Chinese,the French and the Americans.... And in the end, the Vietnamese beat them all!!

Recommend. Our whole family found it a valuable experience. I was able to put things in terms that my kids could understand. The facilities were clean. Note..they have different pricing for non-Vietnamese visitors (written in Vietnamese obviously so you wouldn't know). Within walking distance of Hoan Kiem Lake area.
Hotel Hilton. It was so nice to see the Vietnamese perspective on the difference of prisoner treatments. The French Guillotine was interesting to see.

Looks small on the outside but of BIG importance. This is what is left of the "Hanoi Hilton" prison where John McCain was held after he was shot down over Hanoi. Not surprisingly, this small museum presents the Vietnam perspective on American attacks on Vietnam and the (very nice) way that prisoners were treated. However, it is an interesting historical location well worth a visit.

Interesting but limited. The prison was interesting however it was rather small and had limited information without a guide. a good perspective of history and the hardship. It was an inexpensive venture and worth seeing to fill in time

Interesting museum. Is a pretty interesting museum to visit. Only 20000 dong so very inexpensive. Gives a good history of the use of the prison from the times of French colonialists to when downed US pilots were housed here during the Vietnam war. Is quite propagandaish but thats part of the Vietnamese experience!
just go. dont miss this prison .Shows the brutal colonial french rule in it rawness a must to see together with its cut head off machine
sobering experience. Built as a intimidating colonial prison and later used for the American pilots. Tough place to stay.
Worth a quick look.. If in Hanoi and have a bit of time to spare, worth a look. Exhibits dated but still interesting. Not too difficult to get to from old quarter and down a 'quieter' street!

Hoa lo prison museum. The prison was built by the French in 1896 and later nicknamed " Hilton Hotel" by American prisoners during Vietnam war. Its a reminder of atrocities that happened there and how cruel human beings can be, The prison is interesting to visit if you have some extra time but definitely not a "must see". The exhibition is done in a bit confusing way - I have visited some rooms several times but couldn't find the other ones. Also the part explaining how American POWs (prisoners of War) were treated is not to convincing - I doubt that those guys were really treated that well.

A small site but a big insight into Vietnam's perspective on history. Most reviews have covered that the remaining prison is quite small, the exhibits and guide information limited. The entry fee is cheap, and the English guidebook has all of the material covered in the prison exhibits outlined. A very subjective view of the prison's history and activities conducted therein is presented in the exhibit material, which some may find disturbing and overly biased. However, I would see that is one of the reasons to travel, being to understand different perspectives and points of view.Some of the material is graphic for small children.

Well worth the visit. I found this most interesting. The exhibits are models of how the prisoners were treated are quite disturbing. A little hard to find your way around,.. I'm sure I missed a few things but managed to find a number of rooms twice.

Prison visit. A one off experience. Well presented. Very moving. Dec a good time to go to Hanoi was not too hot and not too many people at the prison when we were there.Able to amble through at leisure.

Hilariously biased. I do wish Trip Advisor would let me rate as 'good', rather than just 'average' or 'very good', as that is what this attraction should be rated.The 'Hanoi Hilton', as it was affectionately known by the US service men held there during the Vietnam War in the 60's/70's was built by the French colonists in the 19th Century to house political insurgents and subsequently by the communists for the same purpose.The tour is basic and like stepping back 40 years in the style and quality of the displays and story boards, however if you are in Hanoi and have a couple of hours to spare spend 20k dong (less than 70p) if only to read the hilariously biased story boards, some had us creased up with laughter!

Interesting but sad. I was surprised to learn how brutal the French were to the local people when they invaded Vietnam. Shocking. The guillotine is still there and photographs of heads they cut off. The French were extremely cruel. The American prisoners were treated much better despite bombing the heart out of Vietnam. An interesting visit but thought provoking.

A must see with a pinch of salt. A bit disappointed that most of the prison is gone and there is nothing original left really. However it is still one of those things you have to see. Quite funny that it really plays up the abuse inmates received under the French regime before showing pics of US pilots having fun playing cards, celebrating Xmas etc and saying how forgiving they were.

A harrowing place, a must see.. A really interesting museum, being the actual prison is sent shivers down my spine, they use models to represent prisioners and it really adds to the atmosphere, and shows a history of Vietnam every visitor should see. Good signs everywhere, shame so much lost to development but that's just the way it goes!

Definitely worth seeing. We spent a good hour here (can't remember how much we paid - I think around VND 20k which is approx £0.60p each!).Yes it is difficult to visualise exactly how grim this place was, on a sunny day with vibrant colours an attractive garden and peaceful atmosphere. There is a huge emphasis on the nasty French submitting beastly atrocities on native population (which will no doubt have an element of truth) but great lengths shown to portray the extent that US prisoners were well treated.This is very much a an attraction where the individual visitor has to make up his or her own mind as to how much information is true either in whole or in part. Either way for us it was definitely one place to see.

Not sure if I'd say very good or average. The Hanoi Hilton is generally considered one of the must sees in Hanoi, and although it doesn't disappoint, it certainly wasn't a highlight of my trip :)The Vietnamese government has kept a part of the original Hoa Lo Prison made during the French rule and showcases the many atrocities committed by the invading country over the locals. The prison was then taken over by the local government and was used as a prison for American soldiers during the Vietnam war. The museum does a decent job of showcasing the devastating effects of the American air assault over Hanoi and other places in the country and then the use of the prison to keep captured American soldiers, John McCain being one of them.I think they gloss over their treatment of the American prisoners a bit too much, although it is still a good place to visit and get some perspective on the fight for independence for the Vietnamese people. The entire place can be seen in just about an hour with a $1 ticket.

A Must See in Hanoi. Was not originally on our prearranged tour, but an email to our tour company made rearranging easy. Did not require much time (one and a half was plenty) but the history of this French built prison later used to house shot down American pilots during the Vietnam war was fascinating.

A horror from the past. This prison was built by the French to imprison, torture and behead political dissidents. It has some graphic accounts and pictures of that era. It was then used by the Vietnamese to imprison American Pilots shot down during the American - Vietnam War. These prisoners appeared to have been treated better. The displays of American Pilots' conditions and uniforms is interesting and included in the display is the flight suit of US Senator John Cain, shot down in Truc Bac lake Hanoi during the war. Well worth seeing but an indictment on the way the French treated the Vietnamese during the French Colonisation. One day perhaps mankind will realise that we are just people and we will all get along together on this planet we call Earth. (I just saw a purple elephant and a flying pig!)

Not much left. Interesting, but the fact that a huge office building now takes up much of the original site leaving only small part of the original area was a little disappointing. Seeing the brutal conditions that had to be injured by the inhabitants gave a sad reminder of Vietnams recent history.

Visit to Hoa Lo prison.. The American "P.O.W'S" sarcastically named this prison the "Hanoi Hilton".Most of the exhibits was on the Vietnamese struggle for Independence from the French with torture chambers and methods of execution depicted as also some famous escapes from this high security prison.There were some escapes through the toilet drainage systems and the toilets kept as exhibits.Prisoners were chained by their legs in small cells.On the "AMERICAN WAR(VIETNAM WAR)" there were exhibits on the bombings of Hanoi by American bombers and the American airmen taken as "P.O.W'S".Senator John.McCain ,a former "P.O.W" is the most famous exhibit in Hoa Lo prison. A television documentary continuously plays details of the bombings of Hanoi and the "American War".Exhibits of possessions of captured American prisoners and photographs were on display.
Hanoi Hilton. This was a very cool visit. John McCain's flight suit is on the wall. The history of the prison is mainly about the French ruling Vietnam. You must see this if you go to Hanoi.

Worth a visit. Wasn't going to se this after some of the reviewsBut like all wars each country puts its own spin on everythingOpened my eyes and I followed up with my own researchIn the end I was glad I checked it out

Disappointing. The major part of the prison grounds have been "developed" into a modern high rise, leaving a small sliver of the original site which had been converted into a museum.For people with a direct link and interest it may be worth a visit but for the average visitor like ourselves it is a disappointing sanitised place.

Historical. A well done tour with photos and life like images at different locations throughout. Known to the US soldiers as the Hanoi Hilton, it was a must for us to see where are boys were kept prisoners.
Humble History. This was very humbling and sad to see this prison where the French and Americans were kept as prisoners. Most prisoners were shackled by the ankles and starved. So sad

Worth a look if you're not too squeamish. This former prison lost a lot of its land area to the Hotel round the back so the scale is lost today. There are still some original features-cell doors, torture equipment (including a very imposing guillotine), mass stocks etc. but otherwise this is sanitized. There is an interesting exhibition about the lives (which were apparently quite pleasant) of American POWs, including a certain John McCain (the guy who ran for US president I 2008). There’s a picture of him being fished out of the water after his plane went down. A quick 45 min walk round if you’ve got time to fill.
Wow. Impressive impressive. Lots of information, relics from the war time, etc. Must see, can be harsh sometiems but sure worh it

A lot of history in a small place!. It is put up really well and you can walk through it to see and try to feel what it was like during those days when the Vietnamese people had to deal with in this prison.

how it was. I was moved to tears here, remembering our years of protest against the Vietnam War and then getting such a vivid sense of what everyone, all sides, endured. The American protest is acknowledged at the museum. It's truly remarkable--here and elsewhere in Hanoi--to see what remains of this time that so changed things for us in the US.

Interesting. More of a historical snapshot of the prison's various uses over time, both when a French colony and during the Vietnamese war, the prison is now a self-guided tour through key historical artifacts and layouts, but is still very much worth a visit.

Disappointing!. There was not a lot of prison left as big Singapore company had bought most of land and built huge luxury hotel next to it. What was left seemed very unreal and tacky. Plenty of photos of the Americans held there but all looked too staged. Lots of gruesome things from when French ruled. I expected much more and would not put this on my list of things to see

Interesting. If you are a history buff, it is definitely interesting.. The methods of imprisonment and torture was a bit much for me.. So in that respect, i could have skipped it.. But there is so much history between vietnam and the US, it seemed like a "must do"

Must see. A must see in order to understand something about history - will only take about 30 minutes but the somber atmosphere should give cause for reflection on the hardships of colonial rule in Vietnam

Better than expected. This museum was near our Movenpick Hotel. We thought it would be focused on theUS war prisoners, but not so. Most of the exhibits focus on the horror of theprison when the French were in charge. Hard to believe such cruelty came from the cultured French. The last section does deal with the US pilots as prisoners. Presented in theexpected propaganda way, but still interesting. Was certainly not as nice for the captives as theypretend to show it. The museum buildings are only a remnant of the original buildings,but are well preserved and nicely presented. Had no expectations going in, but waspresently surprised. Definitely worth a visit.

Hard times in Hanoi. The prison is laughingly described by the US pilots as the Hanoi Hilton seemed to be anything but a good place to stay. The French certainly humiliated and destroyed their prisoners, the guillotine is still there as a grisly reminder. However, the Vietnamese treatment of the Americans seems a little too good to true. Good value at 20,000 dong per person

If you miss it, don't worry too much..... Worth a look. Interesting, yes. A must do, no. Viewpoints presented are not subjective of course, with the Hanoi Hilton, as was known, wasn't really because it was luxurious, but the presentation hopes to show just how grateful the Americans should have been, having been looked after so well during their stay. Some parts of the displays were quite good. If you have time, drop by for an hour....

Nice to see, only 1/4 of the actual prison remains. Went with my wife who isn't really into this sort of thing, but being a bit of a military history buff I really wanted to go. Only about 1/4 of the actual prison remains however, so the displays are few in number. But that doesn't take away from the historical value when it comes to talking about the revolution during the French occupation, where a number of Vietnamese patriots were imprisoned and/or executed here (this section saved me from giving only 1 star). The section about American pilots during the war is extremely laden with propaganda. They have a video playing showing and talking about how the prisoners were very luck to have been here (as opposed to other prisons). Saying things such as they were treated with the utmost respect and fed very well (while the normal Vietnamese citizen didn't have half the food, as they point out). Having read a few books on the war this is a load of crap and simply disinformation/propaganda. The video playing showing the prisoners eating large meals, playing volleyball, smoking, watching films, & listening to the guards play music for them was essentially shot in one day...then the malnutrition, beatings, & torture resumed. This was unfortunate knowing that a large number of people didn't have 1/10th of the knowledge of the war as I did and would go away from there thinking "hey, these guys were pretty lucky". As William Tecumseh Sherman put it, "war is hell" and these guys were not treated with a lick of respect or anything for that matter...The Vietnamese frequently pointed out that the Americans were committing war crimes but failed to tell the truth about the atrocities. I wouldn't waste my time here unless you personally knew someone imprisoned or are a military history freak like me.
Very interesting. Really interesting place with lots of history, would definitely recommend travelers visit the "Hanoi Hilton".

Small Perspective. It does have a good history of the prison from when the French built it. There is plenty of history there, but it is funny to watch the video of the POW's and how they were treated. The ones in the video must have been the only ones treated so well with Vietnam sightseeing and given suits. Definitely a place to visit in Hanoi.

The Hanoi Hilton. Slightly disappointing, in that more could have been made of this as a more rounded historical record. If there had been a good rating, I would have given it, but it doesn't rate as 'Very Good' in my estimation.

Worthwhile visit. Interesting and a peak at prison life for first the Vietnamese and then the American pilots. Only about 1\3 still standing but enough to know about the brutal conditions these prisoners had. The Americans were treated much better by the Vietnamese than the Vietnamese were treated by the French. Worth a look.
Interesting. Interesting, worth an hour or two for those interested in the war.Man's inhumanity to man continues to astound...
interesting. This is definitely worth visiting - the conditions that these prisoners were kept in were shocking. There are video footage to watch as well as the original solitary confinement cell.

A must do in Hanoi. You'll get a one-sided view of the war, but it's historical significance, particularly to Americans (they have the flight suit of John McCain) makes it a must-do in Hanoi. As others have said, only a small portion remains, but you'll learn that the it started out as a French prison so has quite a bit of history behind it. Worth a couple of hours to visit and review the posted material.

Big propaganda show. Only about one third of the prison remains as a museum. While the displays of prison life and the jail cells were interesting, it was somewhat spoiled for me by the propaganda posters and lecture we received as part of the tour.
Must see. Hanoi Hilton prison a must see to start to understand their history.Not a long tour as there is not much to see but important to see the past well worth a spare couple of hours

Hanoi Hilton. Being a Vietnam Vet I just had to see this imfamous prison that I had heard so much about from the yanks during my tour in '69. I had a pretty good idea about what the French were up to and then the US but according to the photographs on the walls it really was portrayed as a Hilton Hotel. I doubt very much that it was anything like that for the US POW's. Anyhow it was indeed an interesting visit and worth while taking the time to visit. Just remember, Museums in Hanoi are not open on Mondays and they all close up shop spot on 12.00 and do not reopen until 13.30 but the entry fee is rediculously cheep (about US$2.00).

Worth Your Time. It's not a "fun" attraction, but very much worth the time. Only a small section of the old prison remains and it has been made into a museum, but it gives you a real sense of what it was like. Easy to cover in an hour or two at the most, depending on how much you stop and read. It is a monument to "Man's inhumanity to man." Built by the French and use to hold and torture Vietnamese people before its use by the Vietnamese to hold the likes of Senator John McCain and Ambassador Peterson. The portrayal of how "enjoyable" it was for the American pilots held there strains credibility, but other than that, it is highly factual and very educational.

Important historical site. This is an essential stop if you want to understand the history of Hanoi. I found it compelling, though it was difficult to absorb as an American with POWs held here and a somewhat subjective point of reference in the captions used on exhibits. In the end it was a very informative and rewarding part of my trip.

Interesting! A must visit in Hanoi.. It is very fascinating to see Hoa Lo Prison how it changed from French Colonization to Vietnam war in 1970's (Hanoi Hilton Prison). Here you can also find McCain's old suit when he was first captured. Although, the museum is smaller compared to the original size of it to give way to the new developments around Hanoi. I am glad that I have a chance to visit Hoa Lo Prison. Absolutely great insight on their history and it's best to visit this place with a private tour guide.

Got there after closed, but odd. So apparently this is still a working prison. While i got back to Hanoi after the "Hanoi Hilton" museum was closed, decided to walk to it at 7pm to see what was there. Unfortunately since it was closed, there really wasn't anything other than a plaque on one wall on the only less lit street side to see. The irony is on the other corner down the block there was a fancy-pants "Hanoi Towers" hotel.

Very interesting. I like the easy way the tour was laid out, with an easy to follow route soth at you do. Not miss anything. The exhibits were very good and the information at each exhibit was good and interesting. When we left zi Felton at we had gained a great insight into what it must have been like to have been a prisoner detained there.

Something to do. Spent over an hour at the prison, definitely a cheap activity to check out when you're bored. Wasn't big on the information that was provided there, felt like they were missing information, especially in the American pilot room. Also, some parts were confusing, I'd recommend reading a but about it before going.

Okay, only see one of this or Army museum as lot of repetition. I liked it, but like other reviewers left a little underwhelmed. Could have spoken more about the effect of the prison on the nationalist movement and rise of insurgency. Shame lot of it has been demolished for the sky scraper.

Interesting. It was worth the $1 to get in. What was interesting to me as an American, though, was that it seemed to be one-sided. It described all the atrocities that the French did to the Vietnamese there; however, when it came to the part about the American POWs in it, it described it more as "Fun and Games" while they were there...with all the "good meals, game-playing, several changes of clothes given" etc. Doubtful it was all that great for the likes of John McCain and the rest of them. It was no Hilton, as its nickname tries to imply. But this is to be expected, I guess. Worth taking a look though, even still.

A tour of McCain's life. I have wanted to go to the famous Hanoi Hilton for a long time and it should be visited in you are in Hanoi. It cost's very little and it wasn't crowded when I went. Most of the museum is dedicated to the imprisonment of the Vietnamese under French rule but there are some areas dedicated to the U.S. soldiers that were there, mainly pilots that were shot down. It does show pictures of McCain and other pilots that were shown playing basketball and havig a good time. Obviously a propaganda video they made back in the day but also interesting. It's worth a visit, if nothing else than to remember the U.S. prisoners that died there.

Worthwhile visit. The visit to the prison was a sobering opportunity as an American to see a Vietnam view point of the American-Vietnam war. As our guide said, "We share a horrible history." The war museum in Ho Chi Ming City is a more complete presentation. I strongly recommend visiting.
Difficult ambiance. I know this is something you should see but it was difficult to see the conditions and the pictures of what so many people endured. You must make up your own mind.

Cheap to get in. This place cost approximately $2 AUD to get in. It does not take a long time but is a great brief first glimpse into the history of the Vietnam war and what happened when people were arrested during this time.

Definitely worth a visit. Great museum for a quick visit and probably one of the Must visits in Hanoi (along with the Mausoleum). It was well laid out and organized. The information and exhibits were well explained. I do wish there was more information on the Vietnam War days and how the prison was used.

don't leave Hanoi without visiting. The prison was very well kept. You could see the cells and there were many artifacts. It was very interesting to see the spin on how things happened...The scrap book with the American POWs was very interesting. I would've enjoyed seeing how many came in vice how many did not make it out. Having Senator McCains book highlighted with his thoughts might have been interesting as well.

Well...it was 1/5th of the Hanoi Hilton. The prison is now a decently interesting museum. Most of it was torn down to make way for a skyscraper that went up next door. So, if you take a look up from the courtyard of the prison you will be gifted to see a car park. The museum itself is rather meager. There are much better museums in South East Asia that were put together with much less funding.I would say, the two rooms that were interesting to walk through were the movie rooms that display the plan to take down the American planes and to display the treatment of the POWs.Cost: 20,000 Dong.

Trip to Ha Noi Hilton. Before my trip to the prison, I new very little of Viet Nam culture or war history. The prison was an eye opener. I have been alone and with a tour guide, the tour guide will surely help to decipher the time period you are learning about, and make sure you do not miss anything. The gift shop is a bit lacking (I love to buy souvenirs).

Well worth a visit. Value for money - you get to see where the prisioners were kept. The site is worth the money you pay for as opposed to the History museum. The presentation was very good and there is a structure to this place. It might be worth reading up a little bit about the histroy before you visit.

Worth the effort. This is a hard prison to visit but well worth it. Unfortunately the men's part of the prison has been torn down for a high rise, but the is still plenty left to see. Well done, and excellent descriptions of prison life. Eerie in a way with life size people in some cells. Lots of memorabilia.

Good to visit. If you are interested in Vietnam war history this is a good place to go. We thought the presentation was quite good. I almost found it more interesting then the war history museum in Hanoi. Thought it was a pretty moving place and there was enough English interpretation to understand the stories. Worthwhile to visit.

Interesting. Worth the lessons of history. This was better than I expected. The descriptions were well done. There was history from pre Vietnam war (interesting) and also a lot about the prisoners from the US during the war. It's distressing but not horribly disturbing so you aren't a total wreck at the end.
Terrible feeling after. Although it was in the past, but with the factors and display help visitors can understand how terrible it was in Vietnam under French colonialism

Disappointing. After visiting the prison and museums in cambodia and Saigon, this museum was disappointing. It lacked creativity and often the letters and explanations were not translated in English which left me feeling uninformed.

Interesting to see things from Vietnamese side. I was not overly impressed with the prison although it was interesting to see the Vietnamese perspective of the war and POWs. I feel that a lot could be done to improve this attraction. John McCain's flight suit was not there when we visited which was disappointing

Soul Searching Place. The Hanoi Hilton as it is known is a must to visit. It does show how bad man can treat fellow mankind. One can only feel the misery of the Vietnamese during the French Occupation.Of course the Propanganda photos of the Americans being well treated stands out but hey they were the invaders. One moment did stand out on my tour here when a girl tapped me on the shoulder and asked me if I mind if she could have her photo taken with me ...there was a group of Hanoi University Students both male and female and I seem to be the only westerner there...so we all had photo shoots...that was so cool...and they are so shy and friendly at the same time.That is what I find about the VN people ...they are so friendly ...not pushy and it does amaze me considering what they have gone through over the years . Well worth the visit.

Moving reminder of a tumultuous past. Although today's "Hanoi Hilton" is only a fraction the size of the original penitentiary, it serves its purpose: to conserve a dark piece of colonial history for posterity. The museum is quite well maintained and contains a number of pretty well-made exhibits that illustrate how prison life was back then. It takes 1-1.5 hours to see this interesting museum. Time well spent to develop an understanding of Vietnam's past. In my opinion this museum is a most for anyone that visits Hanoi.
Fascinating. There isn't much to see in this museum, but the things they had were highly interesting. I had a lump in my throat walking around.

Hoa Lo.. History , a must see of Hanoi. Very well presented. Makes you think a bout the human race. Was used even as a prison for the Us pilots. John Mc Cain wsa a guest here in the sixties. Entrancee fee to be payed.

Worthwhile visit.. Tells it from the Vietnamese side, if you only knowledge is western opinions. Didn't realise this was a notorious prison used earlier by the French.Tip, go by yourself, get there early and avoid the tour buses.
Can't stay indifferent. The exhibition is biased but very moving. It's in a relatively good shape, and the temporary exhibitions are good quality. 20.000 VND per person, 1 hour to visit.

An eye opener. I knew very little of what the vietnamese went through in the past. This prison really opened my eyes and I even became teary eyed when reading some of the stories. This is an absolute must visit place and a great place to understand some of vietnams violent past.

Much Smaller Thanks to Progress???. Unfortunately at least half (probably more like 3/4ths) of it was torn down to build a new hotel. What a shame. It was interesting and important that you know both sides of the story prior to visiting. It was actually created by the French for the Vietnamese prisoners. What was left was very interesting and worth a visit.

It`d be criminal not to visit. It costs around 20,000 VND and is an interesting place to spend a couple of hours. It is reasonably well done with some decent displays and information (most of which is in english, French and Viet).
Disappointing. For me it was disappointing. Too small and lack of good pictures. Too much propaganda and the videos are showed in small TVs.

Interesting, explore at your own pace.. We had a spare day in Hanoi and we were keen to visit this attraction on our own, mostly so that we could take our time. The entry fee to the prison is only about a dollar AU and well worth it! It was well set out with lots of information to read. English translations but a slanted view. It was moving seeing the cells and the conditions the prisoners were kept in. Life size model prisoners shackled to one another. The photos on display had been carefully chosen, part of the propaganda. The guillotine was on display and it was a little eerie standing there beside it and the casket beside it.I'm glad my friend took me there as I doubt I would have visited it myself. It was not crowded and we could spend as much time as we wanted....try and get there if you can as you won't be disappointed.

A history lesson. This prison, dubbed the Hanoi Hilton by the Americans imprisoned there during what the locals call the American War, is a great way to get a potted history of the country from the time of the french occupation until the departure of the US. It contains some fascinating torture instruments used by the french and showed how humanely the US prisoners were treated by comparison. Very well worth the trip.

The Hanoi--Hilton Great place to visit but be prepared for Propaganda. Great visit to Hoi Lo Prison which was primarily a French prison for Vietnam people for 60 years. Very scary place. During the Vietnam all American POWs were kept here including John McCain. Nearly all POWs were tortured here but the pictures on the walls show POWs playing Ping Pong, Volleyball, and looking like a real Hilton hotel. Wonderful movie showing the destruction of the war. Can see why Vietnamese did not treat pilots who were bombing and killing their people well. Just a terrible war
Hanoi Hilton. Very good and interesting,needs 60-90 minutes to give sufficient time.Most exhibits have english translation.Modest entry fee.

Worth a visit while in the area. Lots of info inside about the French and Vietnamese history of the prison including some interesting information about how well the American POW's were treated whilst detained... Inexpensive entry fee and quite close to the War Museum and Temple of Literature.

The walls of propaganda - most definitely worth a visit if in Hanoi. Don't believe everything you see and read within the walls of the famous Hanoi Hilton. A lot of propaganda on show here for sure. If you know your history you will see though the blatant glossing over of certain historical events. However if in Hanoi I would mostly recommend a visit. Allow for about 2 hours. Go in the morning and it is not so busy.

good exhibition. The exhibition is really very interesting although its also depressing to see what the french did to the vietnamese people in their time till they left this country. Its very surprising that the vietnamese were so kind to the american soldiers in their war. the whole exhibition is really a peaceful place.The entrance few is also very less.

History is written by the victors. The original purpose of Maison Centrale was to house and torture rebellious Vietnamese citizens advocating independence. Not surprisingly, the seeds of communist uprising were planted here, ultimately leading to the end of French Indochina.The present location is an exercise in irony. I already knew that most of the original French-built prison was knocked down to make way for the gleaming beacon to capitalism known as Hanoi Towers, a nondescript tall office building that could be in any city in the world. I also knew that its more recent history as a prison for captured Americans during the Vietnam War was highly idealized. And on that note it did not disappoint. After viewing the exhibits on the top notch treatment American POWs received, it's no wonder some decided* to stay for 4 or 5 years. (*Like the prison, my post is also written in irony.)I would not put this at the top (or middle) of the list of places to visit if you have limited time in Ha Noi. There are far more interesting historical and cultural places that you can only see in this city (citadel, Temple of Literature, countless museums). The presentation of Vietnam's more recent history can, on the other hand, be found throughout the country. (War Museum in Saigon, for example.) However, if you have 2 hours to spare this is worth a visit if for no other reason than to see how differently history is interpreted.

Worth paying a visit but don't expect too much. An interesting visit to recommend if you happen to be in Saigon. A large part of the museum is dedicated to the prison when it was built and used by the French (always referred as "french colonialists"). In short, the French were brutal, but could not break the Vietnamese patriots' spirit. On the contrary, they passed the time by helping and teaching each other politics, reinforcing their determination.In another part of the prison, you will see how the US prisoners who were imprisoned there lived. And you will wonder why they left after the war as they had everything they could dream of. The pictures show happy people well fed, doing sport, making a Christmas tree, etc. The propaganda is so incredibly naive, it's "funny" in a way (certainly not for the prisoners who had to play along). At the end of the day, you won't learn too much in this museum as you can question the credibility of pretty much everything you see. But it's nevertheless interesting, one of the few times you will remember that Vietnam is still a "socialist republic".The entry fee was 20,000 DNG - that's 0.8€ or so and the visit won't take more than 30/45 minutes max.
Can not stay indifferent. The exhibition is biased but very moving. It's in a relatively good shape, and the temporary exhibitions are good quality. 20.000 VND per person, 1 hour to visit.

hmmm..... Best part of the museum is reading what it says about how well the American prisoners are treated, perks they were given and how the guards were their buddies. It gave me a chuckle to see how happy they were portrayed. Very small prison, but worth a trip out if you are in the area.

A history lesson?. This is a very interesting place to see how cruel the French were to the Vietnamese for 100 years, but also how kind the Vietnamese were to the Americans during the American War! Yes that is the way it is presented with photographs of USA prisoners enjoying luxury food not available to local people at the time, games of volleyball and basketball and enjoying the holiday camp-type atmosphere. Maybe all history is presented to us in such a way and we just don't see it so it is an interesting place to visit and think for yourself what the truth may be.

Historically a must. Through all the many years of suffering by the Vietnamese people, this prison is part of it. They tried to give the impression that they treated the US POW in a good way, which can be argued, but still worth a visit. On view is McCane's parachute.

The Hanoi Hilton. Hao Lo Prison or the Hanoi Hilton as named by American POW is worth a visit built by the French to imprison Vietnam’s rebels against their struggle for independence. The exhibits mainly focus on the struggle for independence rather than the imprisonment of American POW’s and as most of the prison has been demolished you don’t really get a feel for the horrendous conditions those prisoners both Vietnamese and American prisoners would have endured. It does have some displays of conditions which try and replicate the times but a lot is dedicated to the fight for independence and hero’s and Martyrs to the communist cause. It is worth a visit but be prepared to look beyond the propaganda.
"Interesting...". This is worth a stop, but you have to prepare yourself for the incorrect propaganda you will find there. Don't get a guide as they spew it too.

Small section of the original site. Only around 15% of the original prison remains. What is left though is still worth seeing to understand the conditions that the prisoners experienced, including the guillotine!!

The Hanoi Hilton.... Grim and forbidding French prison, where you can see the terrible Guillotine up close and personal. Downed American airmen were kept here 'til the end of the war. Some saw the error of their ways and stayed on.
A must to see. This has been done so well. I really think it is a must to see .I came away thanking I had had the opportunity to see it.

Prisoner of Change. To look at it now and to think of what hell on earth must have been endured here.
This is a must see for anyone coming to Hanoi.
Excuse the propaganda we're Capitalists. :)
We latched onto a tour group and listened in for free.

Really interesting. We found the Hoa Lo Prison to be really interesting and worth a visit. The displays are all translated into English so we could read and understand everything we saw. There was a bit of propaganda around, which is to be expected in this type of place, but I thought it was one of the most interesting sites we visited in Hanoi.

John McCain's wartime digs. We Americans have heard so much about prison conditions during the Vietnamese War that we had to see for ourselves. The tour is easily self guided with signs in English. It can't be called a fun visit, but it is moving and powerful. English guides are available, but be prepared to hear plenty of government propaganda.

Interesting and well presented!. This is a well executed presentation of the history of hanoi hilton. Plenty to see, lots of information and a sprinkle of propaganda too!Spent 2 hours here, absorbed it all and then downloaded Banged Up Abroad Vietnam which features Senator John McCain telling his side of the story.

An important location to visit, but so darned biased. We wanted to see the famed Hanoi Hilton, but we did not expect a museum so full of government propaganda that basically absolved the current government of all wrongdoing. I know that the communist Vietnamese government runs the museum, so they get to tell whatever story they want to tell, but they really took a pass on any accountability.I have been to the genocide museum in Cambodia, and it was horrible, but it was much more honest. I know the Khmer Rouge isn't running Cambodia now, so that's probably the difference, but Hoa Lo was a joke.
An insight into a dark time.. This place really hits a nerve and gives you a true insight into the conditions the prisoners faced. Well worth a visit.

Hoa Lo Prison. We felt as though we had to do something 'touristy' during our stay in Hanoi so decided to visit the Hoa Lo Prison - very informative and makes for a good hour and a half trip. They have done the museum out so that it replicates what the prison would have been like and it feels fairly authentic. Worth a visit if you have some spare time.

Hanoi Hilton. We toured the prison, took in the information presented from the government's position, and found the actual artifacts extremely interesting.A true bit of history that should not be missed.

Very interesting Museum. I opted out on another tour to visit the infamous "Hanoi Hilton" Hoa Lo Prison. I found the history of this prison very interesting. Eerie dark cells, the guillotine, and propaganda about the American POWs and the American War (Vietnam War). Well worth a look especially for us who grew up during the Vietnam war.

Both sides?. Very interesting exhibit showing the use of the prison in different contexts. From the French colonial use (Maison Centrale) through to the incarceration of US military personnel. Plenty of information explained in Vietnamese and English. No need for a guide here. Not everyone will agree with the local interpretation of the treatment of the more recent incarcerations.
Near our hotel. As it was near hotel we went round to this and found it far more interesting than we thought if you have time do go different than you imagine

Very interesting. Loved this museum and thought it was well laid out. Very interesting displays detailing the prison throughout its usage from Vietnam prisoners of French colonel rule to treatment of US pilots including John McLain. However i feel it needs more English information about some of the displays as most just had one line. But seeing colonialism from the other side was fascinating but beware of the bias.

Well organised and a lot of information. Nestled in the city this old prison is chock a block full of great information and lots of rooms to view, its well organised and i recommend popping in here if you are in Hanoi. Total tour takes around 1 hour if you read everything!

Pretty good. A interesting look and well done re creation of the history of the prison. I enjoyed it, despite it being a bit spooky. Some of the history was quite one sided, but that's probably to db expected. Learned a lot, I was happy with a 30 minute stops, but you need about an hour to read every plaque, which are conveniently in English.

Informative. I assume that this is the infamous "Hanoi Hilton" that was made famous during the Vietnam War. At least that was what I was told by the young man who served as my guide that day. The prison itself was well displayed and had many artifacts that were left by the prisoner from that war. They even have the flight suit of John McCain proudly on display in one of the rooms. A good place to spend a couple of hours.

They call it the hanoi hilton but history scares you. A true story of the past and what people went thru to have achieved freedom. All that forgotten days when slavery and brutal ism was at its peak. Still people survived and fought back. The prison was even used to jail the US pilots but were accorded full importance once treaty was signed.

Too much propoganda but still worth a visit!. This place has been kept pretty nicely and being that it is such an important piece of Vietnam War history it is worth a visit. However, the propoganda and misinformation is rampant and pretty terrible in the small section about the time served there by American soldiers during the war, making it seem as if it was a nice place with great conditions. Quite a contrast to the section about how Vietnamese prisoners kept there by the French, which even has horror movie music playing to emphasize how terrible it was, then you go to the U.S./Vietnam War section which show photos of happy US Soldiers eating Christmas dinner and decorating a Christmas tree and descriptions of how the soldiers lived better than average Vietnamese citizens. If you can get over that and just concentrate on the historical significance you will be happy you visited. They do also show the personal possessions of Sen. John McCain which is pretty interesting as well. Admission is cheap.

Learnt about the past; Contemplated war & peace. It was a very educational and interesting visit. The prison is well preserved and helped us feel/understand just a tiny bit what it might have been like for the prisoners. Really makes you think about war, peace and how we should treat fellow human beings.

Hanoi Hilton. A bit propaganda-ish. But does give the other side of the Vietnam (unification) War. After growing up to Hollywoods take on it, it was good to see the Viet Cong's view. If you are French, don't go!

Informative and Sad. Although we found this to be a very informative visit, this is not a destination for everyone. We would not suggest it for children as many of the displays are frank representations of the conditions endured by inmates of the prison including the guillotine in the execution room. However for those who want to experience both the good and bad of Vietnamese history, this is a must see.

An insight into the war at the hanoi hilton. A bit of propoganda no doubt, I was suprised that the vietnamese openly admit this many of the museums state that photos etc were used as part of propoganda but it did provide an insight into how prisoners were treated by the french. I suspect not all the americans were treated as well as it says but even so if you compare it the tiger cages in the war museum in saigon it stands in stark contrast in terms of how each side saw there enemy.Worth visiting if you have time or have a keen interest in the war and/or french occupation.

Propaganda Museum. The Museaum could be very good, but it's just a propaganda museum.You can see how cruel the bad french treated the vietnamese people and on the other side you see how friendly the vietnamese people were with the americans !I imagine that the french colonist weren't very friendly with the prisoners, but you will not make me believe that the Vietnamese let the American prisoners play guitar, basketball and chat with journalist while decorating a christmas tree !!! Too much propaganda ruines the real history of the place !
Well worth it!. The best part of all is the propaganda film showing what a 'wonderful' life the American POWs had while they were there!!
Nothing really special. If it's your first visit in something of this kind it's ok...but after you pass for another places (like Cambodja) you think that is nothing special....

Creepy place. Creepy place because of the history, darkness and dark music. But very interesting to see. It has a really scary history from before the war, where you see how prisoners was held and how some escaped.

Thought provoking. An eye opening visit which is a reminder of just how much this amazing country has seemingly managed to put behind them in surprisingly few years! A worthwhile visit but obviously quite somber.

His lo prison. Almost missed this as we thought it would be just another tourist tick box, in fact it proved to be very interesting and thought provoking. The tour is a matter of following the arrows boldly displayed around the site so that you get to see everything. A living document of modern history showing how every race, no matter how sophisticated or not, can sink to the depths. History shows this time and again and it can be seen and almost felt here. There is quiet a lot of communist propaganda in some of the narratives given, much similar to the present American stance on Guantanamo and rendition but this does not detract from 2 hours of a very interesting visit to a site that looks as though it has kept it's authenticity.
Interesting to see. A section of the prison buildings have remained intact and the tour gives a good impression of the conditions that the prisoners had to endure.

Worthwhile Visit. Interesting venue and good value for money. The history on the life of the building from the time of occupation by the Chinese, French and American is both fascinating and horrifying. The cruely which people perpetrated on others is laid bare here. A heavy atmosphere can be felt in some parts of the building..

Worthwhile. The French did it to the Vietnamese, the Vietnamese did it to each other then to the Americans and then to each other again. But it is always worthwhile to see how we treat each other.... badly.

Prison propag. Prison Propaganda.It seems that some visitors to Hanoi Hotel forget what US B52's were doing to Vietnam from the relative safety of 30,000ft. Also, what was it that Vietnam did to deserve "special attention" from US Tormentors. Before judging Vietnamese treatment of US airmen, read up on Guantanamo Bay, Abugrabe and the writings of various US Military Chiefs of Staff on American intervention in what was an internal civil war in Vietnam. I thought a lot about these matters after visiting this and other American War museums across Vietnam. US war atrocities trump the worst work by their adversaries.L

Spooky sound effects!. This museum highlights the prison's history in the colonial period more than its function during the Vietnam war. Background sound effects are used to emphasise the cruel and inhumane treatment of prisoners under French rule. In contrast, the museum would have you believe that US prisoners were treated in an exemplary fashion. Somewhat at odds with prisoners' own accounts!

Worth a visit!. We were not expecting much from it but my friend and I actually really enjoyed it! For the price it's definitely worth a visit. Some rooms in there can be a bit scary.. You've been warned! ;)
More interesting than expected!. A very interesting visit for the entry priced paid. All exhibits in English as well, which was brilliant. Ideal for a rainy afternoon in Hanoi.

Very well displayed. A very somber place to visit. It shows how the people were treated by the french during the hard times as well as showing how the US troops were handled. Even though I am an American I was very impressed how they have maintained this facility

Vietnam trip 2013. It is one of those places that I guess you have to visit, but although it was interesting and we were glad we visited, a lot of the original prison has been destroyed so you are only seeing a very small part of what it was really like. Still, very good value for money.

Also known as Hanoi Hilton. I found this quite an emotional visit and could feel in the atmosphere that bad things had happened here and it certainly had. Built by the French in the 1870's and used as late as 1973 when the American pilots and crews were released after capture when they had been shot down in their B52 bombers. My husband wanted to visit this site and I tagged along. i found it very interesting but how cruel man can be to man. Worth a visit.

Valuable History. The history is amazing and well preserved. It's hard to imagine how hard the conditions were and how anyone could endure them. Understandably it takes the view of the North Vietnam struggle to unit the country so American visitors need to bear this in mind.

Eerie atmosphere and then it changes. You starts off the visit based on timeline... Vietnamese revolutionaries against the French colonist. The mood is eerie, my wife was freaked. The life-size model put images into your mind, as if they will just turn alive. You can really feel for them. Then it changes to the scene on the viet war. Where the viet were portrayed as gracious host to the POW. Some might feel it is propaganda at its overdrive. But let's stay rational. Everyone will usually do the same at this demonstration of self pity and self glorifying. It is up to the visitors to hear both side of the story and make their own conclusion. Whether if you feel it is realistic or just part of the story, it is but your opinion. They just also show their opinions and their story.

Interesting place - don't believe everything you read. Was interesting to see. The death rate for this prison seemed to be a lot lower than other prisons. This does not compare with the killing fields or s21 prison in Cambodia. The guillotine was very gruesome to see and death row so close to it. They even showed a guitar that was played by American soldiers. I don't know why they just can't be honest and say what they really did as have other countries have done. Would actually make it more interesting.
interesting. Cheap museum entry, interestIng to see what is on display even if many of the words are not in English. Does ghive another perspective on the American 'war'

Don't call it the Hanoi Hilton. The first visit of about three that I made there over a number of years took my breath away - this was the place where the US prisoners were kept. It really did look like the old photos i'd seen. But inside was even better. The accounts of the Vietnamese freedom fighters who were locked up there brought a completely different history to my attention. However, the bottom line was that no matter what your origin, being a prisoner there was a living hell.

Interesting. This prison offers an interesting insight in the recent history of Vietnam. Some great recreation of the prisoners' lives in Hoa Lo and helpful panels help the visitor to really understand what life was like in the prison.

A Grim Reminder. This is the prison that was occupied by John McCain and many other downed American pilots. It was ironic that the prison was first used by the French to torture and starve Vietnamese protesters. You get the usual propaganda about how well the Americans were treated by their Vietnamese captors, as well as misinformation about bombers "targeting" hospitals, but that's what you can expect from a communist government that's trying to present itself in the best light to its populace.

Very sober experience. Hao Lo Prison (known as the "Hanoi Hilton") is where Senator John McCain was prisoner for over 5 years. The Prison was divided into Men, Women and Women with children. We were shown the black cells where prisoners were shackled up by the ankles and also the electric wire which was used on prisoners. We also saw the prison clothes and where the prisoners tried to escape by sewer. The Prison had miserable, overcrowded conditions for over 2000 prisoners with poor food and unsanitary conditions, often in solitary confinement. We also saw the guillotine which they used to chop off the prisoners' heads and displayed them on trees as trophies. Not for the faint hearted!

Fascinating view of resistance against french. This place is a great place to come to get a (somewhat slanted) view of the resistance against the french occupation of the north and the vietnam war. It does have a bit of feel that some of the commentary is vietnamese propoganda (e.g. pictures and commentary of how well the US prisoners were treated) but in general is shows how grim it must have been for the vietnamese prisoners that were held in this prioson by the french.

Interesting, but telling the truth would be better.. It was an interesting place. The propaganda was pretty bad, though. Their presentation of how "nice" they were to US soldiers during the war was pretty disgusting.

Mixed Emotions. We took a tour of what's left of the Hoa Lo Prison (Hanoi Hilton) The museum was well designed, but it was a little creepy with the life sized prisoners, but it really shows you how it was. It is also interesting see how the war was seen from the Vietnamese point of view.

Well constructed tour of Famous Prison. Worth a visit! The photos of the prison during the U.S. Vietnam war made the place look like a vacation destination, but otherwise they did a nice job showing off the more gruesome treatment of prisoners that the place is known for.

average ~. I've seen worst than this in cambodia hence this is just nothing to me as i felt everything is renovated and make over before displaying it out. Only the dark room was a bit scary tho as there was not really lights inside. But still its nice to know why the american was treated better than their own locals prisoners and their vietnam prespective in this. It just took us less than 1hr to finish touring around for the cost of it.
Interesting but biased museum. Nice place to visit for an hour or so. Not too much to it. Remember it is communist Vietnam and it can be a little biased against the Americans

Not much left. Whats left of the original prison is ok, informative and has some displays available, most of the prison has been demolished to make way for a new hotel, small gift shop located near the entrance but it must be standing a sewerage system as the stench nearly killed us.

Saw John McCain's suit. The old prison is located next door to a hotel in the middle of the city. It is easily found and it does not take long to see, so it is worth fitting it into your daily schedule. The highlight was to see the clothes of John McCain when he was captured in Hanoi. There are many rooms with lots of Vietnamese war propaganda to be seen. An interesting visit even if you are not that much into history.

Propaganda at its best!. Most of the Hanoi Hilton was torn down. This museum focuses a lot on how badly the French treated the Vietnamese prisoners. But wow! We're the Vietnamese so nice to the American prisoners (stated with scarcasm). You'll McCain's flight suit and how "nice" the Vietnamese were to the Americans. Total propaganda, but an interesting place to visit. It costs a dollar to enter. Go. You'll be glad you did!

Fantastic insight to Vietnamese history. My boyfriend and I had studied the Vietnam war in school but had only heard it from the American point of view. We were keen to travel through Vietnam and learn the Vietnamese perspective. This was one of the first places we visited and it was fantastic.There were plenty of signs in English so we understood what had happened in the prison. It was used at various times as a prison by the French for Vietnamese Communists and later during the Vietnam war it was used by the Vietnamese to keep downed American pilots. We did notice a stark difference in how the lives of the prisoners were portrayed. The Vietnamese Communists were treated extremely harshly whereas for the Americans it seemed to be a home away from home.It was presented very effectively and we learnt a lot. Would recommend a visit.

Lot of history here.... Of course you need to stop in and see this place. It is famous worldwide and full of lots and lots of history. If you stop and read some of the walls and watch some of the videos there is a lot here.

Interesting piece of history. We didn't have a lot of time in Hanoi and this was in walking distance of our hotel, so we decided to visit. We were pleasantly surprised and really enjoyed the visit. Very interesting and educational. It's a self guided tour with descriptions in English that thoroughly explain the different areas of the prison and some of the history of Vietnam and Hanoi. It is definitely written from the Vietnam point of view and in the area describing the Vietnam (American) war, it's slanted to sound more like Vietnam was at war with the US, instead of with North and South. I, however, find the interpretation fascinating and found the whole place quite interesting and well organized. Worth a stop if you have the time in Hanoi.

Great place to visit.. We spent a couple of hours here one afternoon. It was really great. The displays are very informative including life size scenes replicating the prisoners conditions. It doesn't take too long to walk through and is excellently priced.

Hanoi Hilton. This was an old French prison. You can see an old guillotine there. It is where captured US pilots, including Sen. John McCain were held and tortured. Although you would not hear that from the vietnamese guides. You see the cells and one exhibit of a US pilots gear and some exhibits of conditions that Vietnamese were held under the French. what's interesting is that there is a statue Of Sen. McCain up by Hong Kiem lake

this is the historical place for the world. Vietnam is like the many tiny countries bigones go over like Russia has made for many and Brittain also so they many many...We recommend to see this place and have a look to the Vietnamies thinking about Usa,France etcVietnam people are very brave and also so friendly

Definitely worth a visit. Otherwise known as the Hanoi Hilton! The prison is a fascinating place to wander through and learn about how prisoners were treated and their daily life. I found it quite harrowing at times - the cells and the conditions were appalling. But nonetheless, worth a visit for the historical aspect alon.

Rather one-sided!. This was ok...I did find it very one-sided and i couldn't help but giggle during a video explaining how happy the US pilots were to be prisoners at Hoa Lo.....yeah who isn't happy to be stuck in prison...It is interesting to see and educational.

Hanoi Hilton. The reason for not rating it a 5 is the bias against Americans which is also the reason you should go if you are an American. It was a good place for me to go but I really took exception to the political bias.

Worth a visit. It's always good to get both sides of a story, this prison-turned-museum did a good job preserving and displaying the conditions and some artifacts from the Vietnam war. The commentary on the displays and the documentaries playing in the background leave you with no question how they felt about the war and their American counterparts. Worth a couple hours visit if you appreciate war history and/or have the time.
Hanoi Hilton. Probably a bit tough on this review, not sure what I was expecting. Probably a bit more on the American involvement like the two Senators who were housed here.
Hanoi 'Hilton' Prison. Great displays and explains a lot about the struggle for independence from France. Wish we had more time to explore there

Hoa Lo of interesting stuff here.. Fascinating museum covering the history of the prison from the bad old days of those nasty Frenchies who apparently abused the Vietnamese, through to the halcyon days of the Hanoi Hilton where the American POWs clearly loved their great life locked up by the Vietnamese. No but really...propaganda aside, this is just an amazing insight into what those poor people - particularly the Vietnamese in the early 20th century had to endure. I spent the 90 minutes we stayed there in tears. It is very moving. There are some great videos of the US soldiers inside too. Highly recommended.

Worth a look - but only if you have time. We recently visited Hoa Lo Prison and personally I was some what disappointed. There wasn't anything in particular but I somewhat expected more. It is well worth the look around for 45mins if you are in the area or looking for time to kill but I certainly wouldn't go out of my way for it.It is full of propaganda but hey it is a communist country so you need to take it with a grain of salt and it does highlight the brutality of the French.

Moving and disturbing but educational!. This was well set up and provided a good range of visual and written material to enable visitors to gain an understanding of the experience for prisoners. I found it amusing how the commentary referred to the Americans as 'puppets'!

Bias but interesting!. Their main focus was on the French use for the prison where they imprisoned the Vietnamese. It was very harrowing in some of the dark corridors and the guillotine was scary! The things we learnt and saw were fascinating and their dummy's were so lifelike it felt like we had a good sense of what it looked like back then.There was one room dedicated to the time when the Vietnamese captured American soldiers and kept them there. Previous to my visit I hadn't known anything about the prison, and found this room very bizzare! Their were video clips of the soldiers playing sports and looking happy etc And all the information around the room stated that they had been well looked after and were allowed to do what they wanted etc! I was really intrigued so when I got home I googled the prison and read about the time the American soldiers were kept there and learnt that they actually had quite a different experience to how the museum had portrayed! Look it up before you go! Very worth while to visit it but keep an open mind!
Fascinating. Well worth checking out- otherwise known as the 'Hanoi Hilton', where the American pilots captured during the war were held.
Hotel Hanoi. Very large focus on the Vietamese struggle against the French but a 'fair' representation of the ÚS/Vietnam War era.

Sobering . Good to see the prison and to learn about the terrible conditions and actions that were used agonist the prisoners. There are models to show the way the prisoners had to sleep and detailed info about the war ( although this is hilariously full of propaganda). Worth a quick look.
Loved the history behind it. It was very interesting the story's behind and how they survived. It must of been horrible . They had so little in there and the conditions were just horrific

A dark place. A very sobering place, I went around with a constant lump in my throat and tears in my eyes. The size of the cells were tiny,dark and depressing, how anyone survived that kind of incarceration is beyond me.

The 'Hanoi Hilton'. Another interesting place to visit in Hanoi, two minutes by taxi from the Old Quarter. Will probably mean more to those who are old enough to remember the Vietnam War. Originally used by the French during their imperialist days.
an interesting experience. easy to tour around it yourself as it is well laid out and there is plenty of printed information. Interesting and some parts are downright creepy!

The "Hilton" that can teach you some history. I was told that this place was nicknamed "The Hanoi Hilton" . Photos and belongings of the POW's were displayed, including those belonged to John McCain. this place is now a means of propaganda but still worthwhile to visit. This place, though not a pleasant place to be (it was a prison afterall) presented that part of the world history in a different version.

Amazing. I can't believe how raw the prison is. Cages made of barbed wire where many prisoners were kept in confined spaces, where every move meant pain. It's definitely thought provoking, not only for the brutality but as a comparison to current day Western prisons. It's the second time for me, visiting the prison. Worth a look. Make sure you read the story boards.
Interesting. Very graphic in history, well exhibited thank goodness it's not in operation now. There was nothing to dislike.

nice visit, but propoganda got old quick. We weren’t planning on stopping in, but it started raining and we had no rain gear on us...so in we went. Parts of this prison are fascinating, like the original prison doors and the guillotine. The American pilots room is a little over the top—but still interesting. Worth visiting!

Good Place with HanoiKids as tour guide. Went here as part of HanoiKids tour of Hanoi. Thought it was good but not great. Hanoikids did an excellent job with describing the prision and the history behind it(with a new luxury hotel taking up much of the space of the old prision....kind of ironic). Wars and colonialism are terrible but did not think this prision was any better or worse then most in the time period.
Very Interesting. A great place to visit not just for the history of the prison itself but also the occupants from the early resistance to a US presidential hopeful!
Changed my perspective. I'm a 60's baby and grew up with a picture of the Vietnamese as the bad guys. This place shows you just how much that probably wasn't the case.

Our 1st stop. You can't visit Hanoi without seeing the Hanoi Hilton. Only $2 and a quick 30 minute self tour. We stayed in a downtown hotel (Hanoi Imperial hotel) and with street map in hand.... Walked to the prison.

Lived up to expectations..... Were looking forward to going here and seeing the "Hanoi Hilton" and we found it lived up to expectations - some small parts are less interesting but on the whole very good and the guillotine is very creepy

Enjoyable. We enjoyed visiting the prison, it was well laid out and very informative. We spent one hour walking around the different sections. It is great value for money, the entrance fee was 20,000VND for an adult and 10,000VND for a student.

Understand the Real Story of the "Hanoi Hilton". Most people associate this with the Vietnam War, but that was not where it had it's beginnings. It was built by the French to imprison Vietnamese agitators seeking to take back their country from the horrible and criminal French occupation, aka colonialism. The methods of torture the French inflicted on the Vietnamese people is well documented here, and breathtakingly heartbreaking to read about.This museum was created for the people of Vietnam, to understand their own history and only of their own struggles for the reacquisition of independence which was rightfully theirs to begin with. The fact that some Americans were held here during that terrible part of Vietnamese history is almost secondary. Go with open eyes, and come away with an inspired appreciation for the unwavering determination of a people to remain free and independent of foreign power, and also a deepened respect for the suffering they endured doing so.

Great insight. Fascinating place to visit, very informative and some parts hit hard with pictures depicting the background of the stories. The prison also showcases the hanoi Hilton part and is well worth a watch of the videos, definitely a place to visit if your interested

'Good' doesn't quite get it ..... Hanoi's prison is a memorial to heroism and cruelty. It's a place of tribute for the brave and the underground; as well as a sobering memorial to the cruelties of war and its depravities. Set beside the Hanoi Towers business precinct with which it had a deal to share space, the prison remains a grim reminder of the Vietnam War and the history of cruelty throughout the region. The Vietnamese have been a nation of the oppressed - and remain a people of resilience and optimism. Hoa Lo Prison might not have the grim reaper impact of Ho Chi Minh's War Museum with its memorial to the atrocities of agent orange; but it remains impactful and memorable. 'Good' might not be the word, but it lingers long in the mind.

Interesting but a bit dated. The museum/ prison is layed out well and offers some insight into the history of the place but it has closed off most of the actual prison so you only see a little of the actual place
Great insight into Hanoi Hilton. Great displays and fabulous video footage along with photographs. The remembrance courtyard is beautiful.
Amazing history. I have to say this trip I have learned a lot about the war and this was no different. A must see when you are in town. About a hour self walking tour.

Get it up to date. Magnificent display of the prison as it was used to detain political activists and insurgents fighting the French, but it's role as a prisoner of war incarceration facility for American and other servicemen appeared to be largely ignored. I can appreciate the significance of many of those imprisoned by the French to the Vietnamese, but as a tourist attraction it would see that a bit more about the prison's more recent history would be more attractive
Historic. An interesting place to visit but really not a lot to see. The highlight was a real guillotine on display and there are English explanations of the different area of the museum.

Worth a visit. Hoa Lo was a prison long before the Vietnam war. The historical walk through this museum is a trail though time beginning with the French imprisoning rebel Vietnamese to a few pics of American senator John McCain (Vietnam War Veteran and prisoner at this prison during the war) visiting the museum. Similar to other places, the information seems biassed but still there is a solemn undertone that gives you the impression that the walls have seen more that they care to let on.

Interesting but biased. The museum is interesting and the mannequins add to the somewhat eerie atmosphere. Seeing a real guillotine is not something you see everyday, and some of the pictures are gruesome. The museum has a lot of focus on what the French did to the Vietnamese, which may be true but painted the Vietnameses treatment of American POW's in a very positive light of basketball and Chistmas lunches. Google John McCain POW torture to get another perspective!Worth visiting and cheap to get in.

Interesting and informative. It helped that before we came to Vietnam that we saw a TV documentary on a U.S. Senator/Pilot that was sent to this prison. It made the visit more real to us. It has a lot of information there and the way it is set up you really get a feel of what it must have been like to be a prisoner there..American or Vietnamese. Worth the visit.

Sobering history lesson. The Hoa Lo Prison i feel is a must see if your interested in the history of Vietnam and what it's people have endured. It's more than just the Hanoi Hilton, it's Vietnamese history. leaves you humbled.

History..... A quick trip here by ourselves to check out the Prison. It was good fun for between 30 mins to an hour. Some interesting bits.Its not rated higher as I am not that interested in it.Its worth a trip if you have nothing better to do.
Good museum. Although this prison has such a sad story to tell, it is certainly worth a visit. It is very well presented, easy to find and reasonable cost to enter
Interesting and confronting. It was great to see and the history very confronting but glad we went as we had no idea of its history.

Interesting but full of propoganda. Having heard of this we decided to give it a visit. I found it very interesting to read about the history of the prison. If you can look past the obvious biased propoganda... but that can be interesting to. Its worth a visit for less then a pound a person.

Informative and interesting. One of the better museums to visit in Hanoi. Much more informative than both the Military History/Army Museum and the disappointing Ho Chi Mihn Museum, and cheaper, although you do have to bear in mind it leans heavily towards the Vietnamese side of the story.
Interesting worth a look. Well presented representations of prison life through the French colonial period and the 'American' war.
