A moving experience. this museum is very well done and especially the pictures speak more than a thousand words. It was very moving to me to learn about the atrocities done to the local Vietnamese "rebels" by the French colonial authorities and to learn about the courageous Vietnamese women held there.

Very Interesting - But Take A Guide. We visited here as part of a city tour round Hanoi. We all found the prison very interesting but that was in part down to our guide who explained what life was like in the prison. Yes it is very one sided but a fascinating place all the same.

Reflection on History. If you have an hour or two whilst in Hanoi it's worth a visit. The information provided is enough for you to feel what the prisoners experienced whilst also giving the other side of the American POW pilots and how they were treated: opposite ends of the scale. The courtyard mural is symbolic of the cruelty received by the prisoners.

prison preview. Good place to spend a couple of hours. Informative without going into huge amounts of details - which suited us as a family. A couple of areas could have done with slightly more details. We took our two children (aged 11 & 12) and they found it interesting. It gives them an insight into history. The displays showing prisoners was good (but sad). Perhaps a bit one sided - but as I wasn't there ... who knows .... It is free for children under 15 which makes it a cheap educational family outing
Nice place little sad. It is a nice place to see but in the and we finished a little sad for seeing so much sad history. The ticket price was quite cheap and it was easy to find the place.

attraction. Very confronting place. The way the men & women were treated and what they had to endure was incredible. They were not given very much at all and their cells were basically big enough for a small single bed with no amenities as such.

Very interesting history. The history behind this museum was fascinating. It had several reincarnations as a town centre, a prison for the revolutionaries, political prisoners and prisoners of war of the French occupation and it also once held American Prisoners from the 'American War' including Senator John McCain amongst others. Very interesting artefacts and displays on prison life, including Death Row and cells etc.

"Hanoi Hilton" Must see in Hanoi. If you only have time to see one or two things in Hanoi, I'd visit Hoa Lo prison. It gives you a good idea of the history of the country. It was built by the French colonists to suppress the Vietnamese. During the 60's and 70's, the North Vietnamese used this prison to hold the American POWs. Senator John McCain was held here for years. This was the first place we visited, we saw only Asian and European tourists, many French, but no American.

Good Historical Reflection of Prison. It's worth spending an hour or two visiting the Hao Lo Prison. Interesting enough information presented and the obligatory use of mannequins these days in prisons is entertaining in itself. We liked the courtyard wall mural which is an artistic impression depicting cruelty. The Prison ties up Vietnamese, French and American prison history reasonably well and it's fair enough to bias this towards Vietnamese being the worst treated - it's their country.

Lot of propaganda, but worth a visit. To me it was worth a visit. The museum give some insight into how terribly prisoners were treated during French occupation and how wonderfully american POW were treated in comparison (with lavish christmas dinners, plenty of medical supplies etc). Decide for yourself how much of it is propaganda. Nevertheless, worth a visit and kind of fun to see "John McKain's flight uniform" on display^^
Horrific. Well worth a visit and a horrific representation of what people will do to each other. Certainly it is one sided in part, but it is not just about the American prisoners....

Propaganda. It seemed like everyone viewing the prison was a foreigner, some political bias against France and US but overall pretty balanced. Only a small area of prison remaining and there is a charge for entry, visit did not take up more than 1hour.

Interesting visit. If you're American it's worth visiting as a part of our history, as well as Vietnamese history. The difference between the museum compares French treatment of Vietnamese prisoners to how the Vietnamese treated American pilots is obvious propaganda, but I found it fascinating.

Reflects Vietnam's sad history. This is one of those not particularly jolly, but very worthwhile, tourist attractions. Vietnam and its people have been so cruelly treated by its invaders and settlers and this prison, built by the French and used right up until the American War tells its story well. The memorial wall in one of the courtyards is especially powerful and most signage is in three languages.

A lot to learn about the country. This attraction is well worth a visit. There is an entrance cost - slips my mind the amount - but worth every cent. There is a lot of history and one learns about how cruelly these people were treated.

Eerie Prison, but Good Museum. Some of the exhibits were a bit eerie, but compared to Alcatraz, it got it's point across. Lots of it was about the French treatment of the Vietnamese rebels. It's only about 20% of what the actual prison used to be. But a good example of the cells and such. Easy to get to. Didn't take long to go through.

'Worth a visit'. I liked visiting this but I studied Criminology so it appealed to me but my boyfriend also enjoyed it. It's not too big and you can probably do it in a hour or so. You can see were and how the prisoners were held and how some escaped. In my opinion you also get to observe some of the Vietnamese propaganda in relation to how they treated the American prisoners. Also you can see a real guillotine which was creepy but interesting to see

Quite Disappointed. Don't let the exterior of the prison fool you. It's actually a small museum. Exhibits are not really detailed and somehow it's biased. A fair bit of propaganda here and there. But worth a stop if your just seeing the major touristic sites in Hanoi.

Also Known As Hanoi Hilton. It is a very interesting visit with historical significance. Obviously, the facts are one sided and not balanced but it gives a good impression of the terrible conditions suffered also by the Vietnamese people who were interned there during the French colonial times.It is really worth a visit. Keep you eyes and mind opened.

Disappointing. Hey its a prison right? Shouldn't be enjoyable. But it was very small, no tour guide was present. I was in and out in 5 minutes. Watch the great underrated movie Hanoi Hilton with Micheal Moriarty and Paul LeMat instead.
good to visit. It is easy to get there, if you stay in the Old town, you can catch a taxi. It will take you to there around 30.000VND. All driver know where it is.

OK if very one-sided.. As many previous reviewers have already stated the prison offers a very biased account of history. At 20,000VND though it still offers a reasonable way to pass an hour or so. It could also do with more English translations for some exhibits but overall at the price its worth a visit if your nearby and at a loose end.

A sad reminder of the country's past. It introduces you to the past struggles of the Vietnamese people against colonists and external military attacks. It might not be exactly balanced or factual but the you will know that if have some idea about the world history in general. I would definitely recommend because it does make you think and the mostly thoughts on non-violence and tolerance towards fellow beings.

Great. We stumbled across this- I was not expecting to go but this was definitely worth visiting. It's informative and there's lots f stories to be told! It seems a lot of political prisoners were held their- it has photos of inmates etc.Loads of figurines/ models of people locked up and in cells (I found it very creepy but it adds to the effect I guess). You're able to see the male area of the prison, female area of the prison, and where the death inmates were held(they also have the guillotine the french used to execute them) . Theres also information on American soldiers who were kept as prisoners of war- lots of photos of them celebrating Christmas, playing games, and a video of them getting ready to be released.Loved the museum- would highly recommend it! I think it was something like 20,000 VD, which is a good price.

One of the best sites in Hanoi. To be able to understand the Nationalism of the country, a visit to this site is a must. Built by the French to jail Vietnamese Nationals, it shows what it took to drive out the French, and the United States. It was truly inspiring. I entered into Hoa Lo Prison during a violent monsoon downpour and actually had to remove my shoes due to the depth of the water at the entrance. When seeing me standing without shoes, a wonderful generous employee actually gave me his sandals, as he saw me walking gingerly in my bare feet. After a comfortable walk throughout the prison, on leaving I tried to tip that staff member, but he smiled and refused my money.

A must visit place.. It is definitely a suggested place to visit in Hanoi but it does not mean you will like the experience. It is important from historical point of view. The Maison Centrale was a prison used by the French colonists for political prisoners. Only the gatehouse is really left from the entire prison and it serves as the museum. Guillotine room, still with original equipment, is the remnant of the French era. There is a bit of political propaganda predictably on exhibit and that leaves at times wrong impression. During the Vietnam war era the prison housed American prisoners of war.

Hanoi Hilton!. One of our friends wanted to visit here and glad we did. It's not too far from the center of the city and it's great reading and seeing the Vietnamese perspective of the Vietnam/American War.

Interesting although slightly subjective. This was one of the places I most wanted to visit in Hanoi, and I'm very pleased that I did. Although quite small, I found the displays to be interesting - particularly the US section. There is a definite difference in the way different periods are presented - the French were barbaric and the US pilots were treated like princes. This is quite common in Vietnamese displays though, and is interesting in itself!

good place worth to pay a visit. They have the video image showing how Americans bombarded Hanoi during WW2 and how strongly they faught back.For that historical archives I think its worth to go. It only cost you one dallor anyway.

Very thought provoking. We went here with our guides from Hanoi kids. They were able to give us more detail than you can read on the exhibits. In the west we only see the American viewpoint and it was good to see it from the other side. You learn a lot but you learn a whole lot more with a guide.
Interesting history. Vietnam's history is very interesting (even if it is now being told a little less accurately than it should). The prison tells the ale of a brutal colonial period.

Interesting but biased. Was interesting to walk around and learnt a fair bit about the history surrounding Hanoi through the ages. Was interesting to see how Vietnamese and then American POW's where kept. Though the whole museum was very biased as is the norm in Vietnam.

Very thought provoking but no Alcatraz. This is worth seeing most certainly to learn more about Vietnamese history, you'll notice a definite bias in how different periods are covered. We'd have preferred to have a tour guide as feel we missed out/didn't learn as much by not having one.

Disappointing. It was a lot smaller than we expected. We did not enjoy it, and felt that most of things that were posted up around the museum were lies. The words are very much Viet Kong words, and say that the people starved because the Americans took all of the food. My father is a Vietnam vet, and did not appreciate what was said. Will not visit again.

Quite interesting and positive for a prison. We walked down to Hoa Lo for a visit from the old quarter and it was interesting. You can really see the terrible conditions prisoners were kept in. The photos and videos in the last few rooms are a good end. There are some stairs to some upstairs rooms with lists of people who died - not very interesting.

Disappointing. A lot smaller than expected, we were all disappointed, although it is another place ticked off the list.We were told part of it had been knocked down a few years ago, to make way for a shopping area, which is such a shame.But if you visit Hanoi it is still a must see, but it will only take up an hour or so of your time.
interesting. very interesting to visit. Tells a lot about the history, and what the prison was used for. Worth a visit.
Well maintained. Entrance fee is reasonable. Well-maintained museum. Very interesting and one would appreciate the country's history and would understand about the effect and result of Vietnam War.

great display and information. this Museum gives you a really good insight look on what happened during french colonialism and to American soldiers during Vietnam War.everything is translated to english aswell, and they even have some original cells and utensils from that timme.great museum.

Moving experience. I really enjoyed our trip to this museum. Although not all their signs are translated to English you still get the experience of the prison just by seeing the exhibits - they have real sized human figures that can speak a hundred words. The music is eerie and there is a movie you can watch about the American prison experience there.Great for a 1-2 hour visit.
Worth a look. Worth a look. Beware of the dodgy taxi people who hang around waiting for tourists - just hail a proper passing one from the street.

Not the best exibition but worth a visit. The exhibition contains a lot of poems, photo's and even a fair bit of propaganda, but still this it is enough to be jaw-dropping. Better parts are the rooms that are kept original or that are built like they used to be. It is very impressive to see the abysmal circumstances the french left their prisoners in.

Gave me goose bumps. Yes, it is made for tourists. Yes, there is propaganda. But still... This place is impressive. It is hard to believe that people could be treated like this - and I am talking about the old part. The death row cells really gave me goose bumps despite the heat outside. Very well done to keep the effect alive.The "Hanoi Hilton" part about the American soldiers is less credible, in fact, not credible at all. If it is true, good for them, but considering those were war times... well...Anyway, well worth a visit.

A view of French Colonialism. I went to this place with my eyes open as I have almost every other historically significant place in Vietnam, and I agree there is a large amount of political rhetoric in the displays. However one needs to remember this when reading things and not berate on trip advisor that they believe the Vietnamese version of history is wrong.The prison museum does what it sets out to do it shows how the French colonial administration treated Vietnamese prisoners including what seems to be predominantly political prisoners. Seeing the guillotine in the death cells was pretty grounding.As for the displays about the US prisoners of war if you take this with a grain of scepticism, there are some interesting exhibits.

Very interesting place. This place is very much from the Vietnamese perspective but it still shows great insight into a different perspective of a horrific war. It guides you through in a clear manner to give you a sense of the horrors the Vietnamese faced (and apparent joy the Americans felt when they were imprisoned there)
Still worth it.. This was good. A lot of the posters are in Vietnamese but when you consider how cheap the entry is.. It's still worth it. You still get a lot out of it.

Hanoi Hilton. A piece of world history opened to the public. There is a particularly beautiful courtyard sculpture that epitomises the suffering of those held here by the French and then the Vietnamese. An interesting commentary on the US airmen that were held here over 7 years during the war.The communist/socialist rhetoric of the displays is oppressive but the photos pretty much tell the real story.
Informative, if potentially biased.... Cheap entry fee: VND 20,000 (Roughly 75p). Informative, if potentially biased. Take some exhibits with a pinch of salt. Overall definitely worth a visit.

Interesting look at Vietnamese history. Our visit to Hoa Lo Prison aka the Hanoi Hilton was very interesting. Our guide took us through each of the areas of the prison that gave an in-depth look at Vietnamese history. The French built the prison over a century ago. The prison housed primarily many political prisioners over many decades while in French hands, then American prisoners were held there by the North Vietnamese. The prison had the original guillotine used by the French that was overwhelming to see. Everyone should take this tour because it is so much more than just a prison, it is a piece of Vietnamese history.
Interesting. The prison is interesting; but the value is limited as the poetry, and letters etc are all only in Vietnamese so its hard to get all the value from the the exhibits.

French colonial shame........ Sobering but important history lesson which goes a long way to explaining Vietnamese determination to expel their colonial overlords over the years. Cruel and utterly inhumane treatment of prisoners (many political) within living memory, and a working guillotine that explains why modern-day vietnamese are not particularly nostalgic for their French connections. Visit and think.

Interesting and well laid out. A worthwhile visit whilst in Hanoi. It traces the history of the museum back to the French colonial times and up to the detainment of US air force pilots during the Vietnam war. It's relatively easy to get to and is perfect to escape the extreme heat of the afternoon!

Interesting but tainted. This museum is one of the more famous in the west and was always on the to do list. I always imagined it would be isolated but it is in the city proper. Like all places in Vietnam related to the Vietnam/American war it became a propaganda vehicle. Take this aspect away and use you're imagination to feel what it was like at that time to those held here. It can be special if you let it A must see regardless
Interesting.... We had to see the "Hanoi Hilton". We have family members that served during the war & we found it very interesting but depressing.

Fascinating. After I found the Hoa Lo Prison I found it fascinating. It is actually very quiet and is pretty easy to navigate. To see how prisoner were held, tortured, and killed was intense. I have been to many jails and museums about torture in my life and this place was pretty fascinating. It was also very quiet here. There were not many visitors so you could take your time wandering and reading. There is English translation and because of that I learned a lot of new things. I think it is definitely worth a visit.
Grim but interesting. Popular with our kids, bit grizzly and depressing. Realistic life sized models of prisoners in shackles.

Fascinating & worth a visit while in Hanoi. While many of the exhibits here are a bit ghoulish for my taste I nonetheless enjoyed the history associated with this place and was glad to have seen it. Enjoyed too by my husband and teenage kids

gotta see it once!. This is the famous site where American airmen were imprisoned during the Viet Nam War. and prior to that served as a prison/torture center for dissenters to French rule over nearly a century. most of the prison has been torn down for a huge high rise. The remaining buildings give one an glimpse of what the prison was like. The communist propaganda is a bit heavy handed but amusing.

Helps to have read 'When Hell Was In Season" before you go. The museum is well worth a visit. Understandably it focuses on history from the North Vietnamese perspective and, in particular, from the French colonial times. There are a few displays concerning the 'American' war and the life of the US PoWs during that conflict.Much of the site has been redeveloped so the prison museum is much much smaller than when it was actually used as a museum.Fortunately I had taken 'When Hell was in Session' by Admiral Jeremiah Denton as holiday reading, which I had completed before the visit. Denton was incarcerated for about 6 years in the 'Hilton' and other such places so his perspective puts a different complexion on the displays.Allow an hour for the complete visit.
Good choice. Appeares to be unimpressive at first glance. Prison had real stuff left like the prison cells and a real guillotine, which we hadn't seen before. nice to visit.

confronting. was a very thought provoking place .the vietnamese people have certainly endured cruelty and hardship over the years but after seeing displays in the prison was good to see they didn't treat western prisoners the same as portrayed in the photos of xmas celebrations etc

Abandon Hope all Ye Who enter Here!. There is nothing redeeming about wars. Wars are all about killing and destruction. People die, sometimes ignobly. Bad things happen on both sides. But people fight wars for many reasons, sometimes to throw off an oppressor and they pay the price selflessly. This place is full of pain. It has had several generations of incarcerations, all of them harrowing, as evidenced by the presence of a Guillotine and basket for catching the severed head. This place seeks to explain and educate about the struggle of the People to throw of the yoke of Colonialism and of Oppression. It is not possible to walk through the exhibits and be unmoved. Some experience shame, others recoil in horror at the confrontation, but it is rare to remain unmoved. On the other hand the presentation and exhibits do not sensationalize or offer any gratuitous material. Instead they speak of the darkness of events and evoke an inkling of what it may have been that kept hope alive. There are publications that can be purchased that are probably not available elsewhere. They are written in a polemic style that doesn't sit easily with the Western aesthetic, but important to read, nonetheless. Although the visuals re-create the awfulness, the oppressive heat of the place is relieved with air conditioning and lots of fans. You will emerge with lots of questions and troubling feelings from this place, if you didn't already have them.

Take time to visit this great attraction. Recommended to us by a local guide and a taxi ride very cheap in Hanoi to the prison was in itself an experience. The prison is very well laid out and a guide is not necessary, it gives a very good illustration of the way Vietnamese treated especially the American pilots and how other prisoners were treated some stories not for the squeamish but a visit worth while, a lovely peaceful garden to relax and gather your thoughts.

Grim reminder of the past. Harrowing reminder of the past in Vietnam. Walking round the museum one is greeted by the sight of the prison cells including Death Row. Included in the display is the Guillotine once used at the prison.Only part of the Prison remains as the rest was demolished to build a hotel. However there is enough left to advise of what life at the prison was like. Allow 1- 1/12 hours visiting time

Cheap entrance, horrible history!. I left humbled and nearly ashamed, such horrible history these people have suffered.A visit to Hoa Lo Prison/Hanoi Hilton is well worth the effort. The premises have lots of fans, and some rooms have AC. Take some time to study history and better yourself. The museum is very relaxed and easy to stroll around in. Entrance is 20k per person, Aug 2013.

Curious.... Well this is worth the visit just to read some of the captions that go with the (American) Vietnam War photos. Interesting and informative history including the bit that I went for - the "Hanoi Hilton". Read how the capitalist imperialists waged terror .....etc etc Well worth a visit.
Very interesting. Very interesting to go with Hanoi kids. They could tellus a lot more interesting little bits of information, much better than reading the plaques.
glad it is 2013. Learnt a lot about the history of Hanoi, the people have had alot of tragedy in there lives and we really need to know it.

Moving experience. We felt this visit well worthwhile. Although a relatively small area of original prison has been preserved it still gave a strong feel of what it must have been like. The room for the women prisoners is mind boggling when you read that more than 300 were kept in its tiny space. There were obviously some heroic women who tried to make it as easy as possible for less fortunate women. Overall good value and well worth spending time here

Learn about the "American War". Interesting place to learn about the history of the "American War" and war against the French colonists. Very informative though some of the cell exhibits were extremely eerie. Small enough to get through in a couple of hours and houses 2008 US Presidential nominee John Mc Cain's flight suit.

Excellent, even if it glosses over some areas. Best museum in Hanoi. OK so it's slightly problematic in the treatment of the US POWs where if you take the exhibits at face value you'd think they were at a holiday camp, but that aside there's lots of interesting photos and well presented exhibits. Just need to interpret them vritically through the lens of history

Fascintating. Hoa Lo prison (Hanoi Hilton prison) is a really nice way to spend a couple of hours in the afternoon learning about the history of the prison and how both Vietnamese and the Americans were kept there. Of course, it is a one sided story but it is important to learn about that side also. It's a shame that most of the prison has been knocked down but what remains is well worth the 20,000 VND entrance fee (10,000 students). There's a good bit of English translations as well as plenty of pictures. However, it may have been useful for some of the documents to be in English, but they are in French. Probably, best not to bring the young kids along - not a lot to see for them.

OK, but quite a lot of propaganda. Open 8am-5pm. Adult entry 20,000 Viet Dong. 10,000 VD for students with ID. Worth a visit for the history. I challenge any Westerner to imagine squeezing into & escaping through the very small sewer tunnels which 100 prisoners did! It must have been horrible being imprisoned there as you can tell from the small cells and wax-model prisoners (including women & children).... and the guillotine :( I had an American with me and the propaganda was really not to our taste. Sorry, but we can't believe that the Americans ate chicken regularly, nor their "Christmas dinner" photographs. Their poor diet was very evident from the way their clothes hung off their skeletal frames on the day they were liberated. Still..... an interesting visit.
Worth and hour or so. Very interesting, although I would love to hear the views of American soldiers who spent time here. Well set out with reconstructed cells, as well as facts throughout.

A disappointment after the museums of Ho Cho Minh City. I was extremely disappointed with this museum, it didn't give much of a feel of how the conditions really used to be, not in comparison with the other war museums I visited in Vietnam. Almost all of the annotations were in Vietnamese, and there were rooms after rooms dedicated to individual people without information about these people! I wished I hadn't bothered. Save the history museums for Ho Cho Minh City!
Hanoi Hilton Maison Central. Good informative exhibition of modern history, French then American use. Several high profile Americans stayed here

Very interesting. This was an awesome place to visit. There are plenty of photos and stories on the walls. Very interesting to walk through and see the videos that are playing. Good way to spend an afternoon.

Interesting. It was interesting but wasn't fabulous. We had our children with us and they thought it was a bit creepy. Didn't really care for the entire room talking about how well the Americans were treated.
"Hanoi Hilton". One of the museums we were recommended to visit during our stay in Hanoi. We found the museum very informative. There were few people visiting the day we were there.

Hoa Lo Prison, Maison Centrale, 'Hanoi Hilton' - all one and the same. Rather somber place to visit but very interesting and worth spending some time here. Interesting history and displays. Particularly liked the sculpture memorial in the courtyard.

A must-see!. Really learned a lot during this visit.
Lovely collection of pictures of former prisoners of war.
Vietnamese and American.
Even shackles used and a guillotine.
Must see to believe it!

Gives you a real sense of what it was like in the prison. This prison is quite small but you get a good sense of what it was like to be locked up here. There are various cells which you can walk into and other artefacts like the guillotine. The descriptions are all in English for you to read.

The Lockup Experience. The prison isn't a place one would want to go but this is the one you would want to go if you're gonna be in Hanoi. Here you can see more than you wanted on how the American pilots were held during the war, how they lived and how uncomfortable it is. Interesting place to see what the prisoners have to go through.

The prison museum, nicknamed "The Hanoi Hilton" by the American Pilots. The prison museum, nicknamed "The Hanoi Hilton" by the American Pilots who were held there during the war, covers not only the war against the Americans, but also the struggle against the French colonialists. Some of it is rather harrowing (the actual French guillotine used to behead Vietnamese insurgents is still on display), but most of the material on the war against the USA is somewhat propagandistically presented, as if the US prisoners all had a nice time there.

Nice place to visit, but.... No one would want to live in a prison, anyway. The exhibits spell out the history of the prison, beginning with French Colonial times. There is a section dedicated to American pilots held there during the Vietnam War, including John McCain.

History the hard way. Thinking we know what the Vietnamese people has been through over the past centuries the Hoa Lo-prison will teach you, that books can only describe til a certain limit. Standing in the death row with view to the French guillotin is an experience that wont leave you right away.
Well presented. Interesting but biased presentation of a historic jail in Hanoi. English signage and tour material meant that I could appreciate the displays.

History as told by the winners. If you enjoy a bit of history this spot is worth a quick visit. It's narrative focuses on the use of the prison by the French to hold political prisoners fighting for independence. A small space is set aside for narrating the "wonderful" treatment of the North Vietnamese of US POW's. This is all a bit galling, do they think no one has heard the testimonies of these prisoners? The winners always get to tell their version of the past.
Great Historical Site. Provides a lot of information. Historically significant because it was used during French and American invasion. A must see.

If you have nothing else to do then visit.. Honestly, this was terrible in my oppinion. I have visited many old prisons before and this has to be the worst. The information was terrible and the way they have "done it up" is ridiculous, it doesnt even feel like it was ever a prision. By all means go and visit, but remember- whatever you think you are going to see.... You wont.

Great history class. Visit of Hoa lo prison was great experience. In the prison because of its way of showing things (shown how prisoners were locked in cells etc) you get the feeling of how prison served for many different purposes. But it lacked of explanations (e.g. This barrel was used by french to torture vietnamiese political prisoners). The inventory in our opinion was poor and you had a lot of readings to do. If you are a student do mention it to get 50% off (10.000 vnd with student id).
a war prison. i had visited this prison,i understood how the vietnamese people were in the war.this place in the heart of the city so very easy to get there.

Interesting but not a must-see. I had a look at the prison as it was only about 200 meters from the Womens museum and while I'm glad I did it certainly isn't a must-see. Interesting and informative but definitely a biased view, especially of the American inmates. I'm pretty sure POWs from the US would disagree with the opinions displayed.The French section I found to be far more interesting and shocking. Seeing the actual guillotine that had taken so many lives was a sobering moment for me. Also found the escape techniques quite interesting too - those sewers are tiny!!English signage throughout which makes things much easier - was a bit shocked at having to pay extra for an English map of the attraction though.
Good to see in Hanoi. A good place to visit, sad to see how people were treated. Good visuals and worth a stop in Hanoi! Do go!!!!!

A bit bizarre and full of propaganda. We're surprised that any of the prisoners wanted to return home, such was the good time they obviously had at the "Hanoi Hilton" — at least if you believe the information boards.Also, rather bizarrely, there was a welcome mat at the entrance!Worth a visit, but take a skeptical view of what you read.If you do a bit of research before you go, you will see it for what it was, to both sides (Vietnamese held by the French, then later the Americans held by the Vietnamese).
Painful. This is interesting and well worth a visit but it is painful- not just to see what the prisoners of war had to endure during their tenure but to endure the propaganda as a visitor.
Well worth a visit.. Fascinatingly awful. How anyone survived this regime is anyone's guess. There is an insight into the American pilots life in the Hanoi Hilton!

Interesting but not a must see. The prison was very interesting and they had many informative signs to let you know what was in front of you. It was very interesting to see a museum fun by the Vietnamese as an American. Lots of propaganda about the "American Imperialists," and this was the most interesting part of the museum for me. If you're in the area, go, but don't go too much out of your way.

Eye opener and very interesting. We were really taken aback by the amount of detail they have put in to the displays. All the information you need is there for only 20,000VD entry. A must see!Go in the morning before it gets too hot.

Sad but incredibly interesting. The famous Hanoi Hilton was incredible to visit. Despite only being the "gate house", the exhibits within the museum were informative and interesting. The museum tends to focus on the prison's use under colonial French rule, which admittedly was horrific, and certainly down plays its use as an American POW prison. The French part of the prison museum was brilliantly, almost dramatically, configured and made the cells seem very real, if not haunting. The part of the museum that does acknowledge the more contemporary use as a POW facility is essentially modern government propaganda, which I found equally interesting. If you read up on the "Hanoi Hilton", apparently the American inmates were coerced and tortured by the North Vietnamese prison guards in order to obtain letters saying how much the inmates enjoyed their stay with the Vietnamese and photos of inmates undertaking recreational activities etc. These such exhibits (the letters and photos of "enjoyment") are proudly displayed, with taglines in Vietnamese and English explaining that American soldiers appreciated the kind treatment of the North Vietnamese. Fascinatingly biased, it's certainly worth a visit!!
Boy what a shock. Great visit very interesting . Learnt a lot and shocked at what i saw. It is easy to get to and you have to pay a small fee to enter

What a sight to see. Learn so many historical events from the tour guide, together with all the figures, recreated scenes and stuffs... Thanks the tour guide for linking all the events and giving us a whole picture of what it is...

Don't miss this. This was a fascinating, small museum. It is a good way to connect to some challenging history. It does not take long, but is certainly worth an hour. It is within walking distance of the old town and French Quarter. Kind of eerie to be walking where John McCain was in prison for 6 years.

Educational but Eerie. Entrance Fee - VND 20,000/paxDuration - 1 to 1.5hrsIf you have not seen a prison before, this might be just the place for you to visit. Educational and informative. Some may find it biased on displays of American POWs but still it is worth a visit in Hanoi. It was horrifying to see how the revolutionaries were tortured and how dark the cells and dungeons were. Tools and photos of decapitated heads were on display. Some parts of the prison were very eerie indeed. Not a place for young children to visit.
Must See for Americans. Any American should pay a visit to this prison turned museum just to see a different perspective on the Vietnam War and to see John McCain's old uniform.
Really interesting. Shows the prison in different lights during the French occupation and the US war. Fascinating - we expected to spend half an hour an spent over 1.5 hours. Well worth a visit.

Known by North Americans as Hanoi Hilton its past is far more sinister.. A visit to this prison gives perspective to not only the "American" war ( Vietnam war) but the plight of the Vietnamese in the past. Well worth a visit.

Just not for small kid!. The place is scary enough to be visited by 5 yrs old kid. Most of the aisles is poor light. A lot of pictures that I can say need parental guidance since just describe the violence during war. And you will feel uncomfortable whn you're going through aisle by aisle with a lot of violence tools and methods described in the wall.
Horrific. It surely educated us on the horrifying tales of war. The place is well maintained, there are a lot of things to see and stories to tell. Some portions were eerie as well.
Hoa Lo Prison. A trip to this prison is a must . It will set your mind to thinking of how could we as humans been so hard on others .

Come face-to-face with two centuries of horror. At first, this ''Hanoi Hilton'' prison may look a little bit like a bad version of a Disney World display but then you realize that this is the prison where thousands were subjected to torture, humiliation and finally, death. This prison started under French colonial rule in the 19th Century and continued to function as a prison during the Vietnam War of the 1960s - 1970s. That is pretty powerful.

Not What Was Expected. With the history that abounds in the "Hanoi Hilton", we were very disappointed with the actual site. The U.S. section was relatively small, and filled with propaganda. Granted there has been so much propaganda on both sides that it is hard to know the facts, but the pictures and descriptions paint the prison as a happy place where US prisoners were treated very well. Of particular interest was the flight suit of Senator John McCain.

An interesting way to kill 30 minutes or so. Some good artifacts and interesting areas where you can stand in a cell that held up to 300 people and look at a guillotine that had been used. However, there was a lot of propaganda and the American section was really odd with pictures of prisoners playing chess and receiving parcels from their families. The thought of air conditioning on a very humid day is what took us in initially but after 30 minutes we were done. Some interesting photos and a moving mural on the wall outside left a lasting impression.

Interesting place to visit. An interesting historical place to visit. Exceptional value for money to enter the prison, but most museums are good value. English translations of the letters posted on the walls would have been useful. Definitely worth a visit.

Life of a prisoner. I haven't seen a prison before, this was my first visit. I enjoyed looking around the prison, learning about the lifestyle of political prisoners, US prisoners. The dark prison rooms, heavy chains, iron doors, head chopping thing is interesting to see. I recommend visiting this place.

Whaat humans do to other humans. Very informative experience. From no real knowledge of the history it is laid out in such a way to dispense valuable information on the past. Lost of anti US propaganda, but with many good photographs. It's so cheap to get in.

Worth your time.. Exercise your propaganda radar here and do some fact checking about some of their claims, but overall a rather interesting place to visit to get a sense of prison life of the different groups who were jailed there.
propaganda. Go here if you want to be amused by the propagandaistic version of how they tell the story of what happened there.
Must see. The Hoa Lo prison is one of the must see places of interests as it allows you to understand a little bit more about the history of Vietnam
Good stop. Interesting hour, lots of photos, get to see cells too. Focuses of French treating Vietnamese badly and then their good treatment of the Americans.

Interesting, yet skewed, take on Vietnamese history. As you would expect, the exhibits in this museum are enormously biased, but it's still a remarkable place to visit. It's quite grim, so to a particularly fun place to be, but hey, it's a prison. It was quite moving at times but could have been a whole lot better with a bit of balance. Thought it was a little distasteful to insist that American POWs here were treated well and even had a great time. I'm sure most would disagree with this analysis! Still definitely worth a visit though, just because its so infamous.

Moving. Once you get past the obvious propagandist presentation – all Vietnamese were ill-treated (which they obviously were) and all Americans were treated humanely by the Vietnamese (which they probably weren't), the visit was very informative and moving. Our three young children were keenly interested in why people were incarcerated and why they were held in such awful conditions. The visited left an impression on them over imprisonment, the death penalty (a guillotine was on display), torture, solitary confinement etc. They were wide-eyed about the escapes from the prison.Some of the sculptures in the courtyard are excellent and moving. A must see when in Hanoi.

Propaganda you can see!. An old prison is an old prison, and while it may have a sad history as most prisons do, this failed to give you a proper historic perspective. No doubt those conditions are horrible in such prisons from the early part of the previous century and it is easy to understand the horrors inmates may have suffered despite their crime. However, if for nothing else, a visit just to see the propaganda is worth the while, as it was so one-sided it became quite “fun” to read – and then disregard, leaving you wondering what the real story is

thought provoking. Definitely worth a look, particularly if you are interested in the history of the Vietnam War. Particularly interesting how the stories of American POWs held at the prison are presented in he museum, considering the conflicting accounts they told after release.

Worth a quick visit. Sometimes called ‘The Hanoi Hilton” this prison barely resembles it’s namesake. Instead the HoaLo Prison is a grim collection of rooms – some reconstructed with models of prisoners living conditions, other rooms contain artefacts from torture and soulless photographs of inmates. It’s a moving reminder of Hanoi’s past and how resilient the Vietnamese people are. Worth visiting but I don’t recommend staying too long.

Emotional. I had to walk out of the rooms a couple of times as this is quite an emotional tour if you really take it all in and read the displays. I walked into the cells and tried to imagine life there. I am glad that we live in the era we do now. All of the political inmates that lived here must have been very strong people. Worth going to but don't do the war museum and the prison on the same day, do something fun in between.

Interesting in a prison kind of way. We visited the Hoa Lo Prison on a very hot July day. The prison was well set out and provided lots of information. It wasn't that busy so it was easy to read the descriptions and learn about this historical site. But as prisons go, there are some awful stories to learn here and many lessons to be learned.

One-sided. We had heard about Hoa Lo Prison as being one of the must-see sights in Hanoi. We went with a couple of Hanoi Kids (university students) as guides. Much of the museum is devoted to the story of Vietnamese detainees incarcerated and tortured by the French from 1900 to 1954. The accounts of what took place here were rather disturbing.A couple of rooms are devoted to the story of American prisoners detained here in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The displays emphasis how well-treated the Americans were and how they regretted their part in the war, etc. Not a balanced portrayal of what happened in this place based on first-hand accounts of those who were prisoners here. Makes you question the overall accuracy of what was portrayed.

Interesting. Focuses mainly on the French occupational period with some interesting displays demonstrating the treatment of political prisoners. The section of the incarceration of American airmen is fascinating, if mainly for the level of propaganda shown.

Hanoi History Must. We visited this fine museum and considered it one of the top attractions for us in Hanoi. The museum area covers only a small part of the original site as most of it was demolished and developed for other use. The remaining parts and the layout allow the visitor to gain a thorough experience of a building that was put to dispicable use in a variety of ways for a wide variety of inmates. It certainly informs and educates and charges a very low entry fee.
Well worth a visit. We really enjoyed our visit here. Yes it's very Vietnamese biased and filled with propaganda, but it's interesting nonetheless and well worth a visit.
Exciting. Very exciting museum. There is a lot of history in this visit, so it you are not interested in history maybe do something else.

Excellent history of Vietnam's French history. This is the prison the French built when they tried to colonize Vietnam. The prison's purpose was to house Vietnamese political persons so most of the history here is focused on the French and their occupation of Vietnam, torture of the prisoners, and executions using the Guillotine (which is on display along with other devices used for torture.)Much of the land the prison was built on was a small village that specialized in ceramics. The prison formerly occupied quite a bit of land, but most has been returned to residential status now and all that remains is the museum which is maybe one tenth of the original prison.Don't be too surprised if you come here looking for information about the American War (Vietnam War) and find that it is limited - only two rooms are dedicated to this. They do show a very friendly point of view, with Christmas meals and inmates playing games or building guitars. In 1984 Orwell wrote something about how the power who has control gets to write the history books!
French prison. This was a great visit. Walking distance from the hotel. It was really interesting peace of hanoi history

Worth a visit. The Hoa Lo Prison has some excelletn displays and provides alot of interesting detail on the role of the French in the prison and later, the detention of American soilders, including John McCain, who spent time there.

Worth a visit but with a pinch of salt!!. The museum is interesting but as I say you would be better having some background knowledge before you go as the image that the Vietnamese paint if of it is through rose-tinted glasses. It is however worth seeing while you are in Hanoi.

Very interesting. We really enjoyed our visit to the prison, although we're a little disappointed to find that most of it has been demolished to make way for the new building behind. We loved what was there though and found it informative and fascinating on the subject of the Vietnam war.
part of history. Take some time to see a part of history in the middle of Hanoi city. Really moving and more appreciating the PRESENT
Hua Lo prison. Not really a place to enjoy as such but a must do if you're in Hanoi. Very interesting and well presented

Interesting. Very interesting, but highly biased interpretation. Always good to have another perspective I guess. Signs were in English so it was helpful for understanding. No need to buy the brochure. Very clean bathroom.

Very interesting!. This prison was incredibly interesting to visit. We spent an hour or so there reading about its history. They supposedly have John McCain's flight suit he was wearing when he was imprisoned in there (though how we know its his, we can't be sure). Interesting place, definitely worth a visit!

A less obvious gem in Hanoi. We had a few hours to spare in Hanoi so decided to visit the Hoa Lo Prison. I was glad we did - this was probably the most educational place we visited in Hanoi, and one of the most worthwhile. Definitely worth a visit.The prison itself dates from the French colonial times. Be prepared for a very one-sided view of things here, and take it with a pinch of salt - all of the exhibits aim to illustrate how poorly the French colonialists treated the Vietnamese imprisoned here and how well the Vietnamese later treated the US POWs held in the complex (when it was known as the "Hanoi Hilton". If you stay aware of the bias, though, there's lots to learn here and I got far more out of it than the Ho Chin Museum. It's still not up to the level of many other museums from a labeling perspective - descriptions are short and don't go into much detail - but it's fascinating to go around the prison and imagine the misery of the people held here. The cells for people with death sentences - and the guillotine itself - are must-see elements, as is the relatively new US exhibit which has an interesting video.Set aside between an hour (if you're in a hurry) and two hours for a more in-depth visit.

Because it's there.... This isn't a place you visit for pleasure -- but if you're in Hanoi, it's one of those things you do have to see. It's not a long tour, but it's an eye-opener in many ways.This prison was clearly a hell-hole when Vietnamese insurgents were held here by the French. But if you believe the exhibits, it suddenly became a holiday camp when the Vietnamese held captured American pilots there: they're pictured enjoying cigarettes, tea, chess games and sports. We commented to our guide, tongue firmly in cheek, on how much conditions in the prison seemed to have improved under the Viet Cong, and she replied with a smile, and remarkable frankness, "Well...propaganda."

HOA LO PRISON. This again been promoted as one of the must see places in Hanoi. The place was once used to house the American war prisoners; and was then nick-named as "THE HILTON of HANOI" !!! It provides quite a good in-sights not only of the American War Prisoners, but the hardship Vietnam experienced through out History over the many wars Vietnam went through. The Prison is quite well kept, and the displays quite well maintained. Visit it for the experience how lucky we are now when devoid of wars!
Prison. A very sad place but interesting to visit, lets hope we can all move forward from this history in a more positive light
Insightful. A really interesting insight into what it was like for the Vietnamese under French colonial rule during the 19th and early 20th Century.

Boring displays, interesting propaganda!. Most of this museum is dedicated to how badly the French treated the Vietnamese POWs who stayed here during the Indochinese war. However, the small section dedicated to American POWs from the War of Independence, is filled with ironic government Propaganda. After (potentially) going overboard about the French, the prison has pictures and videos from American prisoners who were "treated better than the average Vietnamese person" or who "learned the immorality of the American invasion". Very interesting stuff! They also have Senator McCain's original flight suit, and a nice wall dedicated to victims of the prison.

Interesting. This place is very interesting - it is very one sided but it also allows visitors to see what atrocities happened and hopefully they are able to process the information cleverly. Worth visiting.

Sobering but a must see. Visiting Hao Lo is like visiting Dachau or the Budapest Secret Police Museum. It's a shock to see such suffering imposed by one group of people on another, but it's a version of history that is worth seeing. Yes, there's plenty of truth bending. But I learned a lot about the political prisoners of the French. It has prompted me to read more about this period of history.

Selective Perspective. This is actually only a piece of the prison. Much of it was destroyed to make room for a real estate project.The museum represents that Americans prisoners here were treated well. Short version: This was not the case. American POW's were abused, tortured and killed. Research it.
Interesting. Was great to walk through. Not enough information signs. Pretty shocking stuff. Also a bit of propaganda.
A vision of bad times. A very somber place showing the grips of government control and war dealings. Well preserved.Able to walk through most of the prison,exhibits and photos graphic of the era.

Not too much to see. Quite a long walk from the hotel we stayed in (Blue Sky Hotel), and it was not the most interesting museum we have seen. The information provided were mixed and not very detailed. The entrance fee is only 1USD.

A must see for history buffs. I've been to this museum twice, both times that I've been to Hanoi. It's very disturbing - don't go unless you're prepared to be shocked - but absolutely essential if you are interested in the history of the Vietnam war.
Interesting. This is definitely worth a visit when in Hanoi. Plan to spend around one hour. Interesting exhibits throughout covering different parts of Vietnem' history.
Worth seeing. Of course it is a little sad to visit places like this. The details and the displays are very interesting. Ir's a must see.
WASTE OF TIME. The prison was fun to see but there isn't much left. Cheap to get in, however what you actually see is worthless.

Interesting and worth a visit. Most of the building has been torn down and a high rise built in its place. What has been turned into a museum is interesting. The displays do show the conditions that the prisoners suffered from the French. The two rooms devoted to the US and the Vietnam War are pure propaganda. According to the displays the pilots who were held here after they were shot down over Hanoi, had plenty of food, the best medical care, played basketball and chess all day. Wow!

This place was full of propaganda. This place was full of propaganda. It was not worth the price. There was creepy music playing like I was in a haunted house or something. They tried way to hard to make it sad and it came out really hokey and over the top.

Didn't enjoy this...very little explanation or English translation. So much propaganda!. Very disappointed. So little information provided that there was little to do apart from look around a bit, not really understanding the meaning behind a lot of it. So much propaganda....all in all wish we hadn't bothered.

So interesting. As well as quite devastating this small and easy to visit museum is a compelling indictment on the French colonial reign And the cruelty they inflicted on the Vietnamese people who just wanted independence. Simple life like exhibits show the hardships endured by men and women, as well as the American pilots captured during the Vietnam war.

Very interesting. We visited the prison this morning and found it very interesting.The signs are both in English and French and it was clearly laid out and easy to navigate.We had an 11 year old with us and he found it interesting too.There was a part of the prison which provided information on the American prisoners that were held here during the war.If you have a couple of hours to spare in Hanoi I would recommend visiting this place as it gives another insight into life in Vietnam.

Well worth a visit interesting for whole family. Well worth a visit. We took 2 children and we all enjoyed it. The signs are all in English and French so easy to navigate. 20,000 vd to get in and free for under 15s. Not as much of building left now. The guillotine was a bit gruesome for our 8 year old.

Good place to go. This Palce gives a Good insight into how the Prisoners where treated at the Prison , make sure you look into every room as there are a few.Over all the Prison is very well looked after , worth a few hours looking around and reading all about it.

Hanoi Hilton touring. This trip to the museum was really interesting because of two reasons... 1.) I believe most people don't realize this museum was built by the French and used to torture Vietnamese responsible for uprisings during their colonization. This is a part of history largely forgotten.. why? 2.) Becuase of the Vietnam/American War. The prison was then used by the Vietnmase to hold POWs of the War. This is well-known partly due to its rather recent place in history. Overall, this is certainly worth a patient visit and some photos as well.

Very interesting museum. A very well presented museum, which gives you good insight into the lives of prisoners during that time. It also has interesting rooms showcasing the lives of American pilots who were held at the prison until their release.

Be prepared for the propaganda!. This is a very humbling experience (even with all the propaganda). A visit to the Hoa Lo Prison, commonly referred to as the "Hanoi Hilton" by our American servicemen is a place all U.S. citizens need to visit when in Hanoi. Self-guided tour provides the history of the prison and shows its evolution over time.

One of the best things in Hanoi. We visited this in a self-devised day tour that included the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and War Museum. This was definitely one of the best things that we did in Hanoi. My travel partner is an ardent war buff, and was really excited to see the place where all the POWs were!! Many a photo was had with John McCain's flight suit. I was a bit concerned after reading all the reviews upset about the propaganda, but after having visited the prison itself, it wasn't too overbearing and nothing that wasn't expected - you have to remember that this is a showcase of the anti-American War (ie, the Vietnam War) from their perspective. So take it with a grain of salt.

John McCain slept here. A walk back in history. The prison is very old and was first used by the French. John McCain's flight suit is there. A lot of it is gone now but you get a good feeling about what it was like.

maybe a tour would have been better. Interesting enough , But not that special. We should have had a guide, probably...It would have been better with some more specific information panels or films. The cells are well preserved but we still do not think we know what the place was really like.

Humbling experience. On a wet day we deecided to visit the "Hanoi Hilton". Originally constructed by the French in 1896, this was a very tough and cruel prison. Even had a guillotine on display.American displays were informative and it was interesting to read about the war from a Vietnamese perspective. So much American propaganda it was good to see some alternatives!

Interesting but nothing special. The prison was fun to see but there isn't much left. It also abut's the new Hilton which takes away from the historical feel. The juxtoposition between what the prison was "supposed" to be like as a French as opposed to a Vietnamese prison is very interesting.
Sobering and sinister. Right up there with all the other must sees in Hanoi ...very difficult not to be shocked by the exhibits and stories...memorable

Well worth a visit but don't be upset by the propaganda. A very real insight into the brutality and conditions within an old colonial gaol. It takes about 40 - 45 minutes to look around the gaol. There is a communal cell block, individual cells, solitary confinement and a history area with the photos of all the former inmates. Whilst not all of the prison still exists, that which remains gives a very clear insight into what went on there. A must visit.

One of the must do's!. I think this place is really worth a visit. It's a prison that has been very well kept, it has a tourist walk so you don't miss anything. It has different areas where they show what the real prison looked like. The prison cells are just terrifying!! And the ambient is taken care as well, with music and lights. They also have human dummies or manequins filling the scene. Creepy!

Sad but revealing. I really enjoyed this but was saddened a bit - the ralistic touch of having "prisoner dunnies" lent it an authenticity that helped the imagination. Was a bit surprised by the anti-French sentiments in the narratives and amused by the "how well we treated the US POWS" stories

Hanoi Hilton Provides Sobering Perspective. We debated whether to visit the famed "Hanoi Hilton" or not but we were in Hanoi with time to spare so we dropped by. The exhibits are very well done -- and quite sobering to view. An informative piece of history and worth the stop.
Creepy. Interesting but definitely a very heavy experience. The soundtrack plying was a bit over the top. Go check out the women's museum before stopping here for added perspective.

Fascinating and sad chapter in Vietnamese history. We came to see the "Hanoi Hilton" and were fascinated to find that the prison was used to house Vietnamese prisoners by the French for far longer than the site was used to hold American Prisoners of war. The museum was very inexpensive and well done. The museum is full of interesting displays and artifacts from its long history including an actual Guillotine used at the prison. There are cells to view and walk into as well as information plaques translates into several languages including English. There are a few rooms dedicated to the Vietnam War era that include John McCain's actual flight suit and lots of pictures of prison life (albeit from a Vietnamese propaganda perspective). The museum is a must see.

Fascinating, yet propaganda remains.... Hoa Lo Prison (aka the Hanoi Hilton) is absolutely fascinating to visit and well worth seeing.Much of the prison complex has long been demolished and replaced by a high-rise commercial building, but what remains is thoroughly interesting to see. Most of the exhibits are dedicated to the history of the prison from construction to the end of the French-occupation of Vietnam.The hall dedicated to the American War is small, but has some interesting accounts and footage. Never let it pass that the history of Hoa Lo during the American/Vietnam War has very much been re-written and the accounts inside the museum are very much at odds with POW accounts following their release (John McCain for one).

Good place to learn about Hanoi's history. A good place to start to learn about the city's history. It's right in the city centre so it's easily accessible. Perhaps a bit gloomy and uncomfortable for some in some parts of the tour, but I do find the place interesting and insightful into the city's history. What i found particularly interesting was the details about how the American pilots who had been shot down during the war spent their days in the prison.....it was more civilised and pleasant than I had imagined.Would take about an hour or slightly less to complete the tour.

haunting. this attraction was really worth visiting. it has a long history, and had a long history before it became known as the "Hanoi HIlton" in the war with America. there is much more about the prison's earlier history when the french built it and punished anti-colonialist vietnamese, including mannequins that demonstrate the nature of punishment there. there's also a guillotine.relatively speaking, there is much less about its use during the vietnam war, and the descriptions are a bit too polemical for my taste; you'd think it really was a hotel during that period judging by what is written.but it's surely worth a visit regardless.
Interesting. This was an interesting place to see the old prison cells. They claim to have John McCain's flight suit- not sure if it is really his, but still worth visiting Hoa Lo.

The evidence of war appeared in Vietnam. Now Hanoi looks so peaceful without any trace of destructive war; but when I went to Hoa Lo Prison - the images of war came back. It is a prison used by the French colonists in Vietnam for political prisoners, and later by North Vietnam for prisoners of war during the Vietnam War. It reminds me of resented, abhorred and cursed war. And I understand more about Vietnamese people who have go through it but very warm-hearted and friendly. I really love them.

Interesting history and propaganda. The museum focuses almost exclusively on the mistreatment of Vietnamese population under French rule, not exactly what I was expecting given the prison's fame in the West as the 'Hanoi Hilton' where US air pilots were kept during the Vietnam war. However, it was interesting especially to view the presentation of the way the US pilots were treated, no idea if it was accurate or not though.

Heatbreakingly important site to see in Hanoi. The tour is self-paced and the English translation of the exhibits are done pretty well. As an American, it's interesting to see your own country's history told from a different perspective. I wonder if the French will feel the same way. Their treatment of "political prisoners" during the Colonial occupation is pretty heartbreaking to learn about as well.
Eye opening. This place gives you an understanding of what the people of Vietnam have gone through. Well worth the entry fee.

Harrowing but worth a visit!. Wanted to do all the sights in Hanoi so came here one hot afternoon. its only 20,000dong to get it and whilst it doesn't take too long to get around (about an hour) it's well worth a visit.Grab a tour guide for 5,000 as well.I don't want to tell you whats there as it would ruin it if you decided to go, but it's very informative, eye-opening and rather harrowing in some parts.
Interesting. Any attraction that shows the worse aspects cannot be called fun. However the prison was extremely interesting, if somewhat gut wrenching in parts. But a must see in Hanoi.

Don't bother. After visiting many great attractions in many different countries I think you can spend your time doing something a little more worth while! Cheap to get in, however what you actually see is worthless. Doesn't seem to reflect the history well. Most of what is displayed is things like 'the brick they used to build the prison' and things like it. There are many other interesting places in Vietnam. I'd give this one a miss!

Worth a look. We really enjoyed wandering through the building & seeing a little slice of the history of the city. I'd take anything you read with a pinch of salt as it's a rather skewed view of events laced with lots of propaganda. Still interesting to see a different perspective & lovely to step out of the hustle of the city for an hour or two into a cool, shady spot.

Historically important, just go for an hour and little to do there after. It was a great experience even though it is very small a nd an hour visit is more than enough. The history this museum has is very interesting!
Eye opener. Interesting place and a definite must for your tour but you won't feel like taking any photos here. Heart wrenching place.

Surprisingly interesting and worth a visit. Admission is only 20,000 Dong (US$!) and this is a very interesting and historic site. It's well worth a visit and gives you the flavor of this very unique building and its many uses during the 20th century.
good general interest spot. Although a bit away from the centre, worth visiting to see the local spin on events. Displays reasonably informative, and some good movie clips.

The Hanoi Hilton was a bit of a let down. Don't expect too much and you will be fine. The Hanoi Hilton name alone implied to me that there would be more. Self paced. Walk into prison cells. Pictures on the wall describe events. Pretty basic. Nothing too special.
Eye Opener. What an eye opener this was. I had no idea. This should be a required visit. So well done and explained.Sad and horrific, but this is History.
Worth a visit. Came here with hanoikids. Definitely require a guide to bring you about this place. It showcases how the prisoner lived, tortured during the war.
Fascinating but gut wrenching. This is a fascinating museum but it really makes things hit home (obviously that's the point - it does it well). Definitely worth a visit.

This is it...THE Hanoe Hilton, but a little disappointing. The former prison is set up like a museum, giving a good depiction of how the French abused the Vietnamese political prisoners. However, I was disappointed with the captured American pilot display which was sugar-coated as if these guys were treated well. I was hoping to see an actual cell where the pilots were held but these cells were all gone and they only had two large showrooms that contained photos, mainly propagandized, and some items such as John McCain's flight suit. But most of the attraction for me was the fact that I was in the 'Hanoi Hilton', a place about which I heard and read so much.
Impressive. Very harrowing and really hits home - a grave time but very interesting and excellent explanations in English and other languages. Reasonably priced too.

Worth a visit if in Hanoi. My husband and I attended here on recommendation from our tour guide. I'm glad we did. As previous reviews state, you have to make your own mind up about what is displayed. I can't say how much it cost, our guide paid i saw her hand over a 200,000 vnd note which is about £6 and she whisked us round in less then an hour. You could spend longer here, but an hour was good for us.The building itself has a great history and presence, the exhibits are well presented and well spaced, bar the last - kinda crammed into a room.

Research before you go. As one would expect, the information contained within the prison is from the Vietnamese perspective of the conflict with the US. It is not a balanced perspective, which should not surprise or disappoint you. However, you need to take all the written materials and pictures within with a grain of salt and make up your own mind about the site.
A historical vision of french style prison. Nice to remember how the people suffered during the war.There were no winner, but only to remember the people who died for.Good historial place

Interesting visit to the Hanoi Hilton. Wow, what a place, hard to imagine how large it once was as only a small section of the orginal building still stands.Interesting history which is well documented albiet slightly one-sided - to be expected given Vietnam's history and repression. Well worth a visit, I personally found it fascinating.

disappointing. Glad that this was five minutes way from our hotel, as would have been classed as a wasted journey. Quite small exhibit, although some of the War info was interesting but just not enough. then again, i dont think i would lile it presented in a glossy,western way either..
Average Site. It was an interesting sight and cannot help but notice the propaganda worked into some of the exhibits and displays. The site is not very large.
Boring. Go here if you want to be amused by the propangada-istic version of how they tell the story of what happened there.

Thought provoking. Totally naive to the history of Vietnam this museum was informative and graphic. Good balance of text and images however in the future would be great to have an audio guide. It was great value for money at only 20000vnd person.
great history. the history of this prison is amazing and very detailed as you go through it it gave me an education into what the vietnese people have endured

Worth a visit. I found this place quite interesting. Gave you an interesting perspective of prision life during the war. I found parts of the prision dark and creepy though, but definately worth a visit!

Moving visit. The Maison Centrale is a must-see if you're in the area. Most of the building is devoted to the French colonial period when hundreds of prisoners were herded into this quite small building that now seems quite idyllic. Models, re-creations and actual exhibits show conditions during this period. Upstairs, a display is devoted to the American pilots, including John Kerry, who were held here during the Vietnam (Anti-American) War and Vietnamese propaganda films of this period.

not an unbiased attraction but... You will learn a lot about the French and their occupation of Vietnam and their torture and imprisonment of those who resisted and it helps give a different perspective on why communism got a foothold in Vietnam. You will also learn about the Americans who were imprisoned there during the Vietnam war but you won't see anything about mistreatment at the hands of the Vietnamese. They make it seem as though the American prisoners of war were on vacation rather than imprisoned. A less than honest look at a horrible place and time.
interesting. I expected a lot about the involvement of the Americans during the Vietnam war of the 60s and 70s, but learned a lot here about the French occupation which preceded it
It's a prison, with a story. Worth to visit, not a particular inspiring place.Quite depressing really, shows you that no matter which side of the fence, humans can be miserable at times.

An important piece of Vietnam history. A good place to visit and learn more about the war and living conditions of the Vietnamese prisoners and the difference in treatment of the American B-52 pilots who were shot down. Ironically named Hanoi Hilton, it gives an insight to the war in Vietnam.

Worthwhile and Interesting. First a correction - Yes there is a fee to enter. Trip Advisor says NO but the fee is 20,000 dong at the ticket office by the front entrance.The museum had a lot of interesting photographs and information from the Vietnam war (as it is called in the USA) and a lot of info about the battle for liberation from the French. A short primer on the history of the French and American roles in VN would have helped put all the information & artifacts in a more clear context. Nevertheless it was worthwhile! I would recommend it for an hour or two especially those interested in war history and/or John McCain (Republican Politician from Arizona, USA & former military pilot) whose capture is highlighted extensively.Good clean bathroom with paper too - After living in China for so many years this really means a lot, haha!

Great place to learn about the French occupation of Vietnam. I had a student volunteer with me booked from my hotel who explained everything to me clearly and answered all of my questions about the prison.I highly recommend this as I would not have learned as much otherwise. But the explanations are quite clear without a guide.I knew nothing about the atrocities that occurred to the Vietnamese people so I found the Prison fascinating and a bit sad.There was also an exhibition about the American pilots which was interesting too about their lives as POW.

A good place for your to understand Vietnam War History. This museum gives you a lot of information on Vietnam War, showing you information and display from the war veterans. Spend some time to look at the display carefully and know how the POWs lived during the war.

Hanoi Hilton. This former ceramic factory turned French colonial prison turned "Hanoi Hilton" provides a glimpse into some of the more recent history of Vietnam. The larger portion of the museum speaks to the colonial abuse of the local people, with a section focused on the capture and containment of American pilots. Interesting to see John McCain's pilot outfit and parachute he was captured in as well as other photos, videos and momentos of the Vietnam war era. A French era guillotine adds to the somber yet realistic history of this place.

Not up to my expectation. It was supposed to be a highly recommended place of interest in Lonely Planet but other than the replicated structure of the prison cells, there is not much to see. The other museums other better in terms of variety, in my opinion.

Take a map for your taxi driver. The weird thing about Hanoi is that none of the taxi drivers know where the tourist places are located. This place- the taxi driver drove to the general area and then drove around for another 10 min trying to find it. Once we got there it was an interesting experience. One half describes the treatment of Vietnamese people here- which sounded awful and not sugar-coated and was probably accurate. The other half talks about the American pilots (such as John McCain) that were held here during the war and is a completely false depiction of their treatment. Yes, there are lots of pictures of the pilots smiling and doing activities such as painting, playing chess and making it look like they were having such a great time- but I'm sure it was all staged and there were soldiers with AKs behind those cameras. We know the pilots were mistreated. You would think after all these years they would come clean about it.

#1 place to visit during hanoi stay. 20k vnd per person. It's worth it to visit this site. I have to ranked the a must see, must visit place. 100% sadness and 100% impact on the soul. It reminds what Vietnamese had to go thru during the colonial rule. It's not for everyone and do not recommend ppl to bring minors

A surprise. Only a small part of the prison remains. A worthwhile visit. A well documented history of the prison beginning with the French colonisation. Surprisingly a small section of the American War (as the locals call it) was presented despite the image of the conflict was so vividly viewed world-wide. It would appear the Vietnamese bear no rancour against the allied forces.
little sad :(. its a little sad, but its a good way to know abou the history of the country and how the things really happened, there are pictures and real material

Beautiful building. The architecture and fascade of the building were nice. The inside was rather gloomy, which was very befitting for the nature of the building. The guillotine on display reminded visitors of the terrible treatment givent to prisoners of war.

Some Interest Only. It seemed like everyone viewing the prison was a foreigner, some political bias against France and US but overall pretty balanced. Only a small area of prison remaining and there is a CHARGE for entry, visit did not take up more than 1hour
Very sad but glad I went. This is a very well set up exhibition which evokes some strong feelings when you walk around. Such a lot of sad history here, but I learnt a lot.

Also known as the Hanoi Hilton. A nominal entrance fee is required but it is well worth it.
