This prison is now a museum which charts the history of Vietnam from the the late 1800's to the most recent conflict involving the USA. It tells the history of Vietnam through theses conflicts which also included France early on. Some of the pictures are moving and some graphic. The women of Vietnam have always played a prominent role. So you must go and visit this important "attraction" to understand better and to learn a little more about this region.

Interesting. Worth a look.. In my opinion Hanoi is more an 'experience' rather than a 'specific destination' sort of city, but I think it is well worth dropping in to see the small remaining part of Hoa Lo prison. I generally like visiting old prisons as they can be imposing, thought provoking for the conditions that people must have endured and have a real sense of history. The displays are simple but interesting and tell the story from a Vietnamese point of view, but thats OK. There were displays showing how people were detained, and even an old guillotine. We enjoyed the visit and are glad we dropped in while wandering around the city, but don't expect a large and flashy attraction. Probably about half hour to an hour to wander around.

Wonderful but heartbreaking. This was a very emotional place for me to visit as an American citizen. As you enter the place, you can almost feel, hear, and smell what an absolutely tragic place this place was for a very long time. Thank God now a small portion of it remains solely to tell the painful story of the place.
Worth a visit!. Gives you a sense of history, with propoganda to go with it, again choose a guide if you can.Costs around 20,000 dong for entry, so very cheap.

Interesting Insight into What makes Vietnam.... Gives you an insight into what history the Vietnamese endured and then created. The horrors are more imagined than seen but would probably not take very young or sensitive children through all the exhibits. Well worth going to.

History of the time. The name Hoa Lo, commonly translated as "fiery furnace" or even "Hell's hole", also means "stove". The name originated from the street name "Pho Hoa Lo", due to the concentration of stores selling wood stoves and coal-fire stoves along the street from pre-colonial times.Hoa Lo Prison is a historical attraction to many local and foreign visitors. You should pay a visit to the prison to experience the history with your own eyes.

Interesting visit. The price was set at 20 000 Dong (1 Dollar), to look around, which i found very interesting. A detailed look into the lives of inmates, from both sides of the war. Many exhibits and pictures to see. Not a very big museum, but worth the price and time, which takes about an hour.

don't miss it. The prison is not what you expected, it is a poor exhibition, nothing else. BUT don't miss a chance to go there, because you can learn a lot and really interesting to see, how the goverment represents the imprisoned americans soldiers life in Vietnam.
In one word; just great !!. definitively a place to see. The great way to describe both vietnamese and french way to take care of the place is absolutely magical. A nice piece of history

Haunting. A must-do.. No doubt, Vietnam has a long history of protracted oppression, siege, war and foreign occupation. The Vietnamese people have a fighting spirit that is to be respected. But oh my. Hoa Lo Prison is something else and most definitely not for the faint hearted.The prison opens up many of the cells prisoners were kept in, famously including US Senator John McCaine. Torture chambers are also open. So much of the signage is clearly propaganda, although respectfully you can see where the Vietnamese' grievances come from.As fate would have it, during my visit a group of Australian war veterans who had POWs at Hoa Lo were there. For most, it was their first visit to the site since their liberation. It was an extremely moving experience to wander through the prison and see the mixtures of relief, sadness and pure anger at the propaganda, that came from these men.If you want to share an appreciation of the many years of war that have somewhat defined this country (and indeed much of the West and Asia since), I recommend visiting Hoa Lo Prison. It is not a happy experience, but a necessary one.
Check it out. Lots of information to absorb. Interesting to look at all the old images and read about what went on inside the prison and the treatment of prisoners. Enjoy!
Witness of the war. I have many feelings every time I come here. It is a witness for the document what I have read on the book or taught.

snapshot of history. The visit to the prison was an extremelly interesting experience. The way the prisoners were treated at different times through history, depended on who they were and where they came from.My teenage daughters were facinated and the sight of a guillotine was extremelly shocking to them. A "must see" for visitors to crazy Hanoi.
Sobering. This was an experience. The Erie music screens and explosions piped in can send chills up your back. Gives you a greater respect for those who survived their time there.
Worth a visit. Interesting to see history written from the Vietnamese point of view, but hoe they can portray the pilots from the US had a good time is tongue biting!

Enlightening. it offers a glimpse of the history of vietnam,the brutality they experienced under the frenchmen,and how they treated the americans when the time that they were the prisoners.the second floor gave me goosebumps/ghostly experience as its a memorial or sort of like that,i dont know if its just me but wifey had the same thing,and its unusually hot on that side of the prison.if felt like i was going to passed out coz of the intense heat im feeling,so we hurriedly left the place and the feeling i got as soon as i entered the second floor went away,maybe its my fault as i forgot to offer a small prayer for them or if you have any other explanation of what i experienced,pls feel free to reply.
Cruel past. We humans, how depraved we can be - a salient reminder of where we've all come from and certainly paints a picture of the long road to independence for Vietnam

Interesting visit. We went to the old prison today and enjoyed walking through, seeing the various prison areas and photos of the conditions that prisoners were kept in. The exhibitions are well set up but there is not a great deal of information in English, just a brief description under each photo. Well worth a visit.
Meh. Can check it out if you have the time but overall not anything too amazing. Does give you an insight what prison was like at the time

Disappointing. I went here today based on a few recommendations. Its was so boring. The best thing were the old cells and the creepy music they played. That made the atmosphere interesting at times. There is only a tiny section of the old prison complex left. The knocked the rest to build a silly modern tower block. From the model in the museum it seems as though they knocked down the more interesting parts. The memorial wall in nice however.

Quite interesting, but full of propaganda!. There is only a small part of the prison remaining, a large hotel has been built on the rest of the site.It was built by the French in the 1800's & housed political prisoners both men & women, the cells where people were manacled, were tiny & one can only imagine the conditions that prisoners endured, it was pretty warm & claustrophobic, just walking past some of the cells!It was also used to incarcerate captured American airmen, at the time of the Vietnamese war & there is plenty of propaganda around the prison, including repeat playing of footage from the war, which say how well the Americans were treated there, which is in stark contrast to what the prisoners actually reported.They actually christened it the Hanoi Hilton!
Eerie moments.. Relatively informative. Quite a quick trip. If it is a subject you are interested in go for it other wise perhaps not. Entrance at 20vnd is not at all expensive.
A step back in time. More to see here than you might first realise. Kids may find it spooky and fun seeing models of prisoners seated in dingy rooms, dark cells and a guillotine.

a dark historic moment. really dark and creepy and quite biased exhibition.it tells you the story of the different wars and how the vietnamese were treated as POW.the guillotine room still gives me the creeps especially when i look at the photos again.i highly recommend it if you have a strong stomach.

Great layout and informative (if biased) exhibits. I enjoyed learning more about the resistance against the French and the history of this prison. The exhibits are well worth the entrance fee and the time you spend here. I couldn't help but shake my head at the skewed portrayal of the quality of life of the American POW's who were kept here, but overall I enjoyed the entire museum and would recommend it to anyone.

Great to visit but dont believe it all. All prisons are a bit spooky to visit and this was no different.Fascinating to learn the French involvment and the types of people imprisoned over time.Where it really let me down were the outright lies about the treatment of US airmen shot down in the war.Now i appreciate propaganda and the US involvment in Vietnam is very difficult to justify in hindsight BUT-lies are lies and this prison tour is full of lies .The photos they show of US airmen playing guitars and basketball having great fun.You would be excused for thinking they loved being there.Unfortunately the truth is that many were tortured and treated very badly .The Vietnamese didnt uphold the Geneva convention despite their claims.Time for Vietnam to grow upand be honest .Yes it was a war and atrocities were committed on both sides. If they cant bring themselves to be honest best not raise the subjext at all .Enjoy but dont believe everything you read
Chilling. A lot of detail here in the recreation of what it must have been like for the rebels and protestors imprisoned here. Worth a visit
Nothing great. Just another tourist attraction I would say. It did look a little scary in some parts of the prison as they retained how the cell looked like in the past - dark and creepy!

Eye opening ... Hanoi Hilton as it is known.. certainly eye opening as exhibits offers a glimpse of Vietnam under under the French. Part of exhibits also showcased the capture and housing of US forces during the US-Vietnam war years.. a must visit for war buffs.

Definitely a different point of view of the war. As an American, I realized how little I thought of the Vietnamese point of view of the war and I also had no idea that this prison had a much longer history of imprisoning the Vietnamese after built by colonizing France. Well done and interesting.

Defenetly worth seeing!. The Hoa Lo Prison was one of the sightseeing stops we made and we found it very interesting. You should definitely go! It is defenetly an important piece of history and you should not miss it. entrance was very cheap.

It's a Quick Trip!. The Prison is one of those 'must sees' when in Hanoi I guess. It is not Tuel Sleng that is in Phnom Penh, Cambodia (the Genocide Museum). By this I mean it is pretty tame by prison standards or what it could be. The cost to enter is only 1USD, so it is an inexpensive entrance fee and you can be in and out of there in less then an hour.
Very interesting piece of history. There were very few tourists, this was to our advantage as it enabled us to spend some time looking around.Really interesting historical attraction.

Interesting Visit. Very interesting place to visit. Talks about Vietnamese patriots who were held prisoners buy the french, and the US POW. Clearly biased information, but that's part of the experience.
Great experience.. This was an amazing place to visit. I learned so much, though it was sometimes hard to take in. Very sad but a must see in Hanoi. Very interesting.
History put in context. Quite well presented showing the history of the prison, from French colonial times through to its' infamy as the Hanoi Hilton for captured US airmen.

Don't miss it. This is super interesting and informative. It only takes about 1 hour to see it well, and it is nicely laid out with direction signs leading you through the wing that was kept as a museum of the prision.

Interesting prison. The prison is much smaller than it originally was but it still gives you an idea of how hard prisons were at the turn of last century. There are exhibits of when the prison was used for American POWs and also when it was used by the French.

Definitely a must see in Hanoi!. As expected, this museum shows the history in a way Americans will find upsetting. Men playing games and having Christmas celebrations is a ridiculous representation of events. However, what I found interesting was that the majority of the display was about how badly the French treated the Vietnamese. They talk about all the horrors but can't even see they turned around and did the same to the American prisoners. I recommend it to any visitors in Hanoi.

The Hanoi Hilton. Eerie to say the least...and the sound effects add to that feel. A recorded whistle blew and the members of our party all paused to see what was going on........but it was simply part of the mood setting. An in-depth depiction of prison life under the French is presented, but it glosses over (note; avoids!) speaking accurately of the treatment of American POWs who were kept there. To believe the propaganda, the POWs were treated to a visit of Club Med and not the abuse they endured. But, historically, it's a "can't miss" stop.
Jaw dropping. when you see reality, television images pales in comparison. Man's inhumanity to man is too impossible to comprehend. A very sobering experience

Well laid out and very informative. Unlike other museums etc we have visited excellent information and well laid out exhibits. As you would expect a definite slant on the approach taken particularly in the rooms detailing the incarceration of the US prisoners. Well worth a visit

Well worth a visit. This is a very interesting museum but it is quite graphic in content. The only downside is that there is not much information giving the history, and what information presented is very one sided. For 20000dong this is a good trip to do. Go with an open mind!

Enriching experience so long as you temper expectations. Museum is interesting. I found most valuable the two rooms dedicated to presenting the Vietnamese perspective on the role Hoa Lo played during the Vietnam War. As an American, the perspective was dramatically different from that which I expected and for this reason, it was thought provoking, to say the least. Note that only about 10% of the museum is dedicated to its POW days and 90% is dedicated to the prison's role while Vietnam was under French rule.
Interesting, but.... A bit of a disappointment, not that much info and what was there certainly supports "The victors write the history" theory
Hanoi Hilton. It was interesting to learn about the history of Hanoi, especially under the French. The displays were quite graphic, showing the conditions under which the prisoners were kept..

A small part saved - but an important place to visit. Depending on your age details of the war are not necessarily new but to walk through this small remaining part of the "Hanoi Hilton" and see some of the conditions, albeit all nice and clean with non of the smells and noises of reality, was thought provoking. When was the last time you stood next to a guillotine that had been used in anger?

Puts a lot of things in context. This prison built by the French shows without exaggeration the cruelty of colonial France. The US prisoners housed here are pictured. Women's story is an important one. Yes there is propaganda but you still get a sense of the life in there.

Interesting!!. Quite interesting, well restored and with good exhibits, but I found the propaganda a bit much. This is a good little museum which will only take an hour to look round. There is a nice mix of photos and physical items and you can actual walk through the rooms in which prisoners were held. It is quite clear that the way the French colonists treated the locals was pretty poor, and any right-minded human would be appalled on their behalf, so there just isn't any need to lay on the propaganda as thickly as the museum has done.
Very Interesting Visit. Like most prison museums but well thought out and easy route directions. Gave you a good feel of how the prisoners suffered.
Must see. Hoa Lo Prison was one of the better places in Hanoi. Plenty to see and very educational. Highly recommended.

Good Museum, High on Propaganda. Well maintained museum, but only a very small portion of what was the "Hanoi Hilton". Mostly concerning the French period in their history, but with a section on the American prisoners of war. High on "look how kind we were to the prisoners" propaganda, but that's to be expected. Worth a visit.

Hoa Lo Prison. Everyone has heard of the Vietnam war but to see the story and details of the inmates' life personally is heart-wrenching. The prison is a grime reminder of Vietnam's past both under French rule and the imprisonment of US flight crews. With photos and information boards in English it shows daily life in the prison from 1945 to 1973

If you have time- visit this jail. The museum was cheap and gave a good overview of the jail and history of the era. The exhibits were well done and interesting. Being an american it was interesting also to see some of the final exhibits of the POV's during the war (that were treated quite well it seemed).

Historical Value--Must see. Near to old qtr...at walking distance ...well maintained and informative .... slightly off road so need to inquire a little... English speaking people difficult to find but Google translate/ I translate is of great help through out the Vietnam.
Interesting. I really enjoyed the prison unfortunatley there needs to be a lot more english explination with some of the exhibits. It's unbelievable how people were treated.

Once here is enough. A friend was here for seven years and said "go see my cell". So I did. It was a disturbing, but something to experience and think about. My friend missed the dinners and festivities somehow.

Left with a heavy heart. Everyone has heard of the Vietnam war but to see the story and details of the inmates' life personally is heart-wrenching. Especially the room that is made to resemble a prison quarter. It is a must-go because it makes you understand more about the war and why wars should not exist anymore.

A story untold. Entrance fee is 20,000VND. It is interesting to learn what this prison was used for and how they treated their inmates. There were some sad and gruesome artifacts but important to educate us.This prison is said to be the largest prison in Indochina during the late 1800's. However, you will notice that the prison is actually small. This is because most of the original prison was demolished in 1996 to make way for the Hanoi Towers (which can be seen from the prison). I highly recommend visiting the museum.

Reality check. The prison is a grime reminder of Vietnam's past both under French rule and the imprisonment of US flight crews.It is informative from the point of fact of seeing things from the other side of the coin. With photos and information boards in English it shows daily life in the prison from 1945 to 1973. Word of warning, the guillotine in one of the exhibition halls was one of two that was used in the prison.

History revealed. Vivid accounts and photos of captives of North Vietnamese during what the present day Vietnamese refer to as "the American War".A must stop for anyone who, like myself, was on a quest to understand this period of diverse worldwide opinion.

Have your emotions in check if you're American. This is a site that holds interest by many Americans. As in the war museum, be prepared for anti-American propaganda. There is history here of the French use of this prison against Vietnamese rebels.
A Must See. Excellent if very slanted presentation. Give yourself enough time to take it all in. Also there's a nice litle grocery store around the corner.
Very interesting. very interesting to understand how prisoners were treated along the years, being Vietnamese or American

Informative little museum. Distasteful tour guides did sour our experience.. This is a good little museum which will only take an hour to look round. There is a nice mix of photos and physical items and you can actual walk through the rooms in which prisoners were held and look into detainment cells which really brings home the suffering of those held here. One negative point was the tour guides who were letting children sit in the stocks for photo opportunities. Many people suffered and probably died in those stocks and I think letting tourists do this is highly disrespectful. I have been to many museums where history has been rewritten to portray one side in a favourable light but this museum took this to a whole new level. When you reach the section which covers the holding of US prisoners during the Vietnam War it becomes a little ridiculous and insulting that they honestly think we would believe what they're showing us. According to this museum it was a holiday camp for US soldiers, who received presents and were allowed to socialise and enjoy themselves. They are pictures of soldiers laughing, playing cards and generally having a good time which goes against every single account given by these soldiers after the war. Definately visit the museum (it only costs £1 to get in) but take some of the accounts with a very large pinch of salt.

Very pleased to visit but glad we could leave. Went with a group of families. Excellent presentation of how existence would have been for prisoners of the French (shown as oppressed and mistreated which no doubt they were) and prisoners of the NVA, ie downed US airmen ( shown as enjoying basketball, Christmas dinner etc which was no doubt a series of photo ops). Smaller than it used to be with the new Towers development next door. But should be on your list when in Hanoi.

Really interesting little place. We decided to go here as we were staying at the real Hanoi Hilton. It was fascinating, and we got a real sense of what it would have been like in there for the Vietnamese and the American "guests". The lighting is low, so the dummies looked really real. A good one hour spent.

Well worth a visit. Expect to spend around 90mins strolling through various rooms of the old prison set up by the French in the late 19th century. They have recreated some of the conditions prisoners would have experienced here and provide information on some of the regulations and events that took place in the prison's history. It's set up to be very pro communist fight and regime so I'd take some of what you're being told with a pinch of salt. This probably especially true when you get to the US prisoner of war section where it details how easy it was for American POWs here. There is also an exhibition of national heroes upstairs who suffered the persecution of the imperialists.The entrance fee is good value for money and most stuff is in English.

Where is this place. Unable to find the street name on a map, we asked many locals for directions, none had any knowledge of the prison. Eventually through elimination we managed to find the location which is poorly advertised. It was worth the long walk, quite an interesting piece of history. Most of The prison buildings have demolished to make way for a tower building, they have replicated some of the building for display purposes and provide photographic and scripted information to give you an overview of accountabilities, atrocities, including torture, poisoning and malnutrition. Tough realisation for such recent times.

Eye-opening. Located centrally in town, and costing only 40,000VND each (GBP1.40). Showing the history of the prison from the French-occupied era through to the American-Vietnam war. Harrowing, but engaging enough to spend an hour or two here. Not much for little kids but for me it was important to learn about this part of history.
Facinating. i thought the museam was fab, very very interesting and a must see in Hanoi, it is also a lot bigger than i expected and has lots of information

Very interesting and easy way to spend an hour or so. The Jail was great and an eyeopener for us and our 10 and 13 year olds. Seeing the guillotine was sobering and reading about the American airman that were incarcerated here during the Vietnam War was interesting and seeing John McCain photos and flight suit after he was captured made it more relevant for the kids

Well worth a visit. The remaining sections of the Hoa Lo prison next to the Hanoi Towers is well worth visiting. It will take about 45 mins of your time, It gives pretty good idea of what the prison was like for the Vietnamese during the French colonial time and for the American Airmen during the "American" War. It has good displays and reasonable amount of english explanations to tell the story. The dvd of the air war and airmen in the prison also work!

Propaganda alive and well. This was an interesting place to visit. Only part of the prison now stands, much of the old prison has been demolished and had high rise buildings put on it.I found the stories about American airmen being held here during the Vietnam war the most interesting. The Vietnamese government likes to tell visitors that the Americans called this place the Hanoi Hilton because they were treated so well. If you listen to the American accounts it was called that because they were treated in the exact opposite.Perhaps not a whole lot to see in the prison, but well worth a look.

Heavy on propaganda. Quite interesting, well restored and with good exhibits, but I found the propaganda a bit much. It is quite clear that the way the French colonists treated the locals was pretty poor, and any right-minded human would be appalled on their behalf, so there just isn't any need to lay on the propaganda as thickly as the museum has done. I don't doubt everything the museum reports that the French did really happened, but some of the language is rather 'one dimensional' for my taste....I found the representation of the treatment of the US POWs a bit facile....it was all hearty meals, ping pong tournaments and dressing the xmas tree (I kid you not) the way the museum tells it. No one would have criticised the Vietnamese had they given the POWs a minimum of human rights, so why dress it up and make it unbelievable? All in all, the museum has good content, but the hugely heavy handed propaganda ruined it for me. We visited Tuol Sleng in Phnom Penh several years ago, and the handling of a horrific prison couldn't be more different. In Phnom Penh, the simple facts are laid out and you make your own mind up. Here at the Hanoi Hilton you are told what to think with a very heavy hand and it switched me right off. Take it with a pinch of salt and it's ok......

I wish I didn't bring my 10 year old daughter.... It was not graphic but it was gruesome. There were carved models of prisoners shackled in one room so you got the idea how they "lived" it was hard to take for me but my 13 year old son was fascinated. Just not as great for my 10 year old daughter.

Not for the faint hearted!. There were areas in this museum I was not able to enter - it was too emotionally challenging to do so (might sound funny i know but that's how I felt). The information about the way the North American prisoners were held in this prison 'sounded too good to be true'.

Worth an hour!. You can get a bike from Hanoi backpackers for about $1.50, and is worth a quick whip round. Shows the cruel conditions the French kept the Vietnamese in versus the good way in which captured American pilots were treated (make your own mind up whether this is true or propaganda. Some interesting things to see including how Vietnamese prisoners escaped, but not a great deal to see, so wouldnt spend too long there. Fairly sombre experience.

A Reminder of Darker Times. The prison museum, nicknamed "The Hanoi Hilton" by the American Pilots who were held there during the war, covers not only the war against the Americans, but also the struggle against the French colonialists. Some of it is rather harrowing (the actual French guillotine used to behead Vietnamese insurgents is still on display), but most of the material on the war against the USA is somewhat propagandistically presented, as if the US prisoners all had a nice time there.

Small set up and a must see!. We came straight here by taxi from Ho Chi Minhs Mausoleum which cost about 45,000VND. We got there about 10am and it was very quiet which was great. Cost 20,000VND for each of us - excellent value!We walked around at our own pace and saw the small part of the prison that was left. although there is not much left you get the idea and the displays are well kept and descriptions are in both Vietnamese and English. We spent about an hour looking around - we loved the different displays although it was a very one sided view it was an eye opener into life at that time in Hanoi. Photos are allowed anywhere in the prison. It is a must do attraction in Hanoi and we would rank this as one of our favorite spots - a definite highlight of our last day in Hanoi.Give yourself a little over an hour an have a look :)

Worth to pay a visit. Although there isn't much left of its original state (like Tuol Sleng in Cambodia), it is still worth to pay this museum a visit. If you'd like to understand more about the history of Vietnam and how they have suffered in the past, you cannot skip this museum.The information is in English as well in Vietnamese. It's not big, but I have been able to spend a bit over 2 hours here. It's by walking distance of the old quarter.
One sided much??. Well as you can expect very one sided like most museums, but brush that aside and quite a interesting museum with a lot more history than people think, a must see in Hanoi.

Gotta Love the Propaganda!. This museum looks like the curator went to the terror museum in Budapest and tried to emulate it. It's actually pretty well done, although the account of the U.S. POW's time spent there looks pretty rosy. Nonetheless, there are some interesting things to see in here, and it's well worth the admission fee.

Puts things into perspective. It was very interesting to visit the exhibition at the Prison. It gave me the Vietnamese perspective on things and it is an eye opener. Most movies and books portrait the westerner's view and don't really do justice to what really happened in Vietnam during colonisation. Worth going to see things through Vietnamese eyes.

Worth the $1 for a look around. From what I had read up previously about the infamous prison, the modernity and brightness of the museum created an atmosphere which detracted from the story of suffering of the people who were incarcerated there, although I suppose many of the Vietnamese political prisoners are held up as heroes so maybe I've taken things the wrong way. The most striking moment is seeing the guillotine which was used, but otherwise this is something of a photo museum with occasional large exhibits. You can see some of the cells too. Although almost everything is labelled in Vietnamese and English, there are papers and documents from French colonial times which are only translated into Vietnamese, which is a shame since you end up skipping large parts if you're not bilingual (I have some basic French, but too basic for these documents). Maybe this is why I think the atmosphere is all wrong, because of the bright lights and a quick walkthrough. As you should expect, the propaganda and rhetoric is heavy in places and inappropriately amusing at times. Try and latch on to a tour group to overhear their guide give you the Vietnamese take on things in person.

Informative and sobering. Travelling with husband and two teenage boys, this was always going to be a must see, but I was surprised by the extent of information about Vietnamese battles with French particularly. It was interesting getting the Vietnamese perspective on the importance of their long running conflicts with the French. Also highlights the bravery and commitment of the Vietnamese fighting for independence.Of course the place is also simply a blood chilling reminder of why war (and Colonisation) is not to be desired. Very sad.Yes, it is written in socialist propaganda terms, but that's understandable, surely? Still really interesting, for history buffs, and blood thirsty teenagers
Shame its altered. I really looked forward to this trip,but left a bit flat as theres not much of the prison left,and its been modernised to much in my opinion,but still worth seeing

Interesting to see the other side's perspective. Things I have read have said the part about treating the Americans great is pretty much propaganda. Interesting to see though. And this makes up a small portion of the prison. Mostly (understandably) focuses on when it was used by the French against the Vietnamese rebels.

this place makes you think on many issues. this places makes you think long and hard over how we treat people we don't agree with. i know that this museum is aimed at the Vietnamese so the french are nasty as are the americans, but when you see what each of them did to the locals you can understand why the exibits are as they are. please go with an open mind and try and find some truth inb all the spin.

The prison. It was another confronting place to visit, but it told you how people were treated, and lots of information. Not much more to say as that was a prison, and like all prison you can see the hardship of prisoners

Worth a visit. This museum is rather one-sided in its portrayal of the excesses of French colonial rule and in its suggestion that, later, captured American pilots were treated well with plenty of sport and hobbies and even Christmas Dinner. However, it is interesting to visit and to glimpse the Vietnamese "take" on French rule and on the Vietnam War.

worth the visit. I had history during my college days, and therefore, I was inclined to know more about this place. I was always fascinated by the fact that Vietnam’s war tactics was simply superb, and they were able to defend themselves very well, inspite of losing many lives. The place has lot of interesting portraits and also a lot to see and learn about prisoners during the war days.

Interesting bit of history and propaganda. While laid on a bit syrupy, this is an interesting look at the French-indochina history of the prison and then, as per the desire of the museum's orchestrators, a contrasting look at the conversion of the prison to a prisoner of war facility for American pilots during the Vietnam War. No doubt there was some contrast, but the video accompanying to the exhibits is a straight-up propaganda film. That makes it no less interesting, however. History of rebellion exhibits in Vietnam are quite interesting, even if the reenactment designs are a bit heavy handed. This is a worthwhile way to spend 90 minutes around Hanoi, and its only a dollar to walk in. You can skip the gift shop - everything therein is available in the old quarter at a better price.

Disturbing. Many displays of the atrocities of war with storyboards explaining the treatment of American prisoners. Somewhat onesided but makes you think about the horrors that were administerd there depending on what colonial power was in control.
Glimpse of Hanoi's history. A visit to this museum is a must if you want to know more about the gruesome conditions and treatment of political prisoners in Hanoi.

Awesome if a little one-sided.. Must see attraction documenting the evils of the colonial oppressors. Yep, like all the museums in Vietnam there isn't much balance or actual critical history. What you get is the official version of events but nevertheless the brutality of the recent history of Vietnam does come across. Pictures of happy smiling American POWs making their xmas decorations have got to make you wonder who is fooling who. Great to see though, even just for the guillotine.
must see. All Americans in Hanoi must see this. Definitely a lot of communist rhetoric, but cool nonetheless. Cool guillotine and torture devices on display
Historical Prison (Hanoi Hilton). They were closing as we arrived, but allowed us to tour anyway. It was very interesting and sort of spooky in some areas. Worth visiting.

A bit of History. Having read and heard about the Hanoi Hilton it was worth visiting it to say we had seen it. The museum part is well done and some of the displays are realistic. We took about 30-45 minutes to go through it.
Interesting Place to Visit. Prison is worth a visit to see remnants of prison life. Very well preserved and well maintained. I learned a lot from reading and seeing the artifacts.

Hoa Lo Prison aka The Hanoi Hilton: Expect the unexpected aka Hanoi Hilton. We walked to Hoa Lo Prison from the Conifer Boutique Hotel (about eight blocks) wanting to see, if out of curiosity more than anything else. The prison is now a museum and is more than 90% focused on the period when the French ran the prison and jailed a large number of Vietnamese revolutionaries. The harsh and inhumane treatment of these prisoners was hard to digest. Only two rooms focused on the American prisoners, e.g., one room displayed John McCain's flight uniform that he was wearing when he was shot down over Hanoi. We found visiting the prison to be a unique experience and were glad that we had come on the one day in Hanoi that the Gate 1 Discovery Tour had not programmed.
Un moment d'histoire particulière.... A little souvenir of french occupation and also american history in Vietnam. Very usefull place to understand more....

History as it is from the north. This was my second time here after 7 years. I still found it fascinating even if the history is rather skewed. The guillotine had been moved instead. I remember distinctly on my first visit that the French had used the guillotine during the 20th century.You can see pictures and the story of John McCain. There are also sculptures to show how the prisoners lived in the prison. It is very interesting.

Sobering. It's very sobering to spend an hour or so wandering round and reading the info boards. Realising what torment people went through in the name of politics makes you wonder why people fought to have the vote when it can be such a source of trouble. The death cells especially make you appreciate your liberty.

Well worth the visit. We visited the prison earlier this week. I was expecting more information re the 'Hanoi Hilton' and the experiences of the prisoners during the time of the Vietnam War. Even so it was an insight to what went on during the 'rule' of the French. Appalling treatment and Spaulding conditions. I recommend this as a must see when in Hanoi.

Riveting. What an experience in spending some time visiting this historical place known to Westerners as Hanoi Hilton.The displays were interesting and enlightening.It had my children 'gobsmacked' by the cell sizes, the artefacts and the guillotine.The displayed covered all areas of the prison's history from the French to the American pilots incarcerations.We all really enjoyed this historical experience, not one to be missing when visiting Hanoi.

Hanoi Hilton. An interesting place (only part of the old prison still remains) Although known to westerners as the Hanoi Hilton of the Vietnam (American) war the focus is much more on the colonial French occupation as it is throughout n.Vietnam. It is only about one hours entertainment but worth a visit nevertheless.

Hoa Lo prison. An excellent and thought provoking display showing the hardships of the men and women who were incarcerated in this prison. It is not very big but I think it is definitely worth a visit.

Grim place with on-site guillotine!. The inconspicuous entrance from the road masks one of the grimest places I've ever seen, & I live in Wales so it has got some pretty stern opposition for that title!! Loads of photos depict the history of the prison. I didn't know women had such a difficult time in Vietnam earlier in its history. Its quite propagandist but these people have put up with so much in the past, who can blame them.Theres a signposted guided tour which takes you thru the area where the tiger cages were with quite a few photos on the subject, passing various instruments of punishment including a guillotine & incorporating a visit to the cells. We made this the first stop of a walk around the various museums, so if your based in the Old Quarter it is probably easy walking distance, & u can also take in other sites like Vietnam Military Museum, Ho Chi Minh Museaum, mausoleum & One Pillar Pagoda. Definitely worth a visit.

Stark reminder. The oft used name of Hanoi Hilton, may distract from this prison being originally built by the French to detain Vietnamese dissidents. Whilst only a portion of the original prison remains it is worth the visit.Tops of walls have glass imbedded as a reminder of the prison.Apparently some vietnamese prisoners escaped via the sewer and there are examples to view. We were told others plotted to poison/drug guards.--and were dealt withA portable french guillotine used for killing is on show and some graphic photos.You can walk into a long room with side benches for prisoners, restrained with crude metal shackles.The prison certainly documents the very harsh treatment of Vietnamese during French rule.During the Vietnam War the prison held US airmen from planes shot down. Photos on walls paint a calm, easy environment for US prisoners--making Christmas cake, and Christmas treesdowned US airman were held during the war. There is a flying outfit and parachute -listed as from john McCain

Ok - not great. As a museum it does have some interesting and gruesome exhibits and some of the plaques are informative. Unfortunately, the descriptions are packed full of communist spin which really reduced my interest.The Hanoi Hilton is clearly a place where nobody wanted to be when it was in operation and some horrendous things happened there for sure, but as a museum attraction for someone from the West (most visitors when we were there) who cannot read Vietnamese I felt it lacked a bit.It killed some time, and is a talking point when back home but nothing special.
An absolute must. If you leave Hanoi without seeing what was called the Hanoi Hilton (where they kept US pilots caught during the war) you are missing an excellent attraction. Lots of history.

Remember what it was built for. Colonialism had n ugly side...this it and the French were better than most in the colonies with torture and the like. Very eerie and thought provoking as you move around...take your time as this is what has moulded the country and their experience itch the West.
Emotional. Impressed how Vietnam has preserved this historical prison, the walls are filled with sadness but the people incarcerated were filled with determination.
Hanoi Hilton. An interesting and sometimes gruesome visit, it gave you a very good insight into the treatment and conditions of the poor people who were held there.
It's ok...interesting history. Building doesn't look like much..not even a museum. They have some photos of Joh McCain and his flight suit on display. It was an ok place much not a must see.

the famous "Hanoi Hilton". rather interesting in that it is 85% dedicated to the french opressors in great detail, with a brief, almost frivolous view of the american prisoners. thruout the country the people refer to the "American War", and in many instances indicate that the french rule for over 100 years was far more horrendous. perspective is everything here.

Hanoi Hilton. Very interesting exhibits as to what conditions were like for both Vietnamese prisoners during French colonial era and American air force pilots captured during Vietnam War. The latter was very one sided propaganda, but that is common everywhere in Vietnam
one of the best attractions in Hanoi. Keeping in mind who is telling the story, this is a well maintained museum that many will know as the Hanoi Hilton. Easy walk from the Lake

If you're a fan of communist propaganda then go. For us visiting this "museum" was a total waste of time. I sympathize with the people imprisoned here as it must have been a terrible time for them. Still it's so obviously communist propaganda throughout the whole place that there is just no point visiting. They've completely misunderstood the aim of a museum, to tell history from an objective point of view. Sad in a way because they could have made this really interesting and told a bit of their history as it was. Go if you're into communist propaganda and skip it if you get annoyed when historical facts are grossly distorted. Entrance is 20.000VND per person.

A "check the box" visit to see where American POWs were held.. Very little remains of the actual prison, a huge hotel has been built over the land that once held the rest of the prison. It's loaded with propaganda and eerie music plays in the background. Took 45 mins to walk through the whole place slowly. It's only $1, so if you have some time to kill, it's interesting to say you've seen where John McCain and other POWs were held, otherwise take a pass.

The Hanoi Hilton. Interesting view of Vietnams struggle for independance & freedom. Take time to view the photo's & read the articles it is very rewarding & gives you an understanding of the generations of hardship & struggle the Vietnamese endured leading up to their independance. There is a definate biased view to their struggle but if you can see through the propaganda it is understandable.The guillotine is quite forbodding as is the cramped cell conditions the prisoners lived in.You get to understand the irony of the name "The Hanoi Hilton" when you visit.

Don't waste your time. This place was full of propaganda. It was not worth the price. There was creepy music playing like I was in a haunted house or something. It does not even compare to the museums in Cambodia about war. They tried way to hard to make it sad and it came out really hokey and over the top.

Hanoi Hilton. gives you a perspective of what the Vietnamese endured under the French places like this exist to remind us how cruel people can be to each other.well worth spending an hour,admission very cheap
Not impressed. Cost 20,000 VND...if you have been to the Tuol Sleng Museum in Cambodia...I wouldn't bother with this...! Would learn more off the internet.
Hanoi Hilton. Not sure the account of prisoner treatment is accurate but an important part of history and very somber place but important none the less

A lot more than the American Hanoi Hilton. Most definitely worth a visit. What we didn't previously realise is that the prison was originally built by the French to deal with the Vietnamese dissidents and guerrilla fighters. Whilst there is plenty of propaganda around the place, it's still very easy to see that the conditions were pretty brutal and harsh whatever the use of the prison was given to.It's worthy of a visit and worth the small enhance fee that is charged. One of those places you need to go to.

Worth a look. The famous Hanoi Hilton, defiantly worth a visit. It will take you about an hour to have a good look round and is much more than the prison in which downed US airman were held during the war.

Thought provoking; plenty of propaganda. Only a portion of the original prison remains. The propaganda films make big claims on how well US pilots were treated there. still, thought provoking and worth the visit.

Funny Propaganda. a strange prison museum that exposes the jail breaks and colorful political characters who lived-and died in this prison. Begun as a French Prison for freedom fighters, after the north won their freedom, the prison was used to detain American pilots shot down while the pilots attempted bombing runs.

Potentially very interesting. Spoilt by endless heavy-handed propaganda. The behaviour of the French was very bad - as in all their colonies - but the museum seems to be trying to promote the prevailing regime. Very remiscent of the old Soviet Union.

Fascinating Museum. It was very interesting and a cool place to spend a few hours. We visited the exhibits and saw models of how the Vietnamese were treated by the French in the Hoa Lo Prison.After that, we saw how well the Americans lived during the Vietnam War. They showed us all the good things about how they treated us, and all the bad things about how they were treated by the French.Overall, it was an interesting place to learn about the Wars and Prisons.

Worth visiting. Anyone alive in the 1960s heard all about the "Hanoi Hilton" through the media. Now, it's a must-do visit on a visit to Hanoi. When combined with your imagination, it's a chilling experience, but missing the experience would be a mistake.
nice. it was grt place ,must see in hanoi .. i like it it takes 1 to 2 hours to explore whole prison .it is one of the best place in Hanoi .
A bit of history. Interesting and informative and can be seen in a relatively short time. Leaves a rather lasting impression of horror.

Worth the visit. Obviously, I had mixed emotions about this place, but it is worth the trip and the time to explore how French treated the local Vietnamese population and how they returned the favor during the Vietnam (or as they say American) war.

Prison in Hanoi. A bit gruesome but exhibits well display what happened there and how the prisoners were treated. A nice quiet area at the end of the tour in the shape of a memorial garden to reflect.
There are much more interesting things to see. The prison is of course of great historic importance. But there's little that remains of the original prison and the story told is too one sited.

Very interesting with eery music to add to experience. This museum is very interesting with the right amount of exhibits and a good balance of visual displays and written information.The music adds to the feel of the place ...you almost feel like you were there. The mannequins in the cells make it feel real.So sad to read what the Vietnamese people went through to fight for freedom . Well worth a visit
WOW. It was a real insight into the Vietnam war.Hard to say how much was truth and how much was proppaganda.You have to make up your own mind!

Not Much Left but Worth a Visit. Much of the prison has been removed for a big new hotel. What is left is interesting and well done. There is more focus on the time before "the American War", which surprised me a bit.
Sobering. You really need to see to believe it. How man can be so cruel & sadistic is beyond me. Although it is ver slanted toward the locals.

Not worth a special visit. I made an effort to go to the Hanoi Hilton (prison) to get another aspect of the Vietnam War, when I got there the small sign outlining the fact that I was at the correct location, made sure that I was.The North Vietnamese I found are still very anti American and this prison helps to reinforce that. Definitely will not recommend visiting.

Not interesting. I am all for hearing the story of a country's history, but this museum did a great job of telling its story. The French used it as a central hotel building back in the day, then it was used as a prison for 'rebels' to Vietnam. Basically the whole thing is about how Vietnam was killing its own people as rebels before the Americans came there and killed the Vietnamese themselves. Interesting that it was a place for downed US pilots during the 70's. Didn't really enjoy this museum.

worth a trip. A bit gory and not for the sensitive type, but its a fact of life and should be seen. Its beyond belief what humanity can inflict on humanity, and for this reason you should go. Its thought provoking.

Great tour. Visited the hao lo prison (also known as the Hanoi Hilton) and it was definitely worth a visit. I am ashamed to say I didn't know much about the history of Vietnam when the french occupied it. I thought it would be more about the Americans in Vietnam, but there was a section to that time also. Very interesting.

communist propaganda. Being an ex Navy pilot and having read just about every first-person account of American serviceman's experience in the "hilton", I left the museum with one strong emotion: anger.
sad. after finding this attraction we where surprised how cheep it was to enter the prisoner had a very hard life but the americians renamed it the hanio hilton

Look at the photos, read the stories. For most of us we have little idea of what it's like inside a prison, let alone one during war. Although renovated, there are plenty of graphic photos with explanations. For me I felt the exhibitions lacked a flow or connection from one to the next. Also there's a emphasis on women prisoners and later they show models of mal prisoners. For $1 very good value
Not for the faint hearted. Clearly sets out the history of the various invaders of Vietnam and their treatment of the local people.

Great journey thru its life as a prison. We enjoyed this site the most. Well documented information from the French Colonial area thru to the recent detention of US military including John McCain. Learned a lot.

A somber piece of history. Hoa Lo Prison provides a look into the many years of torture and trials of those who were imprisioned there. Allow yourself a couple hours to walk through the exhibits and "feel" the somberness.

Well worth a visit. Very interesting in terms of both French and US conflicts. The treatment (allegedly) of the US airmen, tells you why it was nicknamed the Hanoi Hilton. A gentle intro to the horrors to follow in Saigon and Pnomh Penh museums.

Eerily sad. We went to the Hoa Lo prison not knowing what to expect, but it sure delivered a surprise. With eerie music playing throughout, and lots of info in most rooms, the prison proved to be a sad insight into a different side of the war. The most interesting, sad and eerie piece within the prison is by far the original guillotine used on prisoners, along with quite a few of the used torture devices, which can be a bit distressing for some. A great place to visit for the price, but don't expect it to take up much of your time, a recommended stop.

Hoa La Prison. Extremely good value and very insightful. It is worth paying a bit extra for the book which gives you more background information. Very well set out and very interesting exhibitions they still have the guillotine used when it was owned by the French on display and a lot of photos from the Vietnam War. Well worth a visit and easy to combine with a vist to the Vietnam's Womens Museum.

Small and still hauntingly sad.... Made me redefine civilized...the activities by the French, Japanese, Chinese and even themselves, the Vietnamese gave me much to think about after visiting here. The story is told in the decent displays that exist throughout the facility and its not hard to imagine the horrors that were endured by anyone who was detained here.Gripping, intense at times, some propaganda gets excessive and dilutes the story...some integrity issues but it is what it is and all part of the experience.Worth the price of admission and a good way to spend a few hours downtown

5-10 minutes worth of tour. A good place to stop on your way to/from lunch...don't expect to be entertained for more than 5-10 minutes. For us, the best part was seeing the rather obvious propaganda from the government.

Shocking. Hanoi Hilton for many US pilots but although now a museum most of the original building has been demolished. Makes one realise the brutality of war. There is a Guillotine on display that had apparently been used in the past.

Great insight. The prison provided a great insight into the history of the prison conditions over the last century with plenty of photographic evidence and artifacts to look at. While it is a small museum it is a good place to visit if your passing by and have an hour or 2 to spare. Content was interesting, though if war and history isn't your thing then this probably wont be either. Entry is also very cheap, and is half price for students

Very interesting - well worth a visit. I loved it here, it gave a real insight and opened my eyes to how badly the French (who first opened the prison) treated the Vietnamese politicians who were brave enough to speak out.I think the only downside is how very biased the American war section is. It explains how well the Americans were treated and how respected they were. It shows pictures of them watching movies, playing basket ball, putting Xmas trees up. I'm pretty sure it wasn't always like this when the cameras were not there.But nevertheless it's a very interesting visit.
Sobering.. I wanted to visit this museum and it didnt disappoint me either. found it very sobering to see what happened here.
An interesting and informative visit. Information provided in English which was great as not many places did. Very informative and provided a good visual of the cells, inmates and life in the prison.

Not a must see. If you have time it's something to do. My dad wanted to check this out while we were in Ha Noi and we had some time before going to the water puppet show (which was a lot more fun and interesting than the Hoa Lo Prison). We walked through the whole place in about 30-40 minutes.I wouldn't come back or recommend.

Def need to see this. We learned so much about the Vietnam War, or as they call it the American War - it's so sad to see the devastation that war brings but it's important to see it - def learned a lot

A learning experience. The material presented covers not only the Vietnam War, but the French occupation as well. It is dark in some areas so if your phone has one of those flashlight apps you may need it. Take the time to watch the videos presented to get a real flavor for North Vietnam's perspectives on the war.

Moving experience. This is well worth a visit. Although not all the prison is still there it's enough to give you a very good sense of the scale and condition of it. There is a really helpful storyboard as you walk through the rooms that tracks the history of the prison and the guillotine is still there which was used during the French colonial era.The striking wall sculpture at the end is worth the price of admission alone
Good to see. Very interesting,it's their take on the war. Got to see John McCain flight suit that he was shot down in.You are able to actually go inside the cells.

Educational visit. The prison had manequinns to showcase how the prisoners lived in the prison. It depicted how badly the Vietnamese were treated during the the French colonisation and how well the Americans were treated.

Very little mention of the us pilots except. "how well" they were treated. Not as interesting as I had hoped. A lot about the french and how they imprisoned the locals. A really bad place to be locked up but not as interesting as I thought it would be

Interesting, and then...... Most of us know what we are going to see when we go there. And as an American who is not so proud of his countries past (or present to be Frank), the naked propaganda at the end was still disturbing.It's a shell of an old prison that the Vietnamese do their best to show you how bad it is. And I don't blame them a bit, but you don't go there looking for beauty. You go there looking for history. And after seeing the cells and "pit", you go to the 'main' attraction. Americans, and John McCain's gear when he was caught. And they have it. Up until then, they do a good job of showing what seems an unbiased job of history. Why else go to a museum?Then after seeing McCains flight suit and other military gear, you see a video. This is a puzzle.It shows happy American POWS playings cards, chess, celebrating Christmas, and doing all other kinds of leisurly activities while the citizens of Hanoi are being bombed and maimed. Now I am sure that the people of Hanoi (and other places in Vietnam) suffered during this period, and that the American Air Force did it, It's that they showed those POWS playing around during it. Something that anyone who knows anything about history knows isn't true. They were tortured and beaten and kept in solitary until the cameras were there.Come on Vietnam. I've never been to a country that I've been treated nicer in and thank you for that. You won a long time ago. Bury that video.

Interesting. Old enough to remember the war in Vietnam so this was a must to visit. Very slanted anti American view but if you can get over that worth a visit. French didn't come out too well it started off as their prison.

shameful. I was interested in seeing a historical place. There are always 2 sides to a story. However the Vietnamese portrayal of their treatmenet of US troops held in prison is shameful. Read Senator Mc Caisn biography for his narrative on the years of real torture the troops endured. I feel guilty having paid an entrance fee and supported this site. Yes, the Vietnamese endured extremed hardships and death during the war but to belittle and lie about the abuses they inflicted on captured soldiers will only make the healing process between the countries people more difficult. There are many wonderful places to visit while in Hanoi and great native people to interact with visiting this site tainted my perspective on things.

AKA Hanoi Hilton. Interesting to see but gave made up view of American pilots being treated nicely. They had clearly staged pictures of Pilots playing basketball, decorating a Christmas tree and having a holiday meal. Display of John McCain's flight suit and part of parachute were also disturbing. Built by the French and shows how badly they treated the Vietnamese.

A somber look into the atrocities of war. Looking at the exhibits you have to feel for the Vietnamese people and their struggles.There were a great many revolutionaries who were detained in this prison and much was described about how they have suffered and how they ultimately achieved independence.We had purchased a guide book for the prison but it was not necessary as all of the exhibits are fully detailed.A must see for History buffs.

Skip. Most of the proson is gone with just a small part left which was not very interesting. Most is about the French colonial days with only a small part relating to the barbarian Americans playing ping pong. I would skip it.
Thought provoking. Went to the prison as somewhere to get out of the rain. Found some of it quite hard hitting but throughly interesting and nice to find out some of the history of the war.

Confronting. Not sure of the accuracy of how the US prisoners were treated. There was a lot of stuff about Vietnamese who fought the French and a lot of detail about the revolutionaries which would probably be more interesting to the locals.
Very educational. Definitely worth visiting & rather educational. Quite sad though seeing what the prisoners endured. Its in town & very cheap entry fee.

Confronting. A little more confronting than we were expecting. It seemed to be a good reflection of the time. We did not have a guided tour, but I would recommend one to get the most out of your visit ... I'm sure we missed some great facts.
its wonderfull. I cant undestand how the viet namese people can do that.that the huge .....i not much know about the war in viet nam .when i got here i know well

Very interesting, with lots of historical information. Well worth a visit as it detail a lot a about Vietnam history prior to the war with America as well as about that conflict. Gives you a real feel for what being imprisoned in there would have meant. Well worth an hour or two of time.

Interesting. I would recommend going here, it was an interesting exhibit.
We walked there and got lost quite a bit, I would suggest taking a cab

A long brutal history. The view here is a bit biased, obviously your in Vietnam so its from there point of view, they brush over the period they ran it and focus on the French colonialists, who were brutal. In the period of the American war its all too good to be true, they treated the airmen so well, however I guess if someone was dropping bombs on you you wont be so nice to them.

Hanoi must do. Interesting history, esp the origins of the prison and it's construction and use by the French. The theme is of course one sided communist propaganda, esp for the American war. Short walk from the city center.

Good insight into vietnam history. Good museum lots of information and photos of prison life. Cells very scary. Good to see propaganda.. There for just over an hour so could easily fit in another museum.

Fascinating Propaganda.... Definitely worth a visit - but check the opening hours. The information around the museum has a particularly government-sponsored feel; Americans are still 'capitalist running dogs', and the photos of their supposedly kind treatment at the hands of the Vietnamese don't quite match up to the stories they brought home.Make sure you look at the beautiful murals, and head into the golden room that commemorates Vietnamese victims of the French colonialists. Just don't expect a straightforward, historical account...

Vey interesting. After reading some of the reviews, I wanted to visit this place during my stay. Im glad I did, as its one of the more interesting places I visited during my week in Hanoi.Some reviews give the impression there's not much left of the place, but this isn't true. Granted its not the complete prison remaining, but there are still a lot of interesting rooms, cells and courtyards to wander through. The prison was used by the French to house Vietnamese, then later used by the Vietnamese to house US prisoners of war. There is a certain amount of propaganda regarding these two uses, so I'd advise taking some of the propaganda with a healthy pinch of salt.One highlight was John McCains flight suit on show, after the parachuted into Truc Bach lake, nearly drowned but was dragged out and beaten by the locals before becoming a POW.Other highlights are the dirty and depressing cells, and an original guillotine used by the French. There's also a nicely stocked souvenir shop, I normally avoid these places but they had some interesting stuff and I ended up spending about $100
must do. Definitely a must for Americans who lived through the Vietnam War. This is where John McCain and others were held as POWs. Their version of prisoner treatment is despicable.

must for Americans but not for others. Very small bit left mostly devoted to french imperialists and the noble Vietnamese Communist warriors. Heavily skewed to pro Vietnamese interpretation of US prisoners.. so much so made one wonder why they didnt ask to stay on after peace.

Excellent & Amazing Value for Money. Please pay the £3 it costs to have the personal guide to show you around the museum. Horrific in parts and the guillotine made me feel a bit wobbly but the whole experience was a must see must do.

Still La Maison Centrale. Yes, it is on the must do list. Yes John McCain was one of the unwilling guest. But it is dark, lost in the middle of skyscrapers and very one sided. Most of the exhibit is about the French Colonial period and how the Vietnamese people were tortured and killed.

Interesting. Enjoyed seeing the "Hanoi Hilton" though the pictures depicting how the American pilots were treated was not quite the same as was reported in the Western press - but gave us a different perspective .......................

Worth a visit, but not spectacular. I doesn’t take a long time to do a complete visit to the museum. Unfortunately, most of it is demolished. What's left is a section of death row and some sleeping quarters. Also one of the two operated guillotines is interesting to see.The main attraction for me was the authentic pictures from the period when the French kept Vietnamese prisoners here. The cruelness gets to you.The period when US POWs stayed here is more an anti-US propaganda than authentic. Which is understandable I guess. “Happy” prisoners playing basket ball and preparing xmas turkey etc. They try to make a point of the western prisoners being more humanely treated than themselves, which I guess they were as well - the colonists have been known to be animals elsewhere as well. But I don’t think the US troops were THIS joyful while there.Anyway – worth a couple of hours. It won’t take more.

Hanoi Hilton a must see when in Hanoi. Highly recommended, easy to find on a walking tour of the city. The prison is presented well and gives the visitor a great understanding of the plight of the prisoners form Vietnamese revolutionaries to the american airman. cheap to visit with only and hour or so of your holiday required to get the most from this location.
Hoa Lo Prison or "Hanoi Hilton". I'm glad I went, but prisons and military stuff isn't my thing. The men liked it better than I. It has lots of photos and military stuff.

Interesting, but not what I expected. Was really interesting to go over there and see what happend in those place. After all, I expected a bit more of it, better information and better or more foto's. You can see that there are not many foto's left of those period because we've seen a lot of double foto's hanging there.
Definitely worth a visit. Strangely impressive. A very informative display of how prisoners were kept and the treatment they received. Well worth a visit when your in Hanoi!

Hanoi Hilton........ It was known as the Hanoi Hilton - really glad i managed to go and see this. The information was well documented about how prisoners were treated and the role women played. Some of it was gruesome (guillotine and pictures of prisoners heads that were put on display. Overall it was educational.

Well worth a visit. This was one of the last things we did in Hanoi and I am really pleased we managed to do it.It highlights not only the journey of communism in the North but also elements of the Vietnam War and also the important role women planned in making change happen. It has its gruesome bits but overall was extremely educational interesting and well done - there is even creepy music to put you in the zone and some random mannequins!

Must do in Hanoi. Very well documented information on how prisoners were treated in this prison. Quite horrifying to see the guillotine and the pictures beside it of prisoners heads that were put on display.

Very interesting. Useful insight into the history of Vietnam and Hanoi including quite a bit of "communist propaganda". Paricularly interesting about the American War and the pilots who were imprisoned there

Known as the Hanoi Hilton in the Vietnam war.. The prison dates back to the late 1800's and has been used for political prisoners at all times. In more recent times US airmen were interned there. There is not much left of the prison so it is mainly of historical interest.

Sad but well displayed. most of this prison museum is dedicated to the ill-treatment of the Vietnamese by the French colonizers but there is a section towards the end about the incarceration of US pilots here. Most of the information is in English and French as well as Vietnamese and there is a good amount of information and displays. They show you the conditions of the men and women during the French colonization as well as the isolation areas and prison and torture instruments. Photos are allowed inside.

Really interesting to see what we've done a long time ago.... Very interesting visit.It is a part of our History which no one talk about in France. I know that we did horrible things but it is something else to watch it !A pity it is too far from France. Otherwise we should bring our kids there in order to show them we made terrible things and avoid to act like this later !
Hoa Lo Prison. A very poignant & stirring memory of the suffering undergone by the vietnamese (freedom fighters?) against the french.

What remains of a prison.... Interesting example of a prison in North Vietnam. The building retains very little of what it was originally (behind him stands a new complex ...), but the photographic evidence and reconstructions are significant. Much space is given to both the war of liberation against the French that the next offensive against the South Vietnamese and Americans. There were also some object "taken" to the prisoners, such as the suit of the American Senator McCain.
Impressive!. Impressive and some emotional moments. Must see to understand a bit better. I found a lot of stuff might have bit romantised like how they treated the Americain soldiers.
Well worth a visit. It's very well laid out and worth a visit. The whole place can be seen within 1 hour. It's great to see the details of the American war.
Brilliant. Really enjoyed our visit here. very interesting where John McCain and other americans were held. you are allowed to take photos in the prison. Great place to visit

Really a must-see. Despite being a little ways of the tourist trail, the former French prison is a must see when exploring the colonial legacy in Hanoi and Vietnam as a whole.
It was eye-opening, and quite professionally displayed. A touching memorial does well to balance fact and Communist fiction (this particular museum isn't nearly as propagandist as the others)

Good torture prison. Hey, this is the real deal, the Hanoi Hilton, as it was called. Senator McCain did time here. Too bad the place didn't remain in it's entirety, but it retains the haunting feel of great atrocity. Incidentally, the description tells about tortures by the French, but not by the Vietnamese.

Hoa Lo Prison in Vietnam – Focus on Sufferings. Visiting Hoa Lo Prison in Vietnam nicknamed “Hanoi Hilton” may generate a creepy feeling of sorrow and disgust as it represents the sufferings of Vietnamese revolutionaries. At present the visitors will see only the small southern section of the famous prison complex since most of it was demolished during the 1990s. We entered through the gate on Hoa Lo Street or the “Monster’s Mouth”. Easiest transport to the prison is taxi cab as it is located at the corner of Pho Ha Ba Trung to the south of Hoam Kiem Lake. Prison opens at 8 AM and remains so till 5 PM with one hour lunch break from 11.30AM to 12.30 PM. Entrance fee is about 50 cents on payment of which the visitor gets a colored brochure.
Very one sided. It was interesting seeing all the pictures, but did seem like a lot of propaganda. I don't believe the us soldiers were treated as well as made out.

Worth a visit but go with your eyes open. Interesting and probably worth a visit but it appeared to have a very anti French / American bias - whilst showing that they treated prisioners of war really well. Somehow it did not ring completely true from any perspective.

I was expecting more. There is very little of the old prison left and everything feels cramped as a result. There are a few parts showing how the prison would have looked and a few other rooms with information about the Vietnam war and American prisoners.If you are really interested in seeing the place and have plenty of time it's worth a visit but I feel like a visit to somewhere else would have been a better use of my time in Hanoi.

Suffering. I don't know who suffered more - the Vietnamese under the colonials, or us tourists who have to read the exaggerations and, yes, lies, on the Vietnanglish captions on the exhibits. Be sure to read up on what really happened to American pilots in the "Hanoi Hilton" before going.

French or American, an interesting perspective. Perhaps a place that is not top of everybodies agenda but to gain a perspective as portrayed by the current Vietnamese Gouverment is interesting.Bearing in mind that Vietnam was part of French Indo-China for over a hundred years and that the French were responsible for creating much of the infrastructure, and institutions that still exist today and comparing this to the effects of the American led Vietnam war, the various displays and presentations in this. Building seem to be at odds with other representations in for example Ho Chi Minh City.Having said that, it is an interesting place to visit, the lighting and music certaily make you feel about some of the not so nice things that took place here.There is certainly a big effort to indicate that the American POWs had not too bad a time here!

A Dark and Dim Reminder. This is mainly a museum displaying artifacts of the dark time brought by the French oppressors. You can spend time in the cells and get a glimpse into the suffering that occurred here.

important part of Vietnamese history. I missed this important place in my last visit in March 2012. Interesting place to visit. You see the sufferings of the Vietnamese in the hands of the French colonial rulers. I cant say a visit to this prison is a must to tourist visiting Hanoi but if you have time and if you have not visited any prison it is an interesting place to visit .It is in the center of the city and therefore going there is not a problem.

A good vision into current Vietnam.. Whether you are an American visiting Vietnam with the baggage of the Vietnam War, or not, this attraction gives you a view of the current government and another vision of the "American War". The prison goes into great detail about the maltreatment of Vietnamese prisoners by the French, and then tells of the hotel treatment of American prisoners by the Vietnamese. I suspect the French treated the Vietnamese badly. Perhaps the rest is a bit of a white wash. We had a guide - but it certainly isn't necessary.

Recommend it when you come to Hanoi. Such visits may not like everyone, because they tell of torture and prison conditions. They talk about everything from colonial times to the French. The site itself is interesting to visit a fortress. I noticed that the official line is more focused against the French against the Americans

So moving, we got totally involved in the visit. Though fascinating We found this a very sobering visit. They make it easy to visualise some of what it must have been like during the prison's various eras in a way that isnt contrived and we found parts quite haunting. The walls of the place itself seem to imprint on you as you go through, the dungeons, as my husband put it,' reeked evil'. You can look into the various cells and there are lots of displays and information. There is, as you might expect, a certain spin- 'here are the vietnamese prisoners being tortured by the French' and over here- ' are the American prisoners having a Christmas party!!!'. I don't think that's quite how it happened...but go, it is a real insight.

Very interesting museum and worth a visit.. I visited this museum twice on a recent trip. While this is a somber experience, it helps put more "recent" history regarding the French and American engagements into perspective. The pictures from the Vietnam war were the originals and interesting. Read the signage. Take time to ponder history.

A must-see. We were lucky enough to have a fantastic tour guide, who once worked in the prison interrogating the prisoners. For somnething that you couldn't relate to at all, it brought to life how they were treated. For different people to have control- first the french imprisoning the Vietnamese, then the Vietnamese imprsioning the Americans, this prison has seen war and cruelty.
