Worth a visit. The museum is quite interesting showing what the prison was like for the Vietnamese but I would definitely take the commentary with a pinch of salt as it pretty one sided.
Put this on your visit list!. Interesting perspective and very very well done. Very focused on reminder of struggles of local people.

Interesting. Surely this is a location where many suffered and were ill-treated. American and Vietnamese alike. Quite a bit of propaganda, with a somewhat "glamorized" view of what it must have been like for American's here. But, overall, an interesting experience and certainly one that is significant in Hanoi.

Bone chilling at times..... This is an interesting step back in history. Now only a small portion remains. It is very informational and difficult to see some portions. Interesting to read about the different areas. It is well set up and it was nice it was not overly crowded for a Saturday.
Well Done!. It was hair raising in some parts, but it is real and very educational. we learnt alot about Vietnams History.

A lot of information. Interesting place as it had lots of information about how it was used in the past. Initially used by the french to house Vietcong and then used by the Vietnamese to house American Soldiers. A lot of propaganda, which is a given, make sure to watch the short film on how the Americans were treated. It was a little all over the place, there was an interesting wing up the stairs that discussed women's part in the war which was great. Do not bother getting English guide as the museum is well signed and has all information in English.

much different than I expected. the "Hanoi Hilton" as it was called, actually a very aged French prison converted by the Vietnamese, amazing to see the history, the American artifacts inlcuding Sen McCain's flight suit! Quite an interesting tour--

The other side of the story.. an education - well worth the visit. Gives an entirely different perspective on the Vietnamese war. Prison is now a museum and well preserved with interesting settings and good explanations provided.

Good for a quick visit. This is a good attraction to fill a late afternoon tour. The rooms a quite hot and cramped inside the prison, much like it would have been when it was in use. There is the usual propoganda features in the articles displayed but its interesting to see some of the memorabilia from the later part of its use.

hoa lo prison. a reminder of vietnams colonial past, and recent history, interesting to see john mcains jumpsuit.ask a tuk tuk to take you here from hokiem lake, as the prison was a bit hard to find whist walking through the old quater on foot

Interesting Museum but a bit Disjointed. This was a fascinating museum but the narrative told by the curators seems a bit disjointed and not really compelling. It's worth the visit for a good history of Vietnam, but not worth staying more than 1hr.

If you have nothing better to do. I went to see this prison after hearing and reading about the infamous Hanoi Hilton. Upon our arrival i was dissapointed but not surprised to see a great deal of propaganda in regards to the Vietman War.It only takes about 20min to cover the whole site. If you have something bette to do, do it. Unless your a Prisoner Of War buff.

Looking for 'Hanoi Hilton' - it may not be what you expect. The actual prison does not exist any more and the museum in it's place is mainly dedicated to show the suffering of poor Vietnamese people during French Colonial times. There is however a section demonstrating how well US fighter pilots shot down during the American War, have been treated, incl. John McCains parachute and suit and photos of POWs cooking Xmas dinner. Entrance fee $1. On maps it may just be called Maison Centrale.

Hilariously one sided but still interesting to see. I have become accustomed to the rather one sided accounts of Vietnamese history in attractions around the country. Hoa Lo is no exception to this, where America is referred to as a "den of imperialism" (surely a more suited as a description of Britain in former times) and they talk of "puppet governments". It does make me smile.The prison itself is pretty interesting to walk around- you can walk into some of the cells and there's a giant guillotine on display, amongst other things. Entrance fee was pretty average, at 20,000 dong per person so I'd say it's worth a quick visit. It will take up about 1 and a half hours if you are reading into the detail.

Sobering experience............. Sobering experience but worth the visit. Toured it with three boys [6,10 & 12] who had interest that waned after about 30 minutes. Think the stocks made a lasting impression on them along with the small size of the cells. Very much a tourist entity but worth a visit if time permits. Little bit of the Senator John McCain story is featured.

Worth a visit. This is a great outing...visiting the prison, known also as the Hanoi Hilton really puts Hanoi into context. It really deeply resonated with us...I think it has been very well done. The prison has an eerie atmosphere and you can almost feel the agony of the prisoners. There is a very good selection of items used by US prisoners during the Vietnam War.

Interesting piece of history. Only a small section of the prison remains but it's enough to give you an insight into what life was like for the prisoners. The tour is also is interesting for a Vietnamese perspective of the war. The prison is centrally located and you don't need to allow too much time there.

Interesting history. I found the Hoa Lo Prison a fascinating albeit chilling place to visit. However, I found the obvious contrast between the depicted treatment of prisoners by the French (admittedly, very cruel), and the salubrious "happy happy" conditions given to US prisoners tinged with propaganda.

A sobering look into the past. I was disappointed in the prison. Most of exhibits depict the French colonial period and only a small portion the time of the US-VN War. As expected, there is an obvious anti US/French tilt toward the exhibits, yet there was not a lot of substance. The prison show the inhumanity that was clearly a part of the French occupation, but also of the time that American pilots (including John McCain) were heard. It is worth a sobering view into the past.

Informative tour. Having grown up with the Vietnam War, we found this a very informative tour. It does, however, not just focus on the War years but tells the story of the prison gong back to when it was first opened and also has memorabilia from some of those who were unfortunate enough to have been imprisoned there.

enlightening but biased. very interesting to see the descriptions of the maltreatment of the vietnamese at the hands of the French whilst extolling the virtues of the captors of the Americans. Lots of propaganda but still very thought provoking. Worth the visit.

Historic Site of Suffering. What you see at this historic site is chilling, but what you feel will be impacted by what you bring in your heart on your visit. The prison has a long history of inhumane actvities, and whatever phase you choose to focus upon brings great pain and sadness
Worth a visit. Content is very interesting. take a walk and read the war stories. Prison very well preserved and maintained

Not for the feint hearted but well worth a visit. A powerful reminder of days gone by. Pretty grim but gives a realistic idea of how things were. Interesting how the past is portrayed but you can decipher that quite easily for yourself.

Very interesting!. I was here with my 2 sons ages 7 and 9. It was interesting to see this prison and learn about its Colonial history before the Vietnam war. This museum, as most in Hanoi have a particular political agenda and the message is quite slanted, it's still fascinating to understand these perceptions. It's unclear if local people believe in the political rhetoric communicated at the museum, but this was all part of the experience. I would definitely recommend it.

Worthwhile for Americans. This prison documents fark chapters in the relations between Vietnam, France, and The US. After illustrating the longer involvement of France, it reminds American visitors of the comparatively humane treatment of American POWs in the "Hanoi Hilton."
Good hour spent here. Interesting museum. Was expecting more on the US POW period but actually, a lot of the exhibits focus on the Vietnamese POWs during French colonial times.

Chilling look at a preserved "shop of horrors!". This prison stands as a stark reminder of how inhumanely prisoners were treated, and often died during the darker days in this Nation's French Colonial period, up through its more modern "Hanoi Hilton" period when it was used to hold U.S. military POWs during the Vietnam war. It was built in 1887

A bit biased but...I'm not surprised. Basically, Americans were bad. The French were evil. Uncle Ho was a hero. Worth visiting this historical establishment. Beware of all the touts who were supposed to be local university students. No idea what they were asking for and I was fairly sure they were fishing for victims.

Harrowing. My husband enjoyed this tour but I found it harrowing. To be incarcerated in that place would have been nightmarish. The high walls and tiny cells would have added to the overwhelming despair the prisoners must have experienced.

Museum capturing the struggles of prisoners. A good representation of the struggles of the people during the war. Not as graphically confronting as the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh but offers a good insight into life at the time.

A very quick look at Senator John McCain's old home. I must admit I was a little disappointed. It seems they have knocked down half the prison (the section where the US POW's were kept)This was to make way for a modern high rise. Very sad.You do get to see a portion of the prison and some good history and documentation on that period which is interesting.They do have a section dedicated to John McCain's stay including his air suit etc.If you aren't sure if you have the time to visit, go in and check it out, you'll be in and out in 20 mins.

Soul Searching Experience-worthy visit!. The one place that is worth visiting other than Halong Bay in Hanoi is the Hanoi prison. Many may find this weird but we feel that by visiting the prison and looking at how people were tortured, how resilience the human soul is, makes us aware of the need to keep our earth peaceful. Wars are devastating and the Hanoi prison reminds us of the past. As the human race evolve and modernise, there is a need to learn from our past. The young needs to understand where the current wealth comes from. The young needs to know that with wars, a nation may be destroyed. Without history, we may not have a future. We need to be constantly reminded that we must always long for peace and harmony no matter where we are from. We must learn tolerance of all kinds; political, economic, religious, etc.This Hanoi prison is a good reminder. Worth a visit when in Hanoi!We have good feeling of the vietnamese people of the past; strong, hardworking, smart, etc.We hope the prison will be a reminder for future generations to live and respect one another to survive as ONE PEOPLE!For countries that are still at war or leaders thinking of staging wars...we just hope they can visit the prison and be reminded to love all mankind no matter what colour, breed or mix we are?

good place to see. We can arrived in this place by feet from the Centre and cost some money-but not so more. This is the prison where the american soldiers spend there life during the Vietnam War.
The prison are ok, good route and also good explanation. A little shop at the beginning of the prison.

Haunting and bias. The place itself is haunting. The captions aren't translated into the best English but the images speak volumes.
The videos, however, give a highly biased view of how prisoners were treated in the war between America and Vietnam.

The Hanoi Hilton. This museum is one of the better ones to see in Vietnam. The exhibits are very well done, with the realistic feel of what it must have been like. This is one of the few times that I was not harassed to buy any souvenirs.

Look past the propoganda. This is a "must see" for a trip to Hanoi. Part of the shared VIetnamese-American history. As a U.S. citizen, the propoganda was hard to swallow, and the pictures of smiling American POWs very misleading. In reality, POW survivors recoumted how badly they were treated and how they were forced to pose for propoganda pictures. But this is a Communist country, folks, and you should expect to get a "different" view of history. It comes with the territory. And to walk those corridors and ponder about the people who suffered here is very powerful. Personally, reading how the Communist government regards the war and their role is quite fascinating, not only at this museum, but across Hanoi. Sites commemorating the bravery of the Vietnamese people in the face of American imperialism are all over the place. The patriot in me is offended, but the insight quite enlightening.
Guess you have to go... Its a prison and its a bit depressing, but filled with some interesting facts and stories. Suppose its worth a look if you are in hanoi

Great archive of history. This prison takes you through some of the difficult times the vietnamese people faced from French colonial rule, through to the vietnam war. No longer a functioning prison. It's well worth the visit for the insights it provides.

Propaganda galore. If I'm honest, I'm not entirely sure what I expected but when the guidebook reminds you that previous American prisoners' memories are very different to those reported in the museum, you know to expect a serious amount of propaganda. For those people who believe what they read - the French treated the Vietnamese horrifically, whilst the American POWs had a relatively comfortable stay where they could decorate christmas trees and sing carols around a fireplace that had been drawn on the wall. The photos show those situations, so they happened but there are very few other pictures of the prisoners at any time during their stay. Who knows what is actually true, and I'd imagine that you couldn't put a lot of it in a family museum, but I was shocked by what I read. It was a skewed version of reality with carefully selected photos and no memoirs of POWs. It's worth a visit if you're nearby, but don't take what you read at face value - which I think probably goes for most of Hanoi's museums.
Prison Museum. Very informative, big displays and artifacts from the war. Able to walk up and down death row prison cells, little bit eerie. Massive guillotine on display. Small entry fee.

A quick but interesting diversion. An easy and quick visit that both adults and teenage kids found interesting.Had a great afternoon starting here and then walking the streets to the HCM Museum and other attractions

A great way to learn history. the museum contains wax models and things from the french colony and american war. although this place was quite grim, important history lessons are demonstrated in here. however you should be aware of the propaganda in the American war and medal sections

Biased. It's worth going to but don't expect it to be entirely truthful or factual. The parts about the war against the French are interesting but the so called facts about the "American War" were contradicted from room to room...more entertaining that educational.
It is okay....... Read up on other perspectives of history before you visit Vietnam. There is a lot of propaganda. So yes visit, but have a balanced view with some of your own research.

Very interesting. Totally depressing but easier to look at from a 40-50 year distance. The treatment of the prisoners was atrocious. They have lots of pictures of the American soldiers captured including McCain.
A really fun and interesting place. of all the sights in Hanoi we enjoyed this the best.It was very interesting and informative.modern day prisons could learn a lesson or two!

Interesting, but not one of the city's highlights. The infamous Hanoi Hilton is not really that great.Most of the exhibitions are pictures and recontructions of how the prisioners lived during the french colonial times.Whent we visited a big part of the museum was being renovated so we heard the drilling and hammering in almost every room we went.Compared to other of the many war-related museums in Vietnam this one is far from being a must

Worth a visit. Many pictures and descriptions in English which explain the history of the prison. Made me feel quite sad after visiting the place, but war sites do that to me. We were done touring the place in an hour though.
Small but worth a visit. Of the original prison (where during the American war U.S. war prisoners were kept, is not very much left. But it is well worth a visit.

A must for any visitor. A good place for learning about the French colonial regime, which will come as no surprise if you have seen 'Les Miserables'. There is a very rusty guillotine on display, although more interesting are the rooms on the American GIs who were sent there after being shot down during the Vietnam War.

Grim Place With Important History. Hoa Lo Prison will not be one of the high points of your trip. This is a grim place, but with an important history, and I think that anybody who wants to understand what happened in Vietnam during the French colonial years should make it a point to come here. The French wre brutal, as were most imperialist powers; the Vietnamese resisted heroically. Hoa Lo stands witness to both brutality and resistance.But a visitor needs to be wary of propaganda. When the narrative reaches the 60s and tells the story of American POWs, the propaganda is palpable, which serve as a caution about the way the history of with which we are less familiar is told.

Hanoi Hilton-Something to remember. Easy to visit, not far from the Old Quarters in Hanoi Center. Only parts of the old prison remains but it gives strong impressions of the brutal life in prison during the French colonial times and for American POW's during the American-Vietnamese war. There are a lot of propaganda and the story is one sided but it is a good reminder of the senseless American-Vietnamese war.

Infamous "Hilton Hanoi". Visit this prison to get an overview about how vietnamese see themselves being treated by the foreigners, many propaganda stuffs and a peek at all the cells gave me the goose bumps!
A must see for those who stopover Hanoi...

The Hanoi Hilton - a disturbing place. Just one block of the old prison remains. With mock up models across rooms, its easy to visualize the brutal conditions that would have existed earlier.
The sombre music adds to the atmosphere. Did not feel like taking a single photo here.

Read up first. Great depiction of prison life. Only the gatehouse remains so the place is small but still a must-see. Good information for the most part though it lacks English translations for the copies of French Colonialist correspondence papering many of the walls, which would have been interesting. As is mentioned in other reviews the section describing conditions of the US POW is more of a side-note to the French/Vietnamese history and is entirely propagandised. The experience was great but would have been richer for me if I had done my reading about the place beforehand. There is a polar difference between American and Vietnamese versions of the history concerning the American/Vietnamese war. Knowing the American side before seeing the prison would be a good extra.
Widely known as "Ha Noi Hilton". Seeing depictions of American pilots captured during the Vietnam war was a chilling reminder of a senseless war. A must see nevertheless.

One sided history told by the Vietnamese at the 'Hanoi Hilton'. Most of the information in this prison seems to concentrate on the French colonial era up to 1954, telling how awful the French were and how patriotic and heroic the Vietnamese were. It significantly fails to address how the prison was used from 1954 when it was under Vietnamese control, when there were a number of American POW's held here. There is a small room displaying information on the American POW's held here, but there is too much propaganda on how well the Americans were treated which is laughable.As paying tourists, we find the North Vietnamese rude and inhospitable, I can only imagine how they would have treated the enemy. Its scary to think that this is the history they are taught in schools as it is extremely one sided.

Well worth the time spent. This prison is a place which the French used to keep innocent Vietnamese during the difficult period that Vietnam had gone thru under French rule. This place is well worth a visit firstly because it is right in the middle of the city and as such, you will not need much effort to get there. Secondly, you can also witness how thousands of innocent Vietnamese were routinely imprisoned, tortured, murdered and executed in the most inhuman ways by the French. Most of the Vietnamese imprisoned during the French rule were innocent victims and in this prison, you can see how the French tortured the Vietnamese in the most unthinkable ways. The prisoners were treated worst than any animal. The musuem also has documented records of prisoners being subjected to daily beatings, even the women and children, the old and sick - something which the French were proud to admit during those times and the aim was to create a sense of superiority over the Vietnamese. The heads of the beheaded prisoners were displayed publicly and left to rot under the sun and all these were done to instill fear amongst the Vietnamese. You should visit this place if you are in Hanoi and you can witness how the evil the French were when they illegally occupied Vietnam.

Interesting to see other viewpoints. This infamous Hanoi Hilton was the same prison where Senator McCain was held during his captivity. We visited originally just to check off that we'd seen the place, but it turned out to be better than expected. Although there is clearly a propaganda twist to much of the information portrayed in the museum, it was still interesting to see the prison from a different viewpoint. The displays were mostly above average and were visually engaging. We took one of the tricycle bike taxi's to and from this location, which was well worth it. The slower ride and the view from the front of the trike made the ride to and from equally as entertaining (although never forget to negotiate the price BEFORE you get in the trike). All in all, it was an interesting museum. There is also a very nice restaurant only a few blocks away that serves from a menu but has a cafeteria style offering of all sorts of Vietnamese food. One of the museum staff gave us directions and it was great advice (although I apologize for forgetting the name).

Enlightening. Very enlightening and insightful. Took two young sons and they were very interested in the place - kept them quiet which was worth the entry fee alone. We spent arund 90 minutes looking arund and that was about right for us. Definitely worth a visit.
Hanoi Old Prison. Not much of the old prison left but gave there is gives you an insight into what a terrible life they had to endure in prison.
Definitely worth a visit. I'm not a big museum fan but this was really interesting. It was clean, well-marked, with lots of English information. I would highly recommend a visit here!

Average and touristy. Nothing much to talk about.. Gives a good insight to the battles fought by the patriots of Vietnam. Much better than the single pillar pagoda and HCM Mausoleum .. Which is close by...

Worth a look especially if from USA. Born in this era so this was a must see for this American. several things to see. Clean and well run. Small children ok. Not crowded. 45 min to go through and I read everything.

Victors Interpretation. Although most of the old prison is gone, the most interesting parts remain and despite recent Vietnamese history, much of it deals with Vietnamese opposition to colonial French rule. The interpretation is somewhat biased as might be expected but this also makes the visitor think about cultural bias in our own museums and our own interpretation of the Vietnam War in particular. There is a small but interesting section on US pilots imprisoned there. The displays make it look like a holiday camp which is unlikely to be the complete truth.
Worth A Visit. Went with our two young kids, it was sort of an 'educational' tour about war - the weapons used, how prisoners were treated, how some prisoners escaped and the misery.
Hanoi Hell. Spent half hour checking out the living conditions of prisoners in those days. Good reminder of what war can do to both victims and perpetrators.
Sad Place to Visit. Very historical with some very sad display of prisoners struggling and being tortured in the prison.
Hanoi Hilton. Hanoikids took us here and explained so much, that would have been missed on if we went here without a guide.

Good to understand more about the political history. To start off, I must say that I am not a big fan of prison or war museum. It was good to read about the political side of the history. The prison is not too big and can be done within 30 mins, combine with other museums, such as the History Museum.

adequate short attraction. There are a few interesting objects on exhibited. But not much information available in English and not very well elaborated, so you have to use a lot of imagination, since you'll encountered a lot of empty cells and day - to - day objects that you can't really understand their significance.

Must See. I left feeling very sad, but it was so interesting. Parts of it were really creepy like the cells for the prisoners waiting to be put to death. The creepy music didn't help either, but I guess it helped set the mood.
Ok but very biased. The prison was ok, we went round it in an hour. The whole thing is a bit biased which we expected (it was almost funnily so). Worth a visit but don't expect too much.

Very interesting to see things from another perspective. One of the things that makes the Hanoi museums so interesting is the (unsurprising) way in which they are choosing to present history. The prison is set up to show the living conditions of the Vietnamese prisoners under French rule, followed by an exhibition on its use during the "American" war. They contrast the poor conditions under the French with the (allegedly) "comfortable" conditions of the Americans. Am planning on reading some personal accounts now, but whatever your prejudices on the war this is a fascinating place to spend a couple of hours.

Important piece of the story. The prison focuses on the 2 primary phases of its use - French imprisoning Vietnamese during colonial times, and the imprisonment of US soldiers during Vietnam war. While some reviews indicate this is 'propoganda', I felt like it was an important piece of the war story from their perspective. The story is told as much through the relics on display, and there are a couple of vidoes on continuous loop that were very educational. There's an outdoor area for rememberence and the figures depicted on the wall in relief fashion were so haunting, I hard a hard time leaving and the images have stayed with me. There was a special exhibit upstairs that included items on loan from the Women's Museum that focused on female prisoners and heroes which I found really moving.

Eye-opening. This prison museum enables you to step into history through particularly biased eyes. You see a side of history you usually don't as a westerner, illustrated through some life-like exhibitions. Leaves a lasting impression.

Interesting, for more than reasons than usual. This prison is only a fragment of what it used to be, most of it having been cleared for large residential in its place.It is a good view of what the prison could have been like. Mannequins and displays are excellent to help visualise.A lot of the prison is dedicated to treatment of the local communists during the French occupation. As well as this there is a small section to do with American pilots shot down during the Vietnamese civil war (yes, the war started before american involvement, and ended years after America left, and no I am not American)What I honestly found the most interesting, is the bias involved in the displays. For the French occupation sections there is constant mention of the imprisonment of 'communist patriots' and details about how many died in captivity, but there is no mention of anyone else who could have been imprisoned for other reasons.And for the American section there is a long list of American pilots that had been released, but no mention of the ones who died. There is also a stark contrast with the uniform worn by the 'Americans imperialists', which looks like it was freshly ironed, in comparison to the uniforms worn by 'communist patriots' which looks like it was dragged across a dirty floor before being displayed.And while there is mention of harsh treatment of the Vietnamese at the hands of the French, there is no mention of the torture suffered by the Americans (to this day the Vietnamese government denies there was torture performed there)It was a very interesting experience, and the idea of what could have happened there through out the prisons life is appalling. But keep in mind that it is a government sponsored exhibit and the truth written down is not necessarily entirely accurate.

Interesting and emotionally powerful. This was historically informative and made a strong emotional impact. It included a memorial for those lost; which in travels through this part of the world is not uncommon. It was very interesting seeing material on the lives of US prisoners of war as well as locals interred at the prison - the latter apparently had a far harder time of it.

aka Hanoi Hilton. Graphically shows the harsh treatment the Vietnamese independence people suffered under the French - a real guillotine still stands. This stands in contrast to treatment of US pilots held there (as presented)

Sobering experience. When travelling to Hanoi this is probably the first landmark that springs to mind to Westerners.Very little is left of the original prison, only the main entrance and a few other buildings.The main theme of the prison is about the deplorable conditions in which the French kept and treated their political prisoners, but at the same time fails to mention that the same was done to POW's during the Vietnam conflict.Seeing the conditions, I can only imagine how horrible it must have been to spend years in captivity here. I gained a lot of respect for those who made it through without going completely insane and felt sad for those who did not.

Worthwhile. Sobering exhibit on the prison and the brutal conditions many Vietnamese activists faced - mostly during the French colonization years. Mannequins make the displays more graphic and present.
Interesting. Had a nice time at this museum. A lot of fun and learned more about Hanoi and Vietnam. We spent 1 hour at this museum

A "must" on your list of things to see in Hanoi.. The historical prison is a must see for all in Hanoi. It is very busy with tourists each day. It will take you back in time to the origins of the time of French Indo-China and the atrocities that occured against the Vietnamese by the French. Well presented. There is also a section dedicated to the imprisonment of Americans when this was called by them as the "Hanoi Hilton".

worth a visit. Only 50pence to get into so definitely worth a trip.The propaganda of how 'accommodating' the Vietnamese were to the American pilot prisoners is interesting to see.Easy to navigate and walk to from Old Quarter.

worthwhile. we enjoyed our trip to hoa lo prison and would definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to visit sites of interest in hanoi. for just US$1, its a worthwhile experience for anyone who wishes to spend a quality 1.5-2hrs of their time. very educational and entertaining although the info is a bit biased towards the french colonialist. one negative side to it was that during our trip there, sections of the prison was undergoing renovation so we didnt get to explore the full prison premise.

Good place to learn about history. Inside the complex shows photos and mannequins of how the Vietnamese soldiers were tortured. Also showed the inhumane living conditions and solitary cells.Good place if you know a bit about Viet history.

Good place to know about Viet History. We went to Hoa Lo prison with our Hanoikids guide. It was a good place to know about Viet history as Vietnam had been in war quite a few times previously. Only part of the prison remains. However, it is still worthwhile to see. There is a VND 20000 entrance fee. There are English signboards around. Thus, without a guide, you will also be able to know about the prison and the history. There are scenario rooms around to show how the prisoners was treated.At the end of the walk, it is kinda propaganda on how the Americans are being well treated. Nevertheless, it is a good place to visit and know about the history of Vietnam.

Great facility maintenance, a lot of propaganda. I'm quite amazed to see that this place is well maintained with a lot of guidance and well designed display (which is not common in many places in VN)! Yes, as many said, only a part of the original prison is there, but it is worthwhile to see what's remaining. For VND 20,000, I'm quite happy to see this place with this level of maintenance. I could imagine how hard it was to spend time in this prison, especially during winter - it was very cold when I was there!!Again, as some reviewers mentioned, there are a lot of propaganda, and the things are not presented objectively or some made-ups included, but come on, you know you are in Vietnam -- all museums and places, especially when it comes to past wars, are highly biased towards the current regime. You need to know this and do the discount by yourself, but this place still worth a visit.

Good place to learn about history. I thought it was a good place to learn about the treatment of Vietnamese people by the French. The scenario rooms help you visualize the treatment and conditions of the victims. Not for the faint of heart, but also interesting to see how different countries treat their prisoners.

this is a pass. most of the prison is gone. that which is left and been sanitized to falsely shown treatment of the airman, overly critical of the french which is out of context with the times, or panders to american tourists

A piece of history. An interesting insight into a couple of different periods of Vietnamese history. It's a shame that there's not that much of the prison to see anymore, but what's left will give you enough of an idea of what prisoners had to endure. Obviously the information presented, particularly around the American POWs, is one side of the story but it's still a worthwhile place to visit.

How could they?. Worth a visit but tales are pretty horrific. However, if you are into the history of the place then it is a must. Nothing scary that would upset any children but the stories are horrific.
Worth a look. Shock value to the max. you actually see how the prisoners were housed and what they had to endure. It gives you a whole new perspective on prisons when you see this.
Truly haunting. My family and I were truly haunted by this place. It was depressing to think about what the prisoners went through. Death hangs in the air, and it is pretty creepy.

Spooky. Hoa Lo Prison, a very informative and interesting place to spend a couple of hours! It gives you an insight to how prison life was back then especially for the POW's few things are a bit gruesome but it just makes it all more real.

Very surreal. A great experience, so much history and no holes barred. This was very well orchestrated and told a very sad story about the struggle to remain independent. I would recomend this, it had a very good educational experience attached!!!

A number one must see.. This was located almost next to the Melia Hotel where we stayed. It is now a museum and about two thirds of it has been sold. It is worth 2 to 3 hours of your time. Every room has a story behing it. John McCains flight suit is displayed there along with many photos of the prisoners, This is a must see sight.

Depressing; propaganda. How it was told by our guide: See how well the American prisoners were treated by the North Vietnamese. To hear our guide tell it, American soldiers should have been standing in line to get in here.
Worth a visit.. This was definitely worth the visit. Get an instant insight in to the history of Hanoi and the French invasion. Very Interesting.

Often on the tourist itinerary but think twice. The Hoa Lo Prison is a grim reminder of how human beings can treat each other. There are crowded cells, cramped conditions and elements of torture. This exhibition is not to everyone's taste and some will find it disturbing. But if you want to see the realities of war and control then go and see. The prison is in the middle of the city so you can easily find it and easily walk out if you find it all too disturbing.

Hanoi Hilton. This was one of the places I wanted to go as a few of my friends were "guest" at this place. The visit sequence is well organized and it presents the origins of the prison and the horrible things that the French did while they were the owners. Then it shows that the prison was used to housed US personnel during the war. As expected the pictures show how well the US prisoners were treated, specially CMDR McCain. They still have his flight suit, helmet, boots, life vest and even the parachute. It was a grand propaganda tour, but if in Hanoi it is a must. Now it is in my "been there, done that" list.
If you are interested in American war. Interesting place with massive propaganda. It is not only about American war but also about Vietnam independence struggle .
A feeling of the Vietnam war and more... It´s well worth a visit. You´ll get a feeling of the priosoners suffered in the prioson and get a feeling of the Vietnam war.
Very poignant!. A well done homage to the buildings history. Very reasonable only 20k dong. They are renovating the area but it is not intrusive it's simply upkeep.

American tourist must see. While a good portion of this original historic prison has been destroyed and replaced by a high rise condominiums, the remaining museum gives a small hint of what its historical significance and where American POWs lived for years. A fair amount of propaganda is included in the displays, but nonetheless a very worthwhile experience to walk the hallways, cellblocks and exterior prison areas

Infamous "Hanoi Hilton". This was a must visit for us being Americans who had heard so much about the treatment of US soldiers at the "Hanoi Hilton". The tour is small and doesn't take much time. Like most prisons, the cells and layout depicted grim conditions that the prisoners endured. The photograph exhibit depicted happy healthy US soldiers making it appear as if they were merely "hanging out" until the war was over instead of being tortured as we've come to learn was the case here. Even a smiling photograph of John McCain leads you to believe that his time here was equivalent to being in a country club. I doubt the shots of US soldiers playing basketball, celebrating Christmas and dining together was the norm. Overall though, still worth seeing.

Good Tour. It's a good tour if you like photographs and reading. Probably take you about an hour to hour and half to walk the whole area. I think if you are from the US, you'll appreciate touring; even though it's obvious the emphasis on the good treatment the American prisoners received is probably not what they'd confirm, but you also get the polar opposite view of the treatment of the Vietnamese who suffered imprisonment from the French. It's great history.

Interesting hour or two. This looked obvious on our map but we ended up walking around the block the wrong way until we found it as sign posting is non existent! It was interesting to see the prison, we got around in about an hour as it wasn't very busy. Worth a visit and very cheap entrance fee.

Worth The Visit. Only a small portion of the prison is accessible for tourists, and takes around an hour to read the articles, and look at pictures, artifacts etc. Worth the visit for the small entrance fee. Just beware, there are a few stairs to navigate and may not be convenient for some people.

Moving. You have to ignore some of the anti French and American propaganda but the museum set up and photographs portray very well the awful circumstances of prisoners throughout the last hundred years or so.

Good for Military History. We particularly wanted to visit this place because my husband is a military war buff and very knowledgable about the Viet or American war. He really enjoyed it and the stuff about the american pilots was very interesting although of course very biased. It was also interesting to see info around the fight by Viet people for independence from the French.
an interesting hour visit. this is a short excursion, only takes about an hour to read everything and wander around, very interesting but obviously a little harrowing.

A piece of history you shouldn't miss!. It's definitely a heart wrenching experience but nonetheless part of our history and one we should all remember . We also must remember that it's one side of the story.

Depressing, but historical. I wanted to visit this prison because of it's historical significance. This prison, also known as the "Hanoi Hilton" housed John McCain for over 4 years. Much of the tour was dedicated to past political prisoners and witness their suffering was quite depressing. Nevertheless, for the history buff, it's worth a look. For the squeamish, I say skip it.

The "Hanoi Hilton" has lost none of it's historical impact. This, for me, an air warfare history buff is the best museum in Vietnam.Prison for downed US pilots (including Senator John McCain, whose flight suit is exhibited) it documents their daily lives while they spent 6 years here. A chilling reminder of the ruthlessness of French colonial power remains in the form of a guillotine - with a large part of the exhibit being devoted to political prisoners of said regime

Good to see.... This was a great little find that I made by accident. It was a little confusing to the purpose of the prison but Google can help with that. French, America and Vietnam history all here and well presented.

interesting yet grim. we spent an hour or so at this place as part of a Hanoi tour. The prison itself is much smaller than it was originally but it still portrays how grim life was for the inmates. There are some interesting stories accompanying the cells and exhibits (including the original guillotine) although I have strong doubts that the captured US airmen were treated as well as was portrayed here.Definately worth a visit though.

Worth the trip out of the centre. Maison centrale aka Hoa Lo Prison is such an expeience to really feel ho things would have been during the conflict for the prisoners. Some harrowing sights and stories and even the guillotine is still in place outsideof 'death row'. Quite away from the main attractions in The Old Quarter but well worth the walk or cheap taxi ride ($2 pp)
Interesting. Very well presented museum but I suggest some background reading before you come rather than relying on what is presented to you when you get there.

Short prison visit. This was a bit disappointing. We visited and found that it was only a very small portion of the prison that remains so very hard to get a full idea of what it was like. It was well presented. Short visit.

Depressing, impressive. Obviously not the most upbeat place to go, but definitely worthwhile to stop by. Interesting insight into a small part of Vietnamese historyI managed to get ripped of by people 'collecting money for the Vietnamese Red Cross', but I presume most people are less gullible then I am. Worth watching out for scams nearby though
Interesting prison.. Well worth a visit. Set aside a couple of hours and slowly peruse this grim place. some interesting artifacts.
Fascinating. A must see in Hanoi - you really get a feel for what the conditions were like and the sad history of Vietnam, its wars and this prison. It is well laid out and very informative.

A place to vsit to remind of the need for kindness. It's a gruesome place with clear examples of how cruel the human race can be and some propaganda. Worth visiting to remind you why we need to respect each other. In my view not suitable for children or those with a vivid imagination prone to nightmares.

A different perspective. This isn’t a large prison tour, much of the building has been tore down, or turned into some offices. There is enough of the old prison left to see the living conditions though. There are several areas with photos and artifacts of how the prison was used to detain political prisoners (French/Vietnam war). I walked through this reading every sign and listening to some stories, in about 45 minutes. There are two rooms dedicated to the American pilots prisoned here and how well they were treated – although it contrasts sharply with the accounts that Senator McCain presented, or other prisoners have presented in books. Following the same theme as the “American War Crimes museum” in Ho Chi Minh.All in all, if you are interested in the “Hanoi Hilton” it’s a must see, and well worth the minimal charge (20,000VND) to get in.
Not quite the Hilton. Had always wanted to see the "Hanoi Hilton" Great learning experience and really gave a wonderful insight into what happened
Sobering. This is not a happy place and it is not for the faint of heart to see some of the exhibits. But, it is interesting and I would not steer you away from it.
Great place to visit. A great place to learn Hanoi's history and the bravery of Hanoi's man and woman that sacrifice for what they believe is good for the country.

Interesting visit. Smaller than I thought, but I believe a good portion has been demolished. Interesting, but grim history. The guillotine accompanied by photos of decapitated prisoners at the side is a bit macabre. Difficult to sort propaganda from reality, contrasting horrific stories of French torturers and US bombings, with photos of smiling American POWs. Looking at the surroundings, I'm sure this was not a nice place for any prisoner.

Gives you perspective. The brutality of colonial prisons is well depicted. Being in the actual building gives you a clear picture of what it might have been like. Photos, graphic displays, etc. of Vietnamese prisoners and Americans.
Interesting insight. Worth the small admission fee, though if you have visited many other war museums etc. in Vietnam none of it is likely to be new to you.
reminder of what should not happen again. A place to go and remember what was done to Vietnamese people and how they struggled to be free.Very hard to see some of the cells and how prisoners lived.
A taste of prison life. Authentic and gritty feel for what he prison was like.... Plenty of propaganda ... But well worth a visit

One time visit. The exhibition at the prison is well planned and interesting. At some point however, it is a bit obvious that a fair portion of it is propaganda. For us even watching the propaganda unravel was interesting, and ironical. If you can take it with a pinch of salt, it is worth a one time visit. I really liked the sculptures on the boundary wall inside the museum.

Well worth a visit. We spent 4 days in Hanoi and visited this place as we'd run out of things to do. It was well worth a visit, very photogenic, and very informative. BEWARE the taxis outside the gate as you leave, their meters run at 5 times the rate of the mainstream taxis. A trip from the prison to Old Quarter would normally cost 30,00 Dong but the meter showed 290,000 Dong. I told the driver it wasn't going to happen and gave him the right amount. He knew he was in the wrong so didn't argue much, just said "that's my company charge". He wouldn't take the money so I left it on his front seat and got out. This was our only bad experience with taxis in Hanoi.
Do not believe all you see!. The propoganda was an issue, circumstances were portrayed very differently to those imprisoned by the French to those imprsoned by the Vietnamese.

Sad history. A real eye opener with an unguided look around the old prison. Each of the rooms you walk through has pictures and accounts of life as it was, with dummies in specific positions of daily life and torture. It only cost Aus$1 entry and took about 45mins at your own leisure. About 10mins walk from our hotel near cathedral.

Hanoi Hilton. The prison is worth visiting. It mainly focuses on the time the French controlled the prison (1880's until 1954) an how poorly Vietnamese political prisoners were treated. Even displaying the guillotine they used. The area covering the "American War" continues the war time propaganda about how well the American flyers were treated. What's left of the prison definitely makes an impression and deserves an hour or so.

Hanoi Hilton!. Known locally as the "Hanoi Hilton", the ex-prison is an interesting place to visit. The prison used to house patriots and revolutionary fighters in awful conditions, before it became a place of detention for criminal offenders and American pilots whose planes had been shot down over Vietnam. You can see the old cells, complete with leg irons, the guillotine and many exhibits showing what the prisoners wore and ate, etc. There is also a memorial garden at the rear of the prison. Two thirds of the prison were demolished in 1993, so you are only seeing the SE corner of the original site.

Easy to find. For around 20,000 Dong this is well worth a visit, it gives a real insight into the living conditions & disciplinary actions that were taken out on the inmates. Real size dummies add to the authenticity.

Worth a visit!. Thought it was very good as it gave a brief but comprehensive overview.Small prison, with graphic details.....One hour is plenty.Seems the French didn't treat the prisoners in the same fashion as the Vietnamese treated the Americans.Take a walk from the Old Centre, it's not far and an interesting walk with other landmarks to visit in the area.Failing that take a taxi for about $4

Great insight into life in prison. Whilst a bit depressing this is an interesting historical landmark. The photo exhibits a very good; surprisingly most of the photos of the US prisoners of war show them smiling and playing sport etc.
Hanoi Hilton prison. Not a lot to it and not really into this type of history. Goes to show the French treated their prisoners in an horrendous way and have nothing to be proud of.

Worth a visit to Hanoi Hilton. This was nicknamed Hanoi Hilton during the 1960's as US pilots were held there. The prison goes back many years and like all place of this nature it has an interesting past. The story is told from the French colonial times till the 1970's. Vietnam does not yet have the subtleties of expression in English and the story told seems to be from one side only with the signage at times very blunt in the descriptions. The price of entry was 20,000 dong (67p).
Informative. This is a great place to visit and to get a quick idea of what the Vietnamese people have had to endure over many years.
Fascinating and Historically Important. If you are interested in the French colonizing of Vietnam or the American/Vietnamese war this is a must stop.

Grim Hanoi Hilton. Very grim but interesting visit. It is interesting to see the Vietnamese take on the American War as they call it and the privations which the prisoners were subjected to including one John McCain later a presidential candidate! Built during the French occupation and their influences are everywhere including a Guillotine which was actually used to execute prisoners. This and the terrible conditions in which prisoners were kept makes this a sobering place to visit but is worth it
Interesting insight. Displays from when vietnamese were detained there by the french to when it was used for american army pilots (including John McCain).

Bit Painful. This is the place to see how the political prisoners were treated. You get a different view then what you might have heard in USA. The torture chamber is scary. Lots of picture. Show bit of info on John McCain.

Reminder of A Very Discomforting Past. Our visit to Hoa Lo generated mixed feelings in us.Although the whole place is well preservedand maintained to depict what it had been and the cruelty of humankind, one to another, there are probably a lot of untold stories too. It was not a pleasant walk-around for us although we know that in war and major conflicts, inhuman atrocities are resorted to, even in this presentage. Our view is that Hoa Lo serves as a sad and grim reminder of what courageous and dedicated men and women were prepared to endure and sacrifice, and also the extremes towhich some of those in power and control can enforce. Although photo-taking was allowed, we did not feel inclined to do so.

Interesting experience-overtly propagandistic. Yes, this is an interesting experience. About half of the exhibits are devoted to the period when this was a g sinFrench colonial prison, and describes how Vietnamese political prisoners were poorly treated, which is no doubt true. The other half is devoted to the period when American pilots were interned here, and describes how well. And humanely they were, treated which is a complete pack of lies. They show photos,of American prisoners playing volleyball, having singalongs, etc., which were demonstrations done for the rare Red Cross visits. Still, if you can stomach the lies and propaganda, it is still,an interesting place to go. By the way, I should say that I am an American, but was completely against the Vietnam War, so I am not offended by an anti-American slant to that war, but this prison bias is over the top, and simply inaccurate.

Should see it. It does show history of the Vietnamese people and their treatment while imprisoned there. It does not accurately show, as you might guess, the whole picture of the treatment of US POWs. There are photos and video that you might not see and allegedly John McCain's flight suit. It is difficult and bleak to go through and will you upset. It is not obvious to find . It is about 5 blocks down from the other Hanoi Hilton by the Opera.

Excellant and well organised self-tour. This is a must see for all travelors to Hanoi. An interesting and heart-wrenching place where we learn of the many hardships faced by the Vietnamese during the war, as well as a section for American POWs. The prison is easy to navigate, and the descriptions, and history are written in English so tourists can understand.

Interesting Vietnam propaganda. What a different story compared to what you taught at school :) pictures of the Vietnamese pampering US POW's while they're bombing innocent Vietnamese women n children with B52's. The truth was probably slightly different, but that just makes it all the more interesting
Sad but necessary to see. The historical significance was outstanding. As far as museums go, it was one of the best. The memorial at the end was very moving.
Hanoi Hilton. Excellent side visit. A stark reminder of the hard times endured by the Viet Nam, and later some POW of the infamous 10 year war
Grim but interesting. Sad part of history but thought provoking - worth a visit. John McCain was a prisoner there. Lots of interesting photos.

Interesting and informative. We visited the Prison as part of a half day tour and it was a little macabre - not unlike the Coconut Prison on Phu Quoc Island. Very life like images of prisoners. It is definitely worth adding to a tour of the city.

sobering and informative. The posted literature was a bit slanted in favor of the Vietnamese forces which took over this prison in the 1950s, but not overtly; overall it contributed to my education about Vietnam's colonial and post-colonial history.

Interesting place. Hanoi has many different museums to visit and I think this was one of our favourites, it reveals a lot of history of the Vietnamese people in the last century, and is a wonderful testament to the men and women who fought for their freedom. It has letters, pictures, mock set-ups of the prison in different time periods. Very interesting -worth a visit, and very cheap to get in I thought.
Hao Lo Prison. It was very interesting and kind of scary alot of sad history as they all do but it was good! the models make it more understandable of the living conditions.
Hoa Lo Prision. I likes seeing how the French held prisoners and then later how John McCain and other pilots were held there. I disliked the movie characterizing us as American Imperialists.

Remembering the war. I was emotional when I visited the prison. Even though I dont know much about the history, seeing the numerous pictures and videos stirred up my feelings and compassion for the suffering of the people.

Eye opening. This again is a must when visiting Hanoi. The history of the prison is fascinating, especially if you were around when the Vietnam War was happening. Extraordinary to see the conditions under which South Vietnamese and allied prisoners experienced.

Get a flavour of how grim it was. Seeing the cells and getting an impression of how dark and oppressive it must have been is quite chilling. There also some bizarre photographs of smiling American POWs seemingly having a good time drinking beer and putting up their Christmas tree but I suspect life was rather different most of the time.

Even Women Must Fight.. Nothing beats vietnam's Sprit when it comes to perserverance, determination and fighting for themselves. This place shares a thousands stories of vietnamese lives during war, how they fight and protect their home. This place shares vietnam's history. Read up on Vietnam history before you go, you'll know better. ( sadly i didnt, read up after i was back)
Grim but facinating. Reveals Vietnam history with US/Vietnam war as just small part. Paltry entrance fee makes visit a bargain.

Glad I wasn't there!. Enjoyed the exhibit and it was interesting to see how it was/is being restored. Glad that it wasn't completely knocked down. Good exhibits and pictures, many in English, many in French. Would recommend this on a visit to Hanoi.

Professionally presented Historic Site. Really enjoyed (if that's the right word) wondering around the exhibitions. Didn't expect it to be open on the Monday afternoon when we popped by and were really surprised and impressed by the better standard than normally to be expected in Viet Nam

The great escape of Hanoi. I was disappointed with most of the other tourist sites in Hanoi, but this one was by far the most interesting and the one with the best atmosphere. Well worth the money, a great site for people interested in Wars.
Good perspective on prisons in Vietnam. It's really worth a visit if you are interested of the wars in Vietnam. Lot about female prisoners and political activists.

It is not bad for half an hour activity. We went to this prison museum today it was a fine way to kill some time but did not really engage me. There was some interesting exhibits but a let down for those that wanted to be shocked with gore and hear stories of torture and woe.... Why else would you go to the prison museum???The exhibits could have been updated and more detail given to the lives of prisoners. The whole place was filled with a "creepy" sound track that I think is a little corny. Some of the letters and original documents about prison life were not translated into English.

Not at all that exciting!. Given that this is one of the highlights of Hanoi it is not all that exciting. Looking around it is extremely interesting if you can look past all the communist propoganda but don't expect to spend longer than an hour here as it is relatively small and not a lot of information is provided. Worth a visit if in Hanoi but not great.

Only if you've done everything else. Being in vietnam made us realise that we knew nothing about the war. We thought going to the prison would help us figure it out but it only confused us more. The information at the prison assumes you already know a lot about the war and even then it gives you a very one sided, propagated view. I did think it was cool however, that it does show how people from around the world, including the french and the americans helped the vietnamese after the war.
Worth A Look. As other travellers have said (and it's obvious) take the American prisoner part with a grain of salt but overall a worthwhile place to visit.

The old prison. It was a shock to go through this museum where the French tortured Vietnamese revolutionaries during their struggle for independence. More lately, in the 1960s and 1970s, it was used to house American pilot POWs when they were shot down during the Vietnam/American War. Now it's just a museum.
Hoa Lo Prison Exprience. Have always been a fan of old Prisons/Gaols, and visited this one on my birthday in Ha Noi. Very educational, well preserved and interesting.

A moving experience.... A well done museum that dates back to the mid-1850's under the French and ends after the US/Vietnam war. A moving experience in displays and exhibits even if the US war exhibits are decidedly and obviously slanted with their government's point of view.

More to the history of the place than I thought. History of the prison is a lot longer than I knew about (my ignorance) so learned a lot about the history of Vietnamese struggles over the years. First the French, then briefly the Japanese and then the Americans. A must see location for me on my recent trip to Vietnam.

Interessting but to much propaganda. Its okay to see, but forget all the " americans were so happy here " comunist propaganda [--] here. It was war and there was nobody happy in this time in the prison. As I know some of the prisoners arms were broken often. So just dont believe everything there.

Hoa Lo prison: the Hanoi "Hilton". Interesting glimpse into early 20th century prison and life for the prisoners. A biased view of treatment of US Airmen I think. It is an interesting link to past times.
Educational Visit. Visitor Service Fees is just 20,000VND. No.1 Hoa Lo Str. Hoan Kiem Dist. Ha NoiFull of story and historic place.

Brutal Reality. Prisons are not for liking - they are a sober reminder of a world gone mad. The brutal cruelty used by the French against the Vietnamese in the 1800 makes your stomach churn. Not for the feint hearted this attraction

Horrible histories Vietnam style!. A very atmospheric place telling a harrowing tale of imprisonment and torture by the French (including guillotine and pictures of its effect), though a slightly biased view on the imprisonment of the American prisoners (this was the infamous Hanoi Hotel) who apparently had a bit of a holiday here! This place is a must for anyone who visits Hanoi.
Morbidly Interesting. From the late 1800's to war time this place can tell somestories; I'm not sure that the USA POW's were treated like hotel guests though?

A confronting but educational visit. Yep! The winners write the history! and certainly the whole history of modern Vietnam as presented here is slanted (and why wouldn't it be?). That said, I found the whole experience to be interesting, sometimes educational, and often confronting. I am glad we took the advice of the young lady on reception in our hotel and made the effort to visit.

A nice way to brush up your memories of the bygone years of Vietnam. This place won't take much of your time if you wish to get to know some history. One can see how the political prisoners were treated during the french imperialistic days as well get a glimpse of the vietnam war through a video presentation. It is walking distance from the Hoan Kiem Lake and old quarter if you follow a good map
Worth a visit. Very eerie place - if you are a history junkie you will especially find this very interesting. There are lots of real life models set up to see what it looked like back then.

Good!. It tells you part of Vietnam War History, if you have time, you should go, however if you have been in Ho Chi Minh before, you will find museums and others historic places here not as interesting as similar ones in the old Saigon.

I wouldn't bother. A fully renovated prison doesn't give you much. All nicely painted and with some photos on walls. There is a section which has some paraphernalia of the American war, which might be a little glossed over, indicating how well the American prisoners were treated. There are a few cells with mannequins which give a brief idea of what life might have been like, but I think the highlight is the facade at the front before you enter.

So..so. I've visited many prisons in different places and found this to be quite average really. Vietnam has a very interesting and colourful history, but I felt the prison showed only what they wanted the visitors to see. Still they had some interesting info

Interesting piece of history here. Spend an hour here.There are not many places left in the world where you can watch communist propaganda videos and the pictures and displays of the cells are quite scary.
Interesting place. Good to see some of the history of the hardship that the vietnamese faced. Also some of the war propaganda
Interesting but slightly disturbing. Worth a visit because we should all be aware of what humanity is prepared to do to one another in periods of hostility.

Imperialist prison. So Vietnam had many countries trying to rule it and its people. Well France built the prison and the guilotine while USA pilots were imprisoned during the war. It is amazing the Vietnamese won through and became there own country. An amazing people.

Sobering. A really interesting look at Viet Nam's national struggles over the last 100 years. This place was built by the French to house Viet Nam's political prisoners and much of the revolutionary zeal of people such as Ho Chi Minh was borne of being incarcerated here under inhumane conditions. Later it was used to house downed U.S. airmen during the Viet Nam War (or the American War as it is called in Viet Nam)

Worth a couple of hours. This does give some insight into the Fench and American wars as the prison was first used by the Fench in the colonial days and then by the Vietnames during the wr with america. There are some interesting displays some featuring former air force pilot and presidential candidate John McCain who was held there after being shot down during the American war with Vietnam. There does seem to be a bit of bias within the interpretation of how Vietnamese prisoners were treated by the French (badly) and how Americans were treated by the Vietnamese (5 star) but it is worth a look.

Interesting facts but messy museum. The fact that this huge prison was mostly demolished to build a huge shopping centre is to my opinion killing a bit the feeling of being in a special place. They could have presented better the museum. Well biased too, you see starving statues while all pictures show well fed people.

Worth a Visit. A very educational tour and worth a visit. Go there early to avoid the crowds and will be good if u can hve a local to go with u but it is ok even if you do not hve a local. The displays speaks all for itself.

A dark, sad place - but historically very intersting.. Most of Hoa Lo Prison was torn down to make space for apartments in the 1990's - but what is left is one section that is now a museum. This is a very dark and disturbing place - of course - but very sobering. Was built by the French to detain Vietnamese political prisoners during the revolution - and the exhibits accurately capture the harrowing details. One can not visit without feeling the weight of man's inhumanity to man.

Valuable insight. These buildings give a valuable insight into the lives of North Vietnamese over the centuries and more latterly to the US servicemen who were interned there. The prison fits neatly as a learning experience in trying to understand the pressures and lives of people during the American/Vietnam War.

Ineffective propaganda. The horrible French kept the Vietnamese in appaling conditions and tortured them. But the kind Vietamese kept the Amercians in the same place, but in comfort. Even the staff seem not to beleive it.
Worth a visit. This is where John Mcain was held - the Hanoi hilton which now is right beside an office building. One of the few places worth visiting.

Just OK.. There is not too much remaining from the original prison.
A little bit too much polytics involved to my taste.
They show the French and American "devils", but if you go there you know what to expect, don´t forget this place was called "Hanoi Hilton" by the American pilots during the war.
You can skip this visit, no regrets.

Fascinating Insight. Great visit to make for an hour or so - fascinating to consider the contrast between the 2 principle uses of the prison. Piqued my interest in finding out more about John McCain's experience there.

Moving. Quite a sad place to visit but one of those sad places one feels drawn to witness. Seeing how the prisoners were treated and tortured. there is also a real guillotine there which is a bit gruesome. It's the sort of place where one walks round in pretty much silence.

Interesting, but it felt to modern. I enjoyed walking around and indulge myself in the whole history of the place, but it didn't really feel authentic... not that i want to feel the horror of a prison, but it was to modern, to clean for me
Impressive place.. Even if the comments don't seem to be that objective sometimes, we really appreciated the visit. Photo of the war against USA are really good.

Old Colonial prison with historic links. Lots of photos and descriptions of barbaric practices towards political dissidents during French colonial rule. Also a section on U.S. army personnel held there in the 60's

Fascinating look into history. Known by us as Hanoi Hilton, it is more than just a prison for US pilots shot down during 60s and 70s. The history of the political prisoners during the French occupation was harsh and brutal. A guillotine is still on show. Photographs of the American pilots as prisoners gives another perspective.

A nice line in propaganda!. If you can suspend your disbelief regarding how the treatment of American POWs is described (let's just say it's a little inaccurate). the remnants of the prison are well worth a visit. It's quite wierd to see John McCain's preserved flight suit. There are parts of the museum that are genuinely chilling (eg, the guillotine) and you get a sense of how oppressive the place would have been when operational.

Interesting and Confronting. The horrors of war are never good to review but it certainly opens the eyes when you see what happened only 30 to 40 years ago. Its difficult to actually believe what people went through during these times.

Keep his critical sense. Hanoi Hilton by American pilots, visiting the prison built by the French in 1896 may be interesting. But the bias is present in the reconstitution of cells under French occupation and photos of U.S. pilots treated with respect during their stay!! A visit, yes .... Ask questions, yes .... Being sometimes shocking, yes .... Keep his critical sense, yes, yes and yes!
Interesting. Hoa Lo Prison is an interesting museum to visit - if you have not seen the War Remnants museum in HCMC (also have a special part where they exhibit the Tiger Cages etc.) before.

Great place to learn about Vietnamese history. They have a great exhibition with plenty of information in English, French and Vietnamese. In some parts there is an eerie background music which adds to the atmosphere. People who were held there under the control of the french were torchered and killed. There is even a guillotine on display. Later on American POW's were held there, on display is John McCain's pilot's suit, the one he wore when he crashed in Hanoi as well as photographs of the other American POW's in the prison. Great place to visit to gain more of an insight of Vietnam's history but can be emotional as people were torchered and died there.

Worth the visit. We visited the Hoa Lo Prision while on the Hanoi Kids tours which worked out well as we had a guide who talked us through the history of the prison. It is a very interesting place in Hanoi, finding out how the Americans lived in prison compared to the Vietnamese. The way the prison is layout is great and the displays they have set up are really good. If your travelling through Hanoi defiantly visit the Hoa Lo Prison.

Nothing much to see. we were in a way disappointed. Cheap entrance. Nothing much to see. a few rooms give you the history of the prison. We did arrive late as they wanted to close so it was a bit rushed.

Definitely Worth the Visit. Hao Lo Prison was one of the most interesting places we visited in Hanoi. It's significance and the role it played during the occupation of Vietnam by the French during the 1800's, the role of women as political prisoners during this time and then the housing of American soldiers during the Vietnam war. It is definitely worth the visit.

Fascinating. We visited here on a recent stay in Hanoi and found the prison (now a museum) fascinating. The displays are well done and I learned quite a bit. The most interesting part for me was the section on the Vietnam-American war. The upstairs sections can be skipped (in my opinion) - one is just photo after photo of communist party members and the other repeats a lot of information that is in other parts of the museum. A visit is highly recommended though!

Worth the trip. For a South African you will relate to the stories in this place. It took us 90 mins to go around the place. Some places are spooky but its all worth the effort. Don't forget your camera

Hanoi Hilton. It used to be a prison to keep criminals and American pilots but it's like museum now. It displays documents and pictures about VC captures there. Good place to visit when you are in Hanoi

Didn't McCain stay here?. We went here because we heard it was the infamous "Hanoi Hilton"where American airman had been held.You would not have known it from visiting.Just a propaganda show,Hanoi has way better options

A must-see when in Hanoi. The Hoa Lo Prison is a must-see for any visitor to Hanoi. While only the front part of the original prison remains (a high-rise office tower now stands in the spot where much of the former prison existed), enough is there to give you a good idea of the horrid conditions Vietnamese political prisoners endured under French rule. While the story of its treatment of US POWs is unsurprisingly one-sided (concrary to what they say, it was NOT a country club filled with smiling, happy American GIs playing poker), you can still read between the lines and get a glimpse into what it was like during that time.
Hanoi Hilton. Only small part of original prison remains. Entry VND20,000. Interesting displays. Good review in Lonely Planet Guide.

impressive. A shame that they did not preserved more. The us war photos are a bit how will i say it subjective... us prisoners had a great life according to the photos....i doubt any stay in a prison would have been great... the rest of the museum is impressive

The Winners Write the History. Don't get me wrong I would say it is worth a visit - though do be aware that most of the site was re-developed into a new office complex - it is just hard to get past a bit of the propaganda that underlines all the "history" presented here.If you view it all with a critical eye and have done a bit of your own reading then I think it is interesting to see.Go there, see it and appreciate man's lowest and highest moments but do so with a critical mind.

Very interesting. This place is certainly unique. Going round it certainly gives you room for thought and definitely worth doing whilst in Hanoi.The price was reasonable and it wasn't hectic going round, which was a real plus.

Sobering is an understatement. First, I must admit my disappointment as only a small amount of the prison remains. Within that small portion, however, you can still imagine the screams. How cruel man is! The original guillotine is interesting, the rafters where the prisoners were pulled up, small solitary and its stocks, cells whose first 8' have been painted black to hide all the cries for help. and the black & white original tiled floors (old and dirty now) so many stared at while being interrogated, cried on, and fell on in utter pain. A definite must see for anyone who cares and empathizes.
Hanoi Hilton. A prison... shows that all sides in conflict can (& do) do some dreadful things at times. It is important to preserve such sites
Nice to know. It a nice museum. Should be visited if you have many days in Hanoi. It not belong to list of the most important thing to visit.

You need to see the "Hanoi Hilton".. This site is especially interesting to me as a former soldier in the US Army back in 1967 in the South. Most of the prison has been torn down with a smaller representation being left for history. Although this prison became famous for holding US POW's in the 60's and 70's, one of the little known facts to the outside world is it was built and used by the French to imprison Vietnamese revolutionaries. It looks like a medieval prison and it was used like one. A very interesting part of Hanoi history. Should not be missed.

Worth to visit. It was a part of war history in Vietnam but too small, there are some rooms like small exhibits that you can understand how they treated prisoners. It could be better if they keep all the size of the prison include of the tower beside.
Worth a visit. We found this well worth a visit, we spent time wandering around and trying to imagine life in the facility - very interesting and gald we went.

Very informational. liked:
-very organized
-interesting content
- great exhibits
Disliked:
-not very accurate
- not very interactive

Five star resort for vacationing USAF pilots. The Hanoi Hilton is an amazing exercise in state-sponsored propaganda, and hugely enjoyable for all that! If you appreciate irony and institutionalised hypocrisy, you'll love this place, as the exhibits trace the prison's history from being the historical site of gratuitously-detailed atrocities committed by the state on dissident countrymen (and women!) to its more recent incarnation as the place where captured American pilots and soldiers were apparently treated like princes. Don't listen to those moaning minnies like John McCain who was left physically disabled for life after the treatment he received here - take a look at the charming official snapshots of happy GIs playing poker and smoking specially imported Lucky Strikes. Don't bother with the second rate Military Museum - spend your bucks here and get a free lesson in Political Science into the bargain... Unmissable!

Small. The Prision was knocked a few years back and is only a fraction of its size. It give a very quick look into the past and how the French treated the prisioners. If your going to see the section on the Vietnam War and the US pilots kept there, it consits of 2 small rooms and a few photos of happy/happy playfull pow's
