Good that they kept a part of it.. History can be told better with actual places and buildings. Its sad that a very tall commercial building stands at its very back/side just behind its stone walls. Entry fee VND 20,000 (about USD1).

Interesting but not balanced!. Was interesting although only a portion of the prison remains. Take some of the exhibits with a pinch of salt! Many labels very limited such as the group of exhibits: Barrel used to torture prisoners, jerry can used to torture prisoners, bag used to torture prisoners, bottle used to torture prisoners etc.Generally when in french hands the prison was hell on earth, but when taken over by the Vietnamese to house american pilots it was more like a holiday camp - that is if you believe the information provided at the prison.

Sanitized for your instruction. Unabashed propaganda. Their message- French colonialists were cruel and inhumane when they used the prison to house Vietnamese rebels, while the North Vietnamese were hospitable to their US prisoners. Some interesting displays, and entrance was only 20k VND, but not worth going out of your to see.

Hoa Lo Prison "Hanoi Hilton". Steeped in history most recently used during the Americam Vietnam War, when John McCain was a POW there in October 1967 when on his 23rd Bombing mission his plane was hiy by a missile and he ejected, which making him unconcious breaking both his arms and a leg, he was taken to the infamous "Hanoi Hilton" where he was denied medical treatment andas often beaten by the North Vietnemese, he spent much of his time in solitary confinement. When he was finally released and able to return home years later the Senator McCain continued his service by regaining his naval flight status, as well as this he became Vice President Of the USA.

Could have been much better. It is more of a display, of what is left of the prison they have have left for propaganda use. If you were to believe what little information is available the prisoners apart from the Americans, (who they declare had such an easy time there) every one else were political prisoners of the nasty colonialists. Any one executed by the French for crimes were freedom fighters. There is very little by way of explanations or reasons why. I had to go on the Internet to see the reasons why some of the so called hero's had been placed there in the first place. Usually for trying to poison the local French garrison etc. The American section is small, not much to it at all. There are whole sections dedicated to the puppet government of the souths prisons and how cruel they were. So it seems a big propaganda declaration about the goodness of the the Communist North and the evils of the Southern Government. Section of how badly the women were treated again in the south Vietnam prisons with the usual drawings of starving figures which are in contrast to the actual photos which show them actually well fed. The conditions that people had to live in we're not nice in this prison but it would be better to present a more rounded presentation of life and history of the place rather than the propagander monument that it actually is. Like most museums in Vietnam it tells little by way of informing or telling a story to inform and educate the public.

"Hanoi Hilton". Worth a visit if for nothing else but a picture outside the entrance of this famous prison. Some interesting and disturbing exhibits, and probably not suitable for kids or people of a nervous disposition, but well worth a bit of time...
Interesting history. A nice change from temples and lots of history about the prison. Inexpensive and a lot of information. Worth a visit if you like museums and war history.

Moving, although a little one sided.. Well worth a visit if you have a couple of hours to kill and easy enough to walk to from the Old Quarter. Moving at times, a little bizarre at others and a little one sided towards the Vietnamese but then you kind of expect that. 20k dong to go in, interesting place to see.

What an opportunity lost!. To us, this had the potential to describe the history of the prison; both with Vietnamese as occupants and Americans. Unfortunately, it is simply a political statement about the war.
Sad.
repeat. lots of museums in hanoi .this one is worth a look. a lot of the museums just repeat things from the other museums
Well worth a visit. This is a very eary place well worth a visit but quite shocking at times It's very interesting and as it has been scaled down doesn't need hours to visit if your short of time

One plc tourists should go.... I found this plc really interesting..especially how d French had tortured the prisoners those days..there were real photos n sculptures of d prison n ways they have escaped..really fascinating..
Really interesting. The prison-turned-museum had a great mix of informational exhibits and artistic representations of life in the prison. Definitely worth a visit!

Interesting historical building. We had a nice walk around Hoa Lo Prison. There is a lot to read about how it was to be a prisinor here. A big part of this prison is also the history about the two periods with the french and americans in the country. Definitely a place to go.

Doesn't live up to reviews. After having being to the war remnants museum in Saigon and all the positive reviews of Hoa Lo we had high expectations, however they were not met, they exhibits were not very interesting and they were often repeated. If you had limited time in Hanoi I would give it a miss

Moving. With my father having been killed in the Vietnam War, I was very interested to see Hanoi Hilton. While I am sure how well POW's were treated was embellished a bit, it was interesting to see how the war impacted all involved. While the actual spaces were cleaned up for tours (appropriately so), it was easy to imagine how conditions may have been far different and in very close quarters.A worthwhile stop for those interested in history.

Rather underwhelming.. Well, while a visit to this prison (aka "Hanoi hilton") should've ben a harrowing experience, it was a rather underwhelming experience.Most of the place is reconstructed with numerous photos and prisioners-like puppets, and somehow fails to deliver the grim atmosphere of such a place.A guided tour inside would've ben helpful, too, as the place is a maze.45-60 minutes, tops.

Very interesting and moving. This place is a very interesting and poignant reminder of Vietnam's historical struggles. You can see the conditions in which prisoners were incarcerated and even some of the sewers through which ecsapes were made. Worth a visit - very inexpensive.

Interesting, well worth it. Spent 1-2 hours walking around. Very interesting self-guided tour. I think it cost A$1 to get in. All of the exhibits were translated in English. We went on a week day and there wasnt many people there, if there were alot of people looking at an exhibit it was easy to go to another room to look there and come back later. Very well set out.

Humbling almost. The Hoa Lo Prison was a nice little walk round in the morning. Right next to the hotel built in the area which contributes to keeping the prison museum going. There are direction signs all around and explanations in English at every section. It was kind of humbling to see what conditions the Vietnamese people went through in the hands of their own Government and is well worth a visit if you like learning about History.
Interesting, but harrowing. Spent 2/3 hours walking round what is left of the "Hanoi Hilton". A very interesting tour, but very harrowing also. Definitely well worth a visit if you are in Hanoi.
Best place. Personallyi thought this was my favourite attraction in Hanoi, very informative, set out brilliantly, visited during a week day an was no one else there!

Great Museum but sadly most of it is has been demolished. Hoa Lo Prison or the Hanoi Hilton as it was called during the war with the US when it was used to incarcerate captured US GI's, is steeped in history and a great place to while away an hour in Hanoi.Problem is, most of it was demolished to make way for hideous tower blocks. So most of the displays show pictures of what used to be there rather than you being able to visit it still.But I suppose that's not the fault of the current staff who have done a nice job presenting the place the way it is now. harrowing stuff on display though.

Powerful Despite Lean Curation. I've visited this museum a couple times. I found this museum incredibly moving. Through the placards and curation, you get a real feel for the Vietnamese side of the story, which I didn't get growing up in the US. I walked out not feeling like taking sides, but reflecting on the sadness of war and the incredible suffering it brings. I also walked away with a real respect and admiration for Vietnam, which has made so much progress in rebuilding and moving on after so much war and destruction. At the risk of sounding pushy, I think that any person who visits Hanoi, from the US especially, absolutely must make a visit to the Hoa Lo Prison to understand this important part of the country's history.

Interesting,informative but expect a very one sided point of view.. Really interesting museum wel worth a visit when in Hanoi. Not a long walk at all from the main drag in Hanoi. Expect quite one sided opinions on how American pow's were kept for example one article stated how they were treated with Xmas dinner and beds. How much of this is to be believed is up for debate! Interesting to know that senator John McCain was kept in this prison for 5 and a half years. Read about his experience and you will soon realise how it differs greatly from how the Vietnamese say they treated him. 10,000 to get in with student ID!

Most Interesting in Hanoi. I thought the prison was very interesting. The translations from Vietnamese to English is questionable, but it provides for good laughs. After getting used to the Vietnamenglish, there were a good deal of interesting things to learn. This is where John McCain stayed, and there are some old pictures of him too. It's a decently sized place, so definitely make sure you don't skip out on anything, and read all of the plaques! Interesting stuff. Bring a student ID to receive a discount on admission prices as well (we did not have our student IDs on us, so we showed our drivers licensees and the woman could not tell the difference... oops).
sobering. you have to go here. to see what the prisoners endured is hard to beleive unfortunately or maybe fortunately i dont think all the facts are told. but go there

Quick visit but worth seeing. A Must for any american or history buff who visits Hanoi. Though most of the Prison has been demolished and replaced with a set of highrises, some of the old buildings still remain, including Death Row. John Mcain's flight suit is still on display, and the pictures they show of the american POW's celebrating christmas and playing basketball, are much different than the actual stories of the detainees. There are som other cool historical artifacts including a Gullitine and otehr various torture devices and there is even a section of the old sewage system that political prisoners escaped through.Though it can be seen in about 45 minutes it is definitely worth the price of admission

A powerful reminder. A powerful reminder of the age-old cycle of victim and perpetrator (as in other prison museums like Dachau) where your moral compass is shaken by the perspectives the narrators bring to their stories. Seeing McCain being rescued from the water by local Vietnamese who saved his life after he was shot down on a mission to kill them; then knowing he was tortured in a prison built by the French to torture his torturers provokes the melancholy associated with the reality of the human condition. Not to mention how quickly that melancholy departs when you are back on the engaging streets of Hanoi.
History all over. You get to see first hand prisoners being locked up with thier legs chained, a creepy yet somber feeling. Worth a visit, appreciate and respect the suffering men has gone through.

Hoa Lo Prison. Confronting and informative. The life like statues in the cells gave an understanding of the conditions faced by the political prisoners. Seemed bit of a white wash over the treatment of the captured American pilots. Definitely worth a visit
A bit of history here. It is worth taking the time to go through this representation of the history of conflict in Vietnam. It is easy to reach by cyclo, taxi or on foot.
Well worth a visit. Went here with friends. The museum really puts you in the shoes of the inmates. Some information is repeated throughout.

Worth a Visit. Yes, you can see John McCain's flight suit. But hopefully you will get a lot more out of the visit than that as I have. I realized what little I knew of Vietnam, it's people, its culture and history aside from the war. I was also honestly humbled by what the Vietnamese people have gone through and was glad to have had the chance to visit and the prison really educated me. I strongly recommend a visit.
Historical Gem. This is well worth a visit for it's history. Be sure to watch the propaganda videos! John McCain was held prisoner here, and his flight suit is on display.
wow. worth a visit they had some pieces from US soldiers that had been detained in the Vietnam war it was very interesting walking round.

Very informative, a little creepy. The prison was very interesting, there was a lot of information to take in and exhibits to look it. There was a somber mood inside the prison, and it was a little creepy with the feeling you were being watched. Overall the site was good and definitely worth a tour, the relics were very interesting to see.

Interesting but grim.... As the prison has always been used to house oppressed people it makes it quite depressing. An important part of Hanoi and Vietnamese history, we learned a lot, but the guillotine is not pretty!

Fascinating, a must-see!. Definitely take an hour or two to visit. You can also do it in less time if rushed, but there's a lot of interesting information to take in. Some parts a bit propaganda-ish, but perhaps even more interesting as a result.

how it really was. The prison is the place where you can see all the terrible things that has happened in Vietnam during the war. Ofcourse it is not nice to see but when you visit Vietnam this is also a part of it.

a must see. Although in a way it was disturbing to see examples of the cruelty that the Vietnamese people had suffered during the course of French rule, it was very interesting. We also felt that there was a certain amount of positive propaganda with regard to the American prisoners during the war - it was the photos of US prisoners in brilliant white socks that somehow didn't ring true, but we may be wrong. Basically really glad we went there.

SEE IT!!!. First stop on our walking tour of Hanoi. Nice outer appearance masks the sad history inside. The guillotine of the French Colonial Era is an enduring symbol of that period. Wear your hip boots for the communist propaganda of the "American War". 1ID/67-68.

Hanoi Hilton. most of the original site of the Hanoi Hilton has been redeveloped to a business model...they have recreated some of the conditions the American prisioners encountered....the shocking thing for me ....was to see how the prisoners were attached to a long platform with ankle shackles..it was said if some one was shackled for too long they would never walk again....The use of life size maniquins showing the men shackled side by side in long rows is one lasting impression and of course the punishment cell that had the same type of shackle and held up to 2 prisoners.

Meaningful and Memorable. Let you feel the history of Vietnam and how they lived through during that time.It showed you the life of the women Vietnamese prisoners how they gone through during the French colony time.It also showed the American prisoner's life in the prison and we now knew why it was called The Hilton Hanoi Hotel!

1 of 2 Must See. Hoa Lo Prison site is only a fraction of the actual prison.before it was torn down for a large office building. It is broken up into two parts, French and American. The French portion shows the brutality that colonialism seemed to bring out. You see the areas where Vietnamese prisoners were kept and even the guillotine used for death sentences. The American portion highlights the fact that POWs were treated nicely (I'm sure a POW would disagree) even though they brought death and destruction to North Vietnam (Vietnamese viewpoint). Both the French and American portions contain the Vietnamese slant/version and as expected is bias towards the government view. But if you look through all that, you can get a feel of what life was like for prisoners (Vietnamese and Americans). We went here with a tour guide who explained many of the exhibits but in my opinion you don't need a tour guide as there is English explanations throughout the prison.

A real prison experience. The museum didn't fail to impress since I could feel the horror around me as I walked through the cells.It's recommendable for the ones that are interested in the circumstances of the people that once were held captive here, however this place may not be appropriate for children as some artifacts/ statues/images can lead to nightmares for the faint-hearted.

More than Hanoi Hilton. I must admit I had no idea that this place had any history beyond what I knew about the place from the Vietnam war. Hoa Lo prison dates back to 1886. Built by the French, it has a long and gruesome history, of which the Hanoi Hilton part makes up for only a fraction of it.We went because of its infamous relation to the Vietnam war, but found a place that has much more to offerin terms of history. Unfortunately most of the prison is gone, and only a small section still stands. While the story of American POWs is very interesting, know that this era makes up for just a short period of its history. We found it all very interesting, and we areglad we had a knowledgeable well spoken guide to take us trough the complex. Allow at least an hour for the visit.
Really fascinating. I would definitely suggest visiting this museum/ former prison - very interesting place with good artefacts and pieces.

It's a prison. If your American is might be worth a visit, otherwise not sure what their is to see. A colonial prison, not much else to say, apart from how well they treat the US prisoners compared with how poorly the French treat the locals.

Sad. It is worth visiting but I felt that it could be a better 'museum' experience. Whilst obviously it is a one sided story you can't help but walk away with the feeling that a lot of wrongdoings have been committed on the people of Vietnam

Bit of a wake up call.... Definitely go here if you want to know the struggles of the Vietnamese people during occupation by the French and the American forces.Quite a small place but it packs quite a punch if you take the time to read through some of the literature there. The strength of the Vietnamese women during these attrocious times is quite moving.This place brings home the brutally and injustice of war and the determination and resolve of the Vietnamese people.Definitely worth a visit.
spooky but good. well organised attraction - lots of space and multilingual signs. very moving and a bit scarey but definitely worth the visit,

Interesting. Very interesting to learn some of Vietnams earlier history and the bravery of its citizens, in particular the women. The propaganda surrounding the US pilots stay there was very amusing....

Communist perspective of Colonialism. Enjoyed viewing. Interesting to read the descriptions of treatment of prisoners. Recommend a visit 30,000 dong and also parked my bike there and had to pay 1,000 dong to leave ( amusing).The sense of political history was a highlight for me as all war/political detainees are wrong no matter who is the perpetrator.
Interesting. Was an interesting place to visit and we spent a good 2 hour looking around the site close to the women's mussel so you can walk from one to the other in a short time

Hanoi Hilton but no room service. Great example and insight into how it was. The museum and remaining section of the prison are fascinating, if not a little disturbing. The view from the cells towards the guillotine still sends a shiver down my spine.
Not much left. Only part of it remains; the rest has been replaced by a hotel, so you have to study old photos and diagrams to try to get a picture of what it was like.

Very Interesting. We really liked our visit to the Hanoi Hilton, there are some very interesting displays and its definately something to put you thinking when you see the size of the cells, and the space that the prisoners lived in.

Harrowing insight into the past. I really enjoyed my visit and learned a lot about Vietnamese history, both visually and through the textual information (which is quite well-written, no need to hire a guide). There was a temporary exhibit about the role of women in the military which I found especially touching. Definitely worth a visit, it's a nice break from walking around in the sun and there are fans inside. An hour is plenty of time to get a thorough look at everything.

Very educational, but perhaps a bit one sided.. This prison is better known as the 'Hanoi Hilton', a term coined by the American prisoners of war. But before that, it served as a French colonial prison for Vietnamese nationalists. The museum tries to give you an insight in both those periods in the complex' history. While it's definitely very illuminating and worth a visit, it also tends to be a bit one-sided in the portrayal of how Vietnamese and American prisoners were treated. Both groups are contrasted, with the Vietnamese being (of course) the better ones.

A bit eerie. Intersesting that it has a guillotine used this century, and they show you pictures of how well the American soldiers imprisoned here were treated !!!!,,, Good for a 30 min visit...but not that much there
the ha noi hilton. Thought it would be bigger. No the less also an informative piece of history. Doesn't take long to tour the prison. Add it as part of a city tour.

A must-see.. The 'Hanoi Hilton' is really a central part of Vietnamese history. Used as a gaol by the French, and then as a prison by the Vietnamese, it has a long story to tell about the development of an independent Vietnam. The buildings are well-preserved and the history is well-explained. A visit does leave you with a sense that nations can be awfully slow to give up what is not rightly theirs. That so many people need to be imprisoned, tortured or even killed in the pursuit of independence is beyond our understanding. Do spend at least half an hour here. Admission is cheap and you definitely don't need a guide.

Hanoi Hilton. It amazed me to find the attitude to Americans was as benign as it appeared to be in North Vietnam considering the way the country had been treated during the war. This was exemplified by this prison where the American pilots were imprisoned in apparent comfort if one considers the devastation outside. An interesting experience

Interesting, moving. I found this place a bit emotional, especially where they show you the cells and the guillotine. I found it helpful to understanding the conflicts during the various wars in Vietnam. I'd recommend this as a part of a tour of the city. You can see this place in under 2 hours, but no need to rush through.

history a part of the country. we have been here with the family and I think you cannot visit Vietnam without seeing some things of their past. When you walk trough the old prison it is sometimes creepy especially because it is dark and with music. They show "happy"pictures of the American flyers who have been captures here but that is some propaganda. You should see for yourself. Jonas Sandra Lisa Joost from Holland

Interesting Place for some History!. The visit to the prison I found was pretty beneficial to brush up on the complex history of Vietnam. Firstly, admission was extremely reasonable. There is a lot of information regarding the prison and how it functioned under French occupation. I found that the information was easy to absorb and it helped me get a slight grasp of this part of Vietnamese history. I also really enjoyed the artifacts from the Vietnam or the 'American' War, including the suit John McCain wore when his plane was shot down and when he was taken prisoner. I think the museum/prison although small holds a lot of important information that I think should not be missed on a trip to Vietnam. The history is really important in even trying to understand Hanoi and the people.

Hao Lo Prison. The prison offered information about the stark realities prisoners faced during their time in captivity. It was disturbing to find out how many prisoners died from fever, cholera and dysentery. The solitary confinement cell showed out how prisoners could get sick so easily. It was also interesting to read the information on display. Remember there are always two sides of a coin. ( Be wary of individuals pretending to work for Red Cross and asking for donations if you approach the Hao Lo Prison on foot. )
A must to understand the city's history. Simple exhibition but helps you understand the "modern" history of the city and what they went through

Very Interesting. It was very interesting to see the 'Hanoi Hilton' and in parts I was very moved by what I saw. We would have benefited more if we took a guide, so I would suggest either reading up a bit before you go, or hire a guide to show you around. It won't take long to see, so put aside 45mins and add it to your list of things to do in Hanoi.

Amazing. If you cared at all about the Vietnam war this is an important and moving stop while exploring. Truly interesting and seeing John McCain's uniform (irrespective of your politics) will stay with me forever. Do not miss this.

Interesting look at the 'Hanoi Hilton'. It only takes an hour to walk round the half dozen rooms left of the original museum. Much is made of the cells and decent conditions where the Americans were held during the Vietnam War. Examples of cramped prison conditions and torture instruments show how life was for the other unfortunate inmates. The tiny brink tunnels, where a successful escape bid was made, show just how skinny the inmates must have been!

Worth the visit. Definitely worth a look through, lots of info, its a shame only a small section of the prision is left these days, but you definteily get insight into the history of the prison. Worth paying for a book to read over later.
confronting. It's amazing a culture can survive after so many years of invaders. This experience will give you a confronting insight into the conditions human beings inflict on others.

Visit the real Hanoi Hilton. The tour through the prison is well laid out and English translations are available throughout. The time spent in the “Hanoi Hilton”, is heavy and the prison has done well to portray the atrocities it has seen. The stifling humidity of the city itself and the life size replicas of the prisoners in the cells create a lasting impression of what life must have been like for the prisoners. A trip to the prison is worth a couple of hours or for as long as you can handle it. I would have liked a formal guide, but I doubt the guide services you can pick up know anything more than you can read along the way. Perhaps I had a poor choice, but try to make sure you get hold of an “official” one. The entrance is only about a dollar (US) (20 000 dong) but make sure you count your change properly.

One Of The Best Museums In Hanoi. Having heard a lot about the infamous 'Hanoi Hilton' I made sure to include it on our intinery for Hanoi and I wasn't disappointed. Having only heard reference of the prison from the detained US Pilots and information surrounding them, learning about its primary creation by the French and it's purpose was eye opening and informative. Some of the exhibits were eerie, understandably with the number of Vietnamese that were tortured and killed there, and it is a credit to them that they have preserved a small portion of the prison to illustrate their struggle, where a lot of the land has been sold to commercial business. However, where the information about what the French did to the Vietnamese was at the 'hard sell' end of information, and I have no doubt and am not doubting that atrocities were committed there, the small part of the museum dedicated to the detention of American pilots seemed to be a lot more sugarcoated and slightly at odds to most of what I had read about their detention prior to my visit. I found the whole experience interesting and well worth the visit, but as with all museums (particularly in Vietnam) go with an open mind.

Interesting way to learn aboout Vietnamese history.. I will highly recommend to visit Hoa Lo Prison as it is a very nice way to learn about the history. We saw how polical prisoners had been treated by the French, the Japanese and also how the American pow were treated by the Vietnamese.
Some shocking images there.

A sliver of what it was. The museum provides a great peek at the prison that the French colonial government built to house and torture Vietnamese insurgents. Also on display, though rather glossed over, is the more recent use as a detention center for captured American pilots. Note that the exhibits provides the Vietnamese version of history.
Glimpse of Old History. The prison gave a glimpse of the painful vietnamese history. The pictures inside the prison are good. If you are in Hanoi, then its worth a visit.
A truly real experience. Any war is unpleasant but in this prison you get to see and feel the pain and suffering of the inmates. Eerie at times but worth a visit

A Must See. For Americans the "Hanoi Hilton" was unknown prior to pilots being held there and unless you actually make the trip you probably would not know that the French built this and held and killed MANY Vietnamese people, make sure to go to the upper level to see a list of all the Vietnamese people that the French KILLED there. It will open your eyes.On a side not, if you are not looking for it you will walk right past it. There are no grand signs or markers.

Affronting. Great place to spend an hour or two, contemplating man's inhumanity to man - and not just by the Vietnamese to the American's, also the other way, and the French impact on Vietnam. A complex history...
Eye opening and propagandist. With information that seems to counter what I was taught in school, still enjoyed the vist and the eye opening experience

Interesting but a lot of propaganda. The ' Hanoi Hilton' as this prison was named is interesting to visit and you can learn a lot about the war. However there is a lot of propaganda material so do take it in with an open mind

Well worth the visit. Good exhibits and pretty comprehensive. The exhibitions do try give both sides opinions. Exhibitions are well referenced and video footage relating to some the exhibits is also on hand. To veiw properly you need a good 3 hours!

One word: Propaganda. Hoa Lo Prison is very interesting and a little scary at times. Very eye opening and educational - however don't believe everything they say - and if you are easily offended and American, don't go.

Great musuem to find out more about the history of Vietnam. Travelled with Hanoi Kids and they explained to us in detail about the history of Hoa Lo Prison.
Part of the Hoa Lo prision is preserved and I benefitted greatly from this visit. There are videos to watch to get a better understanding of how the prisoners were treated during their stay in Hoa Lo prision.
A must visit!

Essential viewing. The Hoa La Prison Museum is an astonishing mix of horror and propaganda. Built by the French administration in 1896, and named Maison Centrale during the French rule – the original sign still hangs over the entrance - most of the prison complex was demolished in 1997. What remains is the the Hoa Lo Prison Museum. The prison was used by the French to hold Vietnamese (largely political) prisoners. Originally intended to hold around 450 prisoners, by the 1930s the number of detainees had soared to almost 2,000.  It was difficult to remind myself that this was not the medieval period but the turn of the 20th Century.Not for young children.

Somber experience. Food for thought how grim history was during the French occupation. While maybe biased (bad french good Vietnamese) the cells and displays do speak for themselves. An interesting place to visit providing a recent history lesson for young and old.
A little disappointing.. Not much to see here, but if you have to kill some time, go and kill an hour.
amazing Bit Of History... really a must see. It's just a small portion of what's left of the "Hanoi Hilton" but it's worth seeing. A sobering experience
Interesting expeirence. Found the Prison to be interesting and worth the stop but mostly to take in the propaganda that the government wants to put forward.
Hanoi Hilton is not a hotel. Loved Senator John McCain's flight suit. The exhibits. The Guillotine is still very scary and evil to be around.
An interesting place to visit. Very interesting to walk around the old 'Hanoi Hilton' there is a lot of history here! It is well worth the 20,0000VND.

Grim reminder of Vietnam Colonial past... Only part of the prison is left, but you can still see how terrible it would have been for prisoners. Most of the exhibits cover the plight of the vietnamese prisoners under French rule but there is a small section about the US POWs.. The commentaries are propagandist to say the least...

Hauntingly good. We were impressed with the extensive information on what had happened here over the years. Such a sad place, but a reminder that this is what humans can do to each other. However there is triumph with the amazing escapes through the sewer lines! Tail end of the visit has much propaganda on the American pilots and their time there. They make it out to be such a holiday during the Vietnam war that you would love to have been captured! However I doubt that this is the full picture. Insightful for everyone in our family.

Interesting Place to visit.. The Hanoi Hilton as it is better known. The unlucky captured US pilots got to spend their last days of war. The prison has been pretty much kept the way it was and you can get a sense of what it might have been like. Like every museum / place of interest you can draw your own conclusion from what you read, It appeared to me that some of the literature on display has possibly been written in a biased way. Some pieces of torture instruments are on display and some photographs. It's worth a visit.

Sombre experience. It was good to understand the centuries of history related to this prison and not just associate it with the American War. The Vietamese have been subject to all sorts of cruelty in this jail over so many years. It was good to see but if you are short of time it may not make the priority list.

A chilling place. The "Fiery furnace" is the literal translation from the Vietnamese but most people know Hoa Lo Prison as "The Hanoi Hilton", where captured US pilots spent their last days of the war. The flying suit used by failed Republican Presidential candidate Senator John McCain is one of the many displays, along with Madame Guillotine, which the French used to execute Vietnamese fighting for independence. The way the early prisoners were treated was barbaric and shown in dramatic tableaux. A prison built to hold 600 eventually housed 2000 in terrible conditions. Most of the original prison was demolished to make way for the expansion of the Hilton Hotel but what is left is a chilling reminder of Vietnam's atrocious colonial - and not so distant - past. It's a place to spend a few hours exploring.

Really interesting. This was definitely worth going to and very interesting to see the preserved section of the old prison. It is somewhat biased in its descriptions of what's gone on there over the past hundred years, but that's kinda to be expected! Still very much worth exploring
An interesting stop for viewing another side of the coin. Part of the country history offering you a view of how the Vietnamese endured some of the problems that ravished their country.
Hanoi Goal. Very interesting. Life was very cruel to these prisoners

A different take on the American War. The prison known as the Hanoi Hilton is worth a visit while you're in Hanoi. It was surprising to see how well the American prisoners lived during their stay there. The prison showed actual footage of the American GIs playing sports, socializing freely, and receiving medical attention. John McCain's flight suit is on display from when he was shot down over Hanoi.

This prison was initially. This prison was initially built by the French (with stones imported from France!) to hold disobedient Viets and later used by the Viets to hold US PoWs. Also referred to as 'Hanoi Hilton', the exhibition in the prison (only a small part is left due to construction of a real hotel) goes to great length to show how badly the French treated their prisoners and how well the Vietamese treated the Americans. The most famous prisoner held in this prison was John McCain, the Republican Presidential nominee and Senator.

a sobering place. The guillotine says it all: this was a place of horrors when the French were struggling to keep the nationalists down. The photographs suggest it was a home from home when the US pilots were obliged to take up residence. Aye, right.
Very interesting. It was really interesting to see all of the artifacts and the way that things are presented. And its a little bit creepy...

A turbulent history. This is a must visit as it highlights the struggle of the people. I took my family there and I was concerned about what was going to be portrayed but it was fine and I was happy that they had the opportunity to see this. It was not busy but a group that we passed had a guide which would have been good but with young children time was a factor.
scary prison. i never see that kind of prison before. it was very scary when we saw the inside of the prison.

Worth checking out. Small, short tour (~20 mins self-guided), with cheap admittance ($2-3). It was interesting to see as an American, though be prepped for govt propaganda, especially relating to the treatment of US pilots during the Vietnam War.
only thing interesting was john mccain's flight suit. much propaganda, little to see, but worth the 20k dong

The Hanoi Hilton. Interesting but I don't like the idea of prisons very much. The mock up of chained prisoners was probably realistic but not to pleasant and it was the first time I had seen a guillotine close up - last used in 1932! The American airmen shot down in the Vietnam wars probably had a good time there judging by the photos but this sinot somewhere an "imperialist oppressor" will enjoy although it is interesting in a macabre sort of a way.

Disturbing take on the American POWS held there. If you go, be sure and read up on the experiences of the American POWS held there from their point of view and do it before you go. It would be a disservice to the US airmen who were tortured and suffered there if visitors from around the world thought the representation of their treatment was even remotely accurate.The pictures of them smiling at Christmas and playing baseball and just having a grand old time is shameful! Regardless of one's feelings about this war, the portrayal of how US prisoners were treated is disturbing. They deserve better.
Interesting place. Hoa Lo Prison is worth checking out if you are in Hanoi. It gives a good introduction to Vietnam's history.

Impressive. It was good to learn about the prison, the conditions in wich prisioners were kept in this place by the French and to have a comparison to what happened to the american pilots captured by the Vietnamese and kept in the same place...
People were treated so badly. This place was somewhere where you would not like to be back then. Lots of of information, a must to visit when you are in Hanoi.

Educational and worth a visit. The Hanoi Hilton is worth a visit, even if you only have half an hour to spare. Total we spent probably an hour in there, reading a but about Vietnam history and seeing some of the jail cells. It did start to get a little stuffy toward the end.Nominal entrance fee (maybe ~USD$1).
Must see?. I think visitors to Hanoi should visit the prison. Technically it's not the best museum in the World but the history (beyond the American and French eras) is quite striking.
Lot's of History. Interesting place to visit but also sad to see what happened to people there
Prison. Very interesting and inexpensive to see. Well worth the few dollars we spent.

Excellent museam that gets balance correct. This is an excellent museam explaining the history of the prison dubbed the Hanoi Hilton by the US pilots who were held there. As with every museam in Vietnam it is slightly biased against the US and the French but it does try and balance this out with an excellent section with interviews from the US servicemen who were held thereWell worth a visit and not expensive (20000 VND which is around 1 USD) to enter in JUly 2012
Wonderful perspectives on war in Vietnam. This is a must see for all interested in the Vietnam war. It's set out well, and well maintained. Do yourself a favour and go!
Center of hanoi cbd. old historic prison. A quick tour about 1hour. They still keep small section for tourist to see the Maison central. Lots of interesting facts. Check it out

Must see for the political history fans. Now, I'm biased in this review because I like visiting old prisons to get a feel of the place and to see if the old energies still do reside there in some quarters. Looking at the walls and the history behind it, it serves a constant reminder to those of us who come from a better time and place that freedom for what we believe in and the ability to live freely without much persecutions for what be believe is shouldn't be taken for granted for there were darker times in our human history and that acts of suppression and torture/cruelty do exist across the cultures no matter where we're from. It's just human nature.

Real Hilton, real world.. Enjoyed the walk to find the place. The prison is well kept and has lesser amount of tourists compared to other spots. Surprised to find a real Hilton over the old site. Could be more impressive inside but the external was all we needed. Details of the history of the atrocities committed on the Vietnamese prisoners when interred in this center. It is centered on that theme. Lots of compassion to them...
Prison. Be aware that this is CLOSED Mondays and plan your trip accordingly. Worth visiting, good insight.
Grim but essential. To understand Vietnam you must visit here. Colonial past and American war covered in a uni dimensional way - which is understandable.
Not really worth a visit. Nothing much to see here but a few cells. I suggest you only go if into prisons.

A chance to reflect. So long as you are not put off by the lack of balance, this is a sobering reminder of a difficult past. Once you have completed your visit explore the local streets for a less touristy experience of street markets.
Gorefest. If you like history and don't mind gore. This is a very good trip while in Hanoi you can easily spend a couple of hours here. Very interesting.
good to get a different point of view. Interesting history from a Vietnamese point of view

Interesting, and full of propaganda. Very interesting place to visit. I was entertained by the slant on the Vietnam war PoW - don't really believe that they were kept in 5 star conditions! Definitely worth the walk.

Hanoi Prison. It was hard to take but a harsh reality of the history of the French in Vietnam as well as the Vietnam war. Pictures of John McCain and others during the war. The size of the guillotine was shocking. I had no idea. The treatment of the prisoners disturbing but glad I did not look away.
Interesting.. A good place to get a glimpse of the Vietnam war. Too bad that most of the original building was gone/turned into a high-rise modern hotel.

disturbing. Not a part of our original itinerary but guide took us when many people expressed interest.. I should not have been surprised that there was an emphasis on the terrible treatment of the Vietnamese prisoners by their French captors. The American POWs by contrast were shown cooking, playing games, reading mail, getting good medical care and generally having a swellold time. Very disturbing but I'm glad I saw it.
Spooky Place. A very spooky place, but it would have been nice to see it almost as it was back when it was in operation.
atmospheric. VC show US prisoners planting flowers, US prisoners tell it differently.

An errie place worth visiting. The Hoa Lo Prison was really interesting place to learn more about the French revolution and also the Vietnam war. There are English translations on the wall to read as you walk round. The propaganda video of the Americans stay at the 'Hanoi Hilton' is interesting to watch at the end.It cost 20,000VND for adults and 10,000VND for those with a student card.
Interesting. Filled in some time, was interesting. Sa to see how they treated their Vietnamese prisoners as opposed to the American prisoners who were treated so well.

An Absolute MUST in Hanoi. Excellent museum with English explanations for every picture & exhibit. This place is a must to truly understand the revolution against the French, and then the imprisonment of US POW's. It's haunting, well preserved, and well worth spending several hours exploring.

Worth the Tears. I don't recommend to visit this place with children's. The history of this place still give me chills every time I look at the pictures, I must confess even the tough guys of the group where in tears. It a must see place while in Hanoi. At the end of the tour you can pay your respect to the ones who die by burning incense in the garden.
Worthwhile visit. Another on the must do list in Hanoi. Interesting. The French guillotine still in place, with plenty of information documenting the French harshness during this period.
A must-see for any American. Revealing with respect to the harshness suffered by many. Quite sensitive handling of the US-Vietnam war.

Eye Opener.. aka Hanoi Hilton. Only a part of the prison is still left but you get an idea of the conditions that the French kept their prisoners in.There is a biased view of the Vietnam war but that's to be expected I guess.Very cheap in to get but it can be very hot when inside.
Worthwhile visit. Very interesting to hear and see about the conditions of prisoners (and the associated propaganda!).
Interesting prison. No dislikes. This is the hanoi hilton dubbed by american prisoners

Prison Experience. Treatment of women stood out. An authentic cell block in it's stark reality is on full view in pretty much it's original state. Photographic history veyr interesting. See it if you have time. quite walkable ,not far from the lake.
Interesting. You wouldn't want to stay there!!! still has the guillotine in evidence, Reading the stories on the wall was heart-breaking.

Worth seeing - but focus is not where most Americans would expect. Most of the exhibits deal with the colonial and post colonial period, with only a small bit dedicated to the American war. They do have a guillotine that the French, in their own inimitable and not very enlightened way, installed and used there.Worth a visit to remind one of the myriad troubles that have afflicted this part of the world. The cells and "dungeon" are really pretty bleak.

Propaganda prison. Completely worthy of the visiti. Lots of subtle propaganda. Small section on American pilots captured during american war. They were treated much better than the Vietnamese were treated in detention, from these accounts. Record on French management of prison is brutal.
The 'American' War.......... That's what the Vietnamese call what we call the Vietnam War - this place is amazing!
Totally worth the visit. From French colonization to the Vietnam War, this museum shows the continuous struggles by the VN people against its invaders.

Very insightful. Made me realise how poorly the French treated the Vietnamese people. Parading the women's heads they had cut off in the streets to terrorise the locals. Well worth a visit but be prepared to be a little moved and even shocked at the history.
Impressive. To see the faces of all these woman who played a big part in the war to ready their stories is just incredible

Small, compact, beautiful. It is worth to spend 15 minutes to wander around the prison building. They keep the building as how it used to be, some of the museum interior part (second floor) has been modernized. I came here for the ancient building. The complex is not too big. But it's worth to drop by.
Interesting and sad. It is a prison built by the french and later used for captured servicemen during the Vietnam war - very sad past and worth visiting.
Worth the Visit. A very interesting place to visit. Very sobering to think of people actually locked away in this place.

Very moving and interesting. I am someone who does usually find any interest in the history of war as it genuinely scares the hell out of me. I found I was interested in this as my father was in the Vietnam War. I was so moved in this prison. There is only a section of the prison left but it is enough to give you an understanding of the suffering. We went with Hanoi Kids and it was such a lovely day and really is worth a visit. It will only take you an hour at best but it is really a big part of the history of Hanoi.

worthwhile experience. We came to Hoa Lo Prison as part of a tour not really knowing what to expect. I didn't realise this until I visited the place, which made it all the more interesting. It will only take an hour going through the exhibits but every traveler here could learn something. A monument to man's cruelty to man. And a reminder of what "we" should not do. Very sobering. And a must see. It has added to my knowledge of the Vietnam War, so it was a worthwhile experience

An interesting view on history.. The "Hanoi Hilton" is worth a visit, partially for the sights but mostly for the historical perspective taken. The French and Americans are portrayed as evil aggressive powers theating the freedom fighters. The "muesum" highlights all the torture and war crimes of the US and French while claiming that there imprisonment of the US soldiers was kind, friendly and without stress to the captives. Any account I mistreatment or torture by the Vietnamiese is ignored or ought rightly denied. In any case, it's a interesting example of selective memory and a not so subtle rewritten of history.
very sobering. Intersting to get the Vietnamese perspective on "Hanoi Hilton"

Atmospheric & educational. The museum is well organized, and a very manageable size. You could rush through in less than an hour, and still get a lot out of it, but a couple hours is all you need to see every exhibit/room of the prison. Rooms and artifacts are well-explained in English, so there is no need to hire a guide buy the English guidebooks they sell at the door. The original feel of the place is (at least somewhat) intact - some of the rooms were definitely eerie and dark, and gave a sense of the horror of being in prison there. The information on it's use during the fight for independence from the French seemed very informative; the exhibits on the Americans later imprisoned there definitely (and unsurprisingly) included some propaganda, but were still interesting and insightful.
Excellent. Gives the other sides perspective. It puts the US pow experience in the greater context of Vietnamese resistance to French Colonial rule.

Worth seeing. Hao Lo prison is a bit of a dark and heavy place, but I learned a lot while I was there. The prison is just a small section of what it used to be, but it gives you a good idea of the conditions the prisoners lived in.

Great learning experience and different perspective. I was fascinated with this tour. the French originally built the prison. I was horrified at the conditions the prisoners were kept in. I was especially surprised to learn of the torturing of women who were imprisoned because of "revolutionary activities." There were stories of many women who submitted to the torture, but did not give up their resistance to the government. The life size statutes help drive the points home. There is also a room with Americans were captured during the war (one of the most famous, Senator John McCain -- his pilot uniform is on display there).

Interesting but very sad. Interesting place to visit, but very sad. Not so sure how accurate some of the displays were in this place is, it appeared to very 1 sided. I have no doubt it was absolutely horrendous in its day, and many men & women lived incredibly cruel lives here.I am glad I went as you see and feel what the Vietnamese endured to obtain their freedom.

Worth a Visit. The prison has interesting history and amazing stories attached with it. There are some parts of the prison, including the original cells which I found very sad to see, the atmosphere was quite chilling and sad. This is a good place to learn about dark side of the war, true history of the prison. It is not a large building, part of it now becomes Hanoi Tower but the remaining cells and display area contains so much history in it.

History buff. This is a must. It gives you an insight to what the Vietnamese have suffered over many years in the effort to regain their freedom and their dignity. They have done both to an amazing degree. I respect and love these people enormously and visiting the prison simply re-enforces these feelings.

An interesting look at some difficult parts of Vietnamese history. Built by the french and then later run by the Vietnamese this museum is well arranged and gives a fairly realistic view of life for prisoners, incudingn women. The display relating to the treatment of American soldiers detained there may have been overlooking some reality of treatment meeted out.

Definitely interesting. Well worth a visit, it's not expensive and there are some good exibits. But it's definitely a one sided story as the guide book says. Aparently the vietnamese were angels during the war, they didn't pull anyone's fingernails out, honest.

History and propaganda. This museum is the remaining part of the "Hanoi Hilton", known in the Western world for the imprisonment of American pilots. However, this prison was used during French rule to lock up Vietnamese opponents of the French. Most of the complex is demolished and given over to development (A modern high rise hotel is situated close by). The propaganda bit surfaces because the terrible bad treatment of the Vietnamese prisoners by the French was emphasized (Don't get me wrong. I believe this treatment was really bad), contrasted to the relatively good treatment the American pilots had (according to pictures shown in the museum). Impressive is the way Vietnamese prisoners escaped through the sewer system, even after this system was equipped with bars. Part of the sewer system with sawn-trough bars is on display. Also terrible are the death-row cells and the guillotine, used to execute the Vietnamese convicts (See photo). Upstairs are rooms, dedicated to the American pilots, taken prisoner, with as interesting part a picture of the rescue of John McCain, who was shot down into West Lake (See photo). Generally a place where you touch the history of the French rule and the battle of communist North Vietnam against the Americans in the South. (We all know how it ended, though)
interesting. lots to read, reallyinteresting, would be great if they had an inter active walk like Alcartarz ....

Rubbish Propaganda. 80% of the prison was sold off to developers but the ruling elite decided to keep a small portion for anti-French, anti-American propaganda. There isn't much to see here mostly some pictures and bizarrely quite few shackled Vietnamese 'prisoner' mannequins smiling and looking proudly defiant. The plaques which contain most of the history about the prison reveal very little information but do offer a lot of historical inaccuracies. Basically they tell a story of how peaceful Vietnamese were just living their lives working in the fields then the French invaded turned them all into slaves, imprisoning and torturing all who opposed them. They imply that their was the foundation of a communist rebel party which constantly waged a guerrilla war campaign against the French Imperialist occupation. Then after the Vietnamese defeated the French and drove them from the land the American's (who had used deception to convince the South to attack the North, invaded. Then there is a whole two walls talking about female prisoners who were captured and tortured by Americans at some other prison South of the DMZ. The rest of the exhibit talks about how American's used barbaric torture techniques while the North Vietnamese not only didn't torture their prisoners, they actually treated them really well and bought them gifts, kept them well fed, etc. Of course this is where John McCain was held (who has described his torture in great detail) but there is only one photo of him. The exhibit ends with a wall of photos of all the countries who rallied against the US and sided with the North Vietnamese. Strangely France was North Vietnam's biggest ally in the anti-ward movement even though they were the early Imperialists and still hold vast interests in the country. I loved Vietnam, the country and its people and I felt that this exhibit was a blight on my experience and portrays the country in a bad light. I had always grown up opposed to the American's involvement in the war, I left the exhibit feeling sorry that they lost.

Not for the faint hearted. It is hard when walking through what is left of the original prison without getting a little angry and perplexed with how the Vietnamese people were dealt with by the French during their early struggles in the 19th/20th century. The guillotine located near the 'death row' cells makes you shudder with disbelief. Understand why the Vietnamese government left this place standing, a reminder to all about the journey to get to where they are today.
Interesting. Most of the prison is gone but its still worth a visit for historical perspectives
Lest we forget. It reminds us of the sacrifice that allows us to visit a free Vietnam. The elderly peoples one sees on the streets have lived thro' this horror. Viev le Vietnam I say ..

Propaganda. We just had to visit out of curiosity. Interesting and my son ( 9 ) got a little freaked out, but enjoyed it overall. The French treated them horrendously according to what it says here but all the pictures of torture to Vietnamese show other Vietnamese doing the torture. They however claim that the US soldiers kept there played basketball, chess, cards, quitar and got souvenirs on leaving????? Got a little ticked but that's the gov. not the people.

Well organised, great value and insight into Vietnams history. We stumbles across the prison on the way back from booking our train to Sapa. Only cost 20000vnd to get in and it was well worth it. They plenty of signs to guide you in the looping path through the exhibitions and there was a lot of information, pictures and films about the prison. We both thoroughly enjoyed wandering through at a slow pace to read everything and get a feel for the harsh treatment the vietnamese political prisoners received from the french. Not sure how the rest of building was destroyed but there is a huge hotel immediately behind it, a shame the whole prison is no longer standing. Be careful of the scammers waiting outside the gate to sell u 'toothpicks'!!

definitely worth a visit. also known as hanoi hilton, this is the infamous camp where american pows were detained, along with some vietnamese prisoners. only a portion of the original prison remains but it is enough to give you an idea of the hardship the prisoners suffered as well as the dismal conditions at that time. there are also artifacts on display such as a prison uniform, instruments of torture plus a guillotine. all in all, a very informative place to visit.

Interesting and eerie. Fascinating museum, which takes you back in time. Focused on political prisoners and two rooms covering the Vietnam war. It gives you the Vietnamese perspective on what happened to the prisoners. Only part of the Hanoi Hilton still remains.
Very little on America. True Vietnamese propaganda. There's only a small area about the Americans and it shows them playing and having a grande time, raising chickens, celebrating Christmas.

Make this a priority. You have heard of the Hanoi Hilton and this is it but you quickly realize that our sense of import and time is too narrow. Visit and absorb the amazing story this place has to tell...this country was oppressed invaded and bombed and terrorized. American POWs are just one short chapter in this incredible institution's history.

Worth an hour... Hoa Lo prison "Hanoi Hilton" worth a visit 20,000 vnd per person. Quite disturbing in places especially the guillotine....Loads of info about the war etc. Downstairs more interesting than upstairs. Watch the stairs on the way down.

Interesting, a bit spooky!. Interesting to walk through and read a bit of the prisons history...have random bits and pieces on display... Mock set ups of prisoners... Need only to allow about an hour to visit, very cheap (US$1 I think)

A slice of history of Hanoi. Take a stroll through this place and try to absorb the history of the people who passed through here. It was a real eye opener imagining the overcrowding here and the daily life of the inmates. Take care on the outside stairs to the upper level!
Hanoi Hilton a Must See. The prison has quite a history and the Vietnamese perspective provided on the prison and prisoners was fascinating.

A must. It was very interesting and enlightening. We were a bit surprised (maybe not the correct word) at the end on how they treated some of the history, but if you are in Hanoi I would definitely recommend a visit.

Small but interesting. We had heard about the prison before our visit to Hanoi, but only stumbled upon it accodently while on our way to another museum. We decided to enter and for 10,000 VND we didn't expect a lot. There are some interesting parts of the prison, including the original cells which I found very sad to see and the original guillotine. John McCains flight suit is also there from when his plane was shot down. Of course, there was propoganda in the museum which everyone expects to see, but if you take the information you read with a pinch of salt and look at the real, true history of the prison then it is very sad and sombre. It is not a huge prison, so it depends what you expect to see when you visit, but for me it was very interesting paticularly Reading about the people who fought against the war whilst in the prison and how the prison has been used over time.

Hanoi's dark past, Hoa Lo Prison. Hoa Lo Prison or parhaps better known as the infamous "Hanoi Hilton" POW prison which was used to house American POW's during the Vietnam War.. worth a look but don't be fooled by all the "happy snaps" of American prisoners.. this prison was a hell hole dedicated to torture when the French had it full of Vietnamse prisoners and nothing changed when the Vietnamese held American prisoners here... torture and every attempt to break the human will to endure was a way of life in this place all through its history.

Curse Insane Greed for Power & Wealth. I hated the gruesome and terrible glimpse of history shown here. What an insane species some of us are. And the rest of us are swept along by their awesome will - still! Yuk!

A lesson in history. Anyone interested in the Vietnam/American war will find this place fascinating. I love historic places and this place otherwise known as the "Hanoi Hilton" will strike a chord with anyone who's read anything about those troubled times. It harks back to Indochina when the French ruled and has tragic tales from that time also.

Very impressive! A must see in Hanoi!. If you visit Hanoi you cannot skip the Hoa Lo prison (Hanoi Hilton)! The history of Vietnam is well presented and you will feel the stories in your bones! I liked it better than the Army History Museum.
A bit sad, but part of the history. Not a huge prison, but certainly filled with historic memories of the last war. Shows the barbaric history of French beheadings.....hardly human, let alone humane.

Hanoi Hilton. interesting visit - the site is much smaller than in previous years due to the surrounding property developments. Learnt a lot about the French occupation and was surprised to see a guillotine and the sloping prisoner beds. Horrible stuff. The American area - made famous by downed captured American pilots was interesting but fairly small in coverage.

Hanoi Hilton. Loved the history of the French and Vietnames political struggle. The French have always been brutal and it seems that the Vietnamese were just as hard in resisting in the colonial times. There is a touch of propaganda in the section where US Airmen were held but still a great visit. The route you take is very structured and hard to deviate from if you are time constrained. It's a must to see in Hanoi.
This would have been hell. Quite easy to find and cheap to visit. Spend an hour walking through this place and you will appreciate the horror both men and women were subjected to in this place.
Insight. It gave us a understanding of what Vietnam has been through over the centuries Well laid out displays and tour.

Another Kick in the Gut. We toured Hoa Lo Prison in the last hours of a two-and-a-half -week trip to Cambodia and vietnam. Hoa Lo is known by Americans as the Hanoi Hilton, where John McCain and other POW’s, particularly pilots, were held. At the end of the trip, I was not sure I wanted another kick in the gut, and sure enough this visit dredged up the emotions felt at Tuol Seng and Cheoung Ek in Cambodia. Most of the tour is devoted to the time that the prison was built, expanded, and operated by the French and housed Vietnamese men and women being held as political prisoners. The visit spares no punches against the French, with writings by women prisoners about the horrid conditions and the nasty meals, records of the deaths in the prison from dysentery and other illnesses, stone figures in the men’s and women’s prison depicting people shackled by one leg in a rigid metal brace that forced them to sit naked side-by-side, bare dungeons and death cells, a guillotine and pictures of executed prisoners, and tributes to the prisoners who escaped. The latter part of the visit, conversely, seeks to depict the conditions for American POW’s as humane and hotel-like, with photographs of smiling Americans playing basketball, chess, cards, and engaging in other entertaining past-times. Our young boys commented, "I guess it wasn't so bad here," but I also reminded them that there is always another view, particularly with respect to the conditions for American POW’s. Winners write history. I was grateful when our visit was cut short by the 5:00 closing time. Not because this is an uninteresting place--to the contrary--but because I did not wish to endure further another kick in the gut. You can read more about this and other places at www.maketrax.blogspot.com.

A must see site. allow a couple of hours to wander around . Most of the prison has been demolished when the Somerset Grand Appartments were built but it is sobering to see what cruelty the french colonial masters inflicted on the Vietnamese.
historical but not much else. If you have time and are a real history buff - stop by. Not much to see.

Interesting history. Interesting history. It mostly focuses on prisoners held by the French. There is only a small section relating to Americans held there during the war. Expect a lot of whitewashing of US POW treatment.

Well worth a visit. I found this small museum very informative and atmospheric. It contains some interesting information, an authentic guillotine (I had never seen a real one!) and don't miss the room at the end devoted to the American prisoners during the Vietnam/American war. Gee, they were having such fun there!!!!! Do watch the video showing this.

Haunting. Excellent exhibits show explicitly how the Vietnamese patriots and revolutionsts were treated whilst at the prison. It would have been a harrowing place. Interestingly, by contrast the Americans were treated very well. Definitely worth visiting.
Hanoi Hilton. I recommend everyone visit this location to learn more about what went on during the Vietnam war.
Must see. This is probably the best museum in Hanoi, for 20.000d it is absolutely worth it. Plenty of english references so you don't have to worry that you will just watch and be lost..
worth a visit. Was so interesting to see this place and to understand the conditions. Thank goodness it isnt a working prision now.
Sobering experience. A very good reminder of what western colonialism did to the Vietnamese people. It's very bleak but well worth the visit.
Worth a look.. It was informative but a bit repetitive. Still worth doing.
Must see. A very sad and good account of the war in Vietnam, extremely interesting to see how France and America affected the Vietnamese people during this horrific time.

A place with a tragic history. The museum is an excellent, albeit sobering look at the horrendous conditions Vietnamese prisoners were forced to endure if they opposed French Colonial rule. That trend continued when American prisoners of war were captured and brought to Hoa Lo, though the photos of American soldiers playing sports, cooking holiday dinners, and receiving packages from home would have you believe otherwise. It's well worth visiting, just know you can't believe everything you see.

Hanoi Hilton. Although most of the original prison has gone the main frontage still remains. Quite a few photos of the American airman who stayed there. The images gave the impression they were treated very well or just good propaganda. The French appear to have treated the Vietnamese atrociously, no wonder they fought back.
Hanoi Hilton, bad memories of my youth. Growing up in the 60's it was in the news all the time. It was interesting to see. Worth an hour of two to see
Must see. It is hard to say why this was a highlight as atrocious but a reminder of what has gone on in this great country

A Tribute to Those Who Served.... This is a well documented museum of those Vietnamese and Americans who spent time in the prison. The musuem also present many facets of the prison that are not generally known to the public.
A good reminder. A very good reminder of how the prison's inmates were treated. Amazing to see the methods used by some to escape.
Small but nice. A nice museum to visit an afternoon when the sun is to strong and you need to get indoor.
Interesting Look into the Past. The stop is worth it, but overall it shouldn't be a long stop as it is much smaller then it use to be. It is, however, a good look into the past of Vietnam.
A little slice of Hanoi history. Interesting place to visit and added to my knowledge of Vietnamese resistance against the French.

An eye opener. Although most know it as the famous 'Hanoi Hilton" of the American war, Hoa Lo prison was originally built by the French and housed many past revolutionaries, some of whom were executed there or died under torture. Only part of the original prison now exists as the rest is under the Hanoi Tower buoilt next door. However, there is enough to get the feeling of what it must have been like to be incarcerated there. A must on a visit to Hanoi

Kind of Spooky. This is the prison that was referred to as the Hanoi Hilton, it was built to hold around 600 people and during much of its active service saw between 2 and 3 times that number held within its walls. What you see today is a small portion of the prison but it does have a lot of artifacts and many "propaganda" photos. It is well worth a visit but beware that it may be hard for some people to stomach

Good insight to what happened in Vietnam. Always good to see the other side of a story! The western media always Portrays what it wants to say, and no doubt the viet government are doing the same here.
Good insight. Maybe not the the most balanced museum, but very well done and interesting.

Hao Lo Prison. It was interesting, loads of mannequins in the role of prisoner to give you a first-hand idea of what it was like. See these pictures. http://womentravellingalone.blogspot.com/2009/09/vietnam-hanoi-hilton.html

A prison with a history that mirrors Vietnamese conflicts. Hoa Lo was built by the French colonialists and used by them to torture male and female dissidents fighting for an independent Vietnam. According to the displays, many Vietnamese were martyred at this place. During what the Vietnamese call "The American War" Hoa Lo was used to "house" American POW's, mostly captured from air craft after they were shot down. USA Senator John McCain was one of them. The info panels proclaim how well the POW's were treated. If you like history and want to learn a bit about the struggle against the French then the Americans then it is well worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton. The images within this prison will linger long in the memory. The impact of the French in their colonial days in Vietnam are a sad reflection on the Western Powers of the time. Compare this with the way the shot-down pilots of the US bombers were treated! A wonderful experience for me!

Gruesome!. Even without the smells and noises that would have been part of this place, it is gruesome. One has to come away wondering how human beings can treat each other so horrifically and how there can be so little tolerance of people with differing viewpoints. We all know jails are horrible and can be places of torture and death, but going through here makes it a bit too real!

A real eye opener. The kids learnt a lot. We had no plans to go here but we got some cyclos for the day and they took us there. A very interesting place to spend and hour or so, depending on your interest in the war. They show miodels in some of the cells and also some pictures and literature in some of the officers quarters. The kids really were surprised at the living conditions.
Creepy!. It's a prison! Lots of anti-American propaganda. You get to see where prisoners were kept and their living conditions.

Eye opening experience. We came to Hoa Lo Prison as part of a tour not really knowing what to expect. The prison is very educational and interesting, providing an insight into recent Vietnamese history. It is however very similar to other prisons you can visit in Vietnam, though one we would recommend.The museum is quite small and only requires an hour to be properly viewed and appreciated.
history. it is an one sided story told by the Vietnamese govt. but still worth a look.

Bleak but informative. Saw less than I would like because of a power cut during my tour,but perhaps made the experience a little more authentic.Very little about the infamous "Hanoi Hilton" most exhibits deal with the Vietnam resistance movement heroes,lots of propaganda.Worth a visit,only 1dollar admittance fee.
Good history lesson. As we are younger we didn't have a great knowledge of the war but this is a real eye opener

Interesting as a building. We visited the prison since our hotel was on the same property. The tickets are cheap and the place is worth visiting for reflection purposes but reading the history is up to you and must be done somehwere else. The prison serves as a place to see the cells and the Vietnam view of the war but doesn't really teach you anything about the bigger picture of what happened... So to summarize: do visit but do not expect much.

Visit. Was interesting and gruesome. Old guillotine with photos in action. Liked to read the "official" versions of American airmen's incarcerations and then look up the airmen's versions on wiki. Very different

Hanoi Hilton a sombre experience. It seems like a contradiction but the experience was terrible and excellent at the same time. Terrible for the people who had been imprisoned there (although the American Pilots seemed to get a better deal that there predecessors). It is an excellent place the reflect on the terrible history and hope nothing like it ever happens again.

A little small. This place is worth a visit but it's a little smaller than I anticipated and so didn't take to long to look round. It's cheap to get in though so if you've got a spare bit of time then it's worth it.
A bit creepy but very interesting. Good look at the history of french colonialism but also of the Vietnam war
Good overview of Vietnam history. It's worth a visit just to get a perspective on the history of Vietnam.

Not what I'd expected. Interesting, but what they don't tell you is that years ago they bulldozed 80% of the camp to make way for a huge office tower. The exhibits are interesting, totally worth the $0.50 entry fee, but just not what I expected of a location so hyped in the West.
Interesting to See. This one is very eye opening. It doesn't take too long to see most of the prison (that is now remaining) and would recommend seeing it. The cost is minimal.

Definitely worth a visit. Im really pleased we did this as it was a real insight into the war and how these prisoners lived.. Very informative with documentaries and lots of artefacts giving a great overview to the history of the war. Go.
Interesting. Good to see that they acknowledge the torture of political prisoners but they painted a very different picture of how they treated the American airmen as prisoners of war.
Worth a visit. This was a good place to visit and see the harsh conditions prisoners endured during their stay.

A sobering place for Americans of a certain age. The Hoa Lo Prison, better known to American baby boomers as the Hanoi Hilton, is now a museum set in a corner of what remains of the old colonial prison. The exhibits cover the French colonial period as well as the American War and, despite the occasional heavy-handed propaganda, it's worth a visit.

Very interesting but one sided museum. It was interesting to wander through this museum but is clearly still a one-sided take on the history of the prison. Left us with more questions than answers but was worth a visit.

A must!. It can be hard to find, but worth it.
It was fairly quiet and no one hassling you for money for a change.
You could spend 2-3 hours.
Gives a view on the people in Vietnam. You can feel what the people in Vietnam have gone through, in their struggle for freedom. Great endurance in the people in the country.
A glimpse of the life on the other side. A snapshot of life in the Colonial Prison alongside the Vietnam War. Definitely worth a visit.

Fascinating. The Hỏa Lò Prison (aka Hanoi Hilton) provided a great exhibit, shedding an interesting light on prisoner treatment during "colonial French occupation" and "American imperialism" (i.e., Viet Nam war). Clearly Hỏa Lò Prison serves as a propaganda tool for the Vietnamese government, but that is part of the fascination.
