You should visit with an open mind and remember that it is always the victors who write the history books.

Not as Interesting as I thought.. Not much there any more. Interesting to read about the horrific conditions that prisoners here must have endured. The guillotine was quite horrific. went as part of a city tour, so was great to have a guide to explain things to us. would be pretty boring without this.

If you have visited Tuol Sleng, this place is a palace. Admission 20,000 VND. The museum is rather informative and well presented. I believe for 20,000 dong you get your monies worth, andit's a good hour out of the day.Only negative is that we felt prisoners here were treated well compared to that of the Tuol Sleng, Cambodia. So please if you have been to Tuol Sleng before you may be offended that Hanoi is charging for this.

very moving. Although now a quarter of what it once was this prison - known to us as the Hanoi Hilton, provides a very moving and graphic account of condition the prisoners faced. I found it very moving and at times had difficulty continuing. I had difficulty with the fact that humans can continue to treat each other in this way. Make your own decision but be prepared. it is well worth visiting.

Glad We Saw It. Average in it's presentation but above average in the historical significance of this place. Interesting point of view of what happened there. Too bad they allowed a huge hotel to build overtop of most of it.
Fascination to learn - unmissable!. Plenty to learn aboput the war, prisoners and the Vietnamese people

Good visit with some outdated propoganda. The Hoa Lo Prison, dubbed the Hanoi Hilton by US servicemen during the 1960s, has a history dating back to the beginning of the 20th century. I didn't realise this until I visited the place, which made it all the more interesting. The section about the North Vietnamese treating the US PoWs fairly is pure propoganda material dating back to the war. Also I'm not sure if some of the images of the female PoWs under French rule are authentic as they appear in the War Remants museum in Saigon as images of PoWs under US occupation of Con Dao. Other than that, very interesting place and good for a short-ish visit, around 40-50 mins.
surprisingly good display. so much learnt from a trip here and from the displays (original conditions of cells) and info on the boards

Gave me shivers. Propaganda was very present here, but it's understandable. Visiting this prison gives you a very good look at what exactly happened in Hanoi through all those years. The dungeons were very impressive.

Don't go out of your way unless you have time to kill. Some interesting exhibits here invariably mixed in with a decent dose of propaganda, but it was very, very repetitive...Some of the exhibits included the flight suit of Senator John McCain and some photos of him when he was at the prison.If you are walking nearby, or have spare time on your hands, you may as well go and visit. But otherwise don't make any special trip to come here.

Small museum but powerful experience. I was again quite moved by the experience of going here as I was years ago. A shameful period of history. It will only take an hour going through the exhibits but every traveler here could learn something. Tons of well behaved very young Vietnamese children when I attended.

Pretty cool for us; pretty awful back then. Didnt think I'd care much for this place, but it's an easy walk from the old town and really very interesting. As others have pointed out, the story they tell you is that the French occupiers horribly mistreated the Vietnamese, whereas they treated the Americans with dignity - quite amusing to read the contrasts. Close to top rated restaurant...so yes, I'd go here.
Hanoi Hilton. A simplle tribute to those POWs and other political prisoners. Go early as the buses come late. An interesting 1 hour walk through
Creepy and worth it. The famous Hanoi Hilton: especially the French Guillotine and various torture instruments on display.

Hanoi experience. Hi,I am into grisly affairs and this place was built by the French after displacing the natives and destroying their ancestral lands and wiping out a culture that once thrived here.They used it as an execution place for political prisoners and operated a harsh regime of cruelty and depravation purely because people rebelled at their colonialism. I must say it was very well and strongly built!It housed women and children as well as male political prisoners.There were also cells where prisoners were held for very long periods in solitary confinement with legs shackled leading to many deaths from torture and conditions as well as disease and poor diet. Later on it was used by the Vietnamese to house American pilots that were captured on bombing raids and also even has the American senator John Mc Cain's flying suit on display.Well worth two or three hours but conditions not as bad as the S21 camp in Cambodia. A lot of tributes around the walls and phtographs of women who contributed to the defending of the homeland/ Vietnam throughout French and American occupation

Interesting, a bit eerie.... Very interesting visit to the well kept ex-torture prison. Definitely is centered on the Vietnamese point of view and propaganda. They claim to have McCain's uniform, although its not. The prison has sections of the dungeon and cells. As you walk through the dark halls and walls you can't help but imagine that horrible things that went on there decades ago. Interesting info on the Vietnamese women involved and imprisoned. Cheap too! Def worth it's value.

Difficult to know what to believe. I didn't know what to believe here as the museum was full of so much propoganda. There was also a lot of repetition and I didn't think this attraction was very well organised.

Tad depressing. I suppose if you are going here, you know what you are getting in to. My wife wanted to go for some reason, still not sure. It was fine. Seemed well done, I liked the dramatic music playing and there were jail sound-effects in one part. Reminded me of the Alcatraz tour in that regard. Interesting seeing the photo album of captured American pilots.
amusing vietnam propaganda. the best part of this place is the old propaganda movies. Definitely worth a visit! Actually my profile picture is taken at one of the prison gates in this prison.

Not for the faint hearted. Please don't visit this place if you are at all sensitive to the atrocities that have been committed against the citizens of this beautiful country. i came away extremely upset.
Interesting. The history of the museum is fascinating, and it is very creepy walking inside.

Interesting. Interesting place to visit for its historical significance. Exhibits include old prison cells, a section on female prisoners and John McCain's supposed flight suit from when he was captured and housed there. Definite political overtones in the wording of exhibit information. Some English information available.
interesting. My husband visited the museum and rented a guide at the site which was a good choice. He liked the museum and found it was worth visiting it.
Easy walkable from centre. 20,000 dong entrance(60 p) and an incite into the Hanoi Hilton,takes about 90 mins to do the tour.
Interesting. Very interesting place to visit, especially as an American.
Very harrowing. I dint realise the history of this, but it was fascinating to read and see the conditions.

Lots of emotions live here. This is quite the place. There is only a small portion of the original prison left and it is surrounded by high rises but that does not detract from what this was. It is hard to believe that a culture supposedly as advanced as the French could treat people as inhumanely as they did "only" 50-60 years ago. It would appear that the Vietnamese treated their American prisoners significantly better 20 years later. All-in-all, a very emotional journey one takes through these remaining buildings.

Definitely worth an hour of your time. An important piece of must-see history, including dramatic recreations of what it must have been like to be locked up in this horrible place the French built in 1896.

emotional. this was an emotional place to see. it is a shame that the back of the prision was demolished to build a high rise but the garden is very sereal even though the is a high rie hotel on the other side of the fence.

Very interesting. This was probably the most interesting thing I saw in Hanoi. Definitely worth the visit and better than the other attractions. More than anything I think it goes to explain the antagonism the populations has towards the west and people from other countries as a whole.

sobering place. Worth a visit to get a feel for conditions in this prison under the French regime; especially the treatment given to women; some as young as 14. Not too heavy, more a place of contemplation.

A fascinating insight into Viet Nam history under the French and during the Vietnam Nam War.. The old prison in Hanoi, known to the French as Maison Centrale and to imprisoned US airmen POWs as The Hanoi Hilton, has mostly been demolished but enough remains to form the basis of an excellent and informative and, in places, moving and troubling, museum. It covers the French colonial times and the more recent war with S Viet Nam and, yes, it is one sided and nothing is said of how the prison was used from 1946 under the communist regime in the north. However, it is presented fairly clearly and the way round is easy to follow. It is well worth a visit.

Hanoi Hilton. The propoganda against the US was distrubing to me.This was done through videos. Al of the people we met from Hanoi were very, very nice.In fact our guide get stressing that even though they are Communist they love the Capitalist things!
Educational. This should be on your list. It's rich in history and life changing. You won't come out the same person after your visit.
Sad history. It was interesting if not a very sanitized look at the American conflict, however we learned a great deal about the French occupation.
This is prison Senator John McCain/other American pilots imprisoned. Enjoyable except our guide said the propaganda not all that true about how well the American pilots were treated.
Interesting. Good attraction to see WWII US POW living conditions

Another must-see. If you visited S21 in Phnom Penh or the War Remnants Museum in Saigon, then you must come here and learn about the Vietnamese revolutionaries and their struggles against the French Colonialists. Really, really interesting.

hard to describe!. Being where so many Vietnamese were held and then so many Americans... was humbling. Very bare bones, simply displayed, it tells an amazing story in American history and the Vietnamese history.

Worth visiting. A pretty eerie place considering what horrors went on here. Understandably there's a lot of propaganda so it leaves westerners feeling pretty sheepish! It sounds callous to say it's 'interesting' when you're reading about women who were tortured and died for the Vietnamese cause. However, it is interestingand there is aklso a display of the American servicemen's pictures, possessions etc. - the men who ironically coined the name 'Hanoi Hilton'

Sobering. I had no idea that the French built this prison, or that women were jailed there. Good documentary photos etc of the American airmen imprisoned there during the Vietnam War ( hence the nickname, the 'Hanoi Hilton'! )

Its ok worth a look if you have time. its a look into the past of Vietnam form the french invasion to the "American War" its ok if you have the time only takes about 45 mins to look through and cost a few $ to get it.

Not Much There. The guide books did say that only a little bit of the prison had been preserved and this is true. It is interesting to read the Vietnamese perspective of the war but only an hours trip in total.
Interesting.. It was an interesting afternoon. Nice to learn a bit more about how the war affected Hanoi, and how prisoners were treated. Displays are a bit dodgy though.

Glad I went!. The prison has an interesting history--while I was aware that the prison was used to house American pilots, I didn't realize that it was used for so long by the French to imprision Vietnamese nationalists. Worth a visit if you're in Hanoi. When you pay the entrance fee, they offer a small English guidebook for sale for 20,000VND, but it is poorly written and much of the same information is repeated on signs in front of the exhibits, so I would skip that.

Interesting to see a place I have only read about in history books. Visited on 16 March 2012. GPS coordinates are N 21 01.516, E 105 50.789 Admission fee is 20,000 Dong ($1 USD).Approximately 90% of the displays are dedicated to the prison’s construction history, its role during French colonization, and 10% highlight the American War (known as the Vietnam War in the US). Since history is written by the victors, all displays are presented from the Vietnamese perspective. Special emphasis was placed on the brutality of the French against the Vietnamese political prisoners, to include torture, solitary confinement and capital punishment. Several displays specifically highlighted the role of Vietnamese female prisoners. All displays regarding the American prisoners either highlighted protests against the Vietnam War in the US and other countries or how well the Americans were treated during their captivity. Photos included holiday celebrations, special meals, Americans exercising or playing board games, and the release of the prisoners at the war’s end. My American perspective of the prison’s history based on first-hand POW accounts, history books, and independent documentaries, the prison’s displays could best be described as propaganda. Most of the 30+ Western visitors, who were visiting at the same time, also seemed most interested in this part of the prison’s history.Since my visit, I have spent some time researching specific individuals and events mentioned in their displays. At the very least, it has helped me to visualize the conditions experienced by the American POWs. Overall, it has added to my knowledge of the Vietnam War, so it was a worthwhile experience.
Depressing. Good to see but dont expect a feelgood experience.
An eye opener. Well worth a visit to see the trials and tribulations of the Vietnamese.

I'm so glad I didn't spend time there. I was a Marine during the Vietnam era and this was a very eerie place to visit. There's a very long history there, going back to the imprisonment of the Vietnamese by the French early in the 20th century. Lots of propaganda related to the US involvement there but certainly worth the visit. Even has the flight suit that John McCain wore when he was shot down and imprisoned there (supposedly)

Worth a dollar. Like all Vietnamese museums it's lesson in propaganda and not objectivity i.e, evil colonists treating poor revolutionaries badly (unquestionablly true) and lucky american POW's playing basketball and eating christmas turkey (probably not so accurate). It's got 30 minutes to an hour in it and I don't think that it gets too busy, the building has been well maintained and there is a nice peace garden/sculpture out the back.It's only 20000 VND to get in and it doesn't close for lunch like some of the lazyier museums.
hanoi hilton. really interesting although you do have to remember its just one side of the story. Good exhibits, like the sewer gate prisoners escaped through and photographic displays.
Worth visiting but not great. Tis has improved over the years and there is now more of a balanced view given. As on my first visit it barely mentioned the US war only the French war.
Worth a look. When in Hanoi, it is worth walking to the prison to check it out. As with most 'attractions' if that's the word for it, like this, it is a somewhat sad place to be, but a must see.

A good way to spend a half hour. This is the prison where John McCain spent his time as a POW. There is a lot of history to the prison and the cells have been turned into a museum with exhibits on the wall and plastic models shackled in the cells to demonstrate what prisoners lived through in the prison.The ominous music a la Halloween was a little cheesy and the exhibits are written with a communist propaganda twist. But interesting nonetheless

Hoa Lo prison visit. We managed to find the prison within walking distance of hanoi town about 10 min walk away. The prison looked quite small as most of it had been destroyed or pulled down but when we got in side there was quite alot of information and rooms to see, the place had an austere eerie feel and quite dark in some places along with the music being plumbed in it was quite unsettling but a very worth while place to see and very enlightening on the war and the torture that went on in the prison. the cost was around £1 to go in so very cheap.
Too Much. A bit too much to see how vVC got treated during the war but thats the way to see the real thing which had happening during the war. Tatally worth a visit

Convergence of French prison and Hanoi Hilton. The French built this prison to hold vietnamese prisoners on the site of a pottery village. Displays of defiance, revolutionary learning under the noses of the french. American pilots were kept here until the end of the war. Displays are slanted showing how well the Americans were treated by the Vietnamese.
Nice history but sad. Nice for some history, but not much for my feeling when I came here. It is so sad !!!
Onesided. It is very onesided, but a must see. Some horrbile pictures. Not for children.

Many feelings. The hotel staff said they had many feelings hen they visited this place. They were so right, it was a gruesome time in Vietnamese history but what happened there needs to be remembered. Eerie
Sobering experience. It is hard to believe that this prison, "the Hanoi Hilton" is downtown. One could pass by without knowing the atrocities that occurred here. A must if you like history.

Glad we didn't miss it. This visit was not on our organised itinerary and we only went because we had a day to ourselves. We thought it was not possible to get inside but it has been very well arranged for visitors to see the whole place and also see the conditions that the prisoners endured. Some parts are quite upsetting and I decided against looking through the cells were female prisoners on death row were kept. There is a room dedicated to the American prisoners where great efforts have been spent in showing how marvellously well they were treated - I suspect a fair bit of propaganda!

great for history buffs.... Whenever I travel around Asia I tend to enjoy visits to the old prisons. Main reason being you get to see, read and hear what it took for people to earn their independance and how badly they were treated by their colonists. Hoa Lo is no different.Built by the French and used to house mostly political prisoners. It was alarming to see how they were tortured and even executed. Later on during the Vietnam War it was then used by the North Vietnamese to house American POWs and nicknamed Hanoi Hilton. Their most famous prisoner being John McCain. His flight suit & parachute is displayed there.Most might be bored but its a great visit for history buffs.
Fine. Nice for some history, but not much feeling inducing content.
A stark reminder. This was dark and gloomy but worth a visit to see the dreadful conditions, at least for the victims of Colonialism.

Hanoi Hilton. Still stirs memories of the war, but life has moved on and like any other museum, it should stir you. I dislike anyone that cannot take things at face value and let in curiosity instead of prejudice when traveling

Interesting history, but full of propoganda. It was interesting to see the prison, but beware of the propoganda about the US pilots. So many pictures of them playing basketball, decorating a Christmas tree, and showing them having a "normal and pleasant" experience. Be warned, do your history on it first and you can still enjoy your experience.

Not a big time drain and worth the visit. Though most of the prison is gone there is still quite a lot of interesting history there. It is worth the $1 it costs to get it. it will take about 2 hours to check it out thoroughly...
Can't beleive the French built such a hell hole. Can't beleive the French built such a hell hole. The poor souls who stayed here.
Realistic and a little scary. Loved the way they had brought lifesize models in to show the horrendous conditions prisoners were kept in. Guillotine gives you the shivers.
The Hanoi Hilton. A disturbing view at times of the cruelty we as humans are capable of.

Interesting perspective. History is my favorite subject, and since my husband did four tours of duty in Vietnam, I wanted to visit Hoa Lo Prison. The prison primarily concentrates on the many Vietnamese who were imprisoned here prior to the Vietnam Conflict. I'm not sure if there are normally lights on in the prison, since there were no lights the day we visited. However, I felt that really gave a sense as to how grim the conditions were. We knew there was an area concerning American prisoners held here, but it was very hard to find and we would have missed it if we hadn't known to look for it. There were photos of many of the American prisoners and while some of them showed celebrations, it was clearly obvious that no one imprisoned here would be in a celebratory mood. Perspective is interesting, because there are so many variables. It makes me wonder why we all can't just get along. Be prepared to be sad for everyone.
Interesting. Its well worth the 20000vnd.It's rather confronting where the death row cells are.apart from that it's very informational
Hanoi Hilton. A monument to man's cruelty to man. And a reminder of what "we" should not do. Very sobering. And a must see.

Pure propaganda. This is propaganda personified. It is a building of lies, and took my blood pressure up a few notches because of the blatant falsehoods presented with such arrogance. But my husband and I went to see where our prisoners were held (and many others, too) out of respect for them.It is amazing that people are so brainwashed into believing such drivel. I almost expected to see Hanoi Jane welcoming visitors and giving tours.

Be ready for propaganda. It's only a small part left of the former prison which was built by the french and later used to detain american pow. We planned to visit it for 1 hour and stayed there almost 3 hours. It is very fascinating to see the size of the cells and the living conditions of the prisoners although some parts (e.g the guillotine) are a bit populist.Now comes the second big part: Be ready for massive propaganda and misrepresentation! Especially the exhibition part is not objective at all and mostly pointed against the americans (not surprisingly though, but still too much for a museum in my opinion). One example: They state that "Hanoi Hilton" (name given by American POW) should reflect the good treatment of the prisoners. Hanoi Hilton was de facto given ironically because of all the torturing and mistreatment (which is documented).So, inform yourself in advance and don't be misled by videos and pictures in the exhibition.But alltogether a must see in Hanoi, it's intense and gives you food for thought.

Creepy but interesting!. They managed to preserve the actual cells and put life like statues of the prisoners inside. Interesting history. John McCain was incarcerated in this prison and there are pics of him along with the other American pilots who were held here.
Spooky!. Worth a visit. It is now only a fracion of it's original size and had a lot of other prisoners besides John McCain.
The other Hanoi Hilton. It is hard to take the story told is so one sided and wrong the it makes you sick to read alll the lies they are telling their people.
A SITE TO SEE IF YOU HAVE TIME. This is quite interesting but if you are pushed for time, not necessary. You see how they chained people up and how they lived.

Prison captured my Imagination. There were some amazing displays and stories told throughout the prison. It was definitely worth seeing. Considering this is very recent history its interesting to see things that some of us would have read about in the newspapers all those years ago.

Hanoi Hilton. The Hoa Lo Prison in Hanoi sarcastically dubbed the “Hanoi Hilton” by the American Prisoners during the Vietnam War is truly worth the visit. The museum is dedicated to illustrating the Vietnamese Revolutionist’s imprisonment by the French, so there is a lot of propaganda around the American prisoners of war. However, it is a moving experience that depicts the atrocities of war. I suggest reading up a bit to get a full understanding and experience. The Passing of the Night: My Seven Years as a Prisoner of the North Vietnamese, by General Robinson Risner is a good, quick read and will tell you what the museum won’t.
One of the better museums around. Visit this place to learn a little bit about the Vietnam war (and propaganda)
Hanoi Hilton. Well worth the visit, except totally biased, well done exhibits

Smaller than expected, but interesting and educational.. The wife is a criminology buff so we went and had a look at the "Hanoi Hilton". Admission is very cheap, and the exhibits show a little bit of how hard the prisoners had it. Wandering around, you get a little bit of a sense of what the prisoners went through. I would recommend visiting if you get the chance.
very good. lot to see here ,quite a bit of history both good and bad

Moderately interesting. A relatively small museum which can be covered in 30 minutes. It's interesting to step into some of the actual cells to get some impression of what it would be like, and curious to see the John McCain photos. However I didn't find it hugely informative, so I wouldn't say it's a must see, but worth a quick visit if you are there.
HIlton of Hanoi. okay the place a lil bit creepy with theme song played by the its management and some stuff originaly used in the prison.
Hmmm.. It's greatest contribution was in the ancient history such as Nam Viet and the fact that bronze age artifacts were on display for all to see
great piece of history. had an good time seeing how the prison system in north vietnam worked in the past. Its a good story about the political influences that ruled in the past.
Not my favorite. It is near the Old Quarter and easy to go to. But it doesn't have many things to see inside...

Hanoi Hilton - A must. If you are American or French you must visit this place for its historical value and political 'commentary'. It shows how awful the French treated the Vietnamese nationalist prisons, and how wonderful the Vietnamese treated the American POWs (seriously). The pictures of John McCain are interesting - as long as you keep your cool and dont get riled up about the propaganda. In fact I suggest reading his autobiography or checking out the internet to find the true story of the beatings he took while a guest at the Hanoi Hilton. But that was 50 years ago and thankfully we (the USA and VN) have moved on. The entire visit is only 30 minutes and well worth the time.
Great small musuem. Interesting musuem, with lots of pictures and information in English.
Worth seeing. Quite interesting gives you and good overall of the prisons use and history. Well worth seeing and super cheap entry.

Prison - a face of our "Past". The museum in the prison depicts torture and inhumanities the colonial powers subjected the Vietnamese. Such atrocities were a common phenomenon among all the colonial powers be it the British, the Spaniards, the Portuguese or the French. India has many a stories to tell. It is surprising that these powers today boast of being protectors of human rights. Can the Americans justify their actions as featured in the "War Remnants Museum" in Saigon.
Interesting and disturbing. This prison has a few horror stories worth a look but i could see how some of the stories etc can disturb some people
Just go there!. If u going to Hanboi it definitely worth a visit. It gives you the opportunity to find out some interesting things

IF you like visiting old prisons this is for you. A lot of Vietnam is about remembering the past two wars and this building is part of that circuit - I doubt if the Vietnamese in the street think anything about it as the average age appears to be in the 20's and 30's. So it is a touristy thing to do.
Small, but worth a visit. interesting collection of stuff, and amusing documentation
Interesting spot. Very interesting visit, especially if you like war history. Definitely recommend.

Not all about US POW. The museum is a small remaining portion of the original with some of the original space now taken up by a hotel and shopping centre.The museum shows some of the inhumanities the Vietnamese were subjected to by the colonial powers, but represents the care and treatment of US POW's as humane and comfortable. Its likely safe to say it was terrible for anyone staying here.The location is a little difficult to find form the Old Quarter as there isnt much signage. Look for a yellow-ish wall at the corner of Hoa La street and Hai Ba Trung next to Hanoi Towers...

The 'Hanoi Hilton' you've read about. A grim reminder of the way that some communist states have incarcerated, tortured and oppressed political opponents. A visit to the 'Hanoi Hilton', or so called by US POWs held there during the Vietnam war, demonstrates by way of friezes the misery, suffering and degradation imposed on the unfortunate enemies of state imprisoned there. Worth a visit to remind you just how inhumane such practices are, particularly when you realise that such things still continue elsewhere in the world.
what a place. american can only thanks geneve pact... it's unbelieveble they way they were treated so good while they didnt provide the same treatment to thei enemies...speechless

a must see. This piece of Vietnamese history has been written about often, known as the Hanoi Hilton" during the "American" war where US pilots including John McCain were imprisoned and used by the French to imprison and execute Vietnamese pisoners before that

A shocking but indispensable visit!. The Hoa Lo Prison is an indispensable visit when in Hanoi. Built in 1886 by the french colonialists was used during the Indochina period and was stage for big atrocities in according to the local explanations. Very little remained from the initial building and presently there is a museum in the site "telling" the rich prison history. There are still some original cells and a guillotine used to behead the condemned. The same prison was used during the Vietnam war to the confinement of the american pilots prisoners that ironically nicknamed it of "Hanoi Hilton".
Atmospheric and intriguing. Good information on prison conditions with some disturbing model scenarios. Though the info on conditions for the US prisoners was clearly biased! Cheap entrance fee.

Sobering experience. The Hanoi Hilton through the eyes of the Vietnamese. This prison was built by the French and showed their cruelty toward the Vietnamese people. There are several rooms dedicated to its role in the Vietnam War and the American POWs and it sanitized as you would expect. The bulk of the museum focuses on the Vietnam people and there are memorials of the people who fought to get the French out. There is a real guillotine in one room as well as the flight suit worn by John McCain when he was captured.
Waste of time. It's a typical kitch propaganda museum. It's only interesting if you want to see a real guillotine (there are only a few left in the world).

French colonialism: more than boulevards. The history of French colonialism in Hanoi is oddly concentrated in wistful commentary on the boulevards and airy courtyards. This museum is essential if only because it provides stark visual evidence about the brutality with which the French ruled their Indochine (note: Deneuve is nowhere to be seen).

Interesting Site. The infamous 'Hanoi Hilton' offers some chilling views of life for prisoners when it was operated by the French. There's a small section on when it housed American POW's which is fairly propaganda heavy, but still interesting.

An experience to stick in your memory. Although only a small part of the original facility still exists, it is enough to get a feel of what it must have been like to be incarcerated there. The guillotine was an especially chilling reminder of the prison's history. There is enough here to use a couple of hours of your time.
very interesting. worth a look and was interesting to learn a little more about the past. they have dvds playing in english with actual footage of the prisoners. defo worth a look

Interesting.. The museum is interesting but it felt like it was all a little one sided. Other than that it was a good place to visit, it seems crazy that such a high security prison is right in the middle of the city. Admission is cheap about 30p 10000dong.

interesting visit. hoa lo prison is a very interesting and insightful attraction to visit. the history of the vietnam war is presented very much from the perspective of south vietnam, however very interesting and hoa lo prison is worth a visit

Small but interesting. This is what was called the "Hanoi Hilton" during the Vietnam War era. It was interesting to see the place where the US prisoners (primarily pilots) were held, and gave you a good idea of what it must have been like. The part open to the public is small--not the entire original prison. Also, you always need to keep in mind that these sites are "scrubbed" and presented by a Communist government.
hanoi hilton. a very sombre experience, but a good history of what old life was like under the french (not the americans). people tend to not think of this part of history, or just forget.
Hanoi Hilton. You get a very grim realization of what it was like for 400 US pilots to be held prisoners there. The cells have reproductions to help you imagine what life was like.

Hoa Lo Prison. Nicknamed the "Hanoi Hilton" by the American POWs due to the cushy treatment and accommodations they were offered. Interesting visit with English guided tours if you pre-book but otherwise, you can just walk on your own as there are short captions for the artefacts on display.

Excellent exhibition.. The exibition inside the prision are excellent, it make you thrill and some part make you fell like a real living prision. The description tags are helpful. But the place are very small most of the former prison area become office building nowadays. If it's half or fulll size of the former prison, it would be great and much more interesting.Becareful of scam outside the prison. While I walked on a street near prison, There are 2 Viet girls from Vietman Red-Cross ask me to donate. They show me the donation book full of donator name from around the world. Unbelivable, most of them spent over $50 - $200 or more for street begging without receipt (the book may faked up by the girls). I can't believe they are real Vietnam Redcross because while they talking to me, they keep looking behind and around to beware of something, police, I think. Then I just walk away.

A little disappointing. actual area that American pilots were kept is a tall office building.
Lots of propaganda but some interest for focus on the French colonial period.

Interesting...if one sided. Interesting insight into the "American War", extremely one-sided when you get to the American Quarters and view their treatment of their American POWs, or "invited guests" as they refer to them, complete with displays depicting their Christmas dinners, sporting pursuits and camraderie with the guards. I wonder if the prisoners felt the same way!

Worth a look. Having a look around the prison was interesting. The downstairs area mainly focuses on the French occupancy, who built the prison. Towards the end of the tour and the upstairs area has more on the America prisoners of war. It is bias but interesting to see the rooms the prisoners were held in and get an idea of the conditions.
It's alright. Nothing special to visit but an interesting walk through none the less. May be a bit boring for those who do not like reading though.

Interesting. It was interesting to see the Vietnamese assessment of their prison and this time. It just makes one think about how so many of the things that we take for granted in our home country are written up.
A must-see for history buffs. V interesting to get a different perspective on the war and colonialism. Not gruesome - just interesting
A Prison. Not much to say other than it's place in history is interesting..

Interesting and informative. Best thing we visited in Hanoi.
Compared to other museums (War, History) this was actually informative (with English text boards) using the actual psysical space in an interesting way. Worth a visit!

A nice but small attraction . . .. Firstly Typical Vietnamese attraction - Take the historical side with a pinch of salt, if your really interested I would read books and accounts of the prison in the two different eras it was mainly used for. Very cheap 10'000 dong but only a section remains open to the public so it's a short experience. I would say go if you have time, but I would not return.

very interesting. Just brought back lots of memories for me, although I was only a teenager during the Vietnam war. Seeing John McCain,s, picture and many others from the war I found very interesting..

Good if you're interested in the war. There are some pretty gruesome photos of beheaded Vietnamese 'rebels' from the French era together with the flying suit worn by former American Presidential candidate John McCain who was shot down and imprisoned here.

Very interesting, recommended for people 13 yrs and up.. Very interesting, heartbreaking place to visit. The information is well presented. There are many areas to visit including a second level so make sure not to miss anything. Seeing the conditions the prisoners lived in, photos of those killed, and standing in the exact room where people were horribly tortured and killed is very tragic and creepy. I would recommend doing some research into the prison before hand as I wish I had. Make sure to look up when you first walk in to see the top edge of the prison lined with broken glass bottles to prevent esapes. Would recommend this for people 13 years and up depending on maturity level as there are quite graphic stories which would probably be best appreciated by older audiences. Well worth a visit. Only real negative for me was that a lot of the documents and poems which I'm sure would have been fascinating had not been translated into english.

Only a fraction remains.... A thought provoking place to visit. When I visited there was a gorgeous tree in a courtyard, leaves changing colours and lit by then sun. This was such a contrast to the stories of the horrors inside this building

Very interesting. We hadn't expected to see so much of this prison given that it was 10,000 baht (30p) entrance fee! We're not historians or the type that like to frequent museums but we did find this place pretty interesting, even though not all of the information was translated to English. Did you know John McCain was a POW there for 4 years?? A good hour or so spent here and definitely worthwhile. Also worth following up with a trip to the Cot Co tower in the military museum which houses some of the planes & tanks used during the Vietnam wa and referred to in the Prison.

Fascinating as an American. The prison is an especially compelling site for Americans and were were anxious to visit it. It has some nice displays, but much of it seems somewhat amateurish. Be aware that propaganda runs thick, but it was fascinating seeing Senator McCain's flight suit and photos of many of the other POWs. It was fascinating seeing these events from a Vietnamese perspective.
A Must see. I walked around this place twice so that I could really get the atmosphere. It is chilling and must have been terrifying to all who entered the gates. Many of course never left alive.

Interesting to see. So called 'Hanoi Hilton' much of it destroyed to make way for high rise development now. Full of propaganda as expected and maybe a bit discomforting to any visiting French visitors.
Hanoi Hilton. Place was exciting and tickets were cheap. I took only about 30-60min to see everything.

Interesting but would not rush back. We visited the famous Hanoi Hilton today. We are glad that we have been there but would not rush back. It is interesting to see some of the displays from the Vietnamese perspective of the Vietnam War and how the US POWs were treated. If you like history we would recommend a visit with an open mind. If you are not interested in the war, give it a miss.
Hanoi "Hilton" prison. Insight into the conditions experienced by prisoners. Lots of information and pictures and rooms to visit. Well worth it.
What a sad and sorry place. Interesting and could be a place to take the slightly older kids. A tad upsetting for us older ones though.

what comes around goes around. Originally built by the French as a general prison, later used to hold some of the Vietnamese revolutionary leaders, and following the exit of the French it was used to house US POWs (including downed pilot and later Senator, John McCain).....what is left now of the prison (after some very short-sighted nearby development which saw some of the grounds being used to build an apartment/mall complex) is now a museum....nick-named the "Hanoi Hilton" necessitating that when the well-known hotel chain DID return to Hanoi, they decided to name their hotel the "Hanoi Opera Hilton"....this prison is synonymous with a long history of repression, brutality and torture, regardless of the time or regime....a little mawkish, but an absolute must for history buffs (who can remain tight-lipped and not feel the need to object to some "inaccuracies")

A peek at history. It was a tough visit - it's amazing how human beings can treat each other. But it helped to give us a very different perspective on the war, and it gave us a lot of insight on how the country went down the path that it did. There was certainly a lot of propaganda to take with a grain of salt, but even if we disagree (which we did quite a lot), we felt that it was very important to learn what a good chunk of the country believes as fact. Everyone has a different reality.
A sobering destination. The figures of how prisoners would have been treated, shackled and contained in the actual spaces was sobering. Lots of good information in a variety of display areas.
Cruel and sad place. A interesting and eerie place that gives an insight into lives of the locals during the years of colonisation.

Sobering but fascinating. Seeing the conditions prisoners were kept in (irrespective of the rhetoric in the descriptions) is pretty sobering. Shackled, at a slight upside down angle, with barely enough food to survive, and yet they must have been able to hear the daily life of the city happening just 20 feet away during years of incarceration ... don't mean to make this sound depressing - it is, in fact, enlightening and a tribute to the survival of the human spirit.
a must see. Very interesting and cannot be missed. We learned so much in just one hour about the history and the war
history place. I saw and understand a part of two war in Viet Nam
Hanoi Hilton. Very somber site with some great exhibits, its a prison with lots of history and tells the Eastern view of the last war very intersting and mind provoking

A sad tale of how the French treated the Viet people. The prison is only a few minutes by taxi from the Old Quarter and whilst there's not a lot left of the original building it still leaved the visitor with a real sense of what the Vietnamese people have endured.The guillotine and the accompanying pictures were a bit daunting, as were the cells and foot shackles.Well worth a visit.

Very Vietnamese. As someone who lives in Ha Noi, I can tell you that this place is very Vietnamese. But I'll explain that later. First, this place has a fascinating history, and it is well worthwhile going to see. The idea that the Viet did to the Americans, what the French did to them is very interesting to me. The bullied become the bully. But, here is what you need to watch out for. This places is a propaganda machine. When it comes to the French occupation, they cover the French crimes very well...but they gloss over their treatment of the Americans, and actually show all the images of all the fun and games the Americans had while being captive; it is right on par with how the Nazi's had a photographer come in and take pictures of the great conditions that the Jews were living in. So, take everything with a grain of salt, and realise that the government that held the Americans there is still in power.

Study of human psyche. The winner gets to write history, and propaganda is but a way for the author to convince himself to believe his own lies as truth... yes, the bias is beyond blatant and will incur many an eyebrow-raising stare from western visitors, but the Vietnamese are not alone in such historical manipulation. And war brings out the worst in both sides. A reminder to us all not to forget the atrocities of war.

Fascinating Historical Site and Shameful Propaganda. This is a must see attraction for anyone interested in 20th century historical artifacts and shameful examples of propaganda. Besides the photos of beheadings (which can be avoided), we found it suitable for kids. My 9 year-old figured out without any prompting that the description of the treatment of American POWs was farcical. You are asked to believe that a history of brutal mistreatment under French colonial rule was followed by resort-like treatment under new management.
Very Biased. According to the presentation of the Vietnamese, American POWS were treated humanely and had all the amenities of a country club Interesting tour, but not to be taken seriously.

Worth a look. For anyone who was around during the Vietnam War, this is worth visiting. You know before you go that you will hear propaganda but you still get a feeling for what all prisoners at Hoa Lo had to endure including the Vietnamese during the French occupation.

There are better things to do. A rather grim experience although more a reminder of the French colonial past than of the Vietnam War especially as the majority of the buildings have been demolished to make way for a massive office block.

If history interests you.... ....then you must visit this place. Amongst other things, you will find a begging flag which was found on American pilots when they were captured during the war and a guillotine which the French used as a wretched weapon to quell the Vietnamese uprisings against their unjust rule in the early 20th Century.Be mindful of taking taxis standing outside, only order your cab from more reputable firm like Hanoi taxis or Mai Ling Taxis

One side of the story. I took my teenagers here and was concerned that they would be taken in by the one-sided nature of the pretty displays. The worst was the ludicrous section on how North Vietnam treated U.S. prisoners of war. Afterward, I read John McCain's account of his experience there to my kids so that could see first hand how propaganda is used. Helping to raise skeptical adults is an important role for parents. This museum gives you a chance to do this.

Worth a visit but not what you're probably expecting.. If you're an American, the "Hanoi Hilton", where many of the pilots shot down during the Vietnam war were held, is probably the only attraction you know about in Hanoi; so naturally you're going to want to see it.It's not what you're expecting however. For one thing, 90% of the prison was torn down in the 1990s; all that's left are a few rooms, most of which commemorate the suffering of Vietnamese freedom fighters at the hands of the French colonialists. Only two small rooms are devoted to the American POWs (John McCain's flight suit is on display), and there are lots of pictures of American pilots smiling and playing chess. To hear the Vietnamese tell it, the Americans were treated well, never tortured, and generally had a grand old time as guests of the Vietcong until the war ended. I don't think so...but it's still worth an hour or so of your time.

Mans inhumanity to man.. The prison shackles, sloped floors, bare concrete rooms and French guillotine contrasted with the accounts of humane treatment of prisoners. One wonders what was done to get people to sit at a table with lots of food drinking tea.......for the camera.

A nasty part of history. It is impressive to see this prison that has served as prison for three different groups.
The museum is not that big, but big enough to get an idea of how terrible it has been to serve time there.
Present a student ID and entrance is half price!
Very sobering experience. Chilling exhibits. So interesting to learn of the prison from the perspective of Hanoi.

Interesting perspectives on history. This is worth dropping into if you are in Hanoi. As previous reviewers have noted, there are displays about the prison during the period was run by the French and during the period of the anti-American war (known in Australia as the Vietnam War). It provides an insight into the bombing campaign by the US in December 1972. It tooks us under an hour to have a good look around.

Small, but worth a visit. Americans better know Hoa Lo Prison as the "Hanoi Hilton", the infamous POW prison where American pilots, including John McCain, were held during the Vietnam War. The prison actually has a much deeper and darker history than just that, as a prison used by the French to house Vietnamese nationalists, and what's left of the prison is largely a museum commemorating this period.There is only a small part of the original prison still standing, the rest having been claimed by a high rise development. There is a nice model of the original prison and layout inside one of the display rooms. Most of the displays center around the treatment of Vietnamese prisoners by the French, including depictions of how prisoners were kept in leg irons, the old "death row" section, and even the guillotine used to carry out death sentences.Perhaps in a nod to John McCain's recent celebrity as a presidential candidate, there are two rooms dedicated to Hoa Lo's time as a POW camp, including a display of McCain's flight suit. These areas are pretty heavy on propaganda, making it sound like the POWs were at Club Med rather than a notorious torture center. But the propaganda is interesting in its own right, and this is one of the few well-maintained Vietnam War sites we found. It's an interesting place to stop for the American visitor, even if you won't get any real sense of what the prison was like during that period.Overall I'd recommend this attraction. It's quick and easy to get to, and like most attractions in Hanoi it's very inexpensive to visit. An hour would let you explore the complex pretty thoroughly,

Worth seeing. "Hanoi Hilton" is worth seeing, but I was unprepared for how it sad and angry it made me feel. The Vietnamese have pride for how well they retreated downed fighter pilots, which goes against everything we are told as Americans. Seeing the guillotine and the shackles for prisoners was gutting. And then there's John McCain's flight suit. The gift shop at the end seemed so inappropriate to me after learning about all the terrible things that happened there. I don't need to buy a nick knack to remind me of this heart-wrenching place. I'm very glad I went, as it made me think, but it had a bigger impact on me than I expected.
well worth a visit. Was this was our third trip to Hanoi we had already seen most of the attractions. The prison was well worth visiting.

Amusing propaganda - the winners really do write the history. LOGISTICSHoa Lo Museum is located within walking distance of Old quarter at the Southwestern end of Hoan Kiem Lake, I would recommend you do it as part of a larger walking tour of the city featuring Old quarter sites (Ngoc Son, Memorial house, Bach Ma, St Josephs cathedral) > History museum > Hao lo prison museum > Temple of literature.REVIEWThe propaganda on display at this place is so ridiculous it is amusing. The winners really do write the history books. One aspect of the tour focuses on the Vietnamese's struggle against the French. It's essentially just a tirade of how evil the French were. The other half talks about how much the Americans loved being POW's in the 'Hanoi Hilton'. I particularly loved the photo's entitled 'Americans cooking Christmas lunch' and 'Vietnamese patriot giving present to leaving American soldier;. I was waiting to see a picture of an American crying with the label "American soldier upset at concept of leaving prison behind to return to country". This propaganda is pretty stock standard for Vietnam (particularly in Saigon in it's Cu Chi Tunnels and war museum) so you just have to sit back and laugh. The structure of the prison itself is OK. It's quite small which isn't necessarily a bad thing and it has numerous displays and information which I feel was very good value for the small admission price. It's proximity from old quarter and other sites means you can walk here and this makes for a cheap day. It was also very interesting to see John McCain's pilot suit. I wonder what he thinks of this place now?CONCLUSIONWorth a look due to it's proximity to old quarter and minimal entry fee. Try not to take the propaganda too seriously.

Ok But nothing special. If you're in the area, worth popping in but you won't be in there more than an hour max. Entrance is cheap, reasonably interesting but most of the descriptions are not in English so had no idea what the photos or pictures were about.

Average. Not much of it left now as most of the prison was moved years ago. So, quite small. If you're in the area, worth a look in, as can be done pretty quickly, but wouldn't cross town just to get there.
Give yourself some time. Visit when you have some spare time on your schedule... It's not big, and there's not much to see. But what you see is a bit horrific once you read about the prisoners

Greeted with souvenir shop once you've entered. It's a place with a great perspective on the war history, but navigation within the place was a little haphazard. The souvenir shop is located right after the entrance.

Little left to see at Hanoi Hilton. Only a small portion of the prision remains, the information on dislay makes for an interesting perspective, it was still worth the visit though, just be prepared for the many eager taxis waiting outside for your return trip back to your hotel.
Worth a look. Very interesting.Especially liked the section on the Vietnam war.Seeing the cells and the guilotine sent shivers down our spine!Definately worth a few hours of your time.

If the Walls Could Talk. What is popularly known as the Hanoi Hilton this French designed building holds an interesting and disturbing past. While it may be forever known as the place where US pilots including Senator John McCain was held during the war it holds a far more disturbing place in history. Built by the French to hold political prisoners in cruel circumstances one can only imagine what prisoners went through. The information and models used in the prison are first rate and gona long way towards explaining what went on in the past.

Not for children. My nephew brought my 2 daughters. Very emotional, very eery, and and somber. My kids are Vietnamese and know the history of this prison, but not for the uninitiated child or very young children.
Eye-opener. It was really compact and packed with information. The entrance fee was well worth it. It was a great experience overall.
Worth a visit, but disturbing.. Vietnam tries to present their story as they see it, but it can be a bit disturbing and graphic at times. Seeing pictures of decapitated prisoners was a bit much.

power and music. There is little left of the original complex but there is more than enough to get the experience. Do not miss this place, listen to the music as you go around and sense the history. We also rcommed the Temple of Literature. We were there today (09/12/11) just as a graduation was finishing, Keep going through the complex and find your way right to the back - its worth it.

Compact and Informative. this place is mostly for the history buffs and americans. we're Singaporeans ourselves but my dad was always interested in the Vietnam war and we decided to visit the infamous Hanoi Hilton. As with prisons everywhere life here was truly terrible and I couldn't help but wonder how much of the "high living standards" provided for the prisoners was actually the work of propagandists. In general however, it was well maintained and opened our eyes to an aspect of the Vietnam war.

Interesting Place. I've been here a couple of times; pretty interesting, especially if you are American. They have John McCain's flight suit, a nice guillotine, and some interesting history on US war protesters, by name, you have never heard of and who don't show up on Google. Also, pictures of smiling GIs and Santa! Probably at least some revisionist history going on here, but interesting for that reason alone. Well worth a visit!
interesting. interesting to see how the prison has been used during french time and vietnamese period. Propaganda applies everywhere.
brutal history. Good museum. some propaganda but very interesting insight to french colonial supression and vietnam war history.

Poorly done for a potentially interesting site. I was hugely disappointed when I visited Hoa Lo Prison. I normally have a thing for prisons - just really enjoy visiting and hearing the tales of famous prisoners and relevant conflicts. But Hoa Lo Prison (better known as the "Hanoi Hilton" in the West) was a bit of a letdown.Just to be clear: I don't have a problem at all with the Vietnamese take on history, although I could imagine some patriotic Americans getting upset. Most of the prison is dedicated to talking about the horrors undergone by Vietnamese freedom fighters at the hands of their French colonial masters in the prison. However, after independence we are told that the gaolers suddenly became considerably more enlightened in their sensitive and caring treatment of American GIs during that unfortunate period of conflict. I fully expected that, and usually hearing the "other" side of things makes it more interesting, not less.But it is still a poor tour. Firstly, the majority of the prison was torn down to make way for the massive Hanoi Towers next door (which, on the plus side, makes it easy to find...). So you only really get to tour about a quarter of the old prison. Secondly, the tour is massively random - you just keep circling back over yourself in a demented figure of eight. It really did feel like following breadcrumbs back and forth. Lastly, there isn't very much to it. It is small - there are very few relics left from olden times, and you are hard pressed to spend more than half an hour there.Most of the tour focuses (understandably) on the Vietnamese war of independence. Only two rooms are really dedicated to the "American war". Perhaps not surprising, those two rooms were fairly full of American tourists absolutely absorbed, and the rest of the tour was sparsely populated. Then at the end of the tour, if you want to visit the gift shop, you have to work your way back across the prison, but, unfortunately, it is filled with very banal standard Vietnam tourist souvenirs - generic T-shirts, carvings and paintings. Absolutely nothing specific to the prison (I have a friend who knew people who were incarcerated in the prison during the conflict, and I wanted to bring back something for him - but there is absolutely nothing specific to the site - not even a key chain, far less an amusing "I survived the Hanoi Hilton" T-shirt - I guess it is all still a bit raw for the Vietnamese).To be completely fair, it is only 10,000 Dong (US$0.50), so it is still a place I would suggest people pop in and visit. But for me overall it was a bit of a disappointment.
Very interesting. Our boys (9 yrs & 7 yrs) were fascinated with the prison. The lifelike mannequins really make easier to understand the horrific way the prisoners were treated.

The most biased museum that I have seen anywhere in the world. I understand that all museums and memorials have a built in bias, but saying that the American fliers spent their time here playing basketball and ping pong, and cooking chickens, is like saying that the Nazi concentration camp inmates went sailing and ate bon-bons all day. This was the one place in Vietnam that I felt animosity towards Americans.
Must See. Small prison in center of Hanoi. Good lesson about vietnam history

Maison Centrale - illuminating prison. While the museum is in just a surviving remnant of the original prison, I found it a very interesting display, especially for its early history, showing Vietnamese resistance to French rule. And then the displays devoted to the "American War" showing the imprisonment of US pilots as well as the film of the bombing of Hanoi were also illuminating. Even though I was aware of the war at the time it was occurring, seeing it through the eyes of "the other side" is always an educational experience. I think this museum is not to be missed.

Built by the French. The main point of most of the displays at the Hoa Lo prison is that the facility was built by the French who imprisoned and mistreated Vietnamese revolutionaries during the French occupation. It is a sobering reminder/example of how bad things were. There are only a few displays about the Vietnamese holding American POWs during the war of the late-1960s and early-1970s. The impression left is that they had a jolly time (ping pong, basketball, good medical care, etc.) while waiting for the war to end. I think John McCain and others will tell a far different story. Despite the one-sided presentation of facts, this is definitely worth a visit.FYI, the facility is just a small portion of the original prison which covered a full city block. About 75% was torn down to make room for two high-rise office towers.
Interesting. Worth visiting if you are interested in the history of vietnam!

Hanoi Hilton. I was disappointed. a lot of the maison centrale has been knocked down and redeveloped. A lot of whatremains relates to the Vietnamese political prisoners held captive by the French. very little about the US pilots held captive there
worth a look. We were very tentative around any of the war sites including this former POW camp and French prison. This one was more tasteful and we got a lot from the visit.

True reality check!. I served with John McCain in the US Navy and was surprised to find his picture playing ping pong while enjoying his stay here. Read into that what you will.
It is worth the visit.

educational and interesting perspective. The tickets were less than $.50 each. We enjoyed learning about the Vietnamese history. It's a cross between a history museum and a capital and crime museum. Our favorite part of the museum was the Vietnamese sign that stated "Do not use historical toilet."
Good memorabilia. Historical building with many things to see. A screen plays some of the film of war time events.

Hanoi Hilton - a very interesting self guided tour of this preserved part of Ha Noi history. A trip to Ha Noi needs at least a visit to the Ha Noi Hilton (or Hoa Lo - which roughly translates to 'furnace' or 'stove'). We were pleasantly surprised at the entry price of 10,000VND each (about 50c AUD). The whole place is just a portion of what was the original Hoa Lo Prison during the Indochina period and thence the Vietnam war. We were amazed that what looks like a small tourist site was actually quite large and well kept. You will take your own language guide (predominately Vietnamese, French then English - in that order) and wander the route through the prison. The sparse displays are purposefully so. That said - the sparseness with a key element on display adds to the feeling of desperation and hopelessness the prisoners would have felt in this place. You need to remember that after the French Indochina period (with its political prisoners and the associated torture and killings) the Vietnam War saw numbers of US soldiers held POW here. The range of displays in the French inspired prison buildings (shutters, tall windows, high ceilings, concrete rendering and lots of archways) take you through each part of the history of Hoa Lo, and you leave actually feeling you've learned something of the region's history.I am pretty apolitical, and towards the end I felt a bit of the 'socialist good' theme starting to be delivered (ie: about the modern Vietnam). We decided that we had enjoyed what we had seen and decided to go. Set aside about 2-3 hours to have a look around. You will be surprised how interesting this place is.

Worth a visit. Worth a visit when in Hanoi, especially considered it only costs something like $1 or $2. Nothing revolutionary about the prison display, but adds insight into this part of history. Wondering around the tiny dark cells & huge guillotine left an impression.

Tainted. The prison was interesting but their portrayal of what took place during the Vietnam War was laughable and minimal. Fair balance is needed here. If possible, do some research on your own prior to visiting.

Quite well done. The exhibits here are quite well done and do a good job of telling the story of life here in the prison. Meaning that they do a good job of telling the story of when the Vietnamese were imprisoned. The difference of how the Vietnamese portray life for the Americans who were here vs. when the Vietnamese were imprisoned is stark. But, it is theirs and their story to tell I suppose. Interesting to see the contradictions and the propaganda if nothing else though. I enjoyed this site much more than I expected to.

was so fake. Can only say that one area felt real in this place and the videos portrayed how great they treated the Americans. I have relatives that were there and that is far from true. Alot of propaganda
Good Museum - Hilton Hanoi Hotel. Good to see the history and the 2 periods: French Colonist and American Pilots. See the Vietnamese humanity.
Hot and Steamy. Reminder of the past, quite chilling displays, interesting part of the local history.

Eerie. Me and my friend visited the Hanoi Hilton yesterday. It was incredibly interesting to see, although the accuracy of the information is debatable (ie. the portrayal of the treatment American soldiers received whilst captured). In saying that, there is plenty of information throughout the prison to peruse, which helps to give a vivid idea of what it was like during the war. I found the prisoner mannequins to be very eerie and could not walk into one of the darker cells alone because of them. Definitely visit the Hanoi Hilton while in Hanoi!

Good to Visit. This is the famous "Hanoi Hilton" from the Vietnam War. About 3/4 of the prison is dedicated to the tortures the French imposed on the Vietnamese and only two rooms are dedicated to the incarceration of Americans. It is worth a visit.
Worth a visit, plan for approx 1 hour. After so many movies and books about this place it's a must for any visit to Hanoi , allow about a hour to see it all, it's a great walk back to the old quarter

Hanoi Hilton. This prison was only a very short walk from our hotel, the Sapphire Elegance in Hang Bong Street. Of course there is only a small part left which has been turned into the museum. Definately worth the visit to see the small dungeon rooms as well as the communal rooms where the prisoners where manacled. There are life sized figures (about 30?) showing how they were grouped together and were very well done! There is lots to see and lots of information in English to explain different aspects of the prison. I especially loved the shop there which sold items at VERY cheap prices, no haggling, and the stubby coolers were our best buy. Our favourite was the one from the BBC programm called Top Gear when they did a show while travelling through Vietnam some time ago. We laughed so much during that show that we nearly cried, but now, having been to Vietnam, we will have to watch it again:)

Hanoi Hilton. The original Hanoi Hilton.... very interesting to see, you'll just have to look past the communist propaganda as they show with great care how poorly the French treated the Viatnamese prisoners here but how wonderfully they treated the American Pilots here during the war... Rubbish of course but hey, propoganda is not dead in Vietnam, it's just the way it is..
Hanoi Hilton. Very good, though difficult to find. I suggest getting good directions from the hotel concierge.
For those with a special interest. We stumbled across this on our first day when we took a very wrong turn. It is interesting but if time is short I do not think it's a must see

Intersting but sure makes you stop and ponder. Left with a few harrowing thoughts of the poor souls kept there - but I guess this is what war does to people - it's though provoking. Incredibly life like in its displays.
History buffs must stop.. If you have any interest in the American (Vietnam) War you have to stop. Nice reminder that history repeats itself.

Go. Especially if you are American, it seems silly to go to Hanoi and not see this bit of history. As another reviewer pointed out, it doesn't cost much and doesn't take much time. Most of it focuses on the French, not the Americans. Yeah, they no doubt sent out pictures of GIs playing sports for propaganda purposes, but you can see through that. Oh ... and you can see the uniform John McCain was wearing when he was captured.

Not a must on your visit to Hanoi. We went to the Hoa Lo prison given my interest in the Vietnam War (American War to the Vietnamese). I was prepared not to expect too much given some of the reviews but given that admission for two people was less than $2 i decided to give it a go. The museum is small. Only about 1/3 of the original structure still exists. The museum focuses on the French history of Vietnam rather than the American war history. OK to do if you have some time, but not a must. For real war history the War Remnants Museum in HCMC is still my favorite.

Interesting...though a little slanted. While not the complete facility anymore...it makes an interesting stop to learn more about French Colonization period where they used as a prision....the Vietnam War representation mostly propaganda
Moving. This was not a planned visit, but at the last minute we decided to go. My husband and I were surprised by how moved we were by the visit.

Spooky. The Vietnamese seem to really hate the French Imperialists! Interesting place to visit - there are huge office/residential towers behind the prison - you could miss it if you're not looking!A lot of Communist propaganda around, but that ads to the fun.

Old Prison in New Hanoi. If you are in the area I would take the time to visit. It doesn't take much time to visit and is interesting. For Americans it is most known for its famous prisoner John McCain. It is also interesting because it's history goes well beyond the time of John McCain. It is a very old building surrounded by new office towers.

hanoi hilton jail. It is facinating bit of history, french colonist's , veit communists,american airmen, torture and a USED GULLOTINE a bit spooky but for 15,000 vnd who care's. it is also to note they have demolished 2 thirds of it. to make for the real hanoi hilton ha ha but it is set up as a musem well worth a visit it only takes 1/2 hr to go around unless you read every bit of history, ALSO look at the pictures of the american prisoners look for sila off the TV series" heros"
Torturous prison for everyone. Details of the history of the atrocities committed on the Vietnamese prisoners when interred in this center. It is centered on that theme.
Only visit if you enjoy history. The prison is well kept and has lesser amount of tourists compared to other spots.

Powerful experience. Be sure to take an hour out of your Hanoi itinerary to see this site. It's very moving. As an American, I found it wasn't so much about POWs from the American/Vietnam War but rather the treatment of Vietnamese prisoners during French occupation. The museum is very fair in delivering history on both male and female prisoners as well as the lives they led while detained.
imposing imprison. Enjoyed the walk to find the place. Surprised to find a real Hilton over the old site. Could be more impressive inside but the external was all we needed.

A moving reminder of inhumanity towards man/woman kind. Visiting prisons is not everyone's idea of a vacation, but I make it a point to see these commemorative monuments to human inhumanity so we can all remember not to EVER do this again!Hoa Lo site is dedicated to exposing the history of this prison where the French incarcerated for more than 50 years numbers of Vietnamese political dissidents, both men and women. I finally broke down and wept upon reading the prison records and manifests that document the causes of death of lists of prisoners. The other section deals with its use as the prison for US pilots shot down in the bombing of North Vietnam during the war.Disliked: that these prisons or places like them ever existed in history ANYWHERE!
Interesting and cheap. Cool museum and for the price it's worth checking out!

Hanoi Hilton. Very interesting, but a depressing reminder of what humans can do to each other. Not as gruesome as other museums (ie., War Remnants in HCMC or S21 in Phnom Penh). This museum is well organized and information is neatly displayed. An interesting history (clay put village-turned-prison during the American War). John McCain was imprisoned there, which is an obvious reminder that these events are current and not far behind today's world....one odd thing about the visit is that they play a hallowe'en-sounding audio loop of chains clinking, moaning, screaming as you walk through the containment cells and death row inmate area.

A great history lesson. As Americans were were really glad that we got to see the famous "Hanoi Hilton". Much of the prison was torn down in order to make way for a hotel but the SE corner was preserved as a museum. There were many graphic exhibits showing prison life, which might be frightening for young children. We did not know about HoaLo Prison's long history preceding the VietNam War. It was fascinating to hear the victor's perspective of the American War in Vietnam, a great take-away. Our 8-year old daughter thought it was fortunate for the American pilots that they were able to stay in a place that let them play volleyball all of the time and celebrate Christmas which needless to say led to opportunities for lots of other great conversations.
hoa lo prison... amazing in a tragic sort of way...very creepy...the cells and pictures and torture items

Interesting - great place to wander round for a couple of hours. I wasn't particularly bothered about going here to start with but we had a day to kill in Hanoi and this was one of the things within walking distance so we decided to give it a go. I'm glad we did as it made for a really interesting morning. We wandered around the displays (English, Vietnamese and French languages) and watched the short films available and really enjoyed the morning.

Interesting enough to spend some time wondering through. Only a fraction of Hoa Lo Prison remains but it's enough for you to get a feel and taste of life there. Most things are complimented with both Vietnamese and English descriptions which is great and allows you to tour the place on your own. From the utensils used for eating to the solitary confinement cells (which they would make sloped to make it difficult for you to sleep since you were shackled), the Prison is good enough to waste an hour, if not more, on.There were a couple of really tacky moments. For example, one room had music which sounded like something that comes from Jurassic Park. Another one, which I guess is expected, is a highly biased/propaganda movie that was playing.Overall, it's worth the 10,000 dong entry if you've got some time to spare.

Revisionist History at its Finest.. He who writes history writes anything he wants.The prison itself is a small portion of the grounds that once stood here. There are actual cells and mannequins that simulate prisoners and help you feel just what horror occurred in this prison. The dialogue goes to great length to tell the visitors how horrible the prison was under foreign occupation and then tells how nice it was for the Vietnam war. Completely off putting... Learn the history before you go.There is a souvenir shop located in the prison. Not many photo shots here.

A Must See for Americans in Hanoi. For basically a quarter (student price) you can see a part of history from a very non-American history textbook perspective. The museum is well preserved with good captions in English. Most interesting are the videos and sculptures. Definitely a must see in Hanoi!

Definitely worth a visit, more to it than I expected!. My son and I visited Hoa Lo prison and we both enjoyed the experience. I believe it was his favourite sight in Hanoi. It only took us about 45 mins to see everything as the prison is just a fraction of the size it used to be. The displays are very well done and give a good, yet sad impression of what life would have been like. I thought the history of the museum would be based around the American War but like most parts of Vietnam you soon learn that the battles for independence against the French seem more significant. One of two Guillotines used in the 1930s is on display and sends shivers down your spine. Worth a visit!

Interesting place, not much there though. This is a place that if you have time you stop there and if you do not have time you don't. It was an interesting place to visit as we happend to be nearby. A piece of history for sure. Though I think they could do more with the place then what they have already done. Nothing even close to the impact as the S-21 Prison had in Phnom Penh. There were very few people when we visited also, which was good as we could go in and read what we wanted to and then leave. It is quite small, would take roughly 30-40 minutes to see. There are some interesting parts of the prison. They have knocked out parts of walls to give you an image of how life was in the prison which is a great way to show off the prison. There is one rickety old flight fo stairs you have to climb to get to the second floor, but there is almost nothing there to look at, it seems like a list of names of people who served time in the prison.

Hmm. It's empty now.. I don't know what to make of this. It is a prison, it is said to be the maximum security prison ever built in the SE Asia region.I guess it is ok but there are hardly any visitors when we were there. They played some string spooky music when we were touring the place as well. Some figurines made out of clay were also there to show just how depressing it was.The solitary cell is made to torture. They also got part to show how they treat americans after they were captured. which like all other review said it may be propaganda. Never know. But that being said. Its a good visit but nonetheless no real loss if you don't.
