Hanoi Hilton - little bit tricky to find but worth the visit. From our hotel in the Old Quarter, we took a walk around the lake to it's southern most tip, crossed a few crazy roads and walked around Hoan Kiem district trying to find this place. If you walk down Hang Khay until you reach Quan Su street, you'll just need to hang a left at Tho Nhoum toward the Supreme court (but not quite that far, it's on the corner before the Supreme court block). A big yellow fortress on a funny wedge block.It costs 10,000 VND to get in and it's well worth the fee. Signs lead you through whats left of the prison in an orderly fashion, one of the other visitors had a private tour guide and I'd probably recommend that as they were getting a lot of facts that we were trying to listen to.When you first look in, look up and you can see the top of the walls are edged with broke bottles to keep prisoners from climbing out, as well as electrical wire.The photos and cells were interest to look at and feel, the museum had some mannequins replicating how the prisoners were kept, and some good information on the walls. Some of the artifacts brought the place to life, especially the guillotine.The trip to the prison made me feel a little heavy hearted reading about the vietnamese political prisoners and American POW's, at the end they play a video showing the Vietnamese side of the story (Vietnam war), and it's a bit of propaganda mixed in but it certainly shows you another side to the events.Afterward, don't forget to try Quan An Ngon close by, on 18 Phan Boi Chau. The Banh Xeo is especially tasty.

Interesting attraction but god a sad image. We found this place by the recommendation from Mandy - staff 's working at the hotel. We approached here by taxi from the hotel and it's not too far from our place. We did see lots a different pictures about Vietnamese, war, and about american too. It was really sad to see all of the pity pictures and the dark site of the war. Although, i got a big impression and icon Vietnamese. It's not too far from the war, but for sure if you could have a chance to visit Vietnam, definitely there will be a big different picture about Vietnam. This place is a must attraction for you who is interested with all of the historical stuff

Very Interesting. Unfortunatly most of the prison has been torn down. The remaining part is now the museum., Very easy to find. The majority of the prison is dedicated to French occupation and how they treated the vietnamese people. There was only one room that show cased what the US Military POWS endured. But obviously the propganda shows that they were treated very well.

Close to the Old Quarter, interesting and not too strenuous. For 10,000 dong well worth a visit and always good to see the other sides view. Clearly a little bit more blunt with their propaganda than the west's machine. Its a few minutes walk from the centrer and there are a few interesting pieces including John Mcains air suit. Took me about 1 hour to wander around.

Another wheel in Vietnam's propaganda machine. I'm glad that tickets were only 10,000Dong each to this one sided museum. It takes around an hour to get around the entire prison and all the displays and photographs are quite well signed. It was very interesting though to read about the way that the Vietnamese view their imprisonment by the French, and then their subsequent capture of the American soldiers years later. I very much doubt that the American imprisonment was as rosy as they make it out to be. Nether-the-less, an interesting way to spend an afternoon and learn about another countries view. Probably would skip it if short on time in Hanoi.
Very nice. This is a historical place.You should go there to know Prison of France in Vietnam.Highly recommend
really interesting. well worth a visit. Very interesting history and well presented. A must see when in hanoi. The worst thing about this place is that is is true. really sad.

A lesson in Propaganda. This was the first thing on our "things to see in Hanoi" list. It was 10,000D admission and worth every dong! The majority of the museum is devoted to the imprisonment of the Viet communists by the colonial French from 1896-1945. The suffering was obviously awful and this is explained in clear detail. Contrast this with the capture and imprisonment of US airmen during the bombing campaigns in the 1960s and early 70s - they were treated like royalty! Photos of them playing basketball and preparing and eating Christmas dinner look real enough - perhaps ther was some coersion!There are two sides to every story and some of this should be taken with a pinch of salt but it was certainly a good place to see. There are photographs of captured US airmen (including Senator John McCain and Geoff(?) Patterson (the first US ambassador to Vietnam in 1995) being marched in front of a Viet female farm worker half his size) but none of the iconic images of the war we have seen in the west. Perhaps the authorities should get in touch with the US to obtain photos from the B52 bombers of the devastation caused by Operation Rolling Thunder and Operation Linebacker.Still - a great place to visit in Hanoi.

Interesting and not as depressing as the war museums. This prison is interesting to see. The Americans held here were actually treated very well, although the Vietnamise held by the French decades earlier were certainly not. There isn't as much to see as at the war museum in Saigon, but it is certainly less depressing.

Another country's view. This place was at the top of my list of things to see in Hanoi. A lot of it is devoted to the suffering of the Vietnamese under French colonialism. Then there's the part about the American pilots. As one wanders through the dark, damp cells, he can only ponder what went through the minds of those who were interned here. Whether Vietnamese or American, it wasn't a pleasant place to be. Then, all of a sudden, there it is - the guillotine. I had read about it during the French Revolution but had never seen one. It is certainly one of the most interesting parts of the museum. According to the information in the museum, the French used it often during their colonial stay in the country. This prison and museum is one of the most interesting and fascinating places that I have visited in Hanoi.

Interesting to see the Vietnamese perspective.... Unfortunately, about 2/3 of the original prison has been torn down to make way for a 5-star hotel, but what is left is greatly preserved. Before entering, our guide was very good about saying "I know you are American and have your thoughts/beliefs, and with me being Vietnamese, mine are different so while we are inside I won't say much and let you read for yourself." That was very refreshing because he could have very well firehosed us with propaganda... though the prison did that well enough. Most of what is left is dedicated to how poorly the French treated the VIetnamese who were imprisoned there. There are quite a few artifacts and pictures. It was very interesting. Then there are two small rooms dedicated to the treatment of American pilots who were held there during the war. It was interesting, yet frustrating, to see the blatant propaganda of how well the American's were treated... to see the pictures of the "smiling, happy, Christmas celebrating soldiers." A very interesting take on history. It just makes me curious as to what do the VIetnamese really think?!?!?! I highly recommend seeing this sight if in Hanoi!

Thought provoking. This is worth a visit - I was there last week To go round the place only takes about an hour or so as there is not very much left however what is there gives a pretty good idea of what life must have been like behind bars in a French Colonial Jail.Of course this place is most famous for holding the american pilots that were shot down over Vietnam - there is a small section devoted to them.Typically as with other sites in Vietnam one must overlook the attempts at propaganda at every turn - the usual things, How bad the french were, how bad the americans were and how great the Vietnam government is/was....etc etcIt's worth a visit and the VND10,000 for a "guidebook"......
